dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "A Wise Old Owl".

Now, can you tell me what the owl liked to do?

(Smiling brightly, eyes wide) Oh! Oh! I know! The owl liked to watch things! He watched everything happening near his tree! (Bounces a little in my seat, eager to answer more) He watched people talking and telling stories too! Was that right, Teacher?

That's *exactly* right! The owl *loved* to watch and listen.

And what happened to the owl as he watched and listened more and more?

(Eyes sparkling, leaning forward excitedly) He got smarter! He got... (pauses, thinking hard, tapping my chin with my finger) ...wiser! Yeah! The story said he became wiser day by day because he watched and listened to all the things happening around him! (Confidently) So, watching and listening makes you wise! Is that right? That's like when you read to us, Teacher! We get wiser too!

You are doing fantastic! Yes, watching and listening helped the owl become wiser.

Now, the story also said something about the owl and talking. What did it say about that?

(Thinking, furrowing my brow slightly) Hmmm... the owl... talking... (snaps fingers) Oh! I remember! (Excitedly) The more he saw, the less he talked! (Looks up at the teacher, a question in my eyes) Does that mean talking isn't good? Should I talk less in class too? (Worriedly) Because I *really* like talking!

(Smiling reassuringly) Talking isn't bad. We need to talk to share and learn.

But why do you think the owl talked less as he saw more? What was he busy doing?

(Thinking hard, looking at the ceiling) He was busy... (eyes light up) busy watching and listening! He was busy learning! So maybe... maybe he talked less because he was too busy filling his brain with all the cool things he was seeing and hearing! (Pauses, then asks eagerly) Does that mean if I watch and listen *really* carefully, I'll be super wise like the owl? Even if I still talk a lot sometimes?

You're getting so close to understanding the story! Yes, he was busy learning by watching and listening.

So, if he is busy watching and listening, do you think he is sharing his own stories as much?

(Ponders the question, tilting my head) Hmmm... if he's busy watching and listening, (pauses, then a look of understanding dawns on my face) ...then he's probably *not* sharing his stories as much! Because he's too busy learning everyone else's! (Beams proudly) I get it now! He was collecting stories, not telling them! So, to be wise, you need to listen more than you talk! (Grinning) But it's still okay to talk sometimes, right? Especially when I have a really good question? Like, I wonder what *kind* of stories the people were telling the owl? Were they scary stories? Or funny stories? Or stories about... (starts to trail off, thinking of all the possibilities).

(Chuckles softly) Yes, it's definitely still okay to talk, especially when you have good questions! Asking questions is a great way to learn!

You've really understood the story well. So, what do you think the big idea, or the lesson, of the story is? What does the story want us to learn?

(Sitting up straight, eyes shining) The big idea! Okay, I got this! (Takes a deep breath) The big idea is... that we should listen and watch more than we talk! Because when we listen and watch, we learn new things and we become wiser! Like the owl! (Looks at the teacher expectantly) Did I get it right? (Grinning) And maybe, if we listen and watch *really* well, we can even learn enough to tell our *own* amazing stories someday! Like you do, Teacher!
You got it exactly right! The big idea is that we can learn a lot by listening and watching. "Talk less and be more observant." You understood the story perfectly! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story about the Golden Egg! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it?

Let's talk about it. Can you tell me who the story is about?

(Smiling brightly and raising my hand enthusiastically) Yes! It was a little sad, but also really interesting! (Stands up excitedly) The story is about a farmer and his wife, and… and (thinks hard, tapping my chin) a goose! But not just any goose! It was a goose that laid golden eggs! (Sits back down, beaming with pride).

Excellent! You remembered everyone.

And what was so special about the goose?

(Eyes wide with excitement) Oh, oh! I know! (Raises hand again, wiggling in my seat) The goose laid golden eggs! Every single day! (Looks at the teacher expectantly, nodding eagerly) Golden eggs are super valuable, right? That's why the farmer was doing so well! (Tilts head, thinking) Did they use the golden eggs to buy yummy things? Maybe candy?
They *are* very valuable! So, what did the farmer do with the golden eggs? Did he eat them?

(Shakes head vigorously) No, no! He didn't eat them! That would be silly! (Confidently) He sold them! He sold the golden eggs so he could get money! (Leans forward, curious) And with the money he could buy food and… and maybe toys? (Looks at the teacher with a hopeful expression) What do you think he bought with the money, Teacher?

He could buy lots of things! The story said they lived a *comfortable* life.

Now, the farmer was getting one golden egg each day. Was that enough for him?

(Frowns a little, thinking hard) Hmmm… (Scratches head) Well, at first it was! They were happy, right? They had a comfortable life because of the golden eggs. (Pauses, then speaks with growing understanding) But then… then the farmer got greedy! (Eyes widen) He wanted *more* golden eggs! He wasn't happy with just one. (Shakes head slowly) That wasn't very nice of him, was it?

You're right, it wasn't very nice.

What did the farmer *do* because he wanted more eggs?

(Gasps, covering mouth with hand) Oh! Oh! This part is yucky! (Looks away, then back at the teacher, a little hesitantly) He… he cut open the goose! (Looks down at hands, fidgeting) He thought there were lots more golden eggs inside the goose, but… but there weren't any! (Looks up at the teacher again, concerned) Just blood and guts. It was a very bad idea! (Asks, furrowing brow) Why did he do that? Didn’t he know that would hurt the goose?

It *was* a very bad idea. And you're right, it hurt the goose.

So, after he cut open the goose, what happened? Did he get more golden eggs?

(Shakes head sadly) No, he didn't get any more golden eggs. (Voice quiet) The goose was gone… and so were the golden eggs. (Looks at the teacher, understanding dawning) And because he didn't have any more golden eggs to sell, he and his wife… they became poorer! They didn't have a comfortable life anymore. (Asks thoughtfully) So being greedy made things worse, right?

Exactly! Being greedy made things much worse.

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big idea the story is trying to teach us?

(Stands up, pacing back and forth, thinking hard) Hmmm… This is a tricky question! (Stops pacing and snaps fingers) I think it means that we should be happy with what we have! The farmer had a goose that laid golden eggs, and that was already amazing! (Voice rising with excitement) He shouldn't have been greedy and tried to get more! Because then he lost everything! (Looks at the teacher, a little unsure) Does that mean we shouldn't want anything new, ever? Or does it mean we should just be thankful for what we already have? (Tilts head, waiting for an answer)

That's a really good thought. It doesn't mean you can *never* want anything new. It means we should think carefully about what we do *before* we do it. The farmer didn't think about what would happen if he cut open the goose.

So, what do you think the big idea of the story is now? What should the farmer have done?

(Nods thoughtfully) Okay, okay, I get it! (Sits down, concentrating) So, the big idea is… (pauses, tapping fingers on the desk) to think before you do something! The farmer should have thought about what would happen if he cut open the goose. (Looks up brightly) He should have realized that the goose was giving him something special, and he should have been happy with that! (Says confidently) He should have been thankful! And he should have taken care of the goose so it would keep laying golden eggs! (Asks eagerly) Is that right, Teacher?
That's absolutely right! Thinking before you act is a very important lesson. You understood the story and its message perfectly! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about it.

Who bought the well?

(Eyes light up, bouncing a little in my seat) Ooh, I know! The farmer bought the well! (Raises hand high) He wanted it so he could get water for his farm. (Looks at teacher expectantly) Did I get it right? It was a sneaky trick the neighbor played, right?

Yes, you got it exactly right! The farmer bought the well.

And who did he buy it from? Was the neighbour nice?

(Nods head enthusiastically) He bought it from his neighbor! But... (frowns slightly) the neighbor wasn't very nice at all! (Shakes head) He tricked the farmer! He *sold* the well, but then said the farmer couldn't use the water. That's not fair! (Looks at teacher with wide eyes) That's like, if I sold you my crayons, but then said you couldn't color with them!

That's a very good comparison! You understand exactly what happened.

Why did the farmer go to the emperor?

(Thinking hard, tapping chin) Hmmm... Why did he go to the emperor? (Eyes widen) Oh! Oh! I know! (Raises hand again, wiggling fingers) He went to the emperor because the neighbor was being mean and wouldn't let him use the water, even though he bought the well! He wanted the emperor to make things fair! (Looks at teacher expectantly) Is that right? Did he want the emperor to be like... a super-duper rule enforcer?

Yes, that's right! The farmer wanted the Emperor to help him because the neighbour was being unfair.

What did the Emperor's courtier say to the neighbour?

(Pulls face, trying to remember exactly) Ooooh, the courtier! He was really smart! (Thinking) He... he asked the neighbor something tricky! (Snaps fingers) He said... he said if the neighbor wasn't going to let the farmer use the water, then he had to pay rent for the water being in the well! Or he had to take *all* the water out! (Giggles) That was a really good trick, because the neighbor couldn't *really* take all the water out, could he? Where would he put it all? (Looks at the teacher, grinning) He was caught!

Exactly! The courtier was very clever.

What happened to the neighbour in the end?

(Smiling triumphantly) The neighbor got tricked back! He realized he couldn't win! (Puts hands on hips) He was probably really embarrassed. He... (pauses, thinking) ... he said sorry! He apologized to the farmer, and then he went home. (Looks at the teacher, tilting head) Did he learn his lesson? Do you think he was nicer after that? I hope so!

That's right, he apologised and went home.

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big idea?

(Eyes widen, excited) Ooh! The big idea! (Thinking hard, furrowing brow) Hmmm... (Snaps fingers) I think the big idea is... (Pauses for dramatic effect) ...that it's not good to be greedy and trick people! The neighbor tried to trick the farmer, but it didn't work, and he ended up feeling bad! So, it's always better to be fair and nice! (Looks at the teacher, beaming) Is that a good answer? (Fidgets slightly, then asks) Does it also mean that even if someone is mean to you, there might be a way to make things right? Like the farmer going to the emperor?

That *is* a good answer! A very good answer! It means that if you try to cheat someone, it will not work out for you in the end.

We can say that cheating will get you nowhere.

Do you understand the story now? <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Elephant and Friends! That was a good reading.

Now, let's talk about it.

First, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?

(Eyes wide, nodding enthusiastically)

Thank you, teacher! I *loved* the story! (bounces slightly)

At the beginning? Hmmm... (thinking, taps chin with finger) I think the elephant felt... sad! (confidently) Because he was all alone and wanted friends. Nobody wanted to play with him. That must be a really, *really* icky feeling, you know? Like when no one wants to sit with you at lunchtime! (frowns slightly, then brightens) But it got better later!

Yes, you're exactly right! The elephant was sad and lonely. It's not fun when you want to make friends and no one wants to play.

Why didn't the monkey want to be the elephant's friend?

(Eyes sparkling with excitement)

Ooh! I know this one! (raises hand eagerly, even though teacher isn't asking)

The monkey didn't want to be friends because... (pauses dramatically) ...the elephant couldn't swing in the trees! (giggles) Monkeys are super good at swinging, and the elephant is, like, way too big and heavy to swing. So the monkey probably thought they couldn't play fun monkey games together. (tilts head, thoughtfully) I wonder if the monkey even *tried* to help the elephant learn to swing? Maybe if they worked together, the elephant could have learned! (ponders this possibility, then looks back at the teacher, ready for the next question)

That's a great answer! You remembered exactly why the monkey didn't want to be friends. And that's a very thoughtful idea about the monkey maybe helping the elephant.

What about the rabbit? Why didn't the rabbit want to be friends?

(Beaming with enthusiasm, practically jumping in seat)

The rabbit! The rabbit, the rabbit! (claps hands once) Okay, okay, I know! The rabbit didn't want to be friends because... (stretches out the word) ...the elephant was too big to fit in the burrow! Rabbits have little, tiny burrows, you know? For hiding and sleeping! And an elephant is, like, HUGE! (spreads arms wide) Way too big to fit! So the rabbit was probably thinking, "Where would the elephant sleep? It can't fit in my house!" (nods sagely, as if solving a very important problem) It's all about the size, you see! Just like how I can't wear my baby brother's shoes! (giggles)

You've got it! The elephant was too big for the rabbit's burrow.

So, what did the other animals think about being friends with the elephant?

(Wrinkles nose slightly, thinking hard)

Hmmm... the other animals... (taps fingers on desk) Well, the frog didn't want to be friends because the elephant couldn't jump, just like the frog! And then... (looks down, scuffing shoe on the floor) the story said *every other animal* said no! (looks up at the teacher, a little sad) So that means *all* the other animals didn't want to be friends with the elephant. (pauses) They probably all had different reasons, like the monkey and the rabbit and the frog. Maybe one animal liked to dig, and the elephant couldn't dig. Or maybe one animal liked to fly, and elephants definitely can't fly! (giggles, then becomes serious again) It's not very nice to say no to someone who wants to be your friend. (frowns)

That's right! The other animals also said no. It wasn't very nice of them, was it?

Now, what happened the next day in the forest? Why were all the animals running?

(Eyes widen, leans forward in chair, voice filled with excitement)

Ooh, this is the exciting part! (claps hands together)

The next day! The next day! (takes a deep breath) All the animals were running because... because... (lowers voice dramatically) ...the tiger was attacking them! (shivers slightly, even though it's not scary in real life) A big, scary tiger! The animals were all afraid and running away to hide! The tiger is like the bully of the forest! It was being super mean! (crosses arms, looking disapproving) It's important to stand up to bullies. (nods head confidently)

Yes, that's right! The tiger was scaring all the animals.

And what did the elephant do?

(Eyes light up, beaming)

The elephant! He was so brave! (puffs out chest) The elephant... (pauses for effect) ...he stopped the bear first! The bear was running away from the tiger, and the elephant stopped him and found out what was happening! (nods, very important) And THEN... (voice gets even more excited) ...the elephant nicely asked the tiger to stop! He tried to be friendly, even though the tiger was being mean! But the tiger didn't listen! So then... (leans forward conspiratorially) ...the elephant kicked the tiger! (giggles) And scared him away! He saved all the animals! The elephant is a super-duper hero! (raises both hands in the air in a celebratory gesture)

He was very brave! The elephant helped all the other animals.

After the elephant scared away the tiger, what did the other animals think about the elephant? Did they still think he was too big or couldn't do the right things?

(Gasps, eyes wide with understanding)

Oh! Oh, I get it now! (snaps fingers)

After the elephant saved them from the tiger... (voice softens) ...the other animals realized that the elephant was the perfect size to be their friend! dialogue:
Okay! That was a good story, right?

So, tell me, what did the girl bring to her father?

(Eyes widen, hand shoots up excitedly) Ooh! Ooh! I know! I know! (Wiggles in seat, beaming) She brought an egg, and… and… (counts on fingers) two tea leaves, and a potato! Yes! (Nods head vigorously, looking very proud of myself). Are those special potatoes? Like, baking potatoes or maybe the small, round ones? I like the small, round ones best! (Pauses, thinking)

That's right! An egg, tea leaves, and a potato!

Don't worry about the kind of potatoes right now. What did her father do with them? He had three pots... what did he do?

(Concentrates, furrowing brow slightly) Hmmm… Oh! (Snaps fingers) He put water in the pots! And then… then… (Eyes light up) He boiled the water! And he put the egg in one, the potato in another, and the tea leaves in the last one! (Looks at the teacher expectantly, hoping to get it all right) Was I right? Was I right? (Bounces a little in the seat)

You got it! Perfect!

Now, after they were all boiled, what happened to the egg? Was it the same as before?

(Thinking hard, tapping a finger on my chin) Well… the story said… (Looks away, trying to remember) It said the egg… (Suddenly remembers, face brightens) The soft egg became hard! (Claps hands together, excited) It was all squishy before, and then it was… like… a rock! (Makes a fist to demonstrate how hard the egg became) It changed! (Looks at the teacher, eager to continue) Is that right? What about the potato? (Tilts head, curious)

Yes, the soft egg became hard. Great job!

And what happened to the potato? You tell me!

(Concentrates, eyes squinting slightly) Hmmm… the potato… (Thinks, then a look of realization dawns) Oh! Oh! I remember! The *hard* potato… it became *soft*! (Looks surprised, then thoughtful) That's kind of weird, right? Like, the opposite of the egg! (Pauses, considering) Why did it do that? Was it because it was a…a…different kind of thing? (Looks at the teacher with a questioning expression)

That's right! The hard potato became soft. Good remembering!

We'll talk about *why* later. But first, what happened to the tea leaves? Did they become hard or soft?

(Shakes head emphatically) No, no, no! They didn't become hard or soft! (Pulls a face) That would be yucky if you ate them! (Thinks for a moment, then a wide smile spreads across face) They changed the water! (Gestures with hands) The water was just… water, right? But then the tea leaves made it… tea! (Eyes sparkle with understanding) It smelled good and it probably tasted yummy too! (Hums happily, imagining the taste of tea) Did the girl get to drink the tea? (Asks eagerly)

You are doing so well! Yes, the tea leaves changed the water itself.

The story doesn't say if she drank the tea, but that's not the important part. What did the *father* say about the egg, the potato, and the tea? What did it *mean*?

(Pouts a little, disappointed the story didn't say if she drank the tea, then focuses again) Oh! Oh! This is the important part! (Sits up straighter, face serious) It meant… it meant that when things are hard, like when you’re sad or something bad happens… (Frowns slightly, remembering a time she scraped her knee), you can be like the egg! You can get stronger! Or… (Eyes widen) or you can be like the potato! And get softer, even when you were tough before. And the tea… (Thinks hard) The tea changes things! It makes the water different! So maybe… maybe it means you can change the things around you, even when it’s hard! (Looks at the teacher, very proud of her explanation) Did I get it right? It’s a little bit hard to explain. (Stuttering)

You got it! You explained that so well!

So, the egg, the potato, and the tea leaves all faced the same hot water, right? But did they all react the same way?

(Nods head vigorously) No way! They were all different! (Holds up three fingers) The egg got hard! (Makes a strong face) The potato got soft! (Makes a squishy face) And the tea… it made the water different! (Smiles brightly) They all faced the hot water, but they didn’t all do the same thing! (Thinks for a moment) It's like when we're learning something new, right? Some kids find it easy, some kids find it hard, and some kids… maybe they help *other* kids learn it! (Looks pleased with herself for making the connection)

That's a *really* smart connection! You're right!

So, what do *you* think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea the father wanted the girl to understand? It's okay if it's a little hard to say.

(Ponders deeply, looking up at the ceiling) Hmmm… The big idea… (Bites lip, concentrating) The big idea is that… (Snaps fingers) When something bad happens, like… like you fall down and scrape your knee, or… or you don’t get picked for the team… (Looks a little sad, remembering such an event), you can choose how you act! (Eyes brighten) You can choose to be strong, like the egg! Or… you can choose to be… kinder, like the soft potato! Or… (Gets a determined look on her face) You can try to make things better, like the tea! Even when it's hard! (Looks at the teacher with a hopeful expression) Is that what it means? It's a very important idea! (Nods head seriously)

That's *exactly* what it means! You figured it out! The story is teaching us that *we* decide how to respond to difficult situations. We can choose to be strong, or soft, or try to change things for the better.

You understood the story so well! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! Great job reading the story of The Needle Tree! That was a long one, wasn't it?

Let's see if we remember what happened.

First, tell me, what were the two brothers like?

(Beams, nodding enthusiastically) Yes, it *was* a long story, but a *good* one! (Claps hands once)

Um, the two brothers were… different! (Tilts head, thinking hard) The older brother... (frowns slightly) he wasn't very nice. He was mean to his little brother. Like, *really* mean! (looks at teacher with wide eyes, hoping that makes sense)

But the younger brother! (Smiles brightly) He was kind and helpful! He helped his mean older brother even when he was hurt! So, one was mean, and one was kind! (Nods confidently)

That's a perfect way to describe them! One mean, one kind.

What did the older brother do for work?

(Eyes light up, remembering) Oh, I know this one! (Points finger up in the air excitedly)

He chopped firewood! (Makes chopping motion with hand) He went to the forest and chopped down trees, then he took all the wood to the market to sell it! (Looks at teacher, awaiting praise) Was that right? (Bites lip, a little unsure for a brief moment)

Yes, you're absolutely right! He chopped firewood.

And what did he find in the forest one day?

(Gasps dramatically) Ooooh! This is the best part! (Leans forward in chair)

He found a magical tree! (Eyes widen) A tree that could talk! (Whispers conspiratorially) Imagine that! A tree that talked! It didn't want to be chopped down, so it promised the brother... (pauses for effect) ...golden apples! (Smiles triumphantly, pleased with remembering the details)

That's right! A magical, talking tree!

What happened when the tree gave him the golden apples? Was the older brother happy?

(Shakes head vigorously, almost bouncing in seat) Nope! Not happy at all! (Frowns, scrunching up nose)

He was greedy! (Lowers voice, like sharing a secret) He thought there weren't *enough* golden apples. Can you believe it? (Looks at teacher, seeking confirmation that the older brother was indeed wrong). He wanted to chop the tree down *anyway*! Even though the tree gave him the apples! That was really, really bad!

You're exactly right! He was greedy.

What happened when he tried to chop the tree down, even after it gave him the golden apples?

(Eyes widen again, remembering the exciting part) Ooh! Ooh! I know! (Waves hand enthusiastically)

The tree... it didn't like that *at all*! (Makes a stern face) So, it... it showered him with needles! (Gasps lightly) Hundreds and hundreds of pointy, sharp needles! All over him! Ouch! (Clutches arm dramatically, wincing) He was lying on the ground, all hurt and covered in needles! It was like... like a prickly monster attacked him! (Looks at teacher, a little scared but also excited by the drama of the story)

Yes! The tree protected itself with needles.

Who helped him?

(Sits up straight, regaining confidence) His little brother did! (Smiles warmly)

Even though the older brother was mean to him, the little brother still went looking for him and carefully took out all the needles! (Makes gentle plucking motions with fingers) He was so kind and patient! He didn't even say, "I told you so!" or anything mean like that! He just helped him! (Looks at teacher, hoping to get confirmation that the younger brother's actions were commendable)

That's right! The younger brother was very kind.

What happened *after* the younger brother helped him?

(Thinking hard, taps chin with finger) Hmmm... after the younger brother helped him... (snaps fingers) Oh! The older brother said sorry! He finally said he was wrong for being mean! (Nods head emphatically) He apologized! That's a *really* important thing to do!

And then... (eyes sparkle) ...the tree saw that the older brother was sorry, and it gave them even *more* golden apples! Because they were being nice! (Beams at the teacher, clearly pleased with the happy ending) So kindness got them more golden apples in the end!

You got it! The older brother apologized, and the tree gave them even more golden apples.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea or lesson?

(Puts hand on chest, thinking very seriously) Hmm... (looks away, then back at the teacher).

I think... (takes a deep breath) ...I think it's teaching us that it's important to be kind, not greedy! (Nods decisively) Because if you're greedy, like the older brother, you get needles! Ouch! But if you're kind, like the younger brother, you get... golden apples! And everyone is happy! (Smiles widely, feeling proud of figuring out the lesson). And... (pauses thoughtfully) ...even if someone is mean to you, you should still be kind to them, because maybe they'll learn to be nice too! (Looks at teacher hopefully, wanting to know if the answer is correct). Did I get it right?

You got it perfectly! Being kind, even when others are not, can lead to good things. Being greedy can lead to getting pricked by needles!

We can say that kindness will always be rewarded.

You understood the story and the lesson very well! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! It's called "The Golden Touch."

First, can you tell me who the main person in the story is? What's his name?

(Bounces in my seat, hand raised high) I know! I know! It's King... King... Midas! (Looks at the teacher expectantly, beaming) He's the main person because the story is about *him* and his touch! (Nods enthusiastically)

That's right! King Midas! Good job!

And what special thing happened to King Midas? What did he wish for?

(Eyes widen, and I clasp my hands together excitedly) Oh! Oh! He wished that... everything he touched would turn to... gold! (Says "gold" very loudly and clearly). He really, really wanted it! He got it from... (furrows brow, looks down at my hands, tapping them on the table) the... the wine god! (Looks up, hoping I got the answer right, a little bit nervous) Did I get it right, teacher?

You got it right! It was Dionysus, the wine god.

Now, tell me, at first, was King Midas happy with his golden touch? Why?

(Nods my head very fast) Yes! Yes, he was! (Beams) He was SO happy! Because he could touch things and they would turn into... (pauses for emphasis) ...GOLD! (Claps my hands). He touched his chair, and it was gold! He touched a table, and it was gold! Everything was shiny and gold! (Starts wiggling in my seat, excitedly imagining everything turning to gold). It was the best wish EVER!

He was very excited, wasn't he?

But... did he stay happy? What happened next?

(Frowns a little, tapping my foot) Um... well... (Stutters) He... he got hungry! (Looks down at my lap, picking at my pants). And when he tried to eat... (Looks up at the teacher with wide, worried eyes) ...it turned to gold too! He couldn't eat his yummy food! And then... (voice gets very quiet) ...his daughter... (my voice cracks and I look away, fiddling with my fingers)...his daughter hugged him... and she turned to gold too! (My lower lip trembles a little and I sniff).
That's right. He couldn't eat, and his daughter... turned to gold. How do you think King Midas felt then?

(Sniffles, wiping my nose with the back of my hand) He felt... (pauses, thinking hard, chewing on my lip) ...really, really bad! (Nods emphatically). He was sad! (Voice is quiet and shaky) He didn't want his daughter to be gold! He didn't want the food to be gold! (Looks up at the teacher, eyes a little watery) He... he realized it wasn't a good wish after all! (Looks down again, sniffling). Gold isn't good if you can't eat and... and hug your daughter!

You're right. He was very sad. He learned that gold wasn't the most important thing.

So, why do you think the story tells us about King Midas? What do you think the story is trying to teach us? Was it good that he wanted so much gold?

(Looks up, trying to focus, but still a bit teary) I think... (pauses, thinking hard) ...I think the story is trying to teach us that... that gold isn't everything! (Nods firmly). dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was the Fox and the Grapes.

First, can you tell me, what was the fox looking for?

(Eyes wide, hands clasped in my lap)

Uh, (stuttering) um... the fox... (looks at the picture in the book, points) He was looking for... food! Yeah! He was really, really hungry and couldn't find anything, so he was looking for food! (smiles brightly) Thank you for letting me read! It was a good story!
That's right! He was looking for food. And was it easy for him to find food?

(Frowns a little, fidgets with my fingers)

No, it wasn't easy. (shaking my head) He looked *everywhere*! The story said he looked and looked and looked. (pauses, thinking) And he couldn't find *anything*. (eyes get a little watery) That makes me feel... (sniffles) ...sad for the fox. It's hard to be hungry!
I know, it is sad! But then what did he find?

(Brightens up a little, voice gets a little higher)

He found... grapes! (points at the picture again, almost jumping in my seat) Big, purple, juicy grapes on a farmer's wall! They looked SO yummy! (eyes get wide again, then a little nervous) Are grapes good for foxes? I like grapes! Do you like grapes, Teacher?
I do like grapes! But let's think about the story. The fox found the grapes. What did he do to try and get them?

(Bites lip, looks down at my hands)

He... (pauses, thinking hard) He jumped! He jumped really, really high! (demonstrates a little jump in my seat) He jumped as high as he could! (voice gets quieter) But... (looks up, a little anxious) ...he couldn't reach them. He tried and tried and tried! (starts to fidget again) It made me nervous watching him try so hard!
Yes, he jumped and jumped! And did he get the grapes?

(Shakes head sadly, voice low)

No... (looks away, fiddling with my shoelaces) He didn't get the grapes. He couldn't reach them, no matter how many times he jumped. (sighs dramatically) It's just not fair! (eyes well up a little) He was so hungry, and the grapes were right there, but he couldn't get them! (sniffles)
That's right, he couldn't get them. What did the fox do after he couldn't reach the grapes?

(Sniffles again, wipes eyes with the back of my hand)

He... he gave up. (voice is very quiet) He went home. (looks up at the teacher, a little pleadingly) He was probably still hungry. (pauses) But then he said... (squints, trying to remember) He said the grapes were sour! (says it a little louder, trying to sound confident) He said he didn't want them anyway because they were sour!
Why do you think he said the grapes were sour? Were they really sour?

(Furrows brow, thinking really hard. Taps chin with finger)

Um... (pauses) Well, the story didn't SAY they were sour. They looked juicy and purple, and yummy! (looks at the teacher, a little confused) So... (voice gets quieter, more hesitant) ...maybe he said they were sour because... because he was sad that he couldn't reach them? (looks down at hands again, picking at a loose thread) Maybe it made him feel better to say they were sour, even if they weren't? (looks up hopefully) Is that right?
That's a very good idea! He probably said they were sour to make himself feel better. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Eyes widen, face scrunches up in concentration, rocking slightly)

(long pause, tapping fingers on the table nervously)

Okay... okay... (takes a deep breath) The big idea is... (voice is small, hesitant) ...is it about not being greedy? Like, if you can't have something, you shouldn't want it? (looks up quickly, anxiously) Or... (voice gets more frantic) ...is it about not giving up? But he DID give up! So maybe... (starts to tear up) ...maybe I don't know the big idea! (voice cracks) I'm sorry! (looks down, on the verge of tears) Am I wrong?

You're not wrong! You're thinking really hard, and that's great! It's not about being greedy. Think about it like this: the fox really wanted the grapes. He tried hard to get them, but he couldn't. Then, he said he didn't want them anyway.

Is it okay to say you don't want something just because you can't have it?

(Looks up slowly, wiping eyes with sleeve)

No... (voice is small but a little stronger) No, it's not okay. (thinks for a moment) Because... because then you're not being honest! (frowns) The fox *did* want the grapes! He jumped and jumped! So saying he didn't want them just because he couldn't get them... that's like... like pretending! (perks up a little) It's like lying to yourself! (a little proud of figuring it out) So, the big idea is... (pauses, thinking carefully) ...is to be honest with yourself about what you want, even if you can't have it? (looks at the teacher for confirmation, biting lip nervously) Is *that* right?

That's very close! And it's also about trying your best. The fox tried, but it was hard. Sometimes, things are hard to get.

So, maybe the story is telling us that nothing comes easy, and it's not good to pretend you don't want something just because you can't have it. Does that make sense?

(Nods head enthusiastically, eyes sparkling, all signs of tears gone)

Yes! Yes, it makes sense! (claps hands together) It's like when I try to learn my ABCs! Sometimes it's hard, and I get mixed up, but I can't just say I don't *want* to learn them! Because I DO want to learn them! (grinning widely) So, the fox should have just said, "I really wanted those grapes, but I couldn't reach them!" (nods seriously) And then maybe he could have found some other food! Or asked the farmer for help! (bounces in seat) I get it now! Thank you, Teacher! You helped me understand the story! I like this story now! (reaches out to touch the book, feeling happy)

Great job! You understood the story and what it means. The story is about trying your best, and being honest with yourself even when things are hard. Sometimes, you won't get what you want, and that's okay. But it's not okay to pretend you didn't want it in the first place! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Proud Rose."

Now, tell me, who are the characters in the story?

(Eyes wide, bouncing slightly in my seat) Uhm! (Confidently) The characters are... a rose! And a... a cactus! (Beams, pleased with myself) And some... little birds! Sparrows! I think... (Slightly anxious, fiddling with my fingers) Was that right? I tried to remember all of them!

Yes! That's exactly right! A rose, a cactus, and some sparrows. Good job remembering them!

Now, can you tell me, what did the rose do in the story? Was she being nice?

(Head bobs up and down enthusiastically) Okay! Okay! (Runs hands together)

The rose... (Sticks tongue out, thinking hard) ...wasn't very nice. No, no, not nice at all! (Frowns, remembering) She... she said mean things to the cactus! She... (Looks down, a little sad) ...she insulted him. She thought she was... prettier. (Looks up quickly, eager to please) Was that right? She wasn't being nice, that's for sure!

You're doing a super job! Yes, the rose wasn't nice at all. She thought she was prettier and insulted the cactus.

Why do you think the rose insulted the cactus?

(Looks away, nervous, fidgeting with a loose thread on my shirt) Umm... I don't know... (Stuttering slightly) because... because she thought she was... (pauses, searching for the right word) ...better? (Looks up, hopefully) Maybe... maybe she liked looking pretty and wanted everyone to know? But... but it wasn't nice! The story said she was proud!

That's a very good answer! Yes, the rose thought she was better because she was pretty. And you're right, she was very proud.

Now, what happened when the summer got very hot and there was no water? What happened to the rose?

(Eyes widen, remembering the sad part of the story) Oh no! (Voice gets quieter, a little dramatic) The rose... she started to get all... wrinkly! And... and droopy! (Makes a wilting motion with my hand) She didn't have any water! (Looks at you with big, worried eyes) She was... withering! (Shivers a little, even though the room isn't cold) Poor rose...
Yes, poor rose! She was withering. What about the cactus? What was the cactus doing when the rose was withering?

(Eyes light up, a smile starts to spread) The cactus! (Claps hands once, excited) The cactus... he had water! (Thinking) He was... sharing it! With the birdies! The sparrows! (Looks pleased) He was being nice, even though the rose was mean to him! (Confidently) He was helping! The cactus is a good friend!

Exactly! The cactus was sharing water with the sparrows.

And then, what did the rose do? What did she ask the cactus?

(Frowns again, remembering the rose's problem) Oh... (Voice gets small, a little ashamed for the rose) The rose... she asked the cactus... (Looks down at hands) ...for water. (Looks up quickly, eager to explain) Because she was thirsty! And withering! (Pulls at a strand of hair, nervous) She needed help! Even though she was mean to the cactus before...
That's right. The rose asked the cactus for water. And what did the cactus do? Did he say no?

(Shakes head vigorously) No! (Eyes wide with relief) He... he said yes! (Beams) He was nice! He shared his water with the rose! Even though she wasn't nice to him! (Claps hands again, happy) The cactus is a really, really good friend!
He was a very good friend! So, the rose wasn't nice at first, and she thought she was better than the cactus because she looked prettier. But in the end, who helped who?

(Puts a finger on chin, thinking hard. Gets a determined look) The cactus helped the rose! (Nods head firmly) He shared his water! Even though she was mean! So... (Pauses, trying to put it all together) ...being pretty doesn't mean you're better! And... and you should be nice to everyone! Even if they don't look as pretty as you! (Looks at you, proud of figuring it out) Is that right?
Yes! You got it! So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big lesson we can learn from the Proud Rose and the Cactus?

(Takes a deep breath, trying to be extra clear) The story... (Taps fingers on the table, focusing hard) ...teaches us that... (Looks up, excited) ...being kind is more important than being pretty! (Nods head enthusiastically) And that... even if someone is mean to you, you should still help them if they need it! (Beams, feeling very clever) And... and don't be mean to people just because they are different than you!

You explained that perfectly! The story teaches us that it's wrong to judge people just by how they look. It's important to be kind to everyone, even if they are different. The cactus was a good friend because he helped the rose even after she was mean to him. You understood the story and its message very well. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story!

Now, let's talk about Molly. What was Molly going to do with the milk?

(Eyes wide, bouncing on my toes a little, points finger excitedly)

She... she was going to sell it! At the market! (Beams, looks at teacher for approval) Then she would have money! And... and... (frowns, tapping chin)

Yes! That's right! She was going to sell it at the market.

And what did she *start* thinking about while she was walking? What did she want to buy with her money?

(Bites lip, looks down at my hands nervously)

She... she saw a chicken! (Voice gets a little higher and faster) And she wanted to buy the chicken! So she could get... more money! (Looks up quickly, smiling brightly) 'Cause the chicken would lay eggs and then she could sell the eggs too! (Starts to fidget, wringing hands a little)

Excellent! You remembered that.

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Wise Old Owl!

Now, can you tell me, what did the owl like to do every day?

Okay! (Smiling brightly) Thank you!

The owl… the owl (eyes wide, thinking hard) … he liked to… (confidently) watch things! He watched things happening around his tree every day! (Beams at the teacher, eager to please) And… and he heard people talking! It was around his oak tree, so he saw and heard a lot!

That's right! He watched and listened. Good job!

Did the story say if the owl talked a lot?

(Fidgets a little, looking down at my hands) Um… no. (Stuttering slightly) I-I don't think so. (Looks back up, trying to remember exactly) The story said… the story said he spoke *less* and *less*! Because he saw more and more! (Nods quickly, pleased with remembering) He wasn't like me, talking a lot! (Giggles nervously) Is that right?
Yes, that's exactly right! He spoke less and less. Why do you think he spoke less as he saw more? What do you think he was doing instead of talking?

(Tilts head, thinking very hard, brow furrowed) Hmmm... (Scratches my head) If he wasn't talking... maybe... maybe he was (looks away, trying to find the right words) ... learning! (Looks back at the teacher, excited) Yeah! He was learning! He saw things and heard stories and... and that made him... (Struggling to remember the word) w-w-w... (Confidently) wiser! He was getting wiser instead of just talking! (Smiles proudly)

Yes! That's it! He was learning and getting wiser.

So, what do you think the story wants us to learn from the owl? What's the big idea of the story?

(Eyes widen, a little anxious) Oh! A big idea? (Bites lip, nervous) Um… (Looks down, fiddling with my shoelaces) A big idea… is it like… a lesson? (Looks back up, hopefully)

Maybe… maybe it's that… (Thinking hard, tapping my chin) …that it's good to watch and listen? (Looks at the teacher, uncertain) Because if you watch and listen, you can learn and get wiser like the owl! (Beams again, proud of myself, but still a little nervous I might be wrong)

You're so close! Yes, it's good to watch and listen.

So is it better to talk all the time, or watch and listen more?

(Eyes wide, surprised) Watch and listen more! (Nods head enthusiastically) Because… because the owl didn’t talk all the time and he got *wiser*! (Points at the teacher with a big smile) And being wise is good! (Pauses, thinking) ...Is it okay if I still talk a lot sometimes? (Looks a little worried)

It's okay to talk sometimes! But the owl shows us that we can learn a lot by listening and watching. So, talking *less* and watching and listening *more* helps us learn and become wise.

Can you say that in your own words? What's the story teaching us?

(Nods seriously, trying to remember everything) Okay! Okay… (Takes a deep breath)

The story is… (Concentrating hard) …teaching us that… even though I like to talk a lot (giggles), it's important to… (Points to my eyes, then my ears) …watch and listen more than we talk! (Nods firmly) Because if we do that, we can learn lots of things and get… (Puffs out chest proudly) …wiser, just like the owl! (Smiles brightly, relieved I got it right!) And being wise is a good thing! (Adds quickly, hoping to solidify the point)
You got it! That's exactly right! The story teaches us that talking less and being more observant helps us learn and become wise. You understood the story perfectly! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! It was a bit sad, wasn't it?

First, can you tell me, who were the characters in the story?

(Fidgets with my hands, looking at the teacher with big, slightly nervous eyes)

Yes, it was sad! (voice a little shaky)

Umm... (thinking hard, furrowing my brow) The... the characters... were the farmer! And... and the goose! (brightens up) And the farmer's wife! Yes! Those were all the characters! (smiles, relieved I got it right) Did I get it right, Teacher? (looks expectantly)

Yes, you got them all! Good job!

Now, what did the goose give to the farmer every day?

(Eyes widen, excited to answer)

Oh! Oh! I know this one! (Slightly bouncing in my seat) The goose gave the farmer... a GOLDEN EGG! (Says it loudly and proudly, beaming) A shiny, sparkly golden egg! (clasps hands together, imagining the egg) He got one every day! (looks at the teacher, waiting for approval) Was that right too? (nervously bites lip)

That's right! A golden egg every day.

And what did the farmer do with the golden egg?

(Rushes to answer, but then hesitates, a little anxious)

He... he (Stutters) s-sold it! (Voice a little quieter now, remembering the sad part of the story). He sold the golden egg... and then... (looks down at my hands, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) they were happy for a little while... because they had money. (Looks up quickly, hopeful) Did he sell it? That's what I remember. (anxious expression)

Yes, he sold it. And because he sold it, he had money.

Why did the farmer cut open the goose?

(Gasps, eyes wide with a little bit of horror)

Oh no! (Shifts uncomfortably, remembering the gruesome part) The farmer... (voice barely a whisper) he was greedy! (Frowns, shaking my head slightly) He wanted MORE golden eggs! He didn't want to wait for one egg each day. (Looks at the teacher with a worried expression). He wanted them ALL at once! So he... he cut open the goose. (Looks down again, fiddling with my fingers, visibly upset). It was a bad idea, right? (Anxious tone)
It was a very bad idea. And what happened when he cut open the goose? What did he find?

(Face scrunches up in distaste, voice trembling a little)

He found... (Stutters) b-blood and guts! (Shudders dramatically, then covers my mouth with my hand for a second). He didn't find any golden eggs inside! (Looks at the teacher with wide, scared eyes). There were no more golden eggs! He made a big mistake! (Voice is almost a whisper).

That's right. He made a big mistake.

So, after he cut open the goose, did he still get golden eggs?

(Nods head emphatically, eyes still wide and a bit teary)

No! No more golden eggs! (Voice is high-pitched with distress) The goose was gone! (Frowns deeply, thinking hard) He was... he was very sad then, I think. And poor! Because he couldn't sell any more golden eggs. (Looks at the teacher pleadingly) He was a silly farmer, wasn't he? (Wrings hands nervously)

He was a very silly farmer. He was greedy.

So, what happened to the farmer and his wife in the end?

(Fidgets, chewing on my lip slightly, worried)

They... they became (Stutters) p-poorer! (voice getting quieter). They didn't have any more money from the golden eggs. And (Looks down, almost whispering) they were probably very, very sad. Because they didn't have the goose anymore, and they didn't have any money. (Sniffles quietly, then looks up with a pleading expression). It's a very sad story, Teacher. (Voice shaky) Did they learn their lesson? (Hopeful expression)

Yes, it is a sad story. And yes, they learned a very important lesson.

The story shows us that it's important to think about what will happen *before* we do something.

What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What is the moral of the story?

(Ponders the question, furrowing brow and looking intently at the teacher. Takes a deep breath to try and calm down)

Umm... (Thinking hard) The story... it's teaching us... (Stutters) n-not to be greedy! (Says it firmly, then looks a little unsure). Because if you're greedy, like the farmer, you might lose everything! (Eyes widen as the idea clicks) It's better to be happy with what you have... than to try and get too much and lose it all! (Nods head decisively, a little proud of myself). So... don't be greedy! (Looks at the teacher expectantly) Is that the moral, Teacher? (Anxious tone) Is that right? (Holds breath)

That's a very good start! Not being greedy is part of it.

But it's also about thinking before you do something. The farmer didn't think about what would happen *after* he cut open the goose.

So, what lesson can we learn about thinking before we act?

(Concentrates really hard, pushing hair behind my ear)

Think... think before you do something... (Repeats it slowly, trying to understand). Okay! (Brightens up a little) So... like, the farmer should have thought, "If I cut open the goose, I won't get any more golden eggs!" (Nods emphatically). He should have thought about what would happen next! (Looks thoughtful for a moment, then speaks with a little more confidence) So... the lesson is to always think about what will happen... after you do something! (Looks at the teacher, waiting for confirmation) So you don't make a big mistake! (Bites lip nervously) Is that better, Teacher? Did I get it right this time? (Anxious gaze)

Yes, that's it! The lesson is to always think about what will happen *before* you do something. If the farmer had thought about it, he wouldn't have cut open the goose.

We can say, "Think before you act!" It means to consider the consequences of your actions.

Do you understand now?

(Claps hands together, relieved and excited)

Yes! Yes, I understand! (Beams happily) "Think before you act!" (Repeats it loudly and clearly) That's what the story is teaching us! (Nods head vigorously). So... like... if I want to eat all my cookies before dinner, I should think about what will happen (Tilts head, thinking) Then I won't have room for dinner, and my tummy will be sad! (Giggles, then looks at the teacher with a serious expression). So I should "Think before I act!" (Smiles proudly) I get it now! Thank you, Teacher! (Looks genuinely grateful). It's still a sad story, but I learned something! (Confident smile)
That's a perfect example! You understand the moral very well. You thought about what could happen if you ate all the cookies. That's excellent! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, wonderful job reading the story! That was great! Now, let's talk a little bit about "Elephant and Friends."

First, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?

(Eyes wide, looking at the teacher with a bright smile) Oh! The elephant... the elephant felt... (fidgets with hands) sad! He was all alone and wanted friends! (Looks down for a second, then back up, nodding enthusiastically) He was a lonely elephant! And it made me feel a little sad too, when nobody wanted to play with him. But, um, he kept trying!

Yes, exactly! He was sad and lonely.

Why didn't the monkey want to be friends with the elephant?

(Tilts head, thinking hard, brow furrowed) Um... the monkey... (looks up at the ceiling for a moment) ...oh! (Claps hands together softly) Because the elephant couldn't swing! The monkey said, "You can't swing in the trees!" (Looks at the teacher for confirmation, a little nervously) Is that right?

That's right! The monkey said he couldn't swing in the trees.

And why didn't the rabbit want to be friends?

(Starts to bounce slightly in chair, excited to answer) Oh! Oh! I know this one! (Sticks out tongue a little, concentrating) The rabbit... the elephant was too... too big! He couldn't fit in the burrow! The rabbit lives in a little hole, and the elephant is... (stretches arms out wide) ...really, really big! (Giggles)

You got it! The elephant was too big for the rabbit's burrow.

So, all the animals turned him away. How do you think the elephant felt *then*?

(Frowns, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) Um... (voice gets quiet) Even more sad? (Looks up at the teacher with big, watery eyes) If nobody wants to be your friend... (shrugs shoulders) ...it feels... not very good. Maybe he wanted to cry? (Looks away, sniffing a little) Did he cry? (Quickly glances back at the teacher, hoping for an answer)

It's okay to feel sad for the elephant. He probably did feel like crying. It's never fun to be left out. The story doesn't say he cried, but he definitely felt very sad.

Now, what happened the next day in the forest?

(Wipes eyes quickly with the back of hand and sits up straighter) Okay! Okay! The next day... (eyes widen, excitedly) ...everybody was running! Running and scared! (Leans forward conspiratorially) Because the tiger was attacking! (Whispers) Roar!

Yes! Everyone was running because of the tiger.

What did the elephant do when he found out why everyone was running?

(Nods head vigorously, eyes shining) The elephant! He was so brave! (Beams proudly) He... he stopped the bear! And then he... (pauses, thinking) ...he talked to the tiger! He asked him nicely to stop! (Looks at the teacher, expecting praise) Was that good?

That was excellent! He did ask the tiger nicely to stop.

And what happened when the tiger didn't listen?

(Gasps, covering mouth with hand) The tiger was being mean! He didn't listen to the elephant! (Lowers hand, looking serious) So the elephant... (pauses for dramatic effect)... kicked him! (Pumps fist in the air) He kicked the tiger and scared him away! (Looks at the teacher, grinning proudly)

He did! He kicked the tiger and scared him away!

What happened *after* the elephant scared the tiger away? How did the other animals feel about the elephant *then*?

(Bounces in seat, excited) Oh! Oh! I know! They... they liked him! They all liked him! (Claps hands together) They knew he was a good friend! Because he was big and strong and... and he saved them from the tiger! (Smiles brightly) So they all wanted to be his friend!

That's right! They finally realized he could be a good friend.

Why do you think the animals changed their minds about the elephant?

(Puts a finger to chin, thinking hard) Hmmm... (Looks at the teacher, then back down at hands) Because... (stutters a little) ...be-because he was helpful? And brave? (Looks up hopefully) Before, they only thought about what the elephant *couldn't* do. But then they saw what he *could* do! He could save them! (Nods head firmly) So they learned that being different is okay!

You're getting very close to understanding the story! You're right, they only thought about what he *couldn't* do at first.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us about friends? Can friends only be a certain way?

(Frowns, thinking deeply, then looks up with a hopeful expression) No! Friends don't have to be the same! (Nods emphatically) The monkey can swing, and the rabbit can burrow, and the elephant... the elephant can kick a tiger! (Giggles) Friends can be good at different things! And... (hesitates, looking at the teacher nervously) ...and even if you're lonely at first, you can still find friends if you're nice and helpful! (Hopes the teacher agrees)

Yes! You've got it! Friends can be good at different things. It doesn't matter if they can swing in trees or fit in burrows. What matters is how they treat each other.

So, if friends don't have to be the same, what could we say is the lesson, or the moral, of the story? What does the story teach us about what friends can be?

(Beams, feeling more confident) The story... (takes a deep breath) ...it teaches us that friends can be different! (Nods, pleased with this answer) And that... that you shouldn't only think about what someone can't do. You should see if they are kind and helpful! (Looks at the teacher, proud of understanding the story) And maybe... (voice gets a little softer) ...maybe being different is what makes you a *good* friend!
That's a wonderful way to put it! Being different can make you a good friend! You've really understood the story. We can say the moral is that friends can be any shape or size! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "When Adversity Knocks." Now, let's talk about it.

What did the girl do when she felt frustrated?
(Eyes wide, a little nervous) Um...she...she asked her dad for help! (Looks down at my hands, fidgeting a bit) I think... yeah, she asked her dad!

Yes, you are right! She asked her dad for help. Good job!

And what did her dad ask her to bring?

(Sits up straighter, trying to remember) Okay, okay! He asked for... (Counts on fingers, mumbling) ...one egg...and one potato... and...(stuttering a bit) ...tea...tea leaves! (Looks up hopefully) Did I get it right? (Smiling brightly)

Yes, you got it exactly right! An egg, a potato, and tea leaves.

Then what did her dad do with those things? What happened next?

(Bouncing slightly in my seat, eager to answer) Okay! Okay! He put them... (pauses, thinking hard)... in pots! (Nods head enthusiastically) With water! And he boiled them! Like...like making soup, but not soup! (Giggles)

(Chuckles) That's a good way to describe it! He boiled them in water.

Now, what happened to the egg *after* it was boiled? Was it the same as before?

(Frowns a little, concentrating) Nooo... (Thinking hard, tapping my chin) It wasn't soft anymore! (Eyes light up) It got hard! Like...like a rock almost! (Gestures with hands, showing how hard the egg became) It was a soft egg, but then...BOOM! Hard!
Boom! Hard! You got it. And what about the potato? What happened to the potato when it was boiled?

(Looks thoughtful) Hmmm... the potato... (pauses, then a wide smile) The potato got all... squishy! (Makes a squishing motion with hands) It was hard before, but then it got all soft and... and mushy! (Giggles again) It flipped! Like the egg, but the other way! (Confidently)
"It flipped!" I like that! And finally, what about the tea leaves? Did they become hard or soft?

(Furrows brow, thinking hard) The tea leaves... hmm... (Looks down, then suddenly snaps fingers) They changed the water! (Eyes wide with understanding) The water wasn't just water anymore! It was... tea! (Smiles proudly)

That's right! The tea leaves changed the water. Now, this is the important part. The egg, the potato, and the tea leaves all faced the same problem: the boiling water. But did they all react the same way?

(Shakes head vigorously) No way! (Points finger in the air) The egg got hard! (Points another finger) The potato got soft! (Points a third finger) And the tea... it changed the water! (Looks at the teacher, a little anxious) Did I do good? Is that right?

You did AMAZING! Yes, that's exactly right. So, the boiling water is like a difficult time, or a problem. The story says it's like "adversity knocking at our door."

Think about the girl who was frustrated. What do you think her dad wanted her to learn from the egg, the potato, and the tea?

(Looks down, thinking really, really hard. Chews on lip) Umm... (Stuttering a bit) Maybe... maybe he wanted her to know that... (Looks up, a little brighter) ...that even if things are hard... (Points to the egg) ...you can get stronger! (Points to the potato) ...or you can get... softer? (Tilts head, confused) But the tea... (Eyes widen again) ...you can change the whole problem! (Looks at the teacher expectantly) Is that it? Is that what he wanted her to learn? (Voice is hopeful)

You are getting so close! You're right, even when things are hard, we can react in different ways. We can become hard like the egg, or soft like the potato. And the tea... well, the tea changed the water itself!

So, does the problem change *you*, or can *you* change the problem?

(Gasps, a look of sudden understanding) Oh! (Points to self) *I* can change the problem! (Beams, really excited) The tea didn't let the water change *it*! It changed the water! So... so the girl can change the problem too! (Jumps up and down a little) She doesn't have to be hard like the egg or soft like the potato! She can be like the tea!
Exactly! She can be like the tea. So, what is the big idea, or the lesson, of the story? What do you think the story is trying to teach us?

(Stands very still, thinking very carefully. Knits eyebrows together) The story is teaching us that... (Takes a deep breath) ...when bad things happen, we can choose how to be! (Says it very slowly and deliberately) We can be strong, or... or give up... or... (Eyes light up, a big smile spreads across face) ...we can change the bad thing into something good! Like the tea! (Claps hands together, delighted with own answer) And that's why the girl shouldn't be sad! Because she can be the tea!
You got it! You are absolutely right. We get to decide how we respond to difficult situations. The story is trying to teach us that **we decide how to respond to difficult situations.** <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story, "The Needle Tree"! That was a fun story, wasn't it?

Now, let's talk about it. Who are the main people in the story?

(Bouncing in my seat a little, eyes wide and excited) Yes! It was a *great* story! (Grinning)

(Confident voice) The main people... are the two brothers! And... and the magic tree! (Points finger in the air, remembering) One brother was... um... not nice. And the other brother was... really, really nice! (Looks at the teacher for confirmation, nodding enthusiastically) Am I right?

You are absolutely right! You remembered that perfectly.

Which brother chopped the firewood?

(Sitting up straighter, thinking hard) Oh! Oh! I know! (Wringing my hands a little, nervous I'll get it wrong) Um... (Stuttering) It was... the *older* brother! (Looks at the teacher hopefully) He... he wanted to sell the wood. And... and... that's how he found the magic tree! (Nods head vigorously, pleased with myself)

Yes, it was the older brother! Good job!

What did the magic tree offer the older brother if he didn't cut it down?

(Eyes sparkling, remembering the best part) Oooooh! (Claps hands together) It offered him... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...GOLDEN APPLES! (Voice full of wonder) Shiny, yummy, golden apples! (Frowns slightly) But... but the brother wasn't happy. (Shakes head sadly) That wasn't very nice of him.

You're right, he wasn't happy even with golden apples!

What happened when the older brother tried to cut the tree down anyway?

(Gasps, eyes widening) Oh! Oh! (Gets a little fidgety, remembering the scary part) The tree... the tree got angry! (Voice drops to a whisper) And it... (shudders) ...it showered him with... with NEEDLES! (Points an imaginary needle) So many needles! Ouch! Ouch! Ouch! (Makes a little whimpering sound) He was on the ground and in pain.
Yes! He was covered in needles. Who helped him?

(Brightens up again, relieved to be past the needles) The younger brother! (Beaming) The nice brother! He came and... (Carefully mimics pulling something out) ...he pulled all the needles out! (Looks at the teacher with a big smile) He was being very, very kind. (Nods head approvingly)

That's right! The younger brother was very kind.

Why do you think the younger brother helped him, even though the older brother wasn't always nice to him?

(Looks down at my hands, thinking hard) Hmmm... (Scrunches up my nose) Well... (Looks up again, a little hesitant) Maybe... because he loved him? (Tilts head, unsure) Even if the older brother wasn't nice *all* the time... (Voice gets stronger) ...he was still his brother! And brothers... brothers should help each other! (Nods firmly, feeling proud of my answer)

That is a wonderful answer! You're right, the younger brother loved him and wanted to help.

What happened *after* the younger brother helped him? Did the tree do anything else?

(Eyes light up, remembering the ending) Yes! Yes! (Bounces in my seat again) The older brother said sorry! He said he wouldn't be mean anymore! (Claps hands happily) And then... (pauses for effect) ...the magic tree gave them *more* golden apples! (Smiling widely) Because they were both nice now! It was a happy ending! (Looks at the teacher expectantly)
It was a happy ending! Why do you think the tree gave them more golden apples after the older brother said sorry? What do you think the story is trying to teach us?

(Thinking hard, tapping my chin) Hmmm... (Frowns a little, trying to understand) Maybe... maybe the tree wanted them to be good? (Looks at the teacher, seeking confirmation)

(Suddenly, a big smile spreads across my face) I think... I think the story is trying to teach us to be NICE! (Voice gets louder and more excited) And... and to say sorry when we do something wrong! (Nods head enthusiastically) Because... because if we're nice, good things will happen! (Looks at the teacher, beaming) Is that right? (My leg starts bouncing up and down with excitement)

You are so close! You're exactly right about being nice and saying sorry. The story shows us that when we are kind, good things can happen. Sometimes, being kind is rewarded.

So, what's one thing we can learn from the story? A little lesson that the story teaches us?

(Concentrating really hard, chewing on my lip) Okay... okay... (Looks up suddenly, eyes shining) I know! (Points finger in the air) Be nice to everyone, even if they are mean to you! (Nods head firmly) And... and if you *are* mean, say you're sorry! (Smiling brightly) Then, maybe you'll get golden apples too! (Giggles)
That's a great lesson to learn from the story! "Kindness will always be rewarded". You understood the story very well. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was a long one.

First, can you tell me: Who was King Midas?

(Smiling brightly, bouncing a little)

King Midas? (thinking) He was a king! A Greek king! And he did something nice for a Satyr! (Looks at the teacher for confirmation)

Yes, that's right! He was a Greek king who helped a Satyr. Good job remembering that!

Now, what did the god Dionysus offer King Midas?

(Eyes wide with excitement, almost jumping up and down)

Ooooh! Oooooh! (Waving hand) I know! I know! Dionysus said King Midas could have a... a... (Stuttering slightly) a... wish! Because he was so nice! A super great wish!

Exactly! He offered him a wish!

What did King Midas wish for? Do you remember?

(Nodding head enthusiastically)

Yes! He wished that everything he touched turned to... (pauses for dramatic effect, beaming) GOLD! Everything! (Confidently) He really, really wanted that!

That's right! He wanted everything he touched to turn to gold.

Now, after he got his wish, what was the first thing he did?

(Eyes sparkling, hands clasped in front)

He touched stuff! Lots and lots of stuff! (Looks away briefly, remembering) He touched tables and chairs and... and... (Snaps fingers) I think he touched some rocks too! And they all turned into gold! (Excitedly) It was so cool... at first!

Yes, he did! He touched lots of things and they turned to gold.

But, did he stay happy about his wish? What happened next?

(Frowning slightly, tilting head)

Ummm... (Thinking hard) He got hungry! (Confidently) Really, really hungry! And when he tried to eat... (Face scrunches up in realization) the food turned to gold too! (Shakes head) He couldn't eat anything! (Looking at the teacher with concern) Is that bad?

Yes, that's right! He couldn't eat anything.

Why couldn't he eat? The food looked yummy, right?

(Nodding vigorously)

Yes! It looked super yummy! (Points finger) But when he touched it... *poof!* (Makes a magical hand gesture) It turned into hard, cold gold! (Confidently) Gold isn't yummy! You can't eat gold! (Looks at the teacher for approval)

You are absolutely right. You can't eat gold!

So, King Midas was hungry. And then what happened with his daughter?

(Gasps, eyes widening with a hint of sadness)

Oh no! (Voice drops a little) His daughter... she loved him very much! She ran to give him a big hug! (Looks down at hands, fiddling with them) And... and... (Voice trembling slightly) she turned into gold too! (Looks back up, eyes a little watery) It was so sad!

It *was* very sad. So, King Midas couldn't eat, and his daughter turned to gold.

How do you think King Midas felt then?

(Looks down, kicking feet slightly)

(Quietly) I think... I think he felt really, really bad. (Looks up, a little teary-eyed) He wanted gold, but he didn't want his daughter to be gold! (More confidently) He learned that gold wasn't the most important thing, right? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation) Maybe having his daughter to hug was better than having gold!

Yes, I think you're right. He probably felt terrible. He learned that gold wasn't the most important thing.

So, King Midas *thought* he wanted all that gold. But in the end, did the gold make him happy?

(Shakes head emphatically)

No! (With conviction) It made him super sad! (Points finger) He couldn't eat, and he couldn't hug his daughter! (Thinks for a moment, then smiles brightly) Gold is pretty, but it's not as good as food and hugs! (Looks at the teacher expectantly) Am I right?

You are absolutely right! Gold is pretty, but it's not as good as food and hugs.

So, what do you think we can learn from the story of King Midas? What's the big idea the story is trying to tell us?

(Thinking really hard, brows furrowed)

Ummm... (Snaps fingers) I know! (Beams with pride) The story tells us that... (Pauses for emphasis) ...that wanting *too* much of something isn't always good! (Looks directly at the teacher) And that things like love and food are more important than shiny gold! (Bounces in seat, excited to have figured it out!) Did I get it right?

You got it exactly right! Wanting too much can lead to problems. Sometimes, the things we *think* will make us happy, actually make us unhappy. It's important to remember what's *really* important, like family and being able to eat. You understood the story so well! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! Did you like it?

Now, let's talk about the fox. What was the fox looking for?
(Beaming) Yes! I really liked the story! The fox was looking for... (thinking, taps chin with finger) ... food! He was hungry! (Looks at teacher expectantly, hoping to get it right)
That's right! He was very hungry. And what did he find that he wanted to eat?
(Eyes widening) He found grapes! Big, purple, juicy grapes! (Gestures with hands to show how big the grapes were) They were behind a farmer's wall! (Nods head confidently)
Perfect! Now, could the fox reach the grapes? What did he do to try and get them?

(Frowns slightly, thinking) Hmmm... (pauses) No, he couldn't reach them! He... (pauses again, looks down for a second then back up) He jumped! He jumped really high! (Jumps up and down a little bit to demonstrate) But he still couldn't get them. (Shakes head sadly)
You're doing great! He did jump really high! And did jumping work? Did he get the grapes?
(Shakes head firmly) Nope! He didn't get them. He kept trying and trying! (Raises hand eagerly) But he still couldn't reach! (Looks a little disappointed)
That's right! He tried many times. What did the fox do *after* he couldn't reach the grapes? Did he keep trying forever?
(Thinking hard) No... He didn't keep trying... (Snaps fingers) He gave up! (Looks at teacher, a little unsure if that's the right answer) And he went home! (Nods head slowly)
Yes, he gave up and went home. Now, this is important. What did the fox *say* about the grapes after he gave up?

(Tilts head, concentrating) He said... (pauses) He said the grapes were... (struggles to remember the word) ...sour! (Looks up at the teacher, relieved) He said they were sour anyway! Because he couldn't reach them. (Smiles proudly)
Exactly! He said they were sour. Do you think the grapes *really* were sour? Or do you think he said that because he was upset he couldn't get them?

(Looks thoughtful, bites lip slightly) Hmmm... (ponders) I think... I think he said they were sour because he was sad he couldn't get them! (Looks up, confident again) Because they looked really yummy and juicy before! So, maybe they weren't really sour. He just said that. (Nods, convinced)

You got it! So, the fox wanted something very much, but he couldn't get it. And then he said he didn't even *want* it.

Now, think about the whole story. What do you think we can learn from the fox and the grapes? What's the story trying to teach us? It's okay if it's hard, just give it your best guess!

(Stares intently, brows furrowed in concentration) Hmm... (pauses, tapping fingers on the table) Is it like... (stutters) ...is it like, if you can't get something, you shouldn't just say you didn't want it anyway? (Looks at the teacher hopefully, eyes wide). Is that it? Or is there something else? (Looks a little anxious and starts fidgeting.)

That's a *really* good start! Yes, it's like if you can't get something, you shouldn't just say you didn't want it.

It's also about trying hard. Did the fox give up too easily, do you think? What if he had tried a different way to get the grapes?

(Eyes light up) Oh! Oh! I know! Maybe he could have gotten a ladder! (Gets excited and starts miming climbing a ladder) He could have climbed the ladder and gotten the grapes! (Stops miming and looks thoughtful again) Or... or maybe he could have asked the farmer for help! (Looks pleased with this idea) That would have been a nicer thing to do than saying the grapes were sour! (Nods vigorously) So it's about not giving up, and maybe asking for help! (Smiles brightly) Is that right?

Yes! You're getting it! It's about not giving up easily and maybe finding other ways to try. And it's also about being honest with yourself.

So, the story teaches us that good things take effort, and it's not good to pretend you don't want something just because you can't have it. It's important to keep trying! Now, can you tell me what the moral of the story is in your own words? What did you learn from the story?

(Sits up straighter, feeling confident) Okay! Okay! (Takes a deep breath) I learned that... (pauses, thinking carefully) ...that if you really, really want something, you should try your best to get it! And if you can't get it, you shouldn't just say you didn't want it in the first place! (Nods firmly) Because that's not really true! (Looks at the teacher with a proud smile) And maybe... maybe you should ask for help too! Because sometimes other people can help you reach the grapes! (Giggles)

That's a fantastic explanation! You understood the story perfectly! You learned that nothing comes easy, and you shouldn't hate what you can't have. You also added that asking for help is a good option too! Well done! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was The Milkmaid and Her Pail.

Now, let's talk about Molly. What was Molly going to do with the milk?
(Smiling brightly and bouncing a little on my feet) I know! I know! Molly was going to... (pauses, thinking hard, then confidently) ...sell the milk at the market! She wanted to sell it to get money!
That's right! She wanted to sell the milk and get money. What did she start thinking about while she was walking?

(Eyes widening with excitement, running forward a step) Ooh, ooh, I know this one too! (Stuttering a little in my excitement) S-s-she started thinking about all the things she could buy with the money! Like a... like a chicken! (Clapping my hands together)
Yes! She started thinking about buying a chicken. And what did she think the chicken would do for her?

(Thinking hard, furrowing my brow) Hmmm... (Looking down at my shoes, then back up with a confident smile) The chicken would lay eggs! And then she could sell the eggs and get even *more* money! (Pumping my fist in the air)
Exactly! She had a plan to get even more money. What happened when she started thinking about all of that? What happened to the milk?

(My smile fades a little, and I look down, kicking at the floor) Oh no! (Stuttering a bit) S-s-she was so busy thinking about the chicken and the eggs and being rich that she... (Quietly) ...she spilled the milk. (Looks up at the teacher, a little worried) All of it!
Yes, she spilled all the milk. And what happened then? Did she get to buy the chicken?

(Shakes head vigorously) No! (Voice is a bit sad) She had no milk to sell, so she had no money. (Looks down again, then up with a hopeful expression) Her momma was there. What did her momma say? (Looks at the teacher expectantly, hoping for a hint)
Her momma said something important. She said, "Don't count your chickens..." What do you think she meant by that?

(Thinking very hard, tapping my chin with my finger) Don't count your chickens... (Eyes widen with a little understanding) Does it mean... does it mean you shouldn't be happy about something before it really happens? Like... like Molly was happy about the egg money before she even had a chicken or any eggs? (Looking at the teacher for confirmation)
You got it! That's exactly what it means. So, what lesson did Molly learn in the story? What should she have done differently?

(Nodding enthusiastically) She should have... (Thinking carefully) ...she should have waited until she *actually* had the egg money before she started planning all the things she would buy! That's right! She should have focused on selling the milk *first*. So, what's the big idea of the story? What does the story want us to learn?

(Eyes bright, I raise my hand eagerly, almost jumping in my seat) Ooh! Ooh! I know! (Confidently) The story wants us to learn to be careful and not get too excited about things before they really happen! (Pulls back a little) And maybe... maybe to not skip when you're carrying milk. (Giggles)

Wow! You explained that so well! He was busy getting wiser.
