dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it?

First, tell me, who are the main people in the story?

Yes, it was sad! (Nods head enthusiastically) The main people were… um… (thinking) The farmer! And… and his wife! (Confidently) And the goose! The goose that laid the golden egg! (Beams, eager to please). Did I get it right, teacher? (Looks at the teacher expectantly).

You got it all right! High five! (Teacher gives a high five).

Now, what did the goose give the farmer every day?

(High fives enthusiastically!) The goose gave the farmer… (eyes widen, remembering the exciting part) a GOLDEN egg! (Confidently) Every. Single. Day! That's like… a super special egg! (Grinning widely)
It *is* a super special egg! And what did the farmer do with the golden egg?

(Eyes shining, leaning forward in my seat) He… he sold it! (Confidently) To get money! So he could buy… (thinking hard) I don't know… yummy food? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation, hoping I'm right). Did he buy yummy food, teacher?

He could buy yummy food, yes. The story says they lived a comfortable life. That means they had enough of what they needed.

So, they were doing well, right? What made the farmer change his mind?

(Nods head vigorously) Yeah! They were doing good! (Frowns a little, remembering the bad part) But… the farmer… (looks down at my hands, a little hesitant) he got… um… (struggling to find the right word) …greedy? (Looks up at the teacher with a questioning look) He wanted… more? More golden eggs? He wasn't happy with just one. (Shakes head slightly, disapproving) Is that right?
That's exactly right! He got greedy. And because he was greedy, what did he do to the goose? This is the sad part.
(Looks down, shuffling my feet) Oh… (voice barely a whisper) He… he cut it open. (Looks away, a little sad) To try to get all the eggs at once. (Frowns deeply). It was a very bad idea.
It was a very bad idea. And what happened when he cut open the goose? Did he find lots of golden eggs?

(Shakes head sadly, looking back at the teacher) No… (voice stronger now, understanding the lesson) He found… blood and guts. (Wrinkles nose) Yuck! And… no more golden eggs. Ever! (Looks at the teacher with wide, serious eyes)
That's right. No more golden eggs. So, what happened to the farmer and his wife after that? Did they stay comfortable?

(Shakes head again, very emphatically) No! (Voice full of certainty) They got… poorer! (Frowns, remembering the consequences) Because they didn't have any more golden eggs to sell. They were… (struggling for the right word) …sad! And hungry maybe? (Looks at the teacher, seeking confirmation) It was all the farmer's fault for being greedy. (Nods head decisively).
You're exactly right! It *was* the farmer's fault. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big lesson we can learn from the farmer and his goose?

(Thinking hard, tapping my chin with my finger) Hmmm… It's teaching us that… (eyes light up with understanding) …we shouldn't be greedy! (Confidently) Because if we are greedy, we might lose everything! (Nods head, pleased with my answer) And… (pauses, thinking if there's more) …we should be happy with what we have? (Looks at the teacher hopefully, wanting to get it completely right) Is that it, teacher? Did I get the lesson?

You're very close! It's about being greedy, yes. And being happy with what you have is part of it.

But it's also about *thinking* before you do something, especially something big. If the farmer had thought about it, what do you think he would have realised?

(Ponders for a moment, brow furrowed) If he thought about it… (snaps fingers, eyes widening) …he would have realized that one golden egg a day was already really, really good! (Nods head enthusiastically) And if he cut open the goose, he wouldn't get *any* golden eggs! (Looks at the teacher, excited to have figured it out) So, it's like… think before you act! (Beams proudly). Did I get it now, teacher? Did I get the *whole* lesson?
Yes! You got it! "Think before you act." That's the big lesson. The farmer didn't think, and he made a big mistake. You understood the story really well. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Farmer and the Well."

Now, can you tell me, who bought the well?

(Eyes light up, bouncing slightly in my seat)

The farmer did! (confidently) He bought it from his neighbor! It said so right in the story! (points enthusiastically at the book, then looks back at the teacher, eager for praise) Did I get it right? (beams)

Yes! You got it right! The farmer bought the well from his neighbor.

Now, what did the farmer want to do with the well?

(Thinking, tapping a finger on my desk)

Ummm... (eyes widen in recognition) He wanted to water his farm! (confidently) The story said he bought the well "to water his farm"! He wanted to use the water in the well to help his plants grow! (smiles, pleased with the answer) Is that right too?

That's exactly right! He wanted to water his farm.

But could he use the water? What happened when he tried?

(Frowns, remembering the tricky part of the story)

No! (Shakes head vigorously) The neighbor... the neighbor said he COULDN'T use the water! (Indignant) Even though the farmer bought the well! The neighbor said he only sold the *well*, not the water inside. (Looks at the teacher, confused) That doesn't seem fair, does it?
No, it doesn't seem fair at all. So, what did the farmer do when the neighbor wouldn't let him use the water? Who did he go to?

(Sitting up straight, remembering the exciting part)

He went to the... (pauses, concentrates hard) ...the Emperor! (confidently) He went to the Emperor to get help! Because the Emperor is in charge and can make things right! (Smiles proudly) I remember!

Excellent remembering! The farmer went to the Emperor.

And what did the Emperor's helper, the courtier, ask the neighbor? What did the courtier want to know?

(Sticks out tongue slightly in concentration, thinking hard)

Ummm... (looks away, trying to recall) The courtier asked... (snaps fingers) Oh! He asked the neighbor why the farmer couldn't use the water! He asked him why he wouldn't let the farmer use the water *after* he sold him the well. (Looks back at the teacher, hopeful) Is that close?

That's very close! The courtier wanted to understand what was happening.

And what did the neighbor say? Why did he think he didn't have to let the farmer use the water?

(Rolls eyes, remembering the neighbor's silly excuse)

He said... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...he said he only sold the *well*, not the water! (Emphasizes "well" and "water") He said the water still belonged to *him*! (Shakes head disapprovingly) That's not very nice. He was trying to trick the farmer!
You are right! He was trying to trick the farmer! And was he successful in tricking the farmer? What happened next? What did the courtier say to the neighbor?

(Giggles, remembering the neighbor getting caught)

No! (emphatically) He didn't trick the farmer! The courtier was too smart! The courtier said... (eyes widen, mimicking a stern voice) ...he said the neighbor had to either take all the water out of the well *right now*, or pay the farmer rent for keeping the water in *his* well! (laughs) Because if the well belonged to the farmer, then the neighbor couldn't just keep his water in it for free!
Exactly! And what did the neighbor do then?

(Smiles triumphantly)

He... (pauses) He said he was sorry! (emphatically) He realized his trick didn't work and he said he was sorry and went home! The farmer got to use his well! (claps hands happily) Hooray!

Hooray! The farmer got to use his well!

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big idea of the story?

(Thinking hard, tapping chin)

Ummm... (looks down at the book, then back at the teacher) It means... it means you shouldn't try to trick people! (confidently) Because it's not nice, and you'll probably get caught! (nods firmly) And... and you should be fair! (Looks at the teacher, hopeful) Is that right?

That's a great way to put it! It's about being fair and not trying to trick people.

Another way to say it is that cheating doesn't work. It will get you nowhere. Can you say that?

(Repeats carefully)

Cheating... doesn't work. (pauses, thinking) It will get you nowhere! (nods, understanding) Like the neighbor! He tried to cheat the farmer, and it didn't work and he got nowhere! (smiles, pleased with myself)

Exactly! You understand the story and what it teaches us. The neighbor tried to cheat, and it got him nowhere.

Well done! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends."

Now, let's talk about it. First, how did the elephant feel at the start of the story?

(Beaming, nodding enthusiastically) The elephant... (thinking, tapping my chin with a finger) The elephant felt... lonely! Yes! He wanted some friends! (Looks at the teacher, eager for confirmation) He was all by himself.
That's right! He was lonely. And what did he do because he was lonely?

(Eyes widening, bouncing slightly in my seat) He looked for friends! He went around the forest and asked everyone! (Confidently) He asked the monkey, and the rabbit, and the frog! He wanted to play with them! Did I get it right? (Looking at the teacher expectantly).

You got it exactly right! He asked the monkey, the rabbit, and the frog.

Now, tell me, what did the monkey say? Why didn't the monkey want to be friends?

(Frowning slightly, remembering the story) The monkey... (thinking hard, wrinkling my nose) The monkey said... the elephant couldn't swing in the trees! (Nodding, pleased with myself). He said, "You can't swing like me!" And then he ran off! (Looking at the teacher, hoping I explained it well).

Yes, that's perfect! The monkey said the elephant couldn't swing in trees.

And what about the rabbit? Why didn't the rabbit want to be friends with the elephant?

(Remembering vividly, practically jumping up and down) Oh! Oh! I know this one! (Confidently) The rabbit said the elephant was too big to fit in his burrow! (Giggles) He said, "You're too big for my house!" It's because elephants are HUGE! Right? (Looking for affirmation, pointing to the teacher for emphasis).

Exactly! The rabbit said the elephant was too big for his burrow. You're doing great!

Now, one more... why didn't the frog want to be the elephant's friend?

(Eyes shining with excitement) The frog! The frog! (Pauses for dramatic effect) The frog couldn't be the elephant's friend because... (voice rising with excitement) ...the elephant couldn't jump! (Beaming proudly). The frog said, "You can't jump like me!" and then he hopped away! (Looks at the teacher, completely satisfied with my answer). Am I remembering everything?

You are remembering everything wonderfully! The frog said the elephant couldn't jump.

So, all the animals said no to being the elephant's friend. How do you think that made the elephant feel?

(Thinking carefully, my smile fading a little) Hmm... (scratches head) If everyone said no to me, I would feel... (voice getting quieter) sad. (Looks down for a moment, then back up at the teacher). I think the elephant felt sad too! Because he wanted friends to play with, and nobody wanted to play with him. (A little frown appears, showing empathy).

You're right. The elephant probably felt very sad.

Now, something interesting happened the next day. What was it?

(Eyes widening, suddenly remembering, voice filled with excitement) Oh! Oh! I know! The next day... (pauses for dramatic effect, hand raised) ...all the animals were running away! (Leaning forward, eager to share) They were scared! Something was chasing them! (Looking at the teacher, waiting for confirmation and to see if I'm on the right track). Were they running from a monster?
They were running away because they were scared! Good job! What were they running *from*? Who was scaring them?

(Concentrating, tapping my fingers on the table) Hmmm... they were running from... (eyes lighting up) the tiger! Yes! The tiger was scaring them! (Nodding, pleased with myself). He was being mean! Did I get it? (Looks at the teacher, full of anticipation).

You got it! The tiger was scaring them.

And what did the elephant do about the tiger?

(Eyes widening, voice filled with admiration) The elephant... he was so brave! (Puffs out my chest a little) He stopped the tiger! He asked him to stop being mean. But the tiger didn't listen! (Frowns, remembering the tiger's bad behavior). So... so the elephant... (voice getting stronger) ...he kicked the tiger! And scared him away! (Looks at the teacher, practically bursting with excitement). The elephant saved everyone!

That's right! The elephant scared the tiger away.

And what happened *after* the elephant scared away the tiger? How did the other animals feel about the elephant *then*?

(Eyes shining, remembering the happy ending) Oh! Oh! Then... then the animals were happy! (Clapping my hands together) They realized the elephant was a good friend! Because he was big and strong and could protect them! (Nodding enthusiastically) They wanted to be his friend after all! (Looks at the teacher, beaming). It's because he saved them from the tiger! Right?
Yes! They realized the elephant was a good friend *after* he saved them. Why do you think they didn't want to be his friend before?

(Thinking hard, furrowing my brow) Hmmm... before, they were being silly! (Shaking my head slightly) They only cared about what *they* could do! The monkey could swing, the rabbit could burrow, and the frog could jump. (Pauses, then a look of understanding spreads across my face) They were only thinking about themselves! They didn't think about how the elephant could be a good friend in other ways! (Looks at the teacher, pleased with my insight). Is that right?

That's a very good way to put it! They were only thinking about what *they* could do.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea or lesson we can learn from "Elephant and Friends?"

(Thinking deeply, tapping my chin thoughtfully) Hmmm... the story is teaching us that... (pauses, searching for the right words) ...that everyone is good at different things! And... and we should be friends with people even if they can't do the same things as us! (Eyes widening with understanding) And that being a good friend means helping people when they need it! (Looks at the teacher, feeling very proud of my answer). Did I figure it out? (Grinning widely).

You absolutely figured it out! The story teaches us that friends can be different and good at different things. Being a good friend means helping others.

So, can friends be any shape or size?

(Nodding enthusiastically, bouncing in my seat) Yes! Friends can be any shape or size! Like the elephant and the monkey! They're super different! The elephant is big and can kick tigers, and the monkey is small and can swing in trees! (Looks at the teacher, beaming with understanding) Being friends is about helping each other, not about being the same! Right?
You got it! You understand the story perfectly! Friends can be any shape or size, and it's about helping each other. Great job! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! That was a good story, right?

So, tell me, what did the girl do when she was feeling sad?

(Eyes light up, bouncing a little)

Yes! It was a *really* good story! (Beams at the teacher)

Um, when the girl was sad... (Thinks really hard, brow furrowed) ... she asked her *daddy* for help! She was, like, not happy, so she asked him! (Nods head confidently) He's a good daddy! He helped her! He didn't just, like, say, "Be happy!" He showed her with... with stuff! (Gets excited again, wiggles a little in seat)
That's right! She asked her daddy for help. And what did her daddy ask her to bring him? Three things! Do you remember what they were?

(Eyes widen, leans forward eagerly)

Oh! Oh! I know! (Raises hand high)

He asked her for... um... (Counts on fingers) ... an egg! And a... (Bites lip, concentrating) ... a potato! And... and... (Snaps fingers) ... tea leaves! Tea leaves! Like for making tea! (Beams proudly) I remembered! Was I right? (Looks at the teacher hopefully)

Yes, you're exactly right! An egg, a potato, and tea leaves.

Now, what did her daddy do with those things? He didn't just eat them, did he?

(Giggles)

No! He didn't eat them! That would be silly! (Shakes head emphatically)

He... (Looks down at hands, tracing circles on the desk) ...he put them in... in water! And... and he boiled the water! (Looks up again, excited) He boiled them all! In different... pots! Three pots! One for each thing! (Nods, pleased with self)

Great job remembering! He boiled them in three different pots.

Now, after they were boiled, what happened to the egg? Was it the same as before?

(Thinking face, squints eyes a little)

The egg... (Points finger in the air) ...it was squishy before, right? Like if you dropped it, it would go *splat*! (Makes a splat sound with mouth)

But then... (Voice gets a little quieter, more thoughtful) ...then it got hard. (Taps desk firmly) Like... like a rock! Well, not *really* a rock, but hard! (Looks up to make sure teacher is following) It changed!

You're doing so well! The egg was soft and breakable, and then it became hard.

What about the potato? What happened to the potato when it was boiled?

(Eyes widen, remembering excitedly)

The potato was hard! (Makes a fist and taps it on the desk) You could, like, throw it at someone and it wouldn't break! (Giggles mischievously)

But then... after the water... (Voice gets quieter, more thoughtful) ...it got soft. (Opens hand and wiggles fingers gently) All... smooshy! You could, like, mash it! (Smiles at the thought of mashed potatoes) It *also* changed! (Nods head, very pleased with self)

That's right! The potato was hard, and then it became soft.

And what about the tea leaves? Did they become hard or soft?

(Concentrates, taps fingers on the table)

The tea leaves... (Looks away, thinking hard) ...they didn't get hard or soft... (Snaps fingers) ...they changed the water! (Looks back at the teacher, very proud) The water turned... brown! And it smelled good! Like... like tea! (Inhales deeply, imagining the smell) They made the water different!

Exactly! The tea leaves changed the water itself.

So, the egg changed, the potato changed, and the tea changed the water. Now, the story said this was about when... when what knocks on our door?

(Beams, remembering the title)

When... when *adversity* knocks! (Says the word carefully, proud of self) Like in the story! (Nods head vigorously) It's like... when something bad happens! Right? Like when you're sad! (Looks at the teacher for confirmation)

Yes, you're right! Adversity is like when something bad or difficult happens.

So, the egg, the potato, and the tea leaves all faced the same adversity: the boiling water. But did they all react the same way?

(Thinks hard, brow furrowed)

No! (Shakes head firmly) They were all different!

The egg... it got strong! (Makes a muscle with tiny arm)

The potato... it got... (Looks down, a little confused) ...it got weak. (Looks back up, still thinking) But maybe it's not *really* weak... just... different?

And the tea... (Eyes light up again) ...it changed everything *around* it! Not just itself! (Nods, pleased with understanding) They were all different! (Repeats for emphasis)

You got it! They all faced the same problem, but they each reacted differently.

So, what do you think the story is trying to tell us about how *we* should act when adversity knocks? When something bad or hard happens to *us*?

(Looks away, thinking very hard, lips pursed)

Hmm... (Stuttering a little) ...um... well... maybe...

(Looks back at the teacher, gaining confidence)

Maybe it means that when something bad happens... (Takes a deep breath) ...we can choose how we act! Like the egg! We can get strong! Even if we were squishy before!

(Frowns a little, thinking about the potato)

Or... (Voice gets quieter) ...or maybe we're like the potato. And we get soft. (Shrugs a little) But maybe that's okay too? Maybe it means we can... (Searching for the right word) ...bend! So we don't break!

(Eyes widen, understanding dawning)

But the *best* way... (Voice gets excited again) ...is to be like the tea! And change everything around us! (Gestures expansively with hands) Make things better! Even when it's hard!

(Beams at the teacher, hoping for approval) I think... I think that's what it means!

That's a wonderful way to explain it! You're exactly right. The story is telling us that we can choose how we react to difficult situations. We can become strong like the egg, be flexible like the potato, or even change things for the better like the tea.

So, what's the big idea of the story? What's the message it wants us to remember?

(Eyes sparkle, leans forward with a confident smile)

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story, The Needle Tree! That was a fun one, wasn't it?

Now, let's see if we remember what happened. Can you tell me, what did the older brother do for work?

(Smiling brightly, hands clasped on the table) Yes! It *was* fun! I liked the part with the golden apples!

The older brother... (thinking, tapping my finger on the table) He chopped wood! In the forest! And then he... (confidently) ...sold it in the market! I remember! He worked really hard! Is that right, Teacher?

That's exactly right! He chopped wood and sold it. Good job remembering!

Now, what happened when the older brother found the special tree? What did the tree say?

(Eyes wide with excitement) Oh! Oh! I know! The tree... (stuttering a little, trying to remember the exact words) The tree said... umm... please don't cut me down! (Confidently) And it said it would give him golden apples! (Beaming) He wanted golden apples! Was it a magic tree, Teacher? Because it gave golden apples! (Leans forward eagerly)

Yes, it was a magic tree! You remembered perfectly. The tree offered him golden apples.

Now, did the older brother share the golden apples? Or did something else happen?

(Frowning slightly, but still enthusiastic) Umm... he didn't share! (Shakes head emphatically) No, no sharing! He got... (counting on my fingers) one, two... some golden apples! But he wanted more! (Looks down at the table for a second, then back up, confidently) He was greedy! He wanted to cut the tree anyway! Right? Is that what happened?
Yes, that's right! He was greedy. And what happened *when* he tried to cut down the tree even though it gave him apples? What did the tree do?

(Gasps, eyes widening) Oh! Oh! It gave him... (thinking hard, forehead furrowed) ...needles! (Looks at the teacher, a little unsure) It showered him with needles! Ouch! That must have hurt *so* much! (Shudders dramatically) Did the needles tickle, Teacher? (Bounces in my seat, waiting for an answer)

(Smiling) I don't think they tickled! Needles are pointy and sharp.

Now, who helped the older brother after the needles fell on him?

(Beaming again, remembering the good part) His younger brother! His younger brother found him! (Clapping my hands excitedly) And he took out all the needles! One by one! He was so kind! (Nods head vigorously) I want to be a kind brother too! Is that why the tree gave them *more* golden apples in the end? (Leans forward, curious)

That's right! His younger brother was very kind.

Why do you think the tree gave them more golden apples in the end? What did the older brother do *after* his younger brother helped him?

(Thinking hard, looking up at the ceiling) Hmmm... (snaps fingers) He said sorry! (Looks at the teacher, sure of the answer) He said sorry for being mean! And the tree... (brightens up) ...the tree liked that he said sorry! Because being mean is bad! (Nods firmly) So the tree gave them more golden apples because the older brother learned to be nice! Right, Teacher? Is that the lesson? (Tilts head, waiting for confirmation)

You are so close! You got it! The older brother was mean, then he was sorry, and then the tree gave them more apples.

So, what does this story teach us about being kind? What happens when we are kind to others, like the younger brother was?

(Smiling widely, excited to share what I learned) Being kind is good! (Raises a finger) The younger brother was kind, and... (thinking for a moment, tapping chin) ...the older brother said sorry! (Another finger goes up) And then the tree gave them more golden apples! (Claps hands together) So if we are kind, and say sorry when we're not, good things happen! (Looks at the teacher hopefully) Does that mean if I'm *always* kind, I'll get golden apples too? (Giggles)

(Chuckles softly) Maybe not golden apples exactly, but the story shows us that being kind often leads to good things happening. People will be happy, and you'll feel good too! The story teaches us that kindness is usually rewarded.

Do you think you understand the story and what it teaches us now?<finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Golden Touch"!

Now, can you tell me in your own words, who was King Midas?
Uh... (looks down, fidgeting with hands) He... he was a king? (pauses) A Greek king. (eyes dart up quickly to the teacher then back down)

That's right! He was a Greek king. Good job remembering that!

And what did he do for the Satyr? Do you remember?
(Thinking, bites lip) He... he did a... a good deed. (looks up at the teacher hopefully) He... helped him? (voice trails off into a whisper)

Yes! He did a good deed and helped him! That was very kind of Midas.

Now, because he was kind, Dionysus offered him a wish. What did Midas wish for?

(Eyes widen slightly, remembers something) Gold! (stuttering) He... he wished that everything he touched... (pauses, uses fingers to emphasize) everything... would turn to... gold. (looks at the teacher expectantly, a little nervous)

That's it! Everything he touched would turn to gold.

Did Dionysus think it was a good wish?
(Shakes head slowly) Uh... no. (Thinking) Dionysus... he... warned him. (looks down, tracing patterns on the desk with a finger)

You are doing great! He did warn him.

After he got his wish, what was the first thing Midas probably did?

(Eyes light up, excited) He... he touched things! (pauses, thinking) Lots of things! (gestures with hands, then gets anxious) Like... like his chair? (looks at the teacher for confirmation) And... and his toys? To make them... (voice trails off)
Yes! He touched lots of things! He probably touched his chair, maybe some toys. And what happened when he touched them?
(Confidently) They turned to gold! (pauses, then looks down, worried) But... but then he got hungry. (frowns)
That's right. He got hungry. What happened when he tried to eat?
(Voice gets small and quiet) Uh... the food... it turned to gold too. (looks up at the teacher with wide, worried eyes) He couldn't... he couldn't eat it. (shudders slightly)
He couldn't eat it. That's right. He was probably very sad and scared. Then, what happened with his daughter?

(Eyes well up a little, voice trembling) His... his daughter... (pauses, takes a shaky breath) She ran to... to hug him. And... (voice breaks) she turned into gold too! (looks away, blinking rapidly) It was... it was terrible!

Yes, it was terrible. He couldn't eat, and then his daughter turned to gold.

Did Midas still think the golden touch was a good thing then?

(Shakes head emphatically) No! (voice is stronger, but still a little shaky) He... he didn't want it anymore! It wasn't... it wasn't a good thing. (looks at the teacher, wanting to make sure they understand)

You're absolutely right. It wasn't a good thing.

So, Midas wished for gold because he wanted it so badly. But what happened because he was so greedy for gold?

(Thinking hard, taps chin with finger) He... he couldn't eat. (pauses) And he lost... (whispers) ...his daughter. (looks up at the teacher, a flicker of understanding in their eyes) So... so being greedy... (searching for the right words) ...it made him... unhappy?

Yes! Being greedy made him very unhappy. He lost important things because he only wanted gold.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us about being greedy? What's the big idea of the story?

(Fidgets, thinking) Uh... (pauses, then a little spark of inspiration) Maybe... maybe it's saying that... (struggles with the words) ...that wanting too much stuff... isn't... isn't good? (looks at the teacher, a little anxious) That... that maybe... having people you love... is more important than gold? (frowns, trying to figure it out) Is that right? (worried)

That's *exactly* right! Wanting too much stuff isn't always good. And having people you love is much more important than gold. The story is teaching us that if you are too greedy, it can lead to bad things happening to you.

So how would you summarise the moral of the story?

(Takes a deep breath) Uh... (pauses, then says slowly and carefully) Don't... be too greedy. (looks down, thinking for a moment, then adds quietly) ...Because you might lose what's really important. (looks back up, meeting the teacher's eyes briefly)
That is a wonderful way to put it. You understood the story and what it was trying to teach us perfectly! Well done! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! I liked how you said "purple" and "juicy"!

Now, let's talk about the fox. Was the fox happy at the beginning of the story?

(Looks down, fiddling with my crayons)

Uh… no. (Stuttering) He… he was… hungry.
That's right! He was hungry. What did the fox do because he was hungry?

(Thinking hard, tapping my pencil on the desk)

He… (pauses) he looked for… food? (Looks up at the teacher with a hopeful expression) Lots and lots of places.
Yes! He looked for food. And then what did he find?

(Eyes widen slightly, remembering)

Grapes! Big, purple, juicy grapes! (Confidently, using the words from the story, but then quickly looks down again, feeling a bit anxious about whether I said it right). But… they were… up high. Really, really high. (Hesitates).
You got it! They were up high. What did the fox do to try and get the grapes?

(Worried, biting my lip a little bit)

He… jumped? (Looks at the teacher, nervously). He… he jumped a lot? He tried… very… very hard… (voice trails off). But… (long pause, looking down at my shoes) ... he couldn't… reach them.
That's exactly right! He jumped and jumped and jumped! But could he get the grapes?

(Shakes head slightly, still looking down)

…No… (whispers). He… he couldn't.
And what did the fox do *after* he couldn't get the grapes? What did he say?

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed. Taps pencil again, then looks up, a little less anxious)

He said… (a long pause) …he said the grapes… were sour! (Looks proud of remembering, but also a little confused). But… but why did he say that? (Asks the teacher, genuinely curious). Were they *really* sour?
That's a great question! Do *you* think the grapes were really sour? Remember, he really wanted them at first.

(Confused, looking back and forth between my hands).

Well… if he jumped and jumped… and still couldn’t get them… (Starts to think beyond the story, eyes widening) …maybe… maybe he was just trying to feel… better? Because he couldn't… get what he wanted? (Voice trembling slightly, realizing the connection). Like… like if I really wanted a toy, but I couldn't have it, I might say… it wasn't even a *good* toy anyway? Is that… is that what the fox did?

Yes! That's it! The fox couldn't get the grapes, so he said they were sour to make himself feel better.

So, what do you think we can learn from the story about the fox and the grapes? What is the story trying to teach us?

(Takes a deep breath, still a little nervous, but trying to be brave)

Uhm… (long pause, thinking). Maybe… maybe it’s about… (looks up, meeting the teacher’s eyes for a brief moment then looks away again) …about not… pretending… things you can’t have… aren’t good? Or… (another pause) …or maybe… about trying to… to be okay… even when you don't… get what you want? (Fiddles with the corner of my worksheet, anxious about whether the answer is right).

Is… is that right?

That's a wonderful way to put it! It's about not pretending things you can't have aren't good. It's also about trying to be okay even when you don't get what you want.

The story teaches us that sometimes, things are hard to get. And it's easy to say we didn't want them anyway. But it's better to remember that nothing comes easy, and it's not good to hate what you can't have. The fox tried to make himself feel better, but maybe it would have been better to just accept that he couldn't reach the grapes.

Do you understand now?

(Nods slowly, thinking about everything)

Uh-huh. (Pause). So… (starts to ask a question, then hesitates) …So, it’s okay to be sad… if you can't get something? But… but not to… lie about it? To yourself? (Looks up at the teacher, needing reassurance).

Exactly! It's okay to be sad or disappointed. But try not to lie to yourself about it. It's better to learn from trying, even if you don't succeed.

You understood the story very well! I'm proud of you.<finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Milkmaid and Her Pail."

Now, tell me, who was the main person in our story?
(Looks down, fidgeting with my fingers) Uh... Molly? (pauses, bites lip) The... the milk...maid?

Yes! Molly the milkmaid. Good job!

What was Molly going to do with the milk?
(Eyes widen slightly, thinking hard) Sell it... at the market? (pauses) To... to get money? (Looks up at the teacher briefly, then back down)

Exactly! She was going to sell it at the market to get money.

Now, what did Molly start thinking about while she was walking?
(Thinking, furrowing my brow) Uh... she... she saw a chicken? (Hesitates) And... and thought she could get *more* money? (Looks up, questioningly)
Yes! She saw a chicken. And what did she think she could do with the chicken to get more money?
(Anxious, voice gets smaller) Uh... eggs? (Looks away, nervously) She wanted the chicken to lay eggs... to sell?

Yes! You're doing great! She wanted the chicken to lay eggs so she could sell them.

So, first she sells milk, then she buys a chicken that lays eggs... what happens next? What was she doing when the milk spilled?

(Eyes widen, remembering) Oh! (Stuttering a little) She... she was... she was skipping! (Looks down, ashamed) Because she was... she was thinking about all the... the things she could buy? And then... (voice trails off) the milk... spilled. All of it.

Yes, that's right! She was skipping and thinking about all the things she could buy. And then the milk spilled.

How do you think Molly felt when the milk spilled?

(Frowns, thinking deeply) Sad? (Pauses) Maybe... really, really sad? (Looks up, a little watery-eyed) Because she lost all the... all the money? (Voice cracks slightly) And... and her mom was... was going to tell her... the thing about counting... counting chickens.

Yes, sad is a good word. She lost all the milk and the money she would have gotten.

What did her mother tell her?

(Thinking, trying to remember the exact words) Uh... something about... (looks down, tracing patterns on the floor with my shoe) ...not counting... your chickens... until they... hatch? (Looks up, seeking confirmation)

Yes! "Don't count your chickens until they hatch."

What do you think that means? Why did her mom say that?

(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip) Hmmm... (pauses) Maybe... maybe it means don't... don't plan for things... before they really happen? (Looks up, anxiously) Like... like the chicken *might not* lay eggs? Or... or something could happen to the milk? (Worried expression) You shouldn't... you shouldn't spend the money... before you *have* the money? Is that... is that right?

Yes! That's a great explanation! Don't plan on something good happening until you are sure it *will* happen.

So, what did Molly do wrong in the story?

(Looks down, feeling a little guilty for Molly) She... she got too excited? (Pauses) And... and she was thinking about the *future*, but she... she didn't... take care of the milk *now*? (Looks up, hesitantly) She was... dreaming... instead of... instead of being careful? Is that... is that it?

Yes! She was dreaming instead of being careful. She was planning for the future before she even sold the milk.

So, what is the lesson we learn from this story? What should we *not* do, based on what happened to Molly?

(Thinking hard, biting lip again) Uh... we shouldn't... we shouldn't be too sure of things... before they happen? (Looks up, questioningly) We should... we should be careful... and... and not... not get too excited about... maybe things? (Voice trails off, nervous) And... and focus on what we... what we have *right now*?

Yes! That's it exactly! We shouldn't be too sure of things before they happen. We should focus on what we have right now. We should be careful and not get too excited about maybe-things.

We call that lesson the "moral" of the story. The moral is: Do not depend on something until you are sure it will happen.

Do you think you understand the story and the moral now? <finish>

Now, what did the farmer want to do with the well?
(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip) He… he wanted to… (Stutters) w-w-water his… farm? (Looks at the teacher, anxiously awaiting confirmation) I think…

That's right! He wanted to water his farm. Good job!

And what did the neighbor do when the farmer tried to take water from the well?

(Frowning) He… he said… (pauses, trying to remember) he said the farmer couldn't… because… (eyes widen slightly) …he only sold him the… the well… but not the… the water! (Looks down at my hands) That's… not very nice. (Shakes head slowly)

You're right, that wasn't very nice!

Why do you think the neighbor didn't want the farmer to use the water?

(Thinking deeply, tapping my finger on the desk) Hmm… (looks up, using a slightly more complex word) Maybe… he was being… deceitful? (Looks at the teacher for reassurance) Or… or… he wanted more… more money? (Wrinkles nose)

"Deceitful" is a big word! That's a good thought. He *was* trying to trick the farmer.

So, what did the farmer do when the neighbor wouldn't let him use the water?

(Voice trembling slightly) He… he went to… the emperor? (Looks at the teacher with wide, anxious eyes) Because… because it wasn't fair? (Pulls at my sleeve) I would be… really, really sad if someone did that to me.

You're right, it wasn't fair, and going to the Emperor was a good idea.

What did the courtier tell the neighbor to do?

(Concentrating, trying to recall the details) Uh… (Hesitates, looking down) The courtier… said… (Snaps fingers, remembering) he had to… pay rent… for the water! Or… or take it all away! (Looks up, a flicker of understanding in my eyes)
Yes! Why do you think the courtier said that?

(Thinks for a long moment, furrowing brow) Hmmm… (Looks up, a sudden flash of insight) Because… because the neighbor was being… illogical! (Fidgets again, then states with a little more confidence) If he didn't sell the water, it's still *in* the farmer's well! So it's… it's taking up space that the farmer owns! Right? (Looks at teacher, hopefully)

You got it! That's very clever thinking!

So, what happened to the neighbor in the end?

(Small voice, looking down) He… he said sorry… and went home. (Sighs, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) He… he learned his lesson? (Quietly) I hope so. (Looks up, worried) Did he *really* say sorry?
He did say sorry. Why do you think he said sorry?

(Thinking, tapping a finger on the desk) Because… (hesitates, searching for the right words) …because he realized his… his scheme… didn’t… (grimaces, struggling with the word) …didn’t *work*? (Looks at the teacher, hoping that was the right word.) And… and maybe… (voice softer) …maybe he felt a little bit… remorseful? (Frowns, unsure if I used that word correctly.)

"Scheme" and "remorseful" are great words! You're doing so well!

Yes, he realized his trick didn't work. So, what do you think this story teaches us? What's the lesson?

(Starts to bite my nails, then quickly pulls my hand away) Um… (Looks around the room, then back at the teacher) It… it teaches us that… that being… duplicitous… (eyes widen, realizing I used another complex word) …is bad? (Looks down, tracing patterns on the desk with my finger) And that… being fair… is important. (Voice barely a whisper) And… and that even if you *think* you're clever… you might still… get caught? (Shrugs, looking at the teacher with big, uncertain eyes.)

You are so clever! It teaches us that trying to cheat or trick people doesn't work out in the end. Being fair and honest is always the best way. Cheating will get you nowhere.

Do you understand the story now? <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends."

Now, can you tell me, at the beginning of the story, how did the elephant feel?

(Fidgets with my hands, looks down at my shoes) Uh... (hesitates) ... sad? (Looks up quickly, then down again) He... he wanted friends, but... but nobody wanted to play with him. (Thinking) Because he was... different?
That's right! He felt sad. And why didn't the other animals want to be his friend at first? What did the monkey say?

(Eyes widen slightly) The monkey... (thinking, bites lip)... he said the elephant couldn't swing! (Looks at the teacher expectantly) And the... (Stuttering) ra-ra-rabbit... said he was too big for the burrow? (Looks away, nervous) It wasn't very nice. Why did they say that? (Looks back at the teacher, a little confused)

You're doing great! Yes, the monkey said he couldn't swing, and the rabbit said he was too big.

Do you think those were good reasons to not be someone's friend?

(Thinks hard, furrowing my brow) ...No. (Confidently) Because... (looks down, fiddles with a button on my shirt)... being a friend is about... (struggling to find the right words) ...like, liking someone for who they are? Even if they can't... (pauses) Even if they can't swing or fit in a burrow? (Looks up, a little anxious) Is that right?

That's a really good way to put it! You're exactly right.

So, what happened the next day in the forest? Do you remember?

(Eyes widen, a little nervous) Oh! Oh! (excitedly) The tiger! (Quickly becomes anxious again) Uh... the other animals were running! (Fidgets) Because the tiger was... was being mean? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation)
Yes, the tiger was being mean. And what did the elephant do?

(Takes a deep breath, remembering the story) The elephant... (pauses, thinking)... he stopped the tiger! (Slightly more confident) He asked him to stop, but the tiger didn't listen. So... (voice trails off, hesitant) ...so he kicked him? (Looks at the teacher, worried) Was that... was that okay?
Well, the tiger wasn't being very nice to the other animals. But what's important is, what happened *after* the elephant helped? How did the other animals feel about the elephant then?

(Eyes light up, understanding) Oh! Oh! (Speaking quickly) They... they liked him! They wanted to be his friend! (Pauses, thinking deeply) Because... because he helped them? (Looks at the teacher with a questioning look) Did they finally see he was a good friend, even if he couldn't swing or fit in a burrow? (A little proud of figuring it out)

Yes! That's exactly right! They finally saw that he could be a good friend even though he was different.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us about friends?

(Thinking hard, tapping a finger on my desk) Uh... (pauses, looking at the ceiling) ...maybe... maybe it's about... (struggling) ...accepting people even if they're different? (Looks back at the teacher, a little anxious) And... and that being a good friend means helping others? (A flicker of insight in my eyes) Is... is it about not judging people by what they *can't* do, but by what they *can* do? (Looks hopeful)

You got it! It's about accepting others even if they are different. Friends can be all shapes and sizes, and being a good friend is about helping each other. The animals learned that the elephant was a great friend even though he was big and couldn't swing in trees or fit in burrows. They learned that what matters most is being kind and helpful.

So, what's the big idea, the message, or the moral of the story?

(Thinking very carefully, chewing on my lip) ...So, the message is... (long pause, looks down at my hands)... don't... don't be like the monkey, the rabbit, and the frog at the beginning? (Looks up, hesitantly) ...Be... be open to being friends with anyone, even if they're different? (A small smile) Because... because everyone has something special to offer? (Quietly) Even elephants.

That's perfect! You understood the story so well. The message is that friends can be any shape or size. It's about looking past differences and seeing the good in everyone. You did a great job! <finish>

dialogue: Okay! That was a good story, right? Now, tell me in your own words, what was the girl feeling at the beginning of the story?
(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands) Uh... she... she was... um... (stuttering) like... not happy? She... she told her dad she was... frustrated. (Looks up quickly, then back down)
That's right! She wasn't happy, she was frustrated. Can you remember why she was frustrated? What was making her feel that way?

(Thinking hard, furrowing my brow) Uh... (pauses) Was it... because things were... hard? Like... (using big words I learned) a big *problem* was happening to her? (Looks up at the teacher, hoping I got it right)
Yes! Things were hard for her. It sounds like she was facing some difficult problems. Now, what did her dad ask her to bring him? Three things! Can you remember them?

(Eyes widen a little, trying to remember) Okay... okay... um... (counting on my fingers silently) Potato! (Confidently) And... egg! (Hesitates) And... uh... were they... like... spices? (Looks confused) Or... or... flowers? (Looks down, nervous I got it wrong) Uh...
Almost! Not spices or flowers. Think... what do grown-ups sometimes put in hot water to make a drink?
(Eyes light up) Ooooh! (Confidently) Tea! Tea leaves! Like for tea? (Beams, proud of myself)
Yes! Tea leaves! Great job remembering. Now, what did her dad do with the potato, the egg, and the tea leaves? He put them in something. What was it?

(Thinking, tapping my chin) He... he put them in... (searching for the right word) ...vessels! With... (pauses) ...hot water? (Looks up, questioning) Was it boiling? It felt really important that the water was hot...
Yes! He put them in separate vessels with boiling water. Good job remembering that the water was boiling – that's important! Now, what happened to the potato after it was in the hot water?

(Thinking, trying to remember the details) The potato... (pauses) it got... (searching for the right word again) ...squishy? (Looks up at the teacher, unsure) It wasn't hard anymore. It was... (hesitates) ...softer? (Looks down, anxious about being wrong.)
Softer is perfect! The hard potato became soft. And what about the egg? What happened to the soft egg?
(Thinking, concentrating) The egg... (pauses) ...got hard? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation) Like... the opposite of the potato! (Seems a bit more confident)
Exactly! The soft egg became hard. And finally, what happened to the tea leaves? Did they become hard or soft?
(Thinking really hard, biting my lip a little) Hmm... They... they didn't get hard or soft... (Eyes widen slightly) They... they changed the water! (Looks up, excited) The water became... tea!

Okay, wonderful! You've read "The Needle Tree." That's a great story!

Now, tell me in your own words, what was the story about? What happened first?

(Fidgets with my hands, looks down at my shoes) Uh... (clears throat) The story... it's about... brothers. (Looks up quickly, then down again) One... was mean.

He... (thinking) ...he went to the forest... to cut wood. And... (eyes widen slightly) he found a magic tree! (Looks at the teacher with a hopeful expression)

Yes! You're doing great! One brother was mean, and he went to the forest and found a magic tree.

What did the magic tree *do*? What did it say to the mean brother?

(Bites lip, thinking hard) The tree... (stutters) Th-the tree didn't want to be chopped down! (Looks at the teacher, worried) Uh... it said... it said it would give him... golden apples! (Looks down again, tracing patterns on the floor with my shoe)

That's right! The tree didn't want to be chopped down, so it offered golden apples.

Did the brother like the golden apples? Was he happy with them?
(Shakes head slowly) No... (Looks up, a little frown on my face) He... he wanted more! (Looks away, fiddling with the corner of my shirt) He was... greedy. (Whispers) I think.

"Greedy" is a great word to use there! He *was* greedy.

What happened when he tried to cut the tree down anyway? What did the tree do then?

(Gasps quietly, eyes widening) The tree... (hesitates) ...it didn't give him more apples. (Looks at the teacher, voice barely above a whisper) It gave him... needles! (Shudders slightly, looking anxious) Lots and lots of needles!

Yes, lots and lots of needles! Ouch!

What happened after he was covered in needles? What did the *other* brother do?

(Looks relieved to talk about the other brother) The other brother... (thinking) He... he found him! (Looks at the teacher, a small smile on my face) He helped him! He took out all the needles! (Becomes anxious again) It... it must have hurt a lot!

It *must* have hurt a lot! You're right.

And how did the mean brother feel *after* his younger brother helped him? Did he stay mean?

(Looks down, scuffing shoes on the floor) He... he said sorry. (Looks up, a little surprised at myself for saying it) He said sorry for being... mean. (Frowns slightly) I think he felt... bad. (Chews on lip)

He did feel bad! He apologized.

And what happened with the tree *after* the older brother apologized? What did the tree do *then*?

(Eyes widen, a spark of excitement) The tree... (pauses, searching for the word) It... it saw! It saw he was sorry! (Looks at the teacher, a little more confidently) And... and it gave them... more golden apples! (Beams, then quickly looks down again, suddenly shy)

That's right! It saw he was sorry and it gave them more golden apples.

So, think about the whole story. Why did the tree give the first brother needles? And why did it give them *both* golden apples in the end? What lesson does this story teach us about how we should treat each other?

(Puts a hand to my chin, thinking very hard. Frowns, concentrating) Uh... the tree gave needles because... because he was greedy and... and mean! (Looks up, then down again) And... and it gave apples in the end because... (Stutters) ...because the mean brother said sorry and... and the other brother was... (Searches for the word) ...kind!

(Looks at the teacher, nervously) So... so we should be kind and... and not greedy? (Voice is small and hesitant) Is that... is that right?

That's *exactly* right! You got it! The tree gave needles because of the older brother's greed and meanness. And it gave apples in the end because the younger brother was kind, and the older brother learned to be sorry.

So, what's the big idea of the story? What's the *moral*? What does the story teach us about kindness?

(Takes a deep breath, trying to sound braver) The... (pauses, thinking) The story... teaches us that... (Looks up, making eye contact briefly) ...being kind is good! (Fidgets with hands) And... and being greedy is... bad. (Looks down again, a little smile playing on lips) And... and even if you're mean, you can... you can still say sorry. (Whispers) And... and maybe get golden apples.

Yes! That's perfect! Being kind is good, being greedy is bad, and even if you make a mistake, you can say sorry. And kindness... gets rewarded!

So, we can say the moral of the story is: Kindness will always be rewarded. You understood the story so well! You explained it all perfectly. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was the story of "The Fox and the Grapes."

First, can you tell me, what was the fox looking for?
(Smiling politely and looking at the teacher) Food! He... he was looking for food. (pauses, thinking) He was hungry.
Yes! You're right, he was hungry. Where did he find the grapes?
(Thinking, looking up at the ceiling) Uh... (hesitates) ...on a wall? A farmer's wall, I think. The story said it was a farmer's wall. (Nods confidently)
Excellent! He found them on a farmer's wall. What did the fox do to try and get the grapes?
(Eyes widen slightly, thinking hard) He... he jumped! (Confidently) He jumped really high! He kept jumping, but... but he couldn't reach.
That's right! He jumped and jumped. Did he get the grapes?
(Shakes head slowly) No... He didn't. (Looks down at hands) He couldn't get them.
He couldn't get them. What did the fox say after he couldn't reach the grapes?

(Thinking, furrowing brow) He... he said... (pauses) The grapes were... sour! (Looks up at the teacher, a question in my eyes) He said they were sour anyway. Does... does that mean he didn't really want them?
That's a very good question! Why do you think he said they were sour? He wanted them at first, right?

(Nods enthusiastically) Yes! He wanted them because he was hungry and they looked juicy. (Thinking hard) But... (hesitates) ...if he said they were sour, maybe... maybe he was trying to feel better? (Looks at the teacher, hopeful) Like, if he couldn't have them, he didn't want them anyway?

You're getting very close! Yes, he was trying to feel better. He was disappointed he couldn't get the grapes.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? Is it just about a fox and some grapes?

(Thinking deeply, tapping a finger on the desk) No... (Looks up, a little hesitant) It's... it's about something else, isn't it? It's about... when you can't get something you want, you... you pretend you didn't want it anyway? (Confidently) Like... like if I wanted a really cool toy, but I couldn't have it, I might say it's broken, so I don't feel so sad? Is that it?
Yes! You got it. And is that a good thing to do? To pretend you don't want something just because you can't have it?

(Shakes head slowly, thoughtfully) Uh... no. (Thinking) I don't think so. (Looks at the teacher) Because... because then you're not being honest? And... and you're still sad inside, even if you don't say it. Is... is that right?

That's exactly right! It's better to try your best and if you still can't get it, that's okay.

So, a good lesson from this story is: things aren't always easy to get. And it's not good to pretend you don't want something just because you can't have it.

Do you think you understand the story and what it teaches us now?

(Nods enthusiastically, smiling) Yes! (Confidently) I understand! It's about... (pauses, making sure to remember) ...being honest about what you want and not saying you don't want something just because you can't get it. (Asks a question) Is it also about trying really hard before giving up?

Yes, that's a very good point! It's definitely about trying your best. And it's okay if you don't succeed, but you should try!

You've really understood the story well. I think you've got it! <finish>

dialogue: Okay, great job reading the story, class! That was "The Proud Rose". Now, can you tell me, who are the two main characters in the story?

Exactly! The other plants tried to help the cactus.

That's right, no water. And what happened to the rose because there was no water?

Yes, she started to wither! Good remembering! Now, what was the cactus doing while the rose was withering? What did the cactus have?
(Eyes widen slightly, remembering) The cactus... (pauses, thinking)... the cactus had water! For the... for the sparrows.
Excellent! The cactus shared its water with the sparrows. And what did the rose want when she started to wither?

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of Molly the Milkmaid! That was a fun story, wasn't it?

First, tell me, what was Molly going to do with the milk?
(Smiling politely) Yes, it was a good story! Uh… (hesitates) she was going to… sell it. At the market! (looks down, then back up confidently)

Excellent! That's right. She was going to sell it at the market.

Now, what did Molly start thinking about while she was walking to the market?
(Eyes widen, thinking) She was… (pauses) thinking about what she could BUY! (nods head excitedly) With the money from the milk!
Exactly! She was thinking about what she could buy. What was the first thing she thought about buying?
(Thinking hard, furrowing brow) Hmmm… (pauses, then brightens) A chicken! (nods confidently) So she could get eggs! (looks up at the teacher expectantly)
Yes, a chicken! And why did she want a chicken? What did she hope to get from it?
(Thinking, tapping finger on desk) Because… chickens… lay eggs! (eyes light up) And she could sell the eggs… and then have even MORE money! (looks pleased with herself)
Wonderful! You got it. So she had the milk money, and THEN egg money! What happened while she was imagining all of this? What did she do?
(Looks down, a little embarrassed) She… she was skipping! (shrugs shoulders) And… and the milk… (voice trails off) it spilled. (looks up at the teacher with a slightly worried expression) All of it.
Yes, the milk spilled. Oh no! How did that make her feel, do you think?
(Thinks for a moment) Sad? (tilts head) Because she had no milk to sell. (pauses) And… no money to buy the chicken. (frowns slightly)
Yes, very sad. So, she lost the milk and the chance to buy a chicken. What did her mother tell her when she got home?

(Concentrates, then smiles slightly) Her mother said… something about chickens… (pauses) Don't… count… your chickens… (eyes widen in understanding) until they hatch! (nods head proudly) I know that one!
You do! That's great! What do you think that means in the story? What was Molly counting on before it happened?

(Thinking hard, using logic) Well… she was counting on getting money from the milk… and THEN getting money from the eggs… (pauses) But she didn't HAVE the chicken yet! (eyes widen) So she was… counting her money… before she even HAD it! (looks at the teacher for confirmation) Is that right?

That's exactly right! She was counting on things that hadn't happened yet.

So, what do you think is the lesson of the story? What does the story teach us? It's okay if you need a little help!

(Thinking, looking thoughtful) Hmmm… (pauses, then looks up) Does it mean… don't get too excited… before things really happen? (asks a question, seeking affirmation) And… (hesitates) … maybe don't plan too much… before you ARE sure you can do it? (looks at the teacher expectantly)

That's a fantastic way to put it! You're absolutely right. It's about not being too sure about things before they actually happen.

So we can say: Don't depend on something until you are sure it will happen.

You understood the story and its meaning so well! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "A Wise Old Owl."

So, can you tell me, what did the owl do every day?
(Looks down, thinking) Uh... he... he watched things? (Hesitates) Happening... near his tree? (Looks up quickly, then back down)

Yes, that's right! He watched things happening near his tree. Good job!

And what else did he do? Did he just watch?
(Thinking hard, tapping foot) Uh... and he... (stutters) h-heard people... talking? (Looks at teacher, hopeful)

Yes! He heard people talking. So, the owl watched things and he heard things.

Did the story say the owl talked a lot?
(Shakes head slowly) ...No. (Looks away) He... spoke... less.

You're exactly right! He spoke less. The more he saw and heard, the less he spoke.

Why do you think he spoke less?
(Thinking, furrowing brow) ...Because... he was... getting... wiser? (Looks at teacher with a questioning look)

Yes! You're getting it! The story says he became wiser day by day.

Do you think watching and listening helped him become wiser? Why?

(Nods slowly, looks down at hands) ...Uh... because he... learned... things? (Looks up, a little more confidently) When he... heard stories... and saw... what happened... he... understood... more? I think so... (Looks away again)

That's a really good answer! He learned things by watching and listening.

So, if he learned things by watching and listening, and that made him wiser, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? Maybe about talking and listening?

(Thinking hard, biting lip) ...Uh... maybe... (pauses) ...maybe we should... listen more... than we talk? (Looks at teacher, a little surprised by own answer) ...So we can... learn things... and be wiser... too? (Fidgets with fingers) Is that right?

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Golden Egg! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it?

Let's talk about it. What kind of animal laid the golden egg?

(Nods slowly, looking at the teacher with wide eyes)

Uh... a... a goose? (hesitates, looks down at my hands)
That's right! A goose. And what was special about the eggs it laid?

(Thinking hard, furrowing my brow)

They... they were... (pauses, bites lip) ... golden? Like, made of real gold?
Yes! Golden eggs! And what did the farmer do with those golden eggs?

(Looks up, a little more confidently)

He... (pauses) He sold them! (nods, pleased with myself) So he could get... (pauses again, thinking) ... money!
Exactly! He sold them to get money. And how did the farmer and his wife live when the goose laid golden eggs? Were they happy?

(Thinking, looks up at the ceiling for a moment)

They were... comfortable? (tilts head, unsure) They had... enough? Was it because they sold the eggs? (looks at the teacher, questioningly)

Yes, you're exactly right! They were comfortable because they sold the eggs. They had enough.

But then, what did the farmer start to think? Did he stay happy with one egg a day?

(Frowns a little, remembering the story)

No... (shakes head slowly) He... he wanted more! (pauses) He was... greedy? Is that a big word? (looks at the teacher with a questioning expression)
"Greedy" is a good word! It means wanting more and more, even if you already have enough. So, the farmer was greedy. What did he *do* because he was greedy? This is the really important part!

(Looks down at my hands again, picking at my fingernails, thinking very hard)

He... (pauses, then looks up with wide eyes) ... He cut open the goose! (voice gets smaller) ...to get all the eggs at once? (stuttering) B-But there weren't any!
That's right. He cut open the goose. Was that a good idea? What happened after that?

(Shakes head vigorously, looking a bit sad)

No! (pauses) It was a bad idea! (thinking) Because... because the goose was gone! (looks up, worried) And there were no more golden eggs. (pauses) So... they became poor? Was that because they were greedy?

Yes, that's right! They became poor because the goose was gone and there were no more golden eggs to sell.

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big lesson it teaches us? Why was cutting open the goose a bad idea?

(Thinking really hard, chewing on my lip)

Exactly! And could he get water from the well? What happened?

(Thinks, looks up) He… he said… the neighbor had to pay… rent? …For the water? Or… or take it all out!

Exactly! He had to say sorry and go home with nothing. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Thinks, looks down, then looks up with a sparkle in his eye) Hmmm… (Uses complex words) …That… it's wrong to be… deceitful? And… (Thinking, using more strategies) …that… being honest is… better in the long run? Because… (Hesitates) …uh… you won't get caught!

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends."

First, can you tell me, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?
(Thinking, chewing on my lip) Uh... he was... (looks away) ...lonely? Because... (pauses) ...nobody wanted to be his friend.
You got it! He was lonely. Why didn't the monkey want to be his friend?
(Thinking hard, furrowing my brow) Because... the elephant... couldn't... (hesitates) ...swing... in the trees? (Looks at the teacher hopefully, awaiting confirmation)
Yes! That's right! The monkey said he couldn't swing in the trees. What about the rabbit? Why didn't the rabbit want to be friends?
(Nods, remembering) The rabbit... (pauses, using fingers to count) ...the rabbit... said he was too... (searches for the right word) ...big! To fit in the burrow! (Confidently)
Excellent! He was too big. So, how did the elephant probably feel after all the animals said no?

(Looks down at my hands, fiddling with my fingers) ...Sad? (Quietly) Because... everyone said no. (Pauses) Was he... was he going to find any friends? (Looks up at the teacher with a worried expression)
It must have been very sad for him. But then, something happened the next day, right? What happened in the forest?
(Eyes widen, remembering the exciting part) Uh... everyone was running! (Voice gets a little louder) Because... (pauses, searching for the word) ...the tiger! Was... attacking them!
Yes! The tiger was attacking. What did the elephant do?
(Confidently) He... (pauses to think) ...he stopped the tiger! (Smiling slightly) He... kicked him! And scared him away! (Looks at the teacher proudly)
That's right! He scared the tiger away. What happened *after* the elephant scared the tiger away? How did the other animals feel about the elephant *then*?
(Thinking, tapping my chin) They... they realized... (struggling to find the right words) ...that the elephant... was perfect! (Smiling brightly) To be their friend! Because he helped them!

Exactly! They thought he was perfect to be their friend *because* he helped them. So, at the beginning, the monkey, rabbit and frog didn't want to be his friend because he was too big, couldn't swing and couldn't jump. But at the end, did they still care about those things?

(Thinks for a moment, furrowing my brow) Uh... no? (Looks up at the teacher for confirmation) Because... he saved them... from the tiger? So... it didn't matter... that he was big... and couldn't swing?
You got it! It didn't matter. So, what do you think this story is trying to tell us about friends? Can friends only be a certain size, or be good at the same things?

(Thinking deeply, using complex words) I... (pauses, looks away) ...I think... the story shows... that friends don't have to be... homogenous? (Looks at the teacher, unsure if I used the word correctly) It means... (hesitates) ...the same? Friends can be different... and still help each other. (Looks back at the teacher hopefully)

Wow! "Homogenous" is a big word! But yes, you're exactly right! Friends don't have to be the same. They can be different sizes, and good at different things. The elephant was a great friend even though he was big and couldn't swing or hop.

So, what is the story telling us? Think about the elephant and the other animals.

(Nods slowly, thinking) Uh... (pauses) ...maybe... (looks up, a little more confident) ...maybe it's telling us... to not judge people... by how they look? Or what they can't do? (Thinking harder) But... by what they *can* do... and if they are... kind?

That's a *fantastic* way to put it! You're absolutely right. Don't judge people by how they look, or what they *can't* do, but by what they *can* do, and if they are kind.

So, what is the moral of the story?

(Smiling, confident now) The... the moral is... (pauses, organizing my thoughts) ...that everyone has something... important to offer? Even if they are different? And... (pauses) ...that being kind... and helpful... is more important... than being good at swinging... or fitting in a burrow! (Beams at the teacher)

Yes! That's a perfect way to put it! Everyone has something important to offer, even if they are different, and being kind and helpful is more important than being good at swinging or fitting in a burrow. Great job! You really understood the story! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, you've just read "The Needle Tree"! That was a good story, wasn't it?

First, can you tell me who the story is about?
Uh... (hesitates, looks down at my hands) It's about... two brothers. (looks up quickly, then back down) And... and a tree. A magic... magical tree.

That's right! Two brothers and a magical tree. Good job!

Can you tell me about the *older* brother? What was he like?
(Thinking hard, furrowing my brow) Hmmm... He... (pauses, looks at the teacher with wide eyes) He wasn't... very nice. (confidently) He was mean! To his little brother. (nods, pleased with myself)
You got it! He *was* mean. What did he *do* that was mean?

(Thinking, tapping my finger on the desk) He... (looks up, searching for the right word) He... treated him... badly. (more confidently) He chopped wood and... and didn't share maybe? (tilts head, questioning) And he yelled? I think? (frowns, trying to remember)

"Treated him badly" is a great way to say it! He didn't treat his brother kindly.

Now, what happened when the older brother met the tree in the forest?

(Eyes widen, remembering) The tree... (pauses, searching for the word) Begged! (nods) Begged him not to... not to chop it down. (looks up at the teacher, questioningly) And... and gave him... golden... golden apples! (brightens)
Excellent! The tree gave him golden apples. Was the older brother happy with the apples?

(Shakes head firmly, confidently) No! (pauses, thinking) He wanted... (searches for the word) More! (frowns, dissatisfied) He was... (thinking) un... ungrateful! (nods, pleased with finding the right word)
"Ungrateful" is a *perfect* word! He was ungrateful. What happened when he tried to cut the tree down *anyway*?

(Eyes widen, leaning forward slightly) The tree... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...rained... needles! (grimaces) Ouch! A lot of needles. (thinking, carefully) Because he was greedy. (nods, understanding)
That's right! The tree rained needles. And what happened *after* the needles? Who helped him?
(Brightens, remembering) The little brother! (smiles) He... (thinking, carefully choosing words) He took... took the needles out. Carefully. (nods) He was... kind! (beams)
He *was* very kind! And how did the older brother feel *after* his little brother helped him?
(Looks down, thoughtful) He... he said sorry. (looks up, more confidently) He apologized! (nods) Because... because his little brother was... good. (smiles shyly)
He did apologize! That's very important. And what happened with the tree *after* the older brother apologized?

(Eyes widen, remembering the happy ending) The tree... (pauses, thinking) Gave them... more apples! (smiles brightly) Because... (searching for the word) ...he was... sorry? And... and good now? (looks at the teacher, questioningly)

You're getting it! The tree gave them more apples because the older brother said he was sorry and was trying to be good.

So, what does this story teach us? What's the big idea of the story? If you are kind, what happens?

(Thinking hard, tapping chin) Uh... (pauses, looks up at the ceiling) It... it teaches us to be... nice? (looks back at the teacher, uncertain) And not... not greedy! (nods firmly) And if you are kind... (thinking, carefully) ...good things... happen? (tilts head, questioning) And... and you should say sorry if you're mean. (nods, satisfied)

You're *so* close! You said if you are kind, good things happen. The story shows that kindness is rewarded.

So, a short way to say the big idea of the story is: Kindness will always be rewarded.

Can you say that?
(Looks at the teacher, carefully repeating) Kindness... will... always... be... rewarded. (nods slowly, understanding) Like the little brother! (smiles, pleased)
Exactly like the little brother! You understood the story and its message perfectly. Well done! <finish>

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of King Midas! You just read it, so tell me, who was King Midas?
(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands) Uh... a king? (Stuttering) He... he helped someone.
That's right! He was a king, and he helped someone. Who did he help? Try to remember!
(Thinking hard, biting my lip) A... a... Satyr? (Looks up quickly, then down again)
Yes! A Satyr! Good job remembering. And because he helped the Satyr, who wanted to give him a gift?
(Smiling) The wine guy! You mean Dionysus, the god of wine. That's right! And what did Dionysus offer King Midas?
(Quietly) A wish... (Looks at the teacher briefly, then back down at my hands)
A wish! And what did King Midas wish for? This is the most important part!
(Swallowing hard) Everything... (Long pause) Everything he touched... turn to... gold? (Looks up with wide, anxious eyes)
Yes! Everything he touched would turn to gold. Was Dionysus happy about this wish?
(Shakes head slowly, eyes wide) No... he... he warned him. (Frowns slightly)
He did! He warned him. Why do you think Dionysus warned him? What happened after everything Midas touched turned to gold?
(Looks down, tracing a pattern on the desk with a finger) He... he got hungry. And... and his daughter... (Voice cracks)
Yes, he got hungry, and his daughter... what happened when he touched his food?
(Whispers) It turned to gold... (Tears welling up, looks away, sniffling)
It did. And what happened when his daughter hugged him?
(Voice trembling) She... she turned to gold too... (Starts to cry softly) I... I don't like this story.
(Kneels down beside the student, speaking gently) I know, it's a sad story. It's okay to feel sad. But it's important to understand why these things happened. Why couldn't King Midas eat?
(Wipes eyes with sleeve) 'Cause... 'cause the food... was gold. And you can't... you can't eat gold. (Sniffles) It's hard.
Exactly! You can't eat gold. And why did his daughter turn to gold?
(Looks at the teacher, bottom lip trembling) Because... because he touched her... and everything he touched... turned to gold. (Whispers) Even his daughter...
Right. So, at the beginning, did King Midas think the golden touch was a good thing or a bad thing?
(Thinking, frowns) Good... he was happy... at first. (Looks down, sniffling)
He was happy at first. But what did he think about it *after* he couldn't eat and after his daughter turned to gold?
(Shakes head, tears still in eyes) Bad... it was bad. (Looks up at the teacher, pleadingly) He didn't want it anymore!
He didn't want it anymore. So, tell me, why did all those bad things happen to King Midas? Why did he get the golden touch in the first place? What made him wish for that?
(Thinking hard, forehead furrowed) He... he wanted... more. (Looks down) More gold? (Whispers) Was that greedy?
Yes! He wanted more gold. He was being greedy. And what happened because he was greedy?
(Tears welling up again) He... he lost his food... and his daughter... (Sniffles) He was sad. (Looks at teacher) What does 'greedy' mean?

Greedy means wanting too much. Wanting more than you need, and not being happy with what you have. King Midas already had a lot, but he wanted *more* gold. And because he was greedy, he lost things that were much more important than gold. So what do you think this story is trying to teach us?
(Sniffles, looks down, tracing patterns on the desk again) That... that you shouldn't... shouldn't want too much? (Looks up, hesitantly) That... that being greedy is bad?
Yes! Being greedy is bad. It can make you lose the things that are truly important. So, what is the lesson we learn from the story of King Midas? Try to say it in your own words.

(Long pause, thinking hard, wipes nose with sleeve) Um... (Hesitates) That... that you should be happy... with what you have? (Looks at the teacher with hopeful eyes) And... and don't be greedy, or you'll... you'll lose the things... you love? (Voice trails off, looking anxious)

That's it! You got it! The story of King Midas teaches us that being greedy can lead to losing the things that are truly important. It's better to be happy with what you have. You understood the story really well! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about the fox.

Why was the fox looking around?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my fingers)

Uh... he... (stuttering) ...he was... looking for... food.
That's right! He was hungry. And what did he find?

(Thinking hard, eyes wide)

...Grapes? (Looks at you hopefully)
Yes! Big, purple, juicy grapes! Where were the grapes?
Almost! It was a farmer's wall. And could the fox reach the grapes?
Right. He jumped and jumped, but he couldn't get them. What did the fox do then?

(Bites lip, hesitates)

...He... he went home. (Looks down at my shoes)
He did go home. But what did he say about the grapes before he left? This is important!

(Thinking really hard, furrowing brow. Starts to tear up a little)

...Um... (long pause)... I don't... I don't know. (Sniffles)
It's okay! Don't worry. The story says he thought the grapes were sour. Do you remember that part?

(Wipes eyes quickly with the back of my hand, nods slowly)

...Yes... Sour... (whispers)
Why do you think the fox said they were sour? Were they *really* sour?

(Shrugs shoulders, looks confused)

...I... I don't think so. They were... purple and juicy. (Thinking) ...Maybe... maybe he was sad he couldn't reach them?
That's a great idea! He was probably sad. So, he couldn't get the grapes, and then he said they were sour. Do you think that was a good thing to say?

(Looks at you with wide, anxious eyes)

...No? (Voice trembling slightly) Is it... is it bad?
Why do you think it might be bad? Think about it. He wanted the grapes, but he couldn't get them. Then he said they were sour. Why?

(Stares at my hands, picking at a loose thread on my shirt. Voice very quiet)

...Because... he didn't want to... feel bad? (Looks up quickly, then back down)
Exactly! He didn't want to feel bad. Saying they were sour made him feel a little better about not getting them. But do you think that's really true? Were the grapes really sour?

(Shakes head slowly)

...No... They were... probably good. (Sniffles)
Right! So, what does this story tell us? What did the fox learn, even if he didn't know it? What does this story teach *us*? It's okay if you don't know right away.

(Bites lip again, looks like I'm about to cry. Voice shaky)

...Uh... (long pause)... Don't... don't say things... that aren't true... just because... you're sad? (Looks at you, hoping for reassurance)

That's a part of it! Yes! Don't say things that aren't true just because you're sad. It's better to try your best. And sometimes, things are hard to get. What if the story is telling us something about that? What if it is telling us that it is important to not get angry just because you can't get something?

(Thinking hard, eyes focused on the floor)

...So... so it's okay... to be sad... if you can't get something... but don't... don't lie about it? And don't get angry? (Looks up, a little less anxious)

Yes! It's okay to be sad or disappointed. But the fox tried to make himself feel better by saying the grapes were sour. The story wants us to understand that its important to work hard for things that you want. And that if you can't get them after trying really hard, it is okay, but don't try to act as if those things were bad anyway.<finish>
