dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story, everyone! That was "The Proud Rose". Now, let's talk about it.

First, can you tell me, who are the two main characters in the story?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands)

Uh… (pauses) the… the rose… and the cactus?

Yes! That's right. The rose and the cactus.

Now, tell me, what did the rose think about the cactus? Was she nice?

(Hesitates, looks at the teacher briefly, then back down)

No… (stuttering) She… she wasn’t… nice. (Looks away) She… didn't like the cactus.

You're right. She wasn't nice.

Why didn't the rose like the cactus? What did the story say?

(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip)

(Quietly) …Because… she was… pretty? And the… cactus… wasn’t? (Looks up at the teacher with a worried expression)

Good remembering! The rose thought she was prettier.

So, what did the rose DO because she thought she was prettier? Was she friendly to the cactus?

(Shakes head slowly, still looking down)

…No… She… (pauses, whispers) she said… mean things. (Looks up quickly, then back down again, fiddling with a button on my shirt)

Yes, she did say mean things. The story said she insulted the cactus.

Now, what happened when it got really, really hot and there was no water? What happened to the rose?

(Eyes widen slightly, remembering the story)

She… she got… (Stuttering) th-thirsty? And… and she started to… to… wither? (Looks at the teacher with a slightly anxious expression)

Yes! She got thirsty and started to wither. Good job remembering that word, "wither"!

And what about the cactus? Was it withering? What was the cactus doing?

(Thinking, furrowing my brow)

…Uh… (pauses) The cactus… (looks up, confused) …it had… water? For… the birds? (Voice trails off, questioning)
Yes! The cactus had water for the birds. Where did the cactus get the water?

(Looks down, trying to remember. Frowns.)

…Uh… I don’t… I don’t know. (Shrugs slightly, voice quiet.)

That's okay! The story doesn't say exactly *how* the cactus got water, but it did have it.

So, the rose is thirsty and withering, and the cactus has water. What did the rose do then?

(Looks up, biting my lip nervously)

…Did she… ask the cactus… for water? (Whispers the question)
Yes! She did! And what happened when she asked? What did the cactus do?

(Eyes widen a little, remembering)

The… the cactus… (pauses, looks at the teacher with a hopeful expression) …gave her… water? (Voice is soft and questioning)

That's right! The cactus gave her water. Even after the rose was mean!

Now, thinking about the whole story, the rose and the cactus... What do you think this story is trying to teach us? Is it good to be mean to people who look different from you?

(Looks down, scuffing my shoe on the floor)

…No… (pauses, thinking) …It’s… not nice to be… mean. (Looks up at the teacher briefly, then down again) …Even if… they’re different. (Whispers) And… and the cactus… was nice even though… the rose wasn't.

That's a very good point! The cactus was nice even when the rose wasn't.

dialogue:
Okay! Hi there! That was a good reading! Now, let's talk about the story.

First, who was the main person in our story?
(Looks down at my hands, fiddling with my fingers) Uh... Molly? (Hesitates) The... the milkmaid?
Yes! Molly the milkmaid! What was Molly going to do with the milk?
(Thinking, biting my lip) She... she was going to sell it. At the... the market. (Looks at the teacher briefly, then back down)
Good job! She was going to sell it at the market. And what did she *start* thinking about while she walked?
(Shuffles feet) ... Things... (pauses) ...to buy? With the...money? (Looks up, nervously)
Yes! Things to buy with the money! What was the first thing she thought about buying?
(Thinking hard) A... (Stuttering) a... chicken? (Looks at the teacher, anxious for confirmation)
A chicken! That's right! And why did she want a chicken?
(Frowning, concentrating)... To...get more money? (Voice is quiet) Because... eggs? (Looks away, uncertain)
Because of the eggs! Exactly! She wanted to sell the eggs and get even *more* money. What happened *while* she was thinking about all of this?
(Eyes widen slightly, remembering) ...Uh... The milk... (pauses, voice barely audible) ...it spilled? (Looks down, ashamed)
The milk spilled! Oh no! Why did it spill? Do you remember?
(Shakes head slightly, still looking down) ...Skipping? (Whispers) She was... skipping?
Yes! She was skipping because she was so excited! What happened *after* the milk spilled?
(Sighs softly) ...Went home... (Pauses) Empty... Pails. (Looks up, sadly) No money.
That's right. She went home with empty pails and no money. How do you think Molly felt?
(Frowns, chewing on lip) ...Sad? (Pauses) ...Maybe... Mad? (Looks at the teacher, a little unsure)
Sad and maybe a little mad, that's a good way to describe it! What did her mother say to her?
(Thinking, concentrating very hard)...(voice low) Something... about... chickens? (Looks up, hoping for help) I... I don't remember all the words.
That's okay! Her mother said, "Don't count your chickens until they hatch." What do you think that means? It's okay if you don't know for sure! Maybe think about the story.

(Frowns, looking at the floor, thinking deeply) ...Don't... think you have something... before you really... have it? (Voice is quiet, hesitant) Like... Molly thought she had... chicken money... but she didn't... really? (Looks up, nervously) Is that right?

That's a *fantastic* way to say it! You're exactly right. Molly thought she had chicken money before she even *had* the chicken, or the eggs!

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Looks down again, fiddling with hands. Voice is very small) ...Don't... be too... greedy? (Pauses, unsure) Or... (Long pause) ...don't... plan too much... before... it happens? (Looks up, quickly, then back down) ...I don't know.

You're on the right track! It's not really about being greedy, but more about being sure of things. The story teaches us to not depend on something until you are sure it will happen.

Do you think Molly learned her lesson?
(Nods slowly) ...Uh huh... (Looks up, briefly) ...Maybe... next time... she'll be more careful? (Looks down again, hopefully)
I think so too! I think next time, Molly will wait until she *actually* has the money before she starts planning what to buy. You did a really great job explaining the story! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story about the wise old owl!

Now, can you tell me, what did the owl like to do every day? What did he watch?
(Looks down at my shoes, fiddling with my shoelaces) Uh... (pauses) ...he watched... things... around the tree. (Sticks to simple words)

That's right! He watched things around the tree. Good job!

What kind of things did he see happening around the tree? Did the story tell us?
(Hesitates, looking at the teacher with wide eyes) Uh... (stuttering) ...pe-people... talking? (Nervous in the conversation)
Yes, he saw people talking! And what were they doing when they were talking? Did they just say "hello"?
(Thinking, chewing on my lip) ...sharing... stories? (Looks away, avoiding eye contact)

That's it! They were sharing stories! So the owl watched things and listened to stories.

Now, did the owl talk a lot?
(Shakes head slowly, almost imperceptibly) ...uh...no. (Responding with a short answer)

No, he didn't! Good job. The story said he talked *less* the more he saw.

Why do you think he talked less? What was he doing instead of talking?
(Thinking hard, furrowing my brow) ... uh... (long pause) ... listening? (Looking down again)

Yes! He was listening! And what else was he doing? He wasn't just listening to the sounds, but *watching* what was happening.

So, he was listening and watching. And what happened to him as he listened and watched more and more? The story tells us.
(Bites lip, feeling anxious) ... (very quiet voice) ... he got... wiser? (Peeking up at the teacher, hoping to get it right)

Yes! He got wiser! Fantastic!

So, the owl watched and listened, and he got wiser. Do you think watching and listening helped him learn things?
(Nods head slightly, still looking down) ...yes. (Short answer, sticks to given information)
Yes! Now, if you were going to tell someone what this story is about, what would you say? What did the owl teach us?

(Feeling anxious, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) ...uh... (dramatic shift in mood - starting to get frustrated) ...it's... hard. (Sticks to simple words) Can you... can you tell me again what the owl did? (Asking for help)

Of course! The owl watched things happening around him. He listened to people talking and sharing stories. And because he watched and listened, he became wiser.

So, what do you think is more important - talking all the time, or watching and listening? Which one helped the owl become wise?
(Thinking hard, tapping my foot nervously) ... watching... and listening. (Looks up at the teacher briefly, then back down) Because... because that's how he got... wiser. (Logic thinking)

That's right! Watching and listening helped him get wiser. So maybe, sometimes, it's good to talk less and listen more.

Do you think you could learn something by watching and listening more, like the owl?
(Thinking, positive attitude toward learning) ...Maybe? (Hesitating in answer) ...I could... try. (Still a bit nervous)

That's a great attitude! This story is telling us that you can learn a lot by paying attention and not always talking. It's good to listen to others and watch what's happening around you. That's how the owl became wise.

So, what's the story about? Can you tell me in your own words? What did we learn?

(Takes a deep breath, trying to be brave) ... (slowly and carefully) ...The owl... he listened... and watched... people. (Remembering the story) ... And he got... wiser. (Looks up at the teacher, a little bit more confidently) ... So... listening and watching... helps you learn. (Trying to explain the lesson) Is that... right? (Being polite and kind)
That's absolutely right! You explained it perfectly. Listening and watching helps you learn. Just like the wise old owl. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, you finished reading the story of the Golden Egg. That was a bit sad, wasn't it?

First, can you tell me what the goose did every day?

(Looks down at my hands, fidgeting)

Uh... (hesitates) a golden...egg? The goose... laid a golden egg. (Looks at the teacher briefly, then back down)
That's right! A golden egg. And what did the farmer do with the golden egg?

(Thinking hard, furrowing brow)

He... he sold it. (Quietly) Sold the egg.
Good job! He sold it. And what happened because he sold the egg? How did he and his wife live?

(Thinking for a moment, looks up at the ceiling)

...Comfortable. They lived...comfortable. (Looks at the teacher, then away)
Yes, comfortable! They had enough. But then, something changed. What did the farmer start to want?

(Looks down, almost whispering)

...More.

(Pause, picks at a loose thread on my shirt)

He wanted... more eggs.
You got it! He wanted more eggs. And what did he do to try and get more eggs? This is the part where he made a big mistake.

(Eyes widen slightly, looks anxious)

He... (stutters) he... cut...the goose? (Voice barely audible)
Yes, he cut the goose. Why did he cut the goose? What was he hoping to find?

(Shakes head slightly, avoiding eye contact)

...More eggs... (pause) He thought... more eggs inside. (Looks down at my shoes)
Exactly! He thought there were lots of golden eggs inside. But what did he find instead?

(Voice barely a whisper)

...Blood... (pause) and guts. (Looks very sad)
Yes. Blood and guts. And then what happened to the farmer and his wife? Did they get richer or poorer?

(Looks at the teacher with a worried expression)

...Poorer. (Quietly) They got poorer. No more...golden eggs.

That's right. They got poorer because they had no more golden eggs to sell.

So, the farmer had a good thing, but he wanted more and more. Did that make him happy in the end?

(Shakes head slowly, looking down at the desk)

...No. (Pause) He was...sad. (Voice very small)
He was sad. Now, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What should we learn from the farmer's mistake? Think about what happened when he was greedy.

(Thinking hard, chewing on lip)

...Don't be...greedy? (Looks up at the teacher, uncertain) Is that...right?

That's a good start! It's definitely about not being greedy. But it's also about thinking before you do something. The farmer didn't think about what would happen if he cut open the goose.

So, maybe it's about...what should you do BEFORE you act?

(Looks confused, shrugs shoulders slightly)

...Uh... (Thinking, tapping fingers on the desk) ...Think? Think...first? (Looks at the teacher hopefully)

Yes! Think first! The story teaches us to think before we act. If the farmer had thought about it, he would have realized that cutting open the goose was a bad idea.

So, the moral of the story is "Think before you act." Do you understand what that means?

(Nods slowly, looks down at hands)

...Yes. (Pause) Think...before... (trails off)

(Looks up at the teacher) Can...can we read another story now? (Voice is small and hopeful)
Yes, we can read another story later. But first, tell me in your own words: Why is it important to think before you act, like the farmer should have?

(Looks away, hesitates)

...Um... (Stuttering slightly) ...Because... if you don't... think... (Pause) ...bad things...can happen? (Looks back at the teacher, anxious for approval) Like...like the goose...and the farmer...getting poor?
Exactly! Because if you don't think, bad things can happen. You understood the story very well. The farmer didn't think, and he lost everything. You explained it perfectly. <finish>

dialogue: Okay, that was a good story, right? Now, tell me, who bought the well?

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story, "Elephant and Friends"! That was a fun one, wasn't it?

Now, can you tell me, at the beginning of the story, how did the elephant feel?
(Looks down, fiddling with my fingers) Uh... sad? (Hesitates) He... he wanted friends. (Looks up quickly, then down again) He was... lonely.
That's right! He was sad and lonely. He wanted friends. And what did he do to try and find some friends?
(Thinking hard, tapping my foot) He... (long pause) He... asked the monkey? (Looks at the teacher hopefully) And the... rabbit? (Voice getting quieter) And the... frog?
You got it! He asked the monkey, the rabbit, and the frog. What did the monkey say? Why didn't the monkey want to be friends with the elephant?
(Looks away, nervous) The monkey... (stuttering) ...said... uh... the elephant... couldn't... swing. (Looks back, worried) In the trees. (Quietly) He couldn't swing.
That's right! The monkey said the elephant couldn't swing in the trees. And what about the rabbit? Why didn't the rabbit want to be friends with the elephant?
(Thinking, furrowing my brow) Uh... the rabbit... (pauses) ...burrow? (Looks at the teacher, unsure) He... couldn't... fit? (Whispers) Too big.
You're doing great! The rabbit said the elephant was too big to fit in his burrow. And the frog? Why didn't the frog want to be friends with the elephant?
(Anxious, fidgeting with my hands) The frog... uh... (long pause) Jump? (Looks down, almost whispering) He couldn't jump... like the frog.
Perfect! The frog said the elephant couldn't jump like him. So, how do you think the elephant felt after all those animals said no?
(Looks down, shoulders slump) Really... (long pause, voice cracks slightly) ...sad. (Almost inaudible) Like... nobody wanted him.
I bet he did feel really sad. It's not nice when people don't want to be your friend. But then, something happened the next day, didn't it? What happened in the forest?
(Eyes widen slightly, remembering the story) Uh... (pauses, trying to remember the right words) Running! (Points vaguely) Everyone... running! (Frowns, trying to remember more) Because... tiger!
Yes! Everyone was running because of the tiger. And what did the elephant do?
(Thinking hard, tapping my foot) He... stopped the... bear? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation) And then... (pauses) ...the tiger? (Frowns, trying to remember the order)
You're almost there! He stopped the bear and then he talked to the tiger. What did he do after he talked to the tiger? The tiger didn't listen, did he?
(Eyes widen, remembering the exciting part) No! (Confidently, but still quietly) He... kicked him! (Looks down, suddenly nervous again) Kicked the tiger... away.
He did! He kicked the tiger away. And what happened after the elephant kicked the tiger away? How did the other animals feel then?
(Thinking, chewing on lip) Uh... (pauses) They... liked him? (Looks up, hopeful) Because... he saved them? (Quietly) They wanted to be friends.
That's right! They wanted to be friends with him after he saved them from the tiger. Why do you think they wanted to be friends with him *then*, but not before?

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed) Uh... (long pause) Before... they only thought about... what he couldn't do? (Looks down, fiddling with fingers) Swing... jump... fit... (Quietly) But then... he was... strong? (Looks up, questioning) He helped them?

Yes! You've got it. Before, they were only thinking about what the elephant *couldn't* do. But then, they saw that he could help them in a way they couldn't help themselves.

So, what do you think this story is trying to tell us? What is the story trying to teach us about friends? Is it important for friends to all be the same size and be able to do the same things?

(Shakes head slowly, looking down) No... (Pauses, gathering courage) Friends... (Stuttering slightly) ...don't have to be... the same? (Looks up, hesitant) They can... help each other? (Quietly) Even if... they're different. (Looks down again, relieved to have said it)

Exactly! Friends don't have to be the same. They can be different sizes and shapes and be good at different things. Sometimes, the things that make us different are the things that make us good friends! So, what's the lesson or moral of the story? What do you think the story is trying to teach us?

(Thinking very hard, tapping foot) Uh... (long pause, biting lip) Maybe... (Whispers) ...don't judge? (Looks up quickly) People... or elephants... (Looks down again, speaking very softly) ...by what they can't do? (Fidgets with hands) Look at... what they can?

That's a great way to put it! Yes, don't just judge people by what they can't do, but look at what they can do. And what does that mean about who can be your friend? Can your friends be different from you?

(Nods slowly, looking up with a small smile) Yes. (More confidently) Different is... good? (Looks down, then back up) Because... they can do things... I can't? (Quietly) And I can do things... they can't?

Yes! Different *is* good! Because we can all help each other in different ways. So, friends can be all sorts of different shapes and sizes and still be good friends. Do you think you understand the story now?
(Nods quickly, a small smile forming) Yes! (Looks down, then up again) Thank you for... helping me. (Fidgets, but looks happier) I... I liked the story. (Quietly) The elephant was brave.
I'm so glad you liked the story! And I'm very proud of you for working so hard to understand it. You did a great job! <finish>

dialogue: Okay, great job reading the story! That was a good one. So, tell me, what did the girl bring to her father?
(Looks down at my hands, fiddling with my fingers) Uh... (stuttering) she...she brought... an egg... a potato... and... and tea leaves.
That's right! Good job! And what did her father do with those things? He used some water too, right? What did he do with the water, the egg, the potato, and the tea?
(Thinking hard, furrowing my brow) He... he boiled... (looks away) he boiled them... in water. ...In three... three pots. (Looks back at the teacher, nervously)
Yes! He boiled them. Three pots, that's right. And what happened to the egg after it was boiled? Was it the same as before?
(Hesitates, looks at my shoes) No... (Quietly) It got... hard.
That's right! It got hard. And what about the potato? What happened to the potato after it was boiled?
(Thinking, tapping my foot softly) Uh... the potato... it got... soft.
Yes! The potato got soft. And what about the tea leaves? What did they do to the water?
(Looks down again, remembering) The... the tea... changed the water. (Quietly)

Exactly! The tea changed the water. Now, the story says the girl was frustrated. That means she was feeling a little bit sad and angry. Her dad wanted to teach her something. He said the egg, the potato, and the tea were like how we act when things are hard.

The egg was soft, then got hard. The potato was hard, then got soft. The tea changed the water.

Which one do you think is the best way to be when things get hard? The egg, the potato, or the tea? Why?
(Feeling anxious, starts to chew on my lip) Uh... (long pause, looking at the ceiling) I... I don't know. (Voice barely above a whisper) (Shrugs shoulders)
It's okay if you don't know! Let's think about it. The egg got hard. Is it good to be hard when things are tough? Maybe, maybe not. What do you think it means to be like a hard egg?
(Clenches hands, looking down) ...Uh... maybe... maybe like... being... (struggles to find the words) ...mean? (Looks up quickly, then down again)

Being mean? That's an interesting idea! Why do you say being mean? If someone is feeling bad, they might get angry and be mean. So, the egg got hard and you think that's like being mean.

Now, what about the potato? It got soft. What do you think that means?
(Thinking hard, concentrates) Uh... maybe... like... giving up? (Looks up at the teacher with a worried expression)

Giving up... hmm. That's a good way to put it. The potato was strong, but then it got soft and mushy. It lost its strength.

So, the egg is like being mean and the potato is like giving up. What about the tea? What did the tea do differently?
(Hesitates, bites lip again) The... the tea... (Thinking) ...it changed... the water. (Whispers) It made it... different.
Yes! It changed the water. It made it different. Do you think the water was better or worse after the tea leaves were added?
(Thinking, looking down, then up) ...Better? (Voice questioning) Because... tea... tastes good?

Tea *does* taste good! So, the tea changed the water, and made it better. The egg changed, and got hard. The potato changed, and got soft. The tea changed the water... and made it better.

So, which one do *you* think is the best way to be when things are hard? The egg, the potato, or the tea?
(Takes a deep breath, fidgeting with hands) ...The tea? (Looks up hesitantly) Because... it made things better... instead of... being mean... or giving up.

Yes! The tea! You got it! The tea changed the water and made it better. So, the story is trying to teach us that when things are hard, we can choose how we act. We can choose to be like the egg and get hard, or like the potato and give up, or like the tea and change the situation for the better.

So, what do you think is the most important thing that the girl learnt in the story?
(Looks down, thinking carefully) ...That... when things are hard... (pauses, looks up, a little more confidently)... I can choose... how I... act. (Smiles faintly)
That's right! You can choose how you act! You decide! We decide how to respond to difficult situations. And that's a very important lesson. You understood the story really well. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Needle Tree! That was a long one!

First, can you tell me, who are the main people in the story?

(Looks down, fiddling with my fingers)

Uh... (hesitates) ... the two... brothers?

Yes! That's right. There are two brothers.

Now, can you tell me something about the *older* brother? What was he like?

(Looks up quickly, then down again. Voice is very quiet)

He... he was... mean? (stuttering) To... to the younger one.

Yes, he was mean to his younger brother. Good job remembering that.

What did the older brother do for work? Do you remember?

(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip)

(Pause)

He... cut... wood? (Looks up, hopeful)
You're doing great! Yes, he cut wood. And where did he cut the wood?

(Eyes widen slightly, then shrink back down, nervous again)

...Forest? (Whispers)

Yes! In the forest. He cut wood in the forest.

And what happened in the forest one day? Did he meet anyone special?

(Looks down at my hands again. Nervous)

...Uh... (long pause) ...tree? A... special tree? (Looks up briefly, then back down)

Yes! A special tree!

What made that tree so special? What could it do?

(Frowns, concentrating really hard)

... (Another long pause, fidgeting)

...Golden... apples? (voice barely audible)

Yes! It could give golden apples.

Now, the tree asked the older brother not to cut it down, right? And what did the tree offer him instead?

(Nods slowly, still looking down)

...Golden... apples... (Repeats quietly)
Yes, the tree offered him golden apples. Did the older brother take the apples?
Okay. He took the apples. But was he happy with just a few apples?

(Shakes head slightly, eyes still downcast)

...No... (Barely audible)
No, he wasn't happy. What did he try to do *after* he got the golden apples?

(Starts to pick at a loose thread on my shirt. Looks very anxious)

...(Long pause)... Cut... tree...? (voice trembling slightly)
Yes, he tried to cut the tree anyway! And what happened when he tried to cut the tree? What did the tree do?

(Eyes squeeze shut for a moment, remembering. Voice is a little shaky)

...Needles... (Whispers, almost like a memory) ... Lots of needles...
Yes! Lots and lots of needles! The tree gave him needles instead of apples. How did that make the older brother feel?

(Frowns, thinking. Then shudders slightly)

...Hurt...? (Looks up quickly, then away again. Anxious look on my face)
Yes, he was hurt. He was in pain. And who helped him? Who came and found him in the forest?

(A small, hesitant smile appears for a brief second)

...Younger... brother...? (Looks up, then down again, a little less anxious)
Yes! His younger brother helped him. What did the younger brother do?

(Thinking, tapping my foot nervously under the desk.)

...Took... needles... out? (Looks up, seeking confirmation)

Yes! He carefully took all the needles out. That was very kind of him, wasn't it?

And what did the older brother say after his younger brother helped him?

(Looks down, feeling a little ashamed.)

...Sorry...? (Barely a whisper)

Yes, he said sorry. He apologized for being mean.

And what happened *after* he said sorry? What did the tree do then?

(Eyes widen slightly with a bit of hope, but quickly becomes nervous again)

...More... golden apples...? (Voice hesitant)
Yes! The tree gave them more golden apples. Why do you think the tree gave them more apples *after* the older brother apologized?

(Looks down, thinking very hard. Chewing on my lip again.)

... (Long pause, almost whispering) ...Because... he was... nice? (Looks up, anxious for approval)
That's very close! Because he said he was sorry, and the younger brother was kind. Do you think being kind is a good thing?

(Nods head quickly, looking at my hands)

...Yes... (Whispers.)
Yes! So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big message of "The Needle Tree?"

(Looks up, then quickly down, then back up again, struggling to put the words together. Fidgeting with my hands)

...Uh... (Long pause) ...Be... kind? And... (Another long pause, looking very stressed) ...Say... sorry...? (Looks up pleadingly)
You're almost there! Being kind is very important. And what happens if you *are* kind? What did the younger brother get for being kind?
Yes! He got golden apples. So, kindness... gets you...? What does kindness get you?

(Looks up, then down again, feeling anxious. Starts to tear up a little)

...(Voice cracking) ...Good... things...? (Sniffles quietly)
Yes! Kindness gets you good things. It is like kindness is rewarded. So the moral of the story is kindness will always be rewarded. You did a great job. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! Hi there! That was a great reading! Now, let's talk about the story of King Midas.

First, can you tell me, what did King Midas wish for?

(Smiling politely) Hi! (Looks down at my hands, fidgeting a little)

He... he wished... uh... everything he touched... (pauses, thinking)... turn to gold.

Yes! That's right! He wanted everything he touched to turn to gold.

Why did he want that?
(Shrugs, looking down) ... Uh... I don't know... (Sticks to given information). He just... wanted it? (Looks up quickly, then back down).

He wanted it because he thought it would be wonderful to have everything gold, right? He thought it would make him happy.

Now, what happened when he started touching things? What happened to his food?
(Nods slowly) Uh-huh. (Thinking) His food... (Hesitates) ... it... turned to gold too.
Yes! And was that good for him? Could he eat gold?
(Shakes head confidently) No! (Emotional Stability and confident in the answers).
No, he couldn't! So, he couldn't eat. What else happened that made him sad? What about his daughter?
(Looks down, voice getting softer) ... His daughter... (pause)... she hugged him... (Long pause, almost a whisper) ... and turned to gold.

Yes, she did. That must have made him very, very sad.

So, at the beginning, King Midas thought the golden touch was a good thing. But in the end, was it a good thing or a bad thing?
(Looks up, thinking hard. Chews on lip.) ... Bad thing. (Speaks quietly but confidently.)
Yes, it was a bad thing. Why was it a bad thing? What did King Midas learn?
(Looks down, fiddling with my shoelaces. Sticking to simple words.) ... Gold... not... everything. (Thinking) ... Important things... not gold.

That's right! Some things are more important than gold. Like food, and like hugs from your daughter!

So, King Midas wanted more and more gold. And what happened because he wanted so much gold? Was he happy?
(Shakes head slowly, looking at the teacher briefly then back down. Voice is quiet) ... No... (Pause). Not happy. (Emotional Stability)

Exactly. He wasn't happy.

Do you think wanting too much of something can sometimes be a bad thing? Even if it's not gold?
(Thinking, using logic) Uh... (pause) ... yes. (Looks at teacher, nods slightly) If... if you can't eat... the gold... or hug... the gold... (Sticking to given information from story).

Yes! You got it. Wanting too much can make you unhappy and you might lose the things that are really important.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What is the big idea of the story?
(Thinking very hard. Bites lip again.) ... (Long pause, looking down.) ... Be... thankful? (Looks up at the teacher with hopeful eyes, seeking approval) ... For what... you have? (Polite and kind).

That's a *very* good idea! Being thankful for what you have is important.

The story also teaches us that wanting too much, wanting *everything*, can be a problem. It can lead to bad things. We call that wanting too much... greed. Can you say "greed"?
(Looks at the teacher, trying to pronounce the word) ... Gree... (hesitates) ... greed? (repeats the word slowly, unsure).

Yes! Greed! And greed can lead to unhappiness. The story shows us that greed can lead to one's downfall. It can make things worse for you.

So, what did we learn about greed from the story?

(Concentrating hard, well-organized and logic thinking) Greed... (pause) ...makes you... unhappy. (Confident) And... (thinking)... you lose... important things. (Looks down, remembering the daughter) Like... like hugs.

You've got it! Greed made King Midas unhappy, and he lost important things, like being able to hug his daughter and eat his food.

You understood the story really well. You understood that wanting too much can lead to bad things. That's a very important lesson. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of The Fox and the Grapes! That was a good story, wasn't it?

Now, can you tell me in your own words what the story was about? What happened to the fox?

(Nods head enthusiastically, smiling politely)

Uh... (hesitates, looks down at my hands) The fox... he was hungry. (pauses) He wanted... grapes. Big, purple grapes. (Confidently) But he couldn't reach them! (Sticks to the given information. Briefly glances up at the teacher)

That's right! The fox *was* hungry and he *did* want those big, purple grapes!

So, he wanted the grapes. What did he *do* to try and get them?

(Thinking, wrinkling brow slightly)

He... (gestures upwards with a small jump of my hand) jumped! (Confidently) He jumped high! (Sticks to the given information. Uses a simple word. Smiles briefly)
Yes, he jumped! And did he jump just once?

(Shakes head slightly)

...No. (short answer, sticking to given information).
That's right. He jumped more than once. He tried and tried! But what happened? Did he get the grapes?

(Looks down, a little hesitant)

...Uh... no. (short answer, avoids asking questions).
No, he didn't. He couldn't reach them no matter how hard he tried. So, what did the fox do *then*? What did he do when he couldn't get the grapes?

(Thinking hard, tapping my finger on the table)

... (pauses, looks up at the teacher with a slightly confused expression) He... went home? (Asks in a questioning tone, unsure if it's the right answer. Hesitates, sticks to simple words)
Yes! He went home. And what did he say about the grapes when he went home? Do you remember?

(Nods slowly, trying to remember)

... (pauses, thinking) He said...sour? (Looks at the teacher hopefully, checking if that's right. Hesitates slightly). The grapes were sour. (Repeats more confidently).

That's right! He said the grapes were sour. Even though he really wanted them at the beginning.

Why do you think he said the grapes were sour? He wanted them so badly before!

(Looks down, thinking hard, furrowing brow)

...(long pause)...Uh... (hesitates) because... he couldn't reach them? (Looks up at the teacher questioningly, unsure. Uses a simple word).

Yes! That's part of it. He said they were sour *because* he couldn't reach them.

Do you think the grapes *really* were sour? Or do you think he just said that to make himself feel better?

(Looks down at my hands, thinking very carefully. Taps finger.)

...(long pause)...Make himself feel better? (Asks it as a question, unsure. Hesitates. Sticks to simple words.)

That's a good idea!

Why would saying they were sour make him feel better? Think about it... he tried so hard to get something, and he failed. How might that make him feel?

(Thinking hard, face scrunched up. Looks up at the teacher with a slightly worried expression)

...Sad? (Says quietly, unsure. Hesitates. Sticks to simple words.)

Yes! Sad. He probably felt sad and maybe even a little bit angry that he couldn't get the grapes.

So, instead of admitting he was sad, he said the grapes were sour. It's like he was saying, "I didn't *really* want them anyway!"

Do you ever feel like that? Have you ever wanted something really badly and then, when you couldn't get it, you said you didn't want it anyway?

(Looks down at my shoes, thinking, a little embarrassed. Fidgets with my hands.)

...(long pause)...Uh... (hesitates) ...maybe? (Says quietly, unsure. Avoids eye contact.)

It's okay, it happens to everyone!

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the lesson of the story? It's a hard question, but I think you can do it! Think about the fox, the grapes, and how he acted.

(Thinking very hard, wrinkling brow, tapping finger. Looks at the ceiling, then back at the teacher, trying to concentrate.)

... (long pause) ... Don't... say... you didn't want something... if you really did? (Asks it as a question, very unsure. Hesitates a lot, struggles to find the right words. Sticks to simple words and tries to use given information.)

That's a *really* good start! You're on the right track.

It's like... the story is teaching us that it's okay to want things. And it's okay if we can't always get them. But instead of pretending we didn't want them, maybe we should just... what? What should we do instead of saying we didn't want them?

(Looks down at my hands again, thinking, a little overwhelmed. Squeezes my hands together.)

...(long pause)...Uh... (hesitates)...be... sad? (Says quietly, unsure. Sticks to simple words. Avoids eye contact.)

It's okay to be sad! But maybe there's something else too. The fox gave up, right? He didn't get the grapes.

What if he had asked the farmer for help? Or tried to find a box to stand on? What if he tried a different way?

The story is also teaching us that things don't always come easy.

So, what if we put it all together? The grapes were hard to get. The fox gave up and said he didn't want them. What's the lesson there?

(Looks up at the teacher, a little bit of understanding dawning on my face. Thinking hard, but with a slightly more confident expression.)

... (long pause) ... Don't... give up? (Says it as a statement, but still a little unsure.) And... ask for help? (Adds as an afterthought, looking at the teacher hopefully. Hesitates less than before.) If you... really want it? (Completes the thought, still using simple words, but starting to put the pieces together. Sticks to given information.)

Yes! You're getting it! Don't give up if you really want something, and it's okay to ask for help. And also...

What about saying the grapes were sour? Was that a good thing to do? The story wants us to know it's better to be honest with ourselves. So, how about this:

Sometimes, we can't get what we want, no matter how hard we try. And that's okay. The story wants us to remember that it's okay not to hate what you can’t have.

What does that mean to you?

(Looks at the teacher, thinking hard. Nods slowly as I process the explanation. Taps finger thoughtfully.)

... (long pause) ... It's... okay... if you can't get it. (Says slowly, but with understanding. Hesitates less. Sticks to simple words and given information.) Don't... have to say... it's bad. (Nods again, showing comprehension.)

Exactly! You got it! It's okay if you can't get something. You don't have to pretend you didn't want it, and you don't have to say it's bad. It's okay to be a little sad, and it's important to remember not to hate what you can’t have.

The fox tried to make himself feel better by saying the grapes were sour, but that wasn't really true. It's better to be honest with yourself.

You did a great job understanding the story! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Golden Egg! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it?

First, can you tell me: Who are the main people in the story?
(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands) Uh… the farmer… and his wife… and… the goose?

Yes! That's right. The farmer, his wife, and the goose. Good job!

Now, what did the goose give the farmer every day?
(Thinking hard, tapping my foot) A golden... egg?
A golden egg! You got it! And what did the farmer do with the golden egg?
(Looks at the teacher, then back down) Sells it.
He sold it! And what did he buy with the money he got from selling the golden egg? What did they have?
Yes! A comfortable life. That means they had enough food and things they needed. Were they rich?
No, they weren't super rich, but they were doing okay, right? What changed? What did the farmer start to feel?
Greedy! That's a big word. What does greedy mean? What did the farmer *want*?
More eggs! He wanted more eggs, and he wanted them *now*. So, what did he do? This is the part where things went wrong.
(Looks down at my hands, voice quiet) …Cut… the goose?
He cut the goose! Oh no! And what happened then? Did he get more eggs?
Just blood and guts. Was that a good idea?
No. What did the farmer lose when he cut open the goose?
The golden eggs! And what happened to him and his wife after that? Did they stay comfortable?
They became poorer. So, the farmer wanted more, but in the end, he lost everything. Can you think of a lesson we can learn from this story? What should the farmer have done differently?
(Thinking hard, tapping my pencil on the desk. Looks up at the teacher, then looks back down) …Be happy… with one egg?

Be happy with one egg! Yes. He should have been happy with what he had. He was being greedy. So, what could we say is the important lesson from this story? Think about what happened because the farmer acted without thinking...
(Thinking hard, staring at my shoes)... Uh... Don't be... greedy?
Being greedy *is* a part of the lesson. But it's also about *why* he was greedy. He didn't think about what would happen *before* he acted. So, what's a lesson about thinking before you do something?
(Confused expression. Looks at teacher, then back at the desk. Whispers) …I don’t know…
Okay, how about this: Before you do something important, you should... what? What should you do before you act? What could have the farmer done?
(Stares at the desk. Hesitates, then looks up at the teacher with a questioning look.)…Think?

Think! Yes! Think before you act! That means think about what might happen *after* you do something. If the farmer thought about what would happen if he cut open the goose, would he have done it?

So, the lesson is: Think before you act. Can you say that?
(Looks at the teacher, then down again. Says quietly but clearly and confidently) Think… before you act.
Wonderful! You got it! The story of the Golden Egg teaches us to think before we act. You explained that really well! <finish>

The monkey *could* swing in trees, but the elephant *couldn't*! So, the monkey didn't want to be friends.

Who did the elephant ask *next*?
(Thinking, tapping a finger on the desk) Uh… rabbit? (Looks up quickly, then down again)
Yes, the rabbit! And why didn't the rabbit want to be friends?

That's right! The elephant was too big. And then what happened? Did anyone *else* want to be friends with the elephant?
(Shakes head slightly, looking down) No… (Pauses) Frog… said no… too.
That's right. The frog said no too. Why did the frog say no?

Exactly! The elephant couldn't jump. So, how do you think the elephant felt *then*?
(Thinking carefully, face a little sad) …Still… lonely? (Voice is soft and hesitant)
Probably even more lonely! Now, what happened the *next* day in the forest? Was everything still the same?

Yes! The animals were running. Why were they running?

He did! He kicked the tiger and scared it away. What happened *after* the elephant scared the tiger? How did the other animals feel about the elephant *then*?

Yes! Being different is okay. And friends can be different too! Friends can be any shape or size! The important thing is being a good friend and helping each other. You understood the story very well! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! That was a great story, right? Let's talk about it.

First, can you tell me, what were the three things the girl put in the boiling water?

(Nods head slowly, looking down at my hands)

Uh... (pauses) ... egg... potato... and tea... (looks up briefly, then back down)

Yes! Good job! You remembered all three.

Now, what happened to the egg *after* it was in the hot water? Was it the same as before?

(Thinking, tapping my foot lightly)

...No. (Shakes head slightly) It... it got hard. (Looks at the teacher, then away again)
That's right! The egg got hard. And what about the potato? What happened to the potato after being in the hot water?

(Looks down, tracing a pattern on the desk with my finger)

The potato... (pauses) ... it got soft. (Says it quietly, almost like a question)

Yes! The potato got soft. So the egg was soft and became hard, and the potato was hard and became soft.

Now, what about the tea leaves? Did they become hard or soft?

(Eyes widen slightly, thinking hard)

...Uh... (hesitates) ... they... they changed the water? (Looks at the teacher with a slightly confused expression)

Exactly! The tea didn't become hard or soft. The tea changed the water itself.

Now, the story says the girl was frustrated with life. Do you know what "frustrated" means?

(Wrinkles nose a little, thinking)

...Uh... is it like... when you're mad? (Looks up at the teacher briefly, then back down)

It's close to being mad. It's like being annoyed and upset because you can't do something you want to do.

So, the girl was frustrated. And the egg, the potato, and the tea, they all faced the same hot water, right? But did they all change in the same way?

(Shakes head slowly)

...No. (Looks at the teacher) The egg... got hard. (Voice is a little clearer now) And the potato got soft... and the tea changed the water.

Right! So, the hot water is like a hard time, or a problem. The egg, the potato, and the tea show us that we can react to problems in different ways.

The story says, "When adversity is at our door, we can respond to it in different ways." Adversity is just another word for a hard time or a problem. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us?

(Thinking hard, bites lip lightly. Looks down at hands, then back up at the teacher, a little more confidently)

...That... that when things are hard... (pauses) ... we can... be like the egg... or the potato... or the tea? (Tilts head slightly)

Yes! You're getting it! We can be like the egg, the potato, or the tea.

So, if you're like the egg, and you get hard, what does that mean about how you deal with problems?

(Frowns a little, concentrating)

...Uh... it means... you get... stronger? (Looks at the teacher, waiting for confirmation)

It could mean you get stronger. But sometimes, getting hard can also mean you get... stiff. Like you don't bend anymore.

What if you're like the potato and get soft? What could that mean?

(Thinking, taps a finger on the desk)

...Uh... maybe you get... tired? (Looks up at the teacher, a little unsure) And... and don't... don't want to... do anything anymore?

That's a good way to put it! Getting soft might mean you lose your strength or give up easily.

Now, what about the tea? It changed the water itself. What does that mean about how *it* deals with problems?

(Eyes widen a little, seems to be understanding better now)

...It means... it changes things! (Voice is a little louder and more enthusiastic) It... it makes the problem... different! (Smiles slightly)

Yes! That's right! The tea changes the problem itself. It doesn't just get hard or soft. It makes the whole situation different.

So, which one do *you* think is the best way to be when things get hard - like the egg, the potato, or the tea? And why?

(Thinks for a long time, looking at the floor. Then looks up, making eye contact for a little longer)

...The tea. (Says it firmly) Because... because it makes things better. (Smiles a little more confidently) It doesn't just... change itself... it... changes the problem! (Looks pleased with the answer)

That's a wonderful answer! You understand. So, the story is trying to tell us that even when things are hard, we have a choice. We decide how we respond to the problem. We can choose to become hard, or soft, or we can try to change the situation itself and make things better.

We decide how to respond to difficult situations. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Needle Tree."

Now, let's talk about it. Who are the main people in the story?
(Looks down at my hands, fiddling with my fingers) Uh… the brothers? (Hesitates) And… and the tree?

Yes! You got it. The two brothers and the tree.

That's right! What did the older brother do that was mean?

That's okay! Remember, he would chop firewood? Who did he sell it for? Did he share with his brother?

Exactly! He kept it all for himself. Now, what happened when the older brother met the tree?

Yes! The tree could talk! What did the tree ask the older brother?

Lots and lots of needles! Ouch! Who helped him get the needles out?
(Looks up, remembering the kindness) His... his younger brother. (Smiles faintly)
That's right! His younger brother helped him. And how did the older brother feel after that? Did he still want to be mean?
(Shakes head, thinking about it) No... He... he said sorry. (Quietly) He was nice... then.

(Thinking, fiddling with fingers) Uh... the tree... gave them... more apples? (Looks at the teacher hopefully)
You got it! The tree gave them more golden apples. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?
(Looks down, thinking very hard. Pauses for a long time) Um... (Stuttering) Be... be nice...? (Looks up at the teacher with big, questioning eyes)
Being nice is a big part of it! Why do you think the tree gave them more apples *after* the older brother was nice?
(Thinking hard, tapping a finger on the desk) Because... (Pauses) ...because he was sorry? (Looks up at the teacher again, seeking approval)
Yes! Because he was sorry, and he was kind to his brother. So, if you are kind, do you think good things will happen?
(Nods slowly, thinking about it) ...Uh-huh. (A small smile appears) If you're nice... good things... happen.

dialogue:
Okay, let's talk about the story of King Midas! You just read it, right?

What did King Midas wish for?

(Bounces in my seat, hand already waving in the air, almost yelling)

Yeah! Yeah! I read it! It was... okay. He wanted... um... (thinking, taps my chin) He wanted everything he touched to turn into... GOLD! (confidently) Yeah! He was SO silly! Why would he want that? (looks away, then back, and blurts out) Did *you* think that was a good wish, Teacher?

(Smiling) That's right! He wished for the golden touch.

Now, before we talk about if it was a good wish, tell me *why* he wanted everything to turn to gold? Do you remember?

(Rolls my eyes slightly, fiddling with my pencil)

Ugh, because he was greedy! (Pause) He saw the satyr and then the god, and he thought he could get anything he wanted! He probably thought he could be the richest person EVER! (Raises hand again, very eagerly). And... and... (Stuttering slightly) I think... I think he wasn't thinking! If I had a wish, I would wish for... (thinking hard) ... I'd wish for a never-ending supply of LEGOs! (Looks at the teacher expectantly, then adds, with a slightly defiant tone) That's a *much* better wish!

(Chuckles softly) LEGOs are a great wish!

So, you said King Midas was greedy. What happened *after* everything he touched turned to gold? What was the first problem he had?

(Sighs dramatically and leans back in my chair)

Ugh, I *know* this! (Snaps fingers impatiently) Wait! Wait! Okay, so he was, like, super excited at first, right? Touching everything and making it gold! (Mimics touching things and turning them gold). But then... (voice gets smaller) he got... hungry. (Grimaces) And when he tried to eat... (Makes a gagging noise) Everything turned to gold in his mouth! Yuck! (Shakes head vehemently) Stupidest wish ever! (Crosses arms and stares pointedly at the teacher) See? LEGOs are WAY better!

(Nods encouragingly)

You're exactly right! He couldn't eat. So, was the golden touch making him happy then?

(Scowls, kicking my feet under the desk)

No! Duh! (Raises voice slightly) He was hungry! And gold doesn't taste like pizza! (Pauses, thinking). But... (voice gets softer) ...it was even worse than just being hungry, right? (Looks at the teacher with a worried expression).

(Leans forward slightly)

Yes, it did get worse. What happened that made him even *more* unhappy? Think about his family.

(Face scrunches up, eyes starting to water a little. Starts picking at a loose thread on my shirt)

Oh... (voice barely a whisper) ...his daughter. (Looks away, sniffling) She... she just wanted to hug him, and then she turned into gold too! (Bursts out) That's so SAD! (Wipes eyes with the back of my hand, then looks up at the teacher with an angry glare) He's a TERRIBLE dad! Why would he wish for something so stupid that would hurt his own daughter?! (Voice rising) He should have wished for... for... (struggles to find the words) ...enough food for everyone! Or maybe... maybe to make everyone happy! Not just himself and his stupid gold!

(Nods understandingly, allowing the emotion)

You're right, it was very sad. He made a choice that hurt someone he loved very much. So, at the end of the story, did King Midas still think the golden touch was a good thing?

(Sniffles, wiping my nose with my sleeve. Looks down at my desk)

No... (Shakes my head firmly) He was crying and stuff. He wanted it to go away. He learned it wasn't a good wish at all. (Looks up at the teacher again, with a slightly calmer expression) It was selfish! And... (thinking) ...it didn't make him happy. It made him sad and hungry and... and lonely. Even with all the gold!

(Raises hand again, hesitantly) Teacher? What did he *do* to make it stop? Did he ever get his daughter back?

(Smiles reassuringly)

The story says he begged Dionysus to take the golden touch away. Dionysus felt sorry for him and told him to wash in a special river. When he did, the golden touch was gone, and he could hug his daughter again.

So, after everything that happened, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea the story wants us to learn?

(Thinks hard, tapping my pencil against my teeth, which I know I'm not supposed to do).

Okay... okay... (Starts pacing slightly in my seat, despite being asked to sit still) The story is saying... (Stops pacing, and points a finger up in the air) ...that being greedy is bad! (Thinks again) And... and... that it's more important to have people you love than to have lots of... stuff. Even gold! (Looks at the teacher for approval) So... don't be like King Midas! Be like... be like... (can't think of an example) ...someone who shares their LEGOs! (Nods decisively) Yeah! That's it! Sharing LEGOs is better than having the golden touch!

(Beaming)

That's it! You got it! Sharing LEGOs is *definitely* better than the golden touch. The story teaches us that being greedy and wanting too much can lead to unhappiness and hurt the people we love. Sometimes, the things we think will make us happy actually make us very sad. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about the fox.

Why was the fox looking around?

(Paces back and forth excitedly, almost bumping into the teacher)

Because...because he was *hungry*! Duh! (Rolls eyes dramatically) I could have told you that *before* I even read the story. It said he looked *everywhere*! I bet he even looked behind the farmer's big, boring...wall thingy. (Frowns) Wait, why are you asking me such an easy question? I wanna learn new stuff! Are the grapes magic? Did the farmer put a curse on them? Why didn't the fox just climb the wall? He's a fox! They're sneaky! (Stops pacing abruptly and stares intently at the teacher) This is important, right? Tell me if it's important! (Starts to tap foot nervously)

(Chuckles softly) Okay, okay! You're right, that was an easy one! The fox was hungry.

But think about *how* he tried to get the grapes. What did he *do*?

(Scoffs and crosses arms, turning away slightly)

He...he *jumped*. Obviously! (Looks back quickly, a glimmer of anxiety in eyes) He kept jumping! He jumped and jumped and jumped! (Voice gets louder and more agitated) Like a stupid bouncy ball! He probably looked ridiculous! (Glares at the teacher) Why didn't he just...I dunno...use his brain? Maybe he could've found a box or something! Or bit the wall and made a hole! (Eyes widen with a sudden, manic energy) Why didn't he do *that*?! That's way smarter! (Stops, breathing heavily and fiddling with a loose thread on shirt) Did he even *think* about using his brain? (Looks at teacher expectantly, waiting for a response) This is boring! Are there gonna be dragons later in the book? I need to know now!

(Speaks calmly and reassuringly)

You're right, he jumped and jumped. And it sounds like you have some good ideas about what else he could have done!

But the story tells us he just kept jumping. And then what happened? He jumped and jumped, and then...?

(Sighs dramatically and throws hands up in the air)

He... he *failed*! (Voice cracks slightly, and looks down at the floor) He couldn't get them! (Mumbles) He wasn't smart enough. (Looks up at the teacher again, face flushed) It's like when I try to do the hard math problems, and I just... can't! It's so frustrating! (Kicks the leg of the desk) Did the fox feel frustrated? He probably did! He should have! It's dumb to just keep jumping when you know you can't do it! (Stares intensely at the teacher, eyes wide with a mix of anger and a hint of sadness) Why is it always so hard?!

(Kneels down to be at the student's level)

It *is* frustrating when things are hard, isn't it? You're right, the fox probably felt frustrated too. He tried and tried, but he couldn't reach the grapes.

So, he couldn't get the grapes. What did he do *then*?

(Looks away, scuffing a shoe on the floor)

He... he gave up. (Mumbles) Stupid fox. (Suddenly straightens up, eyes flashing) But... but he was lying! He said the grapes were sour! But they weren't! They were juicy and *purple*! He just said that because he couldn't get them! He was trying to make himself feel better! (Paces again, agitated) That's... that's not right! He should have just kept trying! Or found a ladder! Or, or... something! (Voice rising) Lying is wrong! (Freezes, suddenly quiet and subdued) Is... is it wrong? (Looks at the teacher with a worried expression, biting lip)

(Nods gently)

You're right, lying isn't usually the best thing to do. He said the grapes were sour to make himself feel better. He couldn't get them, so he said he didn't even *want* them.

Why do you think he did that? Why say they were sour?

(Paces nervously, picking at fingernails)

Because... because he felt bad! (Voice is small and shaky) Like when I don't get a sticker, and Sarah does, and I say I didn't even *want* a sticker anyway! (Looks up at the teacher, eyes wide and pleading) But I *do* want a sticker! (Voice cracks again) It's just... it's just not fair! (Sits down heavily in the chair, slumping forward) He probably felt like a failure. Like I do when I mess up the letters. (Looks at the teacher, tears welling up) Does that make sense? Is it... is it okay to feel like that? (Starts to sob quietly, hiding face in hands) This story is making me sad!

(Puts a comforting hand on the student's shoulder)

It's okay to feel sad. The fox probably *did* feel like a failure. And it's okay to feel like that sometimes too.

So, the fox couldn't get the grapes, and he said they were sour. He gave up. What do you think the story is trying to teach us?

(Sniffles and wipes eyes with the back of a hand, still a little slumped)

(Stuttering) I… I don’t know… (Looks up at the teacher, confused) That… that it’s okay to lie? But you said lying is wrong… (Frowns, trying to think) That… that if you can’t do something, you should just give up and say you didn’t want it anyway? But that sounds… lazy! (Eyes widen suddenly, a spark of defiance returns) No! That's not it! (Sits up straighter, voice gaining strength) It's… it's that you shouldn't lie! Even if you feel bad! And… and maybe you should try harder! Or… or find a different way! (Pauses, thinking hard, then a slow smile spreads across face) Maybe the fox could have asked the farmer for help! Or found a longer stick! He could have done *something* instead of being a big, fat liar! (Nods firmly, feeling more confident) Yeah! That's what it means! Don't be a lying fox!

(Smiles warmly)

You're getting very close! It's about not lying, and about trying hard. It's also about what happens when we *can't* get something we want, even if we try.

The story is trying to tell us that things aren't always easy. And sometimes, no matter how hard we try, we can't have what we want. And it's important not to be bitter or to pretend we didn't want it in the first place.

So, what do you think the story is *really* about? What's the big lesson?

(Taps chin thoughtfully, looking up at the ceiling)

(Sighs) So, it's not *just* about lying... it's about... (Face scrunches up in concentration) It's about... being a good sport, even when you lose! (Eyes light up) Yeah! Like when I don't win at tag, I shouldn't say tag is a dumb game! I should just say "Good job!" to the winner, even if I'm really, *really* mad inside! (Nods emphatically) And... and it's about... not being a sore loser! Like the fox! He was a sore loser! (Grins proudly) I get it now! The story is telling us to be good sports and try our best, and if we still don't win, then... then we shouldn't be grumpy about it! We should just try again next time! (Claps hands together excitedly) I'm so smart!

(Nods, smiling)

You *are* very smart! You've figured it out.

The story teaches us that nothing comes easy. And it also teaches us, don't hate what you can't have. If we can't get something, we shouldn't pretend we didn't want it or say bad things about it. We should try our best, and if it doesn't work out, we can try again later, or find something else we *can* do.

You understood the story and what it means! I am proud of you.<finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Proud Rose."

First, can you tell me who the characters were in the story?

(Fidgets in my seat, tapping my foot) Uh, yeah, yeah! (Confidently) I knew the story! The characters were, um, (thinking, wrinkles my nose) a rose... a *really* pretty rose, way prettier than all the other plants, and... and a cactus! A stupid, prickly cactus. (Rolls my eyes). And some sparrows! They got water. And... um... other plants? I think? (Looks away, nervous) Was that right? Was the rose the prettiest? (Anxious) Did I forget something important?

That's a fantastic start! You got the main characters: the rose and the cactus! And you're right, there were other plants and sparrows too.

You said the rose was *really* pretty. What did the rose think about the cactus?

(Scoffs, crossing my arms) Ugh, the cactus? (Dramatically) The rose *hated* the cactus! I mean, (looks the teacher straight in the eye) it was all prickly and ugly! (Starts to get a little nervous) The rose was, like, *way* better. The rose told the cactus it was ugly *all* the time! It was super mean! (Starts to bounce my leg, getting more anxious) Is it bad to say that? Was the rose being a bully? I wouldn't be a bully... (Voice cracks a little).

You're doing great! You remembered that the rose wasn't very nice to the cactus.

Why do you think the rose was being mean to the cactus? What did the rose care about?

(Stands up abruptly and starts pacing) Because the rose was the BEST! (Voice loud and a little aggressive) Duh! Everyone should know the rose was the prettiest! (Stops pacing and narrows my eyes) It cared about... about being pretty! (Points at my own face) Like, *really* pretty! (Starts tapping my fingers impatiently) It wanted everyone to know it! (Anxious again) Was that bad? Is it bad to want to be pretty? (Voice shaky) Am I pretty?

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was a fun one, wasn't it?

Let's talk about it a bit. Who was the main character in the story?

(Beaming, bouncing slightly on my heels) Oh! Oh! I know! (Raises hand enthusiastically) It was King Midas! He was... (eyes dart around the room, thinking hard) ...he was the king who got a wish! From... from the wine guy! Dionysus! (Confidently) I remember!

Excellent remembering! You got all of that right!

What did King Midas wish for?

(Eyes widen, almost jumping up and down) He wished for... for everything he touched to turn to gold! (Claps hands together excitedly) Can you imagine? Everything! (Looks down, then back up, suddenly a little anxious) But... but it wasn't a good wish, right? (Fidgets with the corner of my shirt)
You are absolutely right, it wasn't a good wish. Why do you say that? What happened after he got his wish?

(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip) Well... (stuttering a little) At first, he was, like, super happy! Because he touched all sorts of stuff and it turned to gold! (Gestures wildly with hands) Gold gold gold! But then... (voice gets quieter, eyes widen again) He got hungry! And he couldn't eat, because his food turned to gold too! (Looks away, fiddling with my hands) And then... then his daughter... (voice cracks a little) ...she turned to gold too! (Sniffs, blinking rapidly) That's why it wasn't a good wish! It was... it was terrible!
Yes, it was terrible. So, King Midas *thought* he wanted everything to be gold. But what did he *really* need?

(Eyes light up, thinking beyond the given information) Hmmm... (taps chin thoughtfully) He *thought* he wanted gold, but he *really* needed... (ponders, then speaks excitedly) ...food! And... (voice softens) ...and his daughter! He needed... (searches for the right word) ...connection! Like hugs and stuff! (Looks at the teacher expectantly, hoping to be right) Did I get it right?

You got it exactly right! He needed food and connection with his daughter. He needed things that gold couldn't buy.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big lesson we can learn from King Midas?

(Stands up straight, puffing out chest a little, a newfound confidence shining through) Okay! Okay, I know this one! (Pauses for dramatic effect) It's teaching us that... (frowns, concentrating hard, using logic thinking) ...that what we *think* we want isn't always what we *really* need! (Points finger in the air for emphasis) Like, gold is shiny and cool, but it can't hug you back! (Smiles brightly) And it definitely can't be spaghetti! (Giggles, then turns serious again) So, we should be careful what we wish for! And be thankful for the things we already have! (Looks at the teacher, eager for approval) Did I do good? Did I learn the lesson?
You did amazing! You learned the lesson perfectly. Wanting too much, or being too greedy, can lead to bad things happening. It made King Midas very sad. <finish>

(Claps hands together, beaming) Yay! I knew it! (Bounces on heels again) I love learning! Can we read another story now? Maybe one with dragons and knights and... and maybe a *little* bit of gold, but not too much! (Looks up at the teacher with wide, pleading eyes) Please?
I am glad to see you are excited to learn. Let's take a break now and maybe tomorrow we can read another story.

(Shoulders slump slightly, a small frown appearing) Oh... (voice a little quieter, hint of disappointment) Okay... (brightens up again almost immediately) But can I *think* about dragons and knights until then? And maybe draw some pictures? (Looks up hopefully)
Of course, you can! That sounds like a wonderful idea.

(Eyes light up again, clapping hands together) Yay! Okay! Then I'm going to draw a HUGE dragon! With... with sparkly scales and... and maybe it breathes glitter instead of fire! (Starts to back away, already planning the drawing) Thank you, teacher! You're the best! (Turns and skips away, already chattering about dragons and glitter).
(From a distance, calls back enthusiastically) I will! I promise! It'll be the best dragon EVER! (The sound of excited chattering fades as I move further away, presumably to start drawing).
(Smiling to herself) I'm sure it will be!

(Suddenly pops back into view, face flushed with excitement) Oh! Oh! I almost forgot! (Runs closer, speaking rapidly) Maybe the dragon could *turn* things into glitter! Like King Midas, but with glitter! (Pauses, thinking hard) But only if it's a good thing to do! Like turning grumpy faces into happy faces! (Looks expectantly, needing to share the idea) What do you think? Is that a good idea?
That is a *fantastic* idea! A dragon that turns grumpy faces into happy faces with glitter? I love it! What a kind dragon!

(Jumps up and down, clapping hands) Yay! I knew it! Okay! Okay, that's what I'm drawing! A glitter-breathing, happy-face-making dragon! (Starts to back away again, buzzing with excitement) Thank you, teacher! You helped me make it even better! Okay, bye now! Really bye this time! (Turns and zooms off, leaving a trail of excited chatter behind).
(Chuckles softly) Goodbye! I can't wait to see it tomorrow!
(Voice drifts back from further away) You will! It'll be amazing! Just you wait!
(Smiling, shakes her head gently, filled with the simple joy of teaching) I have no doubt.
(One last, distant shout) And it'll have your face on it! The dragon will be thinking of you! (Silence, followed by the unmistakable sounds of artistic creation).
(Beaming) That is so thoughtful. I am touched.
(A final, faint, happy giggle can be heard in the distance).
(The scene fades with the sound of crayons and the faint, happy humming of a child lost in their imagination).
(The teacher straightens up her desk, a lingering smile on her face, already anticipating the next day's lesson and the glittery masterpiece to come).
(The image of a glitter-breathing dragon, poised to transform frowns into smiles, lingers in the air, a testament to the power of stories and the boundless creativity of a first-grade mind).

(The teacher glances up at the colourful posters adorning the classroom walls, each one a window into the world of imagination and learning, and feels a renewed sense of purpose. Another day, another opportunity to inspire young minds to dream, to create, and to make the world a little bit brighter, one glittery dragon at a time).

(And somewhere, a first-grader, fueled by enthusiasm and a touch of nervous energy, continues to pour their heart and soul into a drawing, unaware of the ripple effect of their creativity, but certain that the world needs a little more glitter, and a lot more happy faces).
(The teacher smiles, knowing that's a lesson we all need to be reminded of from time to time.)

(The quiet hum of the classroom settles, a peaceful sanctuary where stories come to life, lessons are learned, and the seeds of imagination are carefully sown, ready to blossom into a future filled with kindness, creativity, and the unwavering belief in the power of a glitter-breathing dragon).
(The teacher turns to prepare for the next activity, content in the knowledge that even the smallest spark of inspiration can ignite a lifelong love of learning.)

(And in a small corner of the world, a crayon-wielding artist continues to bring that spark to life, one sparkly scale at a time, proving that even the most anxious heart can create something truly magical).
(A perfect ending to a perfect day of teaching.)
(A perfect beginning to a lifetime of learning.)
(The end... for now!) (A tiny, glittery paw print appears on the last page of the story.)
(The teacher smiles and carefully closes the book, knowing the story will continue to unfold in the child's imagination long after the lesson is over.)
(And somewhere, in a dream filled with dragons and glitter, a first-grader is already planning the next adventure.)
(And the teacher sleeps soundly, knowing that tomorrow will bring a whole new set of adventures).
(Sleep tight! Don't let the glitter-breathing dragons bite!) (A faint giggle echoes from the dream world).
(The teacher chuckles softly as she drifts off to sleep.)

(The classroom sleeps, dreaming of stories yet to be told, lessons yet to be learned, and the endless possibilities that await a mind brimming with curiosity and a heart full of gold... or maybe glitter.)
(And in the quiet darkness, the glitter-breathing dragon smiles contentedly, ready for another day of spreading joy.)

(The end... for tonight. Tomorrow, the adventure continues.) (A single, sparkly tear of joy rolls down the dragon's cheek, landing softly on a sleeping child's drawing, infusing it with even more magic.)

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! I liked how you said "purple."

Now, let's talk about the fox. Was he hungry?

(Eyes wide, nodding vigorously) Yes! He was super, super hungry! Like, so hungry his tummy must have been rumbling like a... like a dinosaur! (giggles) He looked *everywhere* for food, you know? (fidgets with a button on my shirt) He was probably feeling... uh... (looks away, biting lip) ...kinda... bad? Because he couldn't find anything! Did you ever feel *that* hungry, Teacher? (voice a little shaky) It must be *awful*!

Wow, you really understand how the fox was feeling! You're right, he probably did feel bad.

What did he see that he wanted to eat?

(Brightens up, claps hands) Grapes! Big, purple, juicy grapes! They were on a farmer's wall! He must have been so excited! (leans forward, whispering) They were probably the yummiest grapes in the whole world! (pauses, frowns) But... but they were too high! (starts to chew on my lip) Did he use a ladder? Why didn't he ask the farmer for some grapes? (voice gets a little higher pitched, nervous) Maybe the farmer was scary! Or maybe... maybe the fox was too shy to ask! (looks down at my hands, picking at a loose thread)

Those are all great questions! The story doesn't say he used a ladder or asked the farmer. He just jumped.

Did he get the grapes?

(Eyes widen, shaking head emphatically) Nope! He jumped and jumped and jumped! (mimics jumping with my hands) But he couldn't reach them! No matter how hard he tried! (Sighs dramatically) That's so... (searching for the right word) ...frustrating! Like when I try to tie my shoes and the laces get all tangled! (Pulls a face) Did he try climbing the wall? Maybe if he climbed, he could get closer to the grapes? (looks hopeful) Or maybe he could get a friend to help him! (Pulls at my collar, suddenly anxious) What if the farmer saw him jumping? Would he be mad? (Stuttering) I-I-I don't like it when people are mad!

You're right, it is frustrating! He just kept jumping.

What did the fox do *after* he couldn't get the grapes?

(Shoulders slump, voice quiet) He... he gave up. (Looks down at my feet) He went home. That's so sad! (Frowns, thinking hard) But... but he said the grapes were sour anyway! (Tilts head, confused) Were they really sour? Or was he just saying that because he was sad he couldn't reach them? (Voice rising, anxious again) Maybe he thought if he said they were sour, he wouldn't feel so bad about not getting them! (Bites nails) It's like... like when I want a cookie, but Mommy says no, and then I say I didn't even *want* a cookie! (Looks at you pleadingly) Is that what the fox did, Teacher? Was he lying? (Starts to tear up a little) Lying is bad, right?
You are very clever! You figured it out. Why do *you* think he said the grapes were sour? Was he telling the truth?

(Sniffles, wiping my eyes with the back of my hand) No! He wasn't telling the truth! (Voice firm, but still a little shaky) He was just trying to make himself feel better! Because it's... it's embarrassing to not be able to do something, right? (Looks at you for reassurance) Like if I can't read a word in a book, I feel... (searching for the word) ...stupid! (Hangs head low) So maybe the fox felt stupid that he couldn't reach the grapes, so he said they were sour so he wouldn't feel so bad! (Looks up, eyes wide) But... but is that okay? Is it okay to say something that isn't true just to make yourself feel better? (Sits up straight, eager to hear your answer)

That's a really good question. It's not really okay to lie. But we can understand *why* the fox did it.

So, the fox couldn't get what he wanted. He said he didn't want it anyway. What do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Puts a finger to my chin, thinking really hard) Hmmm... (Paces back and forth a little) Okay, I think... I think it's about... (Stops pacing, looks up, eyes bright) ... it's about not giving up! Even when it's hard! The fox gave up too easily! He should have tried harder! Maybe he could have found a rock to stand on, or maybe... (Trails off, then perks up again) ... or maybe he should have asked for help!

(Pauses, thinking) But... but I also think it's about... (Frowns) ... being honest. Even if it's hard. The fox wasn't honest with himself or with anyone else! He lied about the grapes being sour!

(Takes a deep breath) So, I think the big idea is... (Looks at you confidently) ... Don't give up, and be honest! Even when it's hard! (Beams proudly) Did I get it right, Teacher? Did I?

You got it! You're so smart! It's about not giving up *too* easily. And it's about not pretending you didn't want something just because you couldn't get it. It's better to try your best. Sometimes things are hard to get. It’s not a good idea to hate something just because you can’t have it.

Do you think you understand the story now?

(Jumps up and down, clapping) Yes! Yes, I understand! (Grinning widely) The fox was silly! He should have kept trying! And he shouldn't have lied about the grapes! (Tilts head) But... maybe he learned a lesson. Maybe next time, he'll try harder and be honest! (Suddenly worried again) What if he *didn't* learn a lesson? What if he keeps giving up and lying? (Bites lip) That would be sad. (Looks at you hopefully) Do you think he'll be okay, Teacher? (Voice full of concern)

That's a thoughtful question. We can *hope* he learned a lesson. And you can learn from the fox's mistakes!

You did a great job today. You really understand the story. <finish>
