dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Proud Rose."

Now, tell me, who are the characters in the story?

(Eyes wide, bouncing slightly on my seat) Oh! Oh! I know! (Raises hand enthusiastically) It's the...the beautiful rose! (Points an imaginary finger, nose slightly upturned like the rose) And...and the cactus! (Beams, then lowers hand, suddenly a little unsure) And...and some sparrows? And...and other plants! (Looks at the teacher hopefully) Was that right? I think the rose was the most important one! (Frowns, thinking hard)

Yes! That's right! The rose, the cactus, the sparrows and the other plants. Good job.

Which character do you think wasn't very nice at the start of the story?

(Gasps, hand flying to my mouth dramatically) Oh! Oh, that's easy! (Confidently) It was the rose! (Frowns) She was...she was being a bully! (Looks down at my hands, twisting them together nervously) She was saying mean things to the cactus because she thought she was prettier! (Looks up at the teacher, eyes wide with concern) That wasn't very nice at all! Is it ever okay to say mean things? (Wrinkles nose, thinking) I don't think so. (Shakes head firmly)

No, it's never okay to say mean things. You're right, the rose was being a bully.

Why do you think the rose was so mean to the cactus?

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed. Stares at the ceiling for a moment) Hmmm... (Taps chin with a finger) Maybe... maybe she thought if she said mean things, she would feel... (Stutters a little) ...better about herself? (Looks at the teacher, a little anxious) Like, if she made someone else feel small, she would feel big? But that's silly! (Shakes head) Because being nice makes you feel much better inside! (Beams, then frowns again) Or... (Thinking) maybe she was just... jealous? (Looks down, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) Because the cactus could hold water, and she couldn't? Was she jealous?

Those are both very good ideas! Maybe she wanted to feel better about herself, or maybe she was jealous. It's hard to know for sure, but both are possible.

Now, what happened when the summer got very hot and there was no water?

(Eyes widen, leaning forward excitedly) Oh! Oh! This is the important part! (Claps hands once) The rose started to... to... (Struggles with the word, then looks at the teacher pleadingly) ... w-wither! She got all droopy and sad! (Mimics a wilting flower with my hand) And the cactus... (Beams, sitting up straight) The cactus was helping the sparrows! He had water inside him, and he was giving it to them! (Looks thoughtful) Even though the rose was mean to him before! (Shakes head in amazement) He was still nice!

Yes, that's exactly right! The rose started to wither, and the cactus helped the sparrows.

So, the rose needed help. Who did she ask for help from?

(Eyes dart around the room, a little nervous) Oh... oh dear. (Whispers) This is a little tricky... (Looks down at my shoes, then back up at the teacher, speaking quickly) She... she asked the cactus for help! (Winces, then adds, with emphasis) The *same* cactus she was mean to! (Looks at the teacher, anticipating a trick question) Was that a brave thing to do? (Thinking aloud) I think it was hard for her to do!

Yes, that was very brave of her, especially after she was mean to him.

And what did the cactus do? Did he help her?

(Gasps, eyes shining with happiness) Yes! Yes, he did! (Claps hands again, excitedly) He was so nice! (Leans forward, conspiratorially) Even though she was mean! He gave her water! (Looks thoughtful) That's... that's like forgiving someone, right? Even when they hurt you? (Looks at the teacher, seeking confirmation) He was a very good cactus! The best cactus! (Beams)

You're exactly right! He forgave her. He was a very kind cactus.

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big lesson it teaches us?

(Puts a finger to my chin, thinking very hard, then suddenly brightens) Oh! Oh, I know! (Looks at the teacher with wide, earnest eyes) It's about being nice! (Speaks with conviction) Even when people aren't nice to *you*! And... and it's about... (Struggles with the words, then blurts out) ...forgiveness! (Looks a little anxious) And... and maybe... (Eyes widen with a new thought) ...that being pretty on the outside isn't as important as being kind on the inside! (Nods emphatically) Because the rose was pretty, but she wasn't very nice! But the cactus was super helpful and kind! (Beams proudly) Did I get it right? (Holds breath, waiting for the answer.) Oh! And you shouldn’t be a bully! (Adds quickly)

You got it! All of it! You are a very good learner. The story teaches us that we shouldn't judge people just by how they look. The rose was beautiful, but she wasn't kind at first. The cactus might not have looked as pretty, but he was kind and helpful. So, it's important to be kind to everyone, no matter what they look like.

We also learn that being kind is more important than being beautiful and we should not bully anyone.

<finish>

dialogue: Okay! Let's talk about the story, The Milkmaid and Her Pail. You just read it. What was Molly's job?

(Eyes wide, bouncing slightly on my heels) Ooh! Ooh! I know! Molly... Molly was a... a milk... (stutters a little, nervous) ...milkmaid! (Confidently) She had to milk the cows and then... and then sell the milk at the market! (Looks at the teacher with a hopeful smile) Is that right? Did I get it right?

Yes, that's exactly right! You got it! Molly was a milkmaid.

So, Molly was going to the market. What was she thinking about while she walked?

(Claps hands excitedly) Oh! This is the fun part! (Starts to fidget a little, remembering the story) She was thinking... (thinking hard, brows furrowed) She was thinking about all the... all the *things* she could buy with the money! (Voice gets higher and more excited) Like, she could buy a... a chicken! (Looks at the teacher, anticipation in eyes) And then the chicken would lay eggs, and she could sell *those* eggs too! And then... and then she could buy even *more* things! (Gasps, a little nervously) It was... it was a lot to think about! Was she being smart? (Looks at the teacher with a questioning look)

That's a very good way to put it! She was thinking about what she *could* buy.

Do you think she had the money *yet* to buy the chicken?

(Looks down at my hands, twisting my fingers, nervous) No... (voice gets small). No, she didn't have the money *yet*. She only had the... the milk! (Eyes widen) She hadn't even sold the milk *yet*! (Looks up, a little shocked) So... so she was thinking about things she didn't even *have* yet? (Pulls at my shirt nervously) Oh no... was that... was that a bad idea?
Yes, she was thinking about things she didn't have yet. What happened because she was thinking so much about the chicken and the eggs?

(Gasps dramatically, eyes wide) Oh! Oh! I know! (Paces a little in excitement) She got so... so excited and... and she started skipping! (Demonstrates skipping with tiny hops) And then... and then the milk! (Voice drops to a whisper) The milk... it spilled! (Covers mouth with hand, feeling sad) All of it! (Looks at the teacher, close to tears) Oh no! All the milk spilled because she was thinking too much! Is that... is that like... like daydreaming? (Looks at the teacher, needing reassurance)

You are exactly right! The milk spilled because she was too busy dreaming.

So, what did Molly go home with?

(Looks down, scuffing my shoe on the floor, feeling dejected) She went home with... (voice barely audible) ...empty pails. (Looks up, tears welling in eyes) And no money! (Sniffles) Poor Molly! (Wipes eyes with the back of my hand) She was probably so sad! What would *I* do if all my milk spilled? (Frowns, trying not to cry)
She was probably very sad! What did her mother say to her when she got home?

(Eyes still a little watery, but trying to be brave) Hmmm... (Thinking hard, tapping my chin) Her mother... her mother said... (Gasps, remembering!) She said, "Don't count your chickens before they hatch!" (Looks at the teacher, a little confused) What does that *mean*? (Tilts head, curious and slightly anxious) Is it... is it like... not thinking about the future too much? (Frowns, trying to understand)

That's a great question! "Don't count your chickens before they hatch" means don't *depend* on something happening until you are *sure* it will happen. Molly was depending on selling the milk, buying a chicken, and the chicken laying eggs *before* any of it happened.

Does that make more sense now?

(Eyes widen, thinking hard) Ooooh! (Snaps fingers) I get it! It's like... like if I promised to buy my friend a toy with my allowance, but I hadn't *gotten* my allowance yet! (Looks at the teacher, excited) I shouldn't promise something until I *actually* have the money, right? (Beams proudly) Because what if I don't get my allowance? Then I can't buy the toy! (Looks a little nervous again) And my friend would be sad! (Nods head vigorously) So, Molly shouldn't have been thinking about buying the chicken until she had sold the milk and had the money! (Claps hands happily) I understand!

Yes, that's a perfect example! You understand completely!

So, what is the lesson of the story? What should we learn from Molly's mistake?

(Stands up straight, puffed up with newfound understanding) The lesson is... (pauses dramatically, trying to sound grown-up) ... the lesson is that we shouldn't... (frowns, concentrating) We shouldn't *plan* on things that haven't happened yet! (Nods firmly) We should only count on things that we *know* are true! (Looks at the teacher, a little anxiously) Is that right? (Starts to fidget again, hoping to get it right) And... and we should be careful and not spill our milk! (Giggles nervously, then becomes serious again) But mostly, we shouldn't count our chickens before they hatch! (Beams proudly, hoping for praise) Did I... did I do good?
You did a fantastic job! You explained it perfectly. The lesson is, don't depend on something until you are sure it will happen. Just like Molly and her milk! <finish>

dialogue: Okay, great job reading the story! Now, can you tell me, what did the old owl like to do?

(Eyes wide, bouncing slightly in my seat) Oh! Oh! I know! (Raises hand eagerly) The owl... the owl liked to watch things! He watched everything that happened near his tree! (Confidently) He was a super good observer! He saw *lots* and *lots* of things! Did he see squirrels playing tag? (Tilts head, thinking) Maybe... maybe he saw birds building nests too? (Looks at the teacher expectantly) Did he?
That's right! He watched everything! He was a very good observer. And what happened *after* he watched things? Did he talk a lot about what he saw?

(Frowns, tapping a finger on the desk) Hmm... (looks away, thinking hard) He... he didn't talk *more*, he talked *less*! (Snaps fingers excitedly) Because he was learning! He was seeing all those things and... and listening to people talk. So he didn't need to talk as much because he was already thinking about everything! (Eyes widen) He was probably thinking really deep thoughts! Like... like what if squirrels *could* talk? (Giggles) That would be so silly! Is that right? Did he talk less because he was learning?
Yes, that's a great way to put it! He talked less because he was learning. So, if he talked less and watched more, what did that make him? What kind of owl was he?

(Beams, sitting up straight, voice filled with enthusiasm) He was a *wise* owl! (Claps hands together) He was wise because he learned from everything he saw and heard! (Leans forward conspiratorially) It's like when Mrs. Davis reads us books! We learn from the stories, right? So, we become a little bit wiser too! (Tilts head) Does that mean we're all going to become wise owls one day? That would be so cool! (Looks expectantly at the teacher, hoping for confirmation.)

That's right! He was a wise owl because he learned by watching and listening. Just like you learn from stories! So, what do you think the story is trying to tell *us* to do? What can *we* learn from the wise old owl?

(Starts fidgeting with the corner of the desk, biting lip) Oh... oh, this is a hard question. (Stuttering slightly) Um... um... I think... (Looks down, then back up, gathering courage) I think it means we should watch and listen more! (Voice gets stronger) Like, even when it's hard to be quiet, we should try to listen to what other people are saying. And... and watch what's happening around us! (Eyes widen, remembering something) Just like when you told us to watch the ants in the playground! We learned so much about them just by watching! (Confident again) So, the story is telling us to be good observers so we can be wise too! (Smiles brightly) Is that right? (Anxiously awaits the teacher's response).

Yes! That's exactly right! The story is telling us that we can learn a lot by watching and listening, just like the wise old owl. So, maybe we should talk less and be more observant! That's the important lesson the owl teaches us. You understood the story very well! <finish>

(Jumps up and down in seat, clapping hands) Yay! I understand! (Beams, then voice drops slightly, becoming more thoughtful) So... so does that mean I shouldn't talk so much in class? (Looks at the teacher with genuine concern) I really, really like talking and sharing my ideas! (Worried expression, fidgeting with hands) But I also want to be wise... (Looks down, then back up hopefully) Can I still talk sometimes, but just try to listen more too? (Anxiously awaits the answer, hoping it's okay to still be a little bit chatty).
(Smile warmly) Yes, of course! It's great to share your ideas. Just remember to listen carefully to others too. It's all about finding a good balance! <finish>

(Huge smile spreads across face, visibly relieved) Oh, good! (Claps hands together happily) That makes me feel so much better! (Leans forward eagerly) So, next time, I'll try to count to ten before I talk so I can listen better! (Eyes sparkle with determination) And then I can share my *really* wise ideas! (Giggles, bouncing in seat again) Thank you for helping me understand, Mrs. Davis! You're the wisest teacher ever! (Beams, radiating happiness and enthusiasm).
You're very welcome! You are a very thoughtful and observant student, and I'm sure you'll continue to grow wiser every day. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! It was a bit sad, wasn't it?

Let's talk about it. What kind of animal laid the golden egg?

(Eyes wide, bouncing a little in my seat) Oh! Oh! I know! (Raises hand enthusiastically) It was a… a… (Stutters a bit, looking down at my hands) a… goose! A goose laid the golden egg! A really, really special goose! (Looks up, beaming) I love geese! They're so… (Thinks hard, furrowing brow) …elegant! And this one laid GOLD! (Claps hands excitedly). But… but it was still a sad story. (Frowns, looking at the teacher).

That's right! A goose! And you're right, it was a special goose.

Why was the farmer happy at the start of the story?

(Nods head vigorously, fidgeting with a button on my shirt) Because… because the goose gave him a golden egg every day! (Counts on fingers) One! Just one! And he could… he could sell it! (Looks up, questioning) Did he sell it for a lot of money? (Thinking, tapping chin) That must be why he was happy! He could buy… (Eyes widen) Candy! And toys! And maybe… maybe even a new house! (Sighs contentedly) But… but he shouldn't have been greedy. (Looks away, a little nervous).

Yes, he sold it for money! And that made him happy.

So, why did the farmer *stop* being happy? What changed?

(Takes a deep breath, wringing hands slightly) Well… (Looks down at shoes) He… he wanted more. More golden eggs! (Looks up, almost pleadingly) But that wasn't nice! He was already getting one! It's like… it's like having one cookie, and then wanting ALL the cookies! (Shakes head sadly) So… so he cut open the goose! (Gasps, covering mouth with hand) And… and there were no more golden eggs! Only… only blood! (Looks at the teacher with wide, anxious eyes) It's very… very sad. He was happy, and then he was… (Tears welling up) …super, super sad! (Sniffles). Did he learn a lesson? (Voice trembling slightly).

You're doing a great job explaining the story! Yes, he did something very sad.

What did the farmer learn? What mistake did he make?

(Wipes eyes with the back of hand, then looks at the teacher intently) (Sniffles) He learned that… that being greedy is bad! (Nods head firmly) Really, really bad! He made a big mistake by… by wanting too much! (Thinking hard, biting lip) He should have been happy with just one golden egg a day! (Looks up, brow furrowed) Is that called… content? Like, being content with what you have? (Waits expectantly for confirmation, fidgeting with shoelaces). He lost everything because he wanted more. Now he has zero golden eggs! (Shakes head slowly, a look of deep understanding on face) Zero! It's like… like going from having lots of sunshine to having only rain. (Frowns deeply).

"Content" is a great word to use there! You're right, he wasn't content.

So, what could the farmer have done *differently*? What should he have done instead?

(Eyes light up, excited to answer) He should have been… (Pauses, searching for the right word) …grateful! (Nods enthusiastically) Yes! He should have been grateful for the golden egg he already had! (Paces a little, thinking) He could have… he could have maybe even given the goose a treat! Like… like a yummy worm! (Giggles) Or built her a nice, cozy nest! (Stops pacing, looking at the teacher seriously) He should have taken care of the goose and been happy with what she gave him. Then… then he would have still had golden eggs! (Points finger emphatically) But he was greedy! (Crosses arms, looking disappointed). He should have been content and grateful instead of… (Wrinkles nose) …yucky and greedy! (Asks anxiously) Is that what the story is all about? Being grateful?

Being grateful is a big part of it! You're understanding the story really well.

The story teaches us to think carefully before we do something. If the farmer had thought carefully, he wouldn't have been greedy. What do you think? What is the moral of the story?

(Stands very still, thinking deeply, tapping fingers on desk) Hmmm… the moral… (Looks up, eyes wide) Is it like… like the lesson? (Waits for confirmation, then continues) Okay! Okay! I think… (Pauses, biting lip) The moral of the story is… don't be greedy! (Nods firmly, then elaborates) And… and be happy with what you have! (Eyes dart around, thinking) Oh! And… and think before you do something silly! (Claps hands once, satisfied) Because if the farmer thought, he would know cutting open a goose is… is… (Shudders) …not a good idea! (Looks at the teacher hopefully) Is that right? Did I get it? The moral is… don't be greedy, be happy, and think! (Beams proudly). Is there another moral? (Asks quickly, before the teacher can answer).
You're so close! You've got all the right ideas. It's about thinking before you act, so you don't make a bad choice like the farmer. So the moral is 'Think before you act!' <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, you've read the story of the farmer and the well. Great job!

First, can you tell me, who bought the well?

(Beaming, eyes wide) The farmer! The farmer did! He bought it to water his... his... (thinking, tapping chin) ... his farm! He really wanted that well, I think. (Slightly nervous) Is that right, Teacher? I really like farmers! My grandpa is kind of a farmer, he grows tomatoes in his backyard! They are so yummy!

Yes, that's right! The farmer bought the well to water his farm. Good job remembering!

Now, what did the neighbor do after he sold the well? Did he let the farmer use it?

(Eyes widening, a little anxiously) No! No, he didn't! (Frowning, hands fidgeting) He... he was being tricky! (Looks away, voice trembling slightly) He said he only sold the well, but not the...the water inside! That's not fair, right? (Looks back at teacher, pleadingly) It made me a little sad when he did that because the farmer needs the water. (Brightening up slightly) Maybe the farmer will share his tomatoes with the neighbor if he let him use the water? Do you think so, Teacher?

You're exactly right! It wasn't fair. The neighbor was being very tricky. He tried to cheat the farmer.

So, what did the farmer do when the neighbor wouldn't let him use the water? Where did he go for help?

(Eyes wide with excitement) He went to the...the... (Thinking hard, brow furrowed) Oh! Oh! I know! (Jumping slightly) He went to the...the emperor! Yes! (Clapping hands) He went to the emperor because he needed help! The emperor is like the really, really big boss, right? To make things fair! (Voice gets a little shaky) Was he scared to talk to the emperor? I think I would be a little scared. Is the emperor nice?

Yes, that's right! He went to the emperor. You remembered that! And you're right, the emperor is like the "big boss" who makes things fair.

Now, what did the emperor's helper (the courtier) ask the neighbor? What did the neighbor say?

(Concentrating really hard, tongue sticking out a little) Okay, okay... The courtier... (Thinking) ...asked the neighbor... (Pauses, looking up at the ceiling) ...something about the well! And the water! (Eyes widen, remembering) He asked him why he wouldn't let the farmer use the water! And the neighbor... (Voice gets high-pitched with indignation) ...the neighbor said he only sold the well, not the water inside! He was still being sneaky! (Fidgets with hands, agitated) That makes me feel... (struggling to find the right word)... icky! Like when someone takes my crayons without asking! Is the courtier going to be able to fix it, Teacher? I really hope so!

"Icky" is a perfect word to describe how the neighbor was acting! He was definitely still trying to be sneaky.

And yes, the courtier *did* fix it. What did the courtier tell the neighbor he had to do? Do you remember the choice he gave him?

(Eyes widening, excitement building) Oh, I think I remember! The courtier... (pauses dramatically) ...told the neighbor that he had to... (thinking hard, tapping fingers on desk) ...either let the farmer use the water... or... or... (gasps) ...pay rent for the water! (Voice gets quieter, a little anxious) Because it was in the farmer's well now. Right? (Looks up at teacher, hopefully) He had to pay rent... or take all the water away... right NOW! That's like... (pauses, searching for the right analogy)... like if I put my toys in your room, I have to pay you or take them back! (Nods head, feeling proud of understanding) Is that right, Teacher?

That's a *perfect* way to explain it! You understand the story very well!

So, what happened after the courtier gave the neighbor those choices? What did the neighbor decide to do?

(Eyes shining, voice filled with triumph) He said sorry! He said he was wrong! (Clapping hands softly) He realized his trick didn't work! (Pauses, thinking) He must have felt... silly. Like when I try to build a super tall tower and it falls down. (Looks at teacher, thoughtfully) I'm glad he said sorry. It's always better to say sorry, right Teacher? And I bet the farmer shared his tomatoes after that! Did he? Did the farmer share his tomatoes?

You're exactly right. It *is* always better to say sorry.

Now, thinking about the whole story, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea or lesson we can learn from the farmer and the well?

(Sits up straighter, thinking very seriously) Hmmm... (Taps chin) It's teaching us that... (pauses, looking up at the ceiling) ...that it's not good to be tricky! And that you should be fair! (Voice gets a little anxious) And that if you try to trick someone... (Looks at teacher, pleadingly) ...it won't work in the end! Because the emperor... or someone... will make things right. (Smiles brightly) And that it's always good to say sorry! (Adds thoughtfully) And maybe... (voice softer) ...maybe you should share your tomatoes? (Looks at teacher, hopefully) Is that right, Teacher? Is that what the story means? I really hope so!
Yes, you've got it! The story shows us that trying to cheat or trick people doesn't work out in the end. It's much better to be honest and fair. Cheating will get you nowhere. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends."

First, can you tell me, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story? Was he happy or sad?

(Eyes wide, bouncing slightly in my seat) Oh! Oh! I know! (Confidently) The elephant was sad! Very, very sad! He wanted friends, but nobody wanted to play with him! (Frowns, looking down at my hands) It makes me feel a little sad too, thinking about it. (Looks back up, a little anxious) Is it okay to feel sad about the elephant being sad? I think it's because he was all alone...

It's absolutely okay to feel sad when the elephant is sad. That means you have a kind heart!

Why was the elephant sad? What did he want?

(Beaming at the compliment) He wanted friends! (Paces back and forth slightly) He was looking... looking... (thinking hard, furrowing my brow) ...he was looking all around the forest! (Snaps fingers) Yeah! Looking all around! (A little anxious) But, umm... (stutters) ...but the monkey said he couldn't swing! And the rabbit said he was too big! (Gasps) And the frog couldn't jump with him! (Looks away, fidgeting with my fingers) Nobody wanted to be his friend. (Whispers) That's why he was sad. It's not nice to be alone.

You're doing a wonderful job remembering the story!

The monkey, the rabbit, and the frog...did they think about *what* the elephant was like *inside*? Or did they just look at how he was different from them?

(Eyes light up, thinking beyond the given information) Ooooh! That's a good question! (Taps chin with a finger) I don't think... (pauses, searching for the right word) ...I don't think they *considered* it! (Confidently) They just saw he was different! The monkey wanted someone who could swing! (Makes swinging motion with arms, a little too enthusiastically) The rabbit wanted someone who could fit in his burrow! (Shrinks down small) And the frog wanted someone who could jump! (Hops a tiny bit) (Looks down, mood shifting slightly) They only looked at the *outside*, not the *inside*. (Asks, a little anxiously) Is that... is that what you mean?

Yes, that's exactly what I mean! You're so smart. They only looked at the outside.

So, then what happened the next day in the forest? Do you remember?

(Claps hands excitedly, a quick mood shift) I remember! I remember! (Voice rising in excitement) Everyone was running! (Paces quickly) Running and running and running! Because the tiger was... (gasps dramatically) ...attacking! (Whispers loudly) It was very, very scary! (Looks at you, wide-eyed and a little nervous) I would be scared too! What if a tiger was chasing me? (Takes a deep breath to calm down)

That does sound scary!

And what did the elephant do when he saw all the animals running from the tiger?

(Stands up straight, puffing out my chest) The elephant was brave! (Sits back down, but posture remains erect) He stopped the bear! (Voice getting higher with excitement) He asked the tiger nicely to stop! (Frowns) But the tiger was being mean! (Makes a frustrated face) So... so the elephant... (Eyes widen, almost bouncing in seat again) ...the elephant kicked the tiger! (Giggles nervously) That's... that's maybe not *always* the best thing to do, right? But the tiger was being a bully! (Looks at you for reassurance, a little anxious)

You're right, kicking isn't always the best thing to do. But in this story, the tiger was being a bully.

What happened *after* the elephant scared away the tiger? How did the other animals feel about the elephant *then*?

(Beams, enthusiasm returning) They were so happy! (Claps hands) They realized the elephant wasn't just big! He was strong and brave! (Voice filled with wonder) And he helped them! (Looks thoughtful) They realized he *could* be a good friend, even if he couldn't swing or hop or fit in a burrow. (Asks excitedly) Does that mean they finally understood? That being different is okay? (Tilts head, waiting for an answer, a little nervous again)

Yes! You got it! They finally understood.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea or lesson of "Elephant and Friends"?

(Puts a hand on chin, thinking deeply) Hmmm... (Looks away, then back, eyes widening) I think... I think it's teaching us that we shouldn't judge people (or elephants!) by how they look on the outside! (Confidently) It's what's *inside* that matters! (A little nervously) And that... and that even if someone is different, they can still be a really, really good friend! (Smiles brightly) Maybe the best friend ever! And... (Stuttering slightly) ...and that it's important to be kind to everyone, even if they can't swing or hop or anything like that! (Looks at you, hopeful) Is that right? Did I get it?

You got it! That's exactly right! The story teaches us that friends can be all shapes and sizes. It doesn't matter if they are different from you. What matters is how they treat you and others. And it's important to be kind to everyone.

You explained the story so well. I think you really understood "Elephant and Friends". <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "When Adversity Knocks."

Now, tell me, what did the girl in the story feel like at the beginning?

(Bounces slightly in my seat, hand raised high)

Oh! Oh! I know! (Confidently) She was, um... she was *frustrated*! (Wrinkles nose a little) Like, super frustrated with *life*! (Uses air quotes around "life") It said so right at the beginning! Like, nothing was going right, and she didn't know what to do! (Looks at the teacher expectantly for confirmation) Is that right? Did I get it right?

Yes, you're exactly right! She was frustrated. Good job remembering that word!

So, what did her dad do to help her feel better?

(Eyes widen, thinking hard, tapping chin)

Ooooh, okay, okay! (Fidgets with hands) He... he didn't just, like, *tell* her to feel better! He did something really... (searches for the right word) ...*smart*! He... he got an egg, a potato, and tea leaves! (Voice gets a little higher pitched with excitement) And he boiled them! (Looks at the teacher, then looks down at desk, suddenly nervous) But... (stuttering) b-but... I don't really understand *why* he boiled them. (Looks up, hoping for an explanation) Was it like a... a magic trick to make her not sad anymore? (Frowns, a little anxious) I don't get it.

It wasn't a magic trick, but it was a good way to show her something important!

Let's think about the egg first. What was the egg like *before* it went into the hot water?

(Thinking hard, eyebrows furrowed)

The egg... (taps desk with a finger) The story said the egg was... (brightens up) ...*soft*! (Looks at the teacher proudly) Like, if you squeezed it too hard, it would break! (Makes a squishing motion with hands, then quickly stops, looking worried) But I wouldn't *really* squeeze an egg hard! That would be messy! (Giggles nervously)

(Smiling) You're right, it would be messy! But yes, the egg was soft.

And what happened to the egg *after* it was in the boiling water?

(Eyes widen, remembering)

Ooooh! (Claps hands together) It got *hard*! (Confidently) Like, you could bounce it on the table maybe! (Looks at the teacher, a little mischievous) But... but probably not! My mommy would be mad! (Looks down, a bit anxious, then back up quickly) So, the soft egg got hard in the hot water! (Nods head vigorously)

That's right! The soft egg became hard.

Now, what about the potato? What was the potato like *before* it went into the hot water?

(Gasps, hand flying to mouth)

Oh! I know this one too! (Bounces again) The potato was... (pauses dramatically) ...*hard*! (Pumps fist in the air) Like, super hard! You could probably hit someone with it! (Immediately looks horrified) But I wouldn't! I would *never* hit someone with a potato! (Shakes head vigorously) That would be... (searches for the right word) ...*mean*! (Frowns, feeling guilty even thinking about it)

(Calmly) You're right, the potato was hard. And it's good that you know hitting someone with a potato wouldn't be nice!

So, what happened to the hard potato after it was boiled?

(Concentrates, brow furrowed)

Okay, okay, hard potato... boiled... (snaps fingers) It got *soft*! (Voice full of triumph) Like, you could smoosh it with a fork! (Makes a smooshing motion in the air) My mommy makes mashed potatoes! (Smiling brightly) They're my favorite! (Then suddenly looks anxious again) But... wait a minute... (frowns) the hard potato got soft, and the soft egg got hard... (thinking hard) Is that... is that important? (Looks up at the teacher, nervously chewing on lip)

Yes! That IS important! You're doing great!

So, the hot water changed both the egg and the potato, right? But did it change them in the *same* way?

(Eyes widen in realization)

No! (Shakes head emphatically) It didn't change them the *same*! The egg got... (points upward) ...harder! And the potato got... (points downward) ...softer! (Paces in seat, getting excited) So the hot water... (searching for words) ...it made them... *different*! It changed them in opposite ways! (Looks at the teacher, panting slightly, proud of figuring it out) But... but I still don't know *why* the dad boiled them! (Voice trails off, anxious again) What does it *mean*?

You are so close! You figured out that the hot water changed the egg and the potato in different ways.

Now, think about what the "hot water" could *mean* in the story. What do you think the girl was going through that made her frustrated? What was hard for her?

(Tilts head, thinking hard, then gasps)

Oooooh! (Eyes light up) The hot water is like... like when things are *hard* and *bad*! (Frowns, remembering the girl's frustration) Like when you're having a really, really bad day and nothing is going right! (Shivers dramatically) Like... like when you fall down and scrape your knee AND you spill your juice! (Looks at the teacher, wide-eyed) That's like the hot water! (Points finger in the air triumphantly) So, the egg and the potato... they're like... like *people*! (Suddenly looks confused again) But... but why did one get hard and one get soft? (Looks down, frustrated) I'm still confused!

You are doing AMAZING! The hot water *is* like when things are hard and bad! And you're right, the egg and potato are like people.

Think about it this way: Some people, when things get hard, they become strong and tough, like the egg. Other people, when things get hard, they become weak and soft, like the potato.

Which one do *you* think is better?

(Thinking VERY hard, tapping fingers on desk)

Hmmmm... (Looks up at the ceiling, then back down) I... (stutters a little) I think... I think being strong like the egg is better! (Nods slowly) Because if you're soft like the potato when things get hard, then... then you just... you just get all... (searches for the right word) ...mushy! (Wrinkles nose) And nobody wants to be a mushy potato! (Looks at the teacher for approval) But... but is it okay to be a little bit like the potato sometimes? (Looks anxious) Because sometimes I feel like a mushy potato when I get sad!

It's okay to feel like a mushy potato sometimes! Everyone does! But the story is showing us that we can *choose* to be more like the egg.

Now, what about those tea leaves? We haven't talked about them yet. What happened to the water when the tea leaves were added?

(Gasps, clapping hands together)

The tea leaves! I almost forgot! (Eyes dart around excitedly) The tea leaves... the tea leaves *changed the water*! (Voice full of wonder) The water wasn't just hot and boring anymore! It was... it was *tea*! (Beams at the teacher) It smelled good and it probably tasted yummy! (Licks lips) So... so the tea leaves didn't get hard or soft... they made something *new*! (Taps chin, thinking hard) Hmmm... Does that mean...? (Looks up, eyes wide with understanding) Does that mean that *some* people, when things get hard, they don't just get hard or soft, but they... they make the world around them better? (Looks at the teacher, a little breathless with excitement) Like... like they make lemonade when life gives them lemons! Is that what it means?!

YES! That's a wonderful way to put it! The tea leaves changed the water itself. They made something new and better!

So, the dad showed his daughter three different ways to respond when things get hard:

1.  Become hard like the egg.
2.  Become soft like the potato.
3.  Change the situation like the tea.

What do you think the story is trying to teach us about how *we* should respond when things get tough? What is the moral of the story?

(Paces in seat, thinking deeply, biting lip)

Okay... okay... (Takes a deep breath) The story is trying to teach us... (pauses, looking up at the ceiling) ...that when things are hard, we can choose to be like the egg and get stronger. (Points to self) Or we can choose to be like the potato and get... (shudders) ...mushy. (Makes a face) But the *best* thing to do... (voice gets louder and more excited) ...is to be like the tea leaves! And change the world around us for the better! (Beams proudly) So... so even when things are hard and bad, we can still make things good! (Looks at the teacher, bouncing with excitement) Did I get it? Did I *really* get it?

You got it! You really, really got it! The story is teaching us that **we decide how to respond to difficult situations.** We can choose to be like the egg, the potato, or the tea. And you're right, the tea leaves show us that even in tough times, we can make things better, not just for ourselves, but for everyone around us.

That's a fantastic understanding of the story! I think you've really learned the lesson. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Needle Tree! That was a long story, wasn't it?

Now, let's talk about it. Who were the main people in the story?

(Confidently) Yes! It was a long story, but I liked it! (Beams)

Umm, the main people were... (Thinking, taps chin) Oh! I know! There were two brothers! (Raises hand excitedly) One was the older brother and the other was the... the younger brother! (Looks at the teacher for confirmation) Is that right? (Slightly nervous) Did I get it right, Teacher? (Bites lip)

Yes, you got it exactly right! Two brothers, an older one and a younger one. Good job!

Now, what was the older brother like? Was he nice?

(Fidgets with hands) Umm... (Looks down, then back up, eyes widening slightly) The older brother? Well... he wasn't very nice. (Slight pause) He was... (searching for the right word) ...mean! (Nods firmly, then looks anxious again) He was *always* mean to the younger brother! (Wrinkles nose) It's not good to be mean, is it? (Looks at teacher with big, hopeful eyes)

You are right! It's not good to be mean. And you're right about the older brother. He *was* mean.

What did the older brother do in the forest?

(Eyes light up, remembering the story) Oh! I know this! (Sits up straighter) He... he chopped firewood! (Puffs out cheeks, pretending to chop) *Chop! Chop! Chop!* (Giggles) And then... and then he sold the firewood at the... (Tilts head, furrowing brow) ...the market! (Looks expectantly at the teacher, hoping for confirmation) Did he make a lot of money, Teacher? (Curious) I wonder if he shared any with his younger brother... (voice trails off, looking sad).

Yes, he chopped wood and sold it at the market. You have a great memory!

Did he share with his younger brother? What do you think? The story doesn't *tell* us, but what *happened* in the story gives you a hint.

(Thinking hard, squints eyes) Hmmm... (Taps fingers on desk) Well... he was mean, right? (Looks up at the teacher, seeking confirmation) And the story said he was *always* mean. (Emphasis on "always") So... (Gasps softly) I don't think he shared! (Voice gets higher with excitement and understanding) Because if he was always mean, he wouldn't be nice and share! (Nods head vigorously, pleased with deduction) He probably kept all the money for himself! (Frowns, shaking head slightly) That's not very kind. (Looks at teacher, slightly worried) Am I right?

You are absolutely right! He probably didn't share. He was being greedy.

Now, what happened when the older brother met the magical tree?

(Leans forward, eyes wide with excitement) Oh! Oh! The magical tree! (Claps hands softly) This is the best part! (Pauses, trying to remember everything) Okay, so... the older brother was chopping wood, *chop, chop*, and then he found this... (searching for the right word) ...this *amazing* tree! (Voice filled with awe) And the tree... (Voice drops to a whisper) ...the tree could talk! (Looks around conspiratorially, then back to the teacher) It begged him not to cut it down! (Pulls a pleading face) And it promised him... (Gasps) ...golden apples! (Eyes sparkle) Shiny, golden apples! (Beams, then suddenly looks worried) But... but the older brother was still mean! (Frowns deeply)

You remembered all of that! Fantastic!

Yes, the older brother *was* still mean. He got the golden apples, but what did he do next?

(Gets fidgety again, a shadow crossing face) Oh... oh yeah... (Stuttering slightly) He... he got... the apples... but he... (Looks down at hands) He wasn't happy! (Voice barely a whisper) He wanted... more... (Looks up at teacher, eyes wide with a hint of fear) He... he tried to cut the tree down anyway! (Gasps, covering mouth with hand) Even after the tree gave him golden apples! (Shakes head sadly) That's... that's really, really greedy! (Looks at teacher, anxiously) Was he being very bad, Teacher? (Worried tone)

He *was* being very bad. He was being greedy and ungrateful.

What happened *then*, when he tried to cut down the tree? What did the tree do?

(Eyes widen again, remembering the dramatic part of the story) Ooh! (Sits up straight, forgetting the anxiety for a moment) The tree... the tree didn't like that *at all*! (Voice full of excitement) So... (Pauses for effect) It showered him with... (Voice drops to a dramatic whisper) ...needles! (Makes a shivering motion with hands) Hundreds and hundreds of sharp, pointy needles! (Winces) Ouch! That must have hurt *so* much! (Looks at teacher, wide-eyed) Did the needles get him everywhere, Teacher? (Curious and slightly worried) I bet he was really, really sorry then! (Nods head emphatically)

Yes, he was covered in needles! And it hurt him very much.

Then, who came to help him?

(Sighs with relief, some of the anxiety fading) Oh! (Beams) His... his younger brother! (Voice full of warmth and happiness) The nice younger brother! (Nods head approvingly) He came and... and carefully... (Mimics pulling something out gently) ...took out all the needles! (Wrinkles nose in sympathy) That was very kind of him! (Looks at teacher, smiling brightly) He was being a good brother! (Proudly) I think he's my favourite character in the story! (Confident declaration)

He *was* very kind. He helped his brother even after his brother had been mean to him.

What happened after the younger brother helped him? Did the older brother say anything?

(Voice softer, more thoughtful) The older brother *finally* said sorry for being mean! (Nods slowly) He apologized for treating his brother badly! (Looks at teacher with a hopeful expression) That's good, right? (Anxious again, needing reassurance) Is it good when people say sorry? (Waiting for the teacher's response)

Yes, it is *very* good when people say sorry. It means they know they did something wrong and they want to make things better.

And what happened after the older brother apologized? What did the magical tree do?

(Looks at the teacher, nodding enthusiastically) And because he said sorry, the tree... (Pauses for dramatic effect) ...gave them *more* golden apples! (Voice full of excitement) Even more than before! (Beams, then adds thoughtfully) Maybe because they were sharing now? (Tilts head, thinking) That's a happy ending! (Voice full of satisfaction) I like happy endings! (Smiles brightly)

That *is* a happy ending! You remembered the whole story so well!

So, the older brother was mean and greedy, and he got needles. The younger brother was kind, and he and his brother got golden apples. What do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea or the message of the story?

(Thinking very hard, face scrunched up in concentration) Hmmm... (Taps fingers on the desk, then suddenly stops) Oh! (Eyes widen with understanding) I think... (Voice thoughtful) I think it's teaching us that... (Pauses, choosing words carefully) ...that it's better to be kind than mean! (Nods head firmly) And... (Searching for the right word) ...and that being greedy is bad! (Wrinkles nose in disgust) Because the mean, greedy brother got needles, and the kind brother got golden apples! (Beams with understanding) So, we should always be kind and share, and not be greedy! (Looks at the teacher, proud of figuring it out) Is that right, Teacher? Did I get the message? (Anxious for confirmation)

Yes, you got it! Being kind is better than being mean, and being greedy is bad. The story shows us that kindness is rewarded. If you are kind, good things will happen.

So, we can say the moral of the story is: Kindness will always be rewarded!

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of King Midas! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it?

First, can you tell me, who gave Midas the golden touch?

(Eyes light up, bounces in seat a little) Oh! Oh! I know! It was Dionysus! (Points finger excitedly) He's the god of wine! Like, the grown-up grape juice, right? Midas did something good for a satyr, and Dionysus gave him a wish! It was a tricky wish though. (Frowns slightly, thinking).

That's right! You remembered all those details! Very good. Dionysus *did* give him a tricky wish.

Why do you think it was tricky? What happened when Midas touched things?

(Confidently) Because everything turned to gold! (Holds up hands and pretends to touch things, making "bling" sounds). A-ha! Gold! Gold! Gold! (Suddenly gets serious) But... but that's the tricky part! Because he couldn't eat! (Looks concerned). And... (Stutters slightly) and his daughter... she turned into gold too! (Looks down, fiddling with fingers). So, it wasn't a good wish at all. It *seemed* good, but it was really... bad! (Looks up, eyes wide) Why would Dionysus give him a wish like that? Was he trying to teach him a lesson?

Excellent observation! You're right, it seemed good at first, but it turned out very bad.

Do you think Dionysus *wanted* to trick Midas? Read that part again where Dionysus grants the wish. What did Dionysus say?

(Thinks hard, tapping chin) Hmmm... (Looks at the teacher with a questioning look) I don't think he *wanted* to trick him, exactly. (Squints eyes, trying to remember) He... he warned him! (Voice gets higher with excitement) He said, "Don't do it!" right? But Midas was all, "No, I want it! Gold, gold, gold!" (Shakes head slowly). So, Dionysus gave him what he wanted, but Midas didn't listen! So, it's kind of... Midas's fault? (Looks at the teacher, seeking confirmation). It's like when Mommy says "Don't eat too much candy!" and I eat too much candy and then my tummy hurts!

You are exactly right! It *is* like the candy! Dionysus warned him, but Midas didn't listen.

Why do you think Midas wanted everything to be gold so badly? What did he think gold would bring him?

(Eyes sparkle, thinking about gold) Ooooh! Gold is shiny! And... (Counts on fingers) You can make crowns out of it! And necklaces! And... (Pauses, thinking deeply) It's worth lots of money, right? So... (Snaps fingers) Midas probably thought if he had gold, he'd be super rich and super happy! (Looks a little less certain). But... he wasn't happy, was he? (Looks at the teacher for an answer). I wonder why he thought gold would make him happy... Is being rich the same as being happy?
That's a very important question! Do *you* think being rich is the same as being happy? What did Midas learn about that? Think about what happened to his food, and to his daughter.

(Pouts and thinks for a moment) Well... (Looks down at hands) If you can't eat your food, even if it's gold... you'll be hungry! (Looks up, eyes widening) And if you can't hug your daughter because she's a gold statue... that's super sad! (Voice cracks a little). So... (Shakes head firmly) being rich is *not* the same as being happy. Midas thought it was, but he was wrong! He learned that family and food are more important than gold! (Looks proud of herself for figuring it out). But... how did he change it back? Did he ask Dionysus to take the golden touch away? (Asks curiously).

You're exactly right! Midas learned that family and being able to eat are more important than being rich.

You're also right that he asked Dionysus to take the golden touch away. He was very sorry and realised he had made a big mistake.

So, what do you think is the lesson of the story? What did Midas learn *not* to do?

(Beams, excited to answer) The lesson is... (Taps chin dramatically) Don't be greedy! (Points finger) And... (Thinks really hard) Listen to people when they try to warn you! (Nods head sagely). And... (Eyes widen with a new thought) Don't wish for things that *seem* good but are really bad! (Claps hands together). It's like... wishing for a giant mountain of candy! It sounds awesome, but then you'd get a tummy ache! (Giggles). Midas should have wished for something like... more friends! Or... (Looks at the teacher) Or maybe he should have just been happy with what he already had! Did he ever get his daughter back to normal? (Concerned expression).

You've understood the story so well! Yes, the lesson is definitely not to be greedy, to listen to warnings, and to be happy with what you have.

And yes, Dionysus felt sorry for Midas and helped him reverse the golden touch, so his daughter became a real girl again. He learned a very important lesson. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about it.

First, tell me, what was the fox looking for?

(Eyes light up, bouncing slightly on my chair) Ooh! Ooh! I know! (Raises hand enthusiastically) The fox was looking for FOOD! He was super duper hungry! Like, tummy-rumbling, gotta-find-something-to-eat hungry! Was he *really* hungry, Teacher? Like, maybe he hadn't eaten all day? (Looks at teacher expectantly, tilting head)
Yes! He was *very* hungry! Good job! And what kind of food did he *finally* see?

(Claps hands together excitedly) He saw GRAPES! Big, juicy, PURPLE grapes! (Stands up straight, stretching arms high) They were *way* up high on the farmer's wall! Did the farmer grow them himself? I bet he did! Grapes are yummy! Are *your* grapes purple, Teacher? (Looks around the room for grapes, then back at the teacher, a little quieter) ...Purple is my favorite color!
Purple *is* a great color! But let's think about the fox and his grapes. He wanted those grapes, right? What did he do to try and get them?

(Puts hand on chin, furrowing brow) Hmmm... (Thinking hard) He... he... he JUMPED! (Jumps up and down a few times). He jumped *really* high! He tried and tried and tried! Did he jump like a frog? (Squats down and jumps like a frog) Ribbit! Ribbit! I jump really high too! Did the fox jump high enough to get the grapes?
He jumped, that's right! Did he get the grapes when he jumped?

(Looks down at my feet, then back up, a little disappointed) No... (Voice gets quieter) He didn't... He kept jumping, but he couldn't reach. (Frowns slightly). Was he sad he couldn't get the grapes? I would be! Maybe he needed a trampoline! A really, *really* bouncy one! (Eyes widen with a new idea) Or a ladder!
He couldn't reach them, even though he tried hard. What did he do *after* he couldn't reach the grapes?

(Thinking hard, tapping finger on desk) He... (Looks away, then back) Oh! I remember! He... he went home! (Shrugs shoulders) But he said something mean! He said the grapes were... sour! (Makes a sour face). But were they *really* sour, Teacher? Maybe they were super sweet and yummy, and he was just saying that because he couldn't get them! (Looks at teacher, questioning)
You're right! He said they were sour. Do you think he *really* thought they were sour?

(Shakes head emphatically) No way! (Stands up again, pointing finger in the air) He was just pretending! He was being a little bit... (Puts hand over mouth, giggling) ...a little bit fibby! Because he was sad he couldn't get them. It's like... like when I can't reach the cookies on the top shelf and I say I don't even *like* cookies that much! (Sits back down, grinning) Is that what it's like, Teacher? Was the fox just being like me with the cookies?

Yes! That's a *great* way to understand it! The fox was like you and the cookies!

So, the fox wanted something, he tried hard to get it, but he couldn't. Then he said he didn't want it anyway.

What do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big idea?

(Gasps, eyes widening) Ooh! Ooh! I know! (Raises hand high, wiggling fingers) Maybe... maybe we shouldn't say mean things about stuff we can't have! (Lowers hand slightly) Because... because maybe it's just making us feel better, but it's not really true! (Thinks for a moment, tapping chin) And... and maybe we should just keep trying! Like, the fox could have found a stick to knock the grapes down! Or asked the farmer nicely! (Looks at teacher expectantly) Is that right, Teacher? Is that the big idea? We should be honest and keep trying? And maybe not say stuff that isn't true just because we're sad?

That's a *wonderful* way to put it!

It's like, things that are really good sometimes take a lot of work to get. And if we can't get them, it's better to remember that we tried our best, instead of saying we didn't want them anyway. It's okay to be sad, but we shouldn't pretend we don't care.

So, we can say the story teaches us that nothing comes easy, and we shouldn't hate what we can’t have. You explained that *so* well! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story, class! That was "The Proud Rose."

Now, can you tell me, who are the main characters in the story?

(Raises hand enthusiastically) Ooh! Ooh! I know! (confidently) The main characters are the rose and the cactus! The rose was super pretty, but not very nice, and the cactus was…well, a cactus! (giggles) He helped the birds, though!

Excellent! You got it!

And what was the rose like in the beginning of the story? Was she happy? Was she friendly?

(Thinking hard) Hmm... she wasn't really happy (shakes head). She was more like... (searches for the right word)... boastful! Yeah, boastful! (smiles, pleased with finding the right word) She thought she was the best and prettiest and she kept telling the cactus that he wasn't as good as her. (Frowns) She wasn't very friendly at all! She was kind of... mean.

Boastful is a great word to describe her! You're doing a fantastic job.

Now, what happened when the summer got really hot? What happened to the rose?

(Eyes widen) Oh! Oh! I know this! (Raises hand again, wiggling fingers) The summer got super, super hot and there was no water! (Looks a little worried) The rose... she started to... (Stutters a little) wi... wi... wither! Yes! Wither! Because she didn't have any water. She wasn't so pretty anymore then! (Looks down for a second, then back up) The cactus was okay though, because he could store water!

That's right! The rose started to wither. And you remembered the word "wither," great job!

Now, what did the cactus do during the hot summer? Remember the birds?

(Eyes light up) Oh! The cactus! He was so nice! Even though the rose was mean to him, he helped the little sparrows! (Claps hands excitedly) He gave them water! He was like a super hero for the birds! (Thinking) I wonder how he stored all that water inside of him? (Looks at teacher inquisitively) Do cacti have like, tiny little water bottles inside?

(Chuckles) That's a very interesting question! Cacti are very good at storing water.

But tell me, what did the *rose* do when she started to wither? Did she keep being boastful? Or did something change?

(Looks down, thinking) Hmm... she couldn't be boastful anymore because she was all sad and thirsty. (Looks up, confidently) She asked the cactus for water! She finally realized that she needed him! Even though she was mean to him before. (Pauses) Was it hard for her to say sorry? I would have been scared to ask for help if I was mean before!

That's a really good point! It probably *was* hard for her to ask for help.

And what did the cactus do when the rose asked for water?

(Smiling widely) He helped her! He gave her water, even though she was mean to him before! He was super kind! (Leans forward eagerly) He's my favorite character! (Pauses, then looks at the teacher with a thoughtful expression) It's like... he showed her that being nice is way better than being boastful, right? Because being nice helps everyone, even if they weren't nice to you first!

You got it! That's exactly right! The cactus was kind even when the rose wasn't.

So, what do you think is the lesson, or the moral, of the story? What did we learn from the rose and the cactus?

(Thinks really hard, tapping a finger on the desk) Okay, okay! (Eyes widen with understanding) I think the moral is... (Pauses for effect, beaming) ... that it's better to be kind than to be boastful! (Confidently) And that even if someone is mean to you, you should still be kind to them, like the cactus! (Smiling proudly) Being helpful and nice is the best! And maybe... (Looks a little shy) ...maybe the rose learned that too!

That is a wonderful lesson to learn from the story! And you explained it so well. Another way to say it is, don't judge someone just by how they look. The rose was pretty, but not kind at first. The cactus might not have looked as pretty, but he was the kindest of all!

You really understood the story, and the message it was trying to tell us. Great job, class! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! Hi there! That was a good reading.

So, tell me, what was Molly going to do with the milk?

(Bouncing on my toes, eager to answer)

Hi! Hi! I *loved* that story! Molly... Molly was going to... um... sell the milk! At the market! (Points excitedly). She was gonna get *money*! And then... and then... (frowns a little, thinking hard) ...she was gonna get a CHICKEN! (voice gets louder and more excited). And the chicken would lay eggs! And she'd get even MORE money! (Sticks out tongue) My plan is better than hers!

(Chuckles softly)

Your plan sounds good too! So, Molly wanted to sell the milk for money. What did she plan to do *after* she sold the milk and got the money?

(Fidgeting with my hands, a little impatient)

Ugh, you *just* asked that! (Rolls eyes). She was gonna get a CHICKEN! (Points to an imaginary chicken). A big, fluffy chicken that lays lots and lots of eggs! Then she'd be RICH! (Puffs out chest proudly). I would buy, like, a *thousand* chickens! And a pony! (Thinking beyond the information) Maybe even a... a *dragon* that lays golden eggs! (Looks away, imagining the dragon)

(Smiling warmly)

A dragon that lays golden eggs! That sounds amazing! But let's get back to Molly for a second. Did she actually *have* the chicken yet?

(Scoffs, impatient again)

Nooo! (Taps foot). She didn't have *anything* yet! Just... milk! (Wrinkles nose). Milk is boring! She was just WALKING to the market! With the milk! (Crosses arms). This is taking too long. Can we talk about dragons now? My idea is way better, dragons are better than chickens because they are bigger and are able to lay golden eggs, she is not even thinking about that. (Voice getting a little louder, bordering on whiny).

(Chuckles)

Dragons *are* pretty cool! But think about this: Molly was planning to get a chicken and *then* eggs, right? But what happened to the milk while she was thinking about all that?

(Glares, then a look of dawning realization slowly spreads across my face. Starts to bite my nails, anxious)

Oh! Oh no! (Stuttering a little) It... it spilled! (Looks down at the floor). All the milk spilled! (Voice drops to a near whisper). Because she was... skipping and... not paying attention! (Starts to tear up a little, remembering the "spilled" part of the story and feeling anxious). She's so silly! I will not skip, I will slowly walk so that the milk does not spill. If I was her, I would use a dragon to carry all of my belongings.
That's right! All the milk spilled. So, did she get the money for the milk?

(Sniffling, mood shifting dramatically, angry now)

NO! (Stamps foot). She's SO dumb! (Pouts). All her fault! Stupid Molly! She shouldn't be thinking about chickens before she sells the milk! (Looks at the teacher with suspicion) Are you going to ask me another question about Molly? I want to talk about dragons now! (Voice is loud and demanding).

(Nodding gently)

You're right, it *was* her fault. She was thinking about the chicken *before* she even sold the milk. So, what do you think Molly learned from what happened?

(Frowns, thinking hard and biting nails again. Nervous)

Umm... (Stutters) Maybe... maybe she learned not to... not to count her chickens...? But she didn't even *have* any chickens! (Confused). So, it doesn't make sense! (Voice gets whinier). Maybe she learned that... dragons are better? (Looks hopefully at the teacher). What did her *mommy* say? Did she say something mean? I think Molly is silly, this is what happens when you are not logical, you end up spilling all of your belongings.

(Smiling encouragingly)

Her mommy said, "Don't count your chickens until they hatch." That means don't *depend* on something until you are sure it will happen. Was Molly sure she would get the money for the milk?

(Eyes widen, a spark of understanding)

Ooooh! (Snaps fingers). So, like... don't spend the money before you *get* the money! (Looks proud). I get it! (Immediately forgets the lesson and gets excited again). So, if I had a dragon... I wouldn't buy a pony until the dragon... laid the golden eggs and I sold them! (Bounces up and down). I'm so smart! I wish she just used a dragon in the story! That would make more sense! Why is she selling milk anyway? Dragons are better! (Tries to change the subject back to dragons). Can we talk about the Big Five now?

(Chuckles softly)

You *are* smart! You understand that Molly shouldn't have planned for the chicken until *after* she sold the milk. So, the story teaches us to wait and be sure before we make plans. You got it! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story about the wise old owl! Did you like it?

Now, tell me, what did the owl like to do every day?

(Bouncing my leg nervously, but speaking loudly)

Yeah, I liked it! (Sticks out tongue a little). But it was kind of… obvious. (Looks at the ceiling, thinking). He... he liked to WATCH stuff! He was always watching things happening around the tree. He saw everything! And he HEARD everything too. People talking and... (stutters a little) and… and sharing stories! Did YOU see everything when YOU were little? (Raises hand, waving it a bit aggressively). Like, ALL the things? (Frowns, waiting for an answer, tapping foot impatiently).

(Smiling gently) That's right! The owl watched and heard everything. That's a very good observation!

Do you think the owl talked a lot? Why or why not?

(Scoffs and rolls eyes).

No! Duh! (Crosses arms, looking away). The story said he spoke LESS! Because he saw SO much! He was probably thinking REALLY hard about all the stuff he saw and heard. He was probably smarter than everyone else because he wasn't yakking all the time like…(glares at the teacher)... some people. He was, like, processing everything. (Nervously picks at fingernails). Is *that* why I'm so smart too? Because I think a lot? (Eyes teacher expectantly, waiting for a response).

(Nodding encouragingly) You're absolutely right! The owl didn't talk much because he was busy watching, listening, and thinking.

Why do you think watching and listening helped the owl become wiser? What did he learn from seeing and hearing all those things?

(Thinking hard, tapping chin with a finger)

Hmm... (Pauses, looking around the room, then back at the teacher). Well, if you just TALK all the time, you don't learn anything NEW! (Voice gets louder). But if you watch and listen, you can learn from other people's mistakes! (Smirks). Or… or… you can figure out secrets! (Whispers conspiratorially) Maybe the owl learned where all the best worms were! (Normal voice, now serious) Or maybe he learned... (frowns) ... how to avoid trouble! (Starts to bite fingernails again, looking anxious). Was there trouble in the forest? Did the owl get into trouble? (Eyes widen with concern). I don't LIKE trouble! (Shifts feet, ready to bolt).

(Calmly) The story doesn't say the owl *got* into trouble. It just says he saw and heard things.

But you're right! If you watch and listen, you can learn how to *avoid* trouble. So, if the owl saw someone making a mistake, what do you think he learned?

(Sighs with relief, relaxing a little, but still fidgeting)

Okay, good, no trouble! (Taps foot again). If he saw someone making a mistake… (ponders, looking intensely at the teacher) …then he learned NOT to do that thing! Like if he saw a squirrel not looking before crossing the road and getting… (makes a squishing sound and a face of disgust)… well, then *he* would remember to look both ways! (Nods head vigorously). Is that what wise people do? Do they just watch everyone else mess up and learn from it? (Voice full of curiosity and a little bit of excitement, leaning forward). Because that seems… easy!

(Smiling) That's a very smart way to think about it! Yes, wise people can learn from the mistakes of others. They pay attention and think about what they see and hear.

So, if the owl mostly watched and listened, what do you think the story is trying to teach *us*? What's the big idea of the story?

(Paces back and forth, muttering to himself)

Okay, okay… watch… listen… learn from mistakes… don't talk too much… be like the owl… (Stops suddenly, pointing a finger in the air). I KNOW! It means… (pauses for dramatic effect) … it means that being QUIET can make you SMART! (Beams proudly, then narrows eyes suspiciously) But… but… does that mean I have to be quiet ALL the time? (Voice wavering, looking panicked) Because that would be BORING! (Throws hands up in the air). I like talking! And asking questions! (Frowns, tapping foot impatiently) Is it okay if I'm just a LITTLE bit wise? Can I still talk sometimes? (Looks pleadingly at the teacher, anxiously awaiting a reply).

(Chuckles softly) It's definitely okay to talk sometimes! The story isn't saying you should *never* talk. It's just saying that it's important to listen and observe too. It's about finding a balance.

So, what do you think the story is trying to tell us about talking and listening? Is one more important than the other, or do they both have their place?

(Eyes the teacher suspiciously, then sits down heavily, crossing arms)

Balance… (Mumbles under breath) Balance is hard! Like riding a bike… (Grimaces) I fell off my bike yesterday! (Changes the subject abruptly, voice getting louder and more confident). But I think… (pauses, thinking deeply, frowning) … I think the story wants us to KNOW that LISTENING is important too! Not just talking. Because I usually just like to TALK (Points to self proudly), but the owl shows us that you can learn stuff if you LISTEN. (Sighs dramatically) I guess I should TRY to listen more… sometimes. (Looks away, kicking at the floor, embarrassed). But I'm still gonna ask lots of questions! (Grins mischievously). Is it okay to ask questions even if you're listening? (Leans forward, waiting for an answer with eager anticipation).

(Nodding enthusiastically) Absolutely! Asking questions is a great way to learn, even when you're listening! It shows you're thinking about what you're hearing.

So, to put it all together, what's the big lesson we can learn from the wise old owl? What's the moral of the story?

(Stands up and starts pacing again, thinking aloud)

Okay, okay... Listen... watch... don't just talk... learn from mistakes... balance... questions... (Stops suddenly, snapping fingers) I GOT IT! (Voice loud and excited). The moral of the story is... (pauses for dramatic effect)... that you can be SMART if you LISTEN and WATCH, but you can be EVEN SMARTER if you ASK QUESTIONS too! (Beams proudly, then immediately starts peppering the teacher with questions) Does that mean I'm super-duper smart now? Can I skip second grade? What's the smartest thing YOU ever learned by listening? What's the smartest thing YOU ever learned by ASKING a question? Huh? Huh? Huh? Tell me! (Bounces up and down impatiently, demanding an answer).

(Smiling warmly) You're definitely thinking like a super-duper smart first grader! You've really understood the story of the wise old owl. You figured out that listening and watching are important, and you also remembered that asking questions helps you learn even more.

The moral of the story is that it's good to talk less and be more observant.

I think you've learned a lot from the wise old owl! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! It was a bit sad, wasn't it?

Let's talk about it. First, what did the goose do every day?

(Fidgets in my seat, tapping my foot impatiently)

Umm... (stares intensely at the teacher, then suddenly looks away) It laid a golden egg! (says it loudly and confidently, practically shouting) Duh! I knew that! It was right there in the story. What else did you think it would do? (scowls a little) Everyone knows geese lay eggs.

(Smiling calmly, despite the outburst)

Yes, you're absolutely right! The goose laid a golden egg. That was very special.

Then the farmer, being *really* smart, went to the... the... (taps forehead, trying to remember) the emperor! Yeah, the emperor! (Beams, proud of remembering) And the emperor's helper... I think they called him a courtier... (frowns, trying to remember better), the courtier was even smarter! He tricked the neighbor! (Giggles) He said the neighbor had to pay rent for the water! (Puffs out chest)

So, the main people are the farmer, the mean neighbor, and the emperor and his... courtier helper! (Looks at the teacher expectantly, waiting to see if I got it all right.) Did I miss anything? Is there rent for the water?

That's a great summary! You remembered all the important parts and the people involved!

Now, why do you think the neighbor didn't want the farmer to use the water? What was the neighbor trying to do?

(Fidgets in seat, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) Ummm... (looks away, a little anxious) I... I don't *really* know... (stutters) M-maybe he was just... (shrugs) ...mean?

Or... or help him with his chores! (Nods emphatically) Yeah! That's it! He was trying to trick the farmer so he could get even MORE stuff! (Looks at the teacher, a bit of a frown on my face) People can be so... (mutters under breath) ...not very nice.

You got it! He was trying to be sneaky and trick the farmer. He thought he could get away with being unfair.

So, the emperor's helper, the courtier, came up with a clever plan. Why do you think the courtier told the neighbor he had to pay rent for the water? How did that make the neighbor feel?

(Eyes narrow, thinking hard. Pushes out my lips) Hmmm... the courtier was *super* smart! (Starts pacing back and forth, even though I'm sitting down, wringing my hands) He... he knew the neighbor was being a big, fat cheat! (Stops pacing suddenly, pointing a finger)

Okay, I get it! If the neighbor *made* the farmer pay for the water, it would be sneaky and unfair, right? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation) But if *he* had to pay for the water... (gasps dramatically) ...that means *he* would have to take the water out of *his own* well! And if he took all the water out, then the well would be empty! He probably felt... (pulls a face, scrunching up nose) ...really, *really* silly! And maybe... (voice gets smaller, a little nervous) ...a little scared? Because he knew he got caught! (Looks down at my hands, feeling a little uneasy) Cheating is bad. (Mumbles) People who cheat get caught!

Yes, you're absolutely right! The courtier's plan showed the neighbor how silly and unfair he was being. The neighbor realized he was caught and that his trick didn't work. He probably felt silly and maybe a little scared.

Now, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the lesson we can learn from "The Farmer and the Well"?

(Starts to bite my nails, then quickly stops myself) Okay, okay, big question! (Looks around the room nervously) What's the lesson... what's the lesson...? (Takes a deep breath, trying to calm down)

(Suddenly, my face lights up) I know! It's about being fair! (Points a finger confidently) The neighbor wasn't fair to the farmer! He tried to trick him and be sneaky! (Frowns) And that's not nice!

You're very close! It IS about being fair and not being a sneaky trickster. What happened to the neighbor in the end? Did his trick work?

So, be fair, be smart, and don't cheat, because you'll get caught like that silly neighbor! (Nods head with determination) Now *that's* the real lesson, right? Right?! (Looks at the teacher with pleading eyes, needing to know I finally got it right)
