dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends."

First, can you tell me who the story is about?

(Bounces in my seat, hand already raised)

It's about an ELEPHANT! (Eyes widen) And... and... (Stutters, biting lip, looking down, fiddling with a loose thread on my shirt) ...um... some other animals. Like a monkey and a rabbit and... a FROG! (Looks up, points finger, but with a slightly nervous, fast voice) But mostly the ELEPHANT! (Sighs dramatically, then blurts out) Is it gonna be a trick question? I'm good at these! Is the elephant the HERO?!

(Smiling warmly) Not a trick question at all! You're doing great!

Yes, the story is mostly about the elephant. And you're right, there are other animals too. Was the elephant happy at the start of the story?

(Scoffs, rolling my eyes, a little rude)

Happy? (Arms crossed, taps foot impatiently) No! Duh! He was LONELY! It said so right there! He was trying to find friends, which means he DIDN'T have any! (Looks at the teacher accusingly) Why would he be happy if he didn't have any friends? That doesn't even make sense! (Suddenly nervous, bites nails) Is... is being lonely bad? (Looks around the room anxiously) Does that mean something bad is gonna happen to the elephant? Because if it does... (Trails off, face crumpling a little) I don't like sad stories! (Looks away).

(Softly) It's okay. Being lonely can feel bad, but the story has a happy ending. Don't worry.

Why was the elephant lonely?

(Sniffs, wipes nose on sleeve)

Because... (Taps fingers on the desk, thinking hard) Because the other animals were... (Wrinkles nose) ...mean! (Frowns) They didn't want to be his friend! The monkey said he couldn't swing! (Gestures wildly with arms) And the rabbit said he was too BIG for the burrow! (Huffs) That's not very nice! They should just LET him play! (Raises hand suddenly) Wait! I have a question! (Eyes narrowed) Why couldn't the elephant swing? Is he too heavy? Could he learn if he practiced? What if they used a REALLY strong rope? (Pulls at the end of my hair while I wait for an answer.)

(Chuckles gently) Those are all good questions! The story doesn't say why exactly the elephant couldn't swing, but maybe he was too heavy, or maybe he just wasn't very good at it.

But you're right, the other animals weren't very nice. They didn't even try to be friends. What happened the next day?

(Sighs dramatically, flopping back in chair)

The next day... (Eyes widen, sitting up straight, excited) The next day the TIGER came! And everyone was SCARED! (Leans forward conspiratorially) Except... except for the ELEPHANT! (Pokes teacher's arm) He wasn't scared! He was... (Struggles for the right word) ...BRAVE! (Beams proudly) He kicked the tiger! (Punches the air) Did he kick him REALLY hard? Did the tiger cry? I bet it did! (Starts humming to myself, a little off-key.) Wait! (Snaps fingers) If the tiger was attacking, why didn't the monkey and the rabbit do something? Were they too scared? Are monkeys and rabbits usually scared of tigers?

(Nods encouragingly) You remembered that part well! Yes, the elephant was very brave.

Why do you think the other animals were scared of the tiger, but the elephant wasn't?

(Scowls, fidgeting with my shoelaces)

Because... (Huffs) Because the elephant is BIGGER! (Stands up suddenly, puffing out my chest) I'm not scared of anything bigger than me! (Sits back down abruptly) Well, maybe a little. (Whispers) But only a little! (Raises hand again, waving it frantically) But wait! If the elephant is bigger, why didn't the tiger just run away when he saw him? Is the tiger dumb? (Glares at the teacher, impatient for an answer) Or maybe the tiger was just trying to be mean like the monkey and the rabbit. (Crosses arms) Mean people are the WORST. (Starts picking at a scab on my knee).

(Patiently) That's a good idea. Maybe the tiger thought he was stronger, even if he wasn't bigger.

After the elephant scared the tiger away, what did the other animals think about him?

(Eyes light up, clapping hands together)

They liked him! They finally liked him! (Jumps up and down a little) They thought he was... (Squints eyes, trying to remember) ... PERFECT! (Sticks tongue out a little, pleased with myself) Because he saved them! So they wanted to be his friend! (Frowns slightly) But that's not very nice, is it? Only liking him when he saved them? Shouldn't they have been his friend even before he kicked the tiger? (Taps chin thoughtfully) I think they should have said sorry! Should I write them a letter telling them to say sorry? They were rude to the elephant and that isn't very kind! (Looks expectantly).

(Nods thoughtfully) You're right, it might have been nicer if they had been friendly from the start.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Paces back and forth in front of my desk, thinking hard, chewing on my lip)

It's trying to teach us... (Stops pacing, points a finger in the air) ...that it's good to be BRAVE! (Shakes head) No, that's not it. (Starts pacing again, faster this time, mumbling to myself) ...and that people should be NICE! (Stops again, looking frustrated) But it's also... (Eyes widen, stops pacing abruptly) ...that even if people are mean to you at first... (Looks up at the teacher, nervous) ...they might like you later? (Voice gets quieter) But only if you do something... something BIG? (Sits down heavily, picks at my fingernails) Is that what it means? Does it mean I have to kick a tiger to make friends? (Looks genuinely worried, on the verge of tears).

(Reassuringly) No, no! You don't have to kick a tiger to make friends!

Think about why the animals didn't want to be friends with the elephant at first. What was the reason?

(Sniffles, wiping my eyes with the back of my hand)

Because... because he was different! (Looks down at my shoes, scuffing them against the floor) He couldn't swing, he was too big, he couldn't jump... (Voice muffled) They didn't like him because he was... different. (Looks up suddenly, angrily) But that's STUPID! Being different is GOOD! (Stands up on my chair, arms crossed, glaring) I'm different! I ask lots of questions! (Looks down, fidgets) And sometimes I talk too much... But that doesn't mean people shouldn't be my friend! (Jumps down from the chair, a bit shaky) So... so the story means that you should be friends with people even if they're different? (Looks at the teacher, hopeful) Is that right? Is *that* the big idea? (Waits anxiously, biting my lip).

(Smiling broadly) Yes! You got it! The story is about how friends can be different shapes and sizes. The elephant was different from the other animals, but he still became their friend.

So, what's the lesson? Should we only be friends with people who are exactly like us?

(Shakes head vehemently, eyes wide, almost shouting)

NO! That's the silliest thing I ever heard! (Stomps foot) If everyone was the same, then everything would be BORING! (Calms down a little, tapping chin thoughtfully) Like, if everyone liked the same color, then all the crayons would be the same! And if everyone liked the same game, then we could only play *one* game! (Gasps dramatically) And what if everyone liked the same flavor of ice cream? What if EVERYONE liked broccoli?! (Makes a face) Yuck! (Points to the teacher, confidently) So, the lesson is... (Puffs out chest) ...is that it's good to be friends with people who are different, because being different is AWESOME! (Beams proudly, then adds quickly, a little nervously) ...Right? I got it right, didn't I? (Fidgets with my hands, looking for approval).

(Nods enthusiastically) Absolutely right! You understand the story perfectly! Friends can be any shape or size, and being different is what makes the world interesting! You did a wonderful job! <finish>

dialogue: Okay! That was a good story, right? Now, can you tell me, what did the girl feel at the beginning of the story?

(Rolls eyes) Duh! She asked her *dad* for help! I mean, who else would she ask? The dog? (crosses arms) (Stuttering) S-she probably already tried asking her friends, but they’re all, like, totally clueless. My friends are. (looks away, picks at a loose thread on shirt) So, yeah. Dad. Because dads are supposed to know everything, right? Even though mine doesn’t always.

(Raises hand eagerly, almost knocking over a pencil) He BOILED them! (Slight pause, thinking intensely) In… water! In three different pots! (Pauses, deep in thought) He was testing something. I bet he knew what would happen! He's a dad, after all. But... (Frowns) what *was* he testing?
You're doing great! Yes, he boiled them in separate pots. Now, think about *what happened* to the egg, the potato, and the tea leaves *after* they were boiled. Did they stay the same?

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed) Okay, okay... (Taps chin) The egg... it was squishy before, right? (Shrugs) Like, if you dropped it, it would break. But after... (Eyes widen) It was HARD! Like a rock! (Looks up, excited) The potato was the opposite! It was hard before, and then it got all… mushy! (Makes a disgusted face) Blah. And the tea... (Pauses, thinking deeper) The tea... it didn't change itself. It changed the WATER! (Confidently) It made the water all brown and tea-y! It's like magic! (Bounces in seat a little)

(Crosses arms again, looking a little annoyed) Ugh, this is getting confusing. (Stares at the ceiling) So, the boiling water is, like, the problem, right? (Snaps fingers) Okay, I get it!

(Points finger in the air) The egg is like someone who starts out all soft and… (struggles for the right word) …sensitive! And then, when bad stuff happens, they get all hard and tough. Like, they don't care anymore. They become like… a grumpy rock!

(Points again) The potato is the opposite! They start out all tough, like they can handle anything. But then the problem, the hot water, makes them all… (makes a squishing motion with hands) …soft and weak! They can't handle anything anymore! They just… give up! (Shudders dramatically)

(Pauses, thinking hard, then gets a mischievous glint in eyes) And the tea leaves… (leans forward conspiratorially) they’re the *coolest*! They don’t change themselves! They change the problem! They make the hot water into something *good*! They're like… superheroes! (Sits back, grinning proudly) Did I get it right? This is hard!

Yes! You got it exactly right! That was fantastic!

So, thinking about the girl in the story, and the egg, the potato, and the tea... what do you think the *real* point of the story is? What was the dad trying to teach his daughter?

(Taps foot impatiently, picks at fingernails) Okay, so the dad… (thinks hard, chewing on lip) He was trying to say… (scoffs) that life stinks, but you have to pick what you want to be, right? (Looks up at the teacher, a little challenging) Are you gonna be a hard egg and be all grumpy? Or a mushy potato and give up? Or… (eyes light up again) …are you gonna be tea and make everything better? (Stands up suddenly, pushing chair back slightly) I wanna be tea! Tea is the best! (Sits back down, but still bouncing slightly) So, yeah. Don't be a grumpy egg or a mushy potato. Be TEA! That's the point!

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Needle Tree! That was a long story, wasn't it?

Let's talk about it. What did the older brother do for work?

(Bounces in my seat, already raising my hand, then lowers it slightly, impatient to answer)

Umm, umm, he... (stuttering slightly, but trying to sound smart) He, like, chopped wood, right? In the forest! (eyes widen, remembering) He... he sold it! At the market! (confidently) I knew that! (starts tapping my foot impatiently) Is that all? (looks around the room, a bit bored)

Yes! That's right! He chopped wood and sold it at the market.

Now, what did he find in the forest one day?

(Raises hand again, almost before the teacher finishes the question, practically jumping out of my seat)

A magical tree! (eyes shining, I lean forward) It, like, talked! (uses air quotes) "Don't cut me down!" (imitates a squeaky voice, then scoffs) Silly tree! (crosses arms, unimpressed) But it gave him... (pauses, thinking hard, furrowing brow) ... golden apples! (snaps fingers, triumphant) He should have been happy! Stupid tree.

You're doing great! He did find a magical tree that gave him golden apples.

Was the older brother happy with the golden apples?

(Scoffs, rolling my eyes)

Happy? (scoffs again, louder) No way! (puffs out cheeks) He's, like, super greedy! (leans in conspiratorially, whispering loudly) He wanted more! He's so dumb! (taps head with finger, giggling) I wouldn't have cut down the tree. Maybe. (looks away, momentarily unsure, then back confidently) I would have asked for a golden castle! With a golden slide! (claps hands excitedly)

Okay! You're right, he wasn't happy. He was greedy.

What happened when he tried to cut the tree down anyway?

(Eyes widen, leans forward, practically vibrating with excitement)

The tree! The tree got him back! (claps hands again) It, like, exploded with needles! (makes exploding hand motion) Hundreds and hundreds! All over him! (giggles, a bit meanly) Serves him right! (crosses arms, satisfied, then pauses, tilting head) Wait... did it hurt? (a flicker of concern crosses my face, quickly replaced by a smirk) Probably tickled a little.

Yes, the tree showered him with needles! Ouch!

Who helped him after that?

(Sighs dramatically, rolling eyes)

Ugh, his brother. (makes a face) The *little* brother. (emphasizes the "little" with a sneer) He was, like, all nice and... (waves hand dismissively) …helpful. Taking out all those stupid needles. (fidgets in seat, unimpressed) Boring! Why couldn’t a bear have found him? A bear would have just eaten the apples and left him there! (giggles mischievously)

You're right, his little brother helped him. He took out all the needles.

How did the older brother feel after his little brother helped him?

(Sighs, drumming fingers on the desk, clearly impatient)

Ugh, he probably said "thank you" or something. (air quotes) I bet he didn’t mean it! He's probably still greedy! (scowls) But... (pauses, thinking, chewing on lip) ... the tree, like, gave them more apples, right? (looks up, searching for confirmation) So maybe... maybe he felt a little bit sorry. Just a little! (holds up fingers, showing a tiny space) He should have! He was being a big meanie!

He did apologize. He said sorry for being mean to his little brother.

What happened after he apologized? What did the tree do?

(Eyes widen, leaning forward, the boredom completely gone)

More apples! (claps hands, excited again) The tree liked that he said sorry! (beams, then frowns slightly) So… being nice gets you golden apples? (taps chin thoughtfully, then shrugs) Maybe. But golden castles are better! (a mischievous glint returns to my eyes) I still want a golden slide! (bounces in seat again)

Yes! The tree gave them more golden apples because the older brother said sorry.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Scoffs, rolling my eyes a little, but also thinking hard)

Ugh, it's probably one of those… (air quotes) “be nice to your brother” things. (frowns) And… and don’t be greedy! (snaps fingers) But that's boring! (brightens up) I think it’s really about the magical tree! It's, like, super powerful! It can give you apples *and* shoot you with needles! (giggles) That’s way cooler than just being nice! (pauses, then adds grudgingly) Maybe… maybe being sorry is okay, if it gets you more golden apples. But only then!

You're very close! The story *is* about being nice and not being greedy. And it's about what happens when you *are* nice. Think about what happened *after* the older brother was mean and *after* he apologized. What did he get *after* he apologized?

(Thinking hard, tapping a finger on the desk, then a lightbulb seems to go off)

Okay, okay! (bounces in seat, excited again) So, if you’re mean and greedy, you get needles! (shudders dramatically) But if you say sorry, even if you don't really mean it... (whispers conspiratorially) ...you get more golden apples! (beams, then adds quickly) So being sorry is smart! You get stuff! (nods decisively) It's not just about being nice! It’s about getting golden apples! (a satisfied grin spreads across my face) I'm so smart! (puffs out chest proudly)
You *are* smart! It's not just about *getting* golden apples, though. Think about why the tree gave them more apples *after* the older brother was kind. What does it mean to be kind?

(Frowns, tilting head, actually thinking this time, a bit frustrated)

Ugh, but the apples! (sighs dramatically, then mutters) Kind… (pauses, then looks up, a glimmer of understanding in eyes) … like… not being mean? (hesitates) Sharing? (makes a face, then adds quickly) With *some* people, maybe. (shrugs) Like… if the little brother got *all* the golden apples, that wouldn’t be fair! So… (pauses, thinking)… being kind means… (struggles to find the words) …not being a total jerk all the time? And then… (eyes widen) … the tree gives you stuff! (beams, understanding dawns) I get it! (claps hands excitedly)

You got it! Being kind means not being mean, and sharing. And in the story, the tree gave them more apples because the older brother was finally kind to his younger brother. The story is trying to teach us that kindness is often rewarded. If you are kind, good things might happen!

So, what's the big idea of the story? Can you say it in your own words?

(Stands up straight, puffs out chest, and says with confidence)

Okay! The big idea is: Don’t be a big meanie or you’ll get needles! But if you say sorry and are a little bit nice – just a little! – then maybe you’ll get golden apples! So being kind is smart… because you get stuff! (sits down with a satisfied thump, grinning proudly) I’m the best at this! Can we read another story now? One with dragons and treasure! (starts bouncing in seat, impatient again)

You explained that very well! The story shows us that when we are kind, good things can happen. Kindness is rewarded.

Do you understand the story and what it is trying to teach us?

(Nods head vigorously, then leans forward conspiratorially)

Yeah, yeah! Be nice… get stuff! Got it! (pauses, tapping finger on chin) But if there's a dragon with treasure, should I be nice to *him*? (eyes gleam mischievously) Or should I just take the treasure? (grins, clearly leaning towards the treasure option) Hmmm… this needs more thinking! (starts tapping foot impatiently, clearly ready to move on)
Okay! I think you understand the story of the Needle Tree and its message about kindness. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, let's talk about the story!

You just read "The Golden Touch". Can you tell me what King Midas wished for?

(Eyes wide, practically bouncing in my seat) I KNOW! I KNOW! He wished that everything he touched would turn to GOOOOOLD! (Flaps hands excitedly) It was SO cool! But… (frowns slightly) I don't get why he didn't think about his food first! (Looks at the teacher, tilting head) Why didn't he think about that? That's not very logical, is it? He should have made a *different* wish! Like...like the ability to fly! That would be *way* better than gold. (Crosses arms impatiently).

Wow, you really remember the story well! You're right, turning everything to gold sounds cool at first.

But you also noticed something important. Midas didn't think about *everything* that would happen, did he? He didn't think about food.

What happened when he tried to eat?

(Scoffs and rolls eyes) Ugh, obviously, it turned to gold! (Taps foot impatiently) I *told* you he wasn't very logical! If I had the golden touch, I would have made a super-special plate that *only* I could use, and it wouldn't turn my food to gold! See? That's way smarter! (Looks away briefly) But then he couldn't eat. (Sticks out tongue in disgust) Yuck, gold-flavored everything. He should have thought that through more... (taps fingers on the desk)

You're being a very clever thinker! You are right, he didn't think it through.

So, he couldn't eat. Was he happy then? Did he still like his wish?

(Scoffs again, even louder this time) HAPPY? Are you kidding me? (Leans forward, almost shouting) Of COURSE he wasn't happy! He couldn't EAT! dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was the story of The Fox and the Grapes.

First, can you tell me who the main character was in the story?

(Stands up straight, puffs out chest, and raises hand high even though teacher is looking right at me.)

The fox! (Points emphatically at the book) It was OBVIOUSLY the fox! He was super hungry, right? I knew that from the BEGINNING! Are we gonna talk about the grapes now? They were purple! Did the farmer spray them with something? Maybe that's why the fox couldn't reach them! (Sits back down with a slight thump)

Yes, the fox was the main character! Good job!

You're right, he was very hungry. What did the fox want to eat?

(Rolls eyes) The GRAPES! DUH! Were you even listening? They were right THERE on the wall! (Points again at the book, jabbing the page with a finger). Big and juicy and PURPLE! You said that already! I pay attention! (Crosses arms and scowls slightly) I bet I know more about grapes than YOU do! Did you know there are green grapes TOO? And red ones? I like the green ones best. But those PURPLE ones looked good, even though the fox couldn't get them.

(Chuckles softly) Yes, the grapes! You're right, and you're very good at paying attention. I *do* know about green and red grapes too!

So, the fox wanted the purple grapes. What did he *do* to try and get them?

(Sighs dramatically and taps foot impatiently)

He JUMPED! He jumped REALLY high! He tried and tried and tried! (Stands up again and jumps up and down, reaching towards the ceiling). See? Like THIS! I bet *I* could get those grapes! (Sits back down abruptly) But the fox couldn't. He wasn't strong enough. Maybe he needed a ladder. Or maybe... (taps chin thoughtfully) maybe he needed a FRIEND to help him! But he didn't ask anyone. He just kept jumping. Which was kinda dumb, don't you think? (Looks at teacher expectantly)

That's a *great* idea - maybe a friend could have helped! You're right, the fox kept jumping.

And what happened when he kept jumping and jumping? Did he get the grapes?

(Scoffs) NO! (Shakes head vigorously) He didn't get ANY grapes! That's why he was so mad! He jumped and jumped and jumped and they were just hanging there, all juicy and purple and...taunting him! (Makes a frustrated face). It's like when I want a cookie and Mom says "Not until after dinner!" It's RIGHT THERE but I can't HAVE it! The fox probably felt the SAME way! (Folds arms and looks away, muttering) Stupid grapes...

You're exactly right! He couldn't get them, no matter how hard he tried.

What did the fox do *after* he couldn't reach the grapes? What did he say?

(Eyes narrow, thinking hard) Hmmm... Okay, okay, I remember! (Snaps fingers). He said...he said... (pauses dramatically) ...he said the grapes were SOUR! (Voice drips with disdain) "Those grapes are probably sour anyway!" He was just saying that 'cause he was mad! He didn't REALLY think they were sour! He was just trying to make himself feel better! (Points an accusing finger) He was being a big, fat LIAR! (Looks intently at the teacher, waiting for agreement). Isn't he?

(Nods slowly) You're very clever! Yes, I think he probably *was* trying to make himself feel better. He didn't want to admit he couldn't get them.

So, why do you think the story tells us that the fox said the grapes were sour? What does that tell us about the fox?

(Paces back and forth in front of the desk, hands on hips) Okay, this is a HARD one! (Stops pacing and looks at the ceiling, thinking). Hmmm... It tells us... it tells us... (snaps fingers again) ...that he's a BAD sport! Yeah! A REALLY bad sport! He couldn't get what he wanted, so he tried to make it seem like he didn't even WANT it in the first place! (Crosses arms and glares). That's what my little brother does when he loses a game. He says "I didn't even WANT to win!" It's the SAME THING! The fox is just like my baby brother! (Wrinkles nose in disgust) He's acting like a BABY! (Sits down heavily).

(Smiles) That's a great comparison to your brother! You're right, he was being a bad sport.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea the story wants us to learn? It's okay if you don't know right away. Think about the fox, the grapes, and how he acted.

(Pushes out bottom lip and squints at the teacher) Okay, lemme think. (Taps fingers on the desk, making a drumming sound). So, the fox wanted something really bad... and he couldn't get it... and then he lied about it... (Eyes widen) ...Maybe it's telling us that it's okay to be sad when you don't get what you want! (Voice gets louder and more excited). But you shouldn't LIE about it! You should just say "I'm sad I didn't get those grapes!" or "I'm sad I lost the game!" and not be a big, fat liar like the fox! (Pushes chair back slightly and stands up straight, beaming proudly) Is that it? Is that the answer? I BET it is! I'm SO smart! (Waits expectantly for praise)

That's a *fantastic* answer! You're right, it's better to be honest about how you feel.

The story is *also* trying to teach us something else: that it's important to not hate things just because you can't have them. It is also about not giving up after you have tried so many times!

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Proud Rose!

Now, can you tell me who the story is about?

(Standing tall, arms crossed, looking a little bored)

Uhm, yeah, I read it. (Rolls eyes slightly). It's about a ROSE! And... and a cactus. (Sighs) Is that all? That was, like, super easy. I knew that before you even asked! It said it right at the beginning. I already get it. (Starts tapping foot impatiently). Can we do something harder now? Maybe something with, like, dinosaurs? I know *tons* about dinosaurs!

(Smiling patiently)

That's right! A rose and a cactus. Good job.

Now, what did the rose think about itself? Was it happy or sad?

(Scoffs) Happy? The rose was, like, *totally* into itself. (Puffs out chest and makes a face). It thought it was the best, the prettiest, the... the most *amazing* flower ever! It kept bragging to the cactus and all the other plants. (Looks away, muttering under breath) Stupid rose. I bet it wasn't even *that* pretty. (Looks back, confidently) I knew that too! That was in, like, the first paragraph.

(Nodding)

You're right! The rose thought it was very beautiful.

And what did the rose think about the cactus?

(Wrinkles nose)

Ugh, the cactus? It thought the cactus was, like, super ugly and... and pokey! (Points finger aggressively). It kept making fun of it! Calling it names and stuff. (Shrugs) Like the cactus was, you know, *nothing*. (Looks at the teacher, impatiently) Is this leading to something? Because I already know what happens. The rose runs out of water, right? Can we just skip to the end?

(Maintaining a calm and encouraging tone)

Yes, you're remembering the story very well! The rose wasn't very nice to the cactus.

Why do you think the rose was so mean to the cactus?

(Thinking hard, furrowing brow)

Hmm... (Paces back and forth a little). Maybe... maybe it was trying to make itself feel better? Like, if it said the cactus was ugly, then it would feel even MORE pretty? (Stops pacing, points a finger). Or maybe it was just a bully! Some plants are just jerks! (Crosses arms again, looking smug) I bet if I was a flower, I'd be way nicer. But I'd still be the prettiest. Just saying.

(Chuckles softly)

That's a good thought. Maybe it was trying to make itself feel better.

Now, what happened when the summer got really hot and dry? What happened to the rose?

(Taps foot impatiently)

Duh! (Rolls eyes). The rose started to, like, wilt and dry up! It was all sad and droopy because there was no water. (Makes a wilting motion with hands). Serves it right for being so mean! I knew that part too. It's obvious, right? If you don't have water in the desert, you die! (Looks at the teacher, waiting for the next question). Are we almost done? I want to draw dinosaurs.

(Smiling encouragingly)

You are doing a great job remembering the story!

What was the cactus doing while the rose was wilting?

(Scoffs) The cactus? Oh, it was being all... helpful! (Makes air quotes). It was, like, saving the sparrows or something. (Thinking hard). Yeah, they were drinking water from it! (Shrugs). I guess it was storing water or whatever. It was being all...heroic. (Looks away, mumbling). Even though it was ugly. (Looks back, confidently) I knew that!

(Nodding)

That's right! The cactus was helping the sparrows.

So, the rose is thirsty, and the cactus is helping others. What does the rose do then?

(Sighs dramatically)

Fine, fine, I'll tell you. (Rolls eyes). The dumb rose... it finally asks the cactus for water! (Raises eyebrows). Can you believe it? After being so mean! It was probably all, "Oh, please, *ugly* cactus, can you spare a drop for *me*, the most beautiful flower ever?" (Mimics a whiny voice). Pathetic! I would *never* ask someone I was mean to for help. Unless... unless I was, like, *really* thirsty. (Thinking) Hmm...

(Waiting patiently)

And what does the cactus do when the rose asks for help?

(Hesitates for a moment, then scowls)

Ugh, the cactus is all... nice! (Says "nice" with obvious disdain). It just gives the rose the water! Even after the rose was a total jerk! (Shakes head in disbelief). I would have told the rose to, like, go find its own water! (Crosses arms defiantly). But the cactus is all...forgiving. (Mumbles under breath). Stupid forgiving cactus. Now can I go draw dinosaurs? I *really* know a lot about dinosaurs.

(Smiling)

The cactus *was* very forgiving.

Now, think about the whole story. The rose was pretty but mean, and the cactus was...well, what was the cactus like?

(Thinking hard, tapping chin)

The cactus... well, it was ugly, I guess. (Shrugs). But it was also... helpful. And... and strong! 'Cause it could store water and live in the desert. (Pauses). And... forgiving! 'Cause it helped the rose even after the rose was mean. (Looks at the teacher, a little less impatiently). So, it was... good? Even though it was ugly. (Frowns). This is getting kinda boring. Can we talk about dinosaurs now? Like, did you know the Tyrannosaurus Rex had teeth as big as bananas?!

(Smiling encouragingly)

Yes, the cactus was good, even though the rose thought it was ugly.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What is the story telling us about being pretty or ugly, or about being kind or mean?

(Sighs loudly and leans back)

Okay, okay, I get it! (Rolls eyes). It's trying to say... it's trying to say that being pretty doesn't matter as much as being... nice. And that even if you're ugly, you can still be a good person... I mean, plant. And that even if someone is mean to you, you should still, like, help them if they need it. (Looks away, muttering). Whatever. It's still a boring story. Dinosaurs are way cooler. They eat meat and roar and stuff! (Looks back, hopefully). Can we PLEASE talk about dinosaurs now? Or maybe draw them? I promise I'll be good.

(Smiling warmly)

You got it! The story is trying to teach us that we shouldn't judge people (or plants!) just by how they look. It's what's inside that matters.

So, what is the moral of the story?

(Grumbling slightly, but slightly more engaged)

The... the moral? (Thinks for a moment, tapping a finger on the desk). Uh... the moral is... don't be a jerk like the rose? And... be helpful and forgiving like the cactus? (Shrugs). And... looks can be deceiving? (Looks up, brightening). But seriously, can we PLEASE talk about dinosaurs now? I even brought my dinosaur book! (Pulls a colorful dinosaur book from backpack). See? I'm super prepared!

(Beaming with pride)

Yes, you are right! Don't judge someone according to how they look! Well done! <finish>

dialogue: Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about Molly. What was Molly going to do with the milk?

(Fidgets a little, but smiles brightly)

Molly? She was gonna... (pauses, thinking, taps chin) She was gonna sell it at the market! For money! (Puffs out chest) I knew that! That's, like, the easiest part! She was gonna be, like, super rich! (Eyes widen, imagining riches) Can *I* sell milk and get rich too? (Looks at the teacher expectantly, before they can answer I ask) Does selling eggs REALLY make you rich? Because chickens poop a lot!
(Chuckles softly) Selling milk and eggs *can* help you earn money, but maybe not super rich right away! But let's focus on Molly. What did she *plan* to do with the money she got from the milk?

(Scoffs, rolls eyes) Okay, okay, I remember! (Taps fingers on the table impatiently) She was gonna buy a...a CHICKEN! (Eyes light up again) A chicken that lays eggs! And then she'd sell *those* eggs, and get even *more* money! (Grins mischievously) See? I *told* you I was thinking! It's like a super-smart plan, right? Way better than just selling milk! (Looks away briefly, considering) Maybe she should have bought, like, ten chickens! Then she REALLY would be rich! (Confidently) That's what *I* would do!
That's a very ambitious plan! But what happened to the milk while Molly was thinking about chickens and eggs?

(Wrinkles nose, a little impatient) Ugh, that's the dumb part! (Crosses arms) She spilled it! All of it! (Raises voice slightly) She was skipping and being all happy and whoosh! Milk everywhere! (Gestures wildly with hands) What a waste! (Shakes head, looking disapproving) I would *never* spill my milk! That's just... (struggles for the right word) ...inefficient! (Nods, pleased with the word choice)
You're right, that *was* a waste. How did Molly feel after she spilled the milk?

(Shrugs, not particularly sympathetic) Probably sad. (Thinks for a second) Maybe even... (searches for a bigger word) ...devastated? Yeah, devastated! (Nods firmly) But she was dumb to skip like that in the first place! (Scoffs) I would have walked really carefully and made sure I didn't spill *any*! Then I'd have all that milk money AND all the egg money! (Grins triumphantly) Plus, she went home with nothing! That's even dumber!
So, Molly went home with empty pails and no money. What did her mother say to her?

(Rolls eyes, mimicking a disapproving tone) "Don't count your chickens before they hatch!" (Makes air quotes around the saying). It's like... (taps chin, thinking) it's like... you shouldn't get all excited about something until it's actually happened! (Nods, understanding dawning) I GET IT! It's like when I think I'm gonna get a gold star on my spelling test, but then I spell "because" wrong! (Makes a face) Then no gold star! (Looks at the teacher expectantly) Is that right? Am I super smart?
Yes, that's exactly right! You *are* super smart! So, what's the lesson we can learn from Molly's story? What should we remember *not* to do?

(Beams, preening) Okay, okay, I got this! (Points finger in the air, thinking hard) We shouldn't... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...we shouldn't PLAN too much before things actually HAPPEN! (Nods emphatically) Like, don't buy the castle before you win the lottery! Or don't name all your baby chicks before they even come out of the egg! (Grins mischievously) And definitely don't skip with a pail of milk! (Pauses, then adds importantly) Unless you *want* to spill it. Which would be really stupid.
Excellent! You understand the story perfectly! You know what Molly did wrong, and you know the lesson we can learn from her mistake. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "A Wise Old Owl."

Now, tell me, what did the owl like to do every day?

(Bounces in my seat, hands waving excitedly) I KNOW! I KNOW! He watched stuff! (Points at an imaginary tree) He watched all the things happening around his tree! People talking and stuff! (Uses big words) He *observed* the incidents!

(Looks at the teacher expectantly, waiting for praise. Then taps my foot impatiently.) Is that right? Did I get it right? What's next?

Yes, you got it exactly right! He watched and observed. Good job using the word "observed"!

Now, did the owl talk a lot?

(Shakes head emphatically, almost too fast) Nope! Not much! The story said... the more he saw, the LESS he talked! (Crosses arms, looks a little bored) That's pretty easy. I knew that already. Why didn't he talk much? (Asks a question back, tilting head, already thinking about the next thing)
That's a great question! Why do *you* think he didn't talk much? Think about all the things he was doing.

(Taps chin with a finger, eyes darting around, then face lights up) Hmmm... (Uses a complex word) Maybe he was *analyzing* everything! Like, he was listening to all the stories and thinking about them REALLY hard. (Looks away, pondering) He was probably so busy thinking he didn't have time to talk! (Confidently) Yeah! That's it! He was thinking instead of talking! It's like... like when I'm building my Lego spaceship, I don't talk much 'cause I'm too busy building! (Grins proudly)

That's a wonderful comparison to your Lego spaceship! You're right, he was thinking and listening.

So, because he watched and listened so much, what happened to the owl? The story tells us.

(Rolls eyes slightly, then points a finger in the air) He got... (pauses dramatically) ...Wiser! He became a *wise* old owl! (Puffs out chest) Because he listened and thought a lot! It's all about learning, right? Like me! I'm learning lots in first grade! (Asks another question back, quickly) What kind of stories did he hear? The story didn't say *what* kind!

You are right, it *is* all about learning! And you're doing a great job in first grade! The story doesn't tell us exactly what kind of stories he heard, but maybe they were happy stories, sad stories, silly stories... all kinds!

But let's go back to the owl for a second. What do you think the story is trying to teach *us* about talking and listening?

(Scrunches up nose, a sign of deep thought) Hmmm... (Paces back and forth in front of the desk) Okay, okay, I got it! (Stops pacing and points at the teacher) It's saying that we should listen more than we talk! (Confidently) Because if we listen, we can learn things! And if we learn things, we can get... (searches for the word) ...wiser! (Snaps fingers) Like the owl! (Gets a sly look on my face) So, maybe *you* should listen to *me* more! (Giggles, then asks another question) Does that mean you think owls are smarter than people?

(Laughs gently) That's a very good point! And I *am* listening to you! You are doing a fantastic job understanding the story.

So, if you were going to tell someone what the story teaches us, what would you say? How would you explain what we should do?

(Thinks hard, tapping a pencil on the desk) Okay, if I was telling my little brother... (makes a face) ...I would say, "Hey! Shut your mouth and open your ears! (Corrects myself quickly) Uh, I mean... listen more than you talk! Because if you listen, you'll learn stuff and get smarter like a wise old owl! (Grins, very pleased with myself) And then you won't be so annoying!" (Whispers the last part) Can I go draw now? This story is kinda boring. (Starts fidgeting)

(Smiles) You explained that perfectly! You're right, the story is about listening and learning. And maybe being a little less chatty sometimes.

The story is teaching us that it is good to "Talk less and be more observant".

You really understood the story of the wise old owl. Great job! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! Great job reading the story! That was "The Golden Egg."

First, can you tell me in your own words, what happened in the story? Just tell me the important things.

(Jumping up and down, nearly tripping over my own feet) Ooh! Ooh! I know! I know! (Runs to the front of the room and points at an imaginary goose on the floor) There was this farmer, see? And he had a goose that pooped out GOLDEN eggs! Real GOLD! (Confidently) He got to sell them and get lots and lots of money! But (frowns, crosses arms), he was dumb! (Rolls eyes) He wanted MORE! More, more, more! He was like, "I want all the golden eggs NOW!" (Paces back and forth, getting closer to the teacher). So, he CUT OPEN the goose! (Looks away, then back at the teacher, unimpressed) But there were no eggs inside, just yucky guts! (Makes a disgusted face). (Confidently) And then he was super poor because he had NO golden eggs anymore! That's what happened!

Wow! That's a great telling of the story! You remembered all the important parts.

Why do you think the farmer cut open the goose?

(Taps foot impatiently) Well, duh! (Rolls eyes). Because he was GREEDY! (Raises voice slightly, bordering on rude). He wanted ALL the golden eggs RIGHT NOW! (Thinking) Like, he didn't want to wait for one each day. That's SLOW! He thought he could get them all at once if he just... (makes cutting motion with hand) ... opened her up! (Shrugs, completely unsympathetic). He was a dummy! (Asks a question) Why didn't he just wait? Golden eggs are awesome!

You're right, he was greedy. And he didn't want to wait.

Do you think cutting open the goose was a smart thing to do? Why or why not?

(Scoffs) (Points finger accusingly) No way! (Confidently) It was the DUMBEST thing EVER! (Thinking hard) Because... because the goose was GONE! (Starts to explain excitedly) If he waited, he would have gotten a golden egg EVERY. SINGLE. DAY! That's like, infinity golden eggs! (Stands up straighter, proud of self) But now? (Shakes head with a look of pity) He has ZERO golden eggs. (Asks a challenging question) Why would anyone do that? It's not logic!

You're exactly right! It *was* a very silly thing to do.

So, at the beginning of the story, the farmer was doing okay, right? He had a golden egg every day. What happened to his life after he cut open the goose?

(Crosses arms, looks bored) (Sighs dramatically) (Confidently) He got POOR! I already said that! (Taps foot faster) He didn't have any more golden eggs to sell. So, no money! (Thinks, eyes lighting up) Maybe he tried to sell the goose guts? (Wrinkles nose in disgust) But no one wants goose guts! (Asks a question, genuinely curious) Do you think he tried to sell them? That would be super gross!

(Smiling) I don't think anyone would buy goose guts! You're right, he became poor.

Do you think the farmer learned a lesson in the story? What do you think he learned?

(Taps chin thoughtfully) Hmmm... (Eyes widen, excitedly) He learned that being greedy is BAD! (Points finger again) And that you can't get everything you want RIGHT NOW! (Stands up and starts to pace again) (Confidently) He learned that patience is important! Like, waiting for Christmas presents, or waiting for my turn to play with the blocks! (Stops pacing, looks thoughtful) (Asks a question) Did he learn it, though? Like, really, really learn it? (Looks up at the teacher expectantly) Maybe he'll try to find another golden goose! (Starts humming a little tune, completely distracted).

Those are all good ideas! He definitely learned that being greedy isn't good and that waiting is important.

The story teaches us to be careful and think about what will happen *after* we do something. What do you think?

(Stops humming, looks up, intrigued) (Thinks hard, scrunches up nose) (Confidently) Oh! Like, if I eat all the cookies before dinner, then I won't have any room for my yummy spaghetti! (Snaps fingers) Or, if I draw on the walls, my mom will be SUPER mad! (Looks slightly mischievous) (Asks a question, curious) Does that mean the farmer should have thought about not having any more golden eggs BEFORE he chopped up the goose? That's smart! (Nods head vigorously, pleased with self).

Yes, exactly! The farmer should have thought about what would happen *after* he cut open the goose.

So, a good lesson from the story is to think before you act. Do you understand why that's important?

(Nods head quickly, very confidently) (Starts to explain excitedly) Yes! Because if you don't think, you might do something STUPID! (Points to self proudly) Like, if I didn't think, I might pour juice all over my head! (Giggles) That would be messy! (Pauses, thinking) Or... (Serious face) Or if I didn't think, I might run into the street without looking! And then a car might... (Shudders) (Asks a question, genuinely wanting to know) Is that why my mom always tells me to "use my brain"? (Looks at the teacher expectantly, eager for an answer).

Yes! That's exactly right. Thinking before you act helps you make good choices and avoid problems.

You really understood the story of "The Golden Egg" and the lesson it teaches. Great job! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was The Farmer and the Well.

First, tell me, who bought the well?
(Standing tall, bouncing slightly on my toes) The farmer did! (Points a finger confidently) He bought the well from his... uh... (Thinking, tapping chin) from his *neighbor*! Yeah!

Yes! You got it! The farmer bought the well from his neighbor.

Now, what did the farmer want to do with the well?

(Eyes widen, a big grin spreads across my face) To get water, of course! (Rolls eyes slightly, as if it's obvious) He needed water for his farm! (Starts pacing excitedly) Duh! What else would he need a well for? To put his toys in? (Giggles loudly)
(Chuckles) Good! He needed water for his farm. And could he get water from the well? After he bought it, I mean.

(Frowns, crossing arms) No! (Stomps foot) That mean old neighbor wouldn't let him! He said... he said... (Thinking hard, brow furrowed) he said he only sold the *well* but not the *water* inside! (Throws hands up in the air, exasperated) Can you believe it? That's so... (searches for a word) *dumb*!

It was pretty tricky of the neighbor, wasn't it?

So, what did the farmer do when the neighbor wouldn't let him take water?

(Stands up straighter, chest puffed out) He went to the... the... (Snaps fingers) The *Emperor*! (Voice dripping with importance) He's like the boss of everyone! (Nods head vigorously) He went to the Emperor to get justice! Because that neighbor was being a big, fat, (pauses for dramatic effect) MEANIE!

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends." Now, let's talk about it.

First, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?

(Fidgets, then confidently answers)

He felt...sad! Because nobody wanted to be his friend! They were all being... (scoffs) ...dumb! He was just trying to find someone to play with, but they said he was too big or couldn't swing. (Rolls eyes) Like, who cares if he can't swing? Elephants are way cooler than monkeys anyway! (Crosses arms)
You're right! He was very sad. Why did the monkey, rabbit, and frog say no to being his friend? What reasons did they give?

(Taps foot impatiently, speaks quickly)

Ugh, because they were being picky! The monkey said he couldn't swing! (Makes a swinging motion with arm, then stops abruptly). The rabbit said he was too big for the burrow! (Makes a small gesture with hands indicating smallness) And the frog... (pauses, thinking)... the frog said he couldn't jump! (Jumps slightly). (Raises eyebrows) Like, seriously? What kind of friends are they if they only care about that stuff?

Okay, so they all said no because the elephant was different from them. They focused on what he *couldn't* do.

Now, what happened the next day in the forest? Why were all the animals running?

(Eyes widen, leans forward)

Ooooh, that's when it got good! (Claps hands once) There was a TIGER! (Makes claws with hands and growls softly). He was chasing everyone! That's why they were running! They were all super scared! (Looks around dramatically). Even the monkey, rabbit, and frog! Serves them right for being mean to the elephant! (Smirks).
You're exactly right! A tiger was chasing them. What did the elephant do when he found out about the tiger?

(Sits up straighter, speaking excitedly)

He was SUPER BRAVE! He didn't run away like the other scaredy-cats! He went RIGHT UP to the tiger! (Makes a fist and pumps it in the air). He even *asked* the tiger nicely to stop! (voice goes high-pitched for "asked"). But the tiger was all, (voice deepens and becomes gruff) "Get out of my way!" So the elephant... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...KICKED HIM! (kicks out leg slightly, almost hitting the desk). Yeah! He kicked the tiger and scared him away! (grins proudly).
Wow! He was very brave! So, what happened *after* the elephant scared away the tiger? How did the other animals feel about the elephant then?

(Thinking, scratches head)

Hmm... (Snaps fingers). Oh! They realized he wasn't so bad after all! (Eyes light up). They saw he was... (Searching for the right word) ...useful! He was big and strong and could protect them from the tiger! (Stands up straighter, puffing out chest slightly). So THEN they wanted to be his friend! (Rolls eyes again). But, like, they should have been nice to him in the first place! (Sits back down, crossing arms again).
That's right! They realized he was helpful and strong. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big lesson we can learn from the elephant and his friends?

(Taps fingers on the desk, thinking hard)

(Suddenly blurts out) Don't be a jerk! (Looks around nervously, then back at teacher, speaking quickly) I mean... (clears throat) ...don't be mean to people just because they're different! Maybe they can do something really cool that you can't! And... (pauses, searching for more words) ...and maybe you should be nice to people even if they can't do all the things you can do. (Shrugs). And... (gets a mischievous look) ...if a tiger is chasing you, find an elephant! (laughs).

You got it! It's about not judging people based on how they look or what they can do. Friends can be different, and that's okay! Sometimes, those differences are even what make them special and helpful. So friends can be any shape or size! The elephant was different, but he was the perfect friend to help them when they needed it. Do you understand the moral of the story now? <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! That was a good story!

Let's talk about it. What did the girl feel at the beginning of the story?

(Confidently) She was, like, totally bummed out! She didn't even want to talk to anyone, just sad, sad, sad! (Rolls eyes) I would *never* be sad like that. That's, like, for babies! She should have just gone outside and played. What's wrong with her? (Fidgets with pencil)
Okay, so she was frustrated and sad. What did she do when she felt like that?

(Sighs dramatically) Duh! She asked her *dad* for help! (Raises hand impatiently) I knew that already. It was, like, the first thing that happened. Can we talk about something else? Like, what kind of tea was it? Did it have sugar? Was it iced? (Starts drawing on desk with pencil) The story didn't say! That's, like, a HUGE detail! (Taps foot impatiently)
Okay, good remembering! She asked her dad for help. And what did her dad ask her to bring him?

(Stops drawing, looks up, points finger) A potato, an egg, and... and... (Thinking, brow furrows) Oh! Tea leaves! (Confidently) I remembered! See? I'm super smart! He was going to make, like, a weird breakfast or something? (Wrinkles nose) Potatoes for breakfast are gross!
You are super smart! He got those things. Then what did he do with them?

(Scoffs) He BOILED them, obviously! (Rolls eyes) Like, hello? The story said so! (Taps pencil loudly on the desk) Is this a test? 'Cause I'm acing it! (Grins smugly) He put them in, like, separate pots, I think. And then... then... (Starts to look bored, glances out the window). Did he put salt in the water? That would make a difference, you know.
Yes, he boiled them. And what happened to the potato *after* it was boiled?

(Sighs) It got all... squishy. Like, yuck! (Makes a face) He took it out and was like, "Ta-da! Squishy potato!" (Mimics a magician pulling a rabbit out of a hat, but with an imaginary potato) Seriously, that's the dumbest trick EVER. (Looks away, uninterested)
The potato WAS hard before. Now it's soft. What about the egg? What was it like *before* it was boiled?

(Scoffs, picks at a loose thread on her shirt) It was all, like, wobbly and jiggly. You know, like... (Shudders dramatically) Ew! Eggs are slimy! (Looks back up, a spark of interest in her eyes) But then he boiled it and it got all HARD! Like a rock! (Pokes her arm muscles to show off) Can I have a snack now? This story is making me hungry.
Yes, the egg got hard. So the potato was hard and became soft. The egg was soft and became hard. What about the tea leaves? What did *they* do?

(Eyes widen, leans forward slightly) They... they... changed the WATER! (Taps finger on desk excitedly) The water wasn't just plain old water anymore! It was... TEA! (Looks around the room triumphantly) See? The tea was the BEST one! It changed everything! (Puffs out chest) I would have picked the tea. The potato and egg are boring.

You're right! The tea changed the water. So, the dad had the potato, the egg, and the tea leaves all in the *same* hot water. But they all changed in different ways. The story says this is like when "adversity knocks." What do you think "adversity" means? It's okay if you don't know!

(Frowns, scratches head with pencil) Adversity... Adver... (Confidently) It's, like, something BAD! (Taps pencil harder on the desk) Like when someone steals your crayons! Or when the teacher makes you do extra homework! Or when... (Trails off, thinking) Or when you have to eat broccoli! (Makes a disgusted face). Yeah, adversity is definitely something yucky! (Looks at the teacher expectantly). Am I right? Am I right?

You're on the right track! Adversity is like a problem or a difficult situation. So, when something bad happens - like your crayons get stolen - that's adversity. The potato, the egg, and the tea leaves all faced the same "adversity" - the hot water. But they all changed differently.

The potato was hard, and now it's soft. The egg was soft, and now it's hard. The tea changed the water itself.

So, when something bad happens, what do *you* think the story is trying to teach us?

(Thinking hard, chews on the end of her pencil) Hmmm... (Looks at the ceiling, then back at the teacher, shrugs) That even if something is yucky like broccoli, it can still turn into... something else? Like, maybe the broccoli can be, like, a superhero? (Giggles at her own idea) Or... or maybe... (Eyes dart around the room) (Confidently) I know! It means that even if something bad happens, YOU can still be the tea! (Puffs out chest again) You can change EVERYTHING! (Smiles proudly) Is that right? I bet it is! I'm the BEST at this! (Grabs her crayons and starts to draw a picture of a tea bag with superhero cape).

That's a *really* good idea! You're very close. The tea *did* change everything! The story is trying to tell us that when something bad or difficult happens, *we* get to choose how we react. The potato became soft, the egg became hard, and the tea changed the water.

So, we can choose to be like the potato... or the egg... or the tea. We decide what happens to us when things get tough. Does that make sense?

(Nods slowly, still drawing) So... (Looks up, confused) If I'm, like, super mad that someone took my crayons, I can choose to be like a potato and get all... (Squishes her face) ...soft and sad? (Shakes head) Nah! That's dumb! Or I can be like an egg and get all HARD and... (Clenches fists) ...angry? (Thinks for a second, then her face lights up) Or... or I can be like TEA! (Points to her drawing) And I can CHANGE the WHOLE situation! Maybe I can share my *other* crayons and make a new friend! And then the crayon thief will be sorry! (Grins mischievously) That's, like, way better than being a potato or a stupid egg! (Returns to her drawing, adding more details to her superhero tea bag) I'm going to be tea from now on!

Exactly! You got it! You decide how to respond to difficult situations. That's what the story is all about! You can choose to be like the potato, the egg, or the tea. It's your choice! And being the tea sounds like a great plan! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Needle Tree! That was a good one.

First, can you tell me: Who are the main people in the story?

(Confidently) Uh, yeah! There were two brothers, right? The older one and the younger one. And... and the magic tree! It talked! (Raises hand high, then taps foot impatiently) Can I tell you what happened? It's, like, super obvious what the story is about!

Yes, you are right! Those are the main characters. You remembered them all.

Okay, before we talk about what the story is about, let's talk about the brothers. Was the older brother nice or not nice at the start of the story?

(Rolls eyes) Not nice! Duh! He was, like, *super* mean to the little brother. Always! (Crosses arms, looking away) What's the point of even asking that? It's in the story! He chopped wood and stuff. (Thinking) He wanted, like, ALL the golden apples for himself, I bet. He probably wouldn't even share if he got more.
You're right, he wasn't nice at all. Why do you think he was mean? The story doesn't really tell us *why*.

(Shrugs shoulders) Who cares *why*? Some people are just mean! Maybe he didn't get enough cookies when he was a baby! (Giggles, then frowns) Or maybe he's just dumb! He should have been happy with the apples he got. He was just greedy! (Taps fingers on the table impatiently) He could have asked the tree nicely for more, you know? I bet the tree would have given him some if he just *asked*! But noooo, he had to be a big meanie and try to chop it down!
Okay, so the older brother was greedy. What happened when he tried to chop down the tree?

(Eyes widen, leaning forward eagerly) Okay, okay! This is the BEST part! The tree, like, BAM! It didn't give him more apples. It gave him NEEDLES! dialogue:
Okay! That was a good reading! Now, let's talk about the fox and the grapes.

First, tell me, was the fox happy at the beginning of the story? Why or why not?

(Eyes wide, bouncing a little in my seat) HAPPY?! No way! (Crosses arms, scowling) He was HUNGRY! Duh! (Rolls eyes). He was looking for food EVERYWHERE! He couldn’t find ANYTHING! That’s why he went to the wall. Stupid grapes. They looked yummy, though. (Quickly glances at teacher then back down at my hands)
(Smiling) You're right! He was very hungry. So, what did he see at the farmer's wall?

(Blurts out, practically yelling) GRAPES! Big, purple, juicy GRAPES! (Stands up and takes a step forward) I'd eat them all up! (Pauses, then stomps foot) But he couldn't REACH them! (Sits back down hard, fidgeting and muttering) Stupid wall, stupid grapes...
(Chuckles softly) They *did* sound yummy. What did the fox do to *try* to get the grapes?

(Scoffs) Jump! (Jumps up and down in seat a couple times, demonstrating) He jumped HIGH! (Stretches arms up high). He tried a LOT of times! (Suddenly gets quiet and avoids eye contact) He couldn't get them, though. (Mumbles) He was too... short, I guess. (Frowns deeply, picking at a loose thread on my pants).
He did jump high! But what happened after he tried and tried? Did he get the grapes?

(Shakes head violently) NO! (Voice rising again) He didn't get them! That's the whole point! (Slams hand on the desk). He couldn't reach! (Starts breathing heavily, face getting red) It's not FAIR! (Looks away, on the verge of tears) He was hungry, and those stupid grapes were just hanging there, all...purple.
(Speaking gently and softly) You're right. It wasn't fair. How did the fox feel *after* he couldn't get the grapes?

(Wipes eyes with back of hand, sniffles loudly) He was... mad! (Voice cracking). And he gave up! He just walked away! (Stands up abruptly, pushing chair back with a loud scrape) He said they were sour anyway! Liar! He just didn't want to admit he couldn't get them! (Paces back and forth, agitated)
(Nods slowly, acknowledging the frustration) You're very good at understanding how the fox felt! Why do you think he said the grapes were sour? Was he telling the truth?

(Stops pacing, glares suspiciously) No! He wasn't telling the truth! (Points a finger) He was lying! He was just... (Thinking hard, scrunching up face) ...trying to make himself feel better! Because he was a FAILURE! (Turns away, muttering under breath) Stupid fox... stupid grapes...

(Pauses, giving the student time to process) He was trying to feel better... That's interesting. So, he couldn't get what he wanted. And then he said he didn't *really* want it anyway...

Does that remind you of anything? Maybe a time when *you* couldn't get something you wanted?

(Hangs head, scuffing shoes on the floor) (Mumbling) ...Maybe...

(Looks up suddenly, eyes flashing with anger) Like when Sarah got the sparkly pink backpack and *I* wanted it! And Mom said no! (Voice rising again) And then Sarah showed it off ALL DAY! (Clenches fists) I HATE that backpack! It's UGLY! I didn't even WANT it! (Stares defiantly, daring the teacher to disagree).

(Nods understandingly) It sounds like you were very disappointed. And maybe you said you didn't want it to help yourself feel better, just like the fox said the grapes were sour.

So, what do you think we can learn from the story of the fox and the grapes? What's the big idea the story is trying to teach us?

(Crosses arms, tapping foot impatiently) (Mumbles) Something about... not being a sore loser? (Looks away, avoiding eye contact) Or... maybe... (Stuttering) ...maybe it's about... not lying? (Shrugs, looking unsure) I don't know! This story is dumb! (Fidgeting, clearly anxious) Can we be done now? I want to go play!

(Smiling encouragingly) You're close! It *is* a little bit about not being a sore loser, and it *is* about not lying to yourself.

Think about it this way: The fox wanted something *very* much. He tried hard to get it. But he couldn't. And then he pretended he didn't want it.

What if the story is telling us that sometimes, no matter how hard we try, we can't *always* get what we want? And that's okay. Maybe the story is about accepting that?

(Pauses, thinking. Chews on lower lip nervously) (Looks up slowly, a flicker of understanding in eyes) So... it's okay to be sad when you don't get something? (Voice small, hesitant) But... (Frowns) ...but what if you REALLY want it? And it's not fair? Like the grapes! Or the backpack! (Starts to get agitated again)

(Takes a deep breath, trying to calm down) So... it's about... trying your best... and... if you can't get it... then... (Struggles to find the words) ...then you just... deal with it? (Looks at teacher, seeking confirmation) Is that it?

(Beaming with pride) YES! That's a big part of it! It's about trying your best. And it's about understanding that sometimes, even when you try your best, you might not get what you want.

And instead of pretending you didn't want it, or getting angry, maybe you can learn something from it. Maybe you can try again later. Or maybe you can find something else that makes you happy.

So what can we say is the moral of the story then?

(Lets out a long sigh, shoulders slump slightly) (Mumbles) So...the moral is... um...(Thinking, tapping fingers on desk)

(Looks up, a little brighter) The moral is... even if you really, REALLY want something... and you try super hard... and you still can't get it... it's okay to be sad... but you shouldn't lie and say you didn't want it anyway... and you should just... (Forces a small smile) ...try to be okay with it? (Looks hopeful, wanting to get it right)

(Suddenly jumps up, energized) Can I go play now?! PLEASE?!

(Smiling warmly) You got it! You understood the story and its message so well! You said it perfectly.

The moral of the story is nothing comes easy, do not hate what you can’t have.

Yes, you can go play now! You deserve it! <finish>

dialogue: Okay! That was a good story, wasn't it? Now, can you tell me... who were the two main plants in the story?

(Bouncing in my seat, then suddenly stopping and looking away) Uh, yeah! It was okay. (Fidgets with my shoelaces) There was… um… (eyes dart around the room) a ROSE! (Sticks out tongue a little) And… and a… pricky thing! A cactus! (Crosses arms, looking impatient)
Yes! A rose and a cactus. Good job! Now, who do you think was nicer in the beginning of the story? The rose or the cactus? Why do you think so?

(Scoffs and rolls eyes) Duh! The rose, of course! (Taps foot impatiently) Because she was… she was pretty! And the cactus was just… (makes a face) prickly and ugly! Everyone likes pretty things! (Looks away, like that's the most obvious thing in the world). It's… logical! (Nods head vigorously)
Hmm, I see. So, you thought the rose was nicer because she was pretty. But what did the rose *do* in the story? Did she say kind things or not-so-kind things?

(Glares at the teacher) She said... (Sticks out tongue a little) she said the cactus was ugly! (Crosses arms again, looking defiant). So what? It's TRUE! (Raises voice slightly) The rose was way prettier! She could say whatever she wanted. (Looks down, scuffing shoe on the floor). The cactus… it just stood there. Being… pricky.
Okay, so the rose wasn't saying very nice things. Even if she thought the cactus was "pricky," do you think it was kind to say that out loud? How do you think that made the cactus feel?

(Shrugs, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) I dunno. (Mumbles) Probably didn't care. It's just a… (hesitates, glances up quickly, then looks back down) ...a plant. (Taps foot nervously) It doesn't have feelings. (Voice gets a little higher) It's not like it's… important. (Starts to fidget more, pulling at the thread harder) Anyway, the rose was thirsty! So… so what happened then? (Changes the subject abruptly, avoiding eye contact)
It *is* important how we treat others, even plants! But let's talk about what happened when the rose got thirsty. What was the cactus doing when the rose was thirsty and the sun was really hot?

(Sighs dramatically, throws hands up in the air) Ugh! Fine! (Pauses, trying to remember, chewing on my lip) The… the birds… were… (Stutters a little) …drinking from the cactus! (Voice cracks slightly) Because the cactus had… (Looks down, avoiding eye contact) …water. (Mumbles) Stupid cactus. (Crosses arms tightly, starting to get red in the face).
Why do you think the birds were drinking from the cactus, but not the rose?

(Voice rising, getting louder and more frantic) Because! (Glares at the teacher) Because the cactus is… is full of… (Voice cracks again) …yucky, slimy water! And the rose is… (Struggles to find the words, face getting even redder) …is DRY! (Starts to sniffle a little) And… and it's not FAIR! (Tears welling up in my eyes) The rose should have water too! It's… it's not LOGICAL! (Begins to cry softly, burying face in arms)
(Softly) It's okay. It's okay to feel sad for the rose. It wasn't very nice to the cactus, was it? But even though the rose wasn't nice, what did the cactus do when the rose asked for help?

(Sniffling, looks up with watery eyes, still red-faced. Rubs eyes with fists) It… it GAVE her water! (Voice shaky) Even though… even though the rose was… (Looks down again, scuffing shoe) …mean. (Mumbles barely audibly) Stupid, nice cactus. (Another sniffle) Why did it do THAT? (Looks genuinely confused and upset)
That's a very good question! Why do YOU think the cactus gave the rose water, even after the rose was mean? What does that tell you about the cactus?

(Thinking hard, forehead wrinkled. Looks away, then back at the teacher, then away again. Still sniffling a little) Maybe… maybe it didn't… (Stutters) …care that the rose was mean? (Voice still shaky but a little calmer) Maybe it… it just wanted to… (Long pause, struggling with the words) …help? (Looks up with a flicker of something almost like understanding in eyes, but then quickly looks away again, pulling at the thread on shirt) But… but that's… (Mumbles) …stupid. (Wipes nose with sleeve) People should only help… people who are… nice to them! (Voice firmer now, almost defiant again) Right?

It's definitely good to be nice to people who are nice to you. But sometimes, even if someone isn't nice to us, we can still choose to be kind. The cactus chose to be kind. What do you think the story is trying to teach us about judging others based on how they look?

(Crosses arms tightly again, but looks thoughtful now, less angry) So… (Chews on lip) …so, it’s not just ‘cause the rose was… pretty… that made her… good? (Looks at the teacher, a little uncertainly) And… and the cactus wasn’t bad just ‘cause it was… (Hesitates) …prickly? (Frowns) So… (Voice trails off, clearly thinking hard) Maybe… maybe looks don’t… (Snaps fingers, remembering something) …matter? (Looks down, scuffing shoe again, but this time not as angrily. More… thoughtfully) The rose was… thirsty. And the cactus… helped. (Mumbles) Even though… (Looks up quickly, then down again) …she didn’t have to.
You're getting it! So, do you think it's a good idea to judge someone just by how they look on the outside? What did you learn from the story of the rose and the cactus?

(Sighs, finally seeming a little calmer. Still avoids direct eye contact, but not as anxiously) I… (Shuffles feet) I guess… (Mumbles) …no. (Looks up quickly, then down again) Don’t judge… (Stutters a little) …plants… just ‘cause… (Takes a deep breath) …one is pretty and one is… not. (Voice is softer, almost a whisper) The cactus… helped the rose even though… (Looks down, almost ashamed) …she was mean. (Picks at the loose thread again, but not as aggressively) So… (Looks up at the teacher, a tiny bit of a smile on face, but it quickly disappears) Maybe… being… nice… is… (Trails off, then shrugs) …better. (Mumbles almost inaudibly) Even if… it's not… logical. (Looks away, a hint of sadness in eyes)

Yes! You've understood the story very well. The story teaches us that it's not good to judge someone just by their looks. Being kind and helpful is much more important. Even if someone doesn't look like us, or isn't nice to us at first, we should still try to be kind. Sometimes, the people who seem the "prickliest" on the outside have the most to offer on the inside, just like the cactus! <finish>

dialogue: Okay! Hi there! Did you like the story about Molly and her milk?

(Running in place excitedly) Yeah! Yeah! I LOVED it! (Starts skipping) It was about milk and...and...MONEY! And...and...chickens! (Looks away, a little anxious) But then...then she spilled the milk! (Frowns, mood suddenly shifts)
You remembered lots of things! You are right! She did spill the milk. Why do you think she spilled it?

(Stops skipping abruptly, folds arms) Hmph. (Looks at the teacher with a slight glare) Because she was STUPID! (Voice raises slightly) She was too busy thinking about...about...buying stuff! Like a chicken! (Taps foot impatiently) I wouldn't spill MY milk. I'm good at carrying things! (Looks away, anxious) But...but she was thinking about being better than the *other* milkmaids! That's what made her spill it, I think. (Voice quietens, almost a mumble)
You are right! She *was* thinking about buying things and being better than others. And you think *that* made her spill it. What was she doing *when* she spilled it?

(Rolls eyes, sighs dramatically) Ugh, you *already* KNOW! (Taps foot faster, getting agitated). She was...she was...skipping! (Looks away, picks at a loose thread on clothes, nervous) She was so busy thinking about all the...the...egg money that she...she wasn't watching where she was going! (Looks back, defiant) I wouldn't skip with milk! That's a DUMB idea! (Crosses arms tighter)
So, she was skipping and thinking about egg money. And because of that, the milk spilled. What did she have *before* she spilled the milk?

(Scoffs) Milk, *obviously*! (Points finger) And...and a pail! A pail FULL of milk! (Pauses, thinking) Enough milk to buy a chicken! (Eyes widen slightly, momentarily excited again) A chicken that makes MORE money! (Frowns again, remembers the end) But...but then she had NOTHING! (Looks down, mood shifts again, voice gets quieter) Just an empty pail.

That's right! She had a pail full of milk, and then she had nothing. So, what do you think she learned from spilling the milk? What do you think her mom meant when she said, "Don't count your chickens until they hatch?"

(Sighs loudly, pushes hair out of face) Ugh, grown-up sayings are SO dumb. (Glares at the teacher) It means...it means...(Struggles, looking away) It means you can't...can't...like...plan on having something before you *actually* have it! (Snaps fingers, excited for a moment) Like, you can't say "I'm gonna buy a toy!" before you *get* the money! (Frowns again, realizing the connection to the story) Molly was thinking she ALREADY had the egg money, but she didn't even HAVE the chicken yet! (Voice gets quieter, almost a whisper) And then she had nothing. (Looks at the teacher, anxious) Is that right?
Yes! That's *exactly* right! You figured it out! So, what should Molly have done differently?

(Paces back and forth, agitated) She should have...should have...uh... (Stops pacing, glares at an imaginary spot on the floor) She should have been CAREFUL! (Voice raises) And she shouldn't have been so...so... (Struggles to find the right word) ...GRABBY! Yeah! She wanted too much! Too FAST! (Crosses arms, looks away, a little ashamed) She should have just...sold the milk. And then maybe buy a *small* chicken later. (Mumbles) Instead of being greedy and spilling everything. (Looks at the teacher, defiant) I wouldn't be greedy like that!

You're right! Being careful is very important. And you used a great word: "grabby." She was being a little grabby, wanting too much too soon. So, what is the story trying to teach us? What's the big lesson? It's okay if you need a little help!

(Fidgets, pulling at sleeves, nervous) Ugh, I hate lessons! (Looks away) It's trying to say... (Stammers) ...don't...don't...get all excited about stuff you *might* get! Like...like... presents for your birthday! (Eyes light up briefly) You might not GET them! (Frowns) So...don't count on it! (Looks back at the teacher, a bit defiant) Is that it? Is that the STUPID lesson? (Taps foot impatiently)

Yes! That's a great way to say it! Don't get too excited about things you *might* get. Or, don't *depend* on something until you are sure it will happen. You understood the story really well! <finish>
