dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about the owl.

What did the owl do every day near his tree?

(Bouncing my leg, looking around the room, but trying to focus) Uh, (stuttering) the owl... the owl... (eyes darting back to the book, pointing with my finger at the first line) He... he observed! Yeah! (Confidently) He observed incidents happening around his oak tree every day! That's what the story said! (Grinning proudly, tapping the book with my finger again, already wanting to show I understand more). Is that right?

That's exactly right! The owl **observed**. Good job finding that in the story.

What does "observed" mean? What was the owl doing?

(Frowning, picking at a loose thread on my shirt. I KNOW this!) Observed... observed... (Thinking hard, tapping my foot impatiently). It means... it means... (Suddenly, I know!) It means he was watching! (Confidently) He was watching all the things that were happening! Like when Billy trips and falls (giggles loudly), or when the squirrels chase each other! He was watching! Is that right? Is that what observed means? (Leaning forward, eager to be correct, forgetting to pick at my shirt.)

Yes! You got it! "Observed" means he was watching very carefully.

Now, the story also says, "The more things he saw, the less he would speak." What does that mean? Why did he speak less?

(Scoffs, rolling my eyes slightly) Less he would speak? (Taps the book again, reading the sentence to myself under my breath, muttering). The *more* he saw... the *less* he spoke... (Suddenly, I get it, standing up from the chair) I KNOW! It's because he was busy watching! You can't talk and watch at the same time! (Running around the table) Like, if I'm watching the ants on the playground, I don't talk! (Stopping abruptly, anxious expression) Or... or... (Looking down at the table, nervous again) Is it because he didn't have anything to say? (Voice quiet, fiddling with my hands) I get nervous when I don't know what to say...

That's a good thought! It *could* be because he was busy watching. But maybe there's another reason too.

The story also says he *heard* people talking and sharing stories. He heard *lots* of things. Do you think that might have changed how much he talked?

(Eyes widen, running back to the book and pointing.) Heard people talking! (Tapping the words excitedly.) He heard stories! (Thinking hard, eyebrows furrowed. I can figure this out, I can.) Hmm... (Pacing back and forth in front of the desk, arms crossed.) He heard so much... and he spoke less... (Suddenly, I stop pacing, snapping my fingers.) I KNOW! (Confidently, pointing at you.) Maybe he was listening so much, he didn't *need* to talk! Because he already knew everything! Like, if I listen to you read, I don't need to read it myself, right? He already *heard* the stories! (Grinning triumphantly.)

That's a really smart idea! He was listening and learning. So, he was watching a lot and listening a lot.

What did all that watching and listening help the owl become? What word did the story use?

(Jumps up and down, pointing at the book, almost yelling) Wiser! (Calmer, but still excited) It made him wiser! (Bouncing on the balls of my feet, looking at the teacher expectantly.) Because he saw and heard everything, he got wiser! (Stops bouncing, frowning slightly) But... what does wiser mean? (Tilts head, genuinely confused.) Is it like... bigger? Stronger? (Fidgeting with my hands, suddenly feeling unsure again.)

"Wiser" means he learned a lot and understood things better. He knew more about the world because he paid attention.

So, what do you think we can learn from the owl's story? If we watch and listen like the owl, what might happen?

(Thinking hard, tapping my chin dramatically) If *we* watch and listen... (Stops tapping, eyes widen) We'll get wiser too! (Jumping up and down again.) Like the owl! If I watch how you write, I'll learn to write better! And if I listen when you tell stories, I'll get wiser about... about everything! (Suddenly serious.) But... (Voice quieter, looking down) it's hard to just listen sometimes. (Looks up quickly, almost defiantly.) Billy makes funny noises, and I *have* to see what he's doing! (Grinning mischievously.)

That's right! Watching and listening helps us learn and become wiser. It's okay to talk and be silly sometimes too, but remembering to watch and listen can help us understand the world better.

So, if you had to tell someone what the story is about in one sentence, what would you say? What's the most important thing to remember from the story?

(Stands up straight, puffs out my chest, trying to sound important.) Okay! (Takes a deep breath, trying to organize my thoughts - this is important!) The story is about... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...how watching and listening can make you wiser, just like the owl! (Grinning proudly, then immediately fidgeting with my hands again.) Did I do good? Was that a good sentence? (Looking at the teacher anxiously.) Is that what the story was *really* about? (I really want to be right!)

That's a fantastic sentence! You explained the story and what we can learn from it perfectly. The wise old owl teaches us that we can learn a lot if we talk less and observe more.

You understood the story very well. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Golden Egg! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it?

Now, let's talk about it. What did the farmer have?

(Bounces in my seat, almost falling off) A goose! He had a goose! (Points at the teacher with a slightly aggressive stab of my finger) A *golden* goose! The best goose EVER! (Frowns, crossing my arms)
(Chuckles gently) Yes, a golden goose! And what did the golden goose give the farmer every day?

(Rolls eyes) Ugh, it's obvious! (Taps foot impatiently) A golden EGG! One egg. He got one. Every. Day. (Looks away, clearly bored) Why are you asking such easy questions? I knew that already! (Starts fidgeting with my shoelaces)
Okay, okay! You're right, that *is* easy. Good job remembering! What did the farmer do with the golden egg?

(Scoffs) Sold it! Duh! (Suddenly excited) He got rich! (Starts running in place a little) I would sell it for, like, ALL THE CANDY! (Stops abruptly, frowns again) But then he... (voice trails off, looks nervous) He did a bad thing... (Stutters) H-he... (Looks down at desk, anxious)
(Softly) It's okay. What bad thing did he do? It's alright, you can tell me.

(Voice barely a whisper, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) He cut the goose... (Looks up suddenly, eyes wide with a flash of anger) It was STUPID! The goose was giving him eggs, and he RUINED EVERYTHING! (Slams a fist lightly on the desk)
You're right! He did do a stupid thing. Why do you think he cut the goose? What did he *want*?

(Thinks hard, tapping a finger on chin. Looks concentrated, then a spark of understanding) He wanted… MORE! He wanted ALL the eggs. All at once! (Suddenly looks disgusted) He was SO dumb! Didn't he know there were NO eggs inside? (Stands up straight, confident again) I knew that!
Yes! He wanted more, all at once. And what happened when he cut open the goose? Did he get more eggs?

(Crosses arms, a smug look on face) Nope! (Shakes head vigorously) He got NOTH-ING! Just… (grimaces) …yucky stuff. And now he's POOR! (Starts pacing back and forth, talking louder) Serves him right! He shouldn't be so greedy! (Stops pacing, pointing accusingly at an imaginary farmer) That's what happens when you're greedy!
Exactly! He got nothing. He was greedy. So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big lesson?

(Sticks out tongue) Don't be greedy! (Starts drawing on the desk with a crayon) It's SO obvious. (Mumbles under breath) Should have kept the goose. Stupid farmer. (Looks up, impatient) Can I go play now? I know the story!
You're close! It is about not being greedy, but it's also about something else. Think about *why* the farmer was greedy. What did he *not* do before he cut open the goose?

(Glares at the teacher) I SAID don't be greedy! (Sighs dramatically, then a flicker of thought crosses face) He didn't… (Taps chin, confused) …he didn't… THINK! (Snaps fingers) He didn't think about what would happen AFTER! He just wanted MORE! (Looks away, irritated) This is hard.

You got it! He didn't think. He acted too fast. So, the lesson is about more than just being greedy. It's about what you should do *before* you do something, especially something big. What should you do *before* you act?

(Grumbling under breath) Ugh, more thinking... (Then, a slow smile spreads across the face) Think before you act! (Bounces in seat again, energized) Think! Think! THINK! Before you do a stupid thing like cut open a golden goose! (Claps hands together loudly) Can I go now? I learned the lesson! I can teach it to everyone!

Yes! You got it! The lesson is: Think before you act! That means to think about what will happen *after* you do something. You understood the story and the lesson really well! You can go play now! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was The Farmer and the Well.

First, tell me, who bought the well?

(Standing tall, hands on my hips, a slight frown on my face)

The farmer did! He bought it from, uh, (looks away, tapping foot impatiently) that other guy! The neighbor. Yeah, the farmer bought the well. (Confidently) He had the money, so he could buy it! Why wouldn't he?

Good! The farmer bought the well from his neighbor.

Now, after the farmer bought the well, could he get water from it?

(Scoffs, rolling my eyes)

No! (Arms crossed tightly) That mean old neighbor wouldn't let him! He said... he said he sold the *well*, but not the *water*. (Sighs dramatically) That's so... so... (Thinking hard) unfair! The farmer bought the well, so the water should be his! (Fidgets with my shirt) I would have just taken the water anyway. (Mumbles under my breath) Stupid neighbor.

You're right! It *was* unfair.

So, what did the farmer do because the neighbor was being unfair? Where did he go?

(Paces back and forth a few steps)

He went to the emperor! (Points a finger in the air) He went to the emperor 'cause that's what you do when someone is being a big meanie and not sharing! (Voice rising) The emperor is in charge and tells people what to do! (Stops pacing and stares intensely) Duh! Everyone knows that! (Stutters, suddenly nervous) I... I mean... that's what the story said.

Yes, you're absolutely right! The farmer went to the emperor.

And what did the emperor's helper, the courtier, do? What did *he* ask the neighbor?

(Taps my chin, thinking, then a lightbulb seems to go off)

Ooooh! (Voice louder again, excited) He asked the neighbor... (pauses for dramatic effect) he asked him why he wasn't letting the farmer use the water! He was all like, (puts on a silly voice) "Hey! You sold him the well! Why can't he have the water?! Are you gonna pay rent, or what?!" (Giggles loudly) That's what *I* would have said!

That's a very good way of putting it!

So, what did the neighbor do when the courtier asked him that? Did he keep being mean, or did he change his mind?

(Scoffs again, rolling my eyes)

He changed his mind! (Crosses arms again, standing firm) He said he was sorry! (Mimics a whining voice) "Oh, I'm so sorry, Mr. Farmer! Please use the water!" (Changes back to my normal voice, sounding disgusted) He only said that 'cause he didn't want to pay rent! He was trying to trick the farmer, but the emperor's helper was too smart for him! (Smirks) He learned his lesson! (Taps foot impatiently) Can we be done now? This is boring.

You're doing great! Just one more question.

Why do you think the neighbor said sorry? What did he learn? What's the big idea of the story?

(Pouts, kicking the floor with my shoe)

Ugh, fine. (Thinking hard, then suddenly gets excited) It's 'cause he learned that you can't be a big fat liar! (Points a finger for emphasis) If you sell someone something, you have to let them use it! (Voice getting louder) It's not fair to trick people! You should be nice and... and... (Stutters, getting nervous again) share... even if you don't want to. (Mumbles) But sharing is hard... (Looks away, feeling anxious) So, the big idea is... don't be a meanie! And don't try to trick people! (Looks up, relieved) There! I'm done! Can I go play now?

You got it! You are right, the big idea is not to trick people. If you try to trick people, it won't work out for you in the end. The story teaches us that cheating will get you nowhere.

<finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading "Elephant and Friends"! That was a good story.

Now, let's talk about it a little bit. First, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?

(Bounces in my seat, almost falling off, then giggles loudly).

It was good! I read it *so* fast! (Proudly) The elephant? Uh... (Sticks tongue out, thinking hard). He felt... (Looks away, fidgeting with my shoelaces). He felt... (Voice gets small and shaky) ... sad? Because nobody wanted to play with him! They were all... mean! (Crosses arms, glares at the table). They said he was too big and stuff! He couldn't swing! And he couldn't jump! It wasn't fair! (Puffs out cheeks). I wouldn't be friends with them either!
You are absolutely right! He was very sad. Why do you think the other animals didn't want to be his friend at first? What reasons did they give?

(Rolls eyes dramatically). Duh! It was in the STORY! (Taps foot impatiently). The monkey... (Counts on fingers)... the monkey said he was too big to swing! (Makes swinging motions with arms, then stops abruptly). And the rabbit... (Scoffs) ... he said the elephant was too big for his burrow! (Wrinkles nose). Stupid rabbit! And the frog! (Voice rising) The frog said he couldn't JUMP! So, they didn't want to be his friend! (Stares intensely at the teacher). It's obvious! (Huffs, then suddenly looks worried). Is... is that right? (Voice quieter) Did I get it right?
Yes, that's exactly right! You remembered all the reasons. So, they all thought the elephant was... what? Too big? Too clumsy? What words would you use?

(Sighs loudly, relieved). Phew! I knew it! (Straightens up, puffing out chest).

They thought he was... (Taps chin importantly) ... useless! (Looks at the teacher, waiting for confirmation). He couldn't do the things *they* could do! He couldn't swing! He couldn't fit! He couldn't jump! (Starts to get worked up again). So they thought he was... WORTHLESS! (Voice cracking a little). But he wasn't! Was he? Was he worthless?
That's a very strong word. "Worthless." He certainly felt that way, didn't he? But do *you* think he was worthless? Even before he helped scare away the tiger?

(Shakes head violently, almost knocking myself out of the chair again). NO! (Stands up, grabbing the edge of the table for balance). He wasn't worthless! Even if he couldn't swing or jump or fit! (Looks down at the floor, scuffing my shoe). Just because you can't do something... (Mumbles) ... doesn't mean you're... bad. (Looks up suddenly, eyes wide). What if I couldn't read as fast as Tommy? Does that mean I'm... worthless? (Voice trembling).

Oh, honey, no way! Not being able to read as fast as Tommy doesn't make you worthless at all! Everyone is good at different things.

Now, let's bring it back to the story. What happened the next day in the forest?

(Sits down heavily, relieved, but still fiddling with my hands). Okay... okay. (Takes a deep breath). The next day... (Eyes light up again, forgetting my worries). The tiger! The tiger was being a BIG MEANIE! (Makes claws with my hands and growls). All the animals were running away! They were SCARED! (Looks around the room dramatically, then giggles). It was so exciting! (Calms down slightly). But... but it was also... bad. Because the tiger was gonna get them!
You're doing great! And what did the elephant do when he saw everyone running from the tiger?

(Eyes widen, bouncing in seat again). He KICKED the tiger! (Pumps fist in the air). He was SO brave! The tiger was all like, "ROAR! Get out of my way!" (Imitates a tiger's roar, then giggles). But the elephant was like, "NO! I'm gonna KICK you!" And he did! He kicked him really, really hard! (Makes kicking motion with leg, almost kicking the table). Then the tiger ran away! (Claps hands together). He saved everyone! He was a SUPERHERO! (Looks expectantly at the teacher). Was it a *really* big kick? Did the tiger cry?

He was very brave, and he definitely helped! The story doesn't say if the tiger cried, but I bet he was surprised!

So, after the elephant scared the tiger away, how did the other animals feel about him? Did they still think he was "worthless"?

(Sticks out tongue, thinking hard). Hmmm... (Taps chin). No! (Shakes head vigorously). They didn't think he was worthless anymore! (Beams proudly). They thought he was... (Snaps fingers). ... useful! (Paces back and forth in front of the desk). Because he could kick tigers! (Stops pacing, looks directly at the teacher, frowning slightly). But... but that's not fair, is it? They only liked him because he could kick tigers? What if there weren't any tigers? Would they still like him? (Looks worried again).

That's a very clever question! You're thinking really deeply about the story. You're right, it wouldn't be very nice if they *only* liked him because he could kick tigers.

Why do *you* think they wanted to be his friend *after* he kicked the tiger? Do you think it was just about the kicking? Or was there something else? Think about how they were feeling *before* the tiger came.

(Paces again, muttering to myself). Before the tiger... before the tiger... They were scared! (Stops pacing suddenly). They were scared! And he helped them! (Eyes widen with realization). Maybe... maybe they realized he wasn't useless after all! Maybe they realized he was... (Struggles for the right word) ... strong? And brave? And... and a good friend to have when there's a scary tiger! (Looks at the teacher, hopeful). Is that it? Is that why? (Chews on lip nervously).

Yes, I think you're exactly right! They saw that even though he was different, he had qualities that were really important, like bravery and strength. He could help them when they needed it most.

So, what do you think is the big lesson we can learn from this story? What's the message the story is trying to tell us?

(Stands up straight, suddenly confident). I know! I know! (Points finger in the air). Don't be mean to people just because they're different! (Paces excitedly). Just because they can't do the same things as you, doesn't mean they're useless! (Stops pacing, looks at the teacher with serious eyes). Everyone is good at something! Even if it's kicking tigers! (Giggles, then gets serious again). And... and you should be friends with people even if they can't swing or jump! Because... because being a good friend is more important than being good at swinging! (Sits down with a thump, beaming proudly). Did I get it right? Did I learn the lesson? (Bites nails anxiously).

You got it exactly right! That's a wonderful way to put it. It doesn't matter if someone is big or small, or can swing or jump. What matters is being a good friend. Friends can be any shape or size!

You understood the story and the lesson perfectly. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was a good one. Now, let's talk about it.

First, tell me, what was the girl feeling at the beginning of the story?

(Fidgets, looks away) Uh, she...she was, like, REALLY mad! (Crosses arms) She was, like, super frustrated with everything! (Taps foot impatiently) It said so RIGHT THERE. (Points vaguely at where the book was) I remember! (Looks proud for a split second). Are we done yet?

You're right! She *was* frustrated! Good job remembering that!

Now, what did her father do to help her? He didn't just *tell* her to feel better, did he?

(Rolls eyes) Noooo! (Sighs dramatically) He got... (Thinking, looks up at the ceiling)... egg, potato, and TEA! (Points finger in the air) Then he boiled them! Duh! (Looks around the room, seemingly bored) Can I go now? This is taking forever!

You got it! Egg, potato, and tea! He boiled them.

Now, what happened to the egg *after* it was boiled? Was it the same as before?

(Scoffs) Of course not! (Taps fingers on the desk, then leans forward, excited) It got HARD! (Makes a fist and punches the air) Used to be all squishy, but then... BOOM! Hard! (Looks expectantly at the teacher, waiting for praise). Is that the BEST answer? I KNOW it is!

That's right! It got hard! Good describing words: "squishy" and "hard"!

And what about the potato? What happened to *it* when it was boiled?

(Squirms in seat) Ugh, the potato... (Makes a face) That's the BORING one! (Thinks for a moment, trying to remember) It... it got soft? (Looks at the teacher doubtfully) Like, all mushy? (Wrinkles nose) Yuck! Can we talk about the TEA now? That sounds way cooler! (Starts to get up from seat)

You're right again! It got soft and mushy. Good job.

Okay, we can talk about the tea. What did the tea do to the water? Did it become hard or soft?

(Sits back down, perking up slightly) The tea... (Eyes widen) The tea changed the WATER! (Beams proudly) It didn't just get hard or soft, it made the water all... (Struggles for the right word) ...tea-y! (Nods emphatically) Like, the water became something NEW! That's the BEST one, right? Because it changed everything! (Bounces slightly in seat)

Yes! You're exactly right! The tea changed the water itself!

Now, the story said the girl's father was showing her how things respond to "adversity." Adversity is like a problem or a hard time.

So, the boiling water was like the problem. The egg, potato, and tea were like...different ways to deal with the problem.

The egg got hard. The potato got soft. And the tea changed the water.

Which one do *you* think is the best way to deal with a problem? Why?

(Sits up straight, looks very serious) The TEA! (Points definitively) Because the egg just got hard, and the potato just got mushy! That's boring! (Scoffs) But the tea... (Voice gets softer, more dramatic) ...it CHANGED EVERYTHING! The water became something totally different! (Gets louder again) It didn't just change ITSELF, it changed the WATER! So, if I have a problem, I want to be like the TEA! I want to CHANGE EVERYTHING! (Stands up, pumps fist in the air) Yeah! (Immediately sits back down, looking slightly embarrassed by the outburst).

Wow! That's a great way to think about it. You really understood that!

So, the story is trying to tell us that when something hard happens (adversity!), we can choose how we react. We can become hard like the egg, soft like the potato, or we can change the whole situation, like the tea.

So, what do *you* think the story is trying to teach us about dealing with problems? What's the big lesson?

(Sighs dramatically, looking at the ceiling) Ugh, a LESSON? (Rolls eyes). Okay, okay... (Taps foot impatiently) The lesson is... (Pauses, thinking hard) ...that problems... (Forces self to concentrate)... make you... something? (Looks at the teacher questioningly). Or you can change the problem... into something else! (Beams, finally getting it) Like TEA! So, don't be a hard egg or a mushy potato! Be TEA! (Looks around proudly, waiting for approval)

You're so close! The lesson is that we get to choose how we react to problems. It's up to *us* to decide if we want to be like the egg, the potato, or the tea. We decide how to respond to difficult situations. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story, The Needle Tree! That was a good story, wasn't it?

Now, tell me, what did the older brother do for work?

(Bounces in my seat, almost falling off) Yeah, it was okay, I guess! (Looks away, picking at my fingernails) He… he chopped wood! (Points finger) To sell! In the market! I knew that! (Confidently) My turn to read next time, okay? I can read way faster than anyone! And I'm the best at remembering stuff! (Starts kicking my feet under the desk)

(Smiling) You did a super job remembering that! Yes, he chopped wood to sell.

So, what did the tree offer him *instead* of being chopped down?

(Frowns, fidgeting) Ugh, this is boring. (Taps fingers loudly on the desk) The...the tree said... (Eyes dart around the room, mumbling) ...golden... golden... (Sighs loudly) ...apples! (Scoffs) I knew that too! Why are you asking such easy questions? (Rolls eyes) I already knew the answer! Golden apples. Dumb tree. Should have given him way more.

(Chuckles softly) Golden apples, that's right!

Did the older brother think the golden apples were enough?

(Crosses arms, leans back in chair) No! (Voice gets louder) He wanted MORE! (Glares, drumming fingers on arm) He's SO smart! He deserves ALL the apples! (Starts tapping feet faster, getting agitated) He's the BEST! Why did the tree only give him a little bit? It's not FAIR! (Almost yells)
(Calmly) Okay, okay. Take a deep breath. He *wanted* more, you're right. What happened when he tried to chop the tree down anyway? What did the tree do *then*?

(Huffs, face turning red) (Glares intensely) (Stuttering) It...it...it was mean! (Slams hands on the desk, startling myself) He was just trying to get MORE apples! (Voice rising) He deserved them! (Starts to cry, wiping eyes with the back of hand) And then… and then… the dumb tree… (Sniffles) …it gave him STICKY needles! (Sobs loudly) It's not FAIR! The tree is a meanie!

(Softly) Oh, honey. It's okay. It's just a story.

The tree gave him needles, yes. How did that make the older brother feel?

(Sniffling, wiping nose on sleeve) (Voice trembling) It...it hurt! (Wipes tears again) (Looking down, avoids eye contact) He was... was sad. And... and sticky. (Mumbles) I would be mad! Way madder than him! That tree should be sorry! (Kicks the leg of the desk lightly) It was mean! He just wanted more! Is it my turn to read now? I'm done talking about the stupid needles.

(Gently) He was hurt and sad. You're right.

Who helped him when he was covered in needles?

(Wipes eyes one last time, takes a deep breath) (Quickly, impatiently) His dumb little brother. (Rolls eyes) He's probably slow and can't even read as good as me. (Muttering) Should have just pulled them out himself. (Straightens up, trying to look confident) He probably took forever! I could have done it faster!

(Nodding) The younger brother helped him.

And what did the older brother say to his younger brother after that? Do you remember?

(Squirms in seat, avoids eye contact) (Mumbles) I don't know. (Taps foot rapidly) Does it matter? (Pulls at a loose thread on shirt) He probably said, "Thanks," or something. (Scoffs) Whatever. The little brother should be thanking HIM for even letting him help! (Glares, arms crossed)

(Patiently) He said sorry. He apologized for being mean to his younger brother before.

What do you think made him say sorry?

(Confused, face scrunched up) Sorry? (Tilts head) Why would he say sorry? (Picks at nails again) He didn't do anything wrong! The little brother should be sorry for not helping him sooner! (Voice rising, agitated) He was covered in STICKY needles! And the little brother was just walking around! (Starts tapping foot very loudly) This is dumb. (Mumbles) I want to go outside and play.

(Calmly) He said sorry because he realized he hadn't been very nice to his brother before. And his brother *still* helped him even though he was mean.

What happened *after* the older brother said he was sorry?

(Sighs dramatically, rolls eyes) Fine. (Grumbling) If you *really* want to know... (Huffs, looking bored) ...the stupid tree... (makes air quotes) ... "magically" ... (stops air quoting) ... gave them MORE apples. (Scoffs) Dumb story. Why did he have to say sorry to get more apples? He was already the best! He should have gotten them anyway! (Leans back, arms crossed, looking defiant)
(Smiling slightly) The tree gave them more apples. Why do you think the tree gave them more apples *after* the older brother apologized?

(Glares, tapping fingers impatiently) (Stutters, voice shaking with anger) I...I don't know! And I don't CARE! (Face gets red, on the verge of tears again) It's a dumb story and it's not FAIR! (Voice cracks) He should have gotten all the apples in the first place! (Starts crying again, burying face in hands) I hate this!

(Softly) It’s okay. Let's think about it. The tree gave him needles when he was greedy. Then, when he was kind, the tree gave him apples.

What do you think the story is trying to teach us?

(Sniffling, voice muffled) (Mumbling) I...I don't know... (Peeks through fingers, looking suspicious) Is this a trick question? (Wipes nose on sleeve again) Maybe...maybe... (Hesitates, looking away) ...maybe being mean is bad? (Shrugs, looking defensive) But he still deserved all the apples! (Lower lip trembles)
(Encouragingly) Being mean *can* lead to bad things, like getting poked with needles! And what happened when he wasn't mean anymore, when he was kind and said sorry?

(Still sniffling, but a little calmer) (Mumbles, avoiding eye contact) He...he got more apples. (Voice barely a whisper) (Looks up, a glimmer of defiance in eyes) But he should have gotten them sooner! The story's still dumb! (Crosses arms, sulking)

(Gently) He got more apples. So, the story shows us that being kind can lead to good things, like getting more apples! It's like the story is saying, if you're kind, good things might happen to you.

What do we call it when you do something nice for someone?

(Sighs loudly, fidgeting in chair) Ugh. This is boring. (Mumbles) Nice... (Looks away, thinking for a moment) (Taps fingers softly on desk) (Finally, blurts out) ...Generous! (Looks proud of herself, but then quickly adds defensively) But he was already generous 'cause he was going to chop the tree to sell the wood to help other people! So he should have gotten ALL the apples for being generous in the first place!

(Nodding) Being generous is definitely a nice thing to be! But in this story, being kind to his *brother* is what made the tree give him more apples.

So, what do we call it when you are nice to someone like your brother?

(Glares, kicking the desk leg a bit harder) (Grumbling) I don't know! And I don't care! (Starts picking at a hangnail) It's still a stupid story. The tree should have known he was already generous on the inside and just given him ALL the apples! He's the best wood chopper ever! (Voice rising, getting agitated again) This is boring! Can I go play now?

(Patiently) It's called being kind. Being kind is being nice to people. The story shows us that being kind can lead to good things. The story teaches us that kindness will always be rewarded.

Do you understand now?

(Sighs dramatically, rolling eyes) (Muttering) Yeah, yeah. Kindness... (Taps fingers impatiently) Whatever. (Looks up, a flicker of defiance in her eyes) Can I go play now? Or do I have to talk about dumb trees and apples forever? (Crosses arms, sulking and waiting for you to say yes)
(Smiling warmly) Yes, you can go play now. You did a good job thinking about the story and what it means. Remember, kindness will always be rewarded. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was King Midas and the Golden Touch.

First, tell me, who gave Midas the chance to make a wish?

(Eyes darting around, fidgeting with my pencil, but voice loud and clear)

Dionysus! He's the god of wine, right? (Sticks tongue out slightly) He gave Midas the wish because Midas did something nice for a… a… (thinking, tapping pencil) …Satyr! I knew that! (Confidently)

That's right! You remembered perfectly. Dionysus, the god of wine, gave Midas a wish because he helped a Satyr.

What did Midas wish for?

(Leans forward, practically bouncing in my seat)

He wished that everything he touched would turn to GOLD! All shiny and stuff! (Grins widely) I would wish for that too! (Looks away, quickly adds) Well, maybe... I'm good at gold, yeah, really good at it. I use lots of strategies, like... um... well, I know lots!

Wow, gold sounds exciting, doesn't it?

After Midas got his wish, what was the first thing that went wrong?

(Scowls slightly, crossing arms)

He couldn't EAT! (Voice rising in indignation) Stupid wish! What's the point of having gold if you can't even eat your lunch? I would NEVER make that mistake. I always think things through. (Taps head) Strategies, you know? Besides, gold doesn't taste good anyway. Yuck! I'm smart to get lots of strategies, too.

You're absolutely right! He couldn't eat. Everything turned to gold, even his food.

Who else did Midas accidentally turn to gold?

(Scoffs, rolling eyes)

Ugh, his DAUGHTER! (Shakes head) She just wanted to hug him. Dumb wish made her all… statue-y. He should have known better. It's obvious! I would have known better. (Mumbles under breath) Always gotta think, think, think...
Yes, his daughter! He loved her very much, didn't he? How do you think Midas felt when he turned his daughter into gold?

(Frowns, kicks the desk lightly)

(Aggressively) He felt…bad! Really bad! Like, the worst ever! (Looks away, voice softer) But it's HIS fault. He shouldn't have been so greedy and stupid. He had to make the wish... He should have used his head more. Like me.

You're right, it was his fault, and he probably felt terrible.

So, Midas wanted everything to turn to gold. He thought it would make him happy. But did it?

(Scoffs, folding arms again)

NO! (Emphasis on "NO!") It made him super sad and hungry! It was a terrible wish! He should have wished for… I don't know… more toys! Or candy! (Suddenly animated) But not too much candy, 'cause that's bad for your teeth! I know that. Strategies for healthy life is important, and I know the best ones!
Okay! So, Midas thought having everything turn to gold would be wonderful, but it wasn't. What do you think this story is trying to teach us? What is the story trying to tell us?

(Taps foot impatiently, staring at the ceiling)

It's trying to teach us... (pauses dramatically) ...that being greedy is BAD! (Points finger accusingly at an imaginary person) And that you shouldn't wish for stupid things! dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was The Fox and the Grapes.

Now, can you tell me, what did the fox want?

(Shifts impatiently, tapping foot) He wanted the grapes! (Points at the book with a little too much force) Big, purple, juicy grapes. The story said it right there! (Rolls eyes slightly) What else would he want? Grapes are yummy!

You're right! He really wanted those grapes.

Why do you think he wanted them so much?

(Scoffs) Duh! (Crosses arms) Because he was hungry! It said he looked "everywhere for food"! (Taps fingers on arm impatiently) He wanted to eat them! Why else would a *hungry* fox want *grapes*? It's super obvious.

Okay, okay, you're right, it was obvious. He was hungry.

What did the fox do to try and get the grapes?

(Looks at the book briefly, then back at the teacher, confidently) He jumped! He jumped "as high as possible." The story said that too! (Taps foot faster) He wanted to reach them, so he jumped. (Raises eyebrows, like 'duh').
Yes, he jumped! Did he get the grapes?

(Looks away, slightly annoyed) No! (Shrugs). He failed. (Taps foot again) The story *also* said that. Why are you asking me things the story already told us? (Voice gets a little louder) It's a waste of time!

I'm asking to make sure you understand! It's okay if you know the answers.

So, he didn't get the grapes. What did the fox do *then*?

(Sighs dramatically, rolls eyes) He gave up! (Waves hand dismissively). He went home! And he said... (pauses, thinking) ...he said the grapes were probably sour anyway! He didn't even want them anymore! (Looks up at the ceiling, then back at the teacher, a little bored) Can we do something else now? This story is kinda dumb.

Okay, so the fox gave up and said the grapes were sour.

Do you *really* think the fox thought the grapes were sour? Or was he just saying that? Why would he say that?

(Confidently) He was just saying that! (Points a finger) He *wanted* the grapes! He was just trying to feel better because he couldn't get them! (Puffs out chest a little). It's like...like when I can't win at tag and I say I didn't even WANT to be "it"! (Nods head decisively) It's the same thing! (Taps foot faster, waiting for the teacher's reaction).

That's a *great* comparison! You really understand!

So, the fox pretended he didn't want something he *really* did. Why do you think the story tells us this? What is the story trying to teach us?

(Looks confused for a second, then shrugs) I don't know. Stories don't *teach* you anything. They're just... stories. (Sticks tongue out a little). Maybe it's just telling us that foxes can't jump very high. (Looks at the teacher expectantly, waiting for the next question, a little bored)

Hmm. It *is* a story, but stories can have a message.

Think about it: The fox wanted something, he couldn't get it, and then he pretended he didn't want it anyway. What does that tell you about trying to get things you want? Is it always easy?

(Sighs loudly) No, it's not always easy! (Rolls eyes). I already knew that! Sometimes the swing is taken, or someone else gets the last cookie, or I don't get to be line leader! (Crosses arms again). It's not fair, but it happens. So? The fox just needs to try harder next time, or find some *lower* grapes. Problem solved! (Looks away, uninterested).

Okay, you're right, things aren't always fair, and we don't always get what we want. And yes, the fox *could* try harder next time.

But what about when you try *really* hard, and you *still* can't get it? What then? Is it okay to be like the fox and say you didn't want it anyway?

(Thinking, scratches head) Hmm... (looks at the teacher, then at the book) I guess... I guess it's okay to say you didn't want it... (Stutters a little) ...but...but maybe you should *still* try to get it? Or ask for help? (Looks down at shoes, then back up, a little defiant) But sometimes, it's just...too hard. So... sour grapes are fine. (Shrugs, taps foot, ready to move on).

You're getting close! It's okay to be disappointed when you can't get something, and it's okay to want to feel better.

But the story might be telling us something else too. It might be telling us that it's important to not hate something *just* because you can't have it. Do you see what I mean?

(Furrows brow, thinking hard. Bites lip for a second) So...so it's bad to say the grapes are sour, even if I *really* wanted them? Even if they're too high up? (Looks at the teacher, a little confused) But... what else am I supposed to do? Just be sad forever? That's even *worse*! (Frowns).

No, not be sad forever! It's okay to be sad. But maybe, instead of saying "I didn't want them anyway," you could find something else you *can* have that's also good.

Maybe the fox could have found some berries instead. He couldn't get the grapes, and that's okay, but he shouldn't pretend grapes are bad just because of that.

Does that make a little more sense? It's like... nothing comes easy, and you shouldn't hate what you can’t have.

(Pauses, thinking hard. Looks at the book, then back at the teacher) Okay... (Nods slowly) So... the fox should have found berries... (Nods faster, understanding a little) ...and not said the grapes were yucky. (Looks up, a little brighter) Because even if *he* couldn't reach them, someone *else* might! And it's not fair to say they're bad if they're not! (Taps foot, but not as impatiently. A small smile appears) I get it! (A little proud). Now can we read a story about a *jumping* fox?

Yes, you got it! The fox shouldn't have pretended the grapes were bad just because he couldn't get them. It's better to find something else you *can* enjoy.

You understood the story and its lesson very well. Great job! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Proud Rose."

Now, can you tell me, who are the two main plants in the story?

(Fidgets with my pencil, tapping it on the desk)

Uh, yeah! (Confidently) The two main plants are a... a rose, a really pretty one, and a… (Looks away, thinking) …cactus! A prickly, green cactus! I knew that! (Smirks a little)

That's right! A rose and a cactus.

Now, can you tell me, what did the rose think about the cactus? Did she like him?

(Scoffs and rolls my eyes) Like him? Pfft! (Sits up straighter, voice a bit louder) The rose didn't LIKE the cactus! She thought she was, like, WAY better! She kept saying mean things to him, cause she was so pretty and he was just... a cactus! Everyone knows roses are better! (Crosses my arms)

Okay, so the rose thought she was better than the cactus because she was pretty.

Why did the other plants try to help the cactus?

(Taps foot impatiently)

Because the rose was being a BIG meanie! (Voice rises slightly) The other plants, they weren't stupid like the rose. They saw the cactus wasn't doing anything wrong! He was just... existing! It's not his fault he's not a rose! It's not fair to be mean to someone just because they aren't as pretty! (Glares a little)
You're right, it wasn't fair. Now, what happened when it got really hot and there was no water?

(Leans forward, eager to answer)

The rose started to, like, droop and get all sad! (Voice is a little excited) She was all withery and yucky because she needed water! But the cactus... (pauses for dramatic effect)... he was okay! He even had water for the birdies! The sparrows! (Nods head emphatically) The rose wasn't so pretty then, huh? (A slight smirk plays on my lips)
That's right! The rose wasn't so pretty then. So, the rose needed something from the cactus. What did she need?

(Raises an eyebrow, like it's obvious)

Duh! (Voice is a little louder again) She needed WATER! She was all dried up and sad, and she had to ask the cactus for help! The cactus had water, and she didn't! Serves her right for being so mean! (Folds arms again, a satisfied look on my face).
Okay, and did the cactus help her? Even after she was mean?

(Nods quickly, but a bit grudgingly)

Yeah, (Voice a bit softer, almost like I'm forced to admit it) he helped her. He gave her water. The stupid cactus was nice, even though the rose was awful to him. I would have let her dry up! (Mumbles the last part, looking away).
The cactus *was* very nice. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? Is it about how important it is to be pretty?

(Scoffs loudly, rolls my eyes again)

No way! (Voice is loud and emphatic) It's not about being pretty! Being pretty doesn't matter when you're all dried up in the desert! (Taps fingers on the desk, thinking harder than before, but still confidently) It's about… it's about being NICE! Even if someone isn't pretty, or... or cool, you shouldn't be mean to them! And even if someone is mean to you, sometimes you still have to help them! (Frowns a little, like that last part is annoying). It's about what's on the INSIDE! (Points to my chest with a flourish)
You got it! It's about being nice and not judging others. Is it okay to judge someone just because they look different?

(Shakes head vehemently, nearly knocking over my pencil cup)

NO! (Voice is very loud and firm) It's NOT okay to judge someone 'cause they look different! That's what the ROSE did, and she was a big jerk! It doesn't matter if you're a rose or a cactus or a… a rock! (Sticks tongue out a little, emphasizing the silliness of the idea) You shouldn't be mean to people just because they're not like you! (Nods head, feeling very sure of myself).
Exactly! So, what's the lesson of the story? What should we learn from the Proud Rose and the Cactus?

(Stands up suddenly, excited)

I KNOW! (Points a finger in the air) We should learn to be like the CACTUS! (Pauses, then corrects myself, but still loudly) Well, not prickly, but... (Taps foot, thinking hard) We should be NICE! And helpful! Even if people are mean to us, we should still help them if they need it! And... and we shouldn't be like the ROSE! (Sits down with a thump, feeling pleased with myself). We should be nice on the inside, not just care about being pretty on the outside! Being pretty doesn't matter if you are MEAN! (Nods firmly, feeling like I've totally nailed it).
Wonderful! You understood the story perfectly. We should never judge someone just because of how they look. It's important to be kind and helpful, just like the cactus. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Milkmaid and Her Pail."

First, can you tell me, who was the main person in our story?

(Sits up straight, tapping my foot impatiently)

Molly! (Confidently) It was Molly! She was the milk... milk... uh... (Sticks out tongue, trying to remember) Milk...maid! Yeah! Molly the milkmaid! And she had milk! Lots of it! (Starts to get excited) I know this!
Yes! You got it! Molly the milkmaid! What was Molly going to do with the milk?

(Jumps a little in my seat, eager to answer)

Sell it! (Points finger) She was gonna sell it at the market! And then... and then... (Eyes widen) Buy a chicken! A big, fat, egg-laying chicken! (Starts miming flapping wings with hands) She was gonna get sooooo many eggs! More than *anybody* else! (Puffs out chest)
That's right! She wanted to sell the milk, and then buy a chicken! What did she imagine she would do *after* she bought the chicken?

(Taps chin importantly)

More money! (Confidently) 'Cause the chicken would lay eggs! And she could sell *those* too! (Looks away, starting to think about all the things she could buy with the money) And... and... make all the *other* milkmaids jealous! (Sniffs dismissively) They probably don't even have chickens. (Crosses arms)
Okay, good! She was thinking about more money from the eggs. Now, what happened *while* she was walking to the market, thinking about all this?

(Frowns slightly)

Ugh. (Rolls eyes) That was the dumb part. She spilled it! (Points emphatically) All the milk! It went *sploosh* on the ground! (Makes a spilling motion with hand) Because she was... skipping! (Looks annoyed) Stupid skipping! (Sticks out tongue)
Yes! The milk spilled! Why was spilling the milk a problem for Molly? What did she lose?

(Scoffs)

Everything! (Throws hands up in the air) No milk to sell, no money for chicken, no eggs, and (Leans in conspiratorially) no making the other milkmaids jealous! (Looks disgusted) It was all gone! (Sighs dramatically) All because of the stupid skipping. (Mumbles under breath) I would *never* do that.
You're right, she lost everything! So, at the end of the story, Molly went home with what?

(Glares)

Empty pails! (Stomps foot lightly) Empty, empty, empty! And probably (lowers voice) super mad! (Looks away, imagining Molly's frustration) Serves her right for skipping! (Mutters) But... still... empty pails. (Sighs again)
Empty pails, exactly! And what did her mother say to her when she got home?

(Wrinkles nose)

Something boring. (Taps fingers impatiently) Something about... (Squints eyes, trying to remember) uh... chickens... and... not... counting... them? (Looks up, confused) Before they... do... something? (Shrugs shoulders) I dunno. It was a weird saying. (Frowns) What *did* she say? (Actually curious for once)
Her mother said, "Don't count your chickens until they hatch." What do you think that means? Maybe think about what happened to Molly and her milk.

(Stares blankly, then narrows eyes, thinking hard)

Okay, you just read "A Wise Old Owl." That was a good story!

What did the owl do every day?
(Taps foot impatiently, looks around the room) He watched stuff! (Confidently) He watched stuff happening by his tree! Like, duh! (Rolls eyes a little) People talking and... stuff.

Okay, good job! He watched stuff.

What happened *after* he watched things and heard people talking? Did he talk a lot about it?

(Scoffs) No! He didn't talk a lot! (Crosses arms) The story said he talked *less*! The more he watched, the less he talked! It's right there! (Points vaguely at the book) Why are you asking me stuff that's RIGHT THERE? (Looks away, annoyed)
You're right! He talked less. So, why do you think he talked less? What was happening *inside* the owl as he watched and listened?

(Shrugs, kicks at the carpet) He... I dunno. (Thinking, taps chin) He was getting... smarter? (Looks up, confidently) Because the story said he got wiser! Because he watched and listened! (Stands up straighter, puffing out chest slightly) So, he didn't need to talk so much 'cause he already KNEW stuff!

Exactly! He was getting wiser. He was learning!

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea?

(Sighs dramatically, rolls eyes) Ugh, another question? (Thinks for a very short time) (Confidently) That if you watch and listen, you get smarter! Like the owl! Then you don't have to talk as much 'cause you already know stuff! (Grins, pleased with self) Can I go play now?

That's right! Watching and listening can help you learn and become wise, like the owl. So maybe, sometimes, it's better to listen than to talk all the time.

Do you think that's a good idea? Why or why not?

(Frowns, considers this for a moment, taps foot) Well... (Looks around the room, distracted for a second) I LIKE to talk! (Confidently) I have lots of good things to say! But... (Glares at the book) I guess... if you just talk, you don't learn anything new. The owl wouldn't have gotten wise if he was just yapping all the time! (Sticks tongue out slightly) I guess listening is... okay. (Shrugs) But I still like talking better!

That's a very good point. It's important to talk and share your ideas too! But the owl reminds us that listening is important as well.

So, the story teaches us that sometimes it's good to talk less and watch and listen more. Then you learn and become wise. Do you understand?

(Nods head quickly, eager to be done) Yeah, yeah, I get it. (Starts to back away slightly) Talk less, listen more, get wise. Like the owl. (Turns and starts to run towards the door) Can I go now? Pleeeeease? I wanna play!
Okay, you understand the story. Yes, you can go play now. <finish>

First, can you tell me, who are the characters in the story?

(Taps foot impatiently, almost bouncing) Yeah, it was kinda sad. (rolls eyes) The characters? Easy! There was the farmer... and his wife... and the goose! (Sticks out tongue a little) That's it! I knew it!
Excellent! You got them all! Now, what was so special about the goose? What did it do every day?

(Puffs out cheeks, clearly impatient) Ugh, this is *so* boring! (But then, remembering the story) The goose... (Confidently) The goose laid a golden egg every day! A GOLDEN egg! (Eyes widen slightly, then quickly return to being bored) It was like, a super-special goose.
That's right! It *was* a super-special goose. And what did the farmer do with the golden egg?

(Crosses arms, leans back in chair) He sold it, duh! (Scoffs) What else would you do with a golden egg? Eat it? (Wrinkles nose) Gross! He sold it and they got money! (Taps foot faster) Can we be done now?
You're doing great! Yes, he sold it and got money. And because he sold the golden eggs, how were the farmer and his wife doing? Were they happy? Were they rich?
(Sighs dramatically) They were... comfortable, I guess. (Looks around the room, clearly uninterested) Not super-rich, but not poor either. Just... okay. (Shrugs) Big deal. Can I go play now?
"Comfortable" is a good word! So, they were comfortable. But then, something changed. What did the farmer want? He wasn't happy being comfortable, was he?

(Eyes narrow slightly, thinking... for a second, then blurts out) He wanted MORE! (Points a finger) He was greedy! He wanted, like, a million golden eggs! All at once! (Makes grabby hands in the air) He's so dumb!
You're right! He was greedy. And what did he do because he was greedy? What did he do to the goose? This is the most important part!

(Grimaces, looks away briefly) He... he cut it open. (Looks back, a little defiant) He wanted all the golden eggs inside. But there weren't any! (Smirks a little) Serves him right! He's a dummy! (Starts swinging legs)
Yes, he did! And was that a good idea? What happened after he cut open the goose? Did he get lots of golden eggs?

(Bursts out laughing) NO! (Laughs harder) He got nothing! Just... (Makes a disgusted face) Blood and guts! Ewww! (Calms down a bit) He messed up BIG TIME! No more golden eggs! He's totally broke now! (Sticks tongue out)

Exactly! He messed up big time. So, because he was greedy and cut open the goose, now he had no more golden eggs. He became poor.

Do you think the farmer thought about what would happen *before* he cut open the goose?

(Scoffs, rolls eyes) NO WAY! (Shakes head vigorously) He's too dumb to think! He just wanted all the gold! He didn't think about, like... the goose being dead and stuff. (Taps fingers on the desk impatiently) He's a super-duper dummy!

You got it! He didn't think about what would happen. And because he didn't think, he made a bad choice and now he's poor.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the lesson we can learn from the farmer and his goose? Think about what happened because he didn't think first.

(Grumbling) A lesson? Ugh! (Thinks for a very short time, then shouts) Don't be greedy! (Pauses, then adds quickly) And... and think before you do something stupid! (Looks proud of himself for a split second, then returns to being bored) Is that right? Can I go now? I wanna play tag!

That's *exactly* right! Don't be greedy, and think before you do something! It's important to think about what might happen *before* you act.

So, the moral of the story is, think before you act. Do you understand the story now? <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! Great job reading the story! It was about a farmer and his neighbour.

First, tell me, who bought something in the story?

(Bounces in my seat, eager to answer)

The farmer! The farmer bought the well! (Points excitedly at the teacher). He wanted it for his farm, so he could get water! (Starts to get up, then remembers to sit down).

That's right! The farmer bought the well.

Why do you think the farmer bought the well? You already started to tell me!

(Eyes widen, ready to explain)

For water! Duh! (Rolls eyes slightly, but tries to hide it). The farmer needed water for his farm! To make the plants grow! He couldn't just let them be thirsty, right? (Taps foot impatiently, waiting for the teacher to agree).

You're absolutely right! He needed water for his farm.

Now, what did the neighbor do that wasn't very nice?

(Frowns, thinking hard, sticks tongue out slightly)

He... he didn't let the farmer use the water! (Looks at the teacher, confused). He sold the well, but he said the farmer couldn't take any water out! That's super dumb! (Crosses arms, huffs a little).

Yes, that wasn't very fair, was it?

So, what did the farmer do because the neighbour wasn't letting him use the water? Who did he go see?

(Paces a little despite sitting)

He went to... (snaps fingers) ...the emperor! (Points up in the air like the emperor is floating there). He went to get justice! The neighbor was being mean! The emperor is like, the boss of everyone! (Looks at teacher expectantly, waiting for praise for knowing such a big word like 'justice').

That's right! He went to the emperor for justice. Good job using that word!

What did the emperor's helper, the courtier, ask the neighbor? What did the neighbor say?

(Eyes dart around, thinking, fidgets with pencil)

Um... (Sticks tongue out, concentrating) The courtier asked the neighbor... (Pauses dramatically) something about the well... and the water! And the neighbor was all like, "I sold him the *well*, not the *water*!" (Mimics a snooty voice for the neighbor). He thought he was so smart! (Scoffs).

You remembered perfectly! He did think he was very smart!

But what happened next? What did the courtier tell the neighbour to do? This is the tricky part!

(Scrunches up face, thinks really hard. Taps pencil rapidly on the desk)

Umm... the courtier... he said... (Stops tapping, looks up suddenly, excited) He said the neighbor had to pay rent! (Grins triumphantly) Pay rent for the water! Or take it all out RIGHT AWAY! Because it was in *the farmer's* well now! (Beams proudly).

Yes! That's exactly right! He had to pay rent or take all the water out.

Why do you think the courtier told him to do that? What was the courtier trying to show the neighbour?

(Leans forward, eager to explain. Speaks quickly)

Because it was a trick! The neighbor was trying to trick the farmer! If the neighbor had to pay rent, he'd be paying *the farmer*! And he couldn't take all the water out, because where would he put it? (Giggles). The courtier was showing him that his plan didn't make any sense! (Nods head decisively). He was being silly!

Exactly! The courtier showed him his trick didn't work.

So, what did the neighbor do after the courtier told him that?

(Sighs dramatically, rolls eyes)

He said he was sorry! (Makes a face like he's about to be sick) He went home. Booooring! He knew he messed up! He didn't want to pay rent! He didn't want to carry all the water! He knew he was beat! (Pumps fist in the air).

Right! He apologized and went home.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea we should learn from this story?

(Puts hand on chin, pretends to be thinking deeply, but already knows the answer)

Ummm... (pauses for effect) ...don't be a trickster! (Points finger accusingly at an imaginary neighbor). Don't try to be sneaky and cheat people! Because you'll get caught! And you'll have to say sorry! (Grins mischievously). And maybe pay rent! (Giggles).

That's it! If you try to cheat someone, it won't work out for you in the end. Cheating will get you nowhere.

You understood the story really well! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends."

First, can you tell me who the story is about?

(Confidently) It's about an elephant! (Starts tapping my foot impatiently) And some other animals, but mostly the elephant. He wanted friends. (Rolls my eyes slightly) That's what the whole story was about! Elephants and friends. Duh.

Yes, that's right! The story is about an elephant who wanted friends.

Why was the elephant lonely at the start?

(Looks away, picking at my fingernails) Because nobody wanted to be his friend! (Scoffs) The monkey was being silly, saying he couldn't swing. And the rabbit... (makes a rude gesture) Stupid rabbit and his stupid hole! The frog was just dumb. (Crosses my arms) No one wanted to be friends 'cause he was too big or something. It's in the story! (Taps foot faster)

You're right, it *is* in the story! You remembered all those details.

So, how did the monkey, rabbit, and frog feel about the elephant being big? Did they think it was a good thing or a bad thing for a friend to be big?

(Glares a little) Bad! Obviously bad! (Rolls eyes again) The monkey wanted someone who could swing! (Waves hands dismissively) The rabbit was all, "You're too big for my burrow!" (Sticks tongue out) And the frog... who cares about the frog? (Taps foot even faster, getting impatient) They all thought it was bad he was big! That's why he was lonely! It's not that hard to understand!

Okay, okay! I see you understand. They thought his size was a problem.

But then, something happened the next day in the forest, right? Something that made the other animals change their minds? What was it?

(Sighs dramatically) A tiger! (Looks around the room quickly, then back to the teacher) A mean tiger was scaring everyone! They were all running around like chickens with their heads cut off! (Confident smirk) But *I* wouldn't be scared. I'd kick the tiger too! (Puffs out chest a little)

(Chuckles) I bet you would be brave!

And what did the *elephant* do about the tiger?
(Smirks) He kicked it! (Nods head emphatically) He told it to stop, but the tiger was being a jerk. So he kicked it! Just like I would! (Pumps fist) Then the tiger ran away. (Crosses arms again)
He sure did! And what happened *after* the elephant scared the tiger away? How did the other animals feel about the elephant *then*?

(Taps chin, but really I already know the answer) Oh! (Smirks again) They were all, like, "Oh, now you're big and strong and you can save us from the tiger!" (Mimics a scared voice) "Please be our friend, Elephant!" (Rolls eyes) They only liked him 'cause he kicked the tiger. (Shrugs) But he *did* kick the tiger! (Grins)

Exactly! They changed their minds about the elephant because he helped them.

So, at the beginning of the story, the animals thought being big was a bad thing for a friend. But at the end, they thought it was a good thing. What changed their minds? What did they *learn*?

(Sighs loudly, like this is taking too long) They learned that being big is good if you can kick tigers! (Stands up and starts pacing) Duh! (Looks expectantly at the teacher) Can I go now? I know everything!

(Chuckles) You *do* know a lot! But maybe it's not *just* about kicking tigers.

Think about it: Was the elephant's size *always* a bad thing? Or was it only a bad thing when they didn't need help?

(Stops pacing and thinks for a moment, frowning) (Mutters under breath) Hmmm... (Taps foot slower, actually thinking)

(Looks up, a little less confident) I guess... I guess it wasn't always bad. Like, when there wasn't a tiger, they just wanted someone who could swing or fit in a hole. But when the tiger came... then being big was good. (Shrugs) So... it depends?

It *does* depend! You're getting it!

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us about friends? Does a friend have to be a certain way to be helpful or good?

(Shrugs, still a little fidgety but thinking more deeply) (Stuttering a bit) Um... I... I guess not. Like, the monkey is good at swinging, and the rabbit is good at hiding, and the elephant is good at kicking tigers... (Looks down, scuffing shoe on the floor) Maybe... maybe different friends are good for different things? And... and maybe you shouldn't just say no 'cause someone is different? (Looks up, a little defiant) Even if they're... big?
You got it! So, can friends be different sizes and shapes? Can they have different skills?

(Nods head quickly, finally understanding) Yeah! (Beams, then quickly tries to look cool again) Yeah, different friends are okay. As long as someone can kick a tiger if they need to! (Grins mischievously) Can I go now? I really, *really* know everything!

(Smiles) Yes, you really do! You figured out that friends can be all sorts of shapes and sizes, and that what makes them special is what they can do and how they help. The story teaches us that friends can be any shape or size. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! That was a good story, right?

Can you tell me, what did the girl want from her dad?

(Fidgets with my pencil, glancing around the room) Yeah, it was okay. (Looks at the teacher briefly, then back down at the desk) She wanted... advice. (Confidently) About her life being frustrating! (Shrugs, tapping the pencil against the desk) It's like, what else would she want? Advice, duh. I would've just fixed it myself, though. Asking for help is kinda... lame.

Okay, she wanted advice because she was frustrated. Good job remembering that!

Now, what did her dad ask her to bring him? Three things! Can you remember them? Take your time.

(Scoffs, rolling my eyes slightly) Taking my time? I don't *need* time. (Taps fingers impatiently on the desk) It was... (Thinking, then confidently) An egg! And a potato! (Looks away, concentrating) Oh! And... tea leaves! (Smirks a little, pleased with myself) See? I got it! No time needed.

You got them all! Excellent remembering!

Now, what did he do with those things? What was happening in the kitchen?

(Leans back in my chair, a slight air of boredom) Ugh, this is taking too long. He put them... in water! (Sighs dramatically) Big deal. He boiled them. I know that already. Anyone knows that. (Taps foot impatiently) Can we move on? This is, like, super simple.
Okay, he boiled them. And what happened to the egg after it was boiled? Was it the same as before?

(Crosses my arms, looking away) No, duh! It got... hard. (Slightly annoyed) It was all soft and squishy before, and then... (Shrugs) Hard. Like a rock almost. That's obvious. What's the point of asking? (Grumbling under my breath) Waste of time...
You're right, it became hard! And what about the potato? What happened to the potato after being boiled?

(Sighs again, louder this time) The potato got... soft. (Rolls my eyes) It's the opposite of the egg. You said it yourself. Hard before, soft after. (Taps my fingers, clearly impatient) Is there, like, a prize for knowing this? Because otherwise... (Trails off, looking pointedly at the teacher).

No prize, but you're doing great! You remembered everything so well.

Okay, last one! What happened to the tea leaves when they were boiled? Did they become hard or soft?

(Scoffs) Tea leaves? Hard or soft? That's a dumb question! (Taps pencil aggressively on the desk) They didn't get hard or soft! They changed the water! (Looks at the teacher with a challenging expression) They made tea! It's not rocket science.

Exactly! They changed the water. So, the egg changed, the potato changed, and the tea leaves changed the water.

Now, the dad said this was like when things are hard in our lives. The egg, the potato, and the tea leaves all faced the same hot water, but they all changed in a different way.

The girl was frustrated with life. How do you think the egg is like her frustration?

(Frowns, pushing my chair back slightly) Frustration? I don't get frustrated. It's stupid. (Thinking, but still sounding annoyed) But... okay, the egg... it was soft before, like... easily messed with, maybe? (Shrugs) And then it got hard. Like, tough. So maybe frustration... makes you tough? I guess. (Looks unconvinced) But I'm already tough, so I wouldn't know.

Okay, the egg got tough. You said maybe frustration makes you tough. That's a good idea!

What about the potato? It was hard, and then it got soft. What could that mean about dealing with hard times?

(Sighs dramatically, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) Ugh, this is so boring. Okay, the potato... it was hard, then soft. So... (Thinks, wrinkling my nose) Maybe hard times make you soft? Like, weak? (Scoffs) That's dumb. Nobody wants to be a soft potato. I'd rather be a hard egg. (Looks up, a bit defiant) Being soft is for losers.

Being a hard egg or soft potato isn't really about being a loser or not. It's just different ways to react.

Think about it this way: Maybe the potato started out tough, but the hard times *changed* it and made it gentle. Someone who is gentle is not necessarily a loser.

Now what about the tea leaves? They didn't become hard or soft. What did they do differently?

(Crosses arms again, looking skeptical) Gentle? (Makes a face) Whatever. Okay, the tea... (Thinking, tapping foot) They changed the water, right? So... (Eyes widen slightly, a flicker of understanding) They didn't just change themselves, they changed everything *around* them. (Shrugs, trying to downplay the idea) I guess that's... kinda cool. But still. Eggs are cooler.

You're right! The tea leaves changed the water, they changed their surroundings.

So, the egg got hard, the potato got soft, and the tea changed the water. They all faced the same problem (the boiling water), but they reacted differently.

What do you think the dad was trying to teach his daughter about dealing with problems?

(Stares at the ceiling for a moment, then back at the teacher, a little less defiant now) He was trying to say... (Frowns, concentrating) that there's, like, different ways to handle stuff when things get bad? (Looks down at my hands, fidgeting) That you can get tough, or... (Makes a face) ...soft, or... (Looks up, a spark of understanding in my eyes) ...change things. Not just yourself, but everything. (Shrugs, trying to sound nonchalant) I still think being an egg is the best, though. But... (Trails off, looking thoughtful) The tea thing is kinda... interesting.

You got it! He wanted her to see that we can *choose* how we react when things get tough.

So, if you were to tell someone the main idea of the story, what would you say? What's the story trying to teach us?

(Sits up straighter, a little more confident again) Okay, so the story is about... (Thinks for a second, organizing my thoughts) ...how when bad stuff happens, you can be like an egg and get tough, or be a stupid potato and get soft... (Pauses, then adds reluctantly) ...or be like tea leaves and change the whole thing. (Looks at the teacher, a hint of pride in my eyes) It's about choosing what to do when things are hard. But being an egg is still the best. (Grins slightly) Just sayin'.
Exactly! You choose! That's the most important part. We decide how to respond to difficult situations. You understood the story really well. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Needle Tree! That was a long story! Now, let's see what you remember.

First, can you tell me about the two brothers? What were they like?

(Standing straight, hands on my hips, looking at the teacher)

Okay! The older brother was, uh... (scoffs) he was not nice! He was mean to his little brother. He chopped wood to sell, and then he got needles! Serves him right! (crosses arms) The little brother... (looks away, thinking) ...he was okay, I guess. He helped the mean older brother. But why did he even bother? He should have just left him there! (frowns) I would have!

Wow, you have strong feelings about the older brother! He *was* mean, wasn't he?

Why do you think the little brother helped him even though he was mean?

(Shrugs, tapping my foot impatiently)

I dunno. Maybe he's just... (searching for a word) ...dumb? Why would you help someone who's mean to you? That's just stupid! (rolls eyes) My brother is sometimes mean to me, but I just ignore him. Or I take his toys. (grins mischievously) He learns his lesson then! This little brother should have done that too! He should have taken all the golden apples for himself! (confidently) That's what *I* would have done!
(Chuckles softly) You're a tough one! But even though the little brother didn't take the golden apples, what did he *do* for his older brother? What did the story say?

(Fidgeting, glancing out the window)

Ugh, fine. (stuttering) H-he... he took out all the needles. All of them! (confidently) But it was probably super boring! (Sighs dramatically) I would have gotten bored and left halfway through. Needles are gross anyway! Did he have to pull out *every single one*? That's a lot of work for someone who was mean to you! Maybe he's not so dumb. Maybe he's just trying to trick the older brother into giving him the golden apples later! (nods head knowingly) Yeah, that's probably it!

He did take out all the needles! That *was* a lot of work, especially after the older brother was mean to him.

After the little brother helped him, what did the older brother do? Do you remember?

(Looks at the teacher suspiciously)

He... he said sorry. (making a face) Blech! Saying sorry doesn't fix anything! (crosses arms) If someone gave me a bunch of needles, I wouldn't just say sorry! I'd... I'd... (thinking hard) ...I'd give them back even *more* needles! Saying sorry is just for babies! Did the little brother even *believe* him? I wouldn't! (confidently) He was probably just faking it so he could get more golden apples. He's still a meanie!
You really don't believe he was sorry, do you? Okay, well, the story says he apologized. And *then* what happened after he apologized? What did the tree do?

(Sighs dramatically, tapping fingers on the desk)

Fine, fine. The stupid tree... (reluctantly) ...gave them more golden apples. (rolls eyes) So, being mean gets you golden apples? That's not fair! (indignantly) The tree should have given *me* golden apples! I'm not mean! Well, not *all* the time... (mumbles) It's just sometimes... (looks away, embarrassed) ...never mind! The tree is dumb! It should have given the nice brother all the apples and told the mean brother to go away! That's what *I* would have done if I was a magical tree!
So, the tree gave them more golden apples *after* the older brother apologized. Why do you think the tree did that? What changed?

(Ponders, looking up at the ceiling)

Hmm... (taps chin) Maybe... maybe the tree was testing them? Like, it wanted to see if the mean brother could *ever* be nice? And when he said sorry (even though he probably didn't mean it!), the tree was like, "Okay, fine, you passed the test. Here's some more golden apples." (pauses) But it's still not fair! (stamps foot) Being mean shouldn't get you rewards! It should get you... (eyes widen) ...extra homework! Yeah! That's what should happen! If you're mean, you get extra homework! (nods head emphatically)
That's an interesting idea about the tree testing them! So, what do you think the tree wanted them to learn? What lesson was the tree trying to teach them?

(Crosses arms, leaning back in the chair)

(Scoffs) That being mean is okay, as long as you say sorry later and get free stuff? (raises eyebrow) That's a terrible lesson! The tree should have taught them that being mean gets you nothing! Or... or that being nice is *actually* better than being mean! (thinking) But that's boring! (Sighs heavily) I guess the tree was trying to teach them to be... (struggling with the word) ...forgiving? But why should you forgive someone who was mean to you in the first place?! It doesn't make any sense! (confidently) I wouldn't forgive him! I'd take all the golden apples and run away!

Okay, you're right, just saying sorry doesn't magically fix everything. But what if the older brother *really* meant it? What if he learned that being mean wasn't a good way to be? And what if the little brother showed him that being kind, even when someone is mean to you, is a good thing? What could we learn from that?

(Looks at the teacher with suspicion)

(Stuttering) I... I don't know! That's... that's a lot of "what ifs"! (Looks away, picking at a loose thread on shirt) Maybe... maybe if the older brother *really* meant it, and if he *really* changed, then... then maybe the little brother was right to help him? (mumbles) But it's still risky! What if he goes back to being mean again? Then all that needle-pulling was for nothing! (confidently) I still think the little brother should have kept all the golden apples! He earned them! (Sighs) This story is confusing! Can we read a different one? One with dinosaurs? (Grins hopefully) Dinosaurs are way cooler!

Dinosaurs are cool! We can read about them later. But let's just think about this a little bit more.

If the little brother had *not* been kind, if he'd left the older brother with the needles, do you think the tree would have given them more golden apples? What do you think the tree wanted to see? It saw the older brother being mean, and then it saw something else. What was that?

(Taps foot impatiently)

dialogue:
Okay, let's talk about the story, The Golden Touch!

You just finished reading it. What did you think about the story? Did you like it?
(Looks down at my hands, fidgeting) Uh... it was... uh... (stuttering) kinda... um... interesting.
Interesting! What part did you find interesting? Was there a part that made you happy, or maybe a little sad?
(Thinking, tapping my foot) The...the part where the... the daughter... turned to gold. (Looks away, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) That was... uh... not good.
No, that wasn't good at all. How do you think King Midas felt when that happened?

(Shrugs) ...Sad? (pauses) He... he wanted gold... but... (eyes widen slightly, thinking beyond the question)... shouldn't have asked for it. (Raises hand) Why didn't he just wish for more food instead? Gold can't be eaten.

That's a great question! You're right, gold can't be eaten.

Why do you think he wished for the golden touch instead of something else, like more food? What did he want *most* of all, before he realised it was a bad idea?

(Hesitates, picks at the thread again, a little anxious) ...uh... Rich? (Looks at the teacher directly, a rare moment of eye contact) Was he... stupid? Dionysus warned him. (Frowns, showing a hint of annoyance) People should listen.

You're very clever! He wanted to be rich, and he thought gold would make him happy.

So, Midas wanted to be rich. He got his wish, and then... what happened? Tell me the order of things. What went wrong?

(Taps fingers on the desk, thinking hard, showing logical reasoning) He touched stuff. Then... gold. Then... hungry. Then... (voice cracks a little) ...daughter. (Looks down again, mood shifting and becoming more anxious) Food turned gold, daughter turned gold... everything turned gold. He couldn't... stop it.

Exactly! He couldn't eat, and then his daughter... You're right, he couldn't stop it.

So, at the beginning, he *thought* the golden touch would make him happy. But in the end, did it? What did he learn?

(Mumbles, almost inaudible) ...No. (Clears throat, speaking a little louder) Gold... isn't everything. (Frowns, thinking further) But if you *could* eat gold... then maybe it would be okay? (Looks at the teacher, a curious glint in their eye, thinking beyond given information again)
That's an interesting thought! But even if you could eat gold, do you think it would be as good as a yummy apple, or a piece of bread? What makes food good?

(Wrinkles nose) Uh... no. (Thinks for a moment, struggling to articulate the complex thought) It... it wouldn't be *alive*. Gold... it's just... shiny. (Looks up at the teacher, a hint of frustration creeping in) Everything he touched became like a statue. (Sighs dramatically). Why do people do dumb things?

That's a very grown-up question! Sometimes people think that having lots of something will make them happy, but they forget about the other important things in life. Like... what do *you* think is important? What's more important than shiny gold?
(Looks around the room, avoiding eye contact, seeming nervous) ...Don't know. (Pauses, then blurts out) Not turning people into statues! (A flash of anger crosses their face, then quickly disappears)

That's right! Not turning people into statues is definitely more important than gold. Think about it like this, Midas was very, very greedy. He just wanted and wanted, even after he was warned.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big message of the story? What happens when someone is *too* greedy?

(Thinking, tapping a pencil on the desk. The tapping gets faster, showing anxiety) ...Bad things? (Looks at the teacher, unsure. Then, a sudden burst of understanding) ...They lose what they already have! (Voice is louder and more confident for a moment, then fades back down to a mumble) They lose... important stuff.

Yes! That's right. Being too greedy, wanting *everything*, can lead to losing what's truly important. You understood that very well.

So, we can say that greed leads to unhappiness. It led to King Midas losing his food and his daughter. What do you think about that? <finish>
