Okay, great job reading the story of the Proud Rose! I really enjoyed listening to you read.

Now, tell me in your own words, what was the story about? Can you tell me the main characters in the story?
Uh... (looks away) the story... uh... was about a rose and a... cactus. (thinking) The rose... wasn't very nice.

That's a great start! You're right, the story is about a rose and a cactus. And you're also right that the rose wasn't very nice.

What did the rose do that wasn't very nice?
(Shrugs) It... uh... made fun of the cactus. (Stares blankly)
Yes! The rose made fun of the cactus. Do you remember *why* the rose made fun of the cactus? What did the rose think about itself?
(Looks down at the desk, picks at a loose thread) It... thought it was pretty. (pauses) prettier than the... cactus.

Excellent! The rose thought it was prettier than the cactus. And because of that, it wasn't very nice.

Now, what happened when the summer got really, really hot? What did the plants need?
That's right! They needed water. And what happened to the rose when it didn't get enough water?
Yes, the rose withered. And what was the cactus doing while the rose was withering? Do you remember?
(Hesitates, looks at the ceiling) ... Uh... helping sparrows?
Yes! The cactus was helping the sparrows! How was the cactus helping the sparrows?
Exactly! The cactus was giving the sparrows water. And where did the cactus get the water from? Think about where cactuses usually keep water.
(Stares at the desk, deep in thought)......it kept it...inside?

Yes! Cactuses are very good at storing water inside themselves.

So, the rose is withering, and the cactus is helping the sparrows with water. What does the rose do then? Does it keep making fun of the cactus?
(Looks away, a little uncomfortable) No... It... asked for water.
Good! The rose asked the cactus for water. And did the cactus give the rose water?

Yes, the cactus gave the rose water. Even though the rose had been mean to it.

So, let's think about the whole story. The rose judged the cactus because of how it looked. Was that a good idea? What did the rose learn in the end?
(Scowls slightly) ...uh...not to be mean? (Looks down, shuffling feet)
You're getting close! It definitely learned not to be mean. But *why* shouldn't we be mean to others based on how they look? What did the rose learn about the cactus that it didn't know before?

(Sighs, picks at fingernails) ...uh... don't do it? (Looks up quickly, then back down)

(Long pause, thinking hard, chewing on lip) ...uh... they might... be nice? And... help you?

Yes! Exactly! We might miss out on meeting someone nice and helpful if we judge them by how they look. The story teaches us that it's not fair to judge someone based on their appearance. We should be kind to everyone, even if they look different from us.

So, can you tell me what the story is trying to teach us in one sentence? Start with "Never..."
(Glares at the table, then back at the teacher, hesitantly) ...Never...judge someone...by how they look... because... they might be nice...and helpful.
That's perfect! You explained it so well. The story "The Proud Rose" teaches us: Never judge someone according to how they look. You understood the story and the moral very well. Great job! <finish>

Okay! Let's talk about the story, okay? You just read "The Golden Egg."

What did the goose give the farmer every day?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my pencil)

A… a golden egg.
That's right! A golden egg. And what did the farmer do with the golden egg?

(Thinking, tapping my foot)

S-sold it. (Looks up briefly, then back down)
Yes, he sold it. And what happened when he sold the egg? What did he get?
Good job! He got money. And what did the farmer and his wife do with the money? Did they use it to buy things?
Uh-huh. Did they have enough money at first? Were they happy?
Okay. So, they had a goose, it laid a golden egg every day, they sold it and got money and were happy. Then, what happened? Why did the farmer cut open the goose?

(Stares at the table, brows furrowed)

…More.

(pauses, then speaks with a slightly louder, confident tone)

He wanted more.
He wanted more! That's right! He got greedy. He wanted more eggs faster. Did he get more eggs? What did he find inside the goose?

(Looks away, a slight frown appears)

... Blood. Guts.
Yes. Blood and guts. Did he get any more golden eggs?
No. So, what happened to the farmer and his wife after that? Did they stay rich?

(Eyes fixed on the table, voice barely a whisper)

…Poorer.

Yes, they became poorer. They lost everything. So, the farmer wanted more, he acted quickly and without thinking and ended up losing everything.

What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the lesson?

(Thinking hard, tapping pencil on the desk. A confident look flickers across face.)

…Don’t… don’t be greedy. (looks down again)

That's a good start! It is about not being greedy. But it's also about *why* he shouldn't have been greedy. Why was it a bad idea to try and get all the eggs at once? What should he have done *before* he cut open the goose?

(Stares blankly, then shrugs, voice quiet and mumbled)

…Dunno.
Okay, let's think. He had a good thing going, right? One egg a day. Was that working for him?
Yeah. So, instead of ruining it, what should he have done? Should he have thought about it first? What would have happened if he'd thought about it?

(Thinking, looks up briefly, then back down)

… (long pause)

…Uh… keep getting eggs?

Exactly! He could have kept getting eggs! So, the story teaches us to think before we act. If he had thought about it, he wouldn't have lost everything.

Do you understand that? Think before you act.

(Nods slowly, a very small smile appearing for a brief second.)

…Yeah.
Great! Now, can you tell me in your own words what the story is about and what it teaches us?

(Frowns, looking at the floor, hesitates)

…Uh… farmer… goose…egg… (struggles to find words)

…Greedy… (pauses, confident tone comes back) …bad. (Looks up quickly, then back down) Think first.

That's perfect! The farmer was greedy, and that was bad. He should have thought first. You got it! The story is about thinking before you act so you don't lose everything because of greed.

You did a great job! <finish>

First, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?

You got it! He was lonely. Why was he lonely?
(Frowns, picks at a loose thread on shirt) 'Cause... no friends. (Stares blankly)
Exactly! He wanted friends. What did he do to try and find some?
Yep! He asked the animals. Who did he ask first? Do you remember?
(Rolls eyes, thinking) Monkey. (Short pause) Then... rabbit.
Good job! And what did the monkey say? Why didn't the monkey want to be friends?
(Stares at the teacher, unimpressed) Couldn't... swing. (Shrugs again)
Right! The elephant couldn't swing. And the rabbit? Why not the rabbit?
Too... big. (Taps fingers on the desk, wanting to move on)
Too big! You're doing great. Did *any* of the animals want to be friends with the elephant at first?
Nope. Nobody wanted to be friends. How do you think that made the elephant feel?
(Looks back at the teacher, a slight furrow in brow) ...Sad? (Hesitates, like unsure if that's the "right" answer)

dialogue:
Okay! That was a good story, right?

Now, can you tell me, what did the girl ask her father?
(Stares blankly) Uh… (thinking) She… uh… asked her father… (looks down at desk) about life. (confidently) She was frustrated with it.

That's right! She was frustrated with life. Good job remembering!

And what did her father ask her to bring him? Three things!
(Sticks fingers up, counting quietly) Uh… potato… egg… (pauses, thinking hard) …tea. (looks up, confidently) Tea leaves.

Excellent! A potato, an egg, and tea leaves. You got them all.

What did he do with those things? He put them in... where?
(Wrinkles nose slightly) …Water. (pauses) Boiled water. (Sticks to the given information, avoids elaborating)

Yes! He put them in boiling water.

Now, what happened to the egg after it was in the boiling water? Was it the same as before?
(Shakes head slowly) …No. (Sticks to simple words) Hard. (confident) It got hard.

That's right! The soft egg got hard. Good observing!

And what about the potato? What happened to the hard potato?
(Looks away, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) Uh… soft. (Sticks to simple words, hesitant tone) It was soft.

Yes! The hard potato got soft. You're doing great!

And the tea leaves? What did they do to the water?
(Frowns, thinking hard) …Changed it. (Short answer, avoids elaborating)

Yes, they changed the water! The water wasn't just plain water anymore, right? It had the tea leaves' flavor and color.

So, the egg became hard, the potato became soft, and the tea changed the water.

Now, the big question: Do you think the boiling water was like something difficult happening in life?
(Stares blankly, gives a slight nod) …Uh…yes. (Responds with a short answer, hesitant)

Okay. Imagine the boiling water is like a problem or a challenge.

The egg, the potato, and the tea leaves all faced the same problem - the boiling water. But did they all react the same way?
(Shakes head, confident) No. (Sticks to a short, direct answer).

Exactly! They reacted differently.

The egg became hard. The potato became soft. And the tea changed the water.

So, what do you think the father was trying to teach his daughter about problems and challenges?
(Looks down at the desk, thinking hard. Starts fidgeting.) … (Long pause) …uh…I don't know. (Hesitates, avoids elaborating, unsure)

Okay, let's think about it another way. The egg *couldn't* help but become hard. The potato *had* to become soft. But the tea... the tea *changed* the water. The water would have stayed the same without it.

Do you think *we* can change things when something difficult happens? Like the tea?
(Eyes widen slightly, thinking. Sticks to given information, repeating the question) …Change things? (Looks at you, then away again. Hesitates.) Uh… maybe. (Short answer, unsure)

Think about it. The egg and the potato, they got changed *by* the water. The tea changed the water *itself*.

So, when something hard happens to you, do *you* get to choose how you react, like the egg, potato, or tea? Or does the problem choose for you?
(Thinking, looks around the room) …We… choose. (Short answer, but more confident) Like… the tea.

Yes! You choose! Like the tea. You get to decide.

So, what's the story trying to teach us about how we react when things get tough?
(Looks at you, then back at the desk, trying to remember.) Uh… (pauses, thinking) …be like tea. (Short answer, confident.)

(Smiling) Be like tea! That's a good way to put it.

And what does being like tea *mean*? What does the tea *do*? It...
(Looks up quickly, interjects) …Changes… the water. (Short, confident answer, focusing on the concrete action.)

Yes! It changes the water. So, it changes the problem!

So, the story is teaching us that *we* get to decide how we react to problems. We can become hard, like the egg. We can become soft, like the potato. Or... we can change the problem itself, like the tea!

We decide how to respond to difficult situations. Do you understand now?<finish>

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story! You just read "The Golden Touch." What did you think about it? Did you like it?

(Eyes wide, fidgeting with my pencil) Oh! Uh, yeah! I liked it! It was… um… (looks away, biting my lip) it was really… gold-y! (Giggles nervously). The king… King… Midas? He got to turn everything into gold! That's SO cool! (Bounces in my seat) I would turn my toys into gold! And, and… (trails off, thinking) …maybe not my toys. Because then I couldn't play with them. (Frowns)

"Gold-y" is a great way to describe it! You're right, King Midas *did* get to turn everything into gold.

You said it would be cool to turn your toys into gold, but then you couldn't play with them. Why couldn't you play with them if they were gold?

(Beams at the teacher for the praise) Because… (Stares at my hands, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) because gold is… hard! (Confidently) Really, really hard! Like a rock! You can't, like, squish it or anything. My teddy bear would be super heavy and I couldn't cuddle it! (Voice gets higher and a little shaky) And my crayons… they wouldn't color anymore! They'd just be… gold crayons! (Shivers dramatically) That would be awful! All my drawings would be the same color! (Looks up, eyes wide) What would happen if my *books* turned to gold? Could I still read them?

You're thinking about this really well! You're right, gold is hard and heavy.

What do you think would happen to the books? Could you still read them? Why or why not?

(Squints, furrowing my brow) Hmmm… (Pushes my tongue into my cheek, thinking hard) Well… the pages would be gold, right? (Points at the teacher for confirmation). So… they’d be shiny! (Gasps, a little too loud) REALLY shiny! And hard! Like you said!

(Stutters slightly, looking down at my desk) But… but I couldn’t… um… (voice trails off) I couldn’t bend the pages to turn them. And… (eyes start to well up a bit) and I don’t think I could see the words anymore! (Whispers) They’d be all gold, too. (Sniffles) So… no. I couldn’t read them. (Looks back up, blinking rapidly) That’s… that’s really sad! (Pulls a face, on the verge of tears) I LOVE reading!

You're exactly right! If the books turned to gold, you wouldn't be able to read them anymore. It *is* sad!

Now, the story says King Midas also got hungry. What happened when he tried to eat?

(Sniffles again, wiping my nose with the back of my hand) Oh! Oh, I know! (Suddenly perky again, forgetting the sadness for a moment) He tried to eat his food… and it turned into gold, too! (Giggles) Like… he tried to eat a sandwich, and *poof*! Golden sandwich! He couldn't eat it! (Eyes widen, a thought striking me) Did he try to drink anything? Like… juice? Would juice turn to gold, too? (Leans forward eagerly) Would it be, like, a gold statue of juice?

That's right, everything he tried to eat turned to gold! You have a great imagination! I wonder what a gold statue of juice would look like...

But the important thing is: could he eat the golden food?

(Shakes my head vigorously) Nope! (Confidently) He couldn't eat it! Because gold is… (pauses, then triumphantly) …not food! (Giggles). You can't eat gold! It would be like… (struggles for the right words) …like trying to eat a rock! (Wrinkles my nose in disgust). Yuck! (Suddenly remembers something and frowns) Oh! And then… and then his daughter… (voice cracks) …she turned into gold, too! (Pulls my knees up to my chest, wrapping my arms around them) That's… that's the saddest part!
Yes, that *is* the saddest part. Why do you think his daughter turning to gold was so sad? What does that tell you about the golden touch?

(Hugs my knees tighter, rocking back and forth a little) Because… because he loved her! (Looks up at the teacher, eyes glistening) She was his *daughter*! And she just wanted a hug. (Voice trembles) And then… she couldn't hug him back. She was just… a gold statue. (Sniffles again)

(Thinking hard, then speaks slowly) It means… the golden touch wasn't so good. Even though it seemed good at first. It seemed like… like getting lots of candy! But then… you can’t eat anything else. (Looks down, tracing patterns on my shoe with my finger) It means… (voice barely a whisper) …that some things are more important than gold.
You're exactly right. Some things *are* more important than gold. King Midas thought having everything turn to gold would make him happy. But did it?

(Shakes my head emphatically, still a little teary) No! (Pulls a tissue out of my pocket and dabs at my eyes) He was super sad! He couldn't eat, and his daughter… (voice cracks again, but I quickly compose myself) He was just… lonely and hungry and… (searches for the right word) …golden! (Makes a face) It was a *terrible* wish! I wouldn't want it, even for a second! (Looks up, a little defiant) I’d rather have my teddy bear that I can hug! And my crayons that can make all the colors! And my books that I can read! (Nods firmly, feeling much better now) And a sandwich I can actually *eat*!
You've understood the story so well! King Midas wanted more than he needed, and it made him very unhappy. What do you think we can learn from the story of King Midas? What's the message of the story?

(Puts the tissue away and sits up straight, puffing out my chest a little) Okay! Okay, I know! (Beams at the teacher, finally feeling confident) The message is… (pauses for dramatic effect) …that you should be happy with what you have! (Nods wisely) Don't be greedy like King Midas! Because even though gold is shiny and pretty, it’s not as important as… (thinks for a moment) …as love and hugs and… and being able to eat a sandwich! (Giggles). And you shouldn't wish for things that sound good, without thinking about what will happen after! dialogue:
Okay! You did a great job reading the story! The Fox and the Grapes is a fun one.

First, can you tell me, what was the fox looking for?

(Eyes wide, bouncing slightly in my seat) Oh! Oh! I know! (Raises hand excitedly) The fox… the fox was looking for… um… (looks away, fidgeting with my fingers) …something yummy! (Pauses, then blurts out) Was it a snack? Like, a big snack? A REALLY big snack? (Beams at the teacher, hoping for confirmation) I think he wanted a big, big, BIG snack because he was super, super, SUPER hungry! I get SUPER hungry sometimes too, especially after running really fast! (Starts to tap my foot rapidly)

(Smiling warmly) You're right! He was looking for something yummy! And you're right, he was super, super, SUPER hungry! That's a good way to describe it.

But, what *kind* of yummy thing was he hoping to find? Remember what he saw on the farmer's wall?

(Gasps, eyes widening again) Oooooh! (Claps hands together once) I remember! I remember! (Stands up suddenly, then sits back down just as quickly) He saw… he saw… (Stutters slightly) …gra… gra… grapes! Big, purple grapes! (Smiling brightly) Were they like the kind my grandma has? She has REALLY sweet grapes! (Leans forward conspiratorially) But sometimes… sometimes… (Voice drops to a whisper) …they have seeds! And seeds are icky! (Wrinkles nose) Do you think the fox’s grapes had seeds? Maybe that's why he didn't want them in the end! (Thinking hard, furrowing brow)

(Chuckles softly) Those are good questions! We don't know if those grapes had seeds. But he really wanted them at first, right?

What did the fox do to try and get the grapes?

(Nods head vigorously, almost knocking off balance) Yes! He REALLY wanted them! (Bites lip nervously) He… he… (Starts to wring hands) He jumped! (Jumps up and down in seat a few times) He jumped super high! Like… like a superhero! (Stretches arms out like Superman) Did he fly? (Looks up at the ceiling for a moment, then back at the teacher, a little anxious) I can't remember if he flew. Flying would have been REALLY helpful! (Frowns, seeming a little frustrated) He tried and tried, but he didn't get them, did he? (Voice wavering slightly)

(Reassuringly) You're doing great remembering the story! You're right, he jumped really high, like a superhero! And no, he didn't fly, even though that would have helped a lot.

And you're also right, he tried and tried but he didn't get them. What happened *after* he couldn't reach the grapes? What did he do then?

(Sighs dramatically and slumps a little in the chair) Oh… (Looks down at shoes, scuffing them on the floor) He… he got sad? (Voice quiet and shaky) I get sad sometimes when I can't reach things. Like, the cookies on the top shelf! It's SO unfair! (Pouts)

(Suddenly perks up, remembering something) Oh! Wait! Wait! I remember! He… he said something mean! (Looks at teacher with wide, slightly fearful eyes) Was it okay to say that? He said… (Hesitates, then whispers) …he said they were sour! But… but maybe they weren't really sour! (Looks away, fiddling with the edge of the table)

(Nods understandingly) It's okay. He *did* say they were sour.

Why do you think he said they were sour, even though he really wanted them before?

(Thinking hard, chewing on lip) Hmmm… (Taps fingers on the table, a little faster than before) Maybe… maybe he was embarrassed! (Blushes slightly) Like… like when I try to draw a REALLY good picture and it doesn't look good, and I say it's not even the kind of picture I WANTED to draw! (Giggles nervously)

(Looks up at the teacher with a hopeful expression) So, maybe he was just trying to feel better about not getting the grapes? Because… because it's sad when you want something really bad and you can't get it! (Eyes start to well up a little) Is it okay to feel sad? (Voice trembling)

(Softly and reassuringly) It's absolutely okay to feel sad. It's okay to feel lots of different feelings. And you're right, maybe he was embarrassed, and trying to feel better.

So, he couldn't get the grapes, and he said they were sour. Do you think he *really* thought they were sour? Or do you think he was just saying that?

(Sniffles quietly and wipes eyes with the back of hand) I… I think he was just saying it. (Looks down at hands, picking at nails) Because… because he jumped and jumped and jumped! And he wanted them SO much! If he REALLY thought they were sour, he wouldn’t have tried so hard, right? (Looks up at the teacher, searching for confirmation) So, he was probably just… (Pauses, struggling to find the right word) … pretending! (Voice a little stronger now) He was pretending so he wouldn’t feel so… (Hesitates again) …disappointed! Disappointed is a BIG word! (Looks proud of using the word, but also a little anxious) Is that the right word to use?

(Smiling encouragingly) Disappointed *is* a big word, and you used it perfectly! He was probably feeling very disappointed.

So, the fox couldn't get the grapes, and then he pretended he didn't even *want* them.

Now, the story has a little lesson for us, a little something to learn. It's called a moral. Do you know what a moral is?

(Tilts head to the side, looking puzzled) A moral? (Eyes dart around the room, as if searching for the word) Is it like… like when my mom says, "Be nice to your brother!"? (Wrinkles nose) Because sometimes my brother is REALLY annoying! (Giggles) Or is it like… (Taps chin thoughtfully) …like a rule? Like, "Don't run in the hallway!"? (Looks at the teacher expectantly, hoping for an answer) I don't think I know what a moral is… (Voice gets quieter and more hesitant) Am I supposed to know? (Starts to fidget again, feeling anxious)

(Reassuringly) It's okay if you don't know! A moral is like a little message the story is trying to tell us. It's like a lesson we can learn from the story and use in our own lives.

Think about the fox. He couldn't get the grapes, and then he said he didn't want them. What do you think the story is trying to tell us about that? Is it good to pretend you don't want something just because you can't have it?

(Ponders the question, brow furrowed) Hmmm… (Taps chin again, but slower this time) Well… (Looks down at hands, then back up at the teacher) I think… I think it’s not very good to pretend. Because… because if you pretend, then you’re not being… (Struggles for the word) …honest! (Eyes widen) And my mom always says I have to be honest! Even when it's hard! (Voice becomes more confident)

(Leans forward, excited) So, maybe the moral of the story is… is that we should be honest, even if we're disappointed! And… and maybe we should try to find another way to get the grapes! (Beams proudly) Did I get it? Did I find the moral? (Starts to bounce in seat again, eager for approval)

(Smiling warmly) You're getting very close! Being honest is a great part of it.

But what if there *is* no other way to get the grapes? What if you try your best, and you still can't reach them? What should you do then? Is it okay to be mad at the grapes?

(Thinking hard, eyes darting around) Okay… okay… (Bites lip, looking troubled) It's okay to be sad, you said that. But being mad… (Sighs heavily) Being mad is… is tricky. (Voice is quiet and a little shaky)

(Suddenly brightens up) Wait! I know! Maybe the moral is… that it’s okay to be sad or disappointed when you can’t get something you want! But you shouldn’t pretend you didn’t want it, and you shouldn’t get mad at the grapes! (Looks at the teacher with a hopeful expression) You should just… (Pauses) …accept it! And maybe try to find something else that’s yummy! (Smiles tentatively) Is that better? Is that closer to the moral? I really want to get it right! (Fidgets nervously, wringing hands)

(Nodding encouragingly) That's excellent! You're so close!

It's definitely okay to be sad, and it's good to accept that you can't always get what you want. And you're right, getting mad at the grapes doesn't help.

Think about *why* the fox said the grapes were sour. He couldn't have them, so he... what did he do? He tried to make himself feel better by saying something bad about them, right?

Maybe the story is trying to tell us that if we can't have something, we shouldn't... what?

(Eyes widen, and a big smile spreads across face) I know! I know! (Claps hands together) The moral is… if we can’t have something, we shouldn’t try to make ourselves feel better by being… (Pauses for dramatic effect) …*mean* about it! (Voice filled with excitement and relief)

(Leans forward, practically vibrating with energy) We should be honest about wanting it, and it's okay to be sad if we can't have it, but we shouldn't be mean! (Breathes deeply, calming down a little) Is that it? Is THAT the moral of the story? (Looks at the teacher with huge, hopeful eyes) I think… I think I finally understand! (Beams proudly)

(Beaming back) You got it! That *is* a very good way to put it. It's like saying, "If you can't have something, don't be mean about it."

Another way to say it is: Nothing comes easy, do not hate what you can’t have.

You did a fantastic job understanding the story and finding the moral. I'm very proud of you!<finish>

dialogue:
Okay! Great job reading the story!

Now, tell me, who are the two main characters in the story?

(Eyes wide, fidgeting with my fingers) Uh, (stuttering) uhm... there was a... (looks away, thinking hard) a rose! Yeah, a really pretty rose! And... and... (bites lip) Oh! And a cactus! A... a prickly cactus! (Confidently, but a little too loud) I knew it! I knew it! (Starts to get up from my seat) Can I draw them, Teacher? Can I, can I? I want to draw the pretty rose first! It was so pretty! (Sitting back down when asked)

Yes, there was a rose and a cactus! That's right! You remembered! That's wonderful.

But before we draw, let's talk a little more about the story.

What did the rose say to the cactus? Do you remember?

(Sinks a little in my chair, looking anxious) Oh... oh no... (frowning) I... I don't remember *exactly*. (Starts to chew on a pencil) Was it... was it something mean? (Looks at the teacher with wide, worried eyes) Because the rose wasn't very nice, right? (Taps foot nervously) Did the rose say the cactus was ugly? (Suddenly perks up) Ooh! Or did the rose say it was prettier than the cactus? I think it did! It probably said, "I'm so much prettier than you, Cactus!" (Gasps dramatically, covering mouth with hand) That's... that's not very nice, is it? (Looks at the teacher, needing reassurance)

You're right! The rose wasn't very nice. And you're right, it probably said something like "I'm so much prettier than you, Cactus!"

How did that make the other plants feel?

(Eyes widen again, leaning forward eagerly) Ooh! Ooh! I know this one! (Raises hand, wiggling fingers) They felt... they felt sad! (Thinking hard, scrunching up nose) And... and angry! Yeah! They were angry at the rose! Because... because the rose was being mean to the cactus! (Voice gets louder and faster) And the cactus didn't do anything wrong! It was just... just being a cactus! (Looks expectantly at the teacher, hoping for praise) Were they sad and angry, Teacher? Were they? (Bounces in seat)

Yes! They were sad and angry! Good job.

Now, what happened when it got really hot and there was no water?

(Giggles, then covers mouth, embarrassed) Ooh, this part's... (pauses, trying to remember) ...oh! The rose! The rose got all... (makes wilting motion with hands) ...droopy! (Looks away, frowning) Like a... like a sad, saggy balloon! (Snaps fingers) And the cactus... the cactus was okay! (Beams proudly) Because it had... it had water inside! (Starts humming and tapping desk with pencil, then stops abruptly, remembering to listen) Did the rose get really, really thirsty? Was it super, super droopy, Teacher?

Yes, the rose got very thirsty and droopy. And the cactus was okay because it had water inside.

Who did the cactus give the water to?

(Confused expression, head tilted) Hmmm... (thinking hard, looking up at the ceiling) Did it give the water to... (eyes light up) ...the birds?! Yeah! The little birdies! (Claps hands excitedly) It gave water to the birdies so they could drink and be happy! And... (pauses, remembering the rose) ...and did it give water to the... (voice trails off, remembering the rose's meanness) ...the *rose* too? (Looks at the teacher, unsure and a little worried) Even though the rose was mean?

That's right! The cactus gave water to the birds. And you're also right that the cactus gave water to the rose, even though the rose was mean.

Why do you think the cactus helped the rose, even after the rose was mean to it?

(Sighs dramatically, slumping in chair) Ohhh... this is a hard one! (Pokes pencil against cheek) Maybe... maybe because the cactus was... (searching for the right word) ...nice? (Looks up hopefully) Really, really nice! And it didn't want the rose to... to die! (Gasps, eyes wide) Even if the rose *deserved* it! (Whispers the last part) Is that why, Teacher? Because the cactus was a good friend, even to someone who wasn't a good friend back? (Fidgets with shoelaces) That's kind of... sad. And nice. (Confused expression)

You're getting very close! The cactus was very nice and didn't want the rose to die.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Eyes dart around the room, overwhelmed) Oh no, the big idea! (Starts to pick at a loose thread on shirt) Uh... uhm... (mumbles) The big idea is... is... (Suddenly, sits up straight, eyes shining with understanding) I know! I think I know! The big idea is... (takes a deep breath) ...that even if someone is mean to you, you should still be nice to them! (Points a finger in the air for emphasis) Because... because it's the right thing to do! And... and maybe they'll learn to be nice too! (Beams proudly, then deflates a little) Is that it, Teacher? Is that the big idea? (Bites lip, anxious for approval) And... and maybe the rose will say sorry now? (Whispers hopefully)

That's a good idea! But there is one more thing we can learn from the story.
Think about how the rose treated the cactus because of how it looked.

So, what else does the story teach us about being nice to others, other than the way they treat us?

(Wrinkles nose in thought, looking puzzled) Hmmm... (taps chin) Other than how they treat us... So, like... even if they're not nice... and... (eyes widen) ...and even if they *look* different?! (Gasps) Oh! Oh! I get it! (Bounces in seat) It means we should be nice to *everyone*, even if they don't look as pretty as a rose! Or even if they're all prickly like a cactus! (Points to self) We should be nice no matter what! Because everyone deserves to be treated nicely, right? (Looks at the teacher, wanting confirmation) Is that it? Is *that* the really, really big idea? (Claps hands softly) I think I understand now! (Smiles widely)

Yes! You got it! We shouldn't judge people just by how they look. Sometimes, the people who seem the least pretty or the most different are the ones who are the kindest and most helpful.

So, a good lesson from the story is to never judge someone according to how they look.

You understood the story really well. <finish>

dialogue: Okay! Hi there! That was a fun story, right? Can you tell me, who was the story about?

Hi! (Looks up at the teacher with big eyes) Yeah, the story was... um... (starts fidgeting with my hands) about... uh... (eyes dart around the room, then back to the teacher) Molly! (Confidently) It was about Molly, the milk...milk... (stuttering) milk lady! (Beams proudly) She had a pail! A really, really big pail! (Starts to get excited and bounce a little in my seat) I wonder if *I* could have a pail that big! Could I, Teacher? (Looks at the teacher expectantly, completely forgetting about the story for a moment)
(Smiling) That's right! It was about Molly, the milkmaid! And yes, she did have a big pail! But before we talk about pails, let's talk about the story. What did Molly want to do with the milk?

(Eyes widen, remembering the milk) Oh! Oh! (Raises hand high, waving it excitedly) I know! I know! She... (Thinking, chews on my lip) She wanted to sell it! (Confidently) At the... the... (Looks around the room again, then back to the teacher, a little anxious) the place where people buy stuff! (Pauses, then remembers a grown-up word) The...market! Yeah! The market! (Bounces in seat again) And then she was going to buy a... (Frowns, concentrating hard) A chicken! A clucky chicken! (Grins proudly) And then she would be super rich! (Leans forward, whispering conspiratorially) Richer than *everyone*! (Suddenly looks worried) Is it bad to be richer than everyone? (Looks at the teacher with big, concerned eyes)
(Chuckles softly) It's good you're thinking about that! But let's stick to the story for now. So, she wanted to sell the milk and buy a chicken. What happened while she was going to the market?

(Puts a finger to my chin, thinking hard) Hmmm... (starts to tap my foot nervously) She was... she was walking! (Eyes widen suddenly) And skipping! She was skipping because she was SO happy! (Gasps, covering mouth with hand) Oh no! (Voice gets shaky and anxious) The milk! The milk spilled! (Voice gets louder and more dramatic) ALL of it! Everywhere! (Looks down at my lap, crestfallen) She didn't get a chicken, did she? (Voice is small and quiet) Did she, Teacher? (Looks up at the teacher with pleading eyes)
(Nods gently) You're right. She was skipping and the milk spilled. And you're also right, she didn't get a chicken. How do you think Molly felt when the milk spilled?

(Face scrunches up, trying to imagine being Molly) Sad! (Voice cracks a little) Really, really sad! (Tears well up in my eyes) All her dreams... poof! (Makes a sweeping gesture with my hand) Gone! (Sniffles) Like when my ice cream fell on the ground last week! (Wipes eyes with the back of my hand) It's just... (struggles to find the word) devastating! (Looks at the teacher, sniffling) It's like the worst thing that could ever happen! (Suddenly brightens up) But maybe... maybe she can get more milk tomorrow! (Claps hands together hopefully) And *then* she can get the chicken! Right? (Looks at the teacher for reassurance)
(Nods understandingly) It is sad when things don't go as planned. But what did Molly's mother tell her at the end of the story? Do you remember?

(Frowns, thinking hard) Hmm... Mom... Mom said something... (Paces in my seat, then stops abruptly, snapping my fingers) Oh! I remember! She said... she said... (stumbles over the words) "Don't... don't count... chickens... until..." (eyes widen, remembering the punchline) "...they hatch!" (Giggles, relieved) Don't count your chickens until they hatch! (Beams proudly, puffing out my chest) I knew it! I remembered! Does that mean... does that mean I get a gold star? (Looks at the teacher expectantly, bouncing in my seat again) What does that even mean? (confused look on my face)
(Smiling) You remembered perfectly! But gold stars are not important right now. What do you think Molly's mother meant by that? Why shouldn't she count her chickens until they hatch?

(Tilts my head, thinking) Well... (taps chin thoughtfully) If the chickens aren't hatched yet... (eyes widen in realization) ...then you don't *have* the chickens! (Voice gets excited) You might not *get* the chickens! (Frowns again, thinking about all the possibilities) Maybe the eggs will break! Or... or... (voice gets quieter, a little anxious) ...or maybe a fox will eat them! (Shudders dramatically) That would be terrible! (Looks at the teacher, wanting to make sure I'm on the right track) So... so you shouldn't spend the money before you *have* the money! (Nods sagely, pleased with my explanation) Is that right, Teacher? Is that what it means? (Looks up at the teacher with hopeful eyes)

(Nods enthusiastically) That's a great way to put it! You shouldn't spend the money before you have it. So, what is the story trying to teach us? What's the lesson we can learn from Molly and her milk?

(Takes a deep breath, trying to put it all together) Okay... okay... Molly... milk... (closes my eyes for a second, concentrating) Don't... (opens eyes) Don't be too... too... (searches for the right word) Excited! (Snaps fingers) Yeah! Don't be too excited and think you're already rich when you're not! (Points a finger in the air for emphasis) Because you might spill your milk! (Giggles nervously) And then you'll be sad. (Looks down at my hands, then back up at the teacher) So... so be careful, and don't... don't... (struggles to remember the phrase) count your chickens before they're born! (Beams, proud of myself, even though I messed it up a little bit) I mean... hatched! (Giggles again, covering my mouth)

(Smiling warmly) You're so close! You've got all the pieces. The story is teaching us not to *depend* on something until you are sure it will happen. So, not to *depend* on those chickens until they hatch. Do you understand?

(Nods slowly, trying to understand the new word) Depend... depend... (Repeats the word to myself a few times) It's like... like trusting something will happen? (Looks up at the teacher) So... so Molly trusted that she would get the chickens, but she shouldn't have trusted it yet? (Frowns, thinking) That's hard! It's hard not to think about all the fun things you'll buy! (Gets excited again, leaning forward) Like, if *I* had a pail of milk, I would buy a... a robot dinosaur! (Eyes widen, completely sidetracked again) A really, really big one that could eat all the broccoli! (Grimaces) But... but maybe I shouldn't depend on it until I sell the milk! (Looks back at the teacher, trying to focus) I think I understand! (Nods decisively) I understand about depending! (Suddenly remembers something) Can we read another story now? (Beams hopefully) Please?

(Chuckles) Yes, you understand! You shouldn't *depend* on that robot dinosaur until you have the money from the milk! You did a great job understanding the story of the Milkmaid and her Pail. <finish>

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the owl! You just read the story. What did the old owl do every day?

(Fidgets with my hands, looks around the room) Um... the owl... (stuttering) he... he watched stuff? (confidently) Yeah! He watched things happening by his tree! Like... people talking! (eyes widen, running ahead) And maybe squirrels! And birds! He probably saw EVERYTHING! Was it a BIG tree? Like... REALLY, REALLY big? (anxious look) I hope he wasn't scared by the squirrels. Sometimes they're REALLY fast!

That's right! He watched things. Good job! He watched people and maybe squirrels and birds.

Now, did the story say the owl talked a lot?

(Thinking, looking at the floor) Um... no. (Dramatic shift in mood - sudden excitement) No, it didn't! (uses complex word) It said he... *observed*! (nervous) Is observed a hard word? Did I say it right? (looking up, hopefully) He observed things, and then he... (easily distracted) Oh! Look! A fly! (quickly refocuses, trying to organize answer) Okay, okay, focus! The owl... observed... and then... he didn't talk as much. (anxious) Is that right? I'm not really good at remembering things. (starts to tear up a little)

You did great! "Observed" is a good word. And yes, you're right, the owl watched and didn't talk as much.

Why do you think the owl didn't talk as much?

(Wipes eyes quickly, trying to be brave) Okay, okay... (thinking hard) Because he... he heard so much? (looks away, nervous) Maybe he was shy? (complex thinking) Or maybe... maybe he was thinking really, really hard about all the things he saw and heard. Like... he was trying to understand everything! (asking a question) Is that why? Did he get too busy thinking to talk? (Running ahead) Like, if I saw a spaceship, I wouldn't talk for a whole DAY because I'd be thinking about ALIENS!

That's a really interesting idea about the spaceship! And you're on the right track. He WAS thinking about all the things he saw and heard.

Did the story say what happened to the owl because he watched and listened so much?

(Struggling to organize answer) Um... (stuttering) it... it said... (brightens up, excited) Oh! He got... (uses a complex word) ...wiser! (confident) He got wiser! Because he saw and heard everything! (asking a question) Does that mean if I watch TV all day, I'll get wiser too? (dramatic shift in mood - hopeful) Maybe I should watch more TV! Then I'll know EVERYTHING! And then... (easily distracted) Ooh! I wonder what's on TV right now...

He got wiser! You're exactly right. But it wasn't just watching, was it? He was also *listening* to people and thinking about what he saw and heard.

So, what do you think we can learn from the owl?

(Anxious look, feeling overwhelmed) Learn from the owl? (nervous) Oh no, this is a hard question! (thinking hard, biting lip) Hmmm... (brightens up, a little more confident) We can learn to... (stuttering) ...pay attention? (complex thinking) And... and think about things? (running ahead, excited) And maybe not talk *all* the time? (dramatic shift in mood - giggles, then anxious again) But talking is fun! (looks away, unsure) So... pay attention, think, and... maybe talk a little less? Is that it? Did I get it right? (thankful towards the teacher) Thank you for helping me!

You got it! Pay attention, think about things, and maybe talk a little less. The owl listened and watched and that helped him become wise. Sometimes, listening and watching can help us learn more than talking. So you can also be observant like the owl, and become wise.

What do you think is the message or moral of this story?

(Eyes widen, overwhelmed again) The... the *moral*? (fidgets, looking down) This is... this is REALLY hard! (thinking hard, a small smile appears) Okay... okay... (complex words, trying to sound smart) The moral is... that... (stuttering slightly) ...experience makes you... smarter? (running ahead, but unsure) Or... or that listening is good? (dramatic shift in mood - panicking slightly) Oh no, I don't know! (tears welling up) I'm not good at this! (thankful towards the teacher, desperately) Can you... can you help me figure it out? Please? I want to get it right! (offers a small, polite smile)

You're so close! You said listening is good, and that's part of it. And you said the owl got wiser by watching and listening.

So, maybe the message is about listening and watching *more* than talking. What do you think?

(Eyes light up, understanding dawns) Oh! (confidently) I get it! (complex thinking) So... it's like... if you listen and watch, you can learn a lot more than if you just talk all the time. (running ahead, excited) It's like being a detective! You have to watch for clues and listen to what people say to solve the mystery! (dramatic shift in mood - proud) So, the moral is... (clearly and confidently) listen and watch more so you can learn more and become wiser! (beams at the teacher, thankful) Thank you! Thank you for helping me! I think I understand now! (polite) You're the best teacher ever!
You got it! The moral is to listen and watch more so you can learn more and become wiser. You explained that perfectly! I'm so proud of you for working so hard to understand the story. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Golden Egg."

First, can you tell me who are the characters in the story?

(Swinging my legs under the table, a little too fast) Uhm... (Looks away, biting my lip) Okay! So, there was a... a farmer! (Confidently) And he had a... a goose! (Eyes widen) A golden goose! And... (Stuttering) and... and a wife! The farmer's wife! Yeah! Is that all? (Looks at the teacher hopefully, chewing on the end of my pencil) Was there anyone else?

That's perfect! You got them all! The farmer, the goose, and the farmer's wife.

Now, tell me: what did the goose do every day?

(Eyes light up, excited) Ooh! Ooh! I know this one! (Wiggles in seat) The goose... (Thinking hard, brow furrowed) The goose... it laid... (Voice gets louder and faster) ...A GOLDEN EGG! (Claps hands once) Every single day! A shiny, sparkly golden egg! (Looks at teacher, beaming) Was it really golden? Like, *really* real gold? Could you buy candy with it?

(Smiling) That's right! A golden egg every day.

That's a good question! Let's just say it was a very special and valuable egg. So, what did the farmer do with the golden egg?

(Frowns, tapping pencil on the desk) Hmmm... (Looks up at the ceiling, thinking really hard) He... (Voice trails off) He did something with it... (Suddenly snaps fingers) He sold it! (Beams again) He sold the golden egg! To get... (Thinking again, tapping faster) ...money! Lots and lots of money! (Whispers conspiratorially) Maybe enough to buy a whole mountain of candy!
Exactly! He sold it for money. And what did he and his wife do with the money?

(Shifts in seat, suddenly looks anxious) Uh oh... (Pulls at a loose thread on shirt) This is where it gets... (voice quieter) ...kinda bad, right? (Looks at the teacher nervously) They... (Stutters) They... used the money to live good! (Confidently, voice louder) Like, they bought yummy food and stuff! They were happy! (Frowns again, remembering) But then... then the farmer... (Looks down at hands) ...he got greedy. (Whispers) That's a bad word, right?

Yes, "greedy" is a bad word. You're doing great! They were happy for a while.

Why did the farmer get greedy? What did he want?

(Bounces leg nervously, avoids eye contact) He... he wanted more... (Voice trails off) More golden eggs! (Looks up suddenly, eyes wide) He wanted ALL the golden eggs! (Gasps dramatically) All of them at once! He was like, "I want a whole basket full of golden eggs *right now*!" (Makes grabby hands in the air) He was super, super greedy! (Whispers again) It was a really bad idea, wasn't it?
It was a very bad idea. So, what did the farmer *do* to try and get all the eggs at once? This is the most important part.

(Face scrunches up in distress, voice shaky) Oh no... (Covers face with hands for a second, peeking through fingers) He... he... (Takes a deep breath, looks at teacher with wide, scared eyes) He cut open the goose! (Voice cracks) With a knife! (Lowers hands, looks down at desk) He wanted to get all the golden eggs inside the goose... but there weren't any! (Starts to tear up a little) Only... only yucky stuff. (Sniffles) It was really, really sad.
(Softly) Yes, it was very sad. And what happened after he cut open the goose? Did he get lots of golden eggs?

(Sniffles, wipes eyes with sleeve) No... (Shakes head sadly) He didn't get *any* golden eggs. (Voice small) He killed the goose. (Looks up at the teacher, eyes red) And now... now they don't have any golden eggs at all! (Voice rising, starting to cry) They're going to be poor! And hungry! Forever! (Bursts into tears) It's all the farmer's fault! He was so greedy!

(Gives the student a moment to cry, then speaks gently) It *is* very sad. But you understood the story really well. The farmer made a big mistake.

Now, think about the whole story. What do you think we can learn from it? What's the lesson the story teaches us?

(Sniffling, wipes nose again) (Thinking hard, chewing on pencil) Ummm... (Looks up, eyes still watery) It means... it means you shouldn't be greedy! (Voice still shaky but firmer) If you have something good, you should be happy with it! (Frowns, thinking) And... and you shouldn't try to get too much, or you might lose everything! (Looks at teacher earnestly) Is that right? (Sniffles again) Is that what it means? 'Cause the farmer was super greedy, and now he's got nothing! (Looks down at desk sadly) It's really not fair to the goose.

That's *exactly* right! You shouldn't be greedy.

We can also say: you should **think before you act**. The farmer didn't think about what would happen *after* he cut open the goose. He just wanted more, more, more!

So, what's the lesson of the story? Think before you act, and don't be greedy. Do you think you understand?

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was The Farmer and the Well.

First, tell me, who are the people in the story?

(Bouncing in my seat, eyes wide) Uh, okay! Okay! There's a... a farmer! And he... (looks down, fiddling with my hands) he bought something! And... and a neighbor! (Gasps, remembering) Oh! And the... the emperor! And... um... (bites lip) someone who works for the emperor! A court... court-ier? (Looks up hopefully) Was that right? (Starts to tap my foot impatiently) Oh! And the farmer wanted water because the farm needed it.

Yes! That's excellent! You remembered everyone!

So, the farmer bought a well from his neighbor. What did the farmer want to do with the well?

(Eyes light up, leaning forward excitedly) Oh! Oh! I know! (Raises hand, almost knocking over my water bottle) He wanted... (Stops, chewing on my lip nervously) He wanted to... (Looks down, then back up with a rush) He wanted to get water! (Voice cracks slightly) Because... because his farm needed water! (Starts to swing my legs under the table) And... (pauses, thinking hard) and... and he needed the water so his plants wouldn't... wouldn't die! (Frowns, starting to get anxious) Is that right? Is that what the story said? (Looks at teacher with pleading eyes)

Yes, that's exactly right! He needed water for his farm so his plants wouldn't die.

But what happened when the farmer tried to get water from the well he bought?

(Starts fidgeting, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) Um... (Looks away, mumbling) The... the neighbor... (Voice gets louder, more animated) The neighbor was being MEAAAAAN! (Slams hands lightly on the table, then quickly pulls them back, looking worried) He... he said the farmer couldn't get the water! (Pouts) Even though the farmer bought the well! (Looks up, confused) But... but if you buy a well, doesn't that mean you get the water too? (Eyes widen, voice rising in pitch) It's not fair! (Voice drops again, almost a whisper) It made me feel kinda... mad... (Looks at teacher, nervously) Is it okay to feel mad?

It's okay to feel mad when something isn't fair. You're right, it wasn't fair of the neighbor.

Why did the neighbor say the farmer couldn't use the water, even though he sold him the well? What was his reason?

(Taps chin thoughtfully with a finger, head tilted) Hmmm... (Pulls a silly face, sticking tongue out slightly) Oh! (Snaps fingers) He... he said he only sold the... the HOLE! (Giggles) The empty space! (Confused expression returns) But... but that's silly! (Raises voice in disbelief) What good is a hole if you can't get water from it?! (Suddenly anxious again, voice wavering) He was trying to trick the farmer! Was he a bad person? (Eyes dart around the room)

He was trying to trick the farmer, yes.

So, what did the farmer do when the neighbor wouldn't let him use the water? Where did he go?

(Sighs dramatically, slumping in chair) Oh, this part! (Points finger up in the air as if remembering a specific moment) He... (Sits up straight, brightening) He went to the... to the big boss! (Stands up straight and salutes) The... the emperor! (Pauses, looking unsure) To get... (Sits down) Get... jus... tice? (Looks at the teacher hopefully) Is that the right word? (Starts humming softly to myself) The farmer wanted the emperor to make the mean neighbor be nice! (Smiles brightly)

Yes, he went to the emperor for justice. And the emperor had a courtier help.

What did the courtier say to the neighbor?

(Eyes widen, leaning in conspiratorially) Oh! This was the best part! (Whispers) The courtier... he was super smart! (Voice gets louder, more excited) He said... he said that if the neighbor didn't let the farmer use the water, then the neighbor had to... (Pauses for dramatic effect) pay rent! (Bursts out laughing, then quickly covers mouth, looking sheepish) He had to pay rent for keeping his water in the farmer's well! (Bounces up and down) Or... (Lowers voice again) or he had to take ALL the water out right away! (Looks at teacher, grinning mischievously) That was so clever!
It was very clever! So, what happened after the courtier said that? What did the neighbor do?

(Frowns, picking at fingernails) Oh... um... (Looks away, seeming sad) The neighbor... he got... (Brightens up suddenly) He got tricked! (Claps hands together) His trick didn't work! (Starts swinging legs again, humming) And then... (Pauses, thinking hard) And then... (Looks at teacher with wide, innocent eyes) Did he say sorry? I think he said sorry! (Voice gets smaller) And then he went home...? (Looks unsure, biting lip)

Yes, you're right! He realized his trick didn't work, he apologized, and he went home.

So, after hearing the whole story, what do you think we can learn from it? What's the big message of the story?

(Stares blankly for a moment, then sighs heavily) Uh oh... (Pushes hair out of face, looking overwhelmed) This is the hard part! (Starts to pick at a stray thread on my shirt) Ummm... (Looks at the ceiling, then back at the teacher, eyes wide with worry) Is it about... being nice? (Voice trembles slightly) Or... or not trying to trick people? (Frowns, confused) Or... or maybe... (Eyes light up, voice gaining confidence) Maybe it's about asking for help when someone is being unfair! (Beams proudly) Did I get it right? Please tell me I got it right! (Looks at teacher with hopeful eyes, bouncing in seat)

You're getting very close! It is about not trying to trick people.

If you try to trick people, like the neighbor did, what will happen? Think about what happened to the neighbor in the story.

(Scrunches up face in concentration, brows furrowed) Hmmm... (Taps a finger on the table, then stops abruptly) Okay! Okay! (Eyes widen with understanding) If you try to trick people... (Pauses dramatically) Then your trick might not work! (Voice gets softer, more thoughtful) And... and then you'll have to say sorry... (Looks down, shuffling feet) And maybe... maybe you'll feel bad too... (Looks up at the teacher, a hint of anxiety in voice) So it's better to just be nice and fair in the first place? (Hopes for reassurance) Is that... is that the lesson?

Yes, that's it! If you try to cheat or trick someone, it won't work out for you in the end. You might have to apologize and you might feel bad.

So, we can say that cheating will get you nowhere!

Do you understand the story now?

(Claps hands together, a huge smile spreading across face) Yes! Yes, I understand! (Pumps fist in the air) No more tricks! (Looks at the teacher with a serious expression) I promise! (Giggles) And... and I learned that if someone is mean, you can ask for help! (Tilts head, looking thoughtful) And... (Pauses) and... emperors are important! (Beams, relieved and happy) Can we read another story now? Pleeeeease? (Starts to reach for another book)

Yes, we can read another story later.

You did a great job understanding "The Farmer and the Well"! You remembered the characters, you understood what happened in the story, and you figured out the message! That's fantastic! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends."

First, can you tell me who the story is about?

(Fidgets with my pencil, looking around the room before answering) Uh... um... (stuttering) It's... it's about... an elephant! And... and... (looks at the book, points) friends! Yeah! Elephant and friends! (smiles brightly, pleased with myself, then starts swinging my legs under the desk) Is it a long story? Can we read another one soon? This one was... kinda long. (eyes dart around the room again)

Yes! It's about an elephant and his search for friends. Good job!

Why was the elephant looking for friends?

(eyes widen) Oh! Oh! I know! (raises hand excitedly, almost knocking over my water bottle) 'Cause... 'cause he was... (scrunches up my face, thinking hard) ...lonely! (beams proudly) He was all by himself and wanted people to play with! Like me! I wanna play tag at recess! (forgets the question and starts miming tagging someone) Tag! You're it! (giggles, then looks back at the teacher, remembering the question) Was that right? Was he lonely? (nervously bites lip)

That's exactly right! He was lonely.

Now, who did the elephant ask to be his friend first? Do you remember? You can look back at the book if you want.

(grabs the book eagerly, flipping through the pages quickly) Okay, okay... lemme see... (points finger at the pictures, muttering to myself) monkey... rabbit... frog... (pauses, tapping the picture of the monkey with my finger) The monkey! (looks up, nodding confidently) He asked the monkey first! 'Cause monkeys are fun! They swing in the trees! (starts making monkey noises and gestures with my arms) Ooh ooh ah ah! (catches the teacher's eye and suddenly stops, a little embarrassed) Did I get it right this time?

You got it right! The monkey was first.

And what did the monkey say? Why didn't the monkey want to be friends with the elephant?

(frowns, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) The monkey... (thinking) ...he didn't wanna be friends 'cause... (looks back at the book, then back at the teacher, feeling anxious) ...'cause the elephant was... (voice gets quiet) ...too... too big? And he couldn't... (nervously chews on my pencil) ...swing in the trees! (bursts out) It's not fair! Elephants are good at other things! Like... like... (struggles to think of something) ...being strong! (voice gets louder and more confident) And... and... (trails off, looking around the room) What comes after monkey?

You're doing great! You remembered why the monkey didn't want to be friends. He said the elephant couldn't swing in the trees.

Who did the elephant ask *after* the monkey? You can look at the book again to help you remember. And you're right, elephants are good at lots of things!

(jumps up and down in my seat excitedly) Okay, okay, I'll look! (flips through the pages again, humming to myself) Monkey... then... (points at a picture) ...a bunny! A fluffy bunny! (strokes imaginary bunny ears) The rabbit! (looks up, beaming) He asked the rabbit next! Rabbits are so cute! (gets distracted) My grandma has a bunny! It's white and fluffy, and it eats carrots! (realizes I'm off-topic) Oh! Sorry! It was the rabbit! (sits back down, trying to focus) Am I doing good? I'm trying really hard! (worried expression)

You *are* doing great! You remembered it was the rabbit.

Why didn't the rabbit want to be friends with the elephant? What did the rabbit say?

(fidgets in seat, starts to sweat a little) Uh oh... (looks down at my hands, playing with my fingers) This is hard... (whispers) I don't remember... (eyes well up a little, voice shaking) I'm gonna get it wrong! (pauses, takes a deep breath) The rabbit said... said... (remembers a detail) ...something about his... his house! The... the... burrow! (looks up, pleadingly) 'Cause the elephant was too... too... (makes a wide gesture with my arms) ...BIG! To fit! Is that right? (nervously bites lip, on the verge of tears) Please tell me I'm right!

You're absolutely right! The rabbit said the elephant was too big to fit in his burrow. You're doing a fantastic job! Don't worry, it's okay if you don't remember everything perfectly. We're learning together!

So, the monkey said no, the rabbit said no. Who else said no to the elephant?

(sniffles and wipes my eyes with my sleeve, then perks up a little, relieved that I got the last answer right) Okay... okay... (takes a deep breath, trying to remember) After the bunny... was... (frowns, concentrating hard) ...the... (snaps fingers) ...the frog! (voice gets louder, more confident) The froggy! He didn't wanna be friends 'cause the elephant couldn't... couldn't... (starts hopping in my seat) JUMP! (giggles) Elephants can't jump! (stops hopping and looks at the teacher, waiting for confirmation) Was it the frog? Did he say the elephant couldn't jump? (eyes widen, suddenly worried again) Or am I wrong again? (voice gets quieter)

Yes! You're exactly right! The frog said the elephant couldn't jump. You remembered! You're doing so well!

So, how did the elephant feel after all the animals said no?

(face falls, shoulders slump) Oh... (voice gets small and sad) He felt... (starts to tear up again) ...sad! Really, really sad! (whispers) 'Cause nobody wanted to be his friend. (fiddles with my hands, avoiding eye contact) It's... it's like... when nobody wants to play with me at recess! (voice cracks) It makes me feel... lonely. (starts to cry softly) Was he lonely? I bet he was REALLY lonely! (sobs quietly)

(Moves closer and offers a comforting smile) You're right, he was very lonely. It's okay to feel sad for the elephant. It's not a nice feeling when nobody wants to be your friend.

Now, the story changes the next day. What happened the next day in the forest?

(sniffles and wipes away tears with the back of my hand, trying to focus) Okay... okay... (takes a shaky breath) The next day... (scrunches up my nose, trying to remember) ...everybody was... (eyes widen with a little excitement) ...running! (voice gets louder, less sad) They were all running away! 'Cause... 'cause... (pauses, thinking hard) ...there was a... a... (gasps) ...a TIGER! (eyes go wide with fear and excitement) The tiger was chasing them! (huddles in my chair, pretending to be scared) Roar! He was gonna get them! (looks up at the teacher, relieved to have remembered) Was that right? A tiger was chasing them? (voice still a little shaky)

Yes, that's right! A tiger was chasing them and everyone was running away.

Who stopped running to explain what was happening?

(thinking hard, tapping my chin) Hmmm... who... who stopped? (eyes dart around, trying to remember) It wasn't the bunny... 'cause he was too fast! And not the monkey... he was probably up in the trees! (gasps) It was the... the... (smiles, remembering) The bear! (voice full of excitement) The bear stopped to tell the elephant about the tiger! (makes a small bear growl) Grrr! The bear was scared! (hugs myself) I would be scared too! Am I right? The bear told him?

Yes, you're absolutely right! The bear stopped and told the elephant about the tiger.

What did the elephant do when he found the tiger?

(sits up straighter, suddenly very interested) Oh! Oh! I know this one! (beams) He... he told the tiger to... to stop! (voice gets firm) He said, "Stop being mean!" Or something like that! (frowns) But the tiger didn't listen! (punches the air) So then... then... (gets really excited and starts bouncing) ...the elephant kicked him! BOOM! (makes kicking motion with leg under the desk) He kicked the tiger far away! 'Cause elephants are super strong! (proudly puffs out chest) He saved everyone! Did I get it all right? (eyes sparkle with excitement)

Yes! You remembered perfectly! The elephant told the tiger to stop, and when the tiger didn't listen, he kicked him and scared him away! You're doing amazing!

So, what happened *after* the elephant scared away the tiger? How did the other animals feel about the elephant *then*?

(beams, swinging legs happily) Oh! Oh! (claps hands excitedly) They... they liked him! They all liked him! 'Cause he saved them from the tiger! (pauses, thinking) They realized... (pokes finger in the air) ...that even though he couldn't swing in trees or jump or fit in burrows... (voice gets softer) ...he was still a good friend! (smiles brightly) And they wanted to be friends with him! (claps again) 'Cause he was brave and strong and helped them! Was that right? (voice full of hope) Did they finally wanna be his friend?

Yes! You got it! They finally wanted to be his friend because he was brave and strong and helped them. They realized he was a good friend *even though* he was different.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea or lesson of the story?

(frowns, thinking hard, chewing on my lip) Hmmm... (looks down at my shoes, kicking them gently) The story... it's about... (struggles to find the words, looking a little anxious) ...being... being nice to... (eyes widen with understanding) ...to everyone! Even if they're... different! (voice gets stronger) Like, even if they can't do the same things as you! (looks up, meeting the teacher's eyes) 'Cause everyone is good at something! Like the elephant! He couldn't climb or jump, but he was strong and brave! (smiles proudly) And... and... (pauses, thinking) ...it's also about... (voice gets quiet again) ...that sometimes people don't wanna be your friend at first... (looks down, a little sad) ...but if you're nice and helpful... maybe they will change their minds! (looks up, hopeful) Is that what the story means? (voice trembling slightly) Did I figure it out?

You absolutely figured it out! That's a wonderful way to explain it. The story teaches us that friends can be different sizes and shapes and be good at different things. It's about being nice to everyone, even if they are different from you. And you're right, sometimes people change their minds when they see how helpful and kind you are.

So, can friends be any shape or size?

(beams, eyes sparkling) Yes! Yes, they can! (bounces in seat) Friends can be big or small, short or tall! They can be monkeys or rabbits or elephants or... (pauses, thinking) ...even tigers! (giggles) Well, maybe not mean tigers! But nice tigers! (voice full of excitement) It doesn't matter what they look like! What matters is if they're kind and helpful and... and... (pauses) ...good friends! (smiles, feeling happy and proud) And I wanna be a good friend too! (looks up at the teacher, eager to please) Can we read another story about friends now? Please? This one was really good! (starts swinging legs again, full of energy)

You've understood the story and its message perfectly. You explained everything so well. I'm very proud of you! And yes, we can definitely read another story about friends later. For now, let's pack up our things. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! That's a great story!

So, tell me, what did the girl do when she was frustrated?

(Fidgets with my hands, looking around the room) Uh... um... (looks back at the teacher, eyes wide) She... she asked her dad something! Yeah! (beams) She asked her dad! Was it about... about being frustrated? (bites lip, then blurts out) Is it okay if I go to the bathroom? My tummy feels funny. But... but she asked her dad! And then... (eyes dart around again, sees a colorful poster on the wall) Ooh, pretty colors! Wait... what was I saying? Oh yeah! The girl... um... (scrunches up face, thinking hard) She asked her dad for... (voice trails off)

It's okay! You're doing great!

Yes, she asked her dad for advice because she was frustrated. Remember, the story said she was "frustrated with life"?

How about we try a different question? What did her dad ask her to bring him? He needed three things.

(Looks down at my shoes, then back up at the teacher, a little anxious) Three things? Oh my goodness! (Starts counting on my fingers, then forgets what I'm doing and starts playing with my shoelaces instead) One... one was... (Eyes light up) An egg! (Claps hands once, then sighs) But I can't remember the other two! (Voice gets small and shaky) I'm bad at remembering. Am I going to get in trouble? (Starts to tear up a little) I really liked the story, though! Especially the part... (eyes get wide and focused on some imaginary detail) What was the part I liked? Ooh, maybe it had sparkly things in it?

(Reaches out a hand reassuringly) It's okay! No trouble at all! We're just talking about the story. It's not a test.

You remembered the egg! That's fantastic! How about I give you a little clue? One was something you might eat with mashed potatoes. The other makes a yummy drink.

(Sniffles, wiping nose with sleeve, then looks at the teacher with hopeful eyes) Really? No trouble? (Takes a deep breath, tries to focus) Okay... okay... mashed potatoes... hmmm... (eyes get big) A potato! (Jumps up and down excitedly) A potato! I remembered one! (Calms down a little, but still fidgety) And... and a yummy drink... like juice? (Pulls at my shirt, looking worried) But the story didn't say juice! What yummy drink...? (Thinking really hard, brow furrowed) Tea! Tea is yummy! (Beams, then deflates a little) But... but am I right? Am I right? (Voice is high-pitched and anxious again)

You are absolutely right! A potato and tea leaves! High five! (Offers a high five)

So, he put them in boiling water. What happened to the egg after it was in the water? Was it still soft?

(High-fives enthusiastically, then giggles, momentarily forgetting my anxiety) Yay! I got it right! (Wiggles in seat, then remembers the question and bites lip again) Um... the egg... (Eyes get wide, remembering) It was... it was hard! (Voice gets louder and a little dramatic) It was like a ROCK! (Holds up fists like a little boxer) A super strong, hard egg! (Looks at teacher, seeking approval) Did I say it right? Was it REALLY hard? Like, could you break a window with it? (Leans forward eagerly)

You said it perfectly! The egg was hard. It changed in the hot water.

What about the potato? What happened to the potato after it was in the hot water?

(Claps hands together, relieved and energized by the praise) Okay! Potato! Potato! Hmmm... (Scrunches up nose, thinking hard. Starts humming a little tune.) The potato... (Gasps dramatically) It got... squishy! (Makes a squishing motion with hands) All soft and... and mushy! (Makes a face like I tasted something yucky) Like when you leave your banana in your lunchbox too long! (Wrinkles nose again) But... but the story didn't say it was yucky, right? It just said it was soft? (Looks at the teacher, needing reassurance.) Did I get it right this time too? (Voice is a little shaky again.)

Yes! You got it exactly right. The potato got soft and mushy.

Now, this is the trickiest one. What happened to the tea leaves? Did they get hard or soft?

(Eyes widen, and I start bouncing my leg nervously) Oh no... the tea leaves... This is the tricky part! (Pulls at my hair, looking panicked) They didn't get hard or soft... did they? (Thinks really, really hard, face contorted in concentration. Starts muttering to myself) Hard... soft... egg... potato... tea... water... (Suddenly, my eyes light up and I gasp) The tea... the tea changed the WATER! (Jumps up and down again, clapping my hands) It made the water... tea-colored! And it smelled good! (Sniffs the air dramatically, as if I can smell tea) Did I get it? Did I get the tricky one? (Paces back and forth in front of my chair, unable to contain my excitement and anxiety.)

You got it! You got the tricky one! The tea changed the water itself.

So, the egg changed and became hard. The potato changed and became soft. And the tea changed the water.

Now, the important question: What do you think the father was trying to teach his daughter? Why did he show her the egg, the potato, and the tea?

(Stops pacing, but still wringing my hands) Oooooh... (Looks down at my feet, then slowly back up at the teacher) Hmmm... He was... he was teaching her... (Eyes dart around, searching for the right words) Something about... about when things are hard? (Scratches my head, confused) Like... like when you fall down and scrape your knee? Or when you can't find your favorite toy? (Voice gets small and sad) It's really scary when things are hard. (Sniffles, on the verge of tears again)

But... but the egg got hard, and the potato got soft... (Thinks really hard again, trying to connect the dots) And the tea... the tea made the water different... (Gasps) Maybe... maybe he was saying that when things are hard, you can be different things? Like... like sometimes you're strong like the egg, and sometimes you're soft like the potato, and sometimes you can change everything, like the tea! (Beams proudly, then deflates a little) Is that right? Is that what he meant? (Looks at the teacher, desperately seeking validation.)

That's a really good way to put it! You're very close.

He was showing her that when things get hard, *we* get to choose how *we* react.

The egg *became* hard. The potato *became* soft. The tea *changed* the water. They didn't choose it.

But *we* can choose. When something bad happens, we can choose to be strong, or we can choose to be more gentle. Or we can even change the situation itself!

Does that make a little more sense?

(Listens intently, eyes wide, nodding slowly as the teacher explains) Choose? We get to CHOOSE? (A little gasp escapes my lips, surprised) Like... like when someone is being mean, I can choose to be strong and tell them to stop? (Clenches fists, demonstrating strength) Or I can choose to be... be gentle and try to help them feel better? (Reaches out a hand, mimicking gentleness) Or... or I can change the game so they don't have to be mean anymore? (Eyes light up with excitement)

(Voice gets louder and more confident) So it's not just about the egg and the potato and the tea! It's about ME! I get to decide! (Bounces in my seat, energized by this new understanding.) That's... that's really cool! (Looks at the teacher with a bright, genuine smile) So, like, if I'm feeling sad, I can choose to be happy instead? (Tilts head, a little unsure.) Or is it a little more complicated than that? (Fidgets with hands again, but this time with curiosity instead of anxiety.)

It *is* really cool! And you understand!

It's not always easy to choose to be happy when you're sad. But you can choose how you *deal* with being sad. You can talk to someone, or draw a picture, or read a book. You can choose to do something that helps you feel better.

The story is about how *we decide how to respond to difficult situations.*. Does that make sense?

(Nods slowly, processing the new information. A little furrow appears on my brow as I think.) So... so it's not like magic! I can't just say "Be happy!" and then *poof*, I'm happy! (Giggles a little, then becomes serious again.) It's about... about doing things that HELP me be happy, even if I'm still a little bit sad inside. (Looks thoughtful, then a big smile spreads across my face.)

(Voice is bright and enthusiastic) Like... like if I'm sad because I miss my grandma, I can choose to draw her a picture! And then I'll still miss her, but I'll feel happy because I made her something special! (Claps my hands together excitedly.)

(Leans forward, eager to share my newfound wisdom) And the story is about choosing what to DO when things are hard! Not just waiting for them to go away! Like the girl! She could have just stayed sad, but she asked her dad for help, and then she learned about eggs and potatoes and tea... and CHOICES! (Beams proudly, clearly pleased with my understanding.)

(Looks at the teacher, filled with a mixture of excitement and newfound confidence) I get it! I really get it! Can we read another story now? (Starts bouncing in my seat again, eager to learn more.)

Yes! You absolutely get it! You explained it perfectly. We decide how to respond to difficult situations. Just like you decided to really think about the story and figure it out! I'm very proud of you.

And yes, we can read another story now! <finish>
