dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Needle Tree."

Let's talk about it. Who are the main people in the story?

(Shifts feet, looks around the room for a moment, then back at the teacher)

Umm... (Stuttering) There... there were two... boys? (Thinking) Were they boys? I think so. Two boys, and... and a... a tree! A talking tree! It was a magic tree, right? With golden apples! (Eyes widen) Can trees *really* talk? My dog barks, but he doesn't talk like *we* talk. (Looks back at the teacher, smiling brightly) Is the tree a person?

(Smiling kindly) You're right! There *were* two boys and a magic talking tree. You remembered the golden apples too. Good job!

The tree isn't a person like you or me. It's a magical thing in the story.

Can you tell me about the two boys? What were they like?

(Confidently) Oh! Oh! I know! One boy was... was... (Frowns, looking down at my shoes) He wasn't very nice. (Looks up suddenly, excited) He was like a... like a... a grumpy monster! He wanted *more* apples, even though the tree gave him some! That's greedy! (Wrinkles nose) My mom says it's not nice to be greedy.

(Voice gets quieter, fiddling with my fingers) And the *other* boy... he was nice. (Looks away, nervous) He helped the... the... grumpy monster boy when he was hurt with the needles. He was being kind. (Looks back at the teacher, hopeful) Is that right? Did I get it right?

Yes! You got it exactly right! One boy was not very nice, and greedy. The other boy was kind.

What did the *grumpy monster* boy do to the tree?

(Eyes widen, leans forward) He... he wanted to... (Gasps) He wanted to cut it down! (Shakes head vigorously) That's SO mean! The tree gave him apples, and he still wanted to cut it down? (Voice gets higher) Why would he do that?! It's like... like if someone gave me a cookie and then I tried to take all their cookies! That would be terrible! (Frowns, thinking) Was he going to make firewood out of the tree? (Looks at the teacher, confused) Why did he want to do that? Was he cold?

That's right! He wanted to cut it down, even after the tree was nice to him. You are right, that's not very kind.

Why do you think he wanted to cut the tree down, even after he got the golden apples? What did he want to do with it?

(Puts a finger on my chin, thinking hard) Hmmm... Maybe... maybe he thought he could get even *more* apples if the tree was gone? Like, he could take all the apples at once! (Shrugs) Or maybe... maybe he just likes chopping things? (Looks worried) Is that... is that a good reason? I don't think so. (Scratches head)

(Suddenly brightens) Or maybe... maybe he didn't *believe* the tree would give him more apples! Maybe he thought the first ones were a trick! But that doesn't make sense, 'cause the tree *did* give him apples! (Looks at the teacher, pleading) I don't know! It's confusing! Why was he so grumpy and mean? (Starts to tear up) I don't like grumpy monster boys!

(Reassuringly) It's okay. It *is* confusing. The story doesn't tell us exactly *why* he was so mean. But it shows us that being greedy and unkind isn't a good thing, right?

What happened when the *grumpy monster* boy tried to cut down the tree?

(Sniffling, wipes nose with sleeve, then remembers what Mom says and uses the other sleeve)

(Voice is wobbly) He got... he got... (Gasps) He got poked with needles! (Shudders) A whole bunch of needles! Ouch! Ouch! Ouch! (Looks at hands, imagining needles sticking in them) Did it hurt really, really bad? (Looks at the teacher, eyes wide with worry) I don't like needles. They give me shots at the doctor's office, and they pinch! (Starts to cry a little) Was he crying? I would cry if I had needles all over me!

(Softly) Yes, it probably hurt a lot.

Then what happened? Who helped him?

(Sniffles again, looks down at the floor) The... the other boy... the nice boy... (Voice gets stronger) He helped him! He took all the needles out! (Looks up, proud) Even though the grumpy monster boy was mean to him, he *still* helped! (Beams) That was very brave and kind! (Pauses) Was it hard to take all those needles out? (Frowns, thinking about how hard that must have been) I bet it took a long time!

That's right. The nice boy helped him, even though the older brother wasn't nice to him.

What happened *after* the nice boy helped? Did the grumpy monster boy say anything?

(Thinking hard, taps chin) Umm... (Eyes light up) Oh! Oh! He said sorry! (Voice gets quiet) He said he was sorry for being mean. (Looks at the teacher, unsure) Does that mean he won't be a grumpy monster anymore? (Hopes) Can people stop being grumpy monsters? (Looks down at hands) I hope so...

Yes! He said sorry. That's a very important step.

What happened *after* the grumpy monster boy said he was sorry? What did the tree do?

(Eyes widen, excited) The tree gave them more apples! Golden, shiny apples! (Claps hands) Because the grumpy monster boy said sorry! (Voice gets lower) Does that mean the tree was happy he wasn't a grumpy monster anymore? (Looks at the teacher, pleading) Does being sorry make things better? I try to say sorry when I do something wrong, but sometimes it's hard.

That's right! The tree gave them more golden apples.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What is the big idea of the story?

(Looks away, fidgeting) The big idea...? (Thinking hard, face scrunched up) It's about... (Suddenly brightens) It's about being nice! (Claps hands again) And not being greedy! And saying sorry! (Pauses, looks thoughtful) And... and... helping people, even when they're mean to you! (Looks at the teacher, hopeful) Is that the big idea? Is it a good big idea? (Worried) I hope I got it right this time! I really, really want to get it right!

You are so close!

Think about what happened to the kind brother and what happened to the unkind brother. Which one got the golden apples in the end?

(Eyes widen, gasps) Both of them! (Thinking hard) But... but only *after* the grumpy monster boy said sorry. (Snaps fingers) So... so the big idea is that... (Takes a deep breath) Being kind and saying sorry can make things better for *everyone*! Even grumpy monster boys! (Beams, proud of myself) Did I do it? Did I get the big idea now?

Yes! You got it! Being kind and saying sorry can make things better for everyone! It's like the story is saying, "Kindness will always be rewarded."

You did a great job understanding the story! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Golden Touch."

First, can you tell me who the main person in the story was? What was his name?

(Eyes widen, excited) Ooooh! I know, I know! (Raises hand eagerly) It was King... King... (Stutters, looking away) King... Mmm...Mi...? (Confidently) King Midas! He was the main person! He got the... the golden... (Thinking) the golden...um... (Looks back at the teacher, smiling widely) touch! Because he was nice to... to the goat man!

Yes! You are right! His name was King Midas. And you remembered about the "goat man," that's great! We called him a Satyr.

So, King Midas did a good deed for the Satyr. What did Dionysus give him for that?

(Bounces in seat, almost falling forward) Oooooh, I KNOW THIS ONE TOO! (Points finger excitedly) He got a WISH! A super special wish from... (Frowns, trying to remember) Die... Die-o... (Looks at teacher expectantly) Die-on-ysus! Yeah! Dionysus gave him a wish! A GOLDEN wish! (Giggles)

You're doing fantastic! Dionysus did give him a wish.

What did King Midas wish for? What did he want more than anything?

(Scrunches up nose, thinking hard) Hmmm... he wanted... he wanted everything to turn to... (Gasps, eyes wide) GOLD! He wanted the golden touch! So everything he touched would be... (Claps hands) SHINY! And GOLD! (Looks around the room, imagining everything turning gold) Oooooh!

That's right! He wanted everything he touched to turn to gold.

Now, after he got his wish, was King Midas happy at first? What did he do?

(Nods head vigorously) YES! He was SO happy! (Starts tapping pencil on desk) He touched EVERYTHING! (Looks around again, then points at the teacher's glasses) He probably touched his bed, and his toys... and his FOOD! (Suddenly stops tapping, face falls) Oh no...
Oh no, indeed. Why "oh no"? What happened when he touched his food?

(Frown deepens, looks down at hands) Because... because it turned to GOLD! And you can't eat GOLD! (Looks up at the teacher, eyes wide with realization) He was HUNGRY! He couldn't eat ANYTHING! All his yummy food... (Shakes head sadly) just turned into hard, cold gold. (Whispers) Poor King Midas.
You're exactly right! He was very hungry. And then something else happened that made him even sadder. What was it? It had to do with someone he loved very much.

(Eyes start to water a little, voice quieter) Oh... oh no... (Looks down, tracing patterns on the desk with a finger) He... he hugged his... (Sniffles) his daughter. And she turned to gold too! (Looks up at the teacher, face crumpled) He didn't mean to! He loved her! (Starts to fidget with a loose thread on shirt)

Yes, that's right. He accidentally turned his daughter into gold.

So, was the golden touch a good thing for King Midas? Was it a blessing, or something that made him happy in the end?

(Shakes head vehemently, almost knocking over a pencil) NO! It was the WORST! (Voice gets louder, more emphatic) It wasn't a blessing at ALL! He couldn't eat, and he turned his daughter into a statue! A GOLDEN statue! (Looks pleadingly at the teacher) He was probably SO sad! He learned that... that gold isn't the most important thing, right?

You are absolutely right! Gold wasn't the most important thing. He learned that the hard way.

So, if King Midas could talk to another king and the king said "I want everything I touch to turn to gold!". What do you think King Midas would say to him?

(Sits up straight, face serious) I think... (Puts a hand on chin, pretending to think hard) I think King Midas would say... "NO! Don't do it! It sounds fun, but it's NOT! You can't eat, and you might turn someone you LOVE into gold!" (Looks at the teacher earnestly) He'd tell him that having friends and family and yummy food is WAY better than having everything turn to gold! (Nods head decisively) Way, WAY better!

That's a wonderful answer! You really understand how King Midas felt.

Now, the story teaches us something important. It teaches us that wanting too much can be a bad thing. What word would we use to describe wanting too much? Is it good to be... greedy?

(Wrinkles nose in disgust) Greedy! (Makes a "yuck" face) Being greedy is yucky! It's like... wanting ALL the candy for yourself, even if your friends don't get any! (Shakes head) King Midas was greedy, wanting all that gold! He should have been happy with what he had! (Looks thoughtful for a moment) Maybe he should have wished for a lifetime supply of pizza instead! (Giggles) But not greedy pizza! Sharing pizza!

(Laughs gently) Sharing pizza is definitely a better idea!

So, what does the story teach us about greed? Does it make you happy in the end? Or does it cause problems?

(Points a finger in the air for emphasis) Greed causes PROBLEMS! Big, HUGE problems! Like turning your daughter into a gold statue kind of problems! (Shudders dramatically) It doesn't make you happy, it just makes you... (Struggles for the right word) ...lonely and hungry and sad! (Nods firmly) So, no greed! Sharing and caring is better! (Beams at the teacher) And pizza!
You got it! You understood the whole story and what it means. Being greedy doesn't lead to happiness. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about the fox.

Why was the fox looking around?

(Jumping up and down a little) Ooh! Ooh! I know! (Raises hand high and waves it excitedly)

The fox was... was... (looks away, fiddling with my shoelaces) He was really, REALLY hungry! (Confidently) He wanted to find some yummy food to eat! Maybe... maybe a juicy chicken? Or... (eyes light up) a big, cheesy pizza! But he couldn't find any!

You got it! He was very hungry. He couldn't find any food.

Then what did he see on the wall?

(Eyes widen, leaning forward) Oh! Oh! I know this one too! (Stands on tiptoes) He saw... (uses complex word) DELICIOUS grapes! (Points upwards, miming reaching for grapes) Big, purple ones! They looked so yummy and juicy! (Starts to skip a little, then stops, remembering I'm supposed to be sitting still) Were they Concord grapes? I like Concord grape juice! Is that what the story meant?

They did sound yummy, didn't they? You have a good imagination! But the story just says they were big and purple.

What did the fox *do* when he saw the grapes?

(Frowns a little, tapping my chin) Hmmm... (Looks around the room, distracted by a colorful poster) He... he tried to get them! (Snaps fingers) Yeah! He jumped! Really, really high! (Jumps up and down again, demonstrating) He wanted to grab those grapes so badly! Did he have to jump super high? Was the wall REALLY tall? (Looks at the teacher with a curious expression)

Yes, he jumped really high!

Did he get the grapes?

(Shakes head vigorously) Nope! (Looks down at my hands, playing with my fingers) He couldn't reach them! He tried and tried, but he just couldn't get them. (Sighs dramatically) That's sad. (Asks a question) But why couldn't he get them? Was he too small? Or were the grapes just too far away? (Looks at the teacher expectantly)

He couldn't reach them, no matter how hard he tried.

What did the fox do *after* he couldn't get the grapes?

(Thinking hard, scrunching up my nose) Hmmm... After he couldn't get the grapes... (Looks out the window for a second, then back at the teacher) Oh! (Snaps fingers) He... he gave up! (Voice gets softer) He went home. Was he sad? I would be sad if I couldn't get yummy grapes. Maybe he cried a little bit on the way home? (Looks at the teacher with a hopeful expression, seeking confirmation)

He did give up and go home.

What did he say about the grapes when he walked away?

(Eyes light up, remembering the ending) Aha! I know! He said... he said the grapes were... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...SOUR! (Puts hands on hips, puffing out my chest) He said they were yucky and sour anyway! (Tilts head) But... but were they *really* sour? Or was he just saying that because he couldn't get them? I wonder if he *really* wanted those grapes. (Starts to hum a little tune, then stops and looks at the teacher expectantly)

That's right! He said they were sour.

Do you think the grapes *really* were sour? Or why do you think he said that?

(Thinks for a long time, tapping my pencil on the desk) Hmmm... I don't think they were *really* sour. I think... (uses complex word) ...he was just *pretending* they were sour! (Points a finger in the air) Because he was sad that he couldn't get them! (Looks thoughtful) It's like... like when I can't reach the cookies on the top shelf and I say I didn't want any cookies anyway! (Giggles) Is that what the fox was doing? Did he feel bad he couldn't jump high enough? (Looks at the teacher, wanting to know if I'm right)

You're exactly right! He felt bad that he couldn't get them, so he said they were sour.

Now, this story has a message, something it wants to teach us. What do you think the message of the story is? What did you learn from the fox?

(Eyes widen, thinking hard, fiddling with my fingers) Ooh, a message! Like a secret code? (Looks around the room, then focuses back on the teacher) Hmmm... I think... (pauses) ...it means that... (uses complex word) ...sometimes, when we can't get what we want, we *pretend* we didn't want it anyway! (Looks down at my shoes) Like... like if I don't get to play with the red truck, I say I wanted the blue car *more*! (Looks up at the teacher) Is that right? Is that the message? We shouldn't say things aren't good just because we can't have them? Maybe we should just keep trying! (Jumps up and down a little)

That's a great way to put it! It's like saying, "If you can't have something, don't hate it."

The story wants us to remember that things take effort. And it is easy to say we didn't want things in the first place.

So, the message is: Nothing comes easy, do not hate what you can’t have.

Do you understand the story now? <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story, [Student's Name]! That was "The Proud Rose."

Now, tell me, who are the two main characters in the story?

(Bouncing in my seat a little) Ooooh, I know! I know! (Raises hand super high and waves it) It's the… the… (Looks away, fidgeting with my pencil) the pretty rose and the… the… (Confidently) and the cactus! Yeah! A rose and a cactus! They were the most important!

Yes, you got it! The rose and the cactus.

Now, can you tell me, what did the rose think about the cactus? Was she nice?

(Eyes widen, leans forward, eager to share) Oh! Oh! The rose? (Thinks, tapping my chin) She wasn't nice, no, not at all! (Frowns a little) She was… she was… (Searching for the right word) mean! She told the cactus he was ugly! (Shakes head) That's not very kind, is it? She thought she was the prettiest ever! (Puffs out cheeks, imitating the rose)
You're right! The rose was being mean to the cactus. Why do you think the rose was being mean? What did she care about most?

(Thinking hard, wrinkles forehead) Hmmm... Why was she mean? (Looks up at the ceiling, trying to remember) Oh! (Snaps fingers) Because she thought she was so beautiful! (Confident again) She cared about how she looked! She wanted everyone to think she was the prettiest! (Starts to get distracted, looking at the colorful posters on the wall) Like… like a princess! (Whispers) A princess rose…

Yes, exactly! She was very focused on how she looked.

Now, what happened when it got really hot and there was no water? What happened to the rose?

(Suddenly focused again) Oh! Oh! I know! (Sits up straight) The sun got super, super hot! (Makes a sizzling sound) And the rose... (Looks down, a little sad) The rose got all… droopy. (Mimics a wilting flower with my hand) She started to… to… (struggles with the word) wither! Yeah, wither! She was thirsty!

Good job remembering "wither"! You're right. The rose was thirsty and started to wither.

What was the cactus doing while the rose was withering?

(Eyes light up, excited to tell the answer) The cactus! The cactus was... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...helping the birds! (Claps hands softly) He was giving them water! He had water inside him! (Points to myself) Like a water balloon, but not sploshy! (Giggles) He was being nice!

That's right! The cactus was helping the birds. So, the rose, who used to be mean, was now thirsty and withering. And the cactus, who she was mean to, was helping others. What happened next? Did the rose ask for help?

(Nods head vigorously) Yes! Yes, she did! (Leans in conspiratorially) She was super thirsty, remember? And she saw the cactus helping the birdies… (Slight pause, thinking) So she… she asked him for water! (Looks at the teacher expectantly)
And what did the cactus do? Did he say no because the rose was mean to him before?

(Eyes widen, a little worried) Oh! Oh no! (Shakes head) The cactus didn't say no! He was… he was nice! (Smiles brightly) He gave the rose water! Even though she was mean to him! (Looks thoughtful) He was a good friend. (Confidently) The cactus is the best!

He was a very good friend. Now, think about the whole story. The rose was proud and judged the cactus for how he looked. But then, when things got tough, who helped her?

What do you think this story is trying to teach us?

(Thinking hard, pokes tongue out a little) Hmmm... (Looks around the room, then back at the teacher) It's... it's like... (Frowns, trying to find the right words) It's like… being pretty doesn’t matter if you're not kind? (Looks up, questioning) And… and… even if someone is mean to you, you should still be nice to them? (Tilts head) Like the cactus! (Brightens up) Is that it? (Eagerly waits for confirmation)

You're getting very close! It's about not judging people based on how they look. The rose thought she was better because she was pretty, but that wasn't true. The cactus was good *inside*, and that's what really mattered.

So, what's the lesson of the story? What can we learn from the rose and the cactus?

(Eyes light up, understanding dawning) Oh! Oh! I get it! (Sits up straight, beaming) The lesson is... (pauses for effect) ...it's not good to be judgy! (Nods head emphatically) We shouldn't think we're better than other people just because of how we look! (Pulls at my own shirt, then smooths it) And... and we should be kind, even to people who aren't nice to us! (Smiles proudly) Like the cactus showed the rose! He was super duper kind! (Wiggles in seat, excited to have figured it out) Can I draw a picture of the cactus now?

Yes, you got it! That's exactly right! We should never judge someone based on how they look, and we should always try to be kind. The cactus is a great example of that.

You can absolutely draw a picture of the cactus now. You understood the story very well! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! You just finished reading "The Milkmaid and Her Pail." That was a fun story, wasn't it?

First, tell me, who was the story about?

(Eyes wide, bouncing slightly) Oh! Oh! I know! (Raises hand excitedly) It was about... um... (looks away, fidgeting with fingers) ... it was about a girl! A girl who... who had a pail! A big pail! (Beams proudly) And... and... she was going somewhere! To... to sell... things! (Looks at the teacher expectantly for confirmation) Was I right? Was it about the girl with the pail? I think her name was... Molly! Yeah, Molly!
Yes! That's right! The story was about Molly. And she did have a pail. What was *in* the pail? What was Molly going to sell?

(Jumps up and down) Ooooh! Ooooh! I KNOW! (Sticks hand up high) It was... it was... (Starts to get distracted by a shiny object on the desk, then quickly refocuses) Milk! It was milk! She was going to sell milk at the... at the... (furrows brow, trying to remember) ...the place where people buy stuff! The... market! Yeah! The market! She was going to sell milk at the market! (Looks very pleased with self, beaming at the teacher) Is that right? Was it milk?
Yes! You're doing great! Molly was going to sell milk at the market. Now, what did Molly start thinking about while she was walking to the market? What did she want to buy with the money?

(Paces back and forth in excitement, almost bumping into the desk) Oh! Oh! She was thinking about... about... a chicken! (Claps hands) A fluffy chicken! (Stops pacing, thinking hard, tongue sticking out a little) She wanted the chicken to... to... (Looks up at the ceiling, searching for the word) ...to make more money! With... with... eggs! (Turns back to the teacher, eyes shining) She wanted a chicken so she could have eggs and sell them too! And then she would have even MORE money! Wow! (Amaze reaction)
That's right! She wanted to buy a chicken to get eggs and sell them for more money. And what happened to the milk while she was thinking about all of that? Remember how she was walking?

(Stops, head tilted, thinking hard. Frowns a little, then face lights up.) Ooooh! I remember! She was... she was skipping! (Demonstrates a little skip, almost knocking over a pencil holder) She was skipping because she was SO excited about the chicken and the eggs and all the money! And then... (Gasps dramatically, covering mouth with hand) ...the milk! It spilled! (Looks at the teacher with wide, concerned eyes) All the milk spilled because she was skipping! Oh no!
Yes! Because she was skipping, the milk spilled. So, what happened to Molly's plan to buy a chicken? Did she get to buy one?

(Sits down heavily, a little dejected) No... (Looks down at hands, picking at a loose thread on shirt) She didn't get the chicken. Because... because the milk was all gone. (Looks up, eyes a little sad) She had no money to buy the chicken now. (Brightens up slightly, remembering something) But... but her mommy said something! (Puts hand up, eager to remember) Something about... about not counting... (Concentrates hard, face scrunched up) ...chickens... until they... (Snaps fingers triumphantly) ...hatch! Yeah! Don't count your chickens until they hatch! (Looks at the teacher, proud to have remembered) What does that mean?

You remembered the saying! "Don't count your chickens until they hatch."

Why do you think her mother said that to her? What did Molly do *before* she actually had the chicken?

(Thinks really hard, tapping chin) Hmm... (Looks at the teacher, a little confused) I don't really get it. (Pauses, then a lightbulb seems to go off) Wait! Wait! I think... I think it means... she was planning what to do with the chicken... *before* she even *had* the chicken! (Nods head vigorously) Like, she was already spending the money from the eggs... but she didn't even *have* the eggs yet! Or the chicken! (Looks at the teacher hopefully) Is that what it means? She was getting too excited too soon! She was... (searches for a big word) ...anticipating! Yeah! She was anticipating before she even had the chicken!

Yes! You got it! She was planning what to do *before* she even had the chicken or the eggs. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the lesson we can learn from Molly and her pail of milk?

(Sits up straight, puffing out chest importantly) Okay! Okay! I know this one! (Points finger in the air) It means... it means you shouldn't... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...you shouldn't plan too much before something REALLY happens! Like, you shouldn't spend your egg money before the chickens even *lay* the eggs! (Beams proudly) It's like... like... (Thinks hard, trying to find a good example) ...like if I said I was going to buy a GIANT robot dinosaur with my allowance... before I even *get* my allowance! (Giggles) That would be silly! Because I might not *get* the allowance! So, the story is teaching us to... to wait! And not get too excited too soon! (Nods head sagely) I think that's right! Did I do good?
You did AMAZING! You explained it perfectly. So, we shouldn't depend on things that might not happen. We should wait until we are sure! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story about the wise old owl! I liked how you read it.

Now, can you tell me one thing the owl did every day?

(Wiggles in seat, beaming) Thank you, Teacher! I liked the story too! Owls are SO cool!

Ummm... (looks away, tapping fingers on the desk) The owl... the owl... it, umm... saw things! Yeah! It watched things happening by the tree! (Confidently) It saw ALL kinds of stuff! People talking and... and... (Stuttering) telling stories! Is that right? Did I get it right? What else did the owl do? (Raises hand, looks at the teacher expectantly).

That's right! You got it! The owl *did* see lots of things and heard people telling stories. Good job!

So, the owl saw and heard all these things. Did the story say the owl talked a lot?

(Eyes widen, thinking hard) Hmmm... (Scratches head) Nooo... I don't think so. (Pauses, looks up at the ceiling) The story said... the *more* the owl saw, the *less* he talked! (Confidently) So, he didn't talk a lot! He was probably listening! Did the people know the owl was watching them? (Leans forward excitedly)

You're doing fantastic! You remembered that the more he saw, the less he talked.

Do *you* think the people knew the owl was watching? Why or why not?

(Gasps, thinking deeply) Oooooh, that's a good question! (Taps chin) Maybe... maybe not! (Looks at the teacher for a clue).

(Confidently) I think MAYBE they didn't know! Because owls are sneaky! They fly super quietly! And... and they can turn their heads ALL the way around! (Demonstrates by trying to turn head really far, giggling). So, the owl could see them without them seeing the owl! BUT! (Raises a finger) Maybe some people DID see him! Maybe little kids who look up in trees a lot!

Is that a good answer? What do YOU think, Teacher? Did they see him? (Bites lip, eager to know).

That's a *great* answer! You thought about lots of possibilities! It doesn't really say in the story if they saw him or not, but your ideas make a lot of sense.

So, the owl is watching and listening all the time. What did all that watching and listening do for the owl?

(Eyes light up) Ooooh! I know! I know! (Waves hand enthusiastically) He got WISER! The story said he got wiser day by day! (Beams proudly) Because he saw everything and heard everything! So he learned a lot! (Pauses, thoughtfully) So, watching and listening makes you... smarter? Is that right? Is that what "wiser" means? Maybe I should watch and listen more! (Starts looking around the classroom, observing things).

Yes, you got it! Wiser means like... smarter, and understanding more about the world. Just like the owl.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? If the owl got wiser by watching and listening and not talking so much, what does that mean for us?

(Fidgets, then concentrates) Hmmm... (Pulls on a strand of hair, thinking hard)

It means... it means we should... (Looks around for inspiration, spots a picture book) ...listen more! And maybe... maybe don't talk SO much! (Giggles sheepishly). Because if we listen to our parents and the teacher and... and other people... we'll learn more and get wiser too! Just like the owl!

(Confidently) So, the story is telling us to be good listeners! And... and that being quiet sometimes is good! So you can learn stuff! But... (Eyes widen) does that mean I have to be quiet ALL the time now? (Looks a little worried).

That's it! You figured it out! It means listening is important, and that we can learn a lot by paying attention. It doesn't mean you have to be quiet *all* the time, of course! It just means that sometimes, listening is the best way to learn.

The story has a moral - 'Talk less and be more observant' What does that mean?

(Nods enthusiastically) Okay! Okay! I get it!

(Excitedly) "Talk less and be more observant" means... don't just talk, talk, talk all the time! (Giggles) Like I do sometimes! (Claps hands over mouth for a second, then grins). It means to LOOK around and SEE things! And listen to what people are saying! Pay attention!

(Confidently) So, it's like saying, "Use your eyes and ears more than your mouth!" That's what the moral is! Is that right? (Bounces in seat, awaiting confirmation).

That's *exactly* right! "Use your eyes and ears more than your mouth!" That's a perfect way to understand the moral of the story. You really understood the story of the wise old owl. I am impressed. <finish>

(Looks expectantly at the teacher) Is that right?
Yes, that's right! It takes place on a farm. A sunny farm sounds lovely! Now, what did the goose give the farmer every day?

(Eyes light up, practically jumping) A GOLDEN EGG! (Whispers loudly) A golden egg! It was so shiny and pretty, I bet! (Thinking) Maybe it was even sparkly! (Asks a question) Did the golden egg have sparkles, Teacher?
(Smiling) That's a lovely thought! The story doesn't say if it had sparkles, but maybe it did! Now, what did the farmer do with the golden egg?

(Sits back, fiddling with a pencil) He... he...(looks around, distracted by a colorful poster) what did he do? (Confused) Oh! (Snaps fingers) He... he sold it! (Brightens up) He sold the golden egg and got money! Lots and lots of money! (Leans forward, conspiratorially) Enough money to buy candy every day, maybe?

(Nods head enthusiastically) Nope! (Thinks for a moment) They were happy... happy and... (struggling for the word) comfortable! (Beaming) They had a good life! But then...(frowns slightly)
But then what happened? What changed?

(Leans in, voice dropping to a dramatic whisper) Then... they got GREEDY! (Eyes widen) The farmer wanted more! (Shakes head) He wasn't happy with just one golden egg! He wanted ALL the golden eggs! (Looks up at the teacher, questioningly) That was silly, right?

(Puts a finger to cheek, thinking hard) Because...(struggling to articulate) because the goose only laid one egg a day! Yes, he was very sad. And what happened to the farmer and his wife *after* that?

(Thinking, taps pencil on the desk) Hmmm... after that...(eyes widen with understanding) they got POOR! (Voice is loud and clear) Because they didn't have any more golden eggs to sell! That's right. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big lesson?

(Sits up straight, thinking very hard, biting lip) The lesson is... (struggling, looks around for inspiration) ...is... (brightens up suddenly) Don't be greedy! (Grins, pleased with self) Is that right, Teacher? Is that another good way to say it?

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! I liked how you read it out loud.

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading "Elephant and Friends"! That was a fun story, wasn't it?

First, can you tell me, why was the elephant sad at the beginning of the story?

(Smiling brightly) Yes! It was a really, really fun story! (Shifts in seat, looking around the room for a second) Hmmm, the elephant was sad... (Thinking hard, tapping my chin) ... because he didn't have any friends! He was all alone in the forest and wanted someone to play with. (Confidently) He was looking for friends, but nobody wanted to be his friend. It was so sad! (Looks at the teacher with big, hopeful eyes) Is that right?

That's exactly right! The elephant was lonely. He wanted a friend.

Why didn't the monkey want to be the elephant's friend?

(Eyes widen) Oh! Oh! I know this one! (Wiggles excitedly) The monkey... (Stuttering slightly) ...the monkey said... said the elephant was too... too big! And he couldn't... (Confidently) ...swing in the trees! The monkey likes swinging, and elephants can't do that, so the monkey said no. (Leans forward, eager) Is that what happened? Can I tell you what the rabbit said too?

Yes, that's right! The monkey wanted a friend who could swing.

And yes, please tell me what the rabbit said!

(Clapping hands with glee) Okay! Okay! The rabbit... (Eyes dart around the room) ...the rabbit lived in a... a burrow! A little hole in the ground! (Confidently) And the elephant was too BIG to fit! So the rabbit couldn't be his friend because he was too big for the burrow. (Frowning slightly) It's hard to be friends when you can't even fit in their house, right? Is that why the rabbit said no? (Looks at the teacher expectantly)

You got it! The rabbit needed a friend who could fit in its burrow.

So, what happened the next day in the forest? Why were all the animals running?

(Gasps, eyes wide with dramatic flair) Oh! Oh! This is the exciting part! (Leans forward, practically bouncing in the seat) The next day... (Voice drops to a whisper) ...the TIGER was attacking everyone! (Looks around nervously, then back to the teacher) All the animals were running and screaming because the tiger was chasing them! (Beams) That's when the elephant came! Was the tiger REALLY going to eat them?

(Nods reassuringly) The tiger was being very scary and chasing them.

What did the elephant do when he saw the tiger?

(Puffs out cheeks, trying to remember) Hmmm... (Thinking hard, brow furrowed) He... he... (Suddenly beams, remembering) He asked the tiger to stop! He was very polite! (Acting out the elephant in a deep voice) He said, "Please, Mr. Tiger, don't scare my friends!" (Giggles, then adds in a normal voice) But the tiger was being mean! He didn't listen! What happened after that? (Looks expectantly at the teacher)

Good remembering! The elephant DID ask nicely.

What did the elephant do *after* the tiger didn't listen? This is the really exciting part!

(Eyes light up with excitement) Oh! Oh! I know! (Stands up straighter, voice full of awe) He... he KICKED the tiger! (Makes a kicking motion with leg) He was so strong, he KICKED the tiger and scared it away! (Sits back down, beaming proudly) The elephant was a hero! He saved all the animals! Was the tiger okay? I hope he didn't get hurt too badly...

The tiger was scared, but he was okay. He ran away and left the other animals alone.

After the elephant scared the tiger away, what did the other animals think about the elephant? Did they still think he was too big or too different?

(Eyes widen, thinking hard) Hmmm... before, they didn't want to be his friend because he was too big... (Snaps fingers) But then! Then they saw that being big was GOOD! (Voice gets higher with excitement) Because he was big, he could scare the tiger away! So they thought... (Pauses dramatically) ...he was the PERFECT size to be their friend! (Beams at the teacher) They finally liked him! Did they all play together after that?

Yes, that's right! They realized that the elephant's size wasn't a bad thing after all. It actually helped them!

So, what does this story teach us about friends? Can friends only be a certain size, or be good at the same things?

(Tilts head, thinking deeply, looking away) Hmmm... (Scrunches up nose) Well, at first, they only wanted friends who were like them. The monkey wanted someone who could swing, the rabbit wanted someone who could fit in his house... (Suddenly brightens) But then they learned that friends don't have to be the same! Even if you're different sizes or good at different things, you can still be friends! (Looks at the teacher confidently) Being different can even be helpful! (Pauses, thinking further) So... friends don't have to be a certain size! Or like the same things! (Smiles) That's a good lesson! Can we read another story now? Maybe one about a talking dog?
That's a wonderful lesson to learn! Friends can be any shape or size. Being different is what makes us special. You understood the story so well. <finish>

So, if life gives you a hard time... do you *have* to become hard like the egg? Or soft like the potato? Or can you be like the tea?

(Eyes light up, understanding dawning) Ooooh! (Confidently) You can be like the tea! Because... because the tea CHANGED everything! It didn't just get hard or soft, it made the water different! dialogue:
Okay, [Student's Name], that was a good reading! Now, let's talk about the story.

Who was the main person in the story?

(Eyes wide, bouncing slightly in my seat) Oh! Oh! I know! (Raises hand really high, almost knocking over my water bottle) It was... it was... (looks away, chewing on lip) ...King... King... (Stuttering) M-M-Midas! Yeah! King Midas! (Confidently) He was the main person! (Grinning, but then quickly looks down, a little nervous). He... he got the golden touch!

Yes! You got it! King Midas.

What did King Midas wish for?

(Squirming in my seat, then looks around the room, distracted by a buzzing fly near the window) Uh... uh... (leans forward, whispering) I know this! It was... (Looks back at the teacher, eyes widening) He wished... he wished for... (Starts tapping my foot nervously) Everything... (Looks down at my shoes, then back up) Everything he touched... (voice trails off, then perks up suddenly) turned to gold! Yeah! He wanted everything to turn into gold! (Smiling brightly, then a worried look crosses my face) But... but... (Fidgeting with my hands).

Good job remembering! You're right. Everything he touched turned to gold.

Was that a good wish, do you think? Why or why not?

(Eyes darting around, fidgeting with my shirt) Uh... (Thinking hard, brow furrowed) Well... at first, he was like... (makes grabbing motions with hands, like grabbing for gold) "Yay! Gold!" (Voice cracks slightly) But then... then... (Looks down at desk, tracing circles with finger) It wasn't good. (Voice is quiet and shaky) Because... because he couldn't... (looks up at the teacher, a little teary-eyed) He couldn't eat! And... and... his daughter! (Gasps, covering mouth with hand) She turned to gold too! (Looks away, blinking rapidly) So... no. It wasn't a good wish. (Voice barely a whisper).

You're exactly right. It wasn't a good wish.

Why wasn't it good that his daughter turned to gold?

(Sniffling a little, wiping my nose with my sleeve) Because... (looks up at the teacher with big, sad eyes) ...because he couldn't hug her anymore! (Voice cracking, almost crying) And... and she couldn't talk! Or play! (Shakes head slowly) Gold is... is shiny, but it's not... (struggling to find the right word) ...it's not... *alive*! (Tears welling up) He loved his daughter! (Voice rising in pitch, getting more upset) And now she's just... a statue! (Buries face in hands, starting to sob quietly).

(Reaches out and gently pats student's shoulder) You're right. That's very sad. He loved his daughter very much.

So, King Midas wanted everything to be gold. But what did he lose because of that?

(Still sniffling, peeks through fingers) He lost... (Thinking, tapping fingers on desk) He lost... (pauses, then looks up at the teacher, eyes still watery) He lost his food! (Gestures dramatically with hands) Can you imagine? No yummy snacks! (Frowning) And... (voice trembles) he lost his daughter! (Hangs head again, voice muffled) He lost... (Struggling to articulate) ...the things that made him *happy*! (Looks up, wiping eyes) Gold didn't make him happy. It made him... (searches for the right word) ...sad! (Nods emphatically, finally understanding).

That's right! He lost the things that made him happy.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea we can learn from King Midas?

(Thinking really hard, wrinkling my nose) Hmmm... (Looks around the room again, then back at the teacher) It's... (Stuttering) It's... that... (Taps chin thoughtfully) ...that wanting too much... (voice trails off) ...is bad? (Looks at the teacher questioningly) And... (voice gets stronger) ...that gold isn't everything! (Nods with conviction) Hugs and... and yummy food... are better than gold! (Smiling a little, relieved to have figured it out) The story is teaching us that... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...love is more important than shiny things! (Beams proudly).

You've got it! Wanting too much can be a bad thing. Sometimes, the things we already have are much more important. This story shows us that being too greedy, wanting more and more, can lead to losing the things we really care about. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the fox and the grapes!

Now, can you tell me, what was the fox looking for in the beginning?

(Eyes wide, fidgeting with my hands) Oh! Oh! (Looks around the room, then back at the teacher, smiling brightly) He was... he was looking for... um... (Stuttering) food! Food! He was really, really hungry! (Bounces slightly in my seat) He couldn’t find any, anywhere!

That's right! He was looking for food because he was hungry. Good job!

And what did he find growing on the farmer's wall? What did he see that looked yummy?

(Gasps, excited) Ooooh! (Claps hands) Grapes! Big, purple, juicy grapes! (Looks at the teacher, beaming) They were SO big! And purple! And… and… the story said they were juicy! (Starts swinging my legs under the chair) Did you ever see grapes that big? (Quickly looks away, nervous) Sorry! I shouldn’t… am I talking too much?

No, you're doing great! I love how excited you are! Yes, they were big, purple, and juicy grapes.

Now, what did the fox do to try and get the grapes?

(Wrinkles nose, concentrating) He... he jumped! (Points finger up in the air) He jumped really, really high! (Looks down at shoes) But... but he couldn't reach them. (Frowns, picking at a loose thread on my pants) He jumped a lot and a lot and a lot of times! He just couldn't get them! (Looks back up at the teacher with a slightly worried expression). Was he silly to jump so much? (Voice is quiet)

He really did try, didn't he? He jumped and jumped!

What happened after he couldn't reach the grapes? What did he do then?

(Shuffles feet, looks down) He... he went home. (Voice gets quieter) He was probably really sad. (Looks up quickly, eyes wide) And he said... he said the grapes were sour! (Frown deepens) But... but I think he just said that 'cause he couldn't get them. (Leans in conspiratorially) Do *you* think they were *really* sour? (Whispers) Maybe they were the best grapes ever!

That's very good thinking! He did say the grapes were sour.

Do you think he really thought they were sour, or was he just saying that because he was upset he couldn't reach them? Why do you think that?

(Bites lip, anxious) Um... (Looks around the room) I think... I think he was just saying it. (Forces a small smile) 'Cause... 'cause if he said they were sour, then it wouldn't be so bad that he couldn't get them! (Voice trembling slightly) Like... like if you *really* wanted a cookie, but someone ate it, you could say it was yucky anyway! (Looks at the teacher pleadingly) Does that make sense? (Starts to pick at nails) I get mixed up sometimes.

That makes perfect sense! It sounds like the fox didn't want to admit that he couldn't get what he wanted. He tried to make himself feel better by saying the grapes weren't good anyway.

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big idea of the story?

(Eyes widen, panicking slightly) Oh no! (Looks around, searching for an answer on the walls) The... the big idea...? (Voice trails off) Is it... is it about... about grapes? (Looks at the teacher hopefully) Or... or is it about... foxes jumping? (Pulls at shirt) I don't know! I don't know the big idea! (Voice cracks slightly) Am I going to get in trouble? Can you just tell me? Please? (Looks on the verge of tears)

Hey, hey, it's okay! No trouble at all. Take a deep breath. We can figure it out together.

Think about it: The fox wanted something he couldn't have, and then he said he didn't want it anyway.

Does that remind you of anything else? Maybe a time you wanted something really badly?

(Sniffs, wipes nose with sleeve) Okay... (Thinking hard, screwing up face) Like... like the toy car at the store! (Eyes light up a little) I *really, really* wanted it! It was red and shiny and had big wheels! (Voice is still a little shaky) But... but Mommy said it was too expensive. And then... then I said I didn't even *like* red cars! (Looks at the teacher, ashamed) But I did! I really, really did! (Looks down at hands, twiddling thumbs) So... is the big idea... that sometimes we say things that aren't true when we're sad we can't have something? (Looks up, hopeful)

You're getting so close! Yes, it's about wanting something you can't have, and then pretending you didn't want it anyway.

The story is trying to teach us that if you can't get something, it's better to be honest about it, instead of pretending you didn't want it. And that sometimes, things are hard to get!

So, a good idea from this story is: Nothing comes easy, do not hate what you can’t have. Can you say that?

(Repeats slowly, carefully) Nothing... comes... easy... Do not... hate what you... can't have. (Looks at the teacher, relieved) I said it! (Claps hands softly) Does that mean I learned the big idea? (Smiles shyly) I think I understand now! (Starts to swing legs again, happier now) The fox should have just said he was sad he couldn't get the grapes! And maybe tried to find something else to eat!
Yes, you did! You learned the big idea! And you explained it so well. The fox could have been honest and maybe found another yummy snack. You understand the story and its lesson perfectly! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Proud Rose."

So, can you tell me, who are the two main characters in the story?

(Eyes wide, shifting in my seat) Uh... um... (Looks away) There was... um... a rose! A pretty, pretty rose! (Grinning, then fidgeting) And... and... (stuttering) a... a... cactus! Yeah! A cactus! (Confidently) They were in the desert! (Bouncing my leg)

dialogue:
Okay! Let's talk more about Molly and her milk.

You just read the story. What was Molly going to do with the milk?

(Eyes wide, looking at the teacher with a big, nervous smile) Umm... (fidgets with hands) Molly... she... she was gonna... sell it! At the... the... market! (Looks down at shoes, voice getting quieter) Was that right? I think... I think that's what it said. Did she? Oh, I hope I got it right! (Looks back up at the teacher, hopeful and a little anxious)

Yes! You are absolutely right! She was going to sell it at the market.

What did Molly start thinking about when she was walking to the market?

(Beams, relieved) Oh! Good! I knew it! (Starts to bounce slightly in seat, then stops, remembering to be polite.)

Okay, um... (furrows brow, trying to remember) She... she saw a... a chicken! (Gasps slightly) And she thought... she thought she could... get MORE money! (Voice gets a little higher pitched with excitement) If she bought the chicken... and then... then it would lay eggs! And she could sell THOSE, too! (Claps hands once, then immediately looks a little nervous, worried about making too much noise) Is that... is that it? (Looks at the teacher with hopeful, but slightly worried eyes).

That's a great remembering! Yes, she wanted to buy a chicken and sell the eggs.

What happened *because* she was thinking about all the extra money? What did she do?

(Starts to chew on lip, looking down) Oh... oh no. (Voice gets very quiet) That's the... the bad part, right? Um... (Stammers) She was... she was like... (Tries to remember, then brightens slightly) Skipping! She was skipping 'cause she was so happy about the chicken and all the money! (Frowns again) But... but then... oh no... (Looks up at the teacher, eyes wide with concern) Did she... did she trip? (Voice is barely a whisper) Did she spill it ALL? Oh no, Molly!

You're doing so well! She *was* skipping because she was happy. And yes, you're right, she spilled the milk.

Why did she spill the milk? Was it because she was being careful?

(Shakes head vigorously) NO! No, she wasn't! (Pulls face) She was... she was being silly! (Giggles a little, then catches self and tries to look serious) She was... (Taps chin, trying to find the right word) ...carried away! Yeah! She was carried away with all the money thoughts and the chicken and... and then... (Looks down again, voice very soft) ...splash. All gone. (Shakes head sadly) Poor Molly. (Looks up, suddenly anxious) Was it... was it her fault? (Bites lip again)

Yes, it was her fault. She was so busy dreaming about the future, she forgot to be careful *now*.

What did Molly's mother say to her when she got home?

(Eyes widen, trying hard to remember) Oh! Oh, I think I know this one! (Squints, concentrating) She said... she said something about... (Taps forehead) ...chickens! But... but not buying them... She said... (Beams, remembering) Don't... don't count your chickens... until... until they... (Snaps fingers) ...hatch! Yeah! (Claps hands softly this time, proud of remembering, but still a little nervous) Is that right? Did I get it? (Looks at the teacher expectantly)

You got it exactly right! "Don't count your chickens until they hatch."

What do you think that saying means?

(Tilts head to one side, thinking hard) Hmmm... (Looks down at hands, tracing circles on the desk) It means... it means don't... don't think you HAVE something... (Pauses, frowning) ...until you REALLY have it? Like... like Molly thought she HAD all that egg money already, but she didn't... because the chicken wasn't even BOUGHT yet! (Looks up at the teacher, eyes wide) Is that... is that what it means? (Voice is a little shaky, unsure if the answer is right)

Yes! That's a perfect explanation.

So, what did Molly learn in the story? What's the big idea of the story?

(Sighs, relieved to hear the explanation was correct. Starts to fiddle with a loose thread on shirt.) Oh... the big idea? (Looks at the ceiling, thinking. A little frown appears.) It's... it's that you shouldn't... (Looks back at the teacher, a little hesitant) ...get TOO excited about things that haven't happened yet? (Pauses, then adds quickly) Because... because you might spill your milk! (Giggles nervously, then immediately worries about giggling) And... and you should be careful... (Voice trails off, uncertain) Is... is that good? I think it's hard to find the big idea. (Looks down again, feeling a little anxious.)

That's a very good way to put it! Yes, it's about not getting too excited about things that haven't happened yet. You need to be careful and make sure things *actually* happen before you start planning.

Another way to say it is: Don't depend on something until you are sure it will happen. Do you think that fits the story?

(Looks up, eyes widening slightly. Listens very carefully to the new sentence, mouthing the words silently.) "Don't... depend... on something... until... you're... sure..." (Pauses, thinking hard, then nods slowly.) Yes! (Voice gets a little more confident.) Yes, that's... that's even BETTER! Because... because Molly was depending on the chicken eggs before she even HAD the chicken! (Claps hands softly, then pulls them back quickly.) Oh! I get it! (Smiles brightly, relief washing over face.) That's a good big idea! (Looks at the teacher with genuine enthusiasm.) Thank you for helping me! It was hard to find it by myself.
You did a fantastic job figuring it out! You understood the story really well, and you explained the big idea perfectly. <finish>

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the owl! You just read the story. What did the owl like to do?

(Looks away, fidgeting with my hands) Um...the owl...uh... (stuttering) He...he watched things! Yeah! (Eyes light up) He watched people and...and stuff around his tree! It was a...a big tree! (Confidently) A REALLY big tree!
That's right! He watched things. And the tree was very big! Good job! What did he watch the people *doing* near the tree?

(Bounces slightly in my seat, excited) They were...talking! (Uses big hand gestures) They were telling...telling stories! (Voice gets quieter, more anxious) Were they...were they good stories? I like good stories! (Looks at the teacher with hopeful eyes) Did the owl like the stories?

That's a great question! The story doesn't say if the owl *liked* the stories, but it does say he *heard* them. What do you think he did with all the things he saw and heard? Did he tell everyone what he knew?

(Wrinkles nose, thinking hard) Hmmm... (looks down at my shoes) I...I don't think so. (Shrugs shoulders) The story said he...he talked *less*! (Voice gets a little shaky) Is that...is that okay? It's okay to talk less, right? My tummy feels funny.
It's absolutely okay to talk less! You're doing great! So, the owl watched and listened and talked less. What happened to the owl because he did that? What did he become? The story tells us.

(Eyes widen) Oh! (Snaps fingers) I remember! He became...he became... (starts to look distressed, biting lip) ...wis...wis...(teacher please help me!) He became... something smart! Was it smart? (Looks at the teacher pleadingly) I think... I think it was smart! My head feels fuzzy.

You're so close! The story said he became *wiser*. Wiser is like being very, very smart because you've learned a lot. So, the owl watched and listened and talked less and became wiser. Why do you think watching and listening helped him become wiser?

(Pulls at my sleeve, looking down) Because...because he... (Struggles to find the words, avoids eye contact). I don't know... (Voice gets small) It's...it's hard. He heard...heard the stories... (Looks up quickly, then back down) And he saw the people... (Shakes head slightly, looking frustrated) My brain doesn't work good. Can we...can we draw a picture of the owl instead? Please? (Anxious expression)
It's okay if it's hard! You're doing a great job. Let's think about it this way: If you only talk, are you learning new things? Or do you learn more when you listen to other people?

(Considers this, tapping my foot) If I...if I only talk...then...then I only hear my voice! (Gasps, eyes widening) And...and if I listen... (Looks up at the teacher, a little less anxious) ...then I hear...hear other people's voices and stories! So...so I learn more when I listen! (Beams proudly) Am I right? Am I right?

You got it! You're exactly right! So, the owl learned a lot by watching and listening. He didn't need to talk all the time. He learned from what he saw and heard. That's why he became wiser.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Paces back and forth a little, energized) The big idea! The big idea is... (Stops pacing, points a finger in the air) ...is that we should...we should listen! (Looks at the teacher for approval) And...and watch! And... (Voice trails off, unsure) ...and...and not talk so much all the time? Is that it? (Nervously chews on my lip) I think... I think so! Because the owl got...got wiser! And I want to be wiser too!

That's fantastic! You figured it out! The story teaches us that sometimes it's better to listen and watch than to talk all the time. We can learn a lot by being observant like the owl. We can become wiser! You understand the story very well. <finish>

Who bought the well?

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends."

First, can you tell me who the story is about?

(Fidgets with my pencil, looking down at my shoes) Um... it's... (stuttering) about... animals? A lot of animals! (Looks up quickly, smiling brightly) And! And! There's an elephant! (Points excitedly at the book, almost knocking it off the table) The... the elephant is, like, the main... (looks away, brow furrowed) ...the most important animal in the story! Yeah! The elephant! (Confidently)

That's right! The elephant is the main animal in the story.

Why was the elephant sad at the beginning?

(Starts swinging my legs under the table, a little too fast) Oh! Oh! (Looks at the teacher, eyes wide) Because... because nobody wanted to be its friend! (Frowns, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) They said it was too big! (Voice gets quieter) The monkey... the monkey said it couldn't swing! And the rabbit... the rabbit had a burrow! (Sighs dramatically, then bounces in my seat) It was a REALLY lonely elephant! (Looks at the teacher again, hoping I got it right) Was that right?

Yes, that's exactly right! The elephant was lonely because the other animals didn't want to be its friend.

Why didn't the monkey want to be friends with the elephant?

(Starts humming to myself, then stops abruptly) The monkey! The monkey... (scratches my head, looking around the room) The monkey... um... (eyes dart to the window, distracted by a bird outside) ...oh! Right! (Snaps fingers) The monkey couldn't... I mean, the elephant couldn't... (confused) ...swing! (Points at the book again, then back at the teacher) The monkey wanted to swing in the trees and the elephant was too big! (Nods emphatically) Yeah! That's it! (Looks a bit anxious, hoping I'm not wrong)

You got it! The monkey wanted to swing and the elephant couldn't.

What about the rabbit? Why didn't the rabbit want to be friends with the elephant?

(Fidgets with the eraser on my pencil, chewing on my lip) Um...the rabbit... (thinking hard) The rabbit... it had... (looks at the teacher nervously) a... a house! (Eyes widen) No, wait! Not a house! A... (whispers) burrow... (voice gets louder) A burrow! And the elephant was too... (stretches arms out wide) ...TOO BIG to fit in the burrow! (Looks down at my hands, picking at my fingernails) It was a small burrow... for a small rabbit... and a BIG elephant! (Looks up, a little worried) Did I get it right this time?

You did! The elephant was too big for the rabbit's burrow.

So, all the animals said no to being the elephant's friend. Then what happened the next day?

(Eyes light up, leaning forward excitedly) Oh! Oh! I know! (Wrings hands together) The next day... the next day... everyone was running! (Looks around the room dramatically, pretending to be scared) Running and screaming! (Gasps) Because... because... (voice gets shaky) ...the TIGER was attacking! (Shivers, then claps hands together) The TIGER! And everyone was SO scared! (Looks at the teacher, a little breathless)
Yes! They were all running from the tiger. What did the elephant do?

(Bounces in my seat, almost falling off) The elephant! The elephant... (thinks for a moment, then beams) ...he helped! (Puts hands on hips, puffing out my chest) He was brave! (Voice gets louder) He stopped the TIGER! (Whispers) He kicked him! (Giggles) He made the tiger go AWAY! (Looks at the teacher, beaming with pride) The elephant saved everyone!

That's right! The elephant scared away the tiger.

So, after the elephant saved them, what did the other animals think about being friends with the elephant?

(Taps my foot excitedly, practically vibrating with energy) They... they... (pauses, trying to remember exactly) ...they liked him! (Eyes widen) No! They LOVED him! (Claps my hands together) They realized he was a REALLY good friend! (Looks at the teacher, tilting my head) Because he was big and strong and... and he saved them! (Gets quiet, voice barely audible) They were probably sorry they weren't nice to him before... (Looks up quickly, smiling brightly again) But then they were all friends! (Bounces happily) Everyone was happy!

Yes, they all wanted to be his friend after he saved them.

Why do you think they wanted to be his friend *after* he saved them, but not *before*?

(Scrunches up my nose, thinking hard. Looks down at my hands, then back at the teacher.) Um... (stutters) because... (hesitates) ...before, they only thought about what *they* wanted. (Frowns, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) The monkey wanted to swing... the rabbit wanted his burrow... they didn't care about the elephant! (Voice gets a little louder, more confident) But then... then the tiger came! And the elephant was the only one who could help! (Looks at the teacher, eyes wide) So they learned that being a good friend isn't just about what *you* want... it's about helping! (Takes a deep breath, looking a little anxious) Did I... did I explain that okay? It's hard!

That was a great explanation! You're right, they only thought about what they wanted before.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us about friends? Can friends only be a certain way?

(Starts chewing on my pencil again, looking thoughtful. Then, a sudden flash of understanding) Ooooh! (Snaps fingers, almost hitting myself in the face.) I know! (Voice gets a little shaky, nervous again) It's... it's about... (looks at the teacher for reassurance, then back down at the table) ...it's about... you can be friends with anyone! Even if they're different! (Voice gets stronger, more confident) The elephant couldn't swing! He couldn't fit in the burrow! But he was still a good friend! (Looks up, smiling brightly, all anxiety gone.) So... so friends don't have to be all the same! They just have to... (pauses, searching for the right word) ...help each other! Yeah! Help each other! (Beams proudly.)

You got it! Friends don't have to be the same size or be good at the same things.

So, how about this: Friends can be any shape or size. What do you think about that?

(Claps my hands together, bouncing in my seat again.) YES! (Nods enthusiastically) That's exactly right! (Looks around the room, excited) The elephant was BIG! And the rabbit was SMALL! And they were still friends! (Points at the teacher, then at myself.) You're big, and I'm small! (Giggles) And we're talking about the story! (Voice gets quieter, a little shy) So... so yeah! Friends can be any shape or size! That's the best part! (Smiles brightly, all fidgeting gone for a moment.)
Wonderful! You understood the story really well, and you explained it perfectly! Friends really *can* be any shape or size. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "When Adversity Knocks."

First, can you tell me who the story is about?

(Wriggles in my seat, glances around the room) Um… it’s about… a girl… and her… (stutters) f-father? (Looks at the teacher with big, hopeful eyes). Was that right? I liked how the dad helped her! (Beams, running ahead) He had all those things! Like a… like a cooking show! Did you see them? An egg and a… and a potato! And the tea! Oh! I like tea with milk!

Yes! You're exactly right. It's about a girl and her father.

Now, what was the girl feeling at the beginning of the story? Was she happy or sad?

(Frowns, fidgeting with my shoelaces) Uh… sad? (Looks away, picking at a loose thread). She was… um… (long pause, whispers) frustrated? Is that a… big word? (Looks back at the teacher, nervously). She didn't like… l-life? (Looks down again, kicking my feet) I don't like when I can't find my crayons! That's frustrating! (Suddenly cheerful) But then I find them! It's much better then.

Yes, "frustrated" is a big word, but you used it perfectly! She *was* frustrated with life. Good job!

So, what did her father do to help her feel better? What did he put in the boiling water?

(Eyes light up, claps hands) Ooooh! I know this one! (Jumps in seat) He put in an egg! And a… (furrows brow, thinking hard) …a tater! (Giggles) A potato! And… (looks around the room, distracted by a colorful poster) … and, oh! (Quickly glances back at the teacher, worried) Tea! (Voice gets quieter) He put tea… in water. (Starts to chew on fingernail, looking anxious) Was that all?

Yes, that's all! The egg, the potato, and the tea leaves.

Now, what happened to the egg after it was in the boiling water? Was it the same, or did it change?

(Eyes widen, remembering the story) It… it changed! (Scrunches up nose, thinking hard) It got… um… (Looks down at hands, nervously twisting fingers) Hard? (Looks up at teacher, pleading) Did it get hard? Like… like when you cook an egg? (Leans forward, excited) I like hard-boiled eggs with salt!

Yes, it got hard! You're doing great!

And what happened to the potato?

(Sticks tongue out, concentrating) The potato… (Paces excitedly in front of desk.) was… (Voice trails off. Looks to the side, distracted.) Ooh! Is that a dinosaur on your desk? (Quickly remembers the question) Oh! The potato! (Giggles, then whispers.) The potato got… soft! (Looks up at the teacher, beaming.) It got all squishy! Like… like mashed potatoes! I like mashed potatoes!

Yes! The potato got soft. Just like mashed potatoes.

And what about the tea? Did it become hard or soft?

(Frowns, thinking really hard. Bites lip) Hmmm… The tea… (Looks up at the ceiling, trying to remember) It didn’t get hard or soft… (Tilts head, confused) It… (Eyes widen with sudden understanding) It changed the water! (Smiles proudly) It made tea! The water wasn’t just water anymore! It was tea!

Exactly! The tea changed the water itself.

So, the egg, the potato, and the tea all went into the same hot water, but they all changed in different ways. Why do you think the father showed his daughter this? What was he trying to teach her?

(Shrugs, looks down at shoes, kicking them together) Uh… (Stammers, nervous) I… I don't know. (Looks up at the teacher, voice trembling slightly) W-was it because… because they were all… different? (Frowns, confused) Like… like how some kids like to draw and some kids like to build with blocks? (Starts to tear up, overwhelmed) I… I don't get it. It's too hard!

It's okay! It's a tricky question. You're right, they were all different. The hot water was like a hard time, like when things get difficult.

Think about it: The egg started soft, and the potato started hard. What happened to them when things got tough (when they went into the hot water)?

(Wipes eyes with sleeve, sniffling) The egg… (Looks down, tracing patterns on the floor with a shoe) The egg got hard. (Looks up, confused) And the potato… got soft. (Frowns, picking at fingernails) But… but why? (Voice cracks) Why did the hard time make the soft egg hard, and the hard potato soft? It doesn't make sense! (Starts to cry quietly) I don't understand!

It's okay to be confused! Think of it this way: the hot water (the hard time) didn't *make* the egg hard or the potato soft. They *chose* to become that way. The egg *chose* to harden. The potato *chose* to soften.

Do you understand what I mean?

(Sniffles, looking at the teacher with wide, watery eyes) Choose? (Tilts head, considering) But… but how can an egg choose? (Frowns, wiping nose with back of hand) That’s silly! Eggs don’t have brains! (Suddenly perks up, remembering something) But *I* can choose! Like… like I can choose to play with blocks or read a book! (Pauses, thinking hard) So… so the girl in the story… she could choose too? (Looks at the teacher, hopeful) She could choose… what to do… when things got hard?

Yes, you got it! The girl could choose what to do when things got hard. Just like the egg and the potato, we can choose how we react when things get tough. The hard time doesn't *make* us do anything. We get to choose!

So, what do you think the father was trying to teach her about dealing with problems?

(Beams, understanding dawning on face) He was teaching her that… that even when things are yucky and hard… (Frowns slightly, then brightens again) …she can choose to be strong like the egg! (Puffs out chest) Or… or maybe she needs to be soft and bendy like the potato! (Wiggles body) Or… (Eyes widen) …or maybe she can change the whole thing, like the tea! (Claps hands excitedly) She can make the problem into something new and… and good! (Looks at the teacher, beaming) Did I get it right? Did I?

Yes! You got it exactly right! He wanted her to know that *she* could decide how to respond when things get difficult. We decide how to respond to difficult situations. We can choose to be strong, bendy, or even change the situation itself! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Needle Tree! That was a fun story, wasn't it?

First, can you tell me: who are the characters in the story?

(Eyes wide, bouncing slightly in my seat) Yeah! It *was* a fun story! (Grinning)

Umm... (Fidgeting with my hands) Okay, so... there's... umm... (Looks at the floor) there's the...the... (Looks up at the teacher, hopefully) ...the brothers! Yeah! Two brothers! (Confidently) And... and there's a tree! A magical tree! (Beaming) Did I get it right? Did I?

Yes! You got it exactly right! There are two brothers and a magical tree.

Now, can you tell me, what kind of person was the *older* brother? Was he nice? Or was he something else?

(Starts to swing legs under the table) Umm... (Thinking hard, chewing on my lip) He... he wasn't very nice. (Looks down at hands) He was mean to the younger brother! (Frowning) He... he took all the firewood! (Voice gets a little quieter) And he... he tried to cut down the tree, even after it gave him apples! (Looks up, eyes wide with worry) Was that... was that bad? He *was* bad, right?

Yes, you're right. He wasn't very nice. It sounds like he was being quite greedy and unkind.

What about the *younger* brother? What kind of person was he?

(Eyes brighten up) Oh! The younger brother! (Sitting up straighter) He was nice! (Smiling) He helped the older brother when he got... (Wrinkles nose, trying to remember the word) ...the... prickles? Yeah! He took out all the prickles! (Looks at the teacher expectantly) He was a good brother! He helped even though the older brother was mean! (Shrugs) That's... that's what you're supposed to do, right? Help people?

That's right! You explained that very well. The younger brother was kind and helpful, even when his older brother wasn't nice to him.

Now, what happened *after* the younger brother helped the older brother? Do you remember what the magical tree did?

(Starts tapping fingers on the desk, looking a little anxious) Umm... (Looks away, trying to remember) After... after the needles... (Voice gets quieter, almost a whisper) My tummy feels funny... (Takes a deep breath) The tree... the tree... (Snaps fingers suddenly) It gave them more apples! (Beaming, relieved) Because the older brother said sorry! He said sorry for being mean! (Looks at the teacher hopefully) Did... did saying sorry make the tree happy?

Yes! That's exactly right! The tree gave them more apples because the older brother apologized.

So, the older brother was mean and greedy at first, and he got needles. Then he said sorry, and the tree gave them more apples. What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Frowns, thinking hard, starts to pick at a loose thread on shirt) Umm... (Stuttering slightly) Is it... is it 'bout... 'bout not being mean? (Looks up at the teacher, nervously) And... and saying sorry? (Voice gets a little louder, more confident) If you're mean, you get needles! But if you say sorry, you get... (Claps hands together) ...golden apples! (Looks down again, shyly) Is that... is that right? Am I close?

You are *very* close! It *is* about not being mean and saying sorry. But it's also about something else the younger brother did. He was kind, even when the older brother wasn't.

So, what happens when you are kind? Do you think good things happen?

(Eyes light up, bouncing in seat again) Ooooh! (Claps hands) It's 'bout being kind too! (Thinking hard, tapping chin) If you're kind, like the little brother... (Smiling) Then... then maybe you get golden apples too! (Looks up at the teacher, excitedly) Does that mean if I'm always kind, I'll get golden apples someday? (Gasps) Maybe not real ones... but like... good things will happen to me? Is that what it means?

That's right! The story shows us that when you are kind, good things can happen. Kindness is like a seed, and good things are the flowers that grow from it.

So, how would you tell someone what this story is about? What's the most important thing you learned?

(Takes a deep breath, trying to organize thoughts) Okay... okay... (Looks around the room, then back at the teacher) The story is about... (Struggles, then blurts out quickly) ...being kind! (Pauses, then continues with more confidence) And... and not being mean! Because if you're mean, you get needles! But if you're kind, and you say sorry when you're not kind... (Beaming) ...then you get golden apples! Or... or good things! (Nods head seriously) So be kind! (Grinning widely) Is that good? Did I do it right?

Yes, that's excellent! You explained the story and what it teaches us perfectly. The story of the Needle Tree shows us that kindness will always be rewarded.

dialogue:
Okay! Hi there! I'm so glad you read "The Golden Touch" with me. That was quite a story, wasn't it?

First, can you tell me who the main person in the story was? What was his name?

Hi! (Grinning widely and bouncing in my seat) It was a *great* story! The main person... (eyes dart around the room, then I stare intently at my shoes for a moment) ...was... um... (stuttering a little) ...Midas! Yeah! King Midas! He was, like, super important! (confidently raises my hand)
That's right! King Midas! Super important indeed! Now, can you tell me what King Midas wished for? What did he want more than anything?

(My hand shoots up again) Ooh! Ooh! I know! (beaming) He wanted... (pauses, thinking hard) ...everything he touched to be GOOOOOLD! (stretches out the word "gold" excitedly and makes grabbing motions with my hands) He wanted a golden touch! It was, like, a superpower! (looks very pleased with myself)
Yes! A golden touch! You remembered perfectly. Now, after he got his wish, was King Midas happy at first? What did he do?

(Running ahead excitedly) Yeah! He was SO happy! He touched, like, everything! (starts miming touching things around the room and turning them into gold with a flourish) The chair! (touches the air) GOLD! The table! (touches the air again) GOLD! His crown! (pretends to put on a golden crown) GOLD! He was, like, the richest king EVER! (eyes widen)
He sure thought he was the richest king ever! But... did he *stay* happy? What happened after he touched all those things and turned them to gold?

(Frowning slightly, fidgeting with my fingers) Um... (eyes start to wander around the room again) He... (pauses, looking down at my shoes) He got hungry! (voice drops a little) But... but his food turned to gold too! (looks up, a little confused) And... and then his daughter... (voice almost a whisper) ...she turned to gold too! (looks sad and bites my lip)
That's right. He got hungry, and his daughter... turned to gold. How do you think King Midas felt *then*? Was he still happy with his golden touch?

(Shakes my head vigorously. Looks down at my hands.) No! (voice is louder again) He was... (scrunches up my nose) ...sad! And maybe... (thinking hard, sticking my tongue out a little) ...scared! Because he couldn't eat, and his daughter was... was gold! (shivers slightly) He didn't want the golden touch anymore! (looks up, eyes wide) It was a *bad* wish!
Exactly! It was a bad wish. So, if the golden touch made him so unhappy, even though he thought it would make him happy, what do you think we can learn from this story? What does the story teach us?

(Thinking, looking up at the ceiling) Hmmm... (taps my chin with my finger) It... (pauses, searching for the right words) ...it teaches us that... (stuttering slightly) ...that gold isn't, like, everything? (looks at you hopefully) That... that maybe having too much stuff... (shrugs) ...isn't so good? (looks around the room, distracted by a colorful poster) And... and hugging your daughter is better than gold! (smiles, a little shyly)
