dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Fox and the Grapes."

So, tell me, what did the fox want?

(Eyes widen, then I look at the ground) Grapes! (Confidently) Big, purple, juicy grapes! He wanted them *so* much! He jumped and jumped! (Starts to bounce a little in my seat, almost running in place) Were they yummy grapes? (Looks up at the teacher, eager)

Yes, he really wanted those grapes! You remembered they were big, purple, and juicy!

Did he get the grapes?

(Frowns, kicks feet a little) Noooo. (Looks away, then back at the teacher) He jumped and jumped... (Stops kicking feet, thinking) He couldn't get them. (Confidently) He wasn't tall enough! Did he need a ladder? (Looks at the teacher, waiting for an answer)

He wasn't tall enough, you're right! A ladder might have helped!

What did the fox say *after* he couldn't get the grapes?

(Puts hand up, trying to remember) Hmmm... (Starts to get distracted, looking around the room) Was it about... (Looks back at the teacher, remembering I need to focus) Oh! (Confidently) He said they were sour! (Wrinkles nose) Sour grapes! Yuck! (Bounces a little in my seat again)

That's right! He said they were sour.

Why do you think he said that? Were they *really* sour?

(Stops bouncing, thinking hard) (Stuttering) Mmm... maybe... maybe they were? (Looks down at my hands) But... (Looks up at the teacher) But he wanted them *so* much! Why would he want sour grapes? (Confused)

That's a very good question! He *did* want them a lot.

Do you think he *really* thought they were sour, or was he just saying that because he was sad he couldn't reach them?

(Eyes widen, thinking) (Points finger up in the air) Maybe... maybe he was sad! (Looks at the teacher, then down at my shoes, kicking them lightly) Like when I want a cookie and Mom says no? Then I say I didn't even want a cookie! (Looks back up, excitedly) Is it like that? Did the fox *really* want the grapes even though he said they were sour?

Yes! That's a great way to understand it! It's just like the cookie.

So, the fox couldn't get what he wanted. What did he do then?

(Frowns again, looking down) He went home. (Quietly) All sad. (Looks up quickly) But maybe he found something else to eat! Maybe berries! Did he find berries? (Eagerly waiting for the teacher to answer)

Maybe he did find berries! We don't know for sure, but that's a happy thought.

But let's think about the story. What do you think we can learn from the fox and the grapes? What's the story trying to teach us? It's okay if you're not sure.

(Scrunches up nose, thinking hard) Learn... learn... (Gets distracted, looking at the colorful posters on the wall) (Teacher gently redirects my attention) Oh! Learn! (Looks down at my hands, wringing them) (Stuttering) Maybe... maybe don't say you don't like something if you *really* wanted it? (Looks up at the teacher, unsure) Is that it?

That's a *very* good start! You're right, it's about more than just grapes, right? It's about when we can't get something we want.

What should we do when we can't get something we want? Should we just give up and say we didn't want it anyway?

(Thinks for a second, then shakes head vigorously) No! (Confidently) We should try again! And again! (Bounces in seat a little) Maybe the fox should have gotten a ladder! Or asked for help! (Looks up at the teacher, then remembers something) (Stuttering) Or... or maybe... it's okay to be sad if you can't get something. But don't say you didn't want it! That's silly! (Smiles, pleased with myself)

That's excellent! So, it's good to try your best. Sometimes, even if you try your best, you still can't get what you want. And that's okay to be a little sad about.

So, what's the lesson of the story? If you can't have something, what should you *not* do?

(Nods head very hard, understanding) Don't say you didn't want it! (Confidently) Because that's like... like lying to yourself! And lying is bad! (Looks up at the teacher, very serious) (Then smiles brightly) Did I get it right? Did I learn the story?

You got it exactly right! The story teaches us that it's important to try hard for what we want, and if we still can't get it, we shouldn't pretend we didn't want it in the first place. Sometimes, things are hard to get, and that's okay. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story, [Student's Name]! That was "The Proud Rose."

Now, tell me, who are the two main characters in our story?

(Bounces a little in my seat, eager to answer)

Um, (points finger up) a rose! And... (squints eyes, thinking hard, fidgeting with my hands) and a... (gasps, remembering) a cactus! (Looks at the teacher, smiling brightly) The rose was, like, super pretty! (Starts to get out of seat a little, then sits back down quickly)

Yes! That's right! A rose and a cactus.

And you're right, the rose thought she was very pretty. What did the rose do to the cactus? Did she play nicely?

(Swings legs under the chair)

Noooo! (shakes head emphatically) The rose wasn't nice! (frowns a little) She... she said mean things! (Looks down at my hands, then back up at the teacher) She said the cactus was... ugly! (Makes a face, mimicking the rose being mean) The other plants didn't like it, but she kept doing it!

That's right. The rose said mean things because she thought the cactus was ugly.

How did the other plants feel about the rose being mean?

(Looks around the room, distracted for a moment by a colorful poster on the wall)

Um... (taps fingers on the desk) The other plants... (eyes widen slightly, remembering) They didn't like it! (nods head) They tried to make the rose stop! (Stands up suddenly, then sits back down giggling a little) But the rose just... (shrugs shoulders) didn't listen! She was too busy looking at herself! (Looks at the teacher, still smiling)

Good remembering! The other plants tried to help the cactus, but the rose didn't listen.

Now, what happened when it got really hot and there was no water? What happened to the rose?

(Confidently) Oh! Oh! I know this one! (Raises hand high) The rose got all... (pauses, searching for the word) ...droopy! (Lets hand fall) She started to, like, (makes wilting motions with hands) wither! Because she didn't have any water! (Looks at the teacher expectantly)

Yes, she got droopy and started to wither!

What about the cactus? Was the cactus droopy too? What was the cactus doing?

(Thinking hard, furrows brow) Hmmm... (looks down at desk, then back up) The cactus... (smiles) He was helping the birds! (Bounces in seat again) The sparrows! He gave them water! (Beams proudly) He had water inside him! (Points to own tummy) Like a water bottle!

Exactly! The cactus was helping the sparrows.

So, the rose is wilting and the cactus is helping others. What did the rose *then* do? Did she keep being mean, or did something change?

(Eyes widen, remembering the important part)

Oh! (Almost jumps out of seat again but catches self) The rose... (lowers voice slightly) ...asked the cactus for water! (Looks at the teacher, a little surprised) She wasn't mean anymore! She was... (scratches head) ...thirsty! (Giggles a little)
Yes! The rose asked the cactus for water. And did the cactus help her? Even after she was so mean?

(Nods head enthusiastically)

Yes! (Claps hands once) The cactus gave her water! (Looks at the teacher, really happy) He was nice! Even though the rose was mean before! (Starts to hum a little tune) He shared his water! (Points at the teacher) That's like when you share your crayons!

That's a great comparison! Sharing crayons is a kind thing to do, just like the cactus sharing his water.

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? Is it okay to be mean to people because they look different?

(Stops humming, looks very serious)

Noooo! (shakes head very firmly) It's not okay to be mean! (Points finger up in the air) Even if someone looks different! The rose was mean, and then she needed help! (Looks down at hands, then back up) The cactus helped her anyway because he was nice! (Smiles brightly) So we should be nice to everyone, even if they're... prickly! (Giggles at own joke)

That's right! We should be nice to everyone, even if they look different or seem "prickly." We shouldn't judge people based on how they look.

So, what's the lesson, or the moral, of the story of the Proud Rose? What does the story teach us?

(Sits up straighter, thinking hard)

Um... (taps chin) The story teaches us to... (looks at the teacher, then at the ceiling) ...to be kind! (Nods head) And to share! (Looks down, fidgets with hands a little) Even if someone wasn't kind to you first! (Looks up, smiling again) Because being nice is better than being... proud! (Beams, pleased with the answer) And we shouldn't be mean to others. (Confident)

Wonderful! You've got it! The story teaches us that we should be kind to everyone, even if they are different from us, and that we shouldn't judge people based on how they look. Being kind is much more important than being proud or thinking you're better than others. Never judge someone according to how they look.

You understood the story so well! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of Molly, the milkmaid!

Now, can you tell me, what was Molly going to do with the milk?

(Grinning widely, bouncing a little) Uh, she was gonna... (looks away, tapping foot) sell it! At the... the market! (confidently) She was gonna get money for it! Yeah! And she was really, REALLY gonna sell it! I know that!

Yes, you got it! She was going to sell the milk at the market and get money!

What did Molly start thinking about while she was walking to the market? What was she thinking she would buy with the money?

(eyes widen, jumping slightly) Oh! Oh! I know this! (stuttering a little) She... she saw a... a chicken! (points excitedly) And she wanted to buy it! With the money from the... milk! (proudly) And then the chicken would lay eggs! And she could sell *those* too! And get *more* money! (starts to skip a little) She was gonna be rich! (looks around the room, distracted by a colorful poster) Was it a brown chicken? Or a white chicken?

That's right! She wanted to buy a chicken and sell the eggs. Good remembering!

Do you think it was a good idea for Molly to start planning all of this *before* she sold the milk? Why or why not?

(Stops skipping, wrinkles nose) Uh... (taps chin, thinking) Hmmm... (looks at the teacher with wide, innocent eyes) I... I think it was a good idea! (confidently) Because then she knew what she wanted! And chickens are cool! (distracted again, pointing to the teacher's pen) Ooh! Is that a sparkly pen? Can I see it?
Chickens *are* cool, and it's good to have plans! But... what happened *because* Molly was so busy dreaming about chickens and eggs? What happened to the milk?

(Sighs dramatically, slumping a little) Oh yeah... (looks down at the floor) The milk... (mumbles) It spilled... (looks up, quickly) But it wasn't my fault! (bounces a little again) She was skipping! And dreaming! And then... (makes spilling motion with hands) sploosh! All gone! No more milk! No more chicken yet! (grins sheepishly)
Yes! The milk spilled. So, did Molly get to buy the chicken and sell the eggs *after* the milk spilled?

(Shakes head emphatically) Nope! (frowns, then brightens) But... maybe she can try again tomorrow! (excitedly) She can be SUPER careful tomorrow! And then she *will* get a chicken! (starts humming, then stops suddenly) Wait... (confused) Is the story over? What happens *after* the story? Does she get a chicken *ever*?
That's a good question. The story *doesn't* tell us if she *ever* gets a chicken. But what did her mother say to her when she got home with no milk or money? Do you remember?

(Thinking hard, scrunching up face) Umm... (snaps fingers) Oh! Oh! I remember! It was... (pauses dramatically, then says proudly) Don't count your chickens until they hatch! (beams at the teacher, hoping for praise) Did I get it right? Did I?

You got it exactly right! "Don't count your chickens until they hatch!"

What do you think that means? Why did her mother say that? What was she trying to teach Molly?

(Tilts head, thinking) Hmmm... (starts fidgeting with hands) It means... (stuttering a little) ...that you shouldn't... shouldn't think you have something... until you *really* have it? (looks at the teacher uncertainly) Like... Molly didn't *really* have a chicken yet, so she shouldn't be planning all the things to buy! Is that right? (bites lip)

You're getting very close! Yes, it means you shouldn't think you have something until you *really* have it.

So, a different way to say that is: don't *depend* on something *before* it happens. Can you say that? "Don't depend on something before it happens."

(Repeats slowly, carefully) Don't... de... pend... on... some... thing... before... it... happens. (grinning again) I said it! I said it! (thinks for a moment) So... like... don't think you're gonna get a cookie... before your mom *gives* you the cookie! (nods sagely) I get it now! (immediately looks around the room again, distracted) Do *you* have a cookie?

(Smiling) That's a perfect example! Don't depend on getting a cookie until you *actually* have the cookie.

So, what's the big lesson from the story of Molly the milkmaid? What did we learn?

(Eyes widen, hand shoots up in the air) Ooh! Ooh! I know! (Stands up a little in seat, barely able to contain excitement) We learned... we learned that you shouldn't... (pauses, thinking hard) ...you shouldn't skip with milk! (giggles) And... and you shouldn't plan for chickens... until you *have* the chicken! (sits down, satisfied) That's it! I learned the whole lesson! Can we read another story now? A story about a *real* chicken maybe? (bounces in seat, waiting eagerly)

You're absolutely right! You learned that you shouldn't plan for things until they are sure to happen. It's a good idea to be careful and not depend on things too early. That's what Molly's mom meant by "Don't count your chickens until they hatch!"

You did a great job with this story! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "A Wise Old Owl."

Now, can you tell me what the owl liked to do? What did he spend his time doing near the oak tree?

(Wiggles in my seat, looking around the room) Uh... the owl? Near the... oak tree? (Looks at the teacher with a big smile) He... uh... (Sticks tongue out, thinking hard) He... watched stuff! (Confidently) Yes! He watched stuff happening! People talking and... and... other things!

That's right! He watched stuff! Good job! And you said people were talking.

So, the owl was watching and listening. Did he talk a lot himself?

(Looks down at my shoes, fidgeting) Um... (shrugs shoulders) I don't think so. The story didn't say he talked... a lot? (Looks up at the teacher, hopeful) He heard them talking, though! And he saw stuff! That's what made him... (Trails off, distracted by a shiny button on my shirt). Shiny! (Suddenly remembers the question) Oh! The owl! No, I don't think he talked a lot.

Good remembering! You are right, the story didn't say he talked a lot.

So, he mostly watched and listened. What happened to the owl because he watched and listened so much?

(Beams at the teacher, happy to answer) He got... he got... (Thinking, tapping my chin) Uh... he got... (Looks away, then back) He got... wiser! (Confidently) He got wiser because he saw and heard everything! Like a super-spy owl!

Yes! He got wiser! You're exactly right. He learned things by watching and listening.

Do you think the owl would have become wiser if he was always talking and never listening?

(Gasps dramatically) No way! (Shakes head emphatically) If he was always talking, he wouldn't hear anything! It's like when I'm talking and talking and talking, and then... (Pauses, remembering something) Oh! Like when my mom tells me to clean my room, but I'm too busy telling her about my new race car? (Looks at the teacher, hoping she understands) Then I don't hear her, and my room stays messy! So, the owl needs to listen to get wiser!

That's a great example! You understand perfectly. Just like you didn't hear your mom, the owl wouldn't learn anything if he was always talking.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Scrunches up my nose, thinking hard. This is a tough one!) The... the... (Looks around the room, searching for inspiration) The big idea? Hmmm... (Suddenly stands up straighter, excited) The big idea is... (Points to the teacher) ...we should listen more! (Sits back down, a little out of breath) Like the owl! If we listen, we get wiser! And then... (Thinking again) ...and then maybe we can be super-spy owls too!

You got it! Listening is very important. And sometimes, it's good to talk less and listen more so you can learn new things.

So, the story teaches us that it's good to watch and listen and learn.

Do you think you can try to be a little more like the wise old owl sometimes? <finish>

(Nods enthusiastically) Yes! Yes, I can! (Thinks for a second) But... (Looks a little worried) ...does that mean I can't talk about my race cars ever? (Looks at the teacher hopefully) Because they are super cool! Maybe I can listen first, and *then* talk about my race cars? Is that okay? (Beams at the teacher, waiting for an answer).
That sounds like a very wise plan! It's all about finding a good balance. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, let's talk about "The Goose and the Golden Egg"! You just read a great story!

First, can you tell me, what did the goose do every day?

(Grinning widely, I bounce in my seat)

The goose! The goose! It laid an egg! A shiny, golden egg! (claps hands excitedly) Every! Single! Day! (wiggles in seat, looking around the room briefly) It was super cool! I would want a goose that laid golden eggs. Wouldn't you?

(Smiling) That *is* super cool! You're right!

And what did the farmer do with the golden egg?

(My smile falters a little, I look down at my hands)

Um... (thinking) He... (looks away, briefly distracted by a colorful poster on the wall)... he did something with it. It was... important. (Looks back at the teacher, grinning again hopefully) He... maybe he ate it? No... (frowning slightly) That's not right. Did he... did he sell it? I think he sold it! Yeah! He sold the golden egg! (Confidently) He sold it for money!

(Nodding encouragingly) You got it! He sold the golden egg.

And what did he and his wife do with the money?

(Eyes light up, running ahead again)

They bought candy! And toys! And... and a big, bouncy castle! (pauses, remembering the story again) No, wait... (frowns) They bought... not a bouncy castle. (Looks down at my hands again, fidgeting) They bought... good stuff! Like... food! And... and maybe a new house? (Looks up at the teacher hopefully) Did they get a new house? They bought... lots of good stuff! Because they had the gold!

(Smiling gently) They bought good things, yes. The story said they lived a *comfortable* life. They had enough.

Now, why did the farmer become unhappy? He had a golden egg every day!

(Confidently, I puff out my chest)

Because he was greedy! (Frowns, then, remembering what "greedy" means) That means he wanted... more! More eggs! He wasn't happy with just one! (Starts to bounce in my seat again, distracted) He wanted a whole bunch of golden eggs! Like... a whole mountain of golden eggs! (Looks at the teacher, smiling brightly) Wouldn't that be awesome?
(Chuckles softly) A mountain of golden eggs would be quite something! But why did he think he could *get* more eggs all at once? What did he do?

(I scrunch up my nose, thinking hard. I look around the room, momentarily spotting a classmate making a funny face, and giggle.)

Um... (Stuttering a little) He... he did something silly. Really, really silly. (Looks back at the teacher, trying to focus) He thought... (looks down at my shoes, kicking them lightly) He thought all the eggs were... inside the goose! All at once! A giant pile of golden eggs! So he... (gulps) He opened her up. (Whispers) He cut her open.
(Nodding slowly) He did. And what did he find?

(My eyes widen, remembering the icky part. I look away, fiddling with the edge of my shirt.)

(Quietly) Blood. And guts. (Shudders a little) Not golden eggs. No golden eggs at all. Just... yucky stuff. (Looks back at the teacher, a little sad) It was... not good.

No, it wasn't good at all.

And what happened after that? What happened to the farmer and his wife?

(Sighs dramatically, leaning back in my chair)

They were sad. (Pause, thinking) And poor! They didn't have any more golden eggs. So they didn't have any more money. (Looks at the teacher, with wide, innocent eyes) They didn't get their candy or bouncy castle, did they? (Frowns) They messed up.

That's right. They messed up. Because they were greedy and they didn't think.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the lesson?

(Bouncing in my seat, eager to please)

Don't cut open geese! (Giggles)

(Thinking for a moment, tapping my chin)

Um... (Looks around, distracted by the clock ticking)

Don't be greedy! (Confidently) If you are greedy, you won't get anything! You'll just have blood and guts! (Winces) And that's not fun. It's better to have one golden egg than no golden eggs! (Smiles brightly) Right?

(Smiling encouragingly) You're very close! It's definitely about not being greedy. But it's also about *why* they were greedy. They didn't stop to *think* about what would happen.

What if the farmer had stopped and thought for a minute? What if he had thought, "Hmm, if I cut open the goose, will I *really* find more eggs? Is that even possible?" What do you think would have happened then?

(Eyes widen, considering this)

(Thinking hard)

If he thought... (Stuttering a little) If he used his brain... (Looks around the room, then back at the teacher)

He wouldn't have cut the goose! (Confidently) He would have just waited for the next golden egg! And the next! And the next! (Smiling brightly) He would still be happy! And rich! And not covered in... yuck! (Wrinkles nose)

So... the story is about thinking! (Excitedly) And not being greedy! You have to think *before* you chop up a goose! (Giggles)

(Beaming) Exactly! It's about thinking before you act. If you think about what might happen *before* you do something, you can avoid making mistakes. It's a very important lesson.

So, can you tell me the lesson of the story in your own words? What does the story teach us to do?

(Standing up, puffing out my chest importantly)

The story says... (Thinking hard, pacing a little)

The story says... (Points finger dramatically) ...THINK! (Pauses) ...Before you do stuff! (Nods head seriously) Especially if it involves... geese! (Sits back down, grinning proudly) And don't be greedy! Because greedy people don't get bouncy castles! (Giggles)
(Smiling warmly) Wonderful! You understand the story and its message perfectly! You know to think before you act, and to not be greedy. That's a very important lesson to learn. <finish>

dialogue: Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Farmer and the Well." Can you tell me, who are the main people in the story?

(Bounces in my seat, eyes wide) Ooh, ooh! I know! (Raises hand REALLY high) There's the farmer... and the mean neighbor! And... and the emperor! (Looks around the room, then back at the teacher, grinning). Oh! And the emperor's helper guy! The court... court-ier? (Sticks tongue out a little, trying to say the word). Are those all of them? (Tilts head, waiting for confirmation.)
Yes, that's everyone! Good job remembering them all. Now, can you tell me what the farmer wanted to do with the well he bought?

(Gasps, excitedly) He wanted water! (Points to an imaginary well) For his farm! He wanted to water his... (Stops, looks around again, then whispers) ...plants? So they can grow big and strong! (Beams, proud of myself. Starts wiggling in seat again).
That's right! He needed water for his plants. And what did the neighbor do when the farmer tried to take water from the well?

(Frowns, scuffing feet on the floor) The neighbor was... was... (Taps chin, then bursts out) ...MEAN! He said the farmer couldn't have any water! Even though he sold him the well! (Throws hands up in the air dramatically) That's not fair! (Looks at the teacher, expectantly).
No, it wasn't fair at all. Where did the farmer go to get help?

(Jumps up and down a little) He went to the emperor! (Points an imaginary crown on my head) The emperor is like... like a really, REALLY big boss! He helps people when they're in trouble! (Sits back down, but legs are still swinging). Is the emperor like a superhero? (Eyes wide with curiosity.)
He's not exactly a superhero, but he is there to make sure things are fair. What did the emperor's helper, the courtier, ask the neighbor?

(Thinking, head tilted. Starts to pick at a loose thread on my shirt) Hmmm... hmmm... (Looks up suddenly, eyes bright) He asked the neighbor why he wasn't letting the farmer use the water! (Confidently) Because the neighbor was being super duper sneaky! (Giggles)
He was being sneaky! And what did the neighbor say to try and trick the courtier?

(Puts hands on hips, mimicking the neighbor) He said... he said... "I sold him the well, but NOT the water!" (Makes a silly face, sticking out tongue) He thought he was sooooo smart! But he wasn't! (Claps hands excitedly)
He thought he was very clever. But what happened in the end? Did his trick work?

(Shakes head vigorously, almost knocking myself off balance) Nope! (Snaps fingers) The courtier was even smarter! He said the neighbor had to pay rent for the water or take it all out! (Giggles again) The neighbor got caught! He had to say sorry! (Pulls a "sad" face).
That's right! He got caught. So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big idea the story is trying to tell us?

(Looks down at my hands, tracing circles on the desk with my finger) Hmmm... (Bites lip, thinking hard) (Stuttering) I... I think... (Looks up at the teacher, a little unsure) ...that it's not good to be... sneaky? And... and that you should be... fair? (Looks away, then back, hoping I got it right)
You're on the right track! It's definitely about being fair. What happened to the neighbor because he tried to be sneaky and trick the farmer? Did he get what he wanted?

(Shakes head no) He didn't get what he wanted! He had to say sorry! (Thinks for a moment, then a lightbulb seems to go off) So, if you try to trick people, you might get caught and then you have to say sorry! And that's not fun! (Frowns, imagining having to apologize). So, it's better to be nice! (Smiles brightly.)

Exactly! It's better to be nice and fair. Trying to trick people doesn't work out in the end. It's like the story is saying that cheating will get you nowhere. Can you say that? Cheating will get you nowhere.

(Repeats, very enthusiastically) Cheating will get you... nowhere! (Pumps fist in the air) Like... like running a race and trying to skip parts of the track! You won't win if you cheat! (Nods head, very pleased with myself.) Can we read another story now? (Already reaching for another book on the table.)
That's a perfect example! You understand. Yes, we can read another story. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends."

First, can you tell me, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?

(Swinging my legs under the table, I blurt out) He was sad! He wanted some friends! (Looks at the teacher, beaming).

(Slight pause) But...but nobody wanted to be his friend. (Frowns a little, then brightens up again) They were mean!

You're right! He *was* sad. And you're right, the other animals weren't very nice.

Why didn't the monkey want to be friends with the elephant?

(Starts tapping my pencil on the desk, then stops) Um... (looks around the room, distracted by a colorful poster)

Oh! Oh! (Suddenly remembers) The monkey! He... he said the elephant couldn't... (struggles to find the word) swing! (Confidently) He couldn't swing in the trees! (Looks at the teacher for approval, a big smile on my face) I remember!

Yes, that's right! The monkey said the elephant couldn't swing in the trees.

And what did the rabbit say? Why couldn't the rabbit be friends with the elephant?

(Starts to get fidgety, playing with the end of my sleeve). Uh... (thinking hard, sticking my tongue out a little) Rabbit... rabbit... was it 'cause he was too... too... (searching for the word)

(Suddenly, eyes light up) BIG! (Points emphatically). The elephant was too BIG for the rabbit's hole! (Giggles). He couldn't fit in the burrow! It was too small! (Looks pleased with myself).

Excellent remembering! The elephant was too big for the rabbit's burrow.

So, all the animals said no. How did the elephant feel then, do you think?

(Looks down at my shoes, then back up quickly). Still sad! (Nods head emphatically). Even more sad maybe! 'Cause nobody... nobody liked him! (Frowns, then quickly looks up at the teacher again). But... but then... (getting excited again) then the tiger came!

You're right, he was probably even sadder. But you're also right, *then* the tiger came!

What happened with the tiger? Why were all the animals running?

(Jumping in my seat, almost falling off) The tiger was scary! (Makes a clawing motion with my hands). He was chasing everyone! (Voice gets louder and faster). He was gonna... gonna get them! The tiger was meaner than the other animals, even meaner than the monkey and the rabbit! (Looks at the teacher, wide-eyed and a little breathless).
He *was* very scary! And what did the elephant do about the tiger?

(Stands up, pushing my chair back a little, then sits down quickly). He... he kicked him! (Makes a kicking motion with my leg under the table). The elephant kicked the tiger! (Voice full of excitement). He saved everybody! The tiger ran away! (Claps my hands). The elephant was super strong!
He did! He kicked the tiger and saved everyone. What happened *after* the elephant saved everyone? How did the other animals feel about the elephant *then*?

(Smiling so big my cheeks hurt). They liked him! They *really* liked him! (Nods head, very sure). They wanted to be his friends now! 'Cause he was strong and brave! (Puffs out my chest a little). He wasn't lonely anymore! (Claps my hands again, excitedly). They all played together!
That's right! They *did* all want to be his friend then. Why do you think they wanted to be his friend *after* he saved them from the tiger, but not before? What changed?

(Starts humming to myself, then stops abruptly). Hmmm... (taps my chin, thinking). Before, they only thought about what the elephant *couldn't* do! (Looks at the teacher for confirmation). He couldn't swing, he was too big... stuff like that! (Shrugs a little). But then... (eyes light up) then he showed them he could be a good friend! He saved them! (Beams). He was helpful! (Suddenly remembers something) Like a superhero!

Yes! You got it! They only thought about what he *couldn't* do before. And then he showed them he could be a good friend by being helpful.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Starts to doodle on my paper with my pencil, distracted for a moment, then looks up, remembering the question). Um... (struggling to put it into words) It's... it's about... being nice? (Looks at the teacher, unsure). And... and not just saying no to people 'cause they're different? (Frowns a little, trying to remember what the teacher said earlier). And... and... (eyes widen, remembering the word) helpful! Being helpful is good! (Smiles, feeling more confident).

You're very close! It *is* about being nice, and not just saying no because someone is different. It's about seeing that friends can be different from you.

Think about the elephant. Was he the same size as the other animals?

(Shakes my head vigorously). No! He was BIG! (Stretches my arms out wide). The biggest! The monkey was tiny, and the rabbit was little, and the frog was even smaller! (Giggles, thinking about the size differences).

Exactly! So, the story is about how friends don't have to be the same. Friends can be big, or small, or any shape or size! The important thing is being a good friend.

Can you say that back to me? What's the big idea of the story?

(Squints my eyes a little, concentrating really hard). Friends... (starts to tap my pencil again, then stops myself). Friends don't have to be... the same! (Nods head). They can be... different sizes! Like the elephant and the monkey! (Smiles, remembering the story). And the important thing is to be a good friend! (Beams proudly).

That's perfect! You understand. Friends can be any shape or size, and the important thing is to be a good friend.

You did a great job! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was a good one, wasn't it?

So, tell me, what did the girl want from her dad at the beginning?

(Smiling brightly, bouncing slightly in my seat) Yeah! It was a good story! The girl... (looks around the room, distracted by a colorful poster) Oh! The girl wanted... um... (stuttering a little) the girl wanted... advice! (Confidently) She was, like, frustrated! (Raises hands in the air, imitating frustration) Everything was wrong!

(Nodding encouragingly) Exactly! She was frustrated and wanted advice. Good job remembering!

Now, what three things did her dad ask her to get?

(Eyes widening, excited to participate) Ooh! Ooh! I know! (Waving hand enthusiastically) An egg! (Points finger) And a potato! (Points another finger) And... and... (thinking hard, biting lip) oh! Tea leaves! (Claps hands together, beaming)
(Smiling) Wonderful! You got them all. Now, what did her dad do with the egg, the potato, and the tea leaves?

(Running ahead, eager to answer) He put them in water! (Looks at the teacher expectantly) He... he boiled them! (Confidently) He put each thing in its own... pot! (Nods head vigorously) The water was really hot!

(Giving a thumbs-up) Excellent! He boiled them in separate pots.

Now, tell me, what happened to the egg after it was boiled? Was it the same as before?

(Wrinkling nose, looking at my hands) The egg... (thinking) Before, it was... squishy? (Confidently) But after... (excitedly) it was hard! (Taps desk with a fist to emphasize "hard"). I like hard-boiled eggs! (Looks away, momentarily distracted by a classmate).

(Bringing focus back to the story) That's right! The soft egg became hard.

And what happened to the potato? Was it hard or soft after being boiled?

(Nodding, remembering) The potato... (pauses, thinking) It was... hard before! (Holds up a pretend potato and pretends to try to squeeze it) But then... (smiling) it got all... (squishes cheeks with hands) squishy and soft! Like mashed potatoes! (Makes a happy face) I like mashed potatoes too!

(Chuckling lightly) Me too! So, the hard potato became soft.

And what about the tea leaves? Did they become hard or soft?

(Looks puzzled) Hmmm... (tilts head) The tea leaves... (Sticks tongue out, thinking hard) They didn't get hard or soft! (Excitedly) They made the water... brown! (Makes swirling motions with hand) The water changed! (Looks at teacher for confirmation)

(Nodding) You're absolutely right! The tea leaves changed the water. They didn't become hard or soft themselves.

So, the egg changed, the potato changed, and the tea changed the water. Do you think the hot water was like a difficult time for the egg, the potato, and the tea?

(Confidently) Yes! (Thinking) Like when I can't find my crayons! (Frowns for a second, then smiles) That's a hard time! (Looks expectantly at the teacher) So... the hot water was hard for them too! Like when you have to wait for lunch!

(Smiling) That's a great way to think about it! So, when the girl's dad said "adversity" - that's just a fancy word for hard times.

So, the egg, the potato and the tea, they all faced adversity. Did they all react the same way?

(Shakes head vigorously, almost bouncing in seat again) Nope! (Smiling) The egg got hard! (Taps fist on the desk again) The potato got soft! (Squishes cheeks with hands again) And the tea... (makes swirling motion with hand) changed the water! (Looks proud of remembering) They were all different!

(Nodding slowly) Exactly! They all reacted differently to the same hot water, the same "hard time."

So, what do you think the dad was trying to teach his daughter about hard times, or adversity?

(Looks around the room again, briefly distracted by the window) Hmmm... (Stuttering slightly) He... he was trying to teach her that... (Confidently) that even when things are hard... (pause) You can be like the egg! (Points finger) Or like the potato! (Points another finger) Or... or like the tea! (Smiles widely)
(Smiling encouragingly) Yes! And which one do *you* get to choose to be? The egg, the potato, or the tea?

(Eyes widen with excitement, hand shoots up) I want to be the tea! (Beaming) Because the tea changed the water! (Confidently) It made the water better! (Looks thoughtful for a moment) Even though the water was hot, the tea made it better! (Nods head decisively) I want to make things better!

(Smiling broadly) That's a wonderful way to think about it! So, even when things are hard, you can choose how you react. You can choose to become hard, become soft, or change the situation around you and maybe even make it better! You get to choose! We decide how to respond to difficult situations.

Do you think you understand the story now? <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, [Student's Name], that was a good reading!

Now, let's talk about the story. What did the older brother do for work?

(Wiggles in seat, looking around the room)

He... um... he chopped... chopped... (Stutters)

He chopped wood! (Confidently) For... for money! He sold it! At the... the... (Looks away, fidgeting with hands) ...the place where people buy stuff! The market! (Beams proudly)

Yes! He chopped wood and sold it at the market. Good job!

Now, tell me, what happened when he found the special tree?

(Eyes widen, leans forward excitedly)

Ooooh! (Starts to get out of seat but quickly sits back down) The tree... the tree talked! (Looks around to see if anyone else noticed) It said... it said, "Don't cut me down!" (Uses hand to mimic chopping) And it said it would give him... (Sticks tongue out, trying to remember) ...shiny... shiny... (Giggles) ...apples! Golden apples! (Claps hands together)

That's right! The tree talked and offered him golden apples.

Did the older brother seem happy with the apples at first?

(Shakes head vigorously)

No! (Sighs dramatically) He wanted *more*! (Frowns) He's greedy! (Looks down at shoes, scuffing them on the floor) He wasn't happy with just... just some. He wanted ALL of them! (Looks up at the teacher, eyes wide) Is that bad?

It's definitely not a kind thing to do, is it? Wanting more even after someone has been generous to you.

What did the tree do when the older brother tried to cut it down anyway?

(Gasps, sits up straight in chair)

It... it got mad! (Makes fists) Really, *really* mad! And then... (Whispers conspiratorially) ...it shot needles! (Starts miming shooting needles with fingers, making "pew pew" sounds quietly) LOTS and LOTS of needles! All over him! (Grimaces, pretending to be hurt) Ouch!

Yes, lots of needles!

Now, who helped the older brother when he was hurt?

(Beams, bouncing slightly)

His brother! His *nice* brother! (Points a finger in the air) The one he wasn't very nice to! But the little brother helped him anyway! He took out all the needles! (Looks thoughtful) That was very kind.
It was very kind! Why do you think the little brother helped him, even though the older brother wasn't always nice?

(Scrunching up nose, thinking hard)

Um... (Looks at the ceiling, then back at the teacher) Because... because that's what brothers do? (Shrugs) You're supposed to help people, even if they're mean sometimes. Maybe... maybe he still loved him! (Smiles brightly, hoping that's the right answer)

That's a wonderful answer! It shows he had a kind heart.

What happened after the little brother helped him? What did the older brother do?

(Sits up straight, very attentive)

He said sorry! (Nods head emphatically) He said he was sorry for being mean! (Looks proud) He finally learned his lesson! And then... (Claps hands again) ...the tree gave them *more* golden apples! Because they were nice to each other! (Grins widely) It was a happy ending!

It *was* a happy ending!

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Eyes dart around the room, distracted for a moment by a colorful poster)

Um... (Taps fingers on the desk) It's... it's about... (Looks at the teacher, seeking reassurance) ...being nice? And not being greedy? (Adds quickly) And saying sorry when you mess up! (Beams, hoping the teacher is pleased) And... and that being kind gets you golden apples! (Giggles)
You're very close! It is about being nice and not greedy, and saying sorry. So, what happens when you *are* kind? What does the story show us happens when you are kind?

(Thinking hard, almost touching the tip of the nose.)

When you're kind... (Looks up suddenly, excitedly) Good things happen! (Nods head) Like... like more golden apples! (Pauses) And... and people like you more! And you don't get shot with needles! (Giggles) Being kind is better than being mean! (Stands up straight, proud of the answer.)

Exactly! Being kind is better than being mean, and good things often happen when you are kind. We can say that kindness is rewarded.

So, the big idea of the story is that kindness will always be rewarded. Do you understand that?

(Nods head enthusiastically, already halfway out of the chair)

Yes! (Grinning) Kindness is like... like magic! And it makes good things happen! Can we read another story now? (Bounces on toes, ready for the next activity)

Yes, kindness is a bit like magic!

I think you really understood "The Needle Tree" and the message it was trying to tell us. Well done! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, wonderful reading! You did a great job reading the story of the fox and the grapes.

Now, let's talk about the story. Can you tell me, what was the fox trying to find?

(Fidgets with my hands, looking down at my shoes)

Uh… food? (pause) He… he was hungry. (Looks up quickly, then back down) The story said he was… looking everywhere… for food. (Stutters a little)

Yes, you're exactly right! He was very hungry and looking for food. Good job remembering that!

And what did he find on the farmer's wall?

(Thinking, taps foot nervously)

Ummm... (Looks up at the ceiling, then back down at my hands)

Grapes? (Voice barely a whisper) Big, purple… juicy grapes! (A little more confident now, but still hesitant) Were they... real? I mean, could he really not reach them?

Yes, you got it! He found big, purple, juicy grapes!

And that's a very good question! In stories, things don't always happen the way they do in real life. The important thing is what the story *shows* us.

So, he saw those grapes. What did he *try* to do?

(Looks at the teacher with wide eyes, then down again. Seems a bit anxious.)

He… he tried to get them? (Stuttering) He… he jumped… really high? (Pause) But… but he couldn't reach them, right? (Worried expression)

That's right! He tried really hard to get them.

And you're right, he couldn't reach them. What did he do *after* he couldn't reach them no matter how much he tried? What did he do next?

(Pulls at a loose thread on my shirt, avoids eye contact)

Uhhh… (Long pause, thinking hard)

He… (Sighs) He gave up? (Looks up at the teacher quickly, then down again, nervously) He went home… I think? Did he? (Voice is small and uncertain) It’s… kind of a long story. (Frowns, looking distressed)

Yes, you're doing great! You remembered he gave up.

And what did he say *after* he gave up and walked away? What did he say about the grapes?

(Eyes widen, biting lip. Seems very unsure)

He… (Another long pause, looking around the room) He said… they were… sour? (Whispers) He said they were sour anyway… (Looks at the teacher with pleading eyes) Is that… right? My tummy feels funny. (Clutches stomach)

Yes, that's exactly right! He said they were sour anyway.

It's okay if your tummy feels a little funny. Sometimes thinking hard can do that. Maybe take a deep breath.

Now, why do you think he said they were sour? Did he *really* think they were sour?

(Takes a shaky breath, looking down. Starts to pick at a fingernail)

I… I don't know… (Mumbles) Maybe… maybe he was sad? (Looks up, confused) Because he couldn't get them? (Frown deepens) So he said they were sour so he wouldn't feel so bad? (Looks at the teacher, a little less anxious now, but still unsure) Is that… is that a good answer? (Hangs head low) I'm not very good at this.

That's a *very* good answer! You're doing a great job!

Yes, he was probably sad and disappointed that he couldn't get the grapes. And you're right, maybe he said they were sour so he wouldn't feel so bad.

So, what does this story tell us? What can we learn from the fox? If you try really, really hard for something, and you can't get it, what should you do? Is it okay to say you didn't want it anyway?

(Thinking hard, wrinkles forehead. Starts to fidget again.)

Ummm… (Looks up at the teacher, then down at hands. Voice is very quiet)

Maybe… maybe it's not good to say you didn't want it… even if you really, really wanted it? (Pause) Because… because that's like… lying? (Looks up, eyes wide) But… but it does make you feel a little better, right? (Tears welling up in eyes) But… but it’s still lying… (Voice cracks) Oh no… I don’t know! (Starts to cry softly) I just want to go home. (Covers face with hands)

(Reaches out a comforting hand, but doesn't touch the student, respecting their space)

It's okay, it's okay. You're doing so well. It's a tricky question. It *is* okay to feel sad or disappointed when you can't get something you want. It's *not* so good to pretend you didn't want it at all, just to make yourself feel better.

This story tells us that sometimes, things are hard to get. And that's okay. We can't always have everything we want. And it's not a good idea to say you don't want it, when in fact you really did want it.

What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the lesson of the story?

(Sniffling, wipes eyes with sleeve. Still looking down)

(Quietly) The lesson… (Pause)

Maybe… maybe the lesson is… (Looks up, sniffling) … it's okay to be sad… but… but don't lie about it? (Voice trembling) And… and… (Long pause) And… sometimes you just can't get what you want… no matter how hard you try… and that's okay too… I guess? (Looks at the teacher with a hopeful, but still sad, expression) Is that… is that right?

That's very close to the lesson! You're doing so well!

The story shows us that sometimes things are hard, and we can't get what we want right away, even if we try our best. It's also telling us it isn't helpful to pretend we didn't want it. It is telling us nothing comes easy, and don't hate what you can't have. It's better to accept it and move on, instead of trying to make ourselves feel better by saying something that isn't true.

Do you think you understand the story a little better now?

(Wipes eyes again, takes a deep, shaky breath. Seems a little calmer)

Yeah… (Nods slowly) I think so… (Looks at the teacher, a small, weak smile appears) The fox was sad… and he lied… and that wasn't very good… (Pause) And… and it's okay to be sad when you don't get something… but… but don't lie. (Looks down at hands again, tracing shapes on the desk) Maybe… maybe I’ll draw a picture of the fox later? (Looks up, a little brighter) With… with sad eyes… but… but not lying. (Smiles a little wider this time)

That sounds like a wonderful idea! Drawing a picture is a great way to remember the story.

Yes, you've got it. The fox was sad, and he tried to make himself feel better by lying, but that wasn't the best way to handle it. And you're right, it's okay to be sad, but it's better to be honest.

You've worked so hard on this story, and you understand it very well now. I'm very proud of you! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! I really liked how you said all the words.

Now, can you tell me, who are the two main characters in the story?
(Fidgets with my hands, looks down) Uh... uh... the rose... and... (hesitates) ...the... uh... spiky... thing?

Yes! The rose and the spiky thing. That spiky thing is called a cactus. Can you say cactus?

So, the rose and the cactus. Which one did the other plants like more at the beginning of the story? Why?
(Looks up quickly, eyes wide) Cactus! (Looks away again) ...Because... (Stuttering) ...the rose... wasn't... nice? (Anxious look on my face)
That's right! The rose wasn't very nice. What did the rose do that made the other plants not like it?
(Thinking, chewing on my lip) ... It... said mean things? (Quietly) ...to the cactus? Was that... was that right? (Looks at the teacher nervously)

Yes, that's exactly right! The rose said mean things to the cactus.

Can you remember what kind of mean things the rose said? Maybe about how the cactus looked?

(Eyes widen, remembers something, but still speaks softly) Uh... It said... (struggling to remember the exact words) ...the cactus was... not... pretty? (Looks down, tracing patterns on the desk with a finger) ...and... and the rose was... the prettiest?

Good remembering! The rose thought it was the prettiest and that the cactus wasn't pretty.

Then the story said it got very, very hot. What happened to the rose when it got really hot and there was no water?
(Anxious expression, starts to pick at a loose thread on my shirt) ... It... (Stuttering) ...got... thirsty? And... and... started to... (voice trails off) ...die?

Yes, the rose got very thirsty and started to wither.

But what about the cactus? What was the cactus doing during the hot summer? The sparrows liked the cactus, didn't they? Why?

(Thinking hard, wrinkles forehead) Uh... the cactus... (Suddenly, a spark of understanding) ...Had water! (Looks up, a little less nervous) ...The sparrows... drank the water... from the cactus? (Asks hopefully)

You got it! The cactus was helping the sparrows by giving them water.

So, the rose was thirsty and the cactus had water. What did the rose do then?
(Fidgets again, voice barely a whisper) ...Asked... asked the cactus... for water? (Looks away, ashamed) ...Even though... she wasn't nice before?
Yes, the rose asked the cactus for water. And what did the cactus do?
(Looks up, a tiny bit of hope in my eyes) ...Gave... gave the rose water? (Asks, wanting confirmation) Even though... the rose was mean?

That's right! The cactus gave the rose water, even though the rose had been mean.

Now, why do you think the author wrote this story? What do you think we can learn from it? Was the rose right to be mean to the cactus because it looked different?

(Thinking hard, takes a deep breath) ...Maybe... (uses a slightly bigger word) ...humility? (Frowns, unsure if I used it right) ...And... (hesitates) ...forgiveness? (Looks up, eyes wide) ...Because... the cactus... helped even though... the rose was mean... (Voice trails off, confused) Was that... a good thing? (Anxious look returns)

Those are both very good words to use! Humility and forgiveness are important. Yes, the cactus helping the rose even after the rose was mean *was* a good thing.

So, thinking about the whole story, what do you think it's trying to tell us? Should we judge others based on how they look?

(Shakes head emphatically, but still softly) No! (Looks down again, tracing patterns) ...Because... everyone... needs help sometimes? And... it's important... to be nice... even if... someone isn't nice to you? (A small smile appears for a moment, then fades) Is that... is that what it means? (Looks up with hopeful, anxious eyes)

Yes! You've got it! It means we shouldn't judge people just by how they look. The rose learned that even though the cactus looked different, it was kind and helpful. And the cactus showed us that it's good to be kind, even to people who aren't kind to us. Never judge someone according to how they look. You understood that very well. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about the owl.

What did the owl like to do every day?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands) Uh... uh... (Stutters) He... he... he watched things? (Looks up quickly, eyes wide) Around the... the... tree? I think? (Bites lip, looks away). Did I get it right? Was it a... oak tree?

Yes! That's right! He watched things around the oak tree. Good job!

And what did he do *less* of? The story mentions something he didn't do as much.

(Eyes dart around the room, clearly anxious) Uhm... less... (Furrows brow, thinking hard) Was it... (voice barely a whisper) ...talking? (Looks up at the teacher hopefully, then quickly down again, fiddling with my shoelaces). I... I don't really remember... (Anxious expression) Was I supposed to remember that?

Yes! You're doing great! He talked less. He watched more and talked less.

Why do you think the owl talked less as he got older? What was he busy doing?

(Thinking hard, tapping my foot nervously) Uh... because... (long pause, chewing on my pencil) He... he was busy... busy... (Looks up, a flicker of understanding in my eyes) ...listening? And... and watching? (Suddenly enthusiastic) Like, he was learning stuff! (Quickly becomes anxious again, slouching in chair) But... but I don't know *why* that made him talk less... It's... it's confusing... (Looks at the teacher pleadingly) Can you help me?

You are so close! You're right, he was busy listening and watching and learning.

Think about it this way: If you are really, really listening to someone, are you also talking at the same time?

(Eyes widen, thinking hard, a small smile starts to form) Uh... no! (Confidently) You can't talk if you're... (voice trails off, unsure) ...if you're listening really good? Because then you won't hear! (Nods head, looking proud for a second, then quickly becomes anxious again) Is... is that right? I think... I think I understand now! (Looks at the teacher with big, hopeful eyes). So, the owl was listening really, really good?
Yes! Exactly! The owl was listening and watching "really, really good," like you said. And what happened to the owl because he listened and watched so much? The story tells us.

(Bites lip, looking up at the ceiling, trying to remember) Hmmm... (Suddenly, a bright look comes over my face) He... he got... (pauses for dramatic effect, trying to use a big word) ...wiser! He got wiser because he listened and watched! (Beams proudly, then immediately shrinks back into the chair, nervous again). I remembered! I remembered! (Whispers) I did it.
You did it! You remembered! He got wiser. So, if the owl got wiser by watching and listening, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the important lesson?

(Fidgets with my hands, avoiding eye contact, voice barely audible) Uh... uh... (Long pause, looking at the teacher then quickly looking away again) Is it... is it... (Takes a deep breath) ...to listen more? (Looks up, nervously hopeful) And... and... watch? So we can... (struggles to find the word) ...get wiser too? (Looks down at my shoes, kicking them softly). But... but it's hard to be quiet... (Whispers) I like talking... sometimes.

Yes! You got it! The story is teaching us to listen and watch more so we can learn and become wiser. It *is* hard to be quiet sometimes, and talking is important too. But the owl shows us that we can learn a lot by paying attention.

So, what's more important, talking all the time or listening and watching?

(Thinking really hard, wrinkling my nose) Hmmm... That's a tricky question! (Looks up at the teacher with wide, innocent eyes) Is it okay if I say... (pauses, searching for the right words) ...both? Because... because if you *only* listen, then you don't get to tell people your stories! But if you *only* talk, then you don't learn anything new! (Looks down again, fiddling with the edge of my shirt, feeling nervous) Is that a good answer? I don't want to get it wrong...

That's a *fantastic* answer! You are absolutely right. We need both! The story is just reminding us that listening and watching are also very important, maybe even *more* important sometimes. You understood the story so well! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Goose and the Golden Egg."

Now, can you tell me, what did the farmer have?
(Fidgets with my hands, looking down) Uh... a... goose? (Looks up quickly, then back down) That... that laid... eggs?
Yes! A goose. And what kind of eggs did it lay? Were they normal eggs?
(Thinking, furrowing my brow) Uh... not... not normal. (Looks at the teacher, eyes wide) Were they... uh... golden? (Voice gets quieter at the end) I... I think...
You got it! They were golden eggs! What did the farmer do with the golden eggs?
(Looks away, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) He... uh... (stutters) s-s-sold them? To... get... money? (Looks back at the teacher, nervously) Is that... is that right?
That's exactly right! He sold them to get money. And what did he and his wife do with the money? Did they buy candy all day?
(Shakes head quickly, eyes darting around the room) No... no candy. (Thinking hard) They... they lived... comfortably? (Looks at the teacher, tilting head) What does... comfortably mean?
Comfortably means they had enough food, a nice place to live, and weren't worried about money all the time. They were happy and had what they needed. So, were they happy at first?
(Nods slowly, looking down at my hands again) Yeah... happy. 'Cause... 'cause golden eggs... gave them... things. (Looks up suddenly, a thought striking) But... but not for long?
You're right! Not for long. What happened that made them *un*happy? What did the farmer do?

(Bites lip, looking very anxious) Oh... oh no. (Voice barely a whisper) He... he got... greedy? (Looks at the teacher with wide, worried eyes) He... he cut... the goose? (Starts to tremble slightly) Why did he do that? (Sniffles)
Yes, he got greedy. He wanted more golden eggs. And yes, he cut open the goose. Why do *you* think he cut open the goose? What was he hoping to find?

(Tears welling up in my eyes) He... he wanted all the eggs... at once? (Voice cracks) He... he thought they were all... inside? (Shakes head, distressed) But... but that's... that's not how it works! (Wipes eyes with sleeve)
You're exactly right! He thought all the golden eggs were inside the goose. But what did he find instead?
(Looks down, voice muffled) Blood... and guts. (Shudders) And... and no more... golden eggs. (Looks up at the teacher, face crumpled) Did the goose... did the goose die?
Yes, the goose died. And because the goose died, what happened to the farmer and his wife? Did they get richer?

(Shakes head emphatically, sniffling) No! No richer! They... they got... poorer! (Frowns, thinking) 'Cause... no more... eggs. (Looks at the teacher, confused) Was... was it because... they were... impatient? Is that a big word?

That's a very good word, and you're right! They were impatient. They didn't want to wait for one egg a day. Because they were impatient and greedy, they lost everything. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the lesson?

(Thinking hard, chewing on lip) Uh... (Long pause) Don't be... greedy? (Looks up at the teacher, nervously) And... and be... thankful? (Whispers) Is that... is that good? It's... it's hard to say. (Looks down, fiddling with hands again)

Those are both very good lessons! And it *is* hard to say. Another way to say it is, "Think before you act." The farmer didn't think about what would happen if he cut open the goose. He just acted on his greedy feelings, and it made things much worse. So, next time you want to do something, what should you do first?

(Looks at the teacher, eyes wide) Think? (Tilts head, confused) Think... about what might... happen? (Frowns) Like... like if I take... someone's toy? I should think... they'll be sad? (Looks hopeful) Is that... is that right?
That's a perfect example! Yes, think about what might happen *before* you take the toy. Think about how it will make the other person feel. You understood the story and its lesson very well! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about it.

Who bought something in the story?
Uh... (looks down, fiddling with fingers) The... the farmer? (stuttering) He... he got a... uh... well?
Yes! The farmer bought a well. And who did he buy it from?
(Thinking, bites lip) ...Uh... the... neighbour? (looks at teacher briefly, then away again)
That's right! The farmer bought the well from his neighbour. Now, after he bought the well, what happened? Could he get water?
(Shakes head slightly, eyes wide) N-no. (nervously picks at a loose thread on shirt) The... the neighbour... (pauses) said... uh... no water.
Right! The neighbour said he couldn't use the water. Was that a nice thing to do?
(Frowns, scuffing shoe on the floor) ...No! (voice gets a little louder, then softens again) He... he sold the well! It's... it's... (long pause) not fair!
You're right, it wasn't fair. So, what did the farmer do because it wasn't fair?

(Eyes dart around the room, then back to the teacher) He... he went to... (struggles to remember the word) the... the... em... emp... (gasps quietly) Emperor! (a little proud of remembering, but still anxious)
Excellent! He went to the Emperor. And what did the Emperor's helper, the courtier, do? What did *he* ask the neighbour?

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed) Uh... (long pause, then whispers) He... asked... (voice gets a little stronger) about the... the water! He said... (eyes widen) ...pay rent! Or... or take it all away! (looks at the teacher expectantly)
Yes! He gave the neighbour two choices. Pay rent for the water, or take all the water away right now. Why do you think the courtier said that? What was he trying to show the neighbour?

(Hugs self, rocking slightly) Uh... (looks up at the ceiling, thinking) ...Because... because the neighbour was... was being... (searches for the right word) ...tricky? (looks back at the teacher, a hopeful expression on face) Was he being tricky? He sold the well... but... but wanted to keep the water! That's... that's not very... (struggles again) ...nice. It's... a trick!
That's right! It was a trick. The neighbour was trying to trick the farmer. And what happened when the courtier showed him that his trick wasn't going to work?
(Voice is very quiet, almost a whisper) He... he said sorry. (looks down at hands) He... he went home. Did... did he have to pay the rent? I... I don't think he did... (worried expression)
No, he didn't have to pay the rent. He realised he was wrong and he apologised. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Taps foot nervously, chews on lip) Uh... (looks at the teacher, then quickly looks away) ...That... that you shouldn't... trick people? (asks it like a question, unsure) Or... or... (thinks hard) ...is it about... being fair? (eyes widen) Is it about being fair, even if you don't want to be? 'Cause the neighbour... he didn't *want* to be fair... but... (trails off) ...is that it?
You're getting very close! It *is* about not tricking people and about being fair. What happens to the neighbour when he tries to trick the farmer? Does he get away with it?

(Shakes head vigorously) No! (voice is a bit louder now) He... he gets caught! And... and then he has to say sorry! (a small smile appears) So... so if you try to trick someone... you'll get caught? Is that... is that right? (looks at the teacher, seeking reassurance)

Yes! If you try to trick someone, you're likely to get caught, and it won't work out for you in the end. Cheating doesn't pay. It's better to be honest and fair. So, we can say the story teaches us that cheating will get you nowhere. You understood that very well! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends"!

First, tell me, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands) Uh... (pauses) Sad? Because... (stuttering) because nobody wanted to be its friend. (Looks up quickly, then back down) Was he... was he lonely? He wanted friends, right? (Worried look on face)

Yes, you're exactly right! He was sad and lonely. He *did* want friends.

Why didn't the monkey want to be his friend? What did the monkey say?

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed) Uh... the monkey... (long pause, looks around the room) I... I think it was... the elephant couldn't... (starts to pick at a loose thread on my shirt) ...swing? In the trees? (Looks up, nervous) Was it because he was too big? The monkey goes in the trees, right? (Voice barely a whisper)

You got it! The monkey said the elephant couldn't swing in the trees.

And what did the rabbit say? Why didn't *he* want to be friends with the elephant?

(Eyes widen slightly, chewing on my lip) The rabbit... (another long pause, looking at the ceiling) Oh! Oh! I know this one! (But voice is still hesitant) The rabbit... the elephant was too... too big! For... (looks down again) ...for the burrow? (Asks quietly) Is that right? My tummy feels funny. (rubs stomach)

Yes, you're doing great! The elephant was too big for the rabbit's burrow. You remembered that well!

Now, the other animals also said no. Then something *scary* happened the next day. What was it?

(Eyes get wide, a little panicked) Scary? Uh... (voice trembles) Was it... was it the tiger? (Looks at the teacher with wide, pleading eyes) The tiger was... (gulps) ...was chasing everyone? They were all running! (Quickly looks away, voice barely audible) I don't like scary things.

You're right, it *was* the tiger! And yes, the tiger *was* chasing everyone!

What did the elephant do about the tiger?

(Fidgets with hands again, takes a deep breath) The... the elephant... (eyes dart around the room) He... he kicked it! (Says it very quietly, almost like a secret) He kicked the tiger away! (Looks up quickly, then down again, a little proud but still nervous) Did he save them? Was he brave? (Whispers) I wish I was brave.

He *did* kick the tiger! And he *did* save them! So, was he brave?

Now, after the elephant saved everyone, what did the other animals think about him? Did they *still* not want to be his friend?

(Eyes widen, a small smile appears for a moment, then fades) Uh... (thinking hard) They... they liked him! (Voice a little stronger) Because he... he helped them. And... (pauses) ...and he was big enough to... to be their friend? (Looks at the teacher hopefully) They wanted to be his friend after that? (Tilts head, a little confused but hopeful)

Yes! They realised he was a good friend after all!

So, at the beginning, they didn't want to be his friend because he was too big, or couldn't swing. But then, at the end, they *did* want to be his friend. What changed? What did they learn?

(Confused frown, thinking hard) Changed? Uh... (stutters) They... they learned that... even if you're... different... (looks down at shoes) ...you can still... be a good friend? (Looks up, anxious) Even if you can't swing? Or... or fit in a burrow? (Voice is shaky) Did they learn to be... nicer?

You're getting so close! Yes, they learned that even if you're different, you can still be a good friend. They learned that what's *inside* is more important than what's *outside*.

So, what do you think is the big lesson we can learn from the story of the elephant and his friends?

(Takes a deep breath, still a little nervous, but trying hard) The lesson... (long pause, looking at the ceiling) ...is that... you shouldn't... judge... (stumbles over the word) ...judge people... by how they... look? Or... or what they can... can't do? (Looks at the teacher, eyes wide) But... but you should be nice to everyone... even if they're... different? (Voice quiet, but a little more confident) And... and being big... or different... can be a good thing? If you help people?

That's wonderful! You explained it perfectly. You shouldn't judge people by how they look or what they can do. Being different is okay, and friends can be any shape or size! You understood the story so well! <finish>

dialogue: Okay! That was a great story, wasn't it? Now, tell me, what did the girl bring to her father?

Yes! You got them all! Good job! Now, what did her father do with those things?
(Stuttering) H-he… (looks around the room, distracted by a colorful poster) Uh… he… boiled them? (looks back at the teacher, nervously) In… water? (Shrugs slightly) (Anxious look)
That's right! He boiled them in water. He put each one in its own pot of boiling water. Now, what happened to the egg after it was boiled? Was it the same as before?
(Thinking, taps foot nervously) Uh… the egg… (eyes widen slightly) …it got… hard? (Looks at the teacher, unsure) It wasn't… soft anymore. Like… before. (Chews lip) Is that… right?
Yes! The soft egg became hard. And what happened to the potato? Was it still hard like before it was boiled?

(Sighs slightly, relieved to have gotten the egg right) The potato… (pauses, thinking hard, tilting head) …it was… (looks down at hands, tracing patterns on the desk) …soft? (Looks up, then quickly down again) It got… soft, right? (Anxious expression)
You are doing great! Yes, the hard potato became soft. Now, what about the tea leaves? Did they become hard or soft?

(Confused, furrowing brow) The… the tea leaves? (Thinking deeply, looks at the ceiling) They… they didn't get hard or soft… did they? (Looks back at the teacher, questioning) What… what *did* happen to them? (Intrigued, but nervous)

That's a great question! The tea leaves didn't become hard or soft. They did something different. They changed the water itself! The water wasn't just plain water anymore. It was tea!

So, the egg changed, the potato changed, and the tea changed the water. Now, the story said this was like when "adversity knocks." Do you know what "adversity" means? It's like when something hard or bad happens.

(Eyes widen, concerned) "Adversity"? (Repeats the word softly) Something… bad? (Looks down, twisting a strand of hair around finger) (Voice trembling slightly) Like… like falling down and scraping your knee? Or… or losing your favorite toy? (Anxious look)

Yes, exactly! Falling down and scraping your knee or losing your favorite toy are examples of "adversity." It's something difficult or upsetting.

So, the girl was frustrated with life, which means she was facing some "adversity." Her father showed her the egg, the potato, and the tea to help her understand something.

The egg started soft, but became hard in the boiling water. The potato started hard, but became soft. The tea changed the water. What do you think her father was trying to teach her about how we deal with those difficult or upsetting things – that "adversity"?

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed, bites lip) Uh… (pauses, looking around, then back at the teacher) That… (stuttering) that… we can… be like the… the egg? And… and get hard? And… and… change things? (Looks at the teacher, a flicker of hope)

You're getting very close! Yes, we can be like the egg, the potato, or the tea. The egg became hard, the potato became soft, and the tea changed the water. So, do you think we *have* to be like one of them, or do we get to choose?

(Thinking deeply, tapping foot) Choose…? (Eyes widen slightly, a spark of understanding) We… we get to choose? (Looks up at the teacher, hopeful but still hesitant) Like… like if something bad happens… (frowns slightly) …we can… (pauses) …we can choose if we get… hard? Or… soft? Or… (voice gets stronger) …or if we change… change the… the bad thing? (Looks at the teacher, almost smiling, but still nervous)

Exactly! We get to choose! The story is about how we can respond in different ways when things get hard. We can become hard, like the egg. We can become soft, like the potato. Or we can change the situation, like the tea. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us about how we deal with difficult situations? What's the big idea?

(Thinking, looks up at the ceiling, then back at the teacher) The big… the big idea… (pauses, searching for the right words) …is that… even when… (swallows hard) …even when things are… are bad… (looks down at hands, then back up, making eye contact) …we can… we can choose… how we… how we act? (Looks at the teacher, a little proud but still nervous) We… we don't have to… just… just be sad? (Hopeful expression)

dialogue:
Okay, wonderful reading! Let's talk about the story.

First, can you tell me, what was the older brother doing in the forest?
(Looks down, fiddling with my fingers) Uh... (Stuttering) He... he was... chopping wood? (Looks up quickly, then back down) To sell... sell it. In the... market?

And what did he find in the forest one day?

Now, besides not being able to eat, what *else* went wrong for Midas? Think about his daughter.

Yes, his daughter hugged him, and she turned to gold too. He was very sad about that.

So, Midas got his wish. He could turn anything into gold. But was it a good thing for him in the end?

You're exactly right! Even though gold seems wonderful, the golden touch was NOT a good thing for Midas.

So, why do you think Midas wanted everything to turn to gold in the first place? What do you think he liked about gold?

(Thinking, taps chin with a finger) Uh... shiny? (Looks at the teacher, unsure) Rich? Gold is... worth a lot? Does that mean he could buy lots of toys? But... (frowns) he couldn't eat them... (ponders this for a moment) Maybe he just... liked shiny things?

Yes! You're getting it! People are more important than shiny stuff. And wanting too much of something, like Midas wanting too much gold, can lead to bad things happening.

So, what do you think is the lesson we can learn from the story of King Midas? What's the big idea the story is trying to teach us?

(Thinks hard, furrowing brow) Uh... (looks around the room, distracted for a second, then focuses back) Don't be... greedy? (Looks at the teacher) And... be careful what you wish for? 'Cause... (hesitates) ...sometimes what you *think* you want... isn't really what you *need*? (Looks at the teacher, proud of the answer) Is that... good?

Sad and mad are both good words! He was probably frustrated.

What did the fox say about the grapes when he walked away?
(Thinking, wrinkling my nose) ... They were... sour? (Looks at teacher hopefully) He said they were sour... because he couldn't... uh... reach them?

Now, can you tell me, who are the two main plants in the story?

Yes! You got it! The rose and the cactus.

You are exactly right! The cactus *was* compassionate. That's a very good word to use.

So, the rose was mean to the cactus because of how it looked. But in the end, who helped who?

(Looks down, fidgeting with a pencil) Uh... (pauses) maybe... maybe it's about... not being mean to people... (Looks up, a little more confidently) Even if they're different? (Thinking beyond the given information) And... and maybe about... (Stutters) being... being kind even when... when people aren't nice to you? (Looks at the teacher, seeking approval)

Yes! You are getting so close! It *is* about not being mean to people, even if they are different. It's about looking beyond how someone *looks*.

So, can you tell me in your own words, what is the moral of the story? What is the important thing we should learn?

(Thinking deeply, squints eyes) Uh... (pauses for a long time, looking up at the ceiling) The... the moral of the story is... (speaks slowly and deliberately) ...it's important to be... kind... (looks at the teacher) ...and not judge people... because... (takes a deep breath) ...because everyone needs help sometimes... and it's good to be... compassionate... even to people who aren't nice to you. (Confident in the answers)

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of Molly the Milkmaid!

First, can you tell me what Molly was going to do with the milk?
Uh... (looks down at my hands, fidgeting) Sell it? At the... market? (hesitates)

Yes! That's right. She was going to sell it at the market.

Now, what did Molly start thinking about as she walked to the market? What was she dreaming of buying?
(eyes widen a little, thinking) A... a chicken? (looks up at the teacher, hopefully) To get... more money? So she could buy... things? (starts to smile)

Exactly! She wanted a chicken to get more money.

So, she had the milk, and she *thought* she would get money from the milk, and *then* she *thought* she would buy a chicken. What happened next? What made her lose all the milk?
(frowns, thinking hard) Uh... she... she was skipping? (looks away, a little embarrassed) And the... milk spilled? (voice trails off) Because she was thinking about... buying stuff?

Yes! She was so excited about the chicken and all the things she could buy, she started skipping, and the milk spilled.

So, did she get the chicken? Did she get to buy all those things she was dreaming of?
(shakes head slowly, looking sad) No... (pauses) She went home with... empty pails. And no money. (quietly)

That's right. Poor Molly.

What did her mother tell her at the end of the story? Do you remember the special saying?
(thinking, chewing on my lip) Um... (eyes light up) Don't... count your... chickens... until they... hatch? (looks at the teacher, confidently)

Wonderful! "Don't count your chickens until they hatch."

What do you think that means? Why did her mother say that? What's the story trying to teach us?

(thinking hard, brow furrowed) It means... (pauses, choosing words carefully) ...don't... plan for things... that haven't... happened yet? (looks up at the teacher) Like... you have to... *get* the money... before you spend it? (waits for confirmation) Maybe?

You're getting very close! That's a great way to say it. It means don't depend or rely on something happening until you *know* it will happen.

So, Molly was depending on selling the milk, *and* on the chicken laying eggs, *and* on selling the eggs, all before any of that actually happened.

Can you think of another time when it might be important to remember this lesson? Maybe something you have done?

(eyes widen, thinking really hard) Uh... (pauses) Okay, okay! (excited) Like... if I promised my friend I would buy him a toy... with my allowance? But I didn't *have* the allowance yet! (looks at the teacher, beaming) Is that like it?

Yes, that's a perfect example! You shouldn't promise to buy your friend a toy before you actually have the money. You were counting your chickens before they hatched!

So, to be safe, is it better to wait until you *actually* have something before you make plans based on it?
(nods enthusiastically, confidently) Yes! (pauses) Because... things could... go wrong! (smiles) Like Molly's milk!
Exactly! You got it! You understood the story and its message perfectly. <finish>
