Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about the owl.

What did the owl like to do every day?

(Looks down at my hands, fiddling with my fingers)

Uh… (pauses) …see things? (Looks up quickly at the teacher, then back down) Around the tree… I think.

Yes! He liked to see things around the tree. Good job!

Did he only see things? What else did the owl do? The story tells us.

(Thinking, tapping my foot a little bit)

…Uh… (looks up at the ceiling for a moment) …hear… things? People talking? (Eyes widen a little) Did he hear stories too? (Confidently) Yes, he heard stories!

Excellent! He saw things *and* he heard things, especially stories! So, the owl was watching and listening.

Now, did the owl talk a lot? What does the story say?

(Hesitates, looks at the book, then back at the teacher)

…No? (Shrugs a little) Less… he speaked less. (Confidently) The more he saw, the less he talked! Why is that? (Tilts head, curious)

That's a very good question! You're thinking hard!

Why do you think the owl talked less the more he saw and heard? What was happening to him as he watched and listened? Think about what the story says he became.

(Looks down, drawing circles on the carpet with my shoe)

…Uh… (Quietly) He was… getting… (Eyes light up) Wise! He became wise! Because he saw and heard so much! (Confidently) He learned things!
Yes! He became wise! And how did he become wise? Was it by talking all the time, or by watching and listening?

(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip a little)

…Watching and… (Pauses) …listening! (Looks up at the teacher, a big question in my eyes) Does that mean if I listen more I'll be wise too? Like the owl?

That's exactly right! You've got it! The owl became wise by watching and listening.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story? It's okay if you're not sure.

(Looks down again, thinking. Frowns a little.)

…Uh… It’s… (Looks up, a little unsure) …important to listen? And… and watch? (Confidently) Because you learn things when you do! And… and you get wise! (Beams at the teacher) Is that it?

Yes, that's a very good way to put it! It's important to listen and watch because you learn and become wise.

So, if you were going to tell someone the lesson of the story, what would you say? Maybe something like... talk less, and...?

(Thinks for a moment, then claps my hands together)

Talk less… (Pauses) …and listen more! (Beams proudly) Because then you get super wise! Just like the owl! Can we read another story now? Maybe one about a talking animal?
You got it! Talk less and listen more! That's the wise old owl's secret! You understood the story very well. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! It was a little sad, wasn't it?

First, tell me, who are the characters in our story?

(Looks down, fidgeting with a crayon)

Uh... (pause) The... the farmer... and the... goose? And... uh... the farmer's wife. (Looks up quickly, then back down)

That's right! Good job! The farmer, the goose, and the farmer's wife.

What did the goose give the farmer every day?

(Thinking, chewing on lip)

A... a... (stuttering) golden... egg? (Looks at teacher hopefully)

Yes! A golden egg!

And what did the farmer do with the golden egg?

(Looks away, tracing a line on the desk with a finger)

He... (pause) sold it?
Exactly! He sold it. And what happened because he sold the golden egg? Did they have money or were they poor?

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed)

They... had... (pause) money? (Looks up with a questioning expression)

Yes, they had money! They were comfortable. They had enough.

But then, what did the farmer want? Did he want more eggs or less eggs?

(Eyes widen slightly)

More? (Looks at the teacher, tilting head) He wanted... more eggs? Is that... right?
Yes! He wanted more eggs. Why do you think he wanted more eggs?

(Thinking, taps crayon on the desk)

Because... (pause) he was... greedy? (Looks at teacher, unsure) Is "greedy" like... wanting too much?

Yes, that's exactly right! "Greedy" means wanting too much. He wanted more and more, even though he already had enough.

So, what did he *do* to try and get more eggs? Remember what happened to the goose?

(Looks down at hands, playing with fingers)

He... (long pause) ...cut... the goose? (Looks up, eyes wide with a little bit of worry) Was that... a bad idea?

Yes, that was a *very* bad idea.

What happened when he cut the goose? Did he find lots of golden eggs?

(Shakes head slowly, still looking worried)

No... (pause) He found... blood? And... guts? (Makes a slight face) Was it... yucky?
Yes, it was yucky, and a very big mistake. He didn't find any more golden eggs, did he? So what happened to the farmer and his wife after that? Did they stay rich, or did they become poor again?

(Thinking, looks out the window)

They... got... poorer? (Turns back to the teacher) Because... no more golden eggs?

That's right! No more golden eggs. So, the farmer was greedy. He wanted more than he had. He didn't think about what would happen if he cut open the goose.

What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What did the farmer learn?

(Thinking hard, picks up the storybook and flips through the pages)

Hmm... (pause) That... (long pause) ...it's bad to be greedy? (Looks up at the teacher, then points to a picture in the book) Is it like... he should have been happy with just one egg a day? Is that... the lesson?

Yes, it's definitely about being happy with what you have and not being too greedy. But it's also about something else. Think about *why* he made such a big mistake. Did he think about what would happen *before* he cut open the goose?

(Thinking, taps finger on chin)

Uh... (pause) No? (Looks at the picture of the cut-open goose) He didn't think... he just... did it? So... (eyes widen) ...thinking is important? Even if you want more?

You're getting it! Thinking *is* important! Before you do something, especially something big, you should think about what will happen.

So, what's a good way to say what the story teaches us? It's about thinking... before you...? What do you *do* after thinking?

(Looks at the ceiling, thinking really hard)

Think... before you... (long pause) ...act? (Looks at the teacher hopefully) Think before you act... and don't be greedy! Is that... good?
That's perfect! "Think before you act." That means don't do something without thinking about what will happen. You understood the story very well! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Farmer and the Well."

Now, tell me, who did the farmer buy the well from?
Uh... (looks away, fidgeting with my pencil) ... the... um... neighbor?

That's right! He bought it from his neighbor.

So, the farmer bought the well. What did he want to do with the well?
(Thinking, chewing on my lip) He... um... wanted water? To... uh... give it to his... uh... farm? (Looks at the teacher hopefully)

Yes! He wanted water for his farm. Good remembering!

But, could he take the water? What did the neighbor say?
(Eyes widen, thinking hard) Uh... the neighbor... said... (hesitates) ... he sold the well... but not the... uh... water? (Looks down at my hands, tracing the lines on my palm) Is that right?

That *is* right! The neighbor said he sold the well, but not the water.

Do you think that was a nice thing for the neighbor to do? Why or why not?

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Elephant and Friends! I really enjoyed that.

Now, let's talk about what happened in the story. Can you tell me, why was the elephant sad at the beginning?
(Looks down at my shoes, fidgeting) Uh... 'cause... (stuttering) 'cause nobody... nobody wanted to be his friend? (Looks up quickly, then down again) They... they said he was too big.

That's right! He was sad because nobody wanted to be his friend.

Why didn't the monkey want to be his friend? What did the monkey say?

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed) Hmmm... uh... (long pause) ... (looks at the teacher with a hopeful expression) The monkey... uh... something about... trees? (shrugs) I... I don't remember the exact words. But it was about trees. (Looks away, embarrassed)

That's close enough! The monkey said the elephant couldn't swing in the trees.

And what about the rabbit? Why didn't the rabbit want to be friends?
(Starts to pick at a loose thread on my shirt) The rabbit... (hesitates)... said he was too... too big for the burrow? (Looks up at the teacher, questioningly) Was that it?

Yes, that's right! The rabbit said the elephant was too big to fit in the burrow.

So, everyone said no to the elephant because of how he looked, right? How did that make the elephant feel, do you think?
(Looks down, thinking) Sad... I think. (Quietly) Really sad. 'Cause... 'cause nobody liked him. (Looks up, eyes widening slightly) Even though... even though he didn't do anything wrong.

Exactly! It made him feel really sad because nobody wanted to be his friend just because of how he was.

Now, what happened the next day in the forest? What were all the animals doing?
(Thinking, taps fingers on the desk) Uh... (eyes dart around the room) They were... running? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation) Running away? (Whispers) Because of the tiger...

Yes! They were all running away because of the tiger.

And what did the elephant do then?
(Sits up a little straighter, a little more confident) He... he stopped the bear! And then... and then he told the tiger to stop! (Pauses, then adds quietly) But the tiger was being mean.
He did! He was very brave. And what happened *after* the elephant scared the tiger away? What did the other animals think then?

(Thinks hard, head tilted) Uh... (Long pause, then a little spark of recognition in the eyes) They... they liked him then! 'Cause he saved them! (Looks at the teacher, a small smile appearing) They wanted to be his friend!

That's right! They finally realized he could be a good friend.

So, at the beginning, they didn't want to be his friend because he was too big to swing in trees or fit in burrows. But at the end, they liked him *because* he was big and strong and could scare away the tiger.

What do you think we can learn from this story? Think about how the animals changed their minds about the elephant.

(Puts a finger to the chin, thinking deeply, a wrinkle forming on the forehead) Hmmm... (Looks up, using a slightly bigger word) Maybe... maybe we shouldn't... (hesitates) ...pre-judge? (Looks at the teacher, unsure if that's the right word) Like... like don't say no to people just 'cause they're different? (Adds quickly, politely) Is that... is that right?

That's a *really* good word to use! "Pre-judge" is perfect. It means deciding if you like someone before you really know them.

So, don't pre-judge people. What else does the story tell us? Do friends all have to be the same size and shape?

(Shakes head slowly, thoughtfully) No... (Looks up, a little more confident) Friends don't have to be the same. The elephant couldn't swing, but... but he could scare away the tiger! So... so being different can be good? (Looks at the teacher, hopeful)

Yes! Being different can be very good! Friends can be different sizes and shapes and still help each other.

So, what's the big idea or lesson of our story, the thing we can learn from it?

(Looks at the teacher, takes a deep breath) Uh... (Thinks really, really hard, tapping a finger on the desk) Maybe... maybe the lesson is... (struggles to find the right words)... that everyone is good at something? And... and you should give people a chance... even if they're different? (Looks up, anxiously) Is that... is that a good lesson? (Fidgets with the hands)

That is a wonderful lesson! You explained that perfectly.

We can say that friends can be any shape or size! Different isn't bad. Different can be really, really good.

You did a fantastic job understanding the story and its lesson! I'm very proud of you. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! That was a good story, right?

So, tell me, what did the girl ask her father?

(Nods head enthusiastically) Uh... yeah, it was a good story! (Looks down at my shoes, shuffling them a little)

She... (thinking) She asked her dad... uh... she was... (looks up, eyes wide) frustrated! (smiles slightly) With... uh... (stutters) life? Yeah, she was frustrated with life!

That's right! She was frustrated with life.

And what did her father ask her to bring?

(Looks away, fiddling with my fingers) Uh... hmm... (pauses, thinking hard)

He asked her to bring... (eyes light up) a potato! And... and an egg! (ponders) And... tea leaves! (beams proudly)

Great job! You remembered everything!

Now, what did he do with the potato, the egg, and the tea leaves?

(Eyes widen, thinking hard) He... uh... (hesitates) put them in... water? (looks at the teacher hopefully) Uh... hot water? (frowns slightly, unsure) He... boiled them! Yeah! (smiles shyly) He boiled the potato, the egg, and the tea leaves! (nods head)

You got it! He boiled them.

Now, what happened to the egg after it was boiled? Was it the same as before?

(Thinking, taps chin with finger) Hmmm... (pauses, looks up at the ceiling) The egg... (eyes widen) it got hard! (nods head confidently) It was soft before, but then it got... like a rock! (makes a fist to show how hard)

Good! The soft egg became hard.

What about the potato? What happened to the potato when it was boiled?
(Looks down at my hands, then back up) The potato... (thinking) it was hard before... (pauses, then brightens) but then it got soft! (smiles slightly) Like... mushy! (giggles softly)

Mushy is a good word! So, the hard potato became soft.

And what about the tea leaves? What did they do to the water?

(Eyes get big, leans forward) The tea leaves... (thinking intensely) they changed... the water! (looks up at the teacher, excited) They made it... tea! (smiles proudly) The water wasn't just water anymore! (nods head vigorously) It was... tea!

Exactly! The tea leaves changed the water itself.

So, the egg changed, the potato changed, and the water changed.

Now, the story said that this shows us how we can be when things are hard. The egg, the potato, and the tea leaves each reacted differently to the hot water, right?

What do you think the story is trying to tell us about how *we* can be when things are hard for us?

(Looks down, thinking really hard. Scratches head) Uh... (long pause, almost whispering) So... (looks up, eyes wide) maybe... (stutters) maybe... when things are hard... we can be like... the potato? (frowns, unsure) Soft? Or maybe... (eyes light up) like the tea? (ponders) Changing things? (tilts head, confused but interested) Or... (voice trails off) ...like the egg? (looks at the teacher expectantly) Is it... is it like... we can choose? (asks hopefully)

You are so close! You're absolutely right, we *can* choose!

The story is showing us that when things get tough, like the hot water, we can react in different ways. The egg got hard, the potato got soft, and the tea changed the water.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us about *our* choices when things are hard? Do we all have to react the same way?

(Eyes widen, thinking) Uh... no! (shakes head slightly) We don't all have to be the same! (thinking hard again) Like... (stutters) some people... maybe they get hard like the egg when things are hard? (looks up at the teacher, questioningly) And some people... get soft like the potato? (shrugs) And... and some people change things, like the tea! (smiles, a little more confident now)

So... (pauses) we can choose how to be? (asks, looking for confirmation) We don't have to be sad if things are hard? (eyes hopeful) We can... change things? Or be strong? (tilts head, thinking)

Yes! You've got it! You can choose how to be! It's all about how *you* react when things get difficult.

The story is saying that when bad things happen, or when you are facing adversity, it is up to you to decide how you will respond. You can choose to be strong, or you can choose to change things, or you can choose another way.

So, what's the main message of the story? What did you learn?

(Takes a deep breath, trying to explain) The story... (pauses, thinking) The story tells us... (eyes widen, realizing) that when bad things happen... (stutters) we get to... decide! (smiles proudly) We can be strong... or change things... or... (thinking) or something else! (nods head enthusiastically) It's... (voice gets quieter) it's up to us! (looks up at the teacher, beaming)
Exactly! It's up to us! We decide how to respond to difficult situations. You understood the story very well. I'm very proud of you! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Needle Tree."

Now, let's talk about it. Who are the main people in the story?
Umm... (looks down, fidgeting with my fingers) There... there were two... brothers. (pauses)
That's right! Two brothers. Can you tell me anything about the brothers? What were they like?

(Thinking hard, wrinkling my nose) Uh... the older one... he was... (struggling to find the right word) ...not nice? He... he chopped wood. (Looks up quickly) And the other one... he... helped? (Looks away again)
Okay, "not nice" is a good way to describe him! What did the older brother do that made him not nice? And what did the younger brother do?

(Stuttering a little) He... he was mean. (pauses) To the... younger one. (thinking) He... he chopped the tree... almost. The younger... uh... helped him... get the... needles out. (Looks up, a little unsure) Was that... right?

Yes, that's all right! The older brother was mean to the younger one. He chopped wood. And he *almost* chopped the tree! And you're right, the younger brother helped him get the needles out.

Why did the older brother *almost* chop the tree down? What did the tree offer him?

(Eyes widening a little) It... it gave him... (searching for the word) ... golden apples! (Looks pleased with myself for remembering). But... but he wanted... more? (Raises eyebrows questioningly) Is "greedy" a big word? (Tilts head, curious)
"Greedy" is a GREAT word! Yes, he was greedy. He wanted more. So, the tree gave him golden apples, but he wanted more. What happened when he tried to chop the tree down anyway?

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Golden Touch."

First, tell me: Who was King Midas?
(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands) Uh... He... (stuttering) He was a... king? (Looks up quickly, then back down) A Greek king? I think... (Voice barely audible)

Yes! That's right! He was a Greek king. Good job remembering that!

Now, who gave King Midas a wish?

(Eyes widen slightly, then quickly look away) Um... (long pause)... The... the wine guy? (Looks at the teacher briefly, then fiddles with a loose thread on my shirt) Dionysus? Was that... was that right? (Whispers) I think so... (Anxious expression)

Yes! Dionysus, the god of wine, that's exactly right! You remembered his name!

Now, what did King Midas wish for? What did he want more than anything?

(Takes a deep breath, avoiding eye contact) He... (pause) he wanted... (voice trails off) Everything... everything to be gold? (Looks up, worried) He touched things... and they... uh... (shrugs slightly) They got shiny? (Nervous giggle) I... I think that's it. (Anxiously chews on my lip)

Yes! He wished for everything he touched to turn to gold. That's right!

So, he started touching things. What happened when he touched his food?

(Frowns, picking at my fingernails) Uh... (hesitates) ...It turned... hard? And... shiny? (Looks at the teacher, confused) He couldn't... (pause) ...eat it? (Voice very quiet) ...Because it was... gold? (Eyes start to well up a little) Uh... I... I don't like thinking about it. (Looks down, close to tears)

You're right. The food turned to gold, and he couldn't eat it. That must have been very upsetting for him.

What happened when his daughter hugged him?

(Sniffles, wiping my eyes with the back of my hand) ...She... (voice cracks) ...She turned... too? (Looks up, eyes wide with fear) ...Into... gold? (Shakes head slightly, lip trembling) ...He didn't want that... (Whispers) ...It's not fair... (Starts to cry softly)

(Reaches out and gently puts a hand on the student's shoulder) It's okay. It wasn't fair. He didn't want that at all.

So, King Midas couldn't eat, and his daughter turned to gold. How do you think King Midas felt then? Was he happy he got his wish?

(Sobs quietly, shaking head) No... (Sniffles) ...He was... sad? (Looks up, tearful eyes searching the teacher's face) ...Really, really sad? (Wipes eyes again) ...He didn't want the gold anymore... (Whispers) ...He wanted his daughter back... and his food...

Yes, he was very sad. He realized the golden touch wasn't such a good thing after all.

Why wasn't it a good thing? What did he learn?

(Thinking hard, chewing on lip) ...Uh... (long pause)... (Looks down, tracing patterns on the floor with a finger) ...Because... (stuttering) ...because he couldn't... eat? And... and his daughter... (voice cracks again) ...was gold... and not... huggy anymore? (Looks up, pleadingly) ...Gold isn't... everything? (Anxious expression) ...It's not... better than... people?

That's right! Gold isn't everything. You're getting it! It's not better than people or food.

So, why did King Midas make that wish in the first place? What did he want so much gold for?
(Shrugs, looking confused) I... I don't know... (Looks down, fiddling with my shoelaces) ...He just... wanted it? (Pause) ...Was he... greedy? (Whispers) ...Is that bad? (Looks up, worried)

"Greedy" is a good word for it. He wanted more and more and more. Yes, being greedy can be bad.

Do you think his greed made him happy in the end?

(Shakes head vehemently, tears drying on my face) No! (Voice a little stronger) ...It made him... really, really sad! (Looks at the teacher, eyes wide) ...He lost... important things! (Hugs myself tightly) ...He didn't know... what was... really important... before.

Exactly! He lost the things that were truly important.

So, what do you think we can learn from the story of King Midas? What's the big lesson it teaches us? What happens when you are greedy?

(Thinks for a long time, looking down at hands) ...Um... (stuttering) ...That... that being... happy... is better than... gold? (Looks up, hesitantly) ...And... and that... (pause) ...being greedy... (voice trails off) ...makes you... lose... the things... that matter? (Eyes start to fill with tears again) ...Like... like your family? (Whispers, scared)

Yes! You've got it! Being happy is better than having gold and being greedy can make you lose what really matters.

So, if you are greedy, what happens in the end?

(Looks down, tracing circles on the floor with my foot. Voice is small and hesitant.) ...You get... sad? (Pause, then looks up with a worried expression.) ...And lonely? (Sniffles quietly.) ...And you lose... the people you love? (Wipes eyes again.) ...Because you wanted... too much...?

Yes! You get sad and maybe lonely. You might lose the people you love, all because you wanted too much. That's a very good way to put it. The story of King Midas shows us that greed leads to sadness, and losing the things that are important. You understood the story very well! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! That was a good reading!

Now, tell me, what was the fox looking for?

(Looks down at my hands, fidgeting with my fingers)

Umm... uh... food? (Stutters) He... he was hungry.
That's right! He was hungry. And what did he find on the farmer's wall?

(Thinking, looks up at the ceiling)

...Grapes? Purple...grapes. (Quietly)
Good job! They were purple grapes. Did he get the grapes?

(Shakes head slowly, looks at the teacher nervously)

...Uh... no. (Whispers)
No, he didn't. He jumped and jumped. Why couldn't he get them?

(Looks away, like I'm trying to disappear)

...Too high? (Barely audible)
Yes! They were too high. What did the fox say about the grapes when he couldn't reach them?

(Tears welling up a little, voice shaky)

...They were... sour? (Sniffles) I... I don't know. (Looks down again)
It's okay. You're doing great. He said they were sour. Do you think the grapes *really* were sour?

(Hangs head low)

...Uh... (shrugs) Maybe? I... I don't know.
Hmm. Think about it. He wanted the grapes *before* he jumped. Why did he want them then?

(Starts to pick at a loose thread on my shirt)

...Because... (Hesitates) ...they looked... yummy? (Voice barely a whisper)
Yes! They looked yummy. And what changed? Did the grapes change?

(Thinking hard, furrowing my brow)

...No? (Looks at the teacher with wide, unsure eyes) The...the fox changed?
Yes! The fox changed. He couldn't get what he wanted. What do you think he was feeling?

(Face scrunches up, almost crying)

...Sad? (Sniffles) Frustrated? (Quietly) Maybe... mad? I get mad when I can't... can't do things. (Looks down, ashamed)
It's okay to feel those things. It sounds like you understand how the fox felt. So, he was sad and frustrated. Do you think it's a good idea to say something is bad just because you can't have it?

(Wipes eyes with the back of my hand)

...No. (Shakes head slowly) That's... that's not nice. (Looks at teacher, a little less nervous now)
That's right. It's not nice. And it's not really true, is it? The grapes probably weren't sour. What do you think this story is trying to teach us? It's okay if you don't know!

(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip)

...Uh... (Hesitates) ...Don't... don't say things are bad just 'cause you can't get them? (Looks up at the teacher, hopeful)
Yes! That's a big part of it! It also teaches us that things take effort. If something is hard to get, don't just give up and say you didn't want it anyway. Do you understand?

(Nods slowly, looking at the teacher. Seems a little calmer now)

...Yes. (Quietly) I think so. Thank you, Teacher. (A small, polite smile appears)

You're welcome! You did a very good job figuring out the story. Remember, things that are worth having might take some effort. And it's okay if you can't get them, but don't pretend you didn't want them in the first place! <finish>

So, tell me, who are the two main characters in the story?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my fingers)

Uh... um... (stuttering) a... a rose... and... and a... cactus?

Yes! That's right! A rose and a cactus.

Now, what was the rose like in the story? Was it happy? Kind? Or something else?
Mean! That's a good word for it. Why do you say the rose was mean? What did it do?

(Shrugs, avoids eye contact)

...Insulted... the... cactus? (voice barely audible)
Yes! You're doing great! The rose insulted the cactus. Do you remember what the rose said to the cactus? Maybe something about how it looked?

(Thinking, chewing on my lip)

... Pretty... rose? ... Ugly... cactus? (looking at the teacher briefly, then back down)
Yes, that's right! The rose thought it was much prettier than the cactus and told the cactus that. How did the other plants feel about the rose being mean to the cactus?

(Shrugs again, a little anxious)

... Uh... sad? (quietly) ...for cactus?
Yes, they felt sad for the cactus. They tried to help the cactus. Now, what happened when the summer got really, really hot? What happened to the rose?

(Eyes wide, a little nervous)

... No water...? ... Rose... withered...? (voice trembling slightly)
Yes! No water, and the rose started to wither. What does "wither" mean? It started to...

(Thinking hard, forehead furrowed)

... Die...? (looks up at the teacher hopefully, then quickly looks down again)
Yes! It started to die because it had no water. Now, what was the cactus doing while the rose was withering?

(Hesitates, then whispers)

...Sparrows...? ...Water...? (looking down at my hands)
Yes! The cactus was giving water to the sparrows. Where was the cactus getting the water from?

(Quietly)

...Itself...? (looks up at the teacher, anxious for confirmation)
That's right! The cactus was using its own water to help the birds. And then, what did the rose do? It was thirsty and withering. What did it ask the cactus?

(Anxious, fiddling with clothes)

...Water...? (barely audible) ...Asked... for... water...?
Yes! The rose asked the cactus for water. And what did the cactus do? After the rose was so mean, did the cactus help?

Yes! The cactus gave the rose water. Even after the rose was mean!

Now, let's think about the whole story. The rose was pretty but mean. The cactus wasn't as pretty, but it was helpful and kind. What do you think this story is trying to teach us? Is it good to be mean like the rose, or is it better to be kind like the cactus?

(Starts to tear up, voice shaky)

...Better... to be... kind...? (sniffling) ...Like... cactus...? (looks up at the teacher with watery eyes) ...Is it okay to be... not pretty...?

(Softly) Oh, honey, it's absolutely okay to be not pretty. The story shows us that being kind and helpful is much more important than being pretty. The cactus wasn't worried about being pretty. It cared about helping others.

So, what's the lesson of the story? What should we remember about how we treat others? Should we only be nice to people who look pretty?

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Milkmaid and Her Pail."

First, tell me, what was Molly going to do with the milk?

(Fidgets with my hands, looking down at my shoes)

Uhm... (Stutters) S-sell it? At the market? (Looks up quickly then back down) I... I think that's right.

Yes! You are exactly right. She was going to sell it at the market.

And what did Molly start thinking about while she was walking?

(Shifts feet, looking nervous)

Uh... (Long pause, chewing on lip) ...Things? (Looks at the teacher briefly, then down again) Nice things... she could buy? (Voice is barely a whisper)

You're doing great! Yes, she was thinking about nice things she could buy.

What *specific* nice thing did she start thinking about buying *first*? It involved an animal!

(Eyes widen a little, but still looking down)

A... a chicken? (Whispers) To get eggs? (Looks up at the teacher, then back down, nervously picking at a loose thread on my shirt)
That's right! A chicken! And what did she think she would do with the chicken's eggs?

(Swallows hard, voice quiet)

S-sell them too? (Looks up, then immediately down again, shoulders hunched slightly) ... Uh... (Trails off)

Yes! She wanted to sell the eggs too. So, she was going to sell milk and then use that money to buy a chicken and then sell the eggs from the chicken.

What happened to the milk while she was thinking about all of this?

(Frowns, looking at the floor, tapping foot nervously)

...It... spilled? (Looks up, uncertainly) All of it? (Voice is very quiet, almost a question) ... Uh...
Yes, the milk spilled! Why did it spill? What was Molly doing that made the milk spill?

(Thinking hard, brows furrowed. Looks at the ceiling for a second)

...She... was skipping? (Voice hesitant, looking back at the teacher for confirmation) And it... w-went everywhere? Uh... (Looks down again, scuffing shoe on the floor)
Yes, she was skipping and it went everywhere! So, what happened to Molly's plan to buy a chicken?

(Shrugs, avoids eye contact)

...Gone? (Whispers) 'Cause... no milk? (Looks up quickly, then back down, anxiously twisting fingers together)

Exactly! It was gone. She had no milk to sell, so she had no money.

So, what do you think Molly learned from this experience? What should she have done differently?

(Long pause, staring at the floor, biting lip)

...Uh... (Shifts weight from one foot to the other) ...Not skip? (Looks up, unsure) ...And... not... count chickens? (Frowns, confused) ...What does that mean?

You're so close! "Don't count your chickens..." means don't *expect* something good to happen *before* it *actually* happens.

Molly was expecting to have lots of money from the milk and the eggs, *before* she even sold the milk. Do you understand now?

(Eyes widen slightly, looking at the teacher)

Oh! (Nods slowly, looking down again, but less nervously) So... she should... wait? (Voice a little stronger) Until she... has the money? And the eggs? (Looks up quickly, seeking confirmation)

Yes! You got it! She should wait until she *actually* has the money from selling the milk, and then wait until the chicken *actually* lays the eggs before she starts planning what to buy.

So, what's the lesson of the story? What does the story teach us?

(Takes a deep breath, looking at the floor, then up at the teacher for a brief second)

...Don't... (Hesitates) ...Don't be... too excited? (Voice shaky) ...Until... it's real? Uh... (Trails off, looking down again, fiddling with hands) ...Is that right?

That's *very* good! Yes!

We can say, "Don't count your chickens until they hatch."

Or, even better, "Don't depend on something until you are sure it will happen." Do you understand? <finish>

Now, let's talk about the owl. What did the owl do every day?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my fingers)

Uh... (pauses) ...saw things... around the tree.
That's right! He saw things. Did he just see them and then forget about them? Or did he do something else? Think about the story.

(Thinking, chewing on my lip)

...uh... he... (looks away) heard... people talking? (shrugs)
Good! He heard people talking! And what did the story say about how much the owl talked? Did he talk a lot?

(Shakes head slowly, looking down at shoes)

...less...
Yes! He talked less. And because he saw and heard so much, what happened to the owl?

(Eyes widen a little, voice barely a whisper)

...wiser? ... (nervously glances up, then down again)

You got it! He got wiser. So, the owl watched and listened a lot, and he didn't talk as much. And that made him wise!

Why do you think watching and listening helped him become wise? What do you think he learned?

I... I don't... uh... (shrugs again) ... know... Too many things to... remember? (Anxious look on face)

...new... things? (looks up hesitantly) ...like... different... stories?

(Nods slowly, eyes still downcast, a little more confident now)

...uh-huh... maybe... (Quietly) Does it?

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Long pause, looking around the room, avoiding the teacher's gaze. Starts to pick at a loose thread on his shirt.)

... (mumbles) ...listen... more? ... than talking? (Anxious look on face. Voice is shaky) ...Is that right?
That's a really good start! So, listen more than talking... and what happens when you listen more? What did it do for the owl?

(Looks down, tracing patterns on the floor with his shoe. Sighs softly)

... (very quietly) ...become... wiser? (voice trails off into a whisper) ...Is it okay if I draw a picture now? This is... hard. (Fidgeting intensifies)

Talk less and be more observant!

And yes, you can draw a picture now! That's a great idea! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Golden Egg! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it?

Let's talk about it. What kind of animal laid the golden egg?
(Fidgets with my hands, looking down at my shoes) Uh... (pauses) ... a goose? (looks up quickly, then down again)
That's right! A goose. And what did the goose lay?
(Shuffles feet) ...A... (long pause, looking around the room)... golden egg. (barely audible)
Yes! A golden egg. And what did the farmer do with the golden egg?
(Looks at the teacher briefly, then away again) He... he... (stutters) ... sold it?
He did! He sold it. And what happened when he sold the golden eggs? How did he and his wife live?
(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip) They... uh... (looks down, scuffing my shoe on the floor) ... were... um... happy? (voice is very quiet, sounds unsure)
They were happy! They had enough money, right? They lived comfortably. But then, something changed. What did the farmer start to feel?
(Looks up, eyes wide, then quickly looks down again, fiddling with a loose thread on my shirt) He... he wanted... more? (voice trembling slightly)
You're right, he wanted more! He became greedy. He wasn't happy with just one golden egg a day. What did he *do* because he was greedy? This is the most important part!
(Tears welling up in my eyes. I start to pick at my fingernails.) He... he... (sobs quietly) ...cut the goose? (voice barely a whisper, shaking my head) ...It was... a bad thing... to do.
Yes, it was a very bad thing to do. Why do you think it was a bad thing to do? What happened after he cut the goose?

(Wipes my eyes with the back of my hand, sniffling) ...Because... (hesitates) ...the goose... couldn't lay eggs anymore... (looks at the teacher with big, watery eyes) ... and then they were... poor... and sad. (Voice cracks.) I don't like that.

You're exactly right. The goose couldn't lay any more eggs. So, they didn't get any more golden eggs to sell. They became poor and sad.

So, the farmer had a good thing, but he wanted *more* and he did something without thinking. What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What lesson can we learn from the farmer's mistake?
(Looks at the teacher, then down at my lap, twisting my fingers together. A tear rolls down my cheek.) (Quietly) ... Don't be... greedy? (Looks up, questioning, seeking approval) ...Is that... right?
That's part of it! Not being greedy is good. But what else could the farmer have done *before* he cut the goose? What should he have done *before* he acted?

(Bites my lip, thinking. Looks up at the ceiling, then back at the teacher, frowning slightly.) ... Um... (pauses) ... Asked... his wife? (Sounds unsure, looking for confirmation.) Or... (eyes widen slightly) ... maybe... be happy with the one egg?
Yes! He could have been happy with one egg! And before doing something so big, he should have... what? What's another word for thinking hard about what will happen next?
(Looks down at my hands, picking at my nails again. Mumbles quietly) ... Think...? (Looks up, eyes wide) Is it... think? (Voice is small and hesitant).

Yes! Think. Think before you act. If the farmer had thought about what would happen *after* he cut open the goose, he wouldn't have done it. He would have realised it was a bad idea.

So, what is the lesson of the story? Try to say it all together.

(Takes a deep breath, looking at the teacher with anxious eyes. Stuttering) U-uh... Don't be... greedy... and... (long pause, looking around the room) ...and... think... before... you... (almost whispers) ...cut the goose? (Looks at the teacher, hopeful but nervous)

You're so close! It's not just about cutting the goose. It's about *anything* you do. Think before you act, in *any* situation. So, a better way to say it is: think before you act. The farmer didn't think, and he made a big mistake. Do you understand?

(Nods slowly, looking down, but a small smile flickers across my face) ...Yes. (Looks up, making brief eye contact) ...Think... before... act. (Repeats it more confidently, but still quietly.) Thank you, Teacher.
You're very welcome! I'm glad you understand the story and its lesson. You did a great job. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! The Fox and the Grapes is a fun one.

...He... went home? (Looks at the teacher hesitantly)
Yes! He went home. And what did he say about the grapes before he left? This is important!

...(Long pause)... Uh... They were... sour? (Looks up quickly, then back down) I think...
Yes! He said they were sour. Even though he didn't even *taste* them! Why do you think he said that?

(Shrugs a little, avoiding eye contact)

...(Quietly)... I don't know.
Think about it. He really wanted those grapes, right? But he couldn't get them. How do you think that made him feel? Maybe a little bit... sad?

(Frowns a little, thinking hard)

...(Softly)... Maybe... (Stuttering) A little sad... 'cause he wanted them. But... (pauses) he said they were sour... so... it's okay? (Looks up with a slightly confused expression)

You're getting it! He was probably sad, but saying they were sour made him feel a little better. It's like he was trying to trick himself.

So, the fox couldn't get what he wanted. And then he said he didn't want it anyway. Does that seem like a good thing to do?

(Thinks for a moment, looking down at my shoes)

... (Quietly) No...? (Looks up at the teacher, a little unsure)
Why not? What would have been a better way for the fox to act?

(Looks around the room, then back at the teacher, fiddling with my fingers)

... (Hesitates) ... I don't know... maybe... try again? (Whispers) ...Or ask for help?
Those are great ideas! Trying again, or asking for help are very good things to do. What else could he do? What if he *really* couldn't get the grapes, no matter what?

(Thinking hard, tapping my foot quietly)

... (Quietly) ... Be... (Stuttering) be okay with it? (Looks up quickly, then back down)

Exactly! Be okay with it. It's okay to be disappointed, but it's not good to pretend you didn't want something just because you couldn't have it.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? It's a big idea, but try your best. What's the lesson?

...(Very softly)... Uh... (Another long pause, looks up briefly) ... Don't say... (Stuttering) ...don't say you don't want something... if you... (Another long pause) ...really do? (Looks at the teacher with wide, unsure eyes.)

That's a *really* good way to put it! Don't say you don't want something if you really do. It's better to be honest with yourself.

This story is telling us that things we want don't always come easy. And it's also telling us that we shouldn't pretend we don't want something just because we can't have it. It's okay to feel sad or disappointed.

Does that make sense?

(Nods slowly, looking at the teacher with a small smile.)

...Uh huh. (Quietly) I... I think so.
Great! You really thought hard about that story. The lesson is that nothing comes easy, and don't hate what you can't have. You understood the story and its lesson very well. <finish>

A chicken! Why did she want a chicken?

More money! How would the chicken help her get more money?

Yes! He was trying to cheat him. And what happened in the end? Did the neighbor get away with cheating the farmer?
(Shakes head, a tiny bit more confidently now.) ...No. (Looks up, then back down). ...Said sorry.
He did say sorry! So, the neighbor tried to cheat the farmer, but it didn't work. He had to apologize. What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends."

First, can you tell me, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?

(Looks down at my shoes, shuffling them a little)

Uh... (pauses) ... sad?
That's right! He was sad. Why was the elephant sad?

(Thinking, taps a finger on the table)

...Because... no friends. (Looks up quickly, then back down)
Exactly! He had no friends. So, what did the elephant do to try and not be sad anymore?
Yes! He looked for friends. Who did he ask first? Do you remember?
Good job! He asked the monkey. What did the monkey say? Why didn't the monkey want to be friends?

(Shrugs a little, avoids eye contact)

...Uh... couldn't... swing? (Mumbles)
You got it! The monkey said the elephant couldn't swing. Then who did the elephant ask next?

(Thinking hard, bites lip)

...Rabbit? (Looks up, a little more confident)
You're on a roll! The rabbit! And why didn't the rabbit want to be friends with the elephant?

(Sticks to given information)

...Too big... for... burrow. (Quietly)
Perfect! Too big for the burrow. Then who was next?

(Struggling to remember, fidgets with hands)

...Uh... (pauses, looks around the room) ...Frog?
Frog! You remembered! And what did the frog say?

(Sticks to simple words, avoids eye contact again)

...Couldn't... jump.
Right! The elephant couldn't jump. So, how do you think the elephant was feeling now? Still happy? Or something else?

(Looks down, drawing circles on the table with a finger)

...Sadder? (Mumbles)
Sadder, I think so too. Then what happened the next day in the forest? Something changed, didn't it?

(Thinking)

...Run... running? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation)
Yes! All the animals were running! Why were they running? What were they scared of?
Yes, the tiger! What did the elephant do when he saw the tiger?
He did! He kicked the tiger! Why did he do that?
Yes! To help the other animals. To keep them safe. What happened after the elephant scared the tiger away? How did the other animals feel about the elephant then?

(Looks up, a little shyly)

...Liked... him? ...Friends? (A small smile)
They did like him! They wanted to be his friend. Why do you think they wanted to be his friend *after* he kicked the tiger, but not before?

(Thinking hard, taps finger on the table again)

...He... strong? (Looks at the teacher, unsure)
He *was* strong! He helped them when they were in trouble. Did the monkey need to swing with him? Did the rabbit need him to fit in the burrow?
No! So, what does this story tell us about what makes a good friend? Does a friend need to be exactly the same size and shape as you?

(Shakes head no again, a little more confidently)

...No... (Pause) ...Help?
Help! That's a great word for it. Friends help each other. So, can friends be different sizes? Can they be good at different things?

Yes! The elephant was a good friend even though he was big and couldn't swing or jump. The monkey, rabbit and frog were good friends even though they were small. So, what do you think the big idea, or moral, of this story is? What do you think it's trying to teach us?

(Looks down, drawing circles again, really trying to think)

... (Long pause) ...Uh... (Looks up quickly) ...Friends... help... each other? ...Even if... different? (Looks down again, unsure if it's right)
That's *really* good! You're almost there! So friends help each other even if they are different. Can you think of a shorter way to say that friends can be any...?

(Thinking, then a small spark of understanding)

...Different? (Looks at the teacher, hoping for confirmation)
Different is a good word! But what else were the animals different in? Like, the elephant was big... the rabbit was small... They were different *sizes*! So friends can be any...?

(Eyes widen a little, understanding dawning)

...Size? (Smiling a tiny bit)
Yes! And shape! Friends can be any shape or size! You got it! You really understood the story. <finish>

dialogue: Okay! That was a good story, right? Now, tell me, what did the girl want from her father?
(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands) Uh… advice? (Hesitates) I think… she was, like, um, sad? Or something? (Sticks to simple words)
Yes, you're right! She was sad and wanted advice. Why was she sad? The story says she was frustrated. What does frustrated mean?
(Looks away, thinking hard) Frus… frus… (Stuttering) …trated? (Shrugs) Uh… I don't know. (Sticks to given information) She was… not happy? (Confident in the answer)
Okay, "not happy" is a good way to say it. She wasn't happy with her life. So, her dad gave her an egg, a potato, and tea leaves. What did he do with them?
(Looks down again) He… (pauses) …boiled them? (Responds with short answers) In… water? (Answering with “uh”)
Yes! He boiled them in water. Three different pots, right? Now, after they were boiled, what happened to the egg? Was it the same as before?
(Sticks to given information) Uh… no. (Short answer) It got… hard? (Looks up, a little more confident)
Great job! It got hard. And what about the potato? What happened to the potato after it was boiled?
(Hesitates, thinking) The… potato… (Looks at the teacher) …uh… soft? (Quietly)
Yes! The potato got soft. And what about the tea leaves? Did they become hard or soft?
(Looks confused) …Tea? (Tilts head slightly) They… uh… changed the… water? (Sticks to given information)

Exactly! The tea leaves changed the water. The water wasn't just plain water anymore, was it? Now, the dad said something important about the egg, the potato, and the tea. He said it was like how we deal with problems.

The egg started soft and became hard. The potato started hard and became soft. The tea changed the water.

Do you think the egg, the potato, and the tea all dealt with the hot water the same way?
(Avoids eye contact, fidgeting) …No. (Short answer) …Uh… different? (Barely audible)
Yes, different! So, the hot water is like a problem, right? Like when things are hard. Did the egg *have* to become hard? Could it have stayed soft?
(Thinking, chewing on lip) …Uh… (Looks down) …I don't… know…(Hesitates and gives short answer)

That's okay! Think about it this way: the hot water *happened* to all of them. The egg, the potato, and the tea didn't *choose* the hot water. But, did they *choose* what happened *inside* the hot water?
(Looks up, confused) …Choose? (Sticks to simple words) …The… egg… didn’t choose… to be… hard? (Avoids asking questions directly, but sounds like a question)

That's right! The hot water made the egg change, but the egg changed in its own way. The potato changed in *its* own way. And the tea changed in *its* own way too.

So, if a problem is like the hot water, what is like the egg, the potato, and the tea?
(Thinking hard, brows furrowed) …Um… (Pauses) …People? (Quietly, unsure) Problems make… people… change? (Sticks to simple words)

You're getting it! Yes, the people are like the egg, the potato, and the tea. The problem is like the hot water. And how the egg, potato, and tea changed is like how people… what? How people…? (Pauses, encouraging the student to finish the sentence)
(Looks at the teacher, then down at the floor) …uh… (long pause, fidgeting) …deal… with… problems? (Very quiet and hesitant)

Yes! How people deal with problems! The story is about how we can choose how we deal with hard things. We can become hard like the egg, soft like the potato, or change the situation like the tea. So, what do *you* think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?
(Shrugs, avoids eye contact) …Uh… (Another long pause) …Problems… change… people? (Very quiet, almost a mumble; sticks to given information, rephrasing what was said before)

That's part of it! But it's more than that. The story shows us that we can respond differently to problems. The egg, the potato, and the tea all had the same problem – the hot water – but they each responded in a different way. So what is the story teaching us about our responses to problems? Is there anything we can do?
(Thinking, tapping foot quietly) …Uh… (Looks up briefly, then back down) …We can… choose? (Quietly, sounds like a question, hesitant) …To be… egg… potato… or… tea? (Sticks to simple words)

Yes! We can choose! We decide how to respond to difficult situations. The story shows us that even when bad things happen (like the hot water), we have a choice in how we react. We're not stuck being a hard egg or a soft potato. We can even try to change the water, like the tea.

Does that make sense?<finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Needle Tree." Now, let's talk about it.

First, tell me, what were the two brothers like?

(Looks down at my hands, fidgeting)

Um... (long pause)

One was... uh... mean? (peeks up at the teacher quickly, then looks back down) And the other... uh... helped?
That's a good start! You're right, one was mean. Which brother was mean? Was it the older brother or the younger brother?

(Thinking hard, tapping my foot)

The... older... brother? (said softly, like a question)
Yes! The older brother was mean. What did he do that was mean?

(Shrugs shoulders, avoiding eye contact)

...Uh... (another long pause)

He... uh... wasn't nice? To the... young... younger one? (Sticks to simple words)
You're doing great! You're right, he wasn't nice. Can you remember *how* he wasn't nice? What did the story say he *did*? Think about what he did every day in the forest.

(Sticks to given information)

(Bites lip)

He... chopped... wood? (looks at the teacher, hopeful) (Hesitating in answers)
Yes, he chopped wood. And what did he do with the wood?

(Looking down again, kicking the chair slightly)

...Sold it? (Responding with short answers) (Quietly)

Yes, he sold it. Now, did he share the money with his younger brother? The story doesn't say he did, does it? So, he kept all the money for himself. That's not very kind, is it?

Now, tell me about the tree. What happened when the older brother met the tree?

(Thinks for a moment, brow furrowed)

...The tree... talked? (Looks at teacher, waiting for confirmation) (Simple words)
Yes, the tree talked! What did the tree *say* to the older brother?

(Looking at the floor, concentrating)

Uh... don't... cut? (Very short answer, almost a whisper)
Right! The tree said, "Don't cut me down!" And what did the tree *promise* if the older brother didn't cut it down?

(Eyes widen slightly, remembering something)

... Golden... apples? (Looks at the teacher, a little more confident) (Simple words)
Golden apples! That's right. And did the older brother get the golden apples?
Yes, he did. Was he happy with the golden apples?

(Looks away, fidgeting)

...Too few? (Said softly, like a question) (Hesitating in answers)
Too few! He thought he should get more. What did he do then?

(Thinking hard, face scrunched up a little)

... Cut... tree? (Looks at the teacher, worried) (Short answer)
He tried to cut the tree, didn't he? What happened when he tried to cut the tree? What did the tree do?

(Giggles nervously, then looks down again)

...Needles? (Quietly) (Short answer)
Needles! Lots and lots of needles. What happened to the older brother then?

(Looks at the teacher briefly, then down at hands again)

...Hurt? (Simple word) (Short answer)
He was hurt, yes. Who helped him?

(Thinking, tapping foot again)

...Younger... brother? (Peeking at the teacher again) (Short answer)
Yes, the younger brother. What did the younger brother do for him?

(Looks at the floor, concentrating)

...Took... needles... out? (Simple words, trying to remember) (Hesitating in answers)
He took the needles out, very carefully. Was that a kind thing to do?

(Nods head slowly, looking at the floor)

...Uh-huh... (Responding with "uh-huh")
Yes, it was very kind. What did the older brother say after the younger brother helped him?

(Thinking, brow furrowed, struggling to remember)

...Uh... (Long pause, looking lost)

...Sorry? (Said softly, unsure) (Hesitating in answers)
He said sorry! That's right! He apologized for being mean. And what happened *after* he said sorry? What did the tree do then?

(Eyes widen a little, remembering)

...More... golden... apples? (Said hopefully, looking at the teacher) (Simple words)
More golden apples! Why do you think the tree gave them more golden apples?

(Looks down, kicking the chair leg softly)

...Because... (long pause) ...He... said... sorry? (Voice barely audible) (Hesitating in answers)
He said sorry, and the younger brother was kind. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? Is it better to be mean, or better to be kind?

(Looks up, finally making eye contact, but only briefly)

...Kind...? (Said quietly, like a question, but with a hint of understanding) (Hesitating in answers)

Yes! It's better to be kind. The older brother was mean at first, and he got needles. But when he was sorry and the younger brother was kind, they got golden apples. So, what do you think the story is trying to tell us about being kind? What happens when we are kind?

(Thinking really hard, almost frowning)

...Good... things... happen? (Looks at the teacher, seeking approval) (Simple words, trying to form a complete thought)
Yes! Good things can happen. Being kind can bring good things. So, we can say that kindness gets rewarded. Do you understand now? What is the story about?<finish>

dialogue:
Okay, [User's Name], that was a great reading! Now, let's talk about the story.

Who was the main person in the story?

(Bouncing in my seat) Uh, duh! (Rolls eyes) It was, like, King... King... (Scratches head) Midas! Yeah! King Midas! He was, like, (gestures wildly) the most importantest guy! Is that right? (Looks at the teacher expectantly, then starts fiddling with my shoelaces). Was he a REALLY REAL king? Like, with a real crown? Did it turn to gold too?

Yes! King Midas was the main person. And "importantest" is a good way to describe him, but we usually say "most important".

That's a great question about the crown! The story doesn't say if his crown turned to gold, but what do *you* think? If he touched it, what would happen?

(Gasps dramatically, eyes widening, then quickly dropping eye contact) Gold! Of course! (Stands up, then sits back down) Everything he touched turned to gold! (Taps the desk impatiently) So, like, (thinking) his crown would be, like, SUPER gold! (Looks away, fidgeting) But then... (Stuttering) then... then he couldn't wear it, right? Because it would be too heavy and, like, scratchy? Ugh! Gold crown sounds kinda lame, actually. Maybe he should have wished for, like, a chocolate fountain! (Giggles, then quickly looks serious again)

That's right! Everything he touched turned to gold. Good thinking about the heavy crown.

Now, why did King Midas get a wish in the first place? What did he do?

(Sighs loudly and leans back in the chair, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) Ugh, this is boring. (Looks at the ceiling) He helped some...some... (Snaps fingers) some sleepy dude! Yeah! (Shrugs) He was all, like, wandering around and King Midas helped him. So the wine guy... the (makes air quotes) "god" gave him a wish. Is this going to take forever? Can I go draw now? (Starts humming loudly)

You're right! He helped a sleepy satyr. And because of that, Dionysus, the god of wine, offered him a wish.

Now, what did King Midas wish for? Try to remember exactly what he asked for.

(Groans and slouches further in the chair) Oh my gosh, (eyes darting around the room) this is SO hard to remember! It was something about... (Stands up abruptly and starts pacing) gold! (Whispering to myself) Gold... gold... (Suddenly shouts) He wanted EVERYTHING he touched to turn to gold! (Stops pacing and beams proudly, then quickly sits down, looking nervous) Was that right? (Pulls at my sleeves anxiously) I KNEW IT!

Yes! You remembered perfectly! He wished for everything he touched to turn to gold.

Now, at first, how did King Midas feel about his wish? Was he happy or sad?

(Beams, then smirks) Happy, duh! (Points at the teacher) SUPER happy! He was like, (makes grabby hands) "Gold! Gold! Gold!" (Starts tapping my feet excitedly) He thought it was the BEST wish EVER! (Looks down, then back up with a mischievous grin) I would wish for a mountain of candy! Would that be a good wish? Would YOU give me a wish if I was super nice? (Wiggles eyebrows)

He *was* super happy at first! That's a great way to put it - "Gold! Gold! Gold!" And a mountain of candy sounds fun!

But what happened *after* he started turning things to gold? Did he *stay* happy?

(Frowns, picking at my nails) Uh... (Looks away, then back) Noooo... (Stuttering) N-n-no. He got, like, (thinking hard, then claps my hands) hungry! Yeah! He couldn't eat! (Makes a disgusted face) Gross! Everything turned into yucky, hard gold! (Shudders dramatically) I'd be SO mad if my pizza turned into gold! (Pouts) That's just mean!
Exactly! He got hungry. And why couldn't he eat? What happened when he tried to eat?

(Rolls my eyes and sighs dramatically) Ugh, you're gonna make me say it again? (Taps my fingers impatiently on the desk) Everything... turned... into... (dragging out the words) G-O-L-D! (Looks at the teacher expectantly) His food, his yummy pizza... (Whispers) all gold. (Pouts again) He couldn't even eat a LITTLE bit!
That's right! His food turned to gold. And how did that make him feel? Was he still happy, or something else?

(Scoffs and crosses my arms) Happy? Are you kidding me? (Raises my voice) He was, like, the opposite of happy! (Looks around the room, then back at the teacher, lowering my voice) He was sad... and maybe a little bit scared! (Fidgets, pulling at my sleeves) I would be scared if my food turned to gold! What if *I* turned to gold? (Gasps and shivers dramatically) That would be the WORST!

You're right! He was sad and scared.

And then what happened with his daughter? What did she do, and what happened to her?

(Starts bouncing my leg nervously) Uh oh... (Looks down at the floor) This is the bad part... (Whispers) She... she hugged him... (Voice cracks) and she turned into gold too! (Suddenly becomes very loud and dramatic) Can you imagine?! His own daughter! A GOLD STATUE! (Covers my face with my hands, then peeks through my fingers) That's, like, the saddest thing EVER! (Sobs quietly)

Yes, that's exactly what happened. His daughter hugged him, and she turned to gold.

So, after all of that happened – the food, his daughter – how did King Midas feel about his golden touch then? Did he still think it was a good thing?

(Sniffs, wiping my nose with the back of my hand) No way! (Shakes my head vehemently) He was, like, super duper sad! (Clenches my fists) He didn't want the gold touch anymore! He wanted his daughter back! (Looks up at the teacher with wide, teary eyes) He learned it was a REALLY bad wish! (Pulls at my sleeves, looking anxious) It was a curse!

That's right! He learned it was a bad wish. He didn't want it anymore.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story? Was gold the most important thing?

(Looks down, then back up, scratching my head) Hmm... (Taps my chin thoughtfully, then gasps) I know! (Points a finger in the air) It's not good to be greedy! Yeah! (Claps my hands together) Because King Midas was super greedy and wanted all the gold, and then he was sad! (Fidgets with my hands) So... so it's better to have, like... (Struggles to find the words) ...friends and family and pizza than a mountain of gold! (Looks at the teacher, pleased with myself) Is that right? Did I get it? (Bites my lip anxiously)

Yes! You got it! It's not good to be greedy. King Midas was so focused on wanting more and more gold that he forgot about what was really important: his food, and his daughter. So being greedy made him very unhappy.

We can say that being greedy can lead to bad things happening to you.

Do you understand the story now? <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Fox and the Grapes."

First, tell me, what was the fox looking for?

(Fidgets in seat, avoids eye contact)

Umm… (scratches head) Food! (Looks around the room at the colorful posters) He... uh... wanted food. Like, duh! Everyone wants food! Are we done yet? I wanna go play. (Starts tapping foot impatiently)

(Smiling gently) Yes, you're right! He wanted food. Good job!

And what kind of food did he *see* that he wanted? Think about the farmer's wall.

(Rolls eyes, sighs dramatically)

Grapes! Big, purple, juicy grapes! (Looks out the window, distracted by a bird) Ugh, this is boring. Why are we talking about grapes? Can I draw something? (Pulls a crumpled crayon out of pocket) Are they even real grapes? Maybe they were fake. Did the fox even try that hard? (Starts doodling on the desk with the crayon)

(Chuckles softly) Okay, okay, let's stick with the story for just a bit longer.

The grapes *looked* yummy, right? What did the fox *do* to try and get them?

(Sighs loudly, throws crayon onto the desk)

He... he jumped! (Stands up suddenly) He jumped really, REALLY high! (Jumps up and down a couple of times, almost knocking over chair) But he couldn't get them! They were too high! Like, WAY too high! (Sits back down with a thump, looking annoyed) Stupid grapes.
(Nodding) He jumped really high! And did he get the grapes?

(Stares blankly, picks at a loose thread on pants)

Noooo... (draws out the word) He didn't get them. I already said that. Are you even listening? This is SO slow. (Starts humming loudly) Can we do something else now? Like... recess? Or maybe even nap time! (Yawns dramatically)

(Trying to keep the student engaged) You're right, he didn't get them.

So, what did the fox do *after* he couldn't reach the grapes? He didn't get the yummy grapes. What happened next?

(Crosses arms, glares)

He left! Duh! What else was he gonna do? Stand there all day? (Mumbles under breath) Stupid teacher asking stupid questions...

He probably went to find, like, a juicy burger or something. Grapes are gross anyway.

(Ignoring the grumbling) He left! You're right! And what did he *think* about the grapes when he left? This is the last question about the story, I promise. What did he think about the grapes when he walked away? The story tells us.

(Taps fingers impatiently on the desk, looking up at the ceiling)

(Mumbles) Sour... he said they were sour. (Raises voice, annoyed) Because he couldn't get them! So they *had* to be sour, right? Otherwise, he'd be sad he couldn't get them. (Scoffs) Grown-ups are so dumb! (Looks directly at the teacher with a challenging stare)

(Smiling warmly) Okay, great job remembering that! He thought the grapes were sour.

So, the fox wanted something, he tried to get it, he couldn't, and then he said he didn't want it anyway.

Why do you think he said the grapes were sour? Even though he wanted them before?

(Sighs dramatically, slumps in chair)

(Mumbles) 'Cause he's a loser! (Raises voice, louder) I don't know! Maybe he's just stupid! Or... or maybe he's lying! He probably REALLY wanted them, but he didn't want anyone to know he couldn't get them. (Looks around nervously) Like... like he's embarrassed! Yeah, embarrassed! Is that the right answer? Can I go now? My tummy hurts. (Clutches stomach dramatically)

(Nodding thoughtfully) Embarrassed... that's a good word for it. He was probably feeling a little embarrassed.

Do you think it's good to pretend you don't want something just because you can't have it?

(Looks away, starts picking at a scab on knee)

(Mumbles) I dunno... (Pauses, then blurts out) Sometimes! Yeah! Like... like if someone has a toy you REALLY want, but they won't let you play with it! You just say it's a stupid toy anyway! (Scowls) 'Cause they're being mean! It's not fair! (Eyes well up slightly, voice trembling)

(Softly) That makes sense. It doesn't feel good when someone won't share, does it?

So, what do you think this story, "The Fox and the Grapes," is trying to teach us? What's the lesson we can learn from it? It's okay if you don't know. We can talk about it more.

(Wipes eyes with back of hand, sniffs)

(Glares defiantly) I DO know! It's... it's about... (Struggles to find the words, face contorted in frustration) ...it's about how people are mean! And... and how things are unfair! (Voice cracks) And... and how if you can't get something, you just... you just pretend you didn't want it anyway! So you don't feel... (Voice trails off, almost a whisper) ...so you don't feel so bad.

(Looks at the teacher with a pleading expression) Can I PLEASE go now? I really don't feel good.

(Kneeling down to be at eye level) You're right, it *is* about how it feels when you can't get something you want, and how it's easy to say you didn't want it anyway.

But maybe, *maybe*, the story is also telling us that it's important to keep trying, and to not give up too easily. And maybe, if you *do* give up, it's okay to be a little sad, but it's not good to pretend that the thing you wanted wasn't good at all.

So, a lesson from the story could be that nothing comes easy and you shouldn't hate what you can't have.

Do you understand now?

<finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Proud Rose! That was a good effort.

Now, tell me, who are the two main characters in the story?

(Fidgets with my pencil, eyes darting around the room)

Uh... (stuttering) ...rose... and... and the... uh... spiky thing? The... (scratches head) I know it! (Taps pencil on the desk loudly)

(Smiling encouragingly)

Yes! You're almost there! The spiky thing is called a... ? Remember? We just read it. It starts with a "Cuh" sound.
(Rolls eyes) Cactus! Yeah, yeah, the rose and the dumb cactus. (Swings feet under the desk impatiently) Can we be done now? I wanna go play! What's for lunch? (Looks longingly out the window)

(Chuckles softly)

We're almost there, just a few more questions! And then you can go play. We have pizza for lunch!

So, the rose and the cactus. How did the rose treat the cactus? Was she nice?

(Scoffs loudly) Nice? (Throws hands up in the air dramatically) Nice?! Are you KIDDING me? She was super mean! She was always like, "Ooh, look at my pretty petals!" and "You're all spiky and ugly!" (Pouts, mimicking a whiny voice) "Nobody likes you!" (Crosses arms, looking away stubbornly) She was a BIG meanie! The other plants tried to tell her to be nice, but she didn't listen!

(Nodding slowly)

Okay, so the rose was not very kind. Why do you think the rose acted that way? What did she think about herself?

(Starts drawing on the desk with the pencil)

'Cause she thought she was, like, the BEST EVER. She thought she was super pretty and the cactus was just a... a dumb old... plant! (Looks up, a spark of curiosity in eyes) Why *is* a cactus so spiky anyway? Is it to keep animals from eating it? (Immediately loses interest) Oh, whatever. She was just showing off. (Continues drawing)

(Bringing focus back to the story)

Yes, she was showing off. So she was very proud.

Now, what happened when the summer got really hot and there was no water? What happened to the rose?

(Starts humming loudly to himself, then suddenly stops)

Oh! Oh, yeah! The rose... (Thinking) ...she got all droopy and sad! (Looks up, eyes wide) Like when I don't get dessert! (Whines slightly) She started to... uh... (Looks around, distracted by a fly buzzing near the window) What were we talking about? Roses? Yeah, she got all... shriveled! (Makes a disgusted face) Ewww.

(Smiling patiently)

Yes, she got shriveled. And who had water? Who was helping the sparrows?

(Taps foot impatiently)

The cactus! Duh! The dumb ol' cactus had water 'cause it's, like, a water hog or something. (Giggles) A water hog! And it was giving it to the birds. (Raises hand suddenly) Can *I* have some water? My throat is, like, super dry! (Forces a cough) *Cough cough*

(Points to a water fountain)

You can get water after we finish talking about the story, okay?

So, the cactus had water and was helping the birds. What did the rose do then? Did she stay proud, or did she do something else?

(Sighs dramatically, slouching in the chair)

She... (Thinking hard, furrowing brow) She asked for water! (Looks surprised) Yeah! She was all like, "Oh, please, Mr. Cactus, I'm gonna die! Give me some water!" (Giggles) Serves her right for being so mean! (Claps hands together excitedly)

(Nodding encouragingly)

And did the cactus help her? Even after she was so mean?

(Looks away, fidgeting)

Yeah... (Mumbles) The stupid cactus helped her. (Picks at a loose thread on his shirt) Why'd it do that? The rose was a jerk! (Kicks the desk lightly) I wouldn't have helped her! (Looks up defiantly)

(Leaning forward slightly)

That's a good question. Why *did* the cactus help her? Even though the rose was mean? What does that tell you about the cactus? What kind of plant was the cactus?

(Sighs, looking bored)

Ugh, I don't know! (Throws hands up again) Maybe it was just... nice? (Looks up, thinking) Or maybe it was, like, trying to be a good example or something. (Shrugs) I still wouldn't have helped her. She was a meanie! (Starts humming again, quieter this time) Can I get my water now? And pizza? Please? (Gives the teacher a pleading look)

(Smiling)

dialogue:
Okay, let's talk about the story!

What was Molly going to do with the milk?

(Jumping up and down, almost tripping) Milk! Molly had milk! She was going to sell it! Sell it! (Runs a few steps away from the teacher and back) So much money! (Uses a big word) Anticipating a lot of dough!

(Looks away, fiddling with fingers) Uh... to get... uh... chicken! Yeah! And then... more money! (Eyes widen) I would get, like, a HUGE chicken! Bigger than you! (Giggles loudly).
(Smiling) Wow, you remembered a lot! Yes, Molly wanted to sell the milk. And what did she want to buy with the money from the milk? You said chicken! Why did she want a chicken?

(Sticks tongue out slightly) Duh! Chickens lay eggs! (Starts pacing in a small circle). And eggs are... are like... (struggling to articulate) a *recurring* revenue stream! More money! (Confidently) Like... like a money tree! Only with eggs! (Dramatic pause) I'd get, like, a gold egg! (Scoffs) The other milkmaids would be SO jealous! (Crosses arms) They're all dumb! (Starts biting nails, nervously). Uh... is it lunchtime yet? This is BORING!

(Chuckles softly) Okay, deep breaths! It sounds like Molly was dreaming about all the money she *might* get. But what happened to the milk while she was dreaming? What happened on her way to the market?

(Suddenly slams hands on desk, startling self and teacher) IT SPILLED! (Immediately shrinks back, looking nervous). Sorry. (Mumbles) Spilled. (Starts tapping foot rapidly). All gone! (Voice gets louder again) Because she was too busy... too busy thinking about... (rolls eyes) dumb chickens and eggs! (Sighs dramatically). It's obvious! (Gets a faraway look). Like if I had a pet dragon that breathed money, I wouldn't trip and fall and let all the money fly away! (Asks suddenly, voice filled with panic) Do... do dragons breathe money?
(Reassuringly) No, dragons don't breathe money. But you are exactly right! The milk spilled. Why did it spill, you think? Because of the dragon?

(Giggles, relieved) No silly! Not 'cause of a dragon! (Stands up and starts walking around). Because she was all... floaty and dreamy! Not watching where she was going! Skipping! (Pulls face) Who skips? That's dumb. (Pauses, thinking). She was too busy (uses a fancy word) *visualizing* all the money she was gonna make! (Stops walking, looks directly at teacher). It's kinda like when I'm building a HUGE Lego tower and I get distracted by a shiny thing and then the whole thing falls down! (Face crumples, close to tears) IT'S THE WORST! (Sniffs loudly). Can... can we build a Lego tower now? Please? (Pulls sleeve and tugs)

(Sympathetically) I know it's the worst when your Lego tower falls! But let's finish talking about Molly first. So, the milk spilled because she was too busy thinking about the future. What did Molly have left at the end of the story?

(Pouts, dragging feet) Nothing! (Throws hands up in the air) Zilch! Nada! Bupkis! (Voice gets whiny) Just an empty pail! And probably a big mess! And maybe her mom yelled at her! (Starts picking at a loose thread on shirt). I bet her mom was SUPER mad! (Frowns). My mom gets mad when I spill juice. Especially grape juice. It stains! (Looks up suddenly, eyes wide) Did the milk stain her dress? Oh no! Then her mom would REALLY be mad!

(Gently bringing the student back to the story) You're right, she had nothing. And her mom probably wasn't too happy. What did Molly's mom tell her at the end of the story? Do you remember those words?

(Scrunches up face, thinking really hard) Uh... uh... something about... chickens? (Suddenly perks up) "Don't count your chickens before they hatch!" (Beams proudly, then immediately deflates). What does that *mean*? Is it like... like you can't count chickens 'cause they run around too much? (Starts flapping arms like a chicken, making clucking noises). Bawk bawk bawk! Try and count *me*! (Runs behind the teacher's chair).

(Chuckles) You're a very fast chicken! The saying means... well, Molly was counting on something *before* it happened, right? She was counting on the eggs and the money *before* she even had the chicken. So, her mom was saying, don't depend on something until you're sure it will happen. Does that make sense?

(Peeks out from behind the chair, looking confused) So... so like... I shouldn't tell everyone I'm going to build the TALLEST Lego tower EVER... (Voice trails off) ...before I actually build it? 'Cause maybe it will fall down? (Comes out from behind the chair, looking thoughtful). Or... or if I promise to share my candy with Tommy, but then I eat it all... that's like counting my chickens before they hatch? (Looks at teacher, anxiously). Did I do it right? Did I understand? (Starts chewing on nails again).

(Smiling encouragingly) Yes! You got it! Don't tell everyone about the tall tower until you build it. And don't promise Tommy candy if you might eat it all yourself! You understood perfectly. So, what's the lesson of the story? What does the story teach us? What should Molly have done?

(Stops chewing nails, brightens up again) Okay, okay! I know! (Paces back and forth, thinking). She should have... (Snaps fingers) ...focused on the MILK! (Points accusingly at an imaginary Molly). Pay attention, Molly! (Sighs dramatically). And she shouldn't have skipped! Skipping is dangerous! (Thinks harder). And... and she shouldn't have been so greedy! Wanting all that money and chickens and stuff! (Suddenly gets excited). So, the lesson is... (takes a deep breath) ...pay attention to what you're doing, don't be a show-off, and don't be greedy! (Beams proudly). I'm REALLY smart! (Suddenly remembers the Lego tower). Can we PLEASE build Legos now? I'll share! I promise! (Looks nervously at teacher, then quickly adds) ...unless I get distracted by a shiny thing! Ha ha! (Bites lip).

(Smiling) You *are* really smart! You figured out the lesson perfectly. It's about focusing on what you *have* and not just dreaming about what *might* be. And it's about not depending on things before they happen. Molly should have focused on selling the milk *first* before planning what to buy. You understood the story and its lesson very well. <finish>
