dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about the owl.

What did the old owl do every day?

(Bouncing my leg nervously, looking around the room) Ummm... the owl... (Stuttering) he... he saw things? Like... lots of things near his tree? And... and people talked! Really loud, sometimes! (Raises hand, even though I'm not sure if I have a question) Did he see squirrels? Were they fighting? 'Cause squirrels fight *all* the time in my backyard! (Confidently) It's super noisy!

(Smiling patiently) Yes, you're right! He saw lots of things near his tree, and he heard people talking. Good job!

Were you able to understand what the owl saw and heard all day?

Forget about the squirrels for a minute. Let's just focus on what the story tells us. What ELSE did the owl do besides seeing and hearing? Did he talk a lot?

(Fidgets with my pencil, tapping it loudly on the desk.) Talk? (Looks away, then back suddenly) NO! He didn't talk! The story said... uh... (Squints, trying to remember. Voice gets louder) He saw more, and talked LESS! He was like a SUPER-SPY! (Eyes widen with excitement) Maybe he had a tiny microphone and he recorded *everything* everyone said! Was he a spy, teacher? Did the story say he was a spy?! (Starts tapping pencil again, faster this time). The stories are boring, the spies are cool!

(Chuckles softly) You have a great imagination! The story doesn't say he was a spy, but it *does* say he talked less.

Now, why do you think he talked less, even though he saw and heard so much? What happened because he was quiet and watched and listened? What did he become? The story tells us.

(Sighs loudly, slumping in my chair). Ugh, this is boring! (Scowls, then looks up with a spark of mischief) Maybe he talked less 'cause he had a sore throat! My throat hurts sometimes and then I *can't* talk! (Whispers conspiratorially) Maybe he yelled too much at the squirrels! (Sits up straight, suddenly) Wait! (Taps head with pencil) I remember! The story said... he became... (struggling to remember) ... a... a... (Points finger triumphantly) ...a WISER owl! (Looks around, pleased with myself) Does that mean he was a superhero? Wiser sounds like a superhero name!

(Nods encouragingly) Yes! He became a wiser owl. That's right!

Now, why did seeing and hearing so much, and talking less, make him wiser? What does "wiser" mean? Think about it. Is a wise person silly, or smart?

(Rolls eyes). Obviously, wise people are smart! Duh! (Crosses arms) But... (Uncrosses arms and picks at a loose thread on my shirt) How does seeing stuff make you smart? I see my brother all the time, and he's still super dumb! (Giggles) Maybe the owl just had really good glasses. Or maybe he cheated on the owl test! Did they have tests for owls back then? (Looks at the teacher expectantly) I bet he cheated! Everyone in my class cheats sometimes! (Looks around shiftily).

(Smiling) Okay, let's not worry about cheating right now. Think about *what* the owl saw and heard. He heard stories and saw things happening.

Do you think he learned something from watching and listening? Do you learn things when you watch and listen? Maybe about how to be a good friend, or what happens when you don't share?

(Pulls a face, scuffing my shoe on the floor). Friends are dumb. They steal your crayons! (Pauses, thinking) Okay, sometimes I watch TV and I see kids sharing their toys. And then they're happy. (Shrugs) But that's just TV. Real kids don't share! (Suddenly points excitedly) Maybe the owl learned that squirrels are always fighting! That's important! If you know squirrels fight, you can stay away from them and not get bitten! (Looks pleased with this observation) That's being wise, right? Not getting bitten?

(Nods slowly) Yes, that's *one* way to be wise - learning to avoid trouble! You're right!

But think bigger. The owl saw and heard *lots* of things, not just squirrels. He learned about all sorts of things. And because he didn't talk so much, he had more time to *think* about what he saw and heard.

So, what do *you* think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Sighs dramatically, leans back in chair). Ugh, "big ideas" are the WORST! (Taps fingers on desk impatiently) I guess... I guess the story is trying to say that if you just shut up and watch, you'll get smarter? (Shrugs) But that sounds boring! I like talking! Talking is way more fun than watching squirrels fight! (Gets an idea, eyes lighting up) Maybe the story is wrong! Maybe the owl was just pretending to be wise so everyone would leave him alone! Then he could secretly play video games all day! (Giggles) Yeah! That's probably it!

(Smiling gently) Well, it's good to have your own ideas! But let's think about it a little more. It's not just about "shutting up." It's about *listening* and *observing*.

If you listen carefully to your teacher, do you learn more? If you watch how other kids play nicely, do you learn how to be a good friend?

Sometimes, talking less helps us to learn more. Can you see that?

(Looks down at my shoes, kicking them lightly against the chair legs). (Mumbling) I guess... but it's still boring. (Looks up suddenly, with a mischievous grin) Unless... unless you're listening to someone tell a *really* good story! Like a story about ninjas! Or pirates! Or maybe... (voice trails off, daydreaming) ...a *super-wise* owl ninja pirate! (Giggles quietly to myself). Can *I* tell you a story now? I have a *really* good one about a superhero with laser eyes who fights a giant robot made of broccoli! It's way better than that owl story!

(Chuckles) Okay, okay, I understand you like exciting stories! But before we get to the broccoli robot, let's just finish up with the owl.

So, the owl watched and listened, and that made him wiser. The story wants us to learn that talking less and paying attention can help us learn and understand things better. It doesn't mean you can *never* talk, just that sometimes it's good to listen first.

Do you understand that a little better now? Does that make sense?

(Nods slowly, looking unconvinced). I guess so. (Pulls out a small, crumpled toy car from my pocket and starts rolling it across the desk). So... can I tell you about the broccoli robot *now*? He has a laser cannon, and he shoots... (makes laser sound effects) ...*Pew! Pew!* ...at the superhero, but the superhero is super fast, so he dodges all the broccoli lasers! It's *really* cool! The broccoli robot is powered by spinach, which is his weakness! (Continues to make car noises and laser sounds, mostly ignoring the teacher now). Vroom! Pew! Vroom!

(Smiling, recognizing the need to end the lesson) Alright, it sounds like you have a very exciting story! Maybe you can write it down later.

For now, I think you understand the owl story. You know that the owl was wise because he watched and listened. And you know that sometimes, talking less can help us learn.

Good job today! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends."

First, can you tell me, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?

(Fidgets with my pencil, tapping it loudly)

Uh... (looks away) Lonely? I guess. (shrugs) He was looking for friends, right? But... monkeys are dumb. Why would he wanna swing in trees anyway? That's... (starts drawing on the desk with the pencil) ...stupid. I can run faster than anyone! Even the teacher! (giggles loudly)

(Chuckles softly) Okay, okay, let's focus on the story for now. You're right, the elephant was lonely.

Why do you think the elephant wanted friends?

(Stops drawing, but keeps tapping the pencil)

Why does anyone want friends? (rolls eyes) So they can... like... give you their snacks? (pauses, thinking) ...Or maybe so you can boss them around! Yeah! (grins) Like, I could tell a rabbit to dig me a hole! That would be awesome! (starts bouncing my leg nervously) The elephant was probably just bored anyway. (sighs dramatically)

Okay, those are some interesting ideas about friendship! Sometimes, friends do share, and sometimes they help each other.

In the story, why *didn't* the other animals want to be friends with the elephant at first? What did they say?

(Scoffs)

Ugh, I *know* what they said! (taps foot impatiently) The monkey was all like, "You can't swing!" (makes a face) And the rabbit was being a baby 'cause the elephant was too big for its hole. (mutters) Stupid rabbit. And the frog... jumpy, jumpy... (mimics jumping with my hands) It was dumb! They were all dumb! (voice gets louder) The elephant could squish them all if he wanted! (nervously glances at the door)

You're right, they all said the elephant was too different. The monkey said he couldn't swing, the rabbit said he was too big for the burrow, and the frog said he couldn't jump.

So, how did the animals feel about the elephant *before* the tiger came?

(Picks at a loose thread on my shirt)

They didn't like him! (states matter-of-factly) They were mean! They were all... (searches for the right word) ...rejecting him! Like when... (trails off, looking down) ...nevermind. They were just being mean! (slams the pencil on the desk) Stupid animals! He should have just stomped on them all! (eyes widen slightly, then looks away again)

Okay. It sounds like you think they weren't being very nice.

What happened *after* the tiger came? What did the elephant do?

(Suddenly sits up straighter, eyes wide)

The tiger! Yeah! He was gonna eat them all! (voice gets excited, then nervous again) Rawr! (makes a clawing motion) But the elephant... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...KICKED HIM! (punches the air) He kicked the tiger RIGHT AWAY! (grins widely) The tiger probably cried! (laughs loudly) He deserved it! (mood swings to anxious) Oh no... Tigers are scary... (starts biting fingernails)

That's right! The elephant kicked the tiger and scared it away.

How did the other animals feel about the elephant *after* he scared away the tiger?

(Stops biting my nails, suddenly interested)

They liked him! (says it quickly) They were all like, "Oh, Elephant, you're so great!" (mimics a high-pitched, whiny voice) "You saved us!" (rolls eyes) They were probably just pretending 'cause they were scared of the tiger! (taps fingers on the desk, thinking) But... (a slight smile creeps onto my face) ...it was still cool that the elephant kicked him. He showed them! (confidence returning)

Yes, they realized he was helpful and brave.

So, they didn't want to be friends with him because he was different. Then he saved them. What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Sighs dramatically and leans back in my chair)

Ugh, lessons. (rolls my eyes) Is this gonna be on the test? (frowns) Fine. (grumbles) Maybe... maybe it's about... (struggles to articulate) ...that even if someone is different... and they can't swing in trees or fit in holes... (pauses, looking thoughtful for a moment) ...they can still be... useful? (shrugs) And maybe... (hesitates) ...maybe you shouldn't be mean to them just 'cause they're different. (looks down at my shoes) But... (voice gets louder again) ...elephants are still way cooler than rabbits! (crosses arms defiantly)

You're getting very close! You're right, it *is* about how even if someone is different, they can still be useful and you shouldn't be mean to them.

Think about it this way: The animals were looking for friends who were just like them. But the elephant was different. He was big, and strong. That's what made him able to help when the tiger came!

So, what do you think the story is saying about what makes a good friend? Does a friend have to be exactly like you?

(Starts humming loudly, then stops abruptly)

No! (says it with conviction) A friend doesn't have to be exactly like you. That would be boring! (grimaces) Like, if I had a friend who was *always* quiet... (shudders) ...I'd go crazy! (pauses, thinking) But... (taps fingers on the desk) ...they should still... like... share their snacks. (a small smile appears) And not be dumb. (frowns again) And they should be able to run fast. (eyes light up) Really, really fast! So we can race! (bounces leg excitedly) And... (quieter now) ...maybe not be mean. (looks down, then quickly back up) Yeah! Definitely not mean! (nods firmly)

You've got it! The story shows us that friends don't have to be the same size or shape, or be good at the same things. What's important is being helpful and kind. Friends can be different!

So, we can say the moral of the story is, 'Friends can be any shape or size.'

dialogue:
Okay! Great job reading the story! That was a good one.

So, tell me, what did the girl in the story feel like at the beginning?

(Fidgets in seat, looks around the room) Uh... she... she was like... (scoffs) ...mad! Yeah! Mad! Like, really, *really* mad! Why she gotta bring a stupid egg, a potato and tea... (grumbles) that's dumb.
(Chuckles softly) Okay, "mad" is a good word! But the story says she was "frustrated." What does "frustrated" mean? Is it like when you can't get your shoes tied right?

(Rolls eyes) Yeah, yeah, like that. (starts tapping foot impatiently) It's like... when you CAN'T get what you want! (voice gets louder) Like, I want to go play outside RIGHT NOW, but I'm STUCK here talking about EGGS! (slams hand on the desk lightly, then looks nervous) Uh... sorry. (mumbles) Just... frustrated.

(Calmly) It's okay. I understand. So, she was frustrated with her life, just like you're a little frustrated now. What did her dad do to help her with her frustration? He didn't just say, "Stop being mad!" did he?

(Starts drawing on the desk with a finger) He made her... cook stuff? (Raises eyebrows, looks at teacher suspiciously) That's a dumb way to fix things. I would've just... told her to go play video games. (Shrugs) Way better than boiling potatoes. Did he even put salt in the water? (Thinking, picks at a loose thread on shirt) Probably not. That's why she was still mad.
(Smiling) Well, maybe *you* would have suggested video games! But her dad did the cooking thing. Tell me about the egg. What happened to the egg when it was in the hot water?

(Eyes light up a bit, leans forward) Oh! Oh! The egg... it got HARD! Yeah! Like... like a rock! (pounds fist on the desk again, then winces). He made the egg hard. (pauses, thinking, chews on lip) Why'd he wanna do that? Is that supposed to make her feel better? (Looks confused) I don't get it.
Okay, you're thinking! That's great! The egg *did* get hard. Now, what about the potato? What happened to the potato in the hot water? Was it hard, like the egg?

(Leans back in chair, sighs dramatically) Ugh, the potato... (Stares at the ceiling) It got all... squishy! Like... mashed potatoes! (Makes a face) I hate mashed potatoes! They're all gloopy and... (shudders) It was hard, and then it was SOFT! So... the egg got hard, the potato got soft. (Taps fingers on the desk, mumbling to self) Hard, soft... hard, soft... what's the big deal?
You're SO close! You got the egg, you got the potato. Now, what about the tea leaves? Did they get hard or soft?

(Looks at teacher like they're speaking a foreign language) Huh? Tea leaves? (Forces a cough) Um... (Stutters) T-they... they made... (Eyes widen) They changed the WATER! (Points excitedly) They made it... brown and... and TEA-Y! (Confidently) They changed the whole water! (Puffs out chest) See! I *was* listening! (Quickly glances away, nervous again) Was that right?

That's exactly right! The tea changed the water itself. So, the egg changed, the potato changed, and the tea changed the water.

Now, the important question. Her dad said that the egg, the potato, and the tea leaves are like us when we have problems. The hot water is like the problem, the "adversity" in the story.

So... if the hot water is the problem, what does that make the egg, the potato, and the tea leaves? What do *they* represent?

(Looks down at shoes, scuffing them against the floor) Represent...? (Mumbles) That sounds like... school work. (Sighs loudly)

(Looks up suddenly, eyes wide) Wait! (Snaps fingers) Maybe... maybe the egg is like... when you get all tough and mean 'cause you're mad? Like... like I was before? (Bites lip) And the potato is like... when you just give up and get all squishy and sad? (Voice gets quieter)

(Pauses, thinking hard) But the tea... the tea is like... like you change the problem itself! You make it... tea! (Looks proud for a split second, then shrinks back in chair) Is that... is that too weird? (Worried expression)

(Smiling brightly) That is *perfect*! Not weird at all! You got it! The egg gets hard, the potato gets soft, and the tea... changes the water.

So, if the egg, the potato, and the tea are like us when we have problems, what do you think the story is trying to *teach* us? What's the *lesson*?

(Scratches head, looking confused) Uh... don't boil eggs, potatoes, and tea at the same time? (Giggles nervously)

(Thinks for a second, then voice becomes serious) No, wait. It's like... you can be tough, or you can be a crybaby... (Frowns) But the BEST thing... (Looks up, making eye contact for the first time) The best thing is to change the problem! Like... like if I'm bored in class, I could ask a question... (Trails off, looking thoughtful) Change the water to tea! (Smiles slightly, then quickly looks away, embarrassed) Yeah... I think... I think that's it.

That's it exactly! You figured it out! We decide how to respond when things get hard. We can get hard like the egg, get soft like the potato, or…

(Pauses, prompting)

(Fidgets again, but this time with a little more energy, like a spark) Or... (Snaps fingers) ...or we can be like the TEA! And change the whole thing! (Grins, then quickly tries to hide it) So... can I go play video games now? (Asks hopefully)

(Chuckles) You got it! You understood the story and its message. That's fantastic!

Yes, you can go play video games now. You earned it! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Needle Tree! That was a good effort.

Now, let's talk about it. Can you tell me, who are the two main people in the story?

(Shifts in my seat, fiddling with my pencil. Avoids eye contact.)

Umm... (stuttering) well...there was... like... a tree... that talked? And... um... gold things?

(Looks away, then back at the teacher with a sudden burst of energy, speaking loudly)

But REALLY... why did the tree GIVE him the apples in the FIRST place? That's DUMB! Why not just, like, *not* give him anything if he's gonna be a jerk? (Crosses arms, scowling) It doesn't make ANY sense!
(Smiling gently) Okay, you're right, the tree *did* talk and there *were* golden things. But who were the two *people* in the story? Think about who was chopping wood.

(Rolls eyes dramatically, taps pencil loudly on the desk)

Ugh, fine. (Sighs heavily). There were... TWO... BORING... BROTHERS! (Suddenly stands up and starts pacing). The dumb one and the... dumber one! (Giggles loudly, then stops abruptly, looking anxious). Wait, that's not right... um... (Looks around the room, distracted by a poster). Is it almost recess yet? I'm hungry.
(Chuckles softly) It's okay, we're almost there! Let's just finish talking about the brothers first. You said there were two brothers. Was one older and one younger?

(Stops pacing and plops back down in chair, slumping).

(Grumbling) Yeah, yeah, yeah... Old and young... big deal. So the *old* one was gonna chop the tree! Why do we even CARE about this tree anyway? Trees are everywhere! What's so special about *this* one? Does it have, like, candy inside or something? (Starts digging in backpack). I bet I have candy in here...
(Gently redirects) Let's focus on the story, okay? You're right, the *older* brother was going to chop the tree. What did the tree *offer* him if he didn't chop it down? Do you remember?

(Rummages through backpack, pulls out a crumpled wrapper, then throws it on the floor)

(Muttering) I don't remember... I don't CARE... gold things, maybe? (Suddenly shouts) I TOLD you, the whole thing is DUMB! Why would the tree even TALK in the first place?! That's, like, SUPER unrealistic! (Starts tapping feet rapidly, looking increasingly agitated) I HATE this story!

(Remaining calm and patient) Okay, it's alright if you don't like the story very much. But let's just try to remember a few things about it. What did the tree give the older brother? Was it something shiny and yellow?

(Crosses arms again, glaring at the teacher)

Shiny... yellow... (pauses, thinking, then blurts out) Lemons! The tree gave him LEMONS! (Giggles again, then frowns). No... wait. Gold... apples! But they weren't enough! He's SO greedy! (Voice rising) He should be HAPPY with the gold apples! My mom says I have to be grateful for what I have! (Starts to tear up suddenly) It's NOT fair!
(Nods understandingly) You're right, he was greedy. The tree *did* give him golden apples, but he wasn't happy with them. What did he do *then*, after he got the golden apples?

(Sniffling, wiping nose with sleeve)

(Muttering) He... he... (voice cracks) ...he tried to cut the tree ANYWAY! He's MEAN! (Starts crying harder, hiding face in hands) He's just like... like... (sobbing) ...like the kids who take my crayons! It's NOT FAIR!

(Offers a tissue) It's okay to feel upset when things aren't fair. The older brother *was* being mean. What happened to him when he tried to cut the tree down *after* he got the golden apples? What did the tree do?

(Takes the tissue, dabbing at eyes)

(Sniffling) The tree... (pauses, thinking, eyes widening slightly)... the tree... got MAD! And it... it... SHOT needles at him! OUCH! That would HURT! (Suddenly grins mischievously) He deserved it! He was being a BIG MEANIE!
(Smiling) He *did* deserve it, didn't he? And then what happened? Who helped him after he was covered in needles?

(Eyes dart around the room, losing focus again)

(Mumbling) Needles... ow... birds? Do birds like needles? Maybe they build nests with them... (Suddenly remembers) Oh! The... the... younger brother! He helped him! He took out all the prickly things! He was nice! (Looks up at the teacher, a flicker of interest in their eyes) But... WHY did he help him? The older brother was MEAN to him! That doesn't make ANY sense!

That's a very good question! Why *do* you think the younger brother helped him, even though the older brother was mean? What kind of person do you think the younger brother was? Was he mean too, or something else?

(Thinks hard, chewing on the end of the pencil)

(Frowns, then speaks slowly, carefully) He was... not mean. He was... (struggling to find the word) ...kind? He... he didn't want his brother to be hurt, even if his brother was a... a butthead. (Looks at the teacher nervously, then quickly adds) Is "butthead" a bad word? Did I say a bad word? I didn't mean to! (Starts fidgeting again)

(Chuckles softly) "Butthead" isn't the *nicest* word, but it's okay. The important thing is you're understanding the story. You're right, the younger brother was *kind*. He helped his brother even when his brother wasn't nice to him.

What happened *after* the younger brother helped him? Did the older brother stay mean?

(Relieved, stops fidgeting for a moment)

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed) Hmmm... After? (Snaps fingers) Oh! He said sorry! The older brother... FINALLY... said sorry! He was ALL covered in needles and hurting, and THEN he was nice! (Rolls eyes) Should've been nice in the first place! (Pauses, then a slow smile spreads across face) Did the tree give them MORE gold apples then? Did it? Did it reward them for being nice... finally? Because that's what *should* happen!

(Nods encouragingly) You're exactly right! Because the older brother *finally* apologized and was kind, the tree gave them even *more* golden apples!

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big lesson?

(Taps pencil thoughtfully, then looks up, a bit more confident than before)

(Speaks a little slower and more clearly) Hmmm... (Thinking) Maybe... maybe it's saying that... if you're mean... bad things will happen? Like getting needles stuck in you! (Winces) And... if you're nice... even if it's after being a big, mean jerk... (pauses, then smiles slightly) ... you get rewarded? Like with... shiny, yummy, GOLDEN APPLES! (Eyes widen) And... and maybe it's about... not chopping down talking trees? (Giggles) Because that's just... mean! (Looks at the teacher expectantly, hoping for approval)

(Beaming) You got it! It *is* about being kind, and you're right, being mean can lead to bad things. So, what's better: being mean, or being kind? And what do you think happens when you are kind to others?

(Sits up a little straighter, looking almost engaged)

(Speaks with more conviction) Being KIND is better! (Nods head emphatically) Because... because if you're kind... people like you! And... and you get gold apples! (Giggles) And... you don't get needles stuck in you! (Suddenly deflates slightly) Unless... unless the other person is still mean... then it's not fair! Then you should get even MORE gold apples! (Looks at the teacher with a hopeful expression, then glances longingly at the door) Is it recess NOW? I'm REALLY hungry! I think being kind makes me want APPLES!

(Smiling warmly) Yes, being kind is definitely better. And it sounds like you understand the story and what it's trying to teach us. The story teaches us that "Kindness will always be rewarded". You did a great job working through that story with me, even though it was a bit tough at times. Now, yes, it's time for recess! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, [User's Name], that was a good job of reading! Now, let's talk about the story.

First, who was Midas?

(Starts swinging my legs under the desk, not making eye contact) Uh... (stuttering) wasn't he... like... a king? (Looks away, then blurts out confidently) A REALLY BIG king! He had, like, a crown and everything! (Pulls a face, wrinkling my nose) Kings are kinda boring though. Can we talk about something else? Like, did you see the super cool race car picture in that book over there? (Points vaguely towards a bookshelf).

Yes, Midas was a king! A big king with a crown. Good job!

But let's stick with the story for a few more minutes. What did Midas do that made Dionysus want to give him a wish?

(Sighs loudly and slumps further down in my chair). Ugh, this is boring. (Thinking, then speaking quickly) Something about... a goat-man? (Looks at the teacher expectantly, tapping my foot impatiently). I dunno. Was it a goat-man? Dionysus likes parties, right? Maybe he was at a party! (Starts humming to myself, drumming my fingers on the desk). Can I draw a picture of a race car now? It'll be way cooler than this story.

You're close! It wasn't exactly a goat-man, but a satyr. A satyr is like a man with goat legs.

Midas helped the satyr. Because of that, Dionysus offered him a wish. What did Midas wish for?

(Eyes widen, and sits up straight suddenly) A WISH?! (Grinning widely) I'd wish for a MILLION race cars! Vroom vroom! (Makes race car noises). Midas is dumb! (Scowls) He shoulda wished for that! But... (confused look) Did he wish for... candy? (Shrugs dismissively) I can't remember. It was something dumb, I bet. (Pulls out a crayon from my pocket and starts fiddling with it). Was it gold? Gold is kinda cool... but race cars are WAY cooler!

You remembered! It *was* gold. Midas wished that everything he touched would turn to gold.

Was that a good wish, do you think? Why or why not?

(Eyes light up again, excited) At first, it would be AWESOME! (Claps hands). Everything would be shiny and gold! I could have a gold race car! Gold crayons! Gold EVERYTHING! (Pauses, frowning slightly). But... (Thinking hard, furrowing brow) ...but then... (Looks up at the teacher, a little worried) ...could he still eat? Would his candy turn to gold? (Makes a disgusted face) Gold candy! Yuck! (Shrugs). Maybe it wasn't such a good wish after all. (Pushes the crayon across the desk, looking bored again) He shoulda asked for unlimited candy that *never* turns to gold. Now *that's* a good wish!
You're thinking about it! What happened when Midas tried to eat?

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about it.

First, tell me: What was the fox looking for?
(Swinging my legs under the desk, not making eye contact) Food! Duh. (Stops swinging legs and looks up, a slight frown on my face) He was hungry! Big deal. (Crosses arms)

You're right, he was hungry! And it *is* a big deal when you're hungry!

Where did he find the grapes?

(Looks away, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) Um... (stuttering) a... a... farmer's wall? I think? (Looks back, eyes narrowed) Why are you asking me this? It's boring! (Starts tapping my foot impatiently)

That's right, a farmer's wall! Good job!

Now, could the fox reach the grapes?
(Rolls eyes) No! (Confidently) He jumped and jumped and jumped! But he couldn't reach! (Leans back in chair, a smirk on my face) I knew that! This is easy!

You *do* know that! You're a super reader!

What did the fox do *after* he couldn't reach the grapes?

(Starts fidgeting, looking around the room) He... uh... (thinking, chewing on my pencil) went home? (Raises hand and waves it dismissively) Said they were sour anyway! I don't know! Can we be done now? I wanna go play! (Starts humming loudly)

Yes, he went home! And he said they were sour!

Why do you think he said the grapes were sour? Were they *really* sour?

(Scoffs, leaning forward) Of *course* they weren't sour! He just said that 'cause he couldn't get them! (Complex word, proud of myself) He's a loser! (Stands up suddenly) Can I go now? I finished! I know everything!

You are very smart!

So, the fox *wanted* the grapes, right? And he tried really hard to get them?
(Running towards the door) Yeah, yeah, yeah! Grapes, hungry, tried! Whatever! Bye! (Reaches for the doorknob)

Wait just one second! (Kindly but firmly)

Is it easy to get everything we want, *all* the time?
(Pauses at the door, foot tapping, clearly annoyed. Arms crossed) No! Duh! (Sighs dramatically) Now can I go?
Okay, almost done. So, if you can't get something, is it okay to say you didn't want it anyway? Even if you *did* want it? Think about the fox.

(Stares blankly, picking at a fingernail) I don't care about the fox! (Looks back at the teacher, a sudden flash of a clever idea) But... (Thinks beyond the given information) maybe he was trying to make himself feel better? 'Cause he failed? (Confidently) Like if I can't beat Tommy at tag, I'll just say tag is a stupid game anyway! (Smirks, pleased with the answer) Now can I *please* go?!

That's a *really* good example! You got it!

So, this story teaches us that it's okay if we can't always get what we want. And it also teaches us not to pretend we didn't want it in the first place! It is hard to get what you want, and sometimes you might not get it at all, so you shouldn't hate what you can't have.

Now, you can go play! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of the Proud Rose! That was a good story, wasn't it?

(Swings my legs under the table, looking around the room instead of at the teacher. I tap my pencil loudly on the desk.)

Now, what did the rose do to the cactus? Did she play nicely?

(Scoffs, rolling my eyes) Play nicely? (Confidently) Nah! She was being a meanie! (Uses a dramatic voice) She kept saying the cactus was ugly! Like, who even says that? (Starts drawing doodles on my worksheet instead of looking at the teacher.) It's not nice to say mean things!

You're absolutely right! It's *never* nice to say mean things. So, the rose was being mean to the cactus because she thought the cactus was ugly.

Why do you think the rose thought she was so much better than the cactus?

(Stops doodling, taps the pencil again, clearly impatient.) 'Cause she was pretty! (Uses complex words) Obviously! Roses are, like, super beautiful and stuff. All red and... and... smell good! (Thinks beyond the given information) And cacti are just... (makes a face) ...prickly and don't even smell like anything! (Shrugs, disinterested) Everyone knows roses are better.

Okay, so the rose thought she was better because she was pretty and smelled good, and the cactus was prickly.

Now, what happened when the hot summer came? What happened to the rose?

(Looks around the room again, completely disengaged.) Uh... (Stuttering) The... the sun came out? (Asks a question to the teacher) Does that mean summer? ( Confidently) The rose was all like...droopy! (Makes a droopy face and lets my arms hang limply.) 'Cause no water! I know that!

Yes, the sun came out and it was a very hot summer with no water. And you're right, the rose got droopy!

Now, what was the cactus doing while the rose was getting droopy? What was the cactus doing for the sparrows?

(Starts picking at a loose thread on my shirt, not making eye contact.) Sparrows? (Thinking) Uh... I dunno... drinking? (Confidently) The cactus had water, right? So they were, like, using it! (Uses significantly longer utterances) Probably splashing around and having a party! Birds always do that! I see them in my yard. They're super loud! Chirp, chirp, chirp all day! (Gets distracted and starts making chirping noises) Chirp! Chirp!

(Chuckles softly) Chirp! Chirp! Yes, the sparrows were drinking water from the cactus.

So, the rose was thirsty and droopy, and the cactus was helping the sparrows. What did the rose do then? Did she keep being mean, or did she do something different?

(Sighs dramatically, like this is taking forever.) Ugh, fine. (Uses complex words) She asked for help! (Rolls eyes, impatient) 'Cause she was, like, dying! (Confidently) Duh! What else was she gonna do? (Thinks beyond the given information) Die?! That's dumb! You gotta ask for help if you're gonna die! Everyone knows that!

You're right! She asked for help. And who did she ask for help from? The one she was mean to!

What did the cactus do when the rose asked for help?

(Taps the pencil rapidly again, impatient) (Confident) Gave her water! (Asks questions to the teacher) I mean, what did you *think* it would do? Let her die? That's a mean thing to do! That's right! The cactus shared its water. Even though the rose had been mean. You're a good friend to share your toys, even when your brother is mean sometimes!

Now, this is the important part. What do you think we can learn from this story? Why is it important to be nice, even to people who are different from us?

(Looks away, scuffing shoes on the floor.) (Stuttering) Uh... (Uses complex words) 'Cause... (Thinking) ...if you're mean, nobody will help you when you need it? (Shrugs, disinterested) I dunno. That's a *very* good start! You're right, if you're mean, people might not want to help you.

(Stops packing, but still doesn't look at the teacher.) (Scoffs) No! (Confidently) That's dumb! Being pretty isn't, like, everything! (Uses complex words) Pretty is boring! (Starts doodling again.)

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about the owl.

What did the owl like to do every day?

(Swinging my legs under the table, not really making eye contact) Uh... the owl? (Looks away, fiddling with my pencil) He... uh... he saw stuff. Yeah! He saw stuff near the tree. (Confidently) Like, a LOT of stuff! (Blurts out, excited) Did he see squirrels? I saw a squirrel in my backyard yesterday! It was HUGE! Bigger than my shoe! (Stops, realizing I went off-topic) Uh... but yeah, he saw things... near the tree. That's what the story said. (Looks back at the teacher, almost daring them to say I'm wrong).

(Smiling gently) That's right! He saw a lot of things near the tree. And squirrels might have been some of them! But what did the story say about *how much* the owl talked? Did he talk a lot, or a little?

(Sighs dramatically and slumps in my chair) Ugh, talking. (Scowls) I don't like talking. (Thinks for a second, then brightens) But the owl... he didn't talk a lot! (Points emphatically) He talked LESS! The more stuff he saw, the LESS he talked. Like, if he saw one thing, he talked a little. But if he saw a HUNDRED things... (Holds up ten fingers, then counts to ten again and again, losing track) ...then he talked like... zero! (Grins proudly). Is that right? (Looks at the teacher with anticipation)
Yes, that's absolutely right! The more he saw, the less he talked. Why do you think he talked less when he saw more things? What else did he do besides seeing things?

(Rolls my eyes) Ugh, WHY? (Stands up and starts pacing around the table, then pauses abruptly) 'Cause he was BUSY! He was seeing all the stuff! You can't talk and see stuff at the SAME time! That's like trying to draw AND eat a cookie! (Giggles) You get cookie crumbs on your paper!

(Sits back down, but keeps fidgeting) And... and the story said... (Scratches my head, struggling to remember) ...he HEARD things too! People talking and stuff. So he was seeing AND hearing. That's DOUBLE the busy-ness! (Looks up, pleased with myself) He was probably SUPER busy!
You're doing great! He was super busy seeing and hearing. Do you think hearing those people talk and seeing all those things helped him in some way? What do you think he learned from it all?

(Crosses my arms and leans back in my chair) Learned? (Wrinkles my nose) Learning is boring. (Stares at the ceiling, then back at the teacher, a thought popping into my head) Maybe he learned... secrets! (Lowers my voice conspiratorially) Like, maybe he heard someone saying where they hid their treasure! (Eyes widen, imagining it) Or maybe he saw someone stealing cookies from the cookie jar! He could tell on them! (Grins mischievously)

But... (Frowns) the story didn't say he told anyone. (Thinking) Maybe... maybe he learned to be quiet so he could hear EVERYTHING. Like a super-spy owl! (Confidently) Yeah! That's it! He was a spy owl who learned secrets by being quiet!

You're thinking about it in a really interesting way! He didn't tell secrets. He just watched and listened. The story says he became "wiser" day by day. What does it mean to be "wise?" Is it the same as knowing secrets?

(Shrugs) "Wise"? (Picks at a loose thread on my shirt) That's a weird word. It sounds like... wizened. Like an old prune! (Giggles)

(Stops giggling and thinks for a moment, then speaks slowly and carefully) Knowing secrets is... knowing secrets. (Makes a face) Being wise is... knowing what to DO with the secrets. (Looks up at the teacher, a little surprised by my own answer) Like... if you knew someone stole a cookie, being wise would be... maybe not telling on them, but helping them not steal cookies again. Or something. (Fidgets again, unsure if I'm making sense) Is that... wise? (Looks at the teacher expectantly).

That's a *really* good way to put it! Knowing what to *do* with what you see and hear. So, the owl saw and heard a lot. And he talked less. And that helped him become wise.

What do you think the story is trying to teach *us* about talking and listening?

(Starts tapping my foot impatiently) Ugh, teaching. (Rolls eyes again, but not as dramatically this time) You're always trying to teach me something! (Pauses, thinking)

Okay, okay. The story... (Looks at the floor, thinking hard) ... maybe it's saying that talking all the time isn't always the best thing. Like... sometimes, it's better to listen. Like the owl. He listened and watched, and that made him... prune-y... I mean, WISE!

(Brightens) So... maybe I should listen more and talk less? (Looks at the teacher skeptically) But talking is FUN! (Grins mischievously) Especially when I'm telling you about squirrels and cookies! (Winks) But... okay. I'll try to listen... a little bit more. (Looks away, already thinking about something else).

That's a great idea! It's good to talk and share your ideas, *and* it's good to listen and learn from others. The owl listened more than he talked.

So what do you think is the lesson of the story? What should we learn from the wise old owl?

(Sighs dramatically and slumps in my chair, then blurts out) Ugh! Lessons! I HATE lessons! (Crosses my arms and pouts)

(Then, after a moment, peeks up at the teacher with a mischievous glint in my eyes) Okay, okay! The lesson is... (Dramatically whispers) ...be a super-spy owl! Learn all the secrets! But don't tell anyone... unless they're stealing cookies! (Giggles)

(Then, more seriously, after a pause) Or... maybe the lesson is... listen more than you talk. So you can... become a wise prune... I mean, a WISE owl! (Grins, pleased with myself) Is that a good lesson? Did I pass the test? (Looks at the teacher expectantly).
Yes! That's a perfect lesson! Listen more than you talk. Be more observant. You understood the story very well. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of The Golden Egg! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it?

First, can you tell me, what kind of animal laid the golden egg?

(Swings my legs under the desk, looks around the room) Uh, yeah, sad. (Confidently) It was a... a... (Thinking, taps pencil on the desk) a bird! A big, feathery bird! Like a... a chicken? (Looks at the teacher expectantly, hoping for confirmation, but already moving on) But bigger, 'cause it laid *golden* eggs! Not just regular, boring eggs!

You're right, it was a bird! Even better, do you remember what kind of bird it was? Was it a chicken or something else? Look at the picture in the book.

(The teacher points to the picture of the goose in the book)

(Looks at the picture, then back at the teacher, unimpressed) That's easy! (Points at the book aggressively) It's a... (Makes a face) a GOOSE! (Rolls eyes) I knew that. So, can we do something else now? Like, recess? (Starts fidgeting with my shoelaces)

Yes, it was a goose! Excellent!

Now, tell me, what did the farmer do with the golden eggs?

(Confidently) He... he sold them! (Stands up abruptly) He got money! Lots and lots of money! (Starts walking around the classroom) Enough to buy... candy! And toys! And... (Forgets what I was saying, stares out the window) ...shiny stuff! (Sits back down with a thump) Is it almost time to go home?
Yes, he sold them and got money. Why do you think he sold them? What did the money help him do?

(Scoffs, like it's the most obvious thing in the world) Duh! Because... because he *needed* it! To buy stuff! Like I said, candy and toys! (Leans back in my chair, nearly tipping over) What else would he do with it? Keep it in a piggy bank forever? That's boring. (Asks teacher) Why are you asking so many questions? Can I draw a picture now? A picture of a rocket ship!
You're right, he needed the money to buy things. But the story said he and his wife "enjoyed a comfortable life". What do you think "comfortable life" means? Is it just about candy and toys?

(Frowns, clearly not happy with the question, starts picking at a loose thread on my shirt) "Comfortable life"... (Mumbles) Sounds... bo-ring! (Looks up, annoyed) Does it mean they had, like, a really big TV? Or a swimming pool? If it doesn't have candy and toys, then I don't care! (Crosses arms, looks away from the teacher)

It means they had everything they needed. They had enough food, a good house, and weren't worried about being poor.

So, they were doing well. Why did the farmer cut open the goose? What did he want?

(Eyes widen slightly, but mostly just looks impatient) He... he wanted MORE! (Raises hands in the air dramatically) More, more, MORE! Like when I want another cookie! (Lowers hands) He thought... (Stutters) h-he thought all the eggs were inside! He was a... a greedy guy! (Makes a disgusted face) Can I have a cookie now? (Points vaguely towards the area where snacks might be)

Yes, he was greedy. He wanted more, and he wanted it *fast*!

What happened when he cut open the goose? Did he find lots of golden eggs?

(Bursts out laughing) Nope! (Shakes head emphatically) Just... yucky stuff! Blood and guts! (Makes a gagging noise) He messed up big time! (Beams, clearly enjoying the farmer's misfortune) Serves him right for being greedy! So, what happens next? Does he get eaten by a monster? That would be cool!
He did mess up big time. And what happened *after* he messed up? What happened to him and his wife?

(Scowls, the fun is over) They... they got poor. (Mumbles) No more golden eggs... no more... shiny stuff. (Looks down at my desk, tracing patterns with my finger) They were dumb. (Looks up at the teacher) Can we read a different story now? One with a monster? Or a rocket ship? This story is sad *and* boring.

You're right, they got poor because they didn't have the golden eggs anymore.

So, the farmer wanted more and more, and because of that, he ended up with nothing. What do you think we can learn from this story? What is the story trying to teach us?

(Sighs dramatically, leans back in chair, looking totally uninterested) Ugh, a lesson? (Rolls eyes) Okay, okay... (Taps fingers on the desk, thinking for a whole two seconds) Don't be... (Struggles) ...greed-y? (Looks at the teacher for approval) Or... (Brightens up) ...don't cut open birds! 'Cause that's gross! (Giggles) Can I go play now? I learned the lesson! See?

You're close! It's not just about not being greedy, but thinking about what will happen *before* you do something. The farmer didn't think about what would happen if he killed the goose.

So, the lesson is to think before you act.

Do you understand why that's important?

(Stares blankly, then yawns loudly and stretches) Think... before... act...? (Tilts head, confused) But... thinking is hard! (Frowns) It takes too long! If I want a cookie, I just *take* the cookie! (Looks expectantly at the teacher, daring them to disagree) Why would I think about it? Thinking is for... for old people! (Starts humming loudly and drumming on the desk) Can I go now?

(Smiling gently) Sometimes thinking is hard, you're right. But if you thought about taking the cookie, you might remember that your mom said no cookies before dinner. And if you take it anyway, you might get in trouble.

So, thinking before you act can help you make good choices. Like the farmer, if you don't think, sometimes things can go wrong. Do you understand?

(Grumbling) "Good choices..." (Makes air quotes with fingers) Fine, fine! I get it! (Looks up with sudden inspiration) So, if I think *before* I act, maybe I can think about how to get *more* cookies! Without getting in trouble! (Grins mischievously) See? Thinking *can* be good! Can I draw my rocket ship now? I promise, I'll think about the colours first! (Grabs a crayon and starts scribbling without waiting for permission) Vroom! Vroom!
(Chuckles softly) Okay, that's a good way to think about it! I think you understand the story and its lesson now. You understand that thinking before acting can lead to better outcomes. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, wonderful reading! That was a good story, wasn't it?

So, can you tell me, who are the characters in the story?

(Wriggles in seat, looks around the room) Uh... yeah, it was okay. (Thinks for a long moment, tapping foot impatiently). Um... there was... the farmer! (Confidently) And the... the other farmer! The one who... who sold the well. And... and the boss man! The super important one! (Stands up suddenly) Can I go to the bathroom? I *really* gotta go!

(Chuckles softly) Okay, one second. Let's just finish this thought first.

You're right! There was the farmer, the neighbor who sold the well, and the "boss man," as you said - the emperor! Good job!

Now, quickly, before you go, can you tell me *why* the farmer went to the emperor? What was the problem?

(Sighs dramatically, eyes rolling) Ugh, *fine*. (Thinking, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) He went to the boss man... (Stands up again, takes a step towards the door) Because... because the other farmer... (Suddenly brightens, voice loud) He was being a *jerk*! (Points finger) He sold the well but wouldn't let him use the water! Can I *please* go now? It's *really* important! (Bounces on the balls of my feet)

(Smiling patiently) Yes, yes, you can go. That's exactly right! The neighbor was being a jerk and wouldn't let him use the water. Excellent! You understood. Go quickly to the bathroom. We can talk more when you get back!
(Bolts for the door, shouting over shoulder) Okay! But don't ask me too many questions! (Slams door a little too hard)

(Waiting patiently as the student returns, a bit calmer) Welcome back! Feeling better?

Okay, so you told me why the farmer went to the emperor. Now, what did the emperor's helper, the courtier, *say* to the neighbor? What question did he ask him?

(Saunters back in, plopping back into the seat with a thump, then leans back.) Yeah, much better! (Looks around, fiddling with a pencil on the desk.) Uh... (Scratches head) what did he say...? (Mumbles under breath) Something about the... (Suddenly blurts out) The water! (Confidently) He asked him if he sold the water too! (Grins, pleased with himself.) I knew that! Is it snack time yet? I'm starving.

(Chuckles) You *did* know that! Good job! He asked about the water.

And what did the neighbor *say* about the water? Did he say he sold it?

(Scoffs, rolling eyes) Noooo! (Leans forward, elbows on the desk, voice loud) He said he ONLY sold the WELL, not the WATER! He was trying to be sneaky! (Pokes the pencil aggressively into the desk.) He thought he was so smart! But he wasn't! (Looks expectantly at the teacher).

You're exactly right! He was trying to be sneaky.

So, what happened *after* the courtier talked to the neighbor? What did the courtier tell him to do? This is the tricky part!

(Starts drumming fingers on the desk, looking around, clearly impatient.) Ummm... (Thinking, chews on the end of the pencil) He... he told him to... (Suddenly, brightly) Pay! (Points excitedly) Pay for the water! Or... or take it all away! (Grins, pleased with himself again) He had to pay... (Frowns slightly) Wait... why did he have to pay?

Excellent! He had to pay for the water or take it all away.

Now, you're asking a very good question: *Why* did he have to pay? Think about what the courtier was trying to show the neighbor. Why would making him pay for the water show he wasn't being fair?

(Leans back again, stretching arms above head, yawning loudly) Hmmm... (Stares at the ceiling, completely disengaged for a moment, then snaps back) Oh! Oh! I know! (Sits up straight, voice loud) Because... because if he didn't own the water, he couldn't just leave it there! He had to pay to keep it in *someone else's* well! Right? (Looks at the teacher expectantly, almost bouncing in the seat) Is that right? Am I super smart?

(Smiling, nodding enthusiastically) You ARE super smart! That's exactly right!

So, the neighbor realized he was being unfair and trying to trick the farmer, didn't he? What did he do then?

(Pulls a face, clearly bored again.) Ugh, I know this... (Starts to doodle on the desk with the pencil). He... he... (Suddenly sits up straight, excited again) He said sorry! (Grins) He said he was wrong and went home! (Claps hands once, loudly) He learned his lesson! Can we be done now? My brain is tired! (Yawns again)

(Chuckles softly) He did say sorry and go home. He did learn his lesson!

So, let's think about the whole story. What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea or lesson we can learn from the farmer and the well? What happens if you try to trick people?

(Sighs loudly, leaning back in chair, staring blankly at the ceiling) Ugh, lessons... (Grumbling under breath) More lessons... (Suddenly sits up, snapping fingers) I know! (Points finger) Don't be a jerk! (Grins, proud of himself) If you're a jerk, you'll get caught! And you'll have to say sorry! (Shrugs) It's better to just not be a jerk in the first place. (Pauses) Is that it? Can I go play now?

(Smiling) That's very close! We can say it like this: "Cheating will get you nowhere." If you try to cheat someone, it won't work out for you in the end. Just like the neighbor!

You understood the story really well. We are done now. You can go play! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was a fun one, wasn't it?

Let's talk about it. First, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?

(Starts fidgeting, swinging my legs under the desk)

Umm... yeah, it was... okay, I guess. (Looks out the window, then back at the teacher)

The elephant... (thinking, chewing on my pencil) He was, like... wanting friends? Because he was alone. But... but the monkey was dumb! Who needs to swing in trees anyway? (Crosses arms, looks annoyed)
You're right! The elephant wanted friends and he was lonely. And you think the monkey was silly! Why did the monkey say no to being the elephant's friend?

(Rolls eyes)

Duh! (Confidently) Because the elephant can't swing! I already said that! The monkey's being a big meanie! Like... (pauses, searching for a word) ... a HUGE meanie! And rabbits are dumb too! (Starts tapping my foot impatiently) Can we be done now? This is boring. I wanna draw a picture of a spaceship! It's going to have lasers! Pew! Pew!

(Smiling patiently)

I know it can be hard to sit still. But we're almost done, and then you can draw your spaceship!

You're right, the monkey was being a meanie. And what about the rabbit? Why didn't the rabbit want to be friends with the elephant?

(Sighs dramatically)

(Mumbling) Because... something about a hole? Or... I don't know! (Raises hand suddenly) I have a question! If my spaceship crashes on the moon, will I need a special wrench to fix it? 'Cause I saw one in my dad's garage. It's HUGE!

(Completely changes the subject and leans forward eagerly) Will I need that huge wrench?

(Chuckles softly)

That's a great question for later! Let's finish talking about the elephant, and then we can talk about your spaceship and the wrench. Deal?

Okay, so you said something about a hole... The rabbit said the elephant was too big for its...?

(Grumbling) Fine. (Looks down at my shoes)

Too big... for the... (Struggling to remember) ... burrow! Yeah! He was too big for the rabbit's burrow! So the rabbit was being a dummy too! Elephants are way cooler than rabbits! They can kick tigers! (Beams proudly) Can a rabbit kick a tiger? No way!

You got it! The elephant was too big for the burrow.

So, at the beginning, did any of the animals want to be the elephant's friend?

(Shakes head vigorously, almost knocking my head against the desk)

Nope! They were all being super mean! The elephant was all alone. (Frowns slightly, then quickly reverts to a more energetic expression) But it's okay, 'cause he kicked the tiger! That's awesome! (Makes kicking motions with my foot under the desk)
That's right. No one wanted to be his friend at first. But then, what happened the next day in the forest? Why were all the animals running?

(Eyes widen, excited)

The tiger! He was gonna eat them all! RAWR! (Makes a clawing motion with my hand) The animals were all scaredy cats! But the elephant wasn't! He was brave! Did you see me draw a tiger before? I could draw one with HUGE teeth! Can I draw it now? Please? (Starts reaching for my crayons)

(Gently pushes the crayons back a little)

We're almost there! Yes, the tiger was scaring everyone. And you're right, the elephant was brave! What did the elephant do to the tiger?

(Bounces in my seat, struggling to stay focused)

He... he... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...KICKED him! Right in the butt! BOOM! (Punches the air lightly) And then the tiger ran away! He was so scared of the elephant! It was the best part! (Grinning widely)
It *was* a good part! And after the elephant kicked the tiger, did the other animals *still* think the elephant was too big, or couldn't swing, or couldn't jump?

(Thinks for a second, tapping my chin)

Umm... (Suddenly understands and gets excited again) ... NO! They liked him! They wanted to be his friend after all! Because he saved them! He was a super hero! Like my spaceship! (Claps hands together) So... does that mean I can draw my spaceship now? The one with the lasers that can shoot asteroids? Pleeeease?

Yes! They wanted to be his friend because he saved them. So, even though the elephant was big and couldn't swing or jump, he was *still* a good friend.

So, what does this story teach us about friends? Can friends be different sizes? Can they be good at different things?

(Starts gathering my crayons and paper)

Yeah, yeah... different sizes are okay. And kicking tigers is a good way to make friends! (Looks up, eyes sparkling) 'Cause if you save them, they'll wanna be your friend, even if you're, like, a giant elephant!

(Stands up, ready to start drawing)

Now can I REALLY draw my spaceship? I'm gonna make it super cool! It's gonna have rockets and maybe a robot dog too!

(Smiling)

Exactly! Friends can be different sizes and good at different things. You don't have to be able to swing in trees to be a good friend. Being brave and helpful is even better! Friends can be any shape or size!

Yes, you can *absolutely* draw your spaceship now! I can't wait to see it! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! That was a good story, right?

Now, tell me, what did the girl want from her father?

(Starts fidgeting with my shoelaces, glances around the room) Uh... yeah, the story was okay. (Looks away) She... she wanted something. Like... (stutters) ...advice? Because she was, like, super mad about stuff? I think so. (Confidently) I knew that! It's, like, totally obvious, right?

That's right! She wanted advice. And she was frustrated. Good job!

Now, what did her father ask her to bring him? Three things! Can you remember what they were?

(Sighs dramatically, kicks the chair a little) Ugh, this is boring. (Thinking, looks up at the ceiling) Okay, okay, let me think. (Snaps fingers) An egg! I remember that! (Points excitedly) And... and a... (frowns, looks down) ...a potato? Maybe? (Confidently) And something else... something... green? Like, leaves? Tea leaves! Yeah! An egg, a potato, and tea leaves. (Grins proudly) I'm super smart!

You ARE super smart! That's exactly right.

What did her father do with the egg, the potato, and the tea leaves?

(Stands up and starts pacing a bit, voice gets louder) He... he BOILED them! Duh! (Rolls eyes) He put them in, like, separate pots or something, with water. (Uses hands to gesture) And then... then he just... waited! (Confidently) It's, like, the easiest thing ever! Why are you even asking me this? (Running ahead of the information) Can we talk about something else now? Like recess?

Yes, he boiled them. Good!

After he boiled them, what did he say about the egg? What was different about it?

(Crosses arms, looks annoyed) Okay, fine. The egg... (Thinking, taps foot impatiently) The egg was... (Confidently, but with a bit of a snicker) ...hard! It was all squishy before, but then it got all hard! Like a rock! (Giggles) That's so weird. Why would you boil an egg to make it hard? Doesn't make any sense. (Starts to wander away from the desk) Can I go now? This is taking forever.

You're doing great! Yes, the soft egg became hard.

What about the potato? What happened to the potato when it was boiled?

(Stops wandering, but still looking impatient) Ugh, the potato... (Rolls eyes) ...it got all soft and mushy! (Makes a disgusted face) Yuck! Like baby food. (Confidently) So the egg got hard, and the potato got soft. Easy peasy! Now can I PLEASE go do something else? I'm, like, totally finished with this story. (Starts humming loudly)

Almost finished! Just one more thing about what happened, then we'll talk about what it *means*.

What happened to the tea leaves? Did they get hard or soft?

(Sighs loudly) The tea leaves... (Thinks for a moment, drumming fingers on the desk) They didn't get hard or soft, silly! (Scoffs) They... they changed the WATER! (Confidently) The water turned into... tea! (Beams proudly) I'm so good at this! Now can I go, like, REALLY go now? I'm missing important stuff!

Yes! The tea changed the water. That's very important.

Now, the father told his daughter that the egg, the potato, and the tea leaves were like... different ways to act when things get hard.

The egg started soft, but became hard. Is that a good way to be when things get hard?

(Starts picking at a loose thread on shirt, clearly not paying full attention) Hard, huh? Like... like being tough? (Confidently) Yeah! Being tough is good! You gotta be tough so nobody messes with you. (Puffs out chest) Like a superhero! Superheroes are always hard, like rocks! So, yeah, it's a good way to be! (Grins, waiting for approval) Now can I *please* go? I promise I'll be good! (Maybe).

Being tough can be good sometimes. But what if being "hard" also means you can't bend or change? The egg couldn't go back to being soft. Is that always a good thing? Think about it... If someone makes a mistake, should they be hard and not admit it, or should they be able to change?

(Frowns, clearly struggling to follow) Uh... (Looks away, scuffing shoe on the floor) Change? Like... like saying sorry? (Confidently, but with a hint of uncertainty) Saying sorry is for babies! You don't wanna be soft like the potato! (Pulls a face) But... (Thinking, bites lip) If you mess up SUPER bad... maybe... maybe you gotta say sorry? But only if it's, like, a REALLY big mess-up. Otherwise, you just gotta be tough! (Shrugs) I don't know! This is too hard! Can we just talk about superheroes again? They're way cooler than eggs and potatoes.
Okay, let's think about the potato. It started hard, but became soft. Is *that* always a good way to be? If you have a problem to solve, should you be soft and mushy, or strong and able to think?

(Shakes head emphatically) No way! Being soft is for losers! (Points accusingly) You said it yourself, it's like baby food! (Confidently) You gotta be strong and smart! Like... like Batman! He's not all mushy, he's got a plan! So the potato is the worst way to be. (Taps foot impatiently) This is so obvious! Why are we even talking about this? (Starts to whisper to self) Batman... Batmobile... gadgets...

You're right, being strong and smart like Batman is important. So, the egg got hard, maybe too hard, and the potato got soft, maybe too soft.

What about the tea leaves? They didn't get hard or soft, they changed the water itself! What do you think that means?

(Snaps fingers, suddenly excited) Ooh! Ooh! I know this one! (Voice gets louder) It means they're, like, magic! (Eyes widen) They changed everything! The water was boring, and then BAM! It was tea! (Confidently) So being like tea leaves means you're super powerful and can change the whole world! (Strikes a superhero pose) That's the BEST way to be! Way better than eggs and potatoes! (Beams, waiting for praise) Did I get it right? Am I a tea-leaf superhero?

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Needle Tree! That was a fun story, wasn't it?

Now, let's talk about it. What did the older brother do for work?

(Swings my legs under the table, then blurts out) He...uh... (looks away, distracted by a fly buzzing near the window) He... chopped... uh... wood! Yeah! Wood! (confidently) He chopped wood and sold it! In the market! (Stands up from the chair) Can I go to the bathroom? I really need to go!

(Chuckles softly, remaining patient) Yes, you can go to the bathroom in a little bit. Just one more question, okay? Let's finish talking about the wood.

That's right! He chopped wood. Good job! And where did he chop the wood? Do you remember?

(Sits back down with a huff, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) Ugh, fine. (Rolls eyes) In the... uh... (thinking, tapping my chin) Forest! (confidently) He chopped the wood in the forest! It was a REALLY big forest, probably bigger than your house! (Stands up again, excited) I bet there were bears and wolves and... and...

(Smiling) Yes, the forest was very big! You have a great imagination.

Okay, focus, just a little longer, please! What happened when the older brother was chopping wood in the forest? Did he meet anyone?

(Sits down heavily, slumping in the chair) (Sighs dramatically) Yeah, yeah, yeah... he met... (eyes dart around the room, spotting a colorful poster) He met a... uh... a talking tree! (grins, remembering the cool part) A magical talking tree! It gave him... (counts on fingers) ...a bunch of golden apples! But they weren't enough! He's so dumb! (crosses arms, pouting)
You're right! It was a magical, talking tree. And he got golden apples. Was he happy with the golden apples?

(scoffs) Happy? (Shakes head vigorously) No way! He was greedy! He wanted more! (Leans forward, getting animated) He was like, "Give me ALL the apples!" But the tree was like, "Nope!" And then... and then... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...needles! Zillions of needles! (Giggles loudly, then quickly covers mouth)
Zillions of needles, you're right! What happened to the older brother after the tree gave him needles?

(Looks down at my shoes, scuffing them on the floor) He... (mumbles) He was all... ouchy. (louder) He was lying on the ground, all covered in needles and stuff! It probably really hurt! (shrugs, looking indifferent) Serves him right! (Stands up again) Can I *please* go to the bathroom now? I'm gonna explode!
(Smiling gently) Okay, one last little thing. Who helped the older brother when he was hurt?

(Groans and plops back down, fidgeting) Ugh... his stupid brother! (Rolls eyes) The little goody-two-shoes one. He pulled out all the needles or something. (Looks away, uninterested) And then they got more apples. Happy ending. Bo-ring! Now, can I *PLEASE* go?!
(Chuckles) Almost there! You're doing great! Why do you think the little brother helped the older brother, even though the older brother was mean?

(Frowns, picking at my nails) Dunno. (Shrugs) 'Cause he's a loser? (Pause, then, thinking beyond the given information) Or maybe... maybe 'cause he's supposed to? Like, brothers are supposed to help each other, even if they're meanies. (Stands up, more insistent) But seriously, I REALLY gotta go now! It's an emergency!
(Nodding understandingly) That's a very good thought. So, what did the older brother do after his little brother helped him?

(Eyes the door longingly) He said sorry! Finally! But it took him, like, a million years to say it! (Starts bouncing on my toes) Can I GOOOOO now?! Please? I promise I'll be super quiet when I get back! (Pulls a puppy dog face)
(Smiling) Okay, okay! Go to the bathroom. We'll finish this when you get back, and then we'll be all done. Hurry back!
(Bolts for the door, yelling over my shoulder) YESSSSSS! Thanks! (Disappears down the hall)

(Waits patiently, gathering thoughts. Once the student returns...)

Welcome back! Feeling better? So, the older brother said sorry. What happened *after* he said sorry? Do you remember?

(Slides back into the chair, but sits on the edge, ready to bolt again) Yeah, yeah... he said sorry... and then... (thinking, tapping a finger on the desk) The tree gave them, like, a HUGE pile of golden apples! More than they could even carry! (grins mischievously) Probably stole some of them! (Looks up, waiting for permission to leave) Did I get it right? Can I go now? I'm, like, starving!

You got it exactly right! The tree gave them lots more apples.

Now, let's think about the whole story. The older brother was mean and greedy at first, and he got needles. Then he was sorry, and they got lots of apples. What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Sighs, clearly wanting to be anywhere else) Ugh, a lesson? Do stories always have to have lessons? (Rolls eyes) Fine! (Thinks for a moment, chewing on my lip) I guess... (Stands up again, pacing a little) ...that being mean doesn't get you stuff? And... and being nice... or at least saying sorry... gets you more apples? (Shrugs) Is that it? Can I go get a snack now? My tummy is rumbling really loud! (Makes a loud rumbling noise with my mouth to emphasize the point)

You're so close! You're right, being mean didn't get him anything good. And being sorry *did* get him something good. So, what's better, being mean or being nice? Which one gets rewarded in the story?

(Pauses, considering this for a brief moment, then brightens up, seeing the end in sight) Being NICE is better! 'Cause you get more apples! (Claps hands together once, definitively) Okay, I'm done! Can I go now? Please, please, PLEASE?! I promise I'll be super good for the rest of the day! (Gives the teacher my most charming, yet slightly mischievous, smile)

Yes! Being nice *is* better! And that's what the story is trying to teach us. Being kind and saying sorry can bring good things. We can say, "Kindness will always be rewarded.". You understood the story so well. Good job!

Yes, you can go get your snack now. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of King Midas! That was a fun one, wasn't it?

First, can you tell me, who gave King Midas the golden touch?

(Bouncing my leg nervously) Uh, yeah, it was... a story. (Looks away)

Dion... Diony... (Stuttering) The wine guy! He gave him the... the gold thing. (Starts looking around the room, distracted by a colorful poster)

That's right! Dionysus, the wine guy, gave him the golden touch. Good job!

Now, why did Dionysus give Midas a wish? Do you remember what Midas did first?

(Sighs loudly) I don't care! (Crosses arms) Just wanted... wanted stuff to be gold. Shiny! (Starts tapping my foot impatiently, not making eye contact) He helped some... someone. I dunno! Can I go play now? (Voice gets louder)

(Softly) Hey, it's okay. Stories can be tricky. You *are* right. Midas *did* want shiny gold things. But let's think... why did Dionysus *offer* him a wish in the first place? Maybe try to remember that part? It was because of something good Midas did. Try to remember.

(Rolls eyes) Ugh, fine! (Thinking, then blurts out) ...Satyr! He helped a... a Satyr! So what? (Shrugs and picks at a loose thread on my shirt) Does that mean I get a wish if I help someone? I want a pony! And a robot! And... (Trails off, getting distracted again)

Yes! You remembered he helped the Satyr! Good job.

Now, what did Midas wish for? What did he want more than anything?

Gold! (Confidently) Everything gold! Like my shoes! (Points to my shoes) Shiny! More shiny than yours! (Giggles loudly, then suddenly frowns) But then... (Frowns) He couldn't eat. (Voice gets quiet and anxious) I like eating. I don't want gold food. (Starts chewing on my fingernails)

You're exactly right! He wanted everything to turn to gold.

And you're also right that he couldn't eat. Why couldn't he eat? What happened when he tried to eat?
(Shouts) It turned into GOLD! Duh! (Starts fidgeting in my seat) Like, even the pizza! (Makes a disgusted face) Gold pizza? Yuck! That's stupid! (Kicks the chair in front of me lightly)
Gold pizza *would* be yucky! So, was the golden touch a good thing for Midas? At first he liked it but what happened after?

(Scowls) No! (Voice rising) He was dumb! Stupid gold touch! (Suddenly bursts into tears) His... his girl turned gold! (Sobs loudly) That's not fair! (Wipes eyes with the back of my hand, smearing dirt on my face) I hate this story! (Kicks the desk)
(Calmly) It *is* sad that his daughter turned to gold. You're right. He must have felt terrible. So, if the golden touch made him sad and he couldn't eat, was it really a good thing for him?

(Sniffling) No! (Shakes head violently) It was bad! Bad, bad, bad! He should've wished for... for... (Looks around, distracted, then remembers) Candy! He should've wished for candy! Then he could eat it! (Eyes widen, briefly forgetting the sadness) But not gold candy! That's still yucky! (Frown returns)
Okay, so the golden touch was bad. It made him sad. He couldn't eat. His daughter turned to gold. Why do you think he wished for it in the first place? What did he want so much?

(Stares blankly) I... I don't know! (Picks at a scab on my knee) He was greedy! He wanted... (Sighs dramatically) MORE! Just MORE, MORE, MORE! Like a big baby! (Makes a face) Can I draw now? Gold is boring! I wanna draw a dinosaur!
You got it! He was greedy. He wanted more and more gold. And what happened because he was so greedy? What did he lose?

(Mumbles) Lost... lost... (Taps fingers on the table) Lost his... his kid! (Looks up, surprised) And his... his lunch! (Giggles nervously) Can I *please* draw now? I'm gonna explode if I have to talk about gold anymore! (Starts tapping my foot rapidly)
That's right! He lost his daughter and he couldn't even eat. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Grumbling) Don't be... don't be... (Sticks tongue out) ...greedy! (Looks away, embarrassed) Or you'll lose your kid and your lunch! And gold pizza is gross! (Bursts out laughing) Can I PLEASE draw now?! I learned the stupid lesson!

Yes! You learned the lesson! Don't be greedy! Being greedy can make bad things happen. You might lose things that are much more important than gold.

Okay, you can go draw now! You did a great job thinking about the story. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was The Fox and the Grapes.

Now, tell me, what was the fox looking for?

(Starts swinging my legs under the desk, looking around the room) Uh... (Stuttering) Food? (Looks away, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) He... he wanted to eat. I want cookies! Can I have a cookie? (Suddenly cheerful) Mom packed cookies today!

Yes, he wanted food! Good job. And cookies sound yummy, but let's talk about the fox first.

What kind of food did he find on the farmer's wall?

(Eyes widen, excited) Grapes! (Confidently) Big, purple ones! I like grapes! They're juicy! (Starts to get out of seat) Can we have grapes for snack time? Are they in my lunchbox? I bet Mom put them in my lunchbox. (Looks back at teacher impatiently) Grapes, grapes, grapes! That's what the fox wanted.

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story, [Student's Name]! That was "The Proud Rose."

Now, tell me, who are the main characters in the story?

(Swinging my legs under the desk, I blurt out, already bored)

Umm... a rose! (Looks away, fiddling with my shoelaces) And... and a prickly thing.

Yes! You're right. The rose and the "prickly thing" which is called a cactus.

Which plant thought it was better than the other?

(Scoffs, rolls eyes)

Duh! (Points finger) The rose! 'Cause it was, like, all pretty and stuff. (Starts humming a made-up tune, tapping my foot impatiently)

Okay, so the rose thought it was better. Why did the rose think it was better? You said it was pretty, right?

What did the rose *do* because it thought it was prettier?

(Sighs dramatically, slouching in my chair)

Ugh, I don't know! (Scratches my head) It, like, told the cactus it was ugly? And dumb? (Shrugs shoulders) I don't remember all the words. Can I go to recess now? (Starts bouncing a little)

You're close, and you *do* remember! The rose was not very nice to the cactus.

Did the other plants agree with the rose? Did they think the cactus was ugly and dumb?

(Furrows brows, scowling a little)

No! (Crosses arms) They were, like, "Hey! Be nice!" But the rose didn't listen. (Taps foot faster, glances at the door) So boring...

Good job, you remembered that!

Now, what happened when the weather got really, really hot? What happened to the water?

(Starts picking at a loose thread on my shirt, voice getting a little shaky)

Umm... (Stutters) The... the water went away? And... and the rose got... (Looks down at my hands, nervously twisting them) It got all... yucky?
Yes! The water went away, and the rose started to get "yucky," or wither. What happened to the cactus?

(Eyes widen a little, momentarily forgetting about wanting to leave)

The cactus? (Thinking) Umm... it... it gave water to... to birds! Little birdies! (Beams proudly, then quickly remembers to be annoyed and looks away) So?
So, the cactus helped the birds. Now, what happened when the rose got thirsty? Who did the rose ask for help?

(Grumbling under my breath)

Ugh, fine. (Huffs loudly) It... it asked the cactus. The stupid cactus. (Avoids eye contact, fiddling with my pencil)
And did the cactus help the rose, even after the rose was mean?

(Chews on the end of the pencil, looking anxiously around the room)

Yeah, yeah! (Mumbles) It gave the rose water. Happy now? Can I go now? (Starts tapping the pencil on the desk, making a loud, rhythmic noise)

Yes, the cactus *did* help the rose.

So, the rose was pretty but mean, and the cactus was prickly but helpful. What do you think we can learn from this story? Is it good to judge people based on how they look?

(Slams the pencil down, face getting red)

I DON'T KNOW! (Voice cracking, on the verge of tears) I just wanna go play! This is too hard! (Pushes the chair back, ready to run out of the room) Leave me alone!

(Softening my voice, leaning forward a bit)

Okay, okay. It's alright. It's not a test. Let's just think about it for a little bit longer.

Sometimes, people look one way on the outside, but they are different on the inside. The rose *looked* beautiful, but it wasn't very kind. The cactus didn't look as pretty, but it was very helpful.

So, should we decide if someone is good or bad just by looking at them? What do you think?

(Sniffling, still avoiding eye contact, but not running away... yet)

(Muttering) Maybe... maybe not. (Quietly) 'Cause the rose... the rose was mean... even though it was pretty. (Wipes nose on sleeve) And the cactus... (Looks up quickly, then down again) The cactus was nice... even though... even though... it was prickly. (A small tear rolls down cheek)

That's right! You got it. The rose *looked* beautiful, but it was mean. The cactus *looked* prickly, but it was kind.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Sniffs again, wiping the tear away. Voice still shaky, but a little bit stronger)

(Hesitates) That... that you shouldn't be... (Struggling) ...mean to people... just 'cause... just 'cause you think you're better? (Looks up, eyes wide and a little scared, waiting for a reaction) And... and that... that even if someone looks... icky... they can still be... good? (Whispers the last word)

You're exactly right!

The story is teaching us that we shouldn't judge people just by how they look. The rose *looked* beautiful, but it was mean. The cactus *looked* prickly, but it was kind and helpful. So, we need to look *inside* and see how people act, not just at their outside.

We should never judge someone according to how they look. You understood that very well. <finish>
