dialogue:
Okay! Hi there! That was a good job reading the story!

So, what did Molly do for work?

(Fidgets with my hands, looks around the room, then back at the teacher) Uh... Milk...milkmaid. (Looks down at my shoes) She... uh... milked the cows? (Shrugs) And, like, sold it? I think. (Starts tapping my foot impatiently) Can we be done now? I wanna go play.

Yes, you're right! She milked the cows and sold the milk. Good job!

Where was she going to sell the milk?

(Sighs loudly, rolls my eyes) The... the market! (Taps fingers on the desk, looks out the window, and then back at the teacher) Ugh, this is boring. Can I draw instead? The market, okay? Happy now? (Crosses arms and slouches in the chair)

Yes, the market! Good job.

What did Molly start thinking about while she was walking to the market? What was on her mind?

(Picks at a loose thread on my shirt, avoids eye contact) Stuff. (Mumbles) Dunno. Things... she wanted. (Scowls) Why do I have to remember all this? (Shifts in seat, looking anxious) It's... it's too hard! (Voice gets louder, almost a whine)

It's okay! It can be a little tricky. Let's think about it together.

Did she want to buy toys? Or something else? What did she see on the way to the market?

(Suddenly perks up, points excitedly) A chicken! (Starts kicking my legs under the desk) She saw a chicken! And... and... (Frowns, then shouts) Eggs! She wanted eggs! (Beams, then immediately gets nervous, bites lip) Is... is that right? (Looks at the teacher with wide, slightly panicked eyes)

Yes! That's right! She saw a chicken. And she wanted to get eggs from it.

What was she planning to do with those eggs?

(Stands up abruptly, starts pacing near my desk) Ugh! More money! (Throws hands up in the air) She wanted more money! So she could... uh... (Stops pacing, looks confused, scratches head) Buy... pretty things! Yeah! And make everyone jealous! (Grins mischievously, then sits down heavily, bouncing my leg nervously) This is taking too long!

You got it! She wanted more money! And you're right, she wanted to buy pretty things and make others jealous.

What happened to the milk when she was thinking about all of this? She was so excited, remember?

(Makes a dramatic face, claps hands to cheeks) Oh no! (Voice cracks) It... it spilled! (Looks down at the desk, avoids the teacher's eyes, on the verge of tears) All gone! She... she lost it all! (Mumbles, barely audible) Stupid milk. (Starts to sniffle quietly)

That's right. It all spilled. She lost the milk.

So, how did she feel when the milk spilled?

(Wipes nose with sleeve, scowls) Mad! (Voice is shaky but loud) And... and sad! (Kicks the desk leg) It's not fair! She wanted pretty things! (Starts to cry quietly, face red and blotchy) And now... now she has nothing! Stupid milk! Stupid chicken! Stupid everything! (Bursts into louder sobs) I... I hate this story!

(Moves closer and speaks softly) It's okay to feel sad. It wasn't a very happy ending, was it?

What did her mother say to her when she got home? Do you remember? It's okay if you don't.

(Sniffles, looks up with tear-filled eyes) Something... something about... (Frowns, thinking hard, then shouts) Chickens! Don't... don't count your chickens! (Wipes face again, but tears keep coming) 'Til they... they hatch! Yeah! (Sobs again, but a little quieter this time) What does that even mean?! (Looks genuinely confused and upset)

You remembered! "Don't count your chickens until they hatch." That's right!

So, Molly was already spending the money from the eggs *before* the chicken even laid them.

What do you think that means, that she shouldn't count her chickens?

(Glares at the teacher, still sniffling) It means... (Pauses, thinking, then throws hands up in the air) I don't know! It's stupid! (Voice rising again) Chickens don't even give you money! You have to sell the eggs! (Sighs dramatically, slumps in chair) It's too hard to think! My head hurts! (Rubs temples, looking overwhelmed) Just... just tell me the answer!
Okay, okay. It's alright. Let's think about it like this: Molly *thought* she was going to get money from the eggs. But did she *actually* have the eggs yet?

(Eyes widen, a glimmer of understanding) No! (Fidgets with fingers again) She only had the... the idea of the eggs. (Looks down, then back up, a little less frantic) So... so it means... don't... don't get excited about things... (Pauses, struggling) ...until they... like... REALLY happen? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation, nervous again) Is... is that it? (Bites lip)

Yes! You got it! Don't get excited or depend on things until they *really* happen.

So, what is the story teaching us? What's the lesson we can learn from Molly?

(Stands up again, starts pacing slowly, muttering to myself) Don't... don't be... (Stops pacing, looks at the teacher with a frustrated expression) Ugh! I can't! It's too many words! Just... (Suddenly brightens, claps hands) Don't be greedy! Yeah! Don't be greedy and... and... spill your milk! (Sits down with a thump, looking pleased with myself) Am I done now? Please?

Okay, "don't be greedy" is part of it, but it's also about something else. It's about being sure of things *before* you start planning. It's about waiting to see if something *actually* happens before you start spending the money in your head.

So, put it all together. What is the story trying to teach us?

(Stares blankly at the teacher, then sighs dramatically) I... I can't. It's too... too much. (Starts to fidget and mumble) Greedy... milk... chickens... spending... (Voice trails off, looking completely overwhelmed.) Can't... can't do it... (Covers face with hands, starting to rock back and forth slightly.) Just... just tell me. Please? Then can I go? (Voice muffled by hands.)

Okay. The story is teaching us: Do not depend on something until you are sure it will happen.

Do you think you understand that now?

(Slowly lowers hands, looks up with red-rimmed eyes) I... I think so. (Sniffles) Don't... don't count chickens 'til they hatch. (Looks away, shuffles feet) Don't be greedy... and spill your milk. (Mumbles the last part, then looks pleadingly at the teacher) Can I go now? Please? I really, really need to go play. (Starts to bounce leg anxiously)
Yes, you can go play now. You did a good job working through the story, even when it was hard. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the wise old owl! Did you like it?

Now, let's talk about the owl. What did the owl like to do?

(Fidgets, avoiding eye contact) Uh... I guess so. It was okay. (Shrugs)

The owl... (scratches head, looks around the room) He... he watched stuff. Yeah. He watched people. (Taps foot impatiently) Can I go play now?

(Smiling patiently) That's right! The owl watched stuff. Good job!

What kind of things did he watch? Where was he sitting when he watched?

(Rolls eyes, sighs loudly) I don't know! (Looks away, kicks the chair) He was... (stuttering) on a... a tree? A big tree! He watched people talk. Is that right? Am I done now? (Voice rising in pitch) This is boring! (Starts to get out of the seat)

(Gently guiding the student back into the seat) It's okay. We're almost done. You're doing great! You're right, he was on a big tree. Do you remember what kind of tree it was? (Pauses, gives a hint) It starts with an "O".
(Crosses arms, pouting) I don't care! (Mumbles) Oak... Oak tree. (Sticks out tongue) Can I draw now? I wanna draw monsters! This is stupid! (Pushes book away)

(Calmly retrieves the book and places it back in front of the student.) Okay, okay. Just a little bit more, and then you can draw monsters. Oak tree is right!

So, the owl was in the oak tree, watching and listening. Did he talk a lot?

(Shakes head violently, looks nervous) No! He... he didn't say much! (Starts to pick at a loose thread on shirt, voice trembling slightly) Talking is dumb. He just... looked. And listened. I don't wanna talk about it anymore! It's making my tummy feel funny! (Eyes start to water)

(Recognizing the student's distress, speaks in a soft, reassuring voice.) Okay, it's alright. We don't have to talk about it if it makes you uncomfortable. Let's just think about it for a second.

The owl didn't talk much, he just watched and listened. Do you think that helped him learn things?

(Sniffling, still avoids eye contact, rubs eyes) I guess... (mumbles) Maybe... (pauses, thinking for a brief moment, then shrugs) I don't know! (Voice cracks) Just let me draw monsters! Please! (Starts to cry quietly) They don't make me feel yucky.

(Pulls up a chair to sit next to the student, speaking softly.) It's okay. It's okay. You don't have to cry. How about this? We'll just look at the pictures in the book. Okay? (Opens the book and points to a picture of the owl)

See the owl? He's watching. Do you think he's learning about the other animals?

(Wipes nose with sleeve, glances at the picture briefly, then looks away again. Mumbles) Maybe... if he's not too... (shudders) ...scared. (Whispers) Sometimes watching makes me scared. Can I draw now? Please? Just one monster?

(Nods understandingly.) I understand. Watching *can* be scary sometimes.

Okay, how about we do this: You tell me *one* thing the owl might have learned by watching, and then you can draw your monster. Deal? Just one thing. What do you think he learned about the people talking?

(Looks up, eyes still red but slightly less anxious, considers the question for a moment. Fidgets with hands) Um... (hesitates, then blurts out) That they lie! (Looks down again immediately, anticipating a negative reaction) They always lie! (Mumbles) Grown-ups lie all the time.

(Resists the urge to correct or dismiss the statement. Instead, acknowledges the student's observation.) Okay. He might have learned that sometimes people don't tell the truth. That's a very interesting idea.

So, if the owl watches and listens, and learns that sometimes people don't tell the truth, do you think that makes him smarter?

(Looks up, surprised by the non-judgmental response. Chews on lip, thinking. A very brief flicker of genuine interest appears.) I guess... (pauses, then says almost reluctantly) Yeah. Maybe. 'Cause he knows stuff. (Looks down again, suddenly embarrassed by showing even a sliver of engagement.) Can I draw *now*? You promised.

(Smiles gently.) I did promise. And you did a great job thinking about the owl!

So, the owl watched and listened, and because of that, he learned things and became wiser. That's the whole point of the story! He talked less, and learned more.

You can draw your monster now. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! Hi there! That was a good read. Now let's talk about the story of the goose and the golden egg.

First, can you tell me who are the people in the story?

(Starts swinging my legs under the desk, looking around the room, then blurts out)

Umm... (Stuttering) ... There's... a farmer! And... (Sighs dramatically) ... and his wife! Yeah! (Confidently) And the GOOSE! (Runs hand through hair) Can I go play now? (Looks away) This is boring!

(Chuckles softly) I know stories can feel long, but we're almost done! You're doing great.

Yes! You got them all! The farmer, his wife, and the goose.

Now, what did the goose give the farmer every day?

(Scoffs) Duh! (Rolls eyes) A... a... golden egg! (Taps foot impatiently) Everyone knows that! (Crosses arms and slouches in chair) What else is there? Are we done now? I wanna go outside! (Starts humming loudly)

(Smiling patiently) You are right! It laid a golden egg.

And what did the farmer do with the golden egg? Did he keep it?

(Sighs loudly) Noooo... (Thinking, fiddling with a pencil). He... he sold it! (Shrugs) To get... money? (Looks at the ceiling) It's obvious! Why are you asking such easy questions? (Mumbles) This is taking forever!

(Nods) Yes, he sold it to get money! Good job.

And because he sold the egg every day, did the farmer have a lot of money or a little money?

(Eyes widen slightly) Lots! (Confidently) D'uh! Golden eggs are worth, like, a zillion dollars! (Pulls a face) He was rich! (Stands up suddenly) Can I get a drink of water? My throat is dry! (Pushes chair back noisily)

(Smiling) Yes, he had lots of money. Okay, you can get a quick drink of water. But come right back, okay? We just have a little bit more to talk about.

(Waits for the student to return and sit back down).

Now, the farmer had lots of money. Was he happy with one golden egg a day?

(Returns, splashing water in the cup, then sits down heavily, leaving the cup on the edge of the table)

(Frowns) Nope! (Shakes head violently) He was greedy! (Points finger) That's what my mom says about my brother when he takes all the cookies! (Suddenly yells) NO FAIR! (Calms down quickly) He... he wanted more! (Taps fingers rapidly on the desk) Can we PLEASE be done soon?

(Nods understandingly) I understand. We're almost finished, I promise.

Yes, the farmer was greedy! He wanted more. So, what did the farmer do to get more golden eggs? This is important!
(Looks down at hands, avoiding eye contact. Mumbles) Uh... (Stands up again suddenly) This is making me feel sick. Can I go to the nurse? (Looks pleadingly) My tummy hurts!

(Concerned) Your tummy hurts? Okay, let's just finish this one question, then we can see about the nurse, okay? Just one more little bit.

What did the farmer do to the goose to get more eggs? Remember the story.

(Huffs, slouches back in chair, and picks at a loose thread on their sleeve). (Reluctantly answers) He... (grimaces) He cut... cut it open! (Covers mouth with hand, looking disgusted). That's gross! (Starts rocking back and forth slightly). He shouldn't have done that! Now can I go? My tummy *really* hurts!
(Nods sympathetically) Yes, it was a very bad thing to do. And what did he find when he cut it open? Did he find lots of golden eggs?

(Shakes head, eyes wide and a little watery). No! (Voice trembles slightly) Just... just yucky stuff! Blood! (Clutches stomach) Ohhh... (Starts to tear up) Can I *please* go see the nurse now? I'm gonna be sick! (Forces out the words) It's your fault!

(Softly) Oh dear, I am sorry you feel sick. It is not my intention to make you feel sick.

So what happened to the farmer after that? Did he still get golden eggs? Did he become richer or poorer?

(Sniffling, wiping nose with sleeve. Mumbles) No... no more eggs. (Looks down at the floor, kicking it softly) He was... poor! (Voice cracking) And it's all... (Looks up accusingly, voice rising) ... YOUR fault! You made me think about the yucky stuff! I wanna go home! (Begins to cry loudly.)

(Stands up and kneels beside the student) I am so sorry. I didn't mean to upset you.

(Lowering my voice to be more soothing) You are right, the farmer became poor because he was greedy and did a bad thing. He didn't think about what he was doing. He acted too fast.

(Pauses, waiting for the student to calm down slightly)

What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What did the farmer learn?

(Continues to cry, but less intensely, hiccuping occasionally. Voice muffled.) That... (Sniffles) ...it's bad to be... greedy! (Wipes eyes again) And... and you shouldn't cut open... (Shudders) ... geese! (Clings to the edge of the desk). Can... can someone call my mom? I don't feel good. And... and you were mean to make me talk about it!

(Speaking gently and reassuringly) You are right, it's bad to be greedy. And it's important to think before you do something, isn't it? If the farmer had thought about it, he would have realised that he was already lucky and shouldn't risk losing everything.

The story teaches us to think before we act so we don't make a mistake that we will regret.

(Pauses, noticing the student's distress)

Okay, I think you understood the story very well. I will call your mom and you can go to the nurse now. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Farmer and the Well."

First, tell me, who bought something? And what did he buy?

(Starts tapping my foot impatiently)

Umm... (looks away, fidgeting with my pencil) A...a...farmer! Yeah! A farmer bought... uh... (eyes dart around the room, focusing on a shiny object) a... well! He bought a well. Can I go play now? (Dramatic sigh). This is boring!

I know it can be hard to sit still. Let's just finish talking about the story, okay? Then you can play.

You're right! The farmer bought a well. Who did he buy it *from*? Do you remember?

(Crosses arms and scowls)

Ugh, why do *I* have to remember? (Rolls eyes). It was the... the... neighbor! Duh! (Says it loudly and then giggles, quickly looking around to see if anyone noticed.) He sold the well to the farmer. Can we hurry this up? I wanna color! (Starts humming loudly and drumming on the desk with a pencil.)

Yes! The neighbor sold the well. Good job!

Now, the farmer bought the well, but was he happy? What happened after he bought it? Could he use the well?

(Sighs loudly, slumping in the chair).

Happy? (Scoffs) No! Stupid farmer wasn't happy! The neighbor... (Sticks tongue out, making a face) ...he was mean! (Suddenly shouts) He didn't let the farmer use the well! (Looks around to gauge reaction, then mumbles) ... told him he only bought the hole, not the water. (Starts drawing doodles on desk with the pencil.) He's so dumb.

You're right! The neighbor was being mean. He said the farmer only bought the hole.

So, what did the farmer do then? He couldn't get water. What did he do?

(Stops doodling and stares blankly ahead).

(Shrugs shoulders dramatically). I dunno. He... he cried? (Giggles and picks nose) Maybe he went home and complained to his mommy! (Grins mischievously). Or... (eyes widen) ...maybe he got really, really mad and punched the neighbor! Yeah! He punched him right in the nose! (Makes punching motions in the air, accidentally knocking over a pencil cup). Oops! (Doesn't attempt to pick up the pencils).

(Helps pick up the pencils). It's okay. Accidents happen.

He didn't punch the neighbor, though. He went to someone important to ask for help. Who did he go to? Someone who could help him get justice.

(Scowls again, clearly annoyed).

Justice? What's *that*? (Pokes at a pencil with a finger). Fine. Whatever. (Mumbles) He went to... uh... the... the... (Snaps fingers) the... king! No! Wait! (Screws up face in concentration) The... em... Em... (Throws hands up in the air). I don't CARE! This is stupid! Can I *please* go play now? My brain hurts! (Holds head dramatically).

Almost there! You're so close to remembering. It wasn't the king, but someone almost as important. He went to the... emperor. The emperor is like a super-king!

And the emperor had a helper, a courtier. What did the courtier ask the neighbor?

(Starts tapping feet again, looking longingly at the door)

(Sighs dramatically) Okay, okay! Fine! (Mumbles under breath) Emperor, schm-emperor. Who cares?

(Louder now, trying to get it over with) The... the... courtier... (Grimaces, struggling with the word) asked the neighbor... (pauses, then blurts out) ...why he was being so mean! Yeah! He asked him why he wasn't sharing! (Grins, pleased with self for (sort of) remembering.) And then the neighbor... (eyes glaze over, attention drifting to a fly buzzing near the window) ...mumble, mumble, mumble... something about water... and rent... (Trails off, completely losing focus).

You're doing great! The courtier asked the neighbor why he wasn't letting the farmer use the well. And the neighbor said he only sold the well, not the water.

Then, the courtier said the neighbor had to either give the farmer the water, or pay the farmer rent for keeping the water in the farmer's well. What happened then? What did the neighbor do?

(Eyes widen, a flicker of amusement crosses the face).

(Giggles) He got tricked! (Claps hands once, loudly). He... he was all like, "Oh no! I'm gonna have to pay rent!" (Makes a sad face for a split second, then bursts into laughter). And then he... (struggles to contain laughter) ...he said sorry! (Gasps for air, still giggling). He was so dumb! Serves him right for being mean! Can I go now? Please? I *really* wanna go! (Jumps up and down, bouncing in the seat).

Yes! He *did* get tricked! He realized he was wrong and said sorry.

So, the neighbor tried to trick the farmer, but did it work? Did the neighbor get away with being mean?

(Stops jumping and crosses arms again, a hint of impatience in the voice).

No! (Says it very loudly). It didn't work! The neighbor was stupid! The farmer won! (Pokes tongue out). Can I GOOOOO now?! I answered all the questions! (Points to the door emphatically).

You did! You answered all the questions.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story? Think about the neighbor trying to trick the farmer. What happened to him when he tried to cheat?

(Sighs dramatically, rolls eyes, and leans back in chair, nearly tipping over).

Ugh... is this MORE questions? (Grumbling) It's trying to teach us... (Pauses, staring at the ceiling). ...that... (Another long pause, tapping fingers on desk). ...that being mean is bad! (Shrugs shoulders as if that should be obvious). And that if you're mean... (Points finger accusingly in the air)... you get in TROUBLE! (Smirks slightly, clearly pleased with this simple answer). Can I PLEASE go now? I'm gonna EXPLODE if I have to sit here one more second!

Being mean *is* bad. You're right! And the neighbor *did* get in trouble. He tried to cheat the farmer.

So, what happens when you try to cheat? Does it work out well for you?

(Eyes glaze over again, attention span clearly exhausted).

(Mumbles) Cheat... cheat... cheating is like... like stealing candy? (Giggles at the thought). If you cheat... um... (Stares out the window, distracted by a bird). ...then the emperor yells at you? (Shrugs). Or... or... the... the... courtier makes you... (Makes a gagging sound) ...eat broccoli! (Wrinkles nose in disgust). I don't know! (Bursts out) I DON'T CARE! Can I just GO?! PLEEEEEEEASE! (Starts pulling at the sleeves of the shirt, fidgeting intensely).

Okay, okay! You're so close to understanding the story's message.

Think about it this way: the neighbor tried to cheat the farmer. Did it make things better for the neighbor, or worse? Did it work out for him to cheat?

(Groans and slams head lightly on the desk).

Worse! It made it... (grunts)...worse! Because he had to say sorry and he looked stupid! (Raises head and glares at the user) Happy now? (Mumbles under breath) I still think punching him would have been better... (Loudly) Can I go? Pretty please with a cherry on top and extra sprinkles? I'll be super, super quiet in class, I promise! (Looks around guiltily, realizing that might be a lie).

You got it! It made things worse for him. Cheating didn't help him at all.

So, the story is trying to teach us that cheating...will get you nowhere! If you try to cheat, like the neighbor, it will make things worse for you. It's better to be honest and fair.

Do you understand now?

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends."

Now, can you tell me, at the beginning of the story, how did the elephant feel?
(Fidgets with my pencil, looking around the room) Uh... (shrugs) He was... um... (scowls) I don't know! What was the question again? I wanna go outside! (starts tapping foot impatiently)

It's okay! Let's take a breath. Remember the first sentence? It said, "A lonely elephant was looking for friends."

How do you think the elephant felt if he was lonely?
(Rolls eyes) Lonely! Duh! (Crosses arms and looks out the window) Is it time for snack yet? (Mumbles) This is boring. Why do we have to talk about dumb elephants?

I understand you're feeling bored, but we're almost done! And the elephant isn't dumb! He's actually quite helpful.

So, he was lonely. And he wanted friends. What did he do to try and make friends?

(Sighs dramatically and slumps in chair) He... asked? I think? (Picks at a loose thread on my shirt) Can I draw? I'm really good at drawing tigers! Roar! (Makes a grabbing motion with hand) This story is dumb!

Yes, you're right! He asked. He asked the monkey, the rabbit, and the frog, right?

And what did they say? Did they want to be his friend?

(Giggles rudely) Nope! They said NO! 'Cause he was too big and clunky and couldn't swing or hop or dig! (Sticks tongue out) They were mean! And... and he was... sad! (Looks away, kicking the desk slightly) So can I draw now? The story's over, right?

You're right, they were mean! And the elephant probably felt sad. Good job remembering!

But the story isn't quite over yet. Something else happened. What happened the next day in the forest? Remember the tiger?

(Eyes widen slightly) Tiger! Yeah! (Sits up a little straighter) The tiger was... ROAR! ... chasing everyone! (Starts making tiger clawing motions with hands, then immediately loses interest) ...But the elephant... he kicked the tiger! (Yawns loudly) Can we talk about something else? Like dinosaurs? They're way cooler than elephants. (Starts humming to himself)

You're doing great! Yes, the tiger was chasing everyone, and the elephant kicked him away!

Why do you think the other animals were running from the tiger?

(Shrugs) 'Cause the tiger was gonna EAT THEM! (Looks at the teacher with a slightly worried expression) Duh! Is it lunchtime yet? I'm really, REALLY hungry. (Starts tapping fingers on the desk impatiently)

That's right! They were scared the tiger would eat them.

And how did the elephant help? What did he do?

(Scoffs) Kicked him! I told you! (Looks around the room, then back at the teacher) He went BAM! And the tiger ran away! The elephant is strong! Can I go to the bathroom? I REALLY need to go. (Starts wiggling in seat)

Yes, he kicked the tiger! You remembered!

And after the elephant helped, how did the other animals feel about him? Did they still think he was too big and clunky?

(Looks confused) Um... (Stares blankly) They... liked him? 'Cause he saved them? (Frowns) I don't remember. This is a STUPID story! (Pushes chair back slightly) I want to play! (Whines) Why do we have to do this?!

It's okay, we're almost finished! Think about it: The elephant saved them from the tiger. Did that change how they felt about him being big?

Did they still care that he couldn't swing in trees or hop like a frog?

(Grumbling) No... I guess not. (Looks at the floor, kicking at it lightly) He was... helpful. So... they liked him. (Mumbles) I knew that...sort of. Can I have a sticker now? Or... or a dinosaur picture? (Looks up hopefully)

Yes! They liked him because he was helpful and strong! Even though he was big, he was the perfect friend to help them.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? Can friends be different sizes and shapes?

(Stares blankly, then suddenly stands up) Can I go now? I don't know! Friends...are... (Struggles) Can be... whatever! (Runs towards the door) I'm going to play! Bye! (Leaves the room without waiting for permission)
Okay, well done! The story shows us that friends can be any shape or size. It's about being kind and helpful, no matter how different you are. <finish>

dialogue: Okay! That was a good story! Now, tell me, what did the girl do when she felt sad?

(Starts tapping foot impatiently, eyes darting around the room)

Umm... (stuttering) she... uh... (looks away) she told her... (shrugs) daddy? I dunno. Can I go play now? This is boring. (Pulls at sleeve) My tummy hurts.
It's okay! Let's take it slow. You are right, she told her daddy. And what did her daddy do? He didn't just say, "Don't be sad!" Did he?

(Scoffs)

Yeah, duh! He got... stuff. (Picks at a loose thread on my shirt) An egg... and... (makes a face) potato! And... (snaps fingers) tea! Can I go now? (Starts to get up) This is taking forever!
You remembered all the things! Good job! He got those things. Then what did he *do* with them? What happened to the egg, potato and tea?

(Sighs dramatically and slouches in chair)

He... cooked them? (Rolls eyes) In water! Like, boiling water! It's not that hard! Why are we talking about this? (Starts humming loudly and taps pen on desk) I wanna draw!
You're doing great! Yes, he cooked them in boiling water. Now, think really hard. What happened to the egg *after* it was in the hot water? Was it the same as before?

(Thinking, squints eyes, briefly focuses then looks away again)

Umm... (mumbles) It got... hard? (Pushes chair back slightly, ready to bolt) It was soft and then it was... (voice trails off) I forget. It's dumb anyway. Can I have a snack? (Eyes the door)
You got it! It *did* get hard! The soft egg got hard. Now, what about the potato? What happened to *it* in the hot water? Was it hard or soft after?

(Crosses arms, face scrunched up in annoyance)

The potato was... hard... and then... (taps foot faster) ...soft? (Grumbles) This is like a trick! (Pulls out a crumpled piece of paper from pocket and starts doodling without looking up)
Not a trick! You're doing so well! The potato WAS hard and then it got soft. You got it! Now, the last one: the tea leaves. Did they get hard or soft? Or something else?

(Stops doodling for a split second, then shrugs)

They... disappeared? (Looks up, eyes wide) No! They made... (frowns) ...tea! The water was brown! (Immediately goes back to doodling, humming again, even louder) So can I leave NOW?

Yes! You are so smart! The tea changed the water! Now, the dad said this showed something important. The egg, the potato, and the tea... they were all put in the same hot water, right? But did they all change in the same way?

(Sighs loudly, throws down the crayon)

Noooooo! (Says it like the teacher is being incredibly stupid) The egg got hard! The potato got squishy! And the tea... made tea! (Rolls eyes and points dramatically at the door) Can I GO?! This is soooooo boring!

Okay, okay! Almost done! The hot water is like... a hard time. Like when you feel sad or mad. The egg, the potato, and the tea show us... different ways to act when things get hard. The egg got hard, the potato got soft, and the tea changed the water.

So, what do *you* think the dad wanted the girl to learn about hard times?

(Scowls and shuffles feet)

I dunno! (Mumbles) To... cook stuff? To make tea? (Kicks the leg of the desk) This is stupid. I don't CARE about the egg or the potato! I just want to go play! (Pouts, lower lip trembling slightly)

It's okay to feel like that. Think about it this way. The hard times are going to happen, right? Like the hot water. We can't always stop the hard times. But do *we* get to choose if we become like the egg, the potato, or the tea?

(Looks up, a flicker of something in eyes, but quickly closes off again)

(Mumbles) I don't know! (Pulls a face) It's too hard! (Hides face in hands) It makes my head hurt! Just... just tell me the answer! (Voice cracks slightly) Then can I PLEASE go?

It's okay, I won't just tell you the answer. But I'll help you. The dad wants her to know that even when things are hard, she can choose how she acts. She can choose if she wants to be strong like the egg, soft like the potato, or change things like the tea. So, *can* she choose?

(Sniffles, wipes nose on sleeve)

(Quietly) ...Maybe? (Looks up, eyes red-rimmed) But it's... it's hard to choose! Sometimes I just... (voice trails off, looks down at hands, twisting them) ...I just get mad! Or... or scared! (Starts to cry softly)

It *is* hard to choose. It's okay to feel mad or scared. But the story is about knowing you *can* choose. Even if it's hard. Even if you don't always choose right.

So, the story is trying to say that when hard times come... what can *we* decide?

(Sniffles again, voice wobbly)

...We can... decide... (pauses, thinking hard, then looks up, a tiny bit of understanding dawning) ...decide... how we... change? (Wipes eyes again) Like... like the egg or the potato or the tea? (Looks at the teacher, waiting for confirmation, a glimmer of hope in those anxious eyes.)
Yes! Exactly! We decide how *we* change! We decide how to respond to the hard times. You got it! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, wonderful reading! That was a good story, wasn't it?

Now, can you tell me, what was the older brother doing in the forest?

(Fidgets with my shoelaces, looking around the room instead of at the teacher)

Uh... (stuttering) wood? He was, like...getting wood. (Confidently) Lots and lots of wood! (Starts humming loudly and taps my foot)
Yes, that's right! He was getting wood. What did he do with the wood he got? Did he keep it?

(Stops humming suddenly, looks at the teacher with wide eyes)

Keep it? (Scowls) Why would he *keep* it? That's... (Long pause, thinking) ...dumb! (Looks away again)

(Whispering, but still loud enough to be heard) He... he did something with it. I... I wanna go outside! Can I go outside now? (Starts bouncing my leg nervously)

(Smiling patiently)

We will go outside later, I promise. But first, let's finish talking about the story. It will be quick!

You're right, keeping the wood wouldn't be very smart. What did he do with the wood so he wouldn't have to keep it? Think about where people go to buy things.

(Sighs dramatically and slouches in my chair)

(Mumbling) I don't wanna think... thinking is booooring.

(Eyes light up slightly) Buy things? Like... candy? Did he buy candy? (Looks up at the teacher hopefully) Can *I* buy candy later? I'll be good, I promise! Just... just tell me the answer! (Starts tapping my pencil rapidly on the desk)

(Chuckles softly)

He didn't buy candy, but you're on the right track with "buying." Where do people go to buy and sell things? It's a place with lots of people selling their stuff.

(Shakes my head vigorously)

I dunno! I *really* don't wanna think anymore! (Whining) It's too hard! Tell me! Tell me! (Starts kicking the leg of my chair) Is it... is it like... (Long pause, chewing on my pencil eraser) ... a store? A big, big store? (Looks at the teacher expectantly, but nervously)
It's like a store, but usually outside. People set up tables to sell things. What do we call that place? It starts with an "M..."

(Screws up my face, clearly frustrated)

(Yelling) M! M is a stupid letter! (Starts to tear a piece of paper into tiny pieces) I HATE M! (Throws the paper scraps on the floor)

(Muttering) It's not fair... stupid "M" words... Can I just draw instead? Please? I'm really, really bad at this.

(Calmly picks up the scraps of paper and puts them in the bin)

It's okay. "M" can be tricky! The place is called a market. The older brother sold the wood at the market.

Now, what happened when the older brother found the special tree? What did the tree say?

(Crosses my arms and turns my body away from the teacher)

(Mumbling, almost inaudible) I don't care... trees don't talk. That's just silly. (Scoffs)

(Suddenly louder) I wanna draw a monster truck! With BIG WHEELS! Can I draw a monster truck NOW? (Starts tapping my foot impatiently again)

(Sighs softly)

Okay, okay. We can talk about monster trucks later. But just one more question about the tree, okay?

Even if trees don't *really* talk, what did the tree *do* in the story? Did it give him something?

(Grumbles under my breath, still facing away)

Fine... one question. But then monster trucks!

(Pauses, thinking for a very short time) It... it gave him stuff. Shiny stuff. (Turns around slightly, a little more engaged) Was it... was it treasure? Like a pirate? Did the tree have pirate treasure? (Eyes widen with interest)
It wasn't pirate treasure, but it was shiny! What kind of shiny things did the tree give him? They were round and yellow...

(Eyes dart around the room, then back to the teacher. Taps fingers on the desk)

Yellow... shiny... round... (Suddenly blurts out) GOLD! It gave him gold! Gold coins! (Jumps up and down excitedly) Did he get to buy ALL the candy with the gold coins?! Did he? Did he? (Starts flapping my hands)
He got something golden, but they weren't coins. Think about things that grow on trees...

(Immediately deflates, slumping back into the chair)

(Grumbling) Booooring... not gold coins? What a rip-off! (Kicks the chair again)

(Pause, then a reluctant mumble) Apples? Were they, like, gold apples? (Looks at the teacher with a suspicious glance, like it's a trick question)
Yes! Golden apples! Now, did the older brother think the golden apples were enough?

(Rolls my eyes dramatically)

(Thinks for a very short moment, then blurts out, loudly) It turned to gold! (Grins triumphantly) I knew it! Gold pizza! Gold lollipops! Gold everything! He's so lucky! (Starts skipping in a circle).
But could he *eat* the gold pizza? Could he eat gold lollipops?

(Stops skipping and frowns, but only for a second) Nope! (Pulls a face). But he could sell it! He'd be, like, super rich! He could buy *all* the candy then! (Starts grabbing invisible handfuls of candy from the air and stuffing them in imaginary pockets).

No, it wasn't cool. How do you think King Midas felt when his daughter turned to gold?

(Scratches my head, avoiding eye contact). Dunno. Sad? He couldn't, like, play with her anymore. Or give her candy. (Sticks out tongue, then quickly retracts it). He messed up. He's not so cool anymore. Can I go play now? I'm bored.

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was the story of "The Fox and the Grapes".

Now, let's talk about the story.

Why was the fox looking around?

(Starts fidgeting, swinging my legs under the desk)

Uh... (scratches head) He was... um... (looks around the room, notices a colorful poster) Was he... (points at the poster) Ooh, pretty colors!

(Teacher's voice brings me back)

Oh, right! The fox! He was... uh... (stares intensely at the teacher) Grapes?
You're right! The fox found grapes. But *why* was he looking for grapes in the first place? What did he want to do with the grapes?

(Puffs out cheeks, then blurts out loudly)

To EAT them! (Crosses arms, looks away, bored.) Duh! Are we done now? I wanna go outside! (Taps foot impatiently.)

Yes, the fox wanted to eat them! Good job!

So, he wanted to eat the grapes. Did he get to eat them?

(Scoffs)

No! (Rolls eyes) He couldn't reach them! He was too... short! (Sticks tongue out slightly). It's obvious! Can I draw now? I'm *really* bored! This is sooooo slow!

You're right, he couldn't reach them! He was trying to get the grapes, but he couldn't.

What did the fox do *after* he couldn't reach the grapes? Did he keep trying forever?

(Leans back in chair, nearly tipping over)

Nah. (Yawns loudly, without covering mouth) He gave up! He said... (Struggles to remember) ...something about them being... (Snaps fingers) ...sour! Yeah! He said they were sour! So he didn't want them anymore! (Looks pleased with myself for remembering). Can I go now? PLEASE?

Perfect! He gave up and said they were sour.

Now, why do you think the fox said the grapes were sour *after* he couldn't reach them? Do you think he really thought they were sour?

(Stares blankly at the teacher, picks at a loose thread on my shirt)

I dunno. (Shrugs shoulders) Maybe they *were* sour! (Looks confident) I'd say that, too! If I couldn't get something, I'd say it was yucky anyway! (Giggles, then quickly gets serious again) But... I wanna go play! This is dumb. Can't we just be done now? It's taking forever! (Starts drumming fingers on the desk)

Hmm, that's an interesting idea. Maybe they *were* sour. But the story doesn't really say that, does it? The story says he couldn't reach them, *then* he said they were sour.

So, if they *weren't* sour, why do you think he *said* they were sour? Maybe he was feeling a little bit of a certain way. Like... maybe a little sad, or a little... something else. What do you think?

(Frowns, looks down at my shoes. Mumbles)

Sad? Nah. (Kicks the desk lightly) He wasn't sad. He was... (thinking, pokes my cheek) He was... mad! Yeah! He was mad he couldn't get them! So he said they were sour so he wouldn't feel so bad about not getting them! (Looks up, beaming) Am I right? Am I right? Can I go now? Please, please, PLEASE? (Starts to get out of my seat)

Yes! You're right! He was probably mad, and maybe a little disappointed. He didn't want to admit that he couldn't get them.

So, the fox couldn't get the grapes, and then he said they were sour. What do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big idea the story is trying to teach us? It's called a moral. What's the moral of this story?

(Pause, giving the student time to think)

(Crosses my arms, slouches in the chair, looking bored again)

A moral? (Sighs dramatically) Ugh. I don't know! Just tell me! (Taps foot rapidly) This is taking too long! I wanna go play tag! Is it about grapes? Or foxes? Or... (trails off, looking around the room for distractions) ...sour stuff? I give up! Just tell me the answer! (Whines loudly)

Okay, okay, I won't just tell you the answer. Let's think about it together.

The fox wanted something, but he couldn't get it. Then, he said he didn't want it anyway. Does that remind you of anything else? Maybe something that happens to you sometimes? Have you ever wanted a toy that you couldn't have, and then you said you didn't want it anyway?

What do you think the story is telling us about wanting things and not being able to get them?

(Squints, thinking hard. Fidgets with my shoelaces)

Hmm... (Pauses) ...Like when Billy has the red race car and I want it, but he won't let me play with it? And then I say his race car is dumb anyway and I don't even WANT to play with it?

(Looks up, a little spark of understanding in my eyes, but still impatient)

Is it like... don't say stuff you don't mean just because you're mad you can't have something? But still... can I go soon?

Yes! You're getting it!

It's like, sometimes things are hard to get. And it's easy to say you didn't want them anyway. But the story is teaching us that it's better to try your best, and not just pretend you didn't want it in the first place. It teaches us to not hate what we can’t have.

So, we can say the moral is that nothing comes easy, and you shouldn't hate something just because you can't have it.

Do you understand? <finish>

(Runs ahead, almost knocking over a stack of books) Yeah, yeah, it was okay. (Shrugs) The rose and the... uh... spiky thing! That's who it was about. (Looks around the room, fidgeting with a loose thread on my shirt) They were in the desert, I think. That's what I remember. (Confidently) Desert!
That's right! The rose and the spiky thing - the cactus! Good remembering! What did the rose do to the cactus in the story?

(Rolls eyes) Ugh, the rose? (Scoffs) She was, like, super mean! She kept saying the cactus was ugly, right? (Pulls a face) "You're so prickly!" or something dumb like that. dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of Molly, the milkmaid!

Let's talk about it. What was Molly going to do with the milk?

(Starts fidgeting with my shoelaces, avoids eye contact)

Umm... sell it? At the market? (Shrugs) I dunno. She was gonna sell it. To get money. (Looks around the room, distracted by a fly buzzing near the window) Is that a fly? Can I catch it?

Yes, you are right! She was going to sell it to get money. But let's focus on the story for now, okay? We can catch the fly later.

So, Molly was going to sell the milk and get money. What did she start thinking about when she was walking to the market?

(Sighs loudly, rolls eyes)

Ugh. (Scratches head) Stuff. She was thinking about... stuff. Buying stuff. (Taps foot impatiently) What kind of stuff? I don't remember. (Looks at the teacher with a bored expression) Why do *I* have to remember? It's boring!
It's okay if you don't remember *exactly* what she wanted to buy. Just tell me in your own words, what *kind* of things was she dreaming about? Things she could buy with her money?

(Leans back in chair, arms crossed)

(Mumbles) A chicken. (Louder) She wanted a CHICKEN! And then, like, eggs. And more money! (Smirks) She thought she was gonna be rich! (Pushes chair back slightly, almost tipping it over) Can I go play now? This is dumb.

You're doing great! Yes, she wanted a chicken so she could get eggs and *more* money!

What happened to the milk while she was busy dreaming about chickens and money?

(Scoffs, picks at a loose thread on my shirt)

It... spilled? (Shrugs, avoids eye contact) Duh. She was too busy thinking about chickens to watch where she was going. (Mutters under breath) Stupid milkmaid. (Starts humming a random tune) So can I go now?
Yes, you're right! The milk spilled. Why did it spill? What was she doing that made the milk spill?

(Sighs dramatically and slouches in the chair)

She was skipping! (Rolls eyes.) Like a silly goose! (Makes a face) Skipping and dreaming about dumb chickens. (Starts drawing doodles on the corner of the worksheet) It's not my fault she spilled her milk.

Okay, so she was skipping and dreaming. And because she was skipping and not paying attention, the milk spilled.

So, what happened to Molly's plans to buy a chicken and get more money? Did they work out?

(Continues doodling, barely glances up)

Nope. (Pops the 'p') She went home with... (Thinks for a second) ...nothing! (Grins mischievously) Ha! Serves her right for being so dumb. (Pushes the worksheet away) Done! Can I go now, pleeeeease?

Yes, she went home with nothing.

What did her mother say to her when she got home? Do you remember? It's a saying.

(Sighs, kicks the chair leg)

(Mumbles) Something about chickens... (Thinks hard, scrunches up face) ...and eggs? Noooo... (Suddenly blurts out) Don't count your chickens 'til they hatch! (Looks proud of himself, but quickly loses interest) So? What does that even MEAN?

You got it! "Don't count your chickens 'til they hatch."

That's the important part of the story. Now, what do *you* think that saying means? What does it tell us about what Molly did? Think about the milk, and the chicken, and the money.

(Looks around the room, clearly not thinking about the story)

Umm... (Points at the window) Is that the same fly? (Tries to stand up) Can I go now? This is HARD! (Whines) I don't know what it means! It's just... chicken talk! (Giggles) Chicken talk! Cluck cluck!

Okay, okay, deep breaths. Let's think about it this way:

Molly was planning on getting money *before* she even bought the chicken, right? Was that a good idea?

(Stares blankly at the teacher, then at the ceiling)

(Mumbles) I dunno... was it? (Shrugs, picks at fingernails) I don't care. Chickens are boring anyway. (Whispers) I want a puppy. Can we talk about puppies instead?

We can talk about puppies later. Let's just finish this one thing first, okay?

So, Molly planned on getting money *before* she even HAD the chicken. What if the chicken didn't lay any eggs?

(Gasps dramatically, then laughs)

Then she'd be REALLY dumb! (Points and laughs) No money AND no eggs! (Calms down, still smirking) She'd be super mad. And her mom would say, "I TOLD you so!" (Makes a silly face) But it wouldn't be *my* fault! (Looks away, humming again)

Exactly! So, she was planning on something *before* it even happened.

So, what does "Don't count your chickens 'til they hatch" mean? It means don't make plans based on something that might not happen. Can you say that back to me in your own words?

(Sighs, leans back in the chair, looking totally bored.)

Ugh... fine. (Mumbles) Don't... make plans... for stuff... that might not... happen. (Rolls eyes) There! Happy now? Can I *PLEASE* go? I promise I'll be good! I won't even run! Maybe. (Wiggles eyebrows)

Yes! That's right! Don't make plans for stuff that might not happen. Molly made plans before she even had the chicken or the eggs.

So, do you think you understand the story now? And what it's trying to teach us?

(Stares out the window longingly, then turns back to the teacher with a weary sigh.)

Yeah, yeah. Chickens, eggs, money, blah blah blah. Don't be a dummy like Molly and plan stuff before it happens. Got it. (Taps fingers impatiently on the desk.) Now... puppies? Or playtime? (Gives a pleading look) Please?
Okay, you understand the story and what it means. You did a great job working through it! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, [Student's Name], that was a great reading of the story, "The Wise Old Owl"!

Now, can you tell me, what did the owl do every day?

(Swings legs under the table, looks around the room, then back at the teacher, speaking loudly)

Yeah, yeah, the owl... uh... (frowns) He... saw stuff! Lots of stuff! (confidently) Like, EVERYTHING! People walking! Trees... uh... being all tree-like! He saw it all! And he didn't talk so much, I guess. (shrugs, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) I wanna go outside now!

(Smiling patiently) You're right, you're right! The owl *did* see a lot of things. He saw people and trees, and lots more.

Now, you said he didn't talk so much. Do you remember *why* he didn't talk so much? What was he busy doing instead of talking?

(Sighs loudly and drums fingers on the desk) He... he didn't talk because... (looks out the window, then back at the teacher, impatiently) ... because he was watching! Duh! (rolls eyes) He was watching all those boring people talking and stuff. He already knew what they were gonna say anyway! (Stands up suddenly) Can I get a drink? I'm thirsty. This is boring. (Doesn't wait for a response, and starts walking towards the water fountain).

(Gently redirects the student) Okay, okay, you can get a drink in a little bit. But you're almost there!

You said he was watching all those people talking. And you said he already knew what they were going to say. But the story doesn't say he knew already. It says he *heard* them talking. Do you think hearing them talk helped him learn anything?

(Stops walking, scowls, then plops back down in the chair with a loud thump. Crosses arms.)

Ugh. (Stares at the desk) I don't know. Maybe? (mumbles) He heard them talk, so what? Talking is dumb. (Looks up, defiant) I like to *do* stuff, not just sit around listening to people blabber on and on! (taps foot rapidly) I want to draw pictures! Can I draw pictures now?
(Calmly) Okay, you think talking is dumb. But think about it this way: Have you ever learned something by listening to me or your parents, or even your friends?

(Scoffs) No! (Pauses, thinking. Looks around, avoiding eye contact.) Well... (mumbles, barely audible) ...maybe when you said not to touch the stove... because it's hot. (looks down at shoes) I touched it anyway. (shrugs)

So... the owl learned stuff by listening? (Looks back at the teacher, a tiny flicker of curiosity) Is that what you're saying? Is that why he got so smart? (frowns again) But I still think doing is better!

(Nods encouragingly) You touched the stove and learned it was hot! That's right! You learned by doing, and a little bit by listening to me.

Now, the owl watched AND listened. He saw things happening and he heard people talking. The story says he became wiser because of it.

Do you think watching and listening *helped* him become wiser, even if he wasn't *doing* anything?

(Sighs dramatically and leans back in chair.) Okay, fine! (Glares at the ceiling) Maybe... just *maybe*... watching and listening a little... helped him. (grumbles) But it's still boring! (Taps fingers loudly on the desk) He probably learned, like... (Pauses, thinking) ... that people argue a lot! And that squirrels steal nuts! Stuff like that. (Shrugs) But I bet he still wanted to fly around and catch mice instead! 'Cause that's way more fun! Can I tell you about the time I saw a squirrel...? (Starts to launch into a completely unrelated story, voice getting louder and more animated.)

(Gently interrupting) Whoa, whoa there! That's great, you're making connections! He probably *did* learn about squirrels stealing nuts and people arguing.

So, the owl watched and listened, and he learned a lot. Did he talk a lot about what he learned? Or did he do something else? Remember the story said, "The more things he saw, the less he would speak."

(Frowns and crosses arms again, clearly annoyed at being interrupted) He... he didn't talk. He was too busy... (pauses, looks away, then back, impatient) ...being wise! That's the whole point! (rolls eyes) He didn't need to talk, because he knew everything! (smirks) Like *I* know that recess is way more important than owls! (Jumps up again, heading for the door) Can I go now? I *really* need to tell my friend about that squirrel!

(Stands up and walks closer, but blocking the door gently) You're right, he didn't talk much. He was busy learning and thinking. So, if he wasn't talking, what was he doing with all that information he learned? He saw so much and heard so much, and that made him wise... so what do you think "wise" means?

(Stops at the door, fidgeting, but doesn't try to push past. Scowls at the floor) Wise means... (Struggles to find the words. Looks up, defiant but unsure.) ...like... knowing stuff? Knowing what's gonna happen? Like, knowing that if you touch the stove, it's gonna hurt! (Pauses, thinking harder than before) ...or knowing that if you share your toys, maybe someone will share back? (looks up at the teacher, almost hesitantly) Is that... is that wise? (A glimmer of genuine curiosity flashes in eyes)

(Smiles warmly) Yes! That's exactly right! Wise is like knowing what's going to happen, and knowing how to be smart about things. Like sharing your toys!

So, the owl watched and listened, and he learned a lot, which made him wise. And he didn't talk as much. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach *us*? Should *we* talk all the time, or should we try to be more like the owl?

(Taps foot, looking conflicted. A genuine moment of thought, rather than just wanting to leave. Looks back at the teacher, almost earnest.)

So... you're saying... maybe... I should listen more? (Frowns again) But talking is fun! And I have lots of important things to say! Like about the squirrel! (pauses, considering)

Maybe... maybe I could try to listen a *little* more. (shrugs) But only if the other person has something interesting to say! (grins) And maybe then... I'd be a little bit wiser... like the owl! (Starts bouncing on the balls of feet, excited again.) Can I go tell my friend *now*? I promise I'll listen to him for at least five seconds!

(Chuckles softly) That's a great idea! Listening for five seconds is a very good start.

So, you understand that the owl became wise by watching and listening, and that maybe we can learn something by doing that too. We don't have to stop talking completely, but we can try to listen and observe more. Talk less and be more observant. That's what the story is about.

Now, yes, you can go tell your friend about the squirrel! And remember to listen for those five seconds! <finish>

(Sighs dramatically, rolls eyes). He sold them! (Louder) Duh! He got money! (Stands up again, points at the door). Can I *please* go now? I need to tell Sarah about the shiny eggs! She likes shiny things!

(Scowls, crosses arms) Happy! (Confidently) They had, like, tons of money! They could buy, like, a million candy bars! (Starts humming loudly to myself, tapping on the desk). So can I go now? This is boring! (Pushes book away)

(Giggles, but still avoids eye contact) He... he cut it open! (Confidently) I know that part! He wanted all the eggs at once! (Makes a chopping motion with hand) Chop, chop, chop! Can I get a sticker for knowing that?

You're right! It was a very silly thing to do. So now the goose is gone. What happens to the farmer and his wife *after* that? Are they still happy with lots of money?

(Shakes head vigorously, starts to draw on the desk with a finger) Nope! (Louder) They were poor! They had no more eggs! (Confidently) Stupid farmer! He ruined everything! He should have just been happy! (Starts making airplane noises quietly)
You're exactly right! They became poor. So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What lesson does it teach us? Should we always try to get more and more, or should we...?

(Stops making airplane noises, scowls) Don't be greedy! (Confidently) That's what it means! If you're greedy, you get nothing! (Points at the book) He was greedy and he got guts! (Giggles) Can I go now? I promise I'll be super quiet sharpening my pencil!

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Farmer and the Well".

First, can you tell me: Who bought the well?
(Starts swinging my legs under the table, not really looking at the teacher) Uh... the farmer! (Confidently) He did! He bought it! I know that! (Looks away, already bored) Can we go outside now?
Yes, you're right! The farmer bought the well. Good job! But what happened *after* he bought it? Could he use it? What did the neighbor say?

(Keeps swinging legs, now humming a little tune) He... (Stuttering) He couldn't... use it? (Frowns, picking at a loose thread on my pants) The neighbor... (Louder, interrupting) said NO! He said it wasn't his water! He just sold the... the... hole in the ground! (Looks at the teacher, a little defiant) He was mean!
You're right, the neighbor *was* being mean! Why do you think the neighbor didn't want the farmer to use the water?

(Scoffs, rolling my eyes) 'Cause he's a jerk! (Crosses arms, looking away) He didn't want the farmer to have any water. Maybe he wanted all the water for himself! (Shrugs) He's probably a big water hog! Can I go get a drink? I'm thirsty.
Okay, he was being selfish. But what did the farmer do when the neighbor wouldn't let him use the water? Did he just give up?

(Taps foot impatiently) No! He... he went to the... the... big boss! The emperor guy! (Points a finger in the air) He told the emperor guy the neighbor was being a... a... meanie! (Grins, pleased with myself) And then the emperor guy would fix it! Emperors are good at fixing stuff!
That's right! The farmer went to the emperor. And what did the emperor's helper (the courtier) say to the neighbor?

(Sighs dramatically, slumping in chair) Uh... (Thinking) He said... (Suddenly shouts) Pay rent! Or take the water away! (Beams proudly) I remembered! Pay rent! That's a funny thing to say about water! (Giggles) Can I draw a picture now?
You did remember! Paying rent for the water IS a funny thing. Why do you think the courtier told him to do that? What was the courtier trying to show the neighbor?

(Stares blankly) Show? (Picks nose) I don't know. 'Cause he was being a meanie? (Shrugs) Maybe the courtier was gonna take all his money! (Grins mischievously) Then he wouldn't be a meanie anymore, 'cause he'd be poor!

Hmm, not exactly to take his money... but the courtier wanted the neighbor to realize that he was being unfair. If the neighbor sold the well, he couldn't stop the farmer from using the water.

So, what happened to the neighbor at the end? Did he win? Did he get to keep the water?

(Shakes head vigorously) No way! (Stands up, ready to run) He lost! He had to say sorry! (Makes a face) "Sorry, farmer! I was being a stinky butt!" (Laughs loudly, running around the table) He lost! He lost! Can I go play now? I wanna play tag!
He *did* lose! He had to say sorry. So, what do you think we can learn from this story? Is it good to be like the neighbor?

(Stops running, but still bouncing on the balls of my feet) No! Don't be a meanie! (Points at an imaginary person) Don't be a water hog! (Shrugs) Share your stuff! (Looks longingly at the door) 'Cause if you don't, the emperor guy will make you pay rent! Or something. Now can I PLEASE go play? Tag is starting! (Starts edging towards the door).
Okay, almost there! So, if you try to trick people and be unfair, like the neighbor, do you think it will work out for you in the end? Will you win?

(Sighs heavily, practically vibrating with impatience) No! (Raises voice slightly) You won't win! You'll have to say sorry! (Looks directly at the teacher, pleadingly) And nobody wants to say sorry! Now can I GOOOOO? Please? Pretty please with sugar on top? (Starts doing a little jump-dance)

You got it! If you try to cheat people, it won't work out for you. You'll probably have to say sorry. So, it's better to be honest and fair. That's what the story is trying to teach us.

Now, go have fun playing tag! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends".

Now, can you tell me, at the start of the story, how did the elephant feel?

(Starts fidgeting with my pencil, looking around the room)

Umm... (stuttering) He... he was... in the story. I heard you read it. (Looks away, then back quickly) He was... trying to find... something. What was it again? Friends? Yeah, he wanted those. But nobody wanted to play.
That's right! He was trying to find friends. And how did he feel when no one wanted to be his friend? Was he happy, sad, or angry?

(Sighs loudly, tapping my foot)

Happy? (scoffs) No way! If I asked people to play tag and they all said no, I wouldn't be happy. (crosses arms) He probably just... kicked something. Like I would! (grins mischievously) He... he was sad. Maybe. I don't care (looks away).

Okay, it's okay if you don't care, but try to remember the story! It's important to understand how the elephant felt. You said if people didn't want to play tag with *you*, you would be sad. Do you think the elephant felt the same way?

(Starts humming, looking at the ceiling)

Tag is way better than... whatever the elephant was doing. (pauses) Probably. Maybe a little bit sad. Not a lot. He's big! He should just find bigger friends. Like a dinosaur! (laughs loudly and then stops abruptly).
Okay, well he couldn't find a dinosaur, could he? So, he asked the other animals in the forest. Why didn't the monkey want to be his friend?

(Picking at a loose thread on my shirt. Blurts out)

'Cause he's too big! Duh! Monkeys climb trees. Elephants don't! It's... it's super obvious! You even said it in the story! (rolls eyes) Can we be done now? I wanna draw.
You're right, the monkey said he was too big to climb trees. What did the rabbit say? Why couldn't the rabbit be the elephant's friend?

(Sighs dramatically, slumping in chair)

The rabbit... (taps pencil on the desk, making a loud noise) ...Something about a hole? (shrugs) It was dumb! He's too big to fit in the hole. Just like the monkey thing. All the animals are stupid. Can I go now? This is boring!

Okay, almost there! You're remembering the story really well! Yes, the rabbit said he was too big to fit in the burrow.

So, all the animals said no because the elephant was too big. Then, what happened the next day? Why were all the animals running?

(Stands up suddenly, almost knocking over the desk)

A tiger! (yells) A big, scary tiger! Rawr! (makes a clawing motion with hands, then sits back down, bored again) Everyone was running 'cause they were gonna get eaten! (grins mischievously) Maybe.
Yes! A tiger! And what did the elephant do about the tiger?

(Starts drawing a spaceship on my notebook, not looking up)

He... uh... (scribbles harder) He kicked it! (Looks up suddenly, grinning) Yeah! He kicked the tiger! Pow! Right in the... (trails off, looking embarrassed) ... wherever!
He did! He kicked the tiger! And what happened after he kicked the tiger? How did the other animals feel about the elephant *then*?

(Stops drawing, leans forward, a bit more interested)

Hmm... (taps chin) They... they liked him! 'Cause he saved them from the tiger! He was... useful. (pauses, thinking) So they wanted to play with him! (smiles slightly) Finally! So, can I go now?
They did like him! And why did they like him *then*, even though he was still the same size? What did they realize about the elephant?

(Shrugs, starts doodling again)

'Cause he was... strong? I dunno. 'Cause they were scared of the tiger and he wasn't? (Looks up, a little confused) He was big enough to kick the tiger! That's all that matters. (grins) Big is good! Can I go color now?

Big *can* be good! You're right! The elephant was big and strong and he helped them.

So, at first, the animals didn't want to be friends with the elephant because he was too big. But then, they *did* want to be his friend because he was big enough to save them. What does that tell you about friends? Can friends be different sizes and shapes?

(Sighs, leans back in chair, looking at the ceiling)

(Mumbles) I guess so...

(Louder) If they can kick tigers. Otherwise, what's the point? (grabs crayons) Can I PLEASE go now? My picture needs blue.

Okay, but think about it. The story shows us that even though the animals were different sizes, they could still be friends. The elephant was big, and the others were small, but he helped them. Does that mean friends have to be exactly the same to be helpful or to care about each other?

Think about it this way. Is there only one type of friend you can have?

(Hesitates, crayon in hand, looks down at the spaceship drawing)

(Mumbles quietly) No...

(Looks up, a little defiant) But it's better if they can kick tigers! Or... or help you get the good snacks! Or... something! (shrugs) I don't know! Just... different is okay, if they're useful. (Starts coloring the spaceship blue, finally satisfied). I'm done! Can I go now? Please?

You're right! Different is okay! And friends don't have to be exactly the same to be good friends. They can be different sizes, have different skills, and help each other in different ways.

So, what's the big idea of the story? What can you learn from it?

(Puts down the crayon, looks at the teacher impatiently)

That big elephants can kick tigers? And then everyone likes them? (Rolls eyes, taps foot) That's it! Can I go now? I need to show this picture to my real friends, not... (gestures vaguely) ...this.

Almost! It's not *just* about kicking tigers. It's about realizing that friends can be any shape or size. The elephant was different, but he was still a good friend.

So, the story teaches us that friends can be any shape or size. We should not judge someone based on appearance or what they look like.

You did really well! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was a fun one, right?

So, tell me, what did the girl feel at the beginning of the story?

(Starts fidgeting with my shoelaces, avoiding eye contact)

Umm... (shrugs) I don't know. Something about...stuff? She asked her dad a question, right? (Looks away, disinterested)

That's okay! It's good you remember she asked her dad a question.

Do you remember *why* she asked her dad a question? Was she happy or sad or maybe a little angry? How did she feel about her life?

(Scoffs, rolling my eyes)

Happy? (scoffs again) No way! Why would she ask her dad something if she was happy? She was probably... mad. Yeah, mad! About... (pauses, trying to remember) ...life, I guess. Life's dumb anyway! (Crosses my arms, looking away from the teacher, kicking the desk lightly with my foot).

Okay, you're right! She wasn't happy. "Mad" is a good word. The story said she was "frustrated". That means she was feeling annoyed and maybe a little helpless about things in her life.

So, she was frustrated with life. What did her dad *do* to help her?

(Starts tapping my pencil on the desk, louder and louder)

He... uh... made food? I think? He put stuff in water. (Stops tapping, looks at the teacher with a bored expression) Like the potato! And... something else. I forget. Can I go now? This is boring.

You're doing great! You remembered the potato. Yes, he put things in water. That's right!

He put *three* things in water. Can you remember one more? Think about breakfast foods! One was white, and you can peel it!

(Grumbling under my breath) Breakfast is yucky.

(Suddenly blurts out) An egg! He put an egg in the water! (Looks around, then quickly back down at the desk, pleased with getting the answer right). So... potato and egg. That's two. What was the third one? I don't wanna guess anymore (whining). Just tell me!

You got the egg! That's fantastic!

Okay, I'll give you a hint for the last one. Think about what adults like to drink in the morning, that sometimes smells really good!

(Wrinkles my nose) Smells gross! (pauses, thinking for a very short moment) Coffee? No! (Shakes my head vigorously) Something like coffee... but not. Is it... tea? Tea leaves? He put tea leaves in the water? That's weird. (Looks at the teacher, expecting confirmation, but also ready to argue if I'm wrong).

Yes! Tea leaves! He put tea leaves in the water. Good job remembering!

Now, after they were in the hot water for a while, what happened to the potato? Was it still hard, or did it change?

(Stands up suddenly, almost knocking over my chair, and starts pacing around the small space next to my desk)

I wanna go outside! This is taking too long. I know the answer! The potato was... soft! It got all mushy! (Continues pacing, ignoring the teacher, starting to hum loudly). Can I go now? The bell's gonna ring soon!

Okay, okay! Almost done. You're right, the potato got soft.

And what about the egg? What happened to the egg?

(Stops pacing and stands still, looking at the teacher with a defiant glare)

The egg? (Rolls eyes) It got hard! Duh! This is SO easy! (Taps foot impatiently, looking around the room).
Exactly! The potato got soft, and the egg got hard. And what did the tea leaves do to the water? Did they get hard or soft?

(Sighs loudly and dramatically)

This is so boring! They changed the water! Like...made it tea! (Throws hands up in the air) Can I PLEASE go now? I already know everything! (Starts heading for the door).

Okay, you're doing great! You're almost there. Stay with me for just a couple more minutes.

The tea changed the water itself. So, the dad showed his daughter the potato, the egg, and the tea. He wanted her to understand something about how we deal with problems.

The hot water was like the problem, right? The adversity. Did the potato, the egg, and the tea all react to the problem in the same way?

(Stops at the door, hesitates, then slowly walks back to my desk, kicking the rug)

No! (Crosses arms again) The potato got soft. The egg got hard. And the tea... made tea. (Shrugs) So? What's the big deal? Everyone knows that!

You're right, they all reacted differently. The big deal is *why* the dad showed her that!

The hot water was like a difficult situation, right? The potato, egg, and tea were like *us*. Sometimes, life throws hard things at us. What do you think the dad wanted his daughter to learn about how *she* could be like the potato, the egg, or the tea?

(Stares blankly at the teacher, then looks out the window, completely disinterested)

I don't know. I don't care. (Mumbles) I want to play outside... (Starts humming again, louder this time, tapping my foot on the floor). Can I go now? Please? Pleeeeease? (Starts pulling on the hem of my shirt, avoiding eye contact). This story is dumb.

Okay, I hear you. You want to go play. Let's just try one more thing.

Think about it this way: The potato started out strong, but the hot water made it weak. The egg started out fragile, but the hot water made it strong. The tea... well, it changed the water itself.

Which one do you think is the best way to be when things get hard? The potato, the egg, or the tea? Why?

(Sighs dramatically, then mumbles, barely audible)

The tea, I guess. (Looks up quickly, then looks away again). 'Cause it changed stuff. Not just itself. It changed the water. (Pause, thinking briefly, then shrugs) I dunno. Can I go now?

You got it! The tea changed the water! That's a really important idea.

The dad wanted his daughter to know that when things get tough, she has a choice. She can become weak like the potato, or hard like the egg, *or* she can be like the tea and change the situation itself! She can decide how she reacts.

So, what's the big idea of the story? What did the dad want his daughter to learn?

(Stands up abruptly, pushing my chair back loudly, making a scraping noise on the floor)

He wanted her to make tea! (Bursts out laughing, then quickly stops, looking embarrassed) Just kidding! (Shrugs) I don't know! I told you, this is boring! (Heads for the door again, mumbling under my breath) Just wanna go outside...

(Gently redirects the student)

Come on, you are so close! The dad wanted his daughter to know that she can *choose* how she reacts when things get hard. She can choose to be strong, or she can choose to change the situation.

So, we *decide* how to...?

(Stops at the door again, sighs heavily, then turns around, scuffing my shoes on the floor)

We... decide how to... (pauses, looks up at the ceiling, thinking for a very brief moment) ...deal with it? Yeah! We decide how to deal with... stuff! (Beams proudly for a fleeting second, then looks down again, eager to escape) Now can I *please* go? I really, really need to go play!

Yes! You got it! We decide how to respond to difficult situations! That's the whole point of the story. You did a great job figuring that out.

You can go play now! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of The Needle Tree!

Now, let's talk about it. What was the older brother doing in the forest?

(Starts fidgeting and swinging my legs) Uh... firewood! (Confidently) He was getting firewood! To sell! In the... market! (Looks around the room, distracted by a colorful poster) Yeah! Firewood! Big pile of it! He was... uh... strong. (Scowls slightly)
That's right! He was chopping wood to sell. And what happened when he found the special tree? What did the tree say?

(Shrugs, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) Don't cut me down! (Confidently, but a little too loud) It said that! (Rolls my eyes) Said it would give... stuff. Golden apples! (Sticks out tongue slightly) Stupid apples.
Good job remembering! The tree offered him golden apples. Did the older brother seem happy with the apples?

(Scoffs) Happy? (Crosses arms and avoids eye contact) No way! (Speaks loudly) He wanted MORE! He's... (pauses, searching for the right word) ...greedy! Like, REALLY greedy! (Taps foot impatiently). He wanted all the apples! All of them!
You're right, he was greedy. What happened when he tried to cut the tree down anyway?

(Grins mischievously) Needles! (Claps hands once, excitedly) Lots and lots of needles! (Frowns quickly) Serves him right! (Shrugs again) He was being a jerk. (Looks out the window, momentarily distracted by a bird)
He did get a lot of needles! Who helped him when he was hurt?
(Grumbling) His... (pauses, thinking) ...little brother. (Looks down at shoes) The dumb one. (Quickly looks up, meeting the teacher's eyes with a defiant stare) He helped him. I guess.
Why do you think the younger brother helped him, even though the older brother wasn't very nice?

(Shrugs, kicks at the floor) Dunno. (Mumbles) Maybe he's stupid too. (Speaks louder) Or... (pauses, thinking) ...maybe... (looks away, hesitant) ...he felt sorry for him? (Looks back, annoyed) But I wouldn't! Not if someone stuck me with a bunch of needles! (Frowns again)
Feeling sorry for someone, even when they aren't nice to you, is called being kind. What happened after the younger brother helped him? Did the tree do anything?

(Confidently) More apples! (Rolls eyes) Of course! The tree gave them even MORE apples! (Sighs dramatically). Stupid tree giving away all its apples. Should have kept them. (Looks around again, losing focus)
Why do you think the tree gave them more apples *after* the younger brother helped? What changed?

(Picks at fingernails) Changed? (Scowls) Nothing changed! (Pauses, thinking for a very short time) Uh... maybe... (hesitates, voice quieter) ...maybe the tree liked that the... the mean brother said sorry? (Looks up quickly, defensively) But saying sorry doesn't fix anything!

It's true that saying sorry doesn't always fix things right away, but it can be a start. Maybe the tree saw that the older brother was learning to be kinder.

So, the older brother was mean, and he got needles. Then he was helped, and he said sorry, and they got more apples. What do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the lesson?

(Sighs loudly, leaning back in the chair) Lessons are boring! (Crosses arms again) Uh... (Stares at the ceiling) ...Don't be greedy? And... (Mumbles) ...say sorry? (Looks at the teacher with a challenging look) But that's dumb. Sometimes people don't *deserve* a "sorry." (Taps foot impatiently) Can I go now?

You're right, it's important to be sorry. But there's more to it. Think about it this way: The mean brother got needles. The kind brother got apples. What does that tell you about being kind versus being mean? Which one do you think the story says is better?

(Frowns, thinking a little harder, but still distracted, doodling on the corner of a worksheet with a pencil) Hmmm... (Pauses) Kind... (Looks down at the doodle) ...I guess kind is... better? (Looks up quickly, defensively) But being mean is more fun sometimes! (Shrugs) But... the story... (Mumbles) ...kind gets you apples... (Looks away, uninterested)

Kindness getting you apples is a good way to put it! So, the story shows that being kind, even when it's hard, can lead to good things. It's like the tree wanted to reward the kindness. Sometimes, being kind to others will make *them* be kind to you. The story is trying to tell us that kindness is usually rewarded. Does that make sense?

(Nods slowly, still doodling) ...Reward... (Looks up briefly, then back down at the worksheet) So, like... if I'm nice... (Scoffs) ...which I'm *not* going to be... but *if* I was... then I'd get... rewards? (Looks up, a flicker of interest in eyes) Like... what kind of rewards? (Taps pencil on the desk). Is it apples? I don't like apples.

The "rewards" don't have to be apples! It could be feeling good about yourself, or having friends who care about you. In the story, what was the *best* reward? Was it just the apples? Or was it that the brothers were nicer to each other in the end?

(Thinks for a moment, actually looking thoughtful) Hmmm... (Taps pencil on the desk again) Not the dumb apples... (Looks at the teacher, a little unsure) ...Maybe... (pauses, searching for the right words) ...maybe the best thing was that they weren't fighting anymore? (Shrugs, but the shrug is less dismissive than before) Like... they were... not yelling at each other? (Looks down at shoes, thinking) That's... okay, I guess. (Mumbles) Not as good as a candy bar though.

You're right, not yelling at each other is a good thing! It made them both happier. So, the story teaches us that being kind can lead to good things, like friendship and happiness. That's why we say, "Kindness will always be rewarded." Do you think you understand the story and its message now?

(Nods slowly) Yeah... (Pauses, then a mischievous glint in eyes) So, if I'm *super* nice... (Leans forward conspiratorially) ...do I get, like, a *giant* pile of candy? (Grins) Just wondering! (Starts fidgeting again, ready to move on). Am I done now?

(Chuckles) Well, maybe not a giant pile of candy! But being kind will definitely bring good things your way. You did a great job understanding the story and its message. Yes, you're all done now! <finish>
