dialogue:
Okay, [Student's Name], that was a good reading! Now, let's talk about the story.

First, who was the main person in our story?

Yes! Midas. Good job!

And what did King Midas wish for?
(Stares at the table, picks at a loose thread) Uh... everything... uh... gold? (shrugs)

You're right! He wished for everything he touched to turn to gold.

Now, tell me, was Dionysus happy about Midas' wish? Did he want him to have it?
(Sighs loudly) ...Uh... no. (eyes dart around the room) He said no.
He did say no! Why do you think Dionysus didn't want him to have that wish?
(Crosses arms, scowls) I dunno. (mumbles) Stupid wish anyway.
It *was* a pretty big wish! Okay, let's think about what happened *after* he got the golden touch. What was the first problem Midas had?
(Thinking, chewing on a fingernail) ...Uh... food? He couldn't... uh... eat it? 'Cause it turned... uh... hard?
Yes! He couldn't eat! Why couldn't he eat? What happened to the food?
(Rolls eyes) ...It turned to gold! Duh! (shifts in seat, looking bored)
Right! The food turned to gold. So, was the golden touch making him happy when he was hungry?
Stupid gold indeed! What happened after he couldn't eat? Who came to see him?
Yes, his daughter! What happened when she hugged him?
(Eyes widen, voice cracks) ...She... she turned to gold too! (starts to tear up, rubs eyes roughly) It's not fair!
No, it wasn't fair. How did Midas feel when his daughter turned to gold?
(Sniffles, voice trembling) ...Sad! Really, really sad! He didn't want that! (buries face in hands) It was a bad wish!
You're right. It *was* a bad wish. He thought gold would make him happy, but did it?
(Looks up, face red) No! (voice louder, more confident) It made him... it made him lose his daughter! Gold is... is dumb! (wipes nose with sleeve)
Gold *can* be pretty, but it's not everything, is it? So, Midas wanted more and more gold. And what happened because he wanted so much gold?
(Thinking, taps foot impatiently) ...He learned that... uh... (struggles) ...that family is... uh... better than gold? (looks at you questioningly)
That's a great way to put it! He learned that family is more important than gold. Sometimes, wanting too much of something... what do you think can happen if we want too much of something?
(Frowns, picks at a scab on knee) ...Uh... we get... greedy? And... and then we lose stuff that's important? (looks up, anxious) Like... like Midas lost his daughter?

Exactly! Wanting too much can make us greedy, and being greedy can make us lose things that are truly important. The story teaches us that being greedy can lead to bad things happening. Do you think you understand the story now? <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! I liked how you said "purple"!

Now, let's talk about the fox. Was he happy at the start of the story? Why or why not?
Uh... (looks away, fidgeting with hands) ...no. He wasn't happy. 'Cause... uh... he was hungry. (Stuttering) He... he couldn't find... food.

That's right! He was hungry and couldn't find food. Good job!

So, he was hungry, then he saw the grapes. How did he feel then? Did he still feel hungry? What did he want to do?
(Sighs heavily) ...I dunno. (Scowls). He... he wanted the grapes. 'Cause they were...big. And...purple. (Uses air quotes) Juicy. He... probably still hungry. ...Uh...

You're doing great! Yes, he probably was still hungry, and he really wanted those big, purple, juicy grapes.

What did he do to try and get them?
(Sits back, picks at a loose thread on shirt) Jumped. (Rolls eyes) He jumped... duh. Like... a million times. (Mumbles) Stupid fox.

He did jump, didn't he? And you're right, he jumped a lot!

Did he get the grapes?
(Shakes head, eyes darting around the room) ...No. (Mumbles under breath) ...Of course not.
No, he didn't. What happened at the end of the story? What did he say about the grapes then?
(Crosses arms, looks down at shoes) ...Said they were sour. (Scoffs) ...Like, whatever. They probably weren't even sour. (Starts tapping foot nervously)

You're very clever! You noticed that he *said* they were sour.

Do you *think* they were really sour? Why did he say that?
(Looks up, surprised) ...Maybe... maybe he just... (Thinking, frowns) ...Didn't wanna say he couldn't get them. (Chews on lip, then blurts out) ...'Cause that's... dumb. (Looks away again, anxious)

That's a very good idea! He didn't want to admit he couldn't get them. It's like he was trying to make himself feel better.

So, he couldn't get something he wanted, and then he pretended he didn't want it anyway. Have you ever felt like that?
(Eyes widen slightly, then quickly looks down again. Voice barely a whisper) ...Maybe. (Shrugs, fidgeting) ...Sometimes things are... hard. (Mumbles) ...Stupid.

Yes, sometimes things *are* hard. And it can be frustrating!

So, what do you think the story is trying to tell us? Is it a good idea to say something is bad just because you can't have it?

(Pauses, staring intently at a spot on the table) ...Uh... (Pulls at a thread on clothing.) No. (More confidently) ...It's... like... lying. To yourself. (Shrugs.) ...Maybe. (Anxious look on face) I... I don't know.

You're on the right track! It *is* a little bit like lying to yourself.

Think about it this way: the fox wanted the grapes, but he couldn't get them. What else could he have done instead of saying they were sour? Maybe try again later? Maybe find something else to eat?

(Thinking hard, pushes hair out of face.) He... he could... (Stuttering) ...try...try to get them... with a... a stick? (Confidently) Or... or find... find apples! (Voice trails off, back to being unsure) ...But... but what if... what if there aren't any apples? (Worried look)

Those are great ideas! Using a stick, or finding apples!

Even if there aren't any apples right *now*, maybe he could keep looking. The story shows us that sometimes, getting what we want is hard. It takes effort. And sometimes, we just can't get what we want *right now*.

So, what do you think the story wants us to remember about trying to get things and not getting them right away?

(Deep breath, seems a little calmer) ...Uh... (Looks at teacher, then away again) ...Don't... don't say they're sour just 'cause... you can't... reach them. (Fidgets) ...Keep... keep trying... maybe? (Hangs head) ...Or find apples. (Small, almost inaudible, sigh)

Yes! Don't say they're sour just because you can't reach them, and maybe keep trying! That's a great way to put it.

So, here is the lesson that the story is trying to teach you.
Nothing comes easy, do not hate what you can’t have.

Can you tell me what this means in your own words?

(Sits quietly for a long time, picks at fingernails, then finally looks up, a little nervous but also a little determined) ...It means... (Stuttering) ...it means... things... things are... hard. (Takes a deep breath) ...And... and if you... if you can't... get something... (Looks down) ...Don't be... mean about it. Or... or lie. (Looks up, almost defiant) ...Just... just try... something else. ...Or wait. (Softly) ...I think.

That's a *perfect* way to say it! You understood the story and what it means. Things are hard, don't lie about it, try something else, or maybe just wait.

You did a wonderful job today! I'm very proud of you. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Proud Rose! I liked how you read it.

Now, can you tell me in your own words, who are the characters in the story?
Uh... (shrugs, looks down at my shoes) The rose... and the cactus. (fidgets with my pencil) ...and... some birds, I think? (scowls a little)

Yes, you got it! The rose, the cactus, and the birds! Good job.

Now, tell me, what kind of plant was the rose? Was it happy or sad?
(Sighs loudly) Happy? (rolls eyes) I dunno. (taps pencil on the desk repeatedly) It was... proud. The story said that. (mumbles) Stupid rose.
(Smiling) You're right, the rose was proud! And what did the rose do because she was so proud? How did she treat the cactus?
(Looks away, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) ...Mean. She was mean to the cactus. (mutters) Like a bully.
That's right! She was being a bully. Why do you think she was being mean to the cactus? What did she say or do?
(Stares blankly at the teacher, then at the ceiling) ...'Cause the cactus wasn't... pretty? (Shrugs again) The story... it said she liked how she looked. (crosses arms) So what?

You're doing great! Yes, the rose thought she was prettier than the cactus.

Now, what happened when the summer got really, really hot? What happened to the rose?
(Starts bouncing my leg nervously) Uh... (stutters) It... it... died? (Looks anxious) It got all... wrinkly and stuff. No water. (eyes dart around the room)
Not quite dead, but she was not doing well! She was thirsty. Now, what about the cactus? What was the cactus doing?
(Thinking, chewing on my pencil eraser) The cactus... uh... it had water? (confused) For the birds? ...I don't get it. Why would it help birds? (frowns)
That's a very good question! The cactus was helping the birds. Now, the rose was thirsty, and the cactus had water. What did the rose do then?
(Sighs dramatically) ...Asked for water? (Looks at the teacher with a challenging glare) I bet the cactus said no. Serves her right.
(Chuckles softly) But what *did* the cactus do? Did it say no, or something else? Remember what happened in the story!
(Hesitates, looks down at my hands) ...Uh... (mumbles) It gave her water. The stupid cactus gave the mean rose water. (voice rising slightly, frustrated) Why would it do that?! That's not fair!

That's a great question! Why *did* the cactus help the rose, even after the rose was mean? That's something to think about.

So, the rose was mean because she thought she was prettier. The cactus helped even though the rose was mean. What do you think we can learn from this story?

(Pushes chair back slightly, looking agitated) Learn...? (Scoffs) Nothing! It's a dumb story! (Stands up abruptly, then sits back down, sighing loudly) ...Uh... maybe... don't be mean? But the rose was pretty! (Looks confused and frustrated) I don't know! (Starts to tear up a little) This is stupid!

It's okay! It can be tricky to figure out the lesson of a story.

Think about it this way: The rose judged the cactus because of how it looked. Was that a good thing to do? What did the cactus do?

(Sniffling, wiping my nose with my sleeve) ...No. It wasn't good. (Mumbles) The cactus... it was nice. Even when the rose... (voice cracks) ...wasn't. (Looks down, avoiding eye contact) So... be nice even if people are mean? (Hesitates) But... that's hard.

It *is* hard! But you're getting close. The story isn't just about being nice *all* the time, but about *why* the rose was mean in the first place. She thought because she looked pretty, she was better. Is that true? Is being pretty the most important thing?

(Thinking hard, tapping my foot) ...No. (Looks up, eyes widening slightly) The cactus... it helped the birds. It was useful. The rose... was just... pretty. And mean. (Frowns) So... being useful is better than being pretty? Is that the lesson? (Anxious) Is that right?

Being useful is definitely important! But the story is also about not judging. The rose judged the cactus *because* of how it looked. The cactus didn't look like a "pretty" rose, so the rose thought she was better. But was that fair? Can we tell if someone is good or bad just by looking at them?

(Shakes head slowly, chewing on lip) ...No. You can't tell. (Looks down at my hands) The rose was pretty... but mean. The cactus... looked weird... but helped. (Looks up at the teacher, a little less anxious) So... don't judge people... by how they look? Be nice... even if they're not pretty? (Hesitates) Or mean? (Sniffs) Is that it?

Yes, that's it! You got it! The story teaches us that we should never judge someone based on how they look. The rose was beautiful on the outside, but not so beautiful on the inside. The cactus may not have looked as pretty, but it was kind and helpful. It's important to look beyond the outside and see the good in everyone. Good job!<finish>

dialogue:
Okay! You just read the story of Molly, the milkmaid.

Can you tell me, what was Molly going to do with the milk?
(Looks down, fidgeting with my shoelaces) Uh... (Stutters) Se...Sell it? At the... market?

Yes! That's right! She was going to sell it at the market.

And what did she start thinking about while she walked to the market? What did she want to buy?
(Sighs, rolls eyes slightly) (Mumbles) I dunno... something stupid. (Looks away, picking at a loose thread on my shirt)
It's okay if you don't remember *exactly*. But try to think... What did she *hope* to do with the money from the milk? What was her *plan*? Even if it was a bit silly.
(Glares) It *was* silly! (Pauses, thinking) (Scoffs) She wanted... a chicken? Yeah, a chicken. So dumb.
A chicken! Yes! Why did she want a chicken? What did she think the chicken would do for her?
(Crosses arms, scowls) Lay eggs, duh! (Looks at the teacher with a challenging look) Then she'd be rich. Stupid rich.

Okay, so she thought the chicken would lay eggs and she could sell *those* too.

What happened *while* she was thinking about all this money and the chicken? What happened to the milk?
(Shrugs, looks away) (Mumbles) It spilled. So what? Big deal. (Starts tapping foot impatiently)
It *did* spill! Was that a good thing or a bad thing that the milk spilled? Why?
(Raises eyebrows, voice dripping with sarcasm) Oh, it was *great*. Super duper! (Pauses) (Normal Voice) No, it was bad! 'Cause then she had no milk. (Looks down, scuffing shoes on the floor)
Right! She had no milk to sell. So, did she get to buy the chicken and become "stupid rich"?
(Shakes head violently) NO! (Says loudly). She got nothin'! (Sighs dramatically, throws hands up in the air) It's so unfair!
It *was* unfair for her! Now, at the end of the story, what did Molly's mother say to her? Do you remember her words? It was something about chickens.

(Frowns, thinking hard) (Bites lip) Ugh... something... somethin' 'bout countin'... (Glares at the ceiling as if the answer is written there) ... before they... (snaps fingers) hatch! Don't count your chickens before they hatch! (Looks proud for a brief second, then the scowl returns) So what?

You got it! "Don't count your chickens before they hatch."

So, what do you think that means for Molly? What should she have done differently?

(Scoffs) It means... (pauses, thinking but looking annoyed) ...uh... don't spend your money 'til you *have* it? (Looks at the teacher expectantly, then looks away again) It's obvious! (Mumbles) Stupid story.

You're right! It means don't spend your money until you *have* it.

Can you think of another way to say that? Maybe like... don't *rely* on something until you're sure it will happen?
(Crosses arms again, leans back in chair) (Grumbling) Whatever. Don't get your hopes up, I guess. 'Cause you'll just be sad when it doesn't happen. Like Molly. (Kicks at the desk leg absentmindedly)
Exactly! Molly got her hopes up too high before she even *sold* the milk. So, do you think you understand the story now? What did Molly learn?

(Sighs deeply) (Reluctantly) Yeah, yeah. I get it. Don't be a dummy and plan your whole life before you even... do anything. (Looks down at hands, picks at a fingernail) (Muttering) It's still a stupid story.
Okay! I think you understand the story and what it's trying to teach us. It's about being careful and not expecting things to happen before they actually do. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, let's talk about the owl!

You just read the story. What did the old owl do every day?
Uh... (shrugs shoulders, looking down at my hands) ...he... uh... saw stuff?
Yes! He saw stuff. What kind of stuff did he see? Was he inside his house?
(Fidgets with my pencil) ... uh... outside? Near... a tree? I think. (Looks away, nervously) Uh... people?
Good job! You remembered! He was outside near his oak tree. And he saw people. What were the people doing? The story tells us.
(Sighs, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) ...Talking? ...Stories? I dunno. Is this gonna be on the test? (Eyes widen, voice trembling slightly) It's not a hard test, right?

Don't worry! This isn't a test. We are just talking about the story. You are doing great!

Yes, the people were talking and sharing stories. So, the owl saw things and heard things. What did the owl *not* do much of? The story tells us that too.
(Thinking, chews on the end of the pencil) ...Not... talk? (Looks up at the teacher briefly, then back down) He... he saw *more* and talked *less*?
You got it! He saw more and talked less. Now, why do you think the story says he became wiser?

(Confused, scrunches up face) ...Wiser? Like... smarter? (Looks around the room, distracted by the other kids) Why's she wearing that weird hat? (Mumbles under breath) It's so dumb...

(Suddenly remembering the question) ... Uh... because he saw stuff? And heard stuff? (Shrugs again) I don't get it.

You're close! He saw and heard things. He *listened* to the stories.

Think about it this way: if you are always talking, can you hear what other people are saying?

(Crosses arms, looks annoyed) ...No. Duh. (Rolls eyes) Everyone knows that.

But what's that gotta do with... with the owl? (Taps foot impatiently) Can we be done now? I wanna go play.

Okay, almost done! You said it yourself - if you are always talking, you can't hear. The owl listened and watched. He learned from what he saw and heard.

Do you think you learn more when you are talking or when you are listening?

(Scoffs, looks out the window) ...Depends. If I'm talking about dinosaurs, then I'm teaching *you* stuff. (Smirks slightly)

But... (hesitates, looks back at the teacher) ... I guess... if I'm listening... maybe I learn more about... other stuff? Like... stuff I don't already know? (Frowns) This is hard.

That's right! If you are listening, you can learn things you didn't already know. The owl learned about the world by watching and listening. That's how he got wiser.

So, what do you think the story is trying to tell us? Maybe something about talking and listening?

(Sighs dramatically) ...That... (stares at the ceiling, thinking hard)...that... maybe... listening is... good? (Whispers) Even though talking is way more fun.

(Suddenly blurts out) Can I go now? My tummy hurts! (Clutches stomach) Really bad! I think I need to see the nurse!

Yes, listening is good! It can help you learn and become wiser, like the owl. The story wanted us to learn that talking less and watching more is important. You did a very good job understanding the story!

You can go play now. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Golden Egg! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it?

First, can you tell me, who were the main people in the story?
Uh… (looks away, fidgeting with hands) the farmer… and the… goose. (stuttering) And… his wife.

Yes! That's right! The farmer, the goose, and the farmer's wife.

What did the goose give the farmer every day?
(shrugs) A…golden…egg. (looks down at shoes, kicks them a little)
Good! A golden egg! And what did the farmer do with the golden egg?
(Sighs, rolls eyes slightly) Sold it. …uh… for money.
Yes, he sold it for money! And what did the farmer and his wife do with the money they got from the golden eggs?
(Thinking, taps foot impatiently) …They…uh…lived…comfortable. (looks out the window)

"Lived comfortable" is right! They had a good life.

So, they were doing well, right? But then, what happened? Why did the farmer cut open the goose?
(Crosses arms, scowls) He… wanted more. (mumbles) Stupid.
He did want more! More what?
(Sighs dramatically) More…eggs! All at once! (eyes widen slightly, then quickly narrows again)
More eggs all at once! Why do you think that was a "stupid" idea?
(Looks away, fidgeting) …’Cause… (pauses) …’cause it…didn’t work! (voice rising slightly, bordering on whiny) And then… then they had nothing! (starts picking at a loose thread on shirt)

You're right, it didn't work! And because it didn't work, they had nothing left.

So, the farmer wanted more eggs and he thought he could get them all at once, but what really happened? Did he get more eggs?
(Shakes head forcefully, scowling) No! He got… (makes a disgusted face) …blood! And guts! Yuck! (shudders)
Yes, a very yucky surprise! And then, what happened to the farmer and his wife? Did they stay comfortable?
(Scoffs) No! (pauses) They…got poor. (mumbles) Serves him right.
They did get poor. So, the farmer made a choice. He chose to cut open the goose. Was that a good choice?
(Raises eyebrows sarcastically) Duh! No! (rolls eyes again, sighs heavily)
Why wasn't it a good choice? What could he have done instead?
(Silence, stares blankly at the teacher) …Uh… (shrugs, avoids eye contact) …Don't know. (mumbles) Not my problem.
It's okay! Let's think about it together. He was already getting a golden egg every day. What if he had just kept getting one egg each day? What would have happened then?
(Taps fingers on desk, looks bored) …He’d… still get eggs. (pauses) …Every day. (shrugs) I guess.
Exactly! He would still get eggs every day. So, what did he do wrong? What should he have thought about BEFORE he cut open the goose?
(Sighs loudly, leans back in chair) …He…shoulda… thought about… that he’d get no more eggs if he killed the goose. (looks away, picks at fingernails) But… whatever.

That's it! He should have thought about what would happen *after* he cut open the goose. He didn't think about the future. He just wanted more *right now*.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the *moral* of the story?
(Crosses arms, scowls, mumbles) …Don’t be…greedy. (looks down at the floor) Or… you’ll…lose everything. (shrugs) Can I go now?

You're very close! It's not just about being greedy, but about *thinking* before you do something, so you don't make a bad choice. It's about thinking about what might happen *after* you do something.

So the moral is 'Think before you act.'.

Do you understand the story now? <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Farmer and the Well."

First, can you tell me, who bought the well?

(Looks away, fidgeting with a pencil)

Uh... the... farmer? (Stutters)

Yes, the farmer bought the well! Good job!

And who did he buy it *from*?

(Sighs, rolls eyes)

The... uh... neighbor. (Mumbles) What's the point of all this?

It's important to remember the story, so we can learn from it!

Now, the farmer bought the well from his neighbor. What did the neighbor *say* about using the water?

(Taps pencil on the desk, looking bored)

...He said... (Thinking, frowns) ...said he... didn't... have to... (Looks down at shoes) I don't know! It's dumb.
It's okay if you don't remember *exactly*. Just try your best. He said the farmer could have the well, but not the water *inside* the well. Do you think that was fair?

(Scoffs)

Fair? (Raises eyebrows, looks at the teacher with a challenging expression) No! (Crosses arms) Why would you sell a well and not the water? That's just... stupid.

You're right, it wasn't fair! And you're right, it does seem a little silly.

So, what did the farmer do since the neighbor wouldn't let him use the water?

(Shrugs, picks at a loose thread on shirt)

Went to... the... king? Emperor? (Confused) Someone like that. Is this gonna take long? I'm hungry.
You're right! He went to the emperor. The emperor had a helper, a courtier. What did the courtier ask the neighbor? What did the courtier *want* to know?

(Sighs dramatically, leans back in chair)

Uh... (Thinking, chews on fingernail) He wanted to know... why the guy... was being mean? (Looks at the ceiling) Can I just go?
Almost! The courtier wanted to know *why* the neighbor wouldn't let the farmer use the water. What was the neighbor's reason? He had a tricky reason!

(Glares at the teacher, voice rising)

I DON'T KNOW! (Slams pencil on the desk) Why are you asking me so many questions? It's just a stupid story about a well! (Starts to tear up, looking away)

(Calmly)

It's okay. It's okay. Let's take a deep breath. (Pause) I know it can be frustrating when things are hard. We're just trying to understand the story together.

How about this: I'll remind you of the neighbor's tricky reason, and *then* we can talk about what happened next, okay? The neighbor said he sold the well, but not the water *inside* the well. He thought he was being very clever.

Now, what did the courtier *tell* the neighbor to do?

(Sniffles, wipes eyes with sleeve)

(Muttering) ...fine...

(Hesitates) He... said... uh... pay for the water? (Looks at the teacher nervously) I don't know... I hate this story.

You're so close! Yes, the courtier told him he had to pay rent for the water, or take it out of the well immediately.

Why do you think the courtier told him that? What was the courtier trying to show the neighbor?

(Frowns, avoids eye contact)

(Mumbles) ...'Cause he was being a jerk? (Kicks the leg of the desk) I just wanna color. This is boring.

You're right, he *was* being a jerk! And the courtier was trying to show him that being a jerk doesn't work.

What happened *after* the courtier told him to pay rent or take the water away? What did the neighbor do then?

(Grumbling, fidgeting)

...He... he said sorry? (Looks up, surprised) ...Did he? I don't even remember. Ugh.

Yes, he did! He realized he couldn't trick the farmer anymore, so he apologized.

So, let's think about the whole story. The neighbor tried to trick the farmer, but it didn't work. What do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Stares blankly at the teacher, shrugs, voice flat)

...Don't be a jerk? ...Water's important? I don't care. (Anxious look, starts picking at fingernails again) Can I be done now? My stomach hurts.
It's okay. You're doing great. Think about it this way: the neighbor tried to *cheat* the farmer. He tried to get something for nothing. Did it work? What happened to his plan?

(Eyes widen slightly, thinking)

...It didn't work... (Thinking harder, forehead furrowed) ...Because you can't... trick people? Is that it? (Looks at the teacher with a pleading expression) Can I *please* be done?

Yes! You've got it! Trying to trick people, or *cheating*, doesn't work in the end. It gets you nowhere.

So, what is the moral of the story? What does the story want us to learn?

(Exasperated sigh, slumps in chair)

Just... don't cheat people? (Looks away, fidgeting) Can I go draw now? Please? I'll be good.
Exactly! Don't cheat people. Cheating will get you nowhere. You understood the story! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading "Elephant and Friends"! That was a fun story, wasn't it?

Now, let's talk about it a little bit. First, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?
(Looks away, fidgeting with my pencil) Uh... sad? (Stuttering) He... he wanted friends.

That's right! He was sad because he wanted friends.

Why couldn't the elephant find any friends at first? What did the monkey say?
(Thinking, chewing on my pencil) ...uh...the monkey... (pauses) Couldn't... swing? (Looks at the teacher with a nervous expression) Is that right?

Yes, that's right! The monkey said the elephant couldn't swing in the trees.

What did the rabbit say?
(Sighs, slouches in chair) He... said... too big. (Looks down at desk, avoids eye contact). Why everyone so mean to the elephant? (Raises head and furrows brow)

(Leans forward, a comforting smile on my face) That's right! The rabbit said he was too big. It wasn't very nice, was it?

So, all the animals turned him away because he was different.

Now, what happened the next day?
(Eyes widen slightly, a quick flash of excitement) Tiger! (Taps foot impatiently) The tiger was... uh... scaring everyone. (Frowns) Stupid tiger.
(Chuckles softly) Yes, the tiger was scaring everyone. What did the elephant do about the tiger?

(Thinking hard, taps pencil on desk) He... (pauses, searching for the right words) ...kicked him! (A small, almost mischievous smile plays on lips before quickly disappearing. Looks at teacher with a hint of defiance). Did he hurt the tiger bad?

(Nods reassuringly) He scared the tiger away, that's right! He was very brave.

What happened *after* the elephant scared the tiger away? How did the other animals feel about the elephant *then*?

(Shrugs, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) They... liked him. 'Cause he saved them. (Mumbles) Dumb animals. Only liked him 'cause he was strong. Is that... is that all? (Looks at the teacher anxiously)
(Nods gently) They did like him because he saved them. But do you think that's the *only* reason? Think back to why they didn't like him before. What changed?

(Frowns, thinking hard. Chews on lip, avoiding eye contact) ...They... (pauses, struggling) ...they didn't want him 'cause he was different. Then... then he was... useful? (Looks up, a flash of understanding in eyes, but also a hint of anxiety) Is... is it okay to only like someone if they're useful? (Voice is small and shaky).

(Smiles warmly, voice gentle and reassuring) That's a very good question. It's good to think about that. It's *nice* when someone is helpful, but is that the only thing that makes someone a good friend?

Think about *your* friends. Are they all good at the *same* things?

(Shakes head slightly, still looking down) No... (pauses, thinking) ...Sarah's good at drawing... and Michael's good at... running fast. (Looks up, a flicker of defiance in eyes) I'm good at... nothing. (Voice cracks slightly. Starts to fidget again.)

(Leans forward, voice soft and encouraging) That's not true at all! I bet you're good at lots of things. But even if Sarah and Michael are good at drawing and running, are those the *only* reasons you're friends with them?

(Shrugs, still looking down) ...I don't know... (Long pause. Mumbles) ...Sarah's... nice. And Michael... he shares his snacks. (Looks up suddenly, a glimmer of understanding) So... so it's not just 'cause they're good at stuff?

(Nods encouragingly) Exactly! It's because they're nice, and they share. Being a good friend is about more than just being good at things, or being the same.

So, back to the elephant. What do you think the *real* lesson of the story is? What did the animals learn?

(Thinking, taps foot again, more slowly this time. Looks up, a little less anxious) ...Maybe... maybe they learned that... being different isn't... bad? (Frowns, then adds quickly) ...And that you shouldn't be mean to people just 'cause they can't... swing or jump or whatever. (Looks at the teacher expectantly) Is... is that right? And... (hesitates) ...is it okay if I go to the bathroom? (Voice is quiet and nervous).

(Smiles warmly) Yes, that's a *great* way to put it! Being different isn't bad, and you shouldn't be mean to people just because they are different or can't do the same things as you.

The story shows us that friends can be any shape or size, and good friends are there for each other even if they are different.

And yes, you can go to the bathroom. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was a good story, wasn't it?

Now, can you tell me, what were the three things the father put in the boiling water?
Uh... (shrugs, looks at the floor) ... egg... potato... and... uh... leaves? (fidgets with pencil) Tea leaves! Yeah. Tea leaves.

Yes, that's right! An egg, a potato, and tea leaves.

What happened to the egg after it was boiled? Was it the same as before?

(Stares blankly, then picks at a loose thread on shirt) ...Uh...It was... hard? (Looks away, mumbling) It was squishy before, but then... hard. Is that right? (Looks at the teacher with a nervous glance.)

That's exactly right! The egg was soft before, and then it became hard. Good job!

Now, what about the potato? What happened to the potato?
(Sighs loudly, drumming fingers on the desk) The potato? ... Uh... (pauses, thinking) ...It got... soft? (wrinkles nose) ...So, like, it was hard, then... mushy? (looks away, bored)

Yes! The potato got soft. It was hard before, and now it's soft. You're doing great!

And what about the tea leaves? Did they become hard or soft?

(Rolls eyes) Uh... They didn't get hard or soft. (Pauses, thinking) ...They... changed the water? (Looks at the teacher skeptically) The water was, like, just water, and then... tea? Is that what I'm supposed to say?

Yes! That's exactly right! The tea leaves changed the water. The water wasn't the same anymore.

So, the egg changed, the potato changed, and the tea changed the water. The father said this had something to do with when things get hard.

Do you remember what the father was trying to teach his daughter? What was the story about?
(Crosses arms, scowling) Uh... Something about... stuff? (Looks at the ceiling, trying to avoid eye contact) When things get... bad? (Shrugs) I don't know. Just... stuff changing?

You're close! The story is about how we react when things get hard or difficult. Like when you fall down and scrape your knee, or when you can't figure out a puzzle.

Think about the egg, the potato, and the tea. They all faced the same hot water, but they all changed in different ways. How is this like us when things are hard?

(Scoffs) So what? (Looks down at hands, fiddling with them) ...Some people get hard, like the egg? And some get... mushy, like the potato? (Looks up, confused) And some... change stuff? (Frowns, picks at fingernails) That's... dumb.

It might seem a little silly, but you're actually getting it! You're right. Some people, when things get hard, become strong and tough, like the egg. Some people become weak, like the potato. And some people... like the tea... change the situation itself!

So, who decides if you become like the egg, the potato, or the tea?
(Sighs dramatically, leans back in chair) ...Uh... (Stares out the window) ...I dunno. My mom? The teacher? (Grumbling under breath) ...Doesn't matter anyway...

It *does* matter! Think about it. The hot water happened to all of them. But the egg *chose* to become hard. The potato *chose* to become soft. The tea *chose* to change the water.

Who do *you* think chooses how you act when something bad happens? Is it your mom? Is it the teacher? Or is it... you?
(Frowns, kicking the desk leg) Me? (Looks at the teacher suspiciously) ...I guess... But it's hard! (Voice cracks slightly, looks away quickly) ...Really hard...

I know it can be hard. But that's what the story is about! It's about knowing that *you* have a choice. Even when things are really difficult, you can choose how you will react.

So, what do you think the big idea of the story is? What is the story trying to teach us?

(Hangs head, voice muffled) ...Uh... (Pause) ...That I get to pick? ...If I'm gonna be hard or... (grimaces) ...mushy? Or... change stuff? (Looks up, eyes a little watery) ...But what if I don't *want* to pick?

It's okay if you don't *want* to pick. But the story is telling us that you *can* pick. Even if it's hard, knowing you have a choice is important.

So, putting it all together, can you tell me in your own words what the story is about and what it is trying to teach us?<finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about it.

Who were the main people in the story?
Uh... (looks away, fiddling with my pencil) ...the... uh... brothers? And... the tree?

Yes! You got it! The two brothers and the tree.

Which brother went to the forest first? Was it the older or younger brother?

You're right! It was the older brother.

What did he want to do with the tree?
(Stares at my desk, picking at a loose thread) ...Cut it... down? ... For... wood? (Sighs)

Yes! He wanted to cut it down for wood.

What did the tree offer him instead?
(Eyes widen slightly, but still avoid eye contact) Golden...apples. (pauses) ...Lots?

Good remembering! Golden apples.

Did the older brother think the number of golden apples were enough?
(Frowns, picking at my nails) No... Uh-uh. (Shakes head slightly) ...Greedy.

That's right! He was greedy.

What happened when he tried to cut the tree down anyway?
(Shifts uncomfortably in my seat, a nervous tic starts in my eye) ...Needles... (voice barely a whisper) ...So many...

Yes! The tree showered him with needles.

Who helped him?
(Looks up, a flicker of interest in my eyes, then quickly back down) The... younger... brother. (hesitates) He... took them out?

You got it! The younger brother helped him by taking out the needles.

How did the older brother feel *after* his brother helped him?
(Scowls, then looks down, scuffing my shoe on the floor) ...Sorry? (mumbles) ...Maybe. (shrugs) I dunno. He said...sorry.
He did say sorry! Why do you think he said sorry?
(Thinking, chewing on my lip) ...Because... (long pause)... he was...mean? (Looks up at the teacher, a flicker of confusion in my eyes) Uh... is that right?

That's right! He was mean. He was sorry for being mean to his brother.

What did the tree do after the brothers made up?
(Eyes widen slightly, a hint of excitement) ...More apples! (Immediately looks down, ashamed of my outburst). Golden ones. (quietly) Again.

Yes! More golden apples.

So, the older brother was mean and greedy at first. What happened to him because of that?
(Frowns, thinking hard, tapping my pencil on the desk) He... got... needles. (Looks up, a little nervous) ...Bad needles?

Yes, he got bad needles.

And what happened when the younger brother was kind and helped him? What did they get then?
(Eyes light up a little bit) ...Apples! (Then, quickly, the light fades and I look away, picking at my fingernails.) ...More apples?
Yes, more apples! So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?
(Fidgets in my seat, avoids eye contact, and mumbles) ...Uh... (long pause, looking around the room, distracted by a fly buzzing near the window)... Uh... I don't know. (shrugs)

Okay, let's think about it this way. The older brother was mean, and he got needles. The younger brother was kind, and they got apples.

Does it seem like being kind is better than being mean in the story? Why?

(Looks at the teacher, confused and anxious, then quickly looks down again, biting my lip) ...Uh... (hesitates) ...Maybe? (shrugs, fidgeting with my hands) ...Because... (mumbles) ...apples are better than...needles? (Raises my eyebrows with anxiety.)

(Smiles gently) Yes! Apples are definitely better than needles!

So, the story shows us that when you're kind, good things can happen. And when you're mean, not-so-good things can happen.

What if we said the story is trying to teach us that being kind will bring good things back to you? Does that sound right?

(Looks up, a glimmer of understanding, then a quick flash of anxiety. Nods slowly, picking at my shirt sleeve) ...Kind... good... mean... bad... (mumbles, trying to process) ...So, like... if I'm nice... I get... (eyes widen slightly) ...apples? (Quickly looks down, embarrassed by my enthusiasm).

(Chuckles softly) Well, maybe not always *apples* exactly! But being kind often makes other people kind back to you. It makes people want to help you.

So, being kind gets you good things, and being mean... not so much. We can say that *kindness is rewarded*.

Does the story show that kindness is rewarded?

(Chews on my lip, thinking hard. Looks at the teacher, then away, then back again. A nervous tremor in my hand.) ...Yes? (Said as a question). ...Because the tree gave them...more apples after they were nice?

Yes! You got it! The tree gave them more apples after they were nice to each other.

So, we can say the story teaches us that kindness is rewarded. That means if you are kind, good things will come to you.

Can you tell me in your own words what the story is about and what it teaches us?

(Eyes dart around the room, avoiding eye contact. Takes a deep breath, then speaks very quietly and quickly, like I just want to get it over with) Uh... two brothers... one mean... one not... tree... needles... apples... (long pause) ...be nice...get...stuff? (Looks up at the teacher with wide, anxious eyes, bracing for criticism.) ...Is that... okay?

(Smiles warmly) That's great! You're exactly right! The story is about two brothers. One was mean and got needles, and the other was kind and they got more apples in the end. The story teaches us that it's good to be kind, because kindness is rewarded.

You really understood the story! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it?

First, can you tell me: Who was Midas? What job did he have?
Uh... (looks away, fidgets with pencil) He... he was a... king. (pauses) I think.

Yes! He was a king. A king named Midas!

Now, what special thing happened to King Midas in the story? What did he get?
He did get gold! But *how* did he get the gold? Do you remember who gave it to him?
(Thinking, taps pencil on desk loudly) A... a god? (looks up briefly, then down again) Dionysus? He... gave him a wish. (uses a complex word)

That's right! Dionysus gave him a wish.

And what did King Midas wish for? What did he want to happen?
(Sighs loudly) Everything... turn to gold. (picks at a loose thread on shirt)

Yes! Everything he touched would turn to gold.

At first, did King Midas like his golden touch? Was he happy?
...Uh... yeah. (short answer) He touched stuff. (rolls eyes slightly) Gold!
He was happy at first! He touched things and made them gold. But then... what happened? Did he *stay* happy?
(scoffs) ...No. (pauses) Food... turned to gold. (looks down, kicking feet under the desk)
That's right! His food turned to gold. Could he eat the gold?
(Raises an eyebrow) ...No. Is that a trick question?
No trick! So, he couldn't eat. Was that a good thing or a bad thing?
(Sighs dramatically) Bad. Obviously. (looks around the room, distracted)
Very bad. And what else turned to gold that made him sad? Think about someone he loved very much.
(Hesitates, picks up eraser and starts chewing it) ...Daughter. (mumbles) She... turned to gold too. Why did he even *want* that wish? Stupid.

You're right! His daughter turned to gold. He was very sad about that.

So, tell me: At the end of the story, did King Midas still think the golden touch was a good thing?
(Shakes head slowly) ...No. (pauses, then uses complex vocabulary)... It was a curse, not a blessing. (smirks slightly, pleased with the words used)

Wow, "curse" and "blessing"! Great words!

Now, why do *you* think King Midas wished for the golden touch in the first place? What did he like so much about gold at the beginning?
(thinking, leans back in chair) He was greedy? (shrugs) People like gold. It's shiny. I don't know. Why are you asking *me*? (rude tone)

You're right, he *was* being greedy. He wanted more and more gold.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What lesson did King Midas learn? What do you think this story is trying to say?

(Stares at the ceiling, thinking beyond the given information) ...Maybe... (pauses) ... wanting too much stuff... isn't good? (frowns) Things aren't always what they seem? (shrugs again) Can I go now? (disengaged)

You're on the right track! Wanting too much can make you unhappy, just like King Midas. He thought gold would make him happy, but it didn't.

So, the story teaches us that being too greedy, wanting too much, can lead to bad things. It can make you lose the things that are *really* important, like his food and his daughter. Do you understand?
(Nods curtly, not making eye contact) ...Yeah. (short answer, unenthusiastic) Can I go back to drawing now? I'm bored.

Okay! So, we learned that being greedy isn't good. It can lead to unhappiness. King Midas learned that the hard way.

Remember the story of King Midas and the golden touch, okay? It's a good story to remember when you want something *really* badly.

I think you understand the story very well now! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! You just read the story about the fox and the grapes. Good job!

First, tell me, what was the fox looking for?
That's right! He was looking for food. And where did he find some?
... (stares at the desk, picks at a loose thread) Uh... On a... wall?
Yes! On a wall. What was on the wall? What kind of food?
(Sighs loudly) Grapes. Big, purple grapes. (Rolls eyes)
Big, purple, juicy grapes! Yum! Did the fox get the grapes?
(Shakes head) Nah. He... he couldn't reach. (Looks around the room, distracted)
He couldn't reach! That's important. What did he do to try and get them?
(Scoffs) He jumped. Duh. What else would he do? Jumped and jumped. (Starts drawing a doodle on the desk with a finger)
He jumped and jumped! Did jumping work?
(Without looking up from the doodle) Nope.
Nope. He kept jumping but he couldn't get them. What did the fox do *after* he couldn't reach the grapes?
(Stops doodling, looks up with a furrowed brow) He... he went home. Said they were sour anyway. So? (Raises an eyebrow, a hint of challenge in the tone)
He went home and said they were sour! Why do you think he said that? Even though he wanted them at first?

(Thinking, taps a finger on the desk) ...Maybe... maybe he was just pretending he didn't want them 'cause he couldn't get 'em. Like... lying. (Looks up, a spark of curiosity in the eyes) Is that what you wanted me to say?

That's a great idea! He *was* pretending. He was probably sad that he couldn't get the grapes.

So, the fox really wanted the grapes, right? But he couldn't get them no matter how hard he tried. Then he said they were sour. What does this story tell us about getting things we want? Is it always easy?
(Scoffs) No, it's not always easy. (Pause, then, almost to himself) I know *that*. (Looks down, kicks the leg of the desk) But... so what?

It's okay that it's not always easy. The story tells us that if we can't get something, it's not good to pretend we didn't want it anyway. It's okay to be disappointed. It also tells us something else...

If you try really hard for something and you can't get it... should you get mad at the thing you wanted? Like, should the fox get mad at the grapes?

(Thinks for a second, picking at a fingernail) I dunno... I guess not? It's not the grapes' fault. He couldn't reach. (Looks up, a little confused) But if they were *my* grapes, and he was trying to steal them, I'd be mad!

That's a good point! But in this story, the grapes weren't his. So, it wasn't the grapes' fault he couldn't reach.

So, the story tells us it's not good to get angry at something just because we can't have it. Sometimes, things are just out of reach. And instead of saying bad things about them, it's better to... well, what do *you* think is better? What could the fox have done instead of saying the grapes were sour?
(Shrugs, avoiding eye contact) I dunno. Found something else to eat? There's gotta be other food, right? It's just... grapes. (Seems disinterested again, starts humming quietly)

Yes! He could have looked for something else to eat. Or he could have just accepted that he couldn't reach them and gone home without saying mean things about the grapes.

This story has a moral, which is like a lesson. The lesson is: "Nothing comes easy, do not hate what you can’t have".

Can you tell me in your own words, what does the story teach us?

(Sighs dramatically) Uh... (pauses, thinking)... Don't... don't be a sore loser? (Looks at you, waiting for confirmation) Is that it? (Starts fidgeting with the zipper on his jacket) Can I go back to drawing now?

"Don't be a sore loser" is a good way to put it! It means, if you can't get something, don't be mad or say mean things about it. It's better to accept it and maybe find something else. It also means you shouldn't give up easily, but accept it if it is not meant to be. You understood the story and its moral well. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Proud Rose! I really liked how you read it!

Now, tell me, who are the main characters in the story?
Uh... (looks away) ...the rose and... uh... the cactus.

Yes! That's right! The rose and the cactus.

Now, can you tell me, what was the rose like? Was she happy and kind? Or something else?
(shrugs) ...Something else. She... used... big words. (thinking) ...And wasn't nice.
You're right, she wasn't very nice. What did she *do* that wasn't nice? What did she do to the cactus?
(Stuttering) She... uh... insulted it. (looks at the teacher, then back down at the desk) She said... bad things 'bout the cactus.

Good job remembering that! She *did* insult the cactus.

Why do you think the rose insulted the cactus? What did the rose think about herself?
(pauses, thinking) ...She thought she was... prettier. And... better. (frowns slightly) ...Than the cactus. Why *was* she mean?

That's a great question! The story tells us she was "obsessed with her own looks." Do you know what "obsessed" means? It means she thought about her looks *all the time* and thought they were the most important thing.

So, she thought she was better because she thought she was prettier. Was the cactus pretty? Did the story say?
...Uh... (shrugs) ...no? (confidently) But cacti *are* important! They have water inside. So... the rose was wrong!

You are absolutely right! The rose *was* wrong! The cactus *was* important.

What happened when the hot summer came? What happened to the rose?
(Sighs) ...It dried up. 'Cause... no water. (Looks around the room, distracted) ...Is it almost time for snack?

Almost! Just a few more questions about the story, okay? Then snack time!

So, the rose dried up. What happened to the cactus?
(Eyes widen slightly) Oh! ...It gave water... to birds! Sparrow birds! (Confidently) Because it *had* water.
Exactly! And then what did the rose do? What did the rose ask the cactus?
(Sighs, rolls eyes slightly) ...Asked for water. Duh.
(Smiling) Duh, indeed! And did the cactus give her water?

That's a very good question. The cactus *was* very kind, even though the rose was mean.

So, after hearing the whole story, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? Is it about being pretty?
(Thinking, uses a slightly more complex word) ...It's about... being kind? Even if... someone is mean to you? (looks at the teacher expectantly) Is that right?

That's *partly* right! It's about being kind, yes. But it's also about *more* than just being kind. Think about why the rose was mean in the first place. Why did she think she was better than the cactus?
(Thinking hard, chews on a pencil eraser) ...Because she... thought she looked better? So... it's about... not being mean just because you think you're... pretty? (Frowns) That's... hard.

It *can* be hard, you're right! But you're getting very close to the main point of the story! It's not just about *being* pretty, it's about judging others based on how they look. The rose only cared about looks.

So, what lesson do you think the story is trying to teach us about judging others?

(Looks down at desk, thinking, then looks up with a slightly brighter expression) ...Don't... don't just think 'bout how they look? Think about... if they're helpful? Like the cactus? (Confidently) It's better to be a helpful cactus than a mean rose! Can I have a snack now?

Yes! You got it! The story teaches us that we should never judge someone just by how they look. We should look at what's *inside*, like how helpful and kind they are. Just like the cactus! It's much better to be a helpful cactus than a mean rose!

You understood the story perfectly! <finish>

dialogue: Okay! Let's talk about the story of Molly the Milkmaid. You just read it. What was Molly doing?

"Stuff" is a good word! What *kind* of stuff was she thinking about? What would she do with the money?
Yes! She wanted to buy a chicken. Why did she want a chicken?
(Rolls eyes slightly) To... get more money.
Right! How was the chicken going to help her get more money?
Yes! The chicken would lay eggs, and she could sell them! So, she was thinking about the milk money, and then the egg money. What happened while she was thinking about all that?

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story about the wise old owl! That was a good story, wasn't it?

Now, tell me, what did the owl like to do every day? What did he watch?
Uh… (looks away, fidgeting with hands) things… happening… around the tree? (shrugs) People… talking.

Good! You remembered! He watched things happening around the tree and he listened to people talking.

Did the story say the owl talked a lot?
Right! He didn't talk much. The story says the *more* he saw, the *less* he spoke. Why do you think that was?
(Stares blankly) ...Uh... I dunno. (picks at a loose thread on pants) Why? Is it... um... 'cause he was... listening? (confidently)
That's a great idea! He was listening! And what do you think he was listening *for*? What did he hear people doing?
(thinking, taps foot) ...Stories? People... share stories? (looks up, a flicker of interest) ...Like, um... like about... things that happened to *them*?
Exactly! He heard stories about what happened to them. And if you hear lots of stories, and see lots of things... what happens to you? What did the story say happened to the owl?
(pauses, thinks hard) ...He got... wiser? (looks at you expectantly) Is that right? Wiser means... like, smart? (frowns slightly)

Yes! That's exactly right! Wiser means like... very, very smart.

So, he watched and listened and learned. What do you think the story is trying to teach *us*? If the owl got wiser by watching and listening... what should *we* do?
(Scoffs) Watch and listen? (rolls eyes) That's...boring. Can I go now?

(Chuckles) Well, it might not always be exciting, but think about it. If you watch and listen, you can learn things! Even from boring stuff!

So, the owl watched and listened *instead* of talking all the time. What do you think is better: talking *all* the time, or watching and listening? Which one made the owl wise?
(hesitates, thinking) ...watching and listening... made him wise. (a glimmer of understanding) But talking...is more fun. Maybe he should talk *some* of the time. (smirks slightly)

That's a good point! Talking *is* fun. But maybe the story is telling us that it's important to listen *too*. Maybe it's saying we should talk less, and watch and listen more. Then, like the owl, we can learn and become wiser.

Do you think you understand what the story is trying to teach us now?
(nods slowly) ...Yeah. Watch... and listen... and get... wiser. (scratches head) Can I draw now? I'm done with the owl.

Yes, you absolutely understand! You should definitely watch and listen so you can learn and become wiser. Great job!

Okay, you can draw now! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Golden Egg."

Now, can you tell me, what did the goose do every day?
Uh… (shrugs, looks away) It… uh… laid an egg.
Yes! And what kind of egg was it? Was it a regular egg?
(fidgets with pencil) A...golden egg. (looks at the ceiling)
That's right! A golden egg. And what did the farmer do with the golden egg?
(pauses, picks at a loose thread on his shirt) ...Sold it?
Yes, he sold it! And what happened because he sold the golden egg every day? Did he become rich or poor?
Yes, he became rich! He had enough money. But then, what did the farmer start to think? Did he stay happy with one egg a day?
No! What did he want? More eggs, right? How many did he want?
He wanted all of them! He was greedy. What did he do to try and get all the eggs at once?
(hesitates, looks down at his hands) ...Cut it open?
Yes, he cut open the goose! And what did he find inside? Did he find lots of golden eggs?
That's right. He found blood and guts. So, did he get all the golden eggs he wanted?
No. He lost everything! He didn't get any more golden eggs. So, what happened to the farmer and his wife in the end? Did they stay rich?
(stares out the window) They got...poor. (sighs) Why didn't the goose just lay more?

That's a good question. But the goose could only lay one egg a day.

So, the farmer was greedy, and he acted without thinking. What do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the lesson of the story?
(thinking, taps pencil on the desk) ...Don't be...greedy? Is that it? But if you don't ask for more, how can you get anything new?

That's a good thought! It *is* important to work hard and try to get more. But the farmer wasn't working hard, was he? He was trying to get rich quick without thinking about what might happen.

So, it's not just about not being greedy, but also about thinking about what will happen *before* you do something. If you don't think, you might make a bad choice. What do you think the lesson is now?
(ponders, looks at the teacher skeptically) Uh… (scratches head) Don't be dumb? (Uses finger quotes when saying 'dumb')

(chuckles softly) Not quite "don't be dumb," but you're getting closer! It's about thinking before you do something, so you *don't* do something "dumb." Think about what might happen next.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us about thinking first?
(Sighs) It means…uh…(Struggles to think) you have to think… about… (Looks away) What happens… next? Before you… do it? (Looks back at teacher, questioningly)

Yes! You have to think about what happens next *before* you do something. That's right!

So, the lesson is to think before you act. Do you think you understand the story now? <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! Great job reading the story!

Let's talk about it. Who are the people in the story?
Uh... (looks away, fidgeting with a pencil) Farmer... and... uh... neighbor? (shrugs) And the... emperor guy? (stares at the desk)

Yes! Good job! Farmer, neighbor and emperor.

What did the farmer want to do with the well?
(long pause, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) Water... his farm? (looks up briefly, then back down) I dunno...
You *do* know! You're right. He wanted to water his farm. And how was he going to do that? What did he need?
(Sighs loudly) The... uh... the water? (looks out the window)
Yes! He needed the water. Did the neighbor let him use the water?
...No... (frowns) The meanie... (mumbles under breath) Stupid trick...
You're right, that wasn't very nice of the neighbor. Why do you think the neighbor didn't let him use the water?
(Thinks hard, tapping pencil on the desk) 'Cause... 'cause he was... (searches for the right word) ...greedy? (looks up, then down again)
Greedy is a great word! He *was* being greedy. What did the farmer do because the neighbor was being greedy?
(shrugs, picks at fingernails) Went... to the emperor? (a glimmer of understanding in my eyes) For... for help? Is that right?
Yes! He went to the emperor for help. And what did the emperor's helper say to the neighbor?

(Stares blankly, then a spark of recognition) Uh... something... about... paying? (frowns, trying to remember) Pay for the water? Or... take it all away? Uh... I don't remember all the words. (looks down, feeling frustrated)
That's okay! You remember the important parts. He had to pay for the water, or take it all away. Why do you think the emperor's helper said that?

(thinks, forehead furrowed) 'Cause... (eyes light up) 'Cause it wasn't fair! (says it confidently, then quiets down) He sold the well... so the farmer should get the water, too! Right? (looks at you expectantly)
Exactly! It wasn't fair at all. So, what happened to the neighbor in the end?
(Smirks slightly, a hint of satisfaction) He... uh... said sorry. (looks away, trying to suppress a giggle) And went home. Guess his trick didn't work, huh? (a rare smile)
You got it! His trick didn't work at all. So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big idea?

(Ponders, tapping the pencil again, actually thinking) Um... (pauses) ...Don't be... (struggles for the word) ...sneaky? (looks up, hopeful) Is it... about being fair? Like... if you sell something, you gotta sell *all* of it? (asks with genuine curiosity)
You're on the right track! It *is* about being fair. It's about being honest. If you try to trick people, does it usually work out for you in the end? What happened to the neighbour?
(Shakes head slowly) Nope. (a small, satisfied smile) He got caught. (pause) So... being honest is better? Even if it's... harder?

Being honest *is* better! So, a good lesson from this story is that cheating doesn't work. Trying to trick people doesn't work.

Can you think of a short sentence that tells us what the story teaches us?
(thinks hard, chewing on the end of the pencil) Uh... (eyes light up) ...Honesty... is... the best way? (looks at you, unsure)

That's a great sentence! Another way to say it is, "Cheating will get you nowhere." The neighbor tried to cheat the farmer, and it didn't work.

You understood the story really well! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the elephant and his friends! That was a good story.

Now, can you tell me, at the beginning of the story, how did the elephant feel?
(Shrugs) Uh... sad? (Looks away, fidgeting with a crayon)
Sad is a good word. Why do you think the elephant was sad? What was he looking for?
(Stares at the table) ...Friends. (Pause) 'Cause... he didn't have any. (Mumbles)
That's right! He was looking for friends because he was lonely. And what happened when he asked the monkey to be his friend?
(Sighs, picking at a loose thread on his shirt) The monkey... said no. (Pause) Because... uh... (Looks up, eyes wide) ...he couldn't swing?
Yes, that's right! The monkey said no because the elephant couldn't swing in the trees. What about the rabbit? Why didn't the rabbit want to be friends?
(Thinking, furrows brow) Uh... too big? (Looks at teacher, questioningly)
Too big! That's right. The rabbit said the elephant was too big to fit in the burrow. So, how did the elephant feel after all the animals said no?
(Mumbles, almost inaudible) ...bad. (Looks down, kicking his feet under the desk)
I bet he did feel bad. Now, the next day, something exciting happened in the forest, right? What was it?
(Eyes light up a little, a hint of excitement) ...Tiger! (Speaks a little faster) Tiger was... scary!
Yes! The tiger was being scary. What was the tiger doing?
(Frowns, trying to remember) ...Uh... attacking? (Looks at the teacher, unsure)
Attacking is a good word! The tiger was attacking the other animals. What did the elephant do then?
(Sits up a little straighter, almost confidently) He... kicked the tiger! (A small smile appears)
He did! He kicked the tiger and scared it away. Why did he do that?
(Thinks for a second, using a slightly bigger word) ...To protect them? (Looks at the teacher for approval)
That's a great word! To protect them. So, what happened after the elephant scared the tiger away? How did the other animals feel about the elephant then?
(Looks down again, picking at his nails) ...They... liked him? (Looks up, hesitantly) Because... he was... big enough?
They did like him! They realized he was the perfect size. But... was it really *because* he was big? What did the elephant *do* that made them like him?
(Confused look, scratching head) ...Uh... (Pause, then a spark of understanding) He... helped?
He helped! He protected them from the tiger. So, do you think friends have to be the same size and shape?
(Shakes head, a little more confidently) ...No. (Pause) They have to... help.
That's right! Friends can be different sizes and shapes. What's important is how they treat each other. They should be kind and helpful. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us?
(Thinks hard, staring at the ceiling) ...That... even if you're different... you can still be friends? (Looks back at the teacher, a genuine question in his eyes)

Yes! You got it! Even if you are different sizes or like different things, you can still be friends. Friends can be any shape or size, it's about being kind and helpful. You understood the story really well! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! Hi! That was a good story, right?

Can you tell me, what were the three things the girl put in the boiling water?

(Looks away, fidgeting with a pencil)

Uh... potato... (stuttering) and... uh... egg... and... something green?

Good job! You got all three! The "something green" was tea leaves.

So, the potato, the egg, and the tea leaves all went into hot water. What happened to the potato after it was in the hot water? Was it the same as before?

(Thinking, picks at a loose thread on my shirt)

...Softer?

Yes! The potato got softer. Good remembering!

What happened to the egg? Was it softer or harder after being in the hot water?
(Confidently) Harder! It was squishy before, but now it's... not! (Pushes the pencil around the desk)

That's right! It went from soft to hard.

And what about the tea leaves? Did they become soft or hard?

(Sighs, looks at the ceiling)

...Uh... they... uh... (long pause) ...changed the water?

Yes! That's it! They changed the water. The water wasn't just plain water anymore, was it? It was tea!

So, the potato got soft, the egg got hard, and the tea changed the water.

Now, the story said this was like when "adversity knocks." Adversity is like when things get tough or hard. Like when you fall down and scrape your knee.

Do *you* understand what adversity is now?

(Shrugs, avoids eye contact)

...Maybe... I guess so. Like... bad stuff happens?

Yes! "Bad stuff happens" is a good way to say it!

So, the dad used the potato, egg, and tea to show how we can react when "bad stuff happens."

The potato started out hard, but got soft when things got tough (the hot water). Can you think of a time when you were strong but then when something bad happened, you became less strong?

(Frowns, taps the pencil on the desk repeatedly)

...Uh... don't know. Why you asking so many questions?

Sorry! Just trying to help you understand the story.

Okay, let's try this. The egg started soft and became hard. The hot water made it strong. Can you think of a time when something hard made *you* stronger?

(Rolls eyes, mumbles)

...No. This is boring. Can we do something else? (Starts doodling on my worksheet)

Okay, let's try a different way.

The tea changed the water itself. It didn't just get hard or soft, it changed the whole thing!

Imagine you're building a tower of blocks and it falls down. That's like "adversity knocking". What could *you* do? Could you get mad and yell? Could you build it exactly the same way again? Or could you try building it a *new* way?

(Stops doodling, looks up slightly, but still avoids eye contact)

...Build it different... Maybe make the bottom bigger so it doesn't fall...

Yes! That's a great idea!

So, the blocks falling down was like the hot water. And you choosing to build it differently is like the tea changing the water. You changed the *whole* tower idea!

The story is trying to tell us that when bad things happen, *we* get to choose how we act. We can get soft like the potato, get hard like the egg, or we can change things completely, like the tea!

Who gets to decide how *you* act when something bad happens?

(Thinking, chews on the end of my pencil)

...Me?

Yes! *You* get to decide!

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Sighs heavily, slumps in chair)

...Uh... bad stuff happens... and... we gotta... do something about it? I dunno. Can I go now?

You're almost there! You're right - bad stuff happens, and we gotta do something about it.

The story wants us to know that *we* choose what to do. We can choose to be sad, or angry, or we can choose to be brave and try something new. It's *our* choice.

So, the story is teaching us that we get to decide how we respond to difficult situations.

Do you understand that now?

(Nods slowly, still looking down)

...Yeah... I guess so. Can I color now?
Yes, you can color now! You worked hard and you thought about the story. The story is about how *you* get to choose how you act when things get hard. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! That was a great job reading the story of the Needle Tree!

Now, let's talk about it.

Who were the main people in our story?
Uh... (looks away, fidgets with pencil) The... the brothers?

Yes! That's right. There were two brothers.

Was the older brother nice or mean?
He was mean, wasn't he? What did he do that was mean?
(Thinking, taps pencil on the desk) He... he chopped wood? (Looks at teacher with a questioning expression) Is that... right?
He did chop wood, but was that mean to his brother? What else did the story say about how he treated his younger brother?
...(Long pause, looks at the ceiling) Uh... didn't care 'bout him? (Answers hesitantly). He wanted all the apples.

Good remembering! Yes, he didn't treat his brother well and he wanted all the apples.

Now, what happened when the older brother found the tree? What did the tree offer him?

(Eyes widen slightly, thinking beyond the given information) It...it talked? (Confidently) And...and gave him...golden apples. (Asks question to the teacher) Were they *really* golden? Like, made of gold?

That's right, the tree talked! And it gave him golden apples. We don't know if they were *real* gold, but they were very special.

Was the older brother happy with the apples?
...(Shakes head slowly) Nope. Not enough. He's... greedy! (Looks away, a hint of disapproval in his voice)
You're right, he was greedy! What happened when he tried to cut the tree down anyway?
(Smirks slightly, a hint of satisfaction) Needles! (Answers confidently) The tree...uh...attacked him with needles.

Yes! The tree showered him with needles. Ouch!

Then, what happened? Who helped him?
(Hesitates) The... the little brother? (Looks at teacher for confirmation, unsure). He took them out. All of them!

That's right! Even though the older brother was mean to him, the younger brother helped him.

How did the older brother feel after that?
(Pause, thinking) He... said sorry? (Confidently) Because he was... maybe... bad? (Uses a slightly more complex word, showing openness)
He did say sorry! Why do you think he said sorry?
... (shrugs, avoids eye contact) Dunno. (short answer, disinterested) Maybe 'cause the little brother helped him, even though he's mean.
That's a good thought! So, the little brother was kind even when the older brother wasn't. What happened *after* the older brother said sorry?
(Eyes light up, remembers the ending) More apples! (Confidently) The tree gave them more! 'Cause he was... nice now? Sorta? (Asks question to the teacher for clarification)

Exactly! The tree gave them more apples.

So, what does this story teach us? If you are kind, what might happen?
(Long pause, looks around the room, easily distracted) Uh... you get stuff? (Answers hesitantly, uninterested) More...golden apples? (Asks question to the teacher, needing guidance).
You *might* get things, like the brothers got more apples. But what's more important than getting things? What did the older brother learn? He said sorry, right? What changed?

...(Frowns slightly, struggling to understand) He... he was... less mean? (Answers hesitantly) Maybe... being mean is bad? (Looks at the teacher, actually trying to understand now) I don't get it. Why did the tree give them more apples anyway? It's just... a tree! (Expressing genuine confusion and thinking beyond the given information, while still retaining a touch of negativity)

That's a great question! Why *did* the tree give them more apples? The tree saw that the older brother was sorry and that the younger brother was kind. Maybe the tree wanted to reward their kindness and forgiveness.

So, maybe the story is telling us that being kind... does what? What do you think? Sometimes, if you do good things, good things happen to you!

...(Thinking, looks down at his hands) So... if you're nice... (Looks up, hesitantly) Good stuff happens? (Seemingly making a connection, but still unsure) But... sometimes it doesn't, right? (Asks a skeptical question, showing a lingering touch of negativity)

That's true, sometimes good stuff doesn't happen right away. But being kind is still important, even if you don't get something back right away. It makes *you* feel good, and it makes other people feel good. And sometimes, like in the story, kindness *is* rewarded.

So, can you try to say what the story is teaching us in your own words? What's the big idea of the story?

...(Long pause, chewing on his pencil) Uh... (looks away, trying to formulate an answer) Be...be nice? (Answers hesitantly, still struggling to articulate the lesson) Or... or you get needles? (Adds a touch of negativity and humor) And... and maybe... maybe then you get more apples? (Finishes with a question, seeking confirmation)

You're getting closer! It's not just about getting apples. It's about *being* nice.

Think about it this way: What if the younger brother was mean back? Would they have gotten more apples? What was the *good* thing the younger brother did?

...(Eyes widen slightly, a realization dawning) He... helped him! (Answers with a bit more confidence) Even though he was mean! So... (thinking hard, putting it together)... you should help people, even if they're mean to you? (Poses it as a question, still a bit unsure, but getting there) Is that... it?
Yes! That's a big part of it. And if you *are* mean, like the older brother, what should you do?

...(Looks down, a slight hint of shame) Say... sorry? (Answers quietly) And... be nice after that? So you don't get needles? (Adds the humorous element again, but the understanding is growing) Maybe... then... you get... more apples... because you're... a better person? (Finishes with a hesitant, hopeful tone)

Yes! You got it! Saying sorry and trying to be better is very important. So, the story teaches us that being kind, even when it's hard, and saying sorry when we make mistakes, can lead to good things. It's about more than just apples, it's about being a good person.

Kindness will always be rewarded! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, let's talk about the story of King Midas. You just read it, right?

Can you tell me, who was King Midas? What did he do?

(Looks away, fidgeting with hands)

Uh… (long pause)... King… Midas… (stutters) …gold?

(Looks down at desk, avoids eye contact)

That's right! He did have something to do with gold.

Let’s start at the beginning. Did he do something nice for someone at the start of the story? Who was it?

(Shrugs, avoids eye contact)

...Satyr. Helped...it. (mumbles) Doesn't matter.

It *does* matter! That's how the whole story started.

He helped a Satyr, good! Because he was kind, who offered him a wish?

(Sighs loudly, rolls eyes slightly)

…Dionysus… (taps foot impatiently)
Yes! Dionysus! And what did Midas wish for? What did he want more than anything?
(Mumbles) ...Gold. Everything gold. (picks at fingernails) Stupid wish.
You think it was a stupid wish? Why? But first, tell me *what* the wish was. What would happen if he got his wish?

(Glares briefly, then looks away again)

…Everything… he touched… turned… gold. (crosses arms) So what?
So, what happened when he *got* his wish? Was he happy at first? What did he touch?
Yes! He touched his food. What happened when he touched his food? Could he eat it?

(Shakes head slightly, eyes darting around the room)

…No. Gold. Couldn’t eat. (frowns)
Right! He couldn't eat. Was he still happy then? What else happened? What about his daughter?

(Voice gets a little shaky)

…Daughter… (eyes widen slightly, then quickly narrows them again) …hugged… turned… gold too. (mumbles under breath) …dumb story…
It *is* a sad part of the story. How do you think King Midas felt then? He couldn't eat, and his daughter turned to gold. Was his wish a good thing after all?

(Stares blankly at the desk. Fidgets)

…Bad…wish. (hesitates) …Sad. (mumbles almost inaudibly) …Didn't want gold anymore.

You're right! He didn't want gold anymore. He learned something important, didn't he?

What do you think he learned? What's the story trying to teach us? Was wanting *everything* to be gold a good idea? Why or why not?

(Looks down, shuffling feet)

…(long pause) …Gold…not…everything. (shrugs) …Dumb to want too much. (mumbles) …Maybe.

"Dumb to want too much" - that's a good way to put it. The story shows us that wanting too much, being too greedy, can make us unhappy and can even hurt the people we love. Is it better to be happy and have the people you love, or to have a lot of gold?

(Looks up briefly, then back down, scuffing shoe against the floor)

…Happy…with…people. (mumbles) …I guess. Can I go now?

Yes, happy with people. That's the important thing. The story of King Midas shows us that being too greedy doesn't make us happy. It can even make things worse. You understood the story very well! <finish>
