dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! The Fox and the Grapes is a fun one.

First, can you tell me, what was the fox looking for?

(Shifts in seat, fidgeting with hands)

Uh… (looks down) food?
Yes, that's right! He was looking for food. And what did he find on the farmer's wall?

(Hesitates, picks at a loose thread on shirt)

...grapes. (mumbles)
Yes! He found grapes! Can you tell me what the grapes looked like? The story says they were a certain color and... well, how did they look?

(Avoids eye contact, shrugs shoulders)

Purple... (long pause)...big? Uh... juicy.
Perfect! Purple, big, and juicy. Mmm, they sound yummy! What did the fox try to do?

(Stares at the desk, voice barely audible)

...reach...them?
Yes! He tried to reach them. And did he get the grapes?
That's right, he didn't. He kept jumping and jumping but couldn't get them. What did the fox do *after* he couldn't reach the grapes anymore?

(Starts to tap foot nervously, eyes darting around)

...went home. (mumbles)
He went home. And what did he say about the grapes *before* he went home? Do you remember?

(Bites lip, looks down at hands)

...they were...sour? (almost a question) I...I don't know. (voice cracks slightly)
You almost got it! He said they *must* be sour. He *thought* they were sour. Why do you think he said that, even though he didn't taste them?

(Tears well up in eyes, voice shaky)

I...I don't know! (starts to cry softly) This is...this is hard. (looks down, wiping eyes with sleeve)

(Reaches out and gently puts a hand on the student's shoulder)

It's okay. It's okay if it's hard. We can take a break if you want. Or we can try to figure it out together. Don't worry, I'm here to help.

(Pauses, gives the student a moment to compose themselves.)

How about this? Imagine you *really* want a cookie, but it's on a shelf you can't reach. You try and try, but you can't get it. What would you do?

(Sniffles, still looking down, voice still quiet)

...I don't know... I guess...I'd be mad. (wipes nose on sleeve again)

You would be mad. And maybe a little sad, right? Because you really wanted that cookie. Now, what if you told your friend, "That cookie probably tastes yucky anyway!" Even though you didn't try it? Why would you say that?

(Hesitates, looks up briefly, then down again)

...so...so I don't feel...so bad? (sniffles) ...'cause I couldn't get it?
Yes! That's it! You got it! So you don't feel so bad. The fox couldn't get the grapes, so he said they were sour. Do you think he *really* thought they were sour?

(Shakes head slightly, still avoiding eye contact)

...no. (whispers)

(Thinking, staring at the floor)

...'cause he didn't...didn't even...try them. He just...said that. So he wouldn't feel...like a...failure. (voice barely audible)
That's right! He said it to make himself feel better. So, what does this story teach us? If you try really hard to get something, and you can't get it... what should you *not* do?

(Long pause, looks up hesitantly, a glimmer of understanding in their eyes)

...don't...don't say you didn't want it anyway? (voice a little stronger) ...even if...you really did?

Yes! You got it! Don't pretend you didn't want it. And maybe... maybe don't be upset about what you can't have. Sometimes, things are hard to get. It takes a lot of work. The story teaches us that things don't always come easy and that it's not good to hate something just because we can't have it. Do you understand?

(Nods slowly, wipes remaining tears, looking a little less anxious)

...yeah. (quieter, but more confident) I...I think so.
Great! You did a super job working through that, even when it was tricky. You understood the story and what it means. I'm proud of you. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! Hi there! That was a great reading of "The Proud Rose"!

Now, tell me, who are the two main characters in our story?
(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands) Uh... the... the rose... and... uh... (long pause) ...the... cactus?

Yes! You got it! The rose and the cactus!

Now, can you tell me something about the rose? What was she like?
(Shrugs, avoids eye contact) ...Pretty? (Mumbles) Don't... don't know...
Pretty is a good word! The story does say she was beautiful. But did she *act* nicely? What did she *do* to the cactus?
(Looks away, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) ...Mean? (Stutters) ...She... uh... said bad things... to the... cactus... I... I don't... remember...
You're right, she was mean! She said mean things. Do you remember *why* she said mean things? What did she think about herself?
(Sighs, shifting in my seat) ...'Cause... she thought... she was... better? (Looks up briefly, then back down) ...Than... the cactus...

Yes! That's right! She thought she was better than the cactus because she was pretty.

Now, what about the cactus? Did the story say anything about what the cactus looked like?
(Thinking, chews on my lip) Uh... (shrugs) ...Don't... think so? ...Spiky? ...Maybe? (Looks anxious) I... I don't know!
Spiky is a good guess! Cacti are often spiky. But did the cactus do anything *mean* like the rose?
(Shakes head slightly, looking at my shoes) ...No... (Quietly) ...Just... there...
Right! The cactus was just... there. And when the summer got really hot, what happened? To the rose?
(Frowns, looks confused) Hot? Uh... the... (long pause) ...the rose... got... (Stutters) ...sick? ...Dry? (Looks up with a worried expression) I... I don't understand... Can I... can I go?

It's okay! You're doing great! The rose got dry and started to *wither*. That means she started to droop and lose her prettiness because she needed water.

Now, who had water? Think about who the birds were visiting.
(Eyes widen slightly, then quickly look away again) ...The... cactus? (Whispers) ...Gave water... to... birds?
Yes! The cactus was helping the birds! So, who did the rose ask for help when she was thirsty?
(Hesitates, looks around the room nervously) ...The... the cactus...? (Voice barely audible) ...I... I don't like this story...
I understand it can be a little sad. But the ending is happy! The rose asked the cactus for water, and what did the cactus do?
(Mumbles) ...Gave her... water...? (Looks at the floor, scuffing my shoe) ...I wanna draw...

Yes, the cactus gave her water! Even though the rose had been mean, the cactus helped her.

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? Is it good to be mean to people because of how they look?
(Shakes head vehemently, still looking at the floor) ...No! ...Mean... is bad! (Voice rising slightly, almost a whine) ...I... I don't wanna talk anymore! It's... it's hard!

You are doing so well! I know it's a little hard.

So, if it's not good to be mean because of how someone looks, what *should* we do? Should we judge people based on how pretty they are, like the rose did? Or should we be kind, like the cactus?
(Pulls at my sleeves, avoiding eye contact) ...Be... kind...? (Almost inaudible) ...Like... cactus...? ...Please... can I... can I be done now...? My tummy hurts...

Yes! Be kind like the cactus! Don't judge people just because of how they look. Sometimes, the people who seem the least pretty or impressive are the ones who can help us the most. We should treat everyone with kindness.

So, the story teaches us to Never judge someone according to how they look. You understood that very well! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about Molly.

Why was Molly going to the market?
Uh... (shrugs, looks down at my shoes) ...milk?
Yes! She was going to sell milk. And what was she thinking about while she walked?
...(long pause, fidgets with my hands)... Money. (mumbles)
Yes! She was thinking about the money. What did she want to buy with the money?
(Looks away, kicking the leg of the chair) ...Chicken... I dunno.
You're right, she thought about buying a chicken! What would the chicken give her?
...(Shrugs again, sighs loudly)...Eggs. Is it almost recess?
Almost! Just a little bit longer. So, Molly wants to buy a chicken. The chicken will give her eggs. Then what will she do with the eggs?
(Pulls a face) Sell them, I guess? (looks out the window)
Right! Sell them. So, she sells the milk, then buys a chicken, then sells the eggs. Was that a good plan? What happened to the milk?
(Anxious look, fidgets more) It... it spilled? (voice cracks slightly) I don't like this story.
It *did* spill. It's okay if you don't like the story, but let's just finish talking about it. Why did the milk spill?
(Looks down, scuffing shoes on the floor) ...Skipping? I don't know! Leave me alone! (starts to tear up a little)
Okay, okay. It's alright. She was skipping and got excited. She wasn't watching what she was doing, and the milk spilled. Now, did she get to buy the chicken?
...(Sniffles, wiping nose with sleeve)... No. (mumbles) Stupid milk.

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of "The Farmer and the Well"!

Now, let's see if we can remember what happened. Who bought something in the story?

Uh... the... the farmer? (stuttering)
Yes! The farmer bought something. What did he buy? Take your time.

...dunno... (mumbles)

...Well. (said flatly, almost a mumble)

...neighbor... (said with a bored tone)

...Don't... cheat... (mumbles, sounding slightly annoyed) ...Whatever...

That's right. They all said no. Why did the monkey say no? Do you remember?
(stares blankly) … Uh… don’t know. (picks at a loose thread on shirt)
That's okay! Let's think. Could the elephant swing in the trees like the monkey?

(hesitates) …Too big? (looks up briefly, then back down)
Yes! The elephant was too big to fit in the rabbit's burrow. And the frog? What was the problem there?

… (long pause, looks upset) … Bad. (voice cracks a little)
Bad. I think so too. Really bad. Now, what happened the next day in the forest? What were all the animals doing?
The tiger! Yes. What did the elephant do about the tiger?

To stop it! You're right. The elephant was being brave. What happened *after* the elephant scared away the tiger? Did the other animals still think the elephant was too big and clumsy?

Think about the tiger. Could the monkey, rabbit, or frog scare away the tiger?

… (long pause, fidgeting, looks near tears) … Uh… Don’t know. Can I go now? (whispers)
It's okay. We can figure it out together. The elephant was different from the other animals, but he still became their friend. So, can friends be different?

Size! That's right! Friends can be any shape or size. You understood the story and what it means! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! Great job reading the story, [User's Name]! That was a fun one, wasn't it?

So, tell me, what did the girl bring to her dad?
(Looks down, fidgeting with hands) Uh... (Stuttering) Potato... egg... tea?

Yes! You got them all! A potato, an egg, and tea leaves. Good job!

What did her dad do with those things?
(Looks away, shrugs shoulders) Boiled... them? (Mumbles) I dunno...

You're right! He boiled them. He put each thing in a pot of hot water.

What happened to the egg after it was boiled? Was it the same as before?
(Hesitates, picks at a loose thread on shirt) ...Hard? (Barely audible)

Yes! The egg got hard. It was soft before, but now it's hard. Good job!

What happened to the potato? Was it hard or soft after boiling?

Soft! You got it. The potato was hard before, but boiling made it soft.

And what about the tea leaves? What happened to *them*? This one's a little trickier.

You're so close! The tea leaves didn't just change, they changed the *water*! The water wasn't tea before, but after boiling, it was!

So, the egg changed, the potato changed, and the tea changed the water. Do you think the hot water was like something hard or bad happening to them? Like when something goes wrong?

Okay. So the hot water is like something bad.

The egg started soft, but got hard when things got tough. The potato started hard, but got soft when things got tough. And the tea... it changed the water itself!

Do you think the girl's dad wanted her to be like the egg, the potato, or the tea? Why do you think he showed her that?
(Long pause, fidgeting intensifies) ... (mumbles) ...dunno... (shrugs, almost inaudible) ...don't care...

It's okay if you don't know for sure. It's a tricky question!

Think about it this way: the egg got hard and stayed the same inside. The potato got soft and changed inside. The tea changed the water, it changed things around it.

Which one do you think is best when something bad happens? To get hard? To get soft? Or to change things?
(Shakes head slightly, avoids eye contact) ...Don't know... (mumbles) ...just wanna be done...

I understand. It's a lot to think about. Let's try this.

Imagine someone is being mean to you.

If you're like the egg, you get hard and don't let anyone in.
If you're like the potato, you get soft and maybe sad.
If you're like the tea, you try to make the situation better, maybe by talking to the person or telling a grown-up.

Which of those sounds like the best way to handle it?
(Glares at the floor, crosses arms) ...None... Leave me alone...

I hear you. You're feeling frustrated. It's okay to feel that way.

But even when we feel frustrated, we still get to choose what we do. Do we get hard like the egg? Soft like the potato? Or do we try to change things, like the tea?

Think about it just a little bit. Which one has the most power to change things?
(Sighs loudly, slouches further in chair) ...Tea... I guess... (Mumbles) ...Still don't care...

Okay. The tea changes the water. It makes something new.

The story is trying to tell us that even when bad things happen (like the hot water), we get to choose how we react. We can choose to be hard, soft, or we can try to change the situation.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us about difficult times? Do *we* get to choose what happens next?

Okay. Maybe it feels like "whatever" right now, and that's okay.

But the story wants us to know that we have *some* power. Even if we can't control *what* happens to us, we can control *how* we react. We get to choose to be like the egg, the potato, or the tea.

So, if you had to say in your own words what this story is about, what would you say? Even just a little bit.
(Shrugs, looks away) ...Stuff... happens... (pauses) ...Choose... something...? ...I dunno... (mumbles) ...Can I go now...?

You're almost there! "Stuff happens," that's right! And we get to *choose* something. We choose how to react!

So, the story is about how we choose how to react when things are hard. It's about *our* choice.

That's it! You understood the story! You said that we get to *choose* when stuff happens. That's what the story is about. We decide how to respond to difficult situations. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Needle Tree! That was a fun story, wasn't it?

Let's talk about it. Can you tell me, what was the older brother doing in the forest?

(Shrugs, looks down at my shoes, fidgeting)

Uh... (long pause) ... cutting... wood?
Yes! That's right. He was cutting wood. And what did he do with the wood he cut?
Sold it! You got it. He sold it where? Do you remember?

(Eyes dart around the room, avoids eye contact)

...The market... (whispers)
Yes! The market. You remembered! Now, what did he find in the forest one day? Something special...

(Stares blankly at the teacher, chews on my lip)

...Uh... I don't... know. (Looks down again, shuffles feet)
That's okay! Let's think. It was in the title of the story. The Needle Tree! He found a...?

(Frowns, picks at a loose thread on my shirt)

...A tree? ... (very quiet)
A tree! A special tree. What did the tree offer him if he didn't cut it down?

(Sighs, avoiding eye contact, fidgets with hands)

... uh... (long pause, whispers) ... Apples?
Yes! Golden apples! Were the golden apples enough for the older brother?

(Shakes head slightly, looks at the floor)

...No...
No, they weren't. What did he do then?

(Bites lip, looks nervous)

...Tried to... cut it? (voice barely audible)
He did! And what happened when he tried to cut it? What did the tree do?

(Looks up quickly, eyes wide, then looks back down)

...Needles! (mumbles) ... It hurt him...
Yes! The tree gave him needles. Ouch! Who helped him after that?

(Shrugs, avoids eye contact, looks anxious)

...The other... brother?
Yes! His younger brother. And what did the younger brother do?

(Stares at the table, thinking hard, furrowing brow)

...Took... out... the needles? ... (uncertain)
Yes! He carefully took out all the needles. Was that a kind thing to do?
Why do you think it was a kind thing to do?

(Looks down at hands, picks at a fingernail, avoiding eye contact)

... 'Cause it... hurt? (mumbles)

Yes, because it hurt! And the older brother wasn't very nice to him usually, right?

So, what happened after the younger brother helped him? Did the older brother say anything?

(Shrugs again, sighs, looking bored and anxious)

...Said... sorry? ... maybe? (voice barely audible)
Yes! He said sorry. Why do you think he said sorry?

(Frowns, avoids eye contact, looks confused and a little angry)

...Dunno... (mumbles) ... 'Cause he had to?

Maybe. But maybe also because his younger brother was so kind to him, even after he had been mean.

What happened after the older brother said sorry? What did the tree do?

(Hesitates, looks around the room nervously)

...More apples? ... (whispers, unsure)
More apples! Why do you think the tree gave them more apples?

(Looks down, kicks at the floor, seems irritated)

... 'Cause... they were... nice? ... (mumbles, reluctantly) ... I dunno!

Okay, you're getting there! The tree saw that the older brother said sorry and that the younger brother was kind.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the lesson? Is it good to be mean, like the older brother at the start? Or is it better to be kind, like the younger brother?

(Crosses arms, glares at the floor, and hesitates, looking agitated)

...Better... to be... kind? ... (says it very quietly, like it hurts to admit it) ... Whatever. (mumbles)
Why is it better to be kind? What happened when the younger brother was kind?

(Sighs dramatically, avoids eye contact, taps foot impatiently)

...Got more... apples... (mumbles, reluctantly) ...Can I be done now? (voice barely audible)

You're so close! So, if you are kind, sometimes good things happen to you, right? The tree gave them more apples because they were kind to each other.

So, is the story trying to tell us that kindness gets you good things?

(Looks up briefly, then back down, fidgeting, clearly wants the conversation to end)

...Uh... Yeah... (mumbles, impatiently) ... I guess so. Can I go now? I'm tired...

Okay! So, the story teaches us that kindness is rewarded. Being kind, like the younger brother, can lead to good things, like getting more golden apples. And being mean, like the older brother at first, can lead to getting poked with needles!

You did a good job figuring out the story! <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story!

So, the fox was very hungry, right? What was he looking for?
That's right! He was looking for food. And what did he find on the farmer's wall?
Good! What did the grapes look like? Were they small and green, or big and purple?
Yes! Big and purple. Did the fox get the grapes easily?
No! He tried really hard, didn't he? What did he do to try and get them?
He did jump! He jumped as high as he could! Did he get them after jumping?
He jumped and jumped, but did he reach the grapes? Yes or no?
That's right! He didn't get them. What did the fox do after he couldn't reach the grapes?
(shrugs, picks at a loose thread on clothes)... Went home.
He did go home. And what did he say about the grapes before he left? Do you remember?
Sour! He said they were sour. Why do you think he said that? Even though he wanted them before?
Okay, think about it this way. He really wanted the grapes, but he couldn't get them. How did that make him feel? Maybe a little sad?
(Shrugs again, mumbled under breath) Not sad.
Okay! Not sad. Maybe...frustrated? Like, he tried really hard and couldn't do it.
It's okay! So, he couldn't get the grapes. And then he said they were sour. Do you think he REALLY thought they were sour? Or was he just saying that because he was...disappointed?
Okay! He was just saying it. Why would he say something that wasn't true?
Hmm... Was he maybe trying to make himself feel better? Because he couldn't get what he wanted?

Maybe! So, the fox wanted something really badly, but he couldn't get it, and then he pretended he didn't want it anyway.

Now, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? Is it good to give up when things are hard?
(Looks down, kicks the desk leg) ...Uh...Dunno. Don't care.
It's okay if you don't know right away. Let's think about it. The fox gave up and then said the grapes were sour. Do you think that was a good thing to do? What else could he have done?

Maybe he could have tried to find another way to get the grapes? Or maybe he could have looked for something else to eat? What do you think? Is it good to just say you don't want something when it's hard to get?
Okay. What if you really, really wanted a toy, but it was too expensive. Would you say you didn't want it anyway? Or would you save up your money to buy it?
(Looks up, a flicker of interest, then back down) ... Don't save.

Okay, you don't save. But some people do save, right? The story is telling us that things that are good take effort. And it isn't a good idea to act like you didn't want it anyway, just because it was too hard to get. Do you understand?

Okay. So, the story teaches us that it's important to try hard and not give up easily. And if you can't get something, don't pretend you didn't want it in the first place. Does that make a little more sense?
Almost! One last thing. What is one thing that you want very much, but is hard to get?
(Without looking up, scuffs shoe on the floor) Recess.
Recess! Okay. Is it easy to get recess right now?
No! You have to finish our lesson first. So, instead of saying "I don't want recess," you're going to finish our lesson, and then you can go to recess. Right?
Great! So, the story teaches us, "Nothing comes easy, do not hate what you can't have." Do you think you understand the story now?
(Nods once, very slightly, and avoids eye contact) ...Uh-huh. Can I *really* go now?

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story of the Proud Rose! That was a good effort.

Now, let's talk about it. Who are the main characters in our story?
Uh... (shrugs, looks at the floor) The...rose and...uh... (taps foot) the cactus.

Yes! You got it! The rose and the cactus.

Now, can you tell me, what was the rose like? Was it happy? Sad? Kind?
...(long pause, fidgets with pencil) Uh... (looks up briefly, then back down) ...Proud? (said quietly, almost like a question)
Proud! That's a great word to describe the rose. Why do you say the rose was proud? What did the rose *do* that makes you think it was proud?
(Shrugs, picks at a loose thread on pants) ...It...uh... told the cactus it was... ugly? (looks away, avoids eye contact)

Yes! You remembered! The rose wasn't very nice, was it? It said mean things to the cactus.

How did the rose treat the cactus?
Badly is right. And how did the other plants feel about the rose's behavior? Remember what the story said.
(Silence, stares blankly ahead) ...Uh... (scratches head, avoids eye contact completely) ...Don't know.
That's okay! Let's think... Did the other plants like that the rose was being mean to the cactus? Or did they try to help the cactus? Reread the story if you need help.
(Grumbling) Don't wanna read it... (Pushes the book away slightly) ...They... they helped the cactus? (Sounds unsure, like a guess)

You're right! The other plants *did* try to help the cactus. Good job remembering that.

Now, what happened when it got really hot and there was no water? What happened to the rose?
(Eyes widen slightly, looks down again) ...It...died? (said very softly)

It started to wither, which means it started to dry up and get sick. It didn't die *yet*.

But what was happening to the cactus? What was the cactus doing in the desert heat?
(Stares at hands, picks at fingernails) ...Uh...giving water...to birds? (Says it almost inaudibly)
Yes! The cactus was helping the sparrows! And because the cactus had water, what did the rose eventually do?
(Looks up quickly, then down again, chewing on lip) ...Asked for...water?
Exactly! The rose asked the cactus for water. And did the cactus help the rose, even after the rose was mean?
...(Nods very slightly, almost imperceptibly. Voice is barely a whisper.) ...Yeah.

Yes! The cactus *did* help the rose.

So, let's think about this. The rose was beautiful, but it was mean. The cactus maybe wasn't as pretty, but it was helpful and kind. What do you think this story is trying to teach us? Is it good to be mean like the rose, or kind like the cactus?
(Stares at the table, taps a pencil eraser repeatedly) ...Uh... (Long pause) ...Cactus...good? (Sounds like a question, avoids eye contact)

Cactus good! You got it. The cactus *was* good. So, what does the story teach us about being pretty on the outside versus being kind on the inside? Does the story care more about being pretty or being kind?
(Shrugs, kicks the leg of the desk) ...Don't know... (Mumbles almost inaudibly) ...Kind, I guess.

Kind! Yes! The story shows us that being kind is more important than just being pretty. The rose was pretty, but it wasn't kind, and it got into trouble. The cactus was kind, and it helped others, even the rose!

So, can you tell me in your own words, what is the moral of the story? What does the story teach us?
(Sighs heavily, slumps down in the chair. Avoids eye contact, staring at the floor.) ...Uh...Be nice? (Says it quietly and with no enthusiasm)

Be nice is a good start! It's more than just being nice, though. The rose judged the cactus because of how it *looked*. The story teaches us not to judge people based on how they look. The cactus looked different, but it was kind and helpful.

So, how about this: don't judge a book by its cover. Have you heard that before? It means don't judge something by how it *looks* on the outside. Is that like our story?
(Picks at a scab on knee) ...Uh...Yeah... (Barely audible)

Yes! It's like our story.

So, one last time: what's the big lesson we learn from "The Proud Rose"? Try your best!

(Sighs, fidgets with the pencil again) ...Don't...be...mean? (Looks up briefly, then back down, chewing on the end of the pencil) ...And...uh...be...nice...even if...someone is...mean to you? (Said in a very low voice, almost a mumble)

You are SO close! You're absolutely right about not being mean and being nice even if someone is mean to you. But it's even more than that. The story is really about not judging others based on what they *look* like. It's about looking beyond the outside to see the good inside. It is about understanding that even if someone looks different, they can still be a great friend.

So, we can say that the moral of the story is, "Never judge someone according to how they look."

Do you understand now? <finish>

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story! What was Molly going to do with the milk?

Yes! She was going to sell it. And where was she going to sell it?
(long pause, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) …Market?
Good job! The market! Now, what did Molly start thinking about while she was walking to the market?
That's okay! Think back... Did she see something on the way to the market that made her think about something else? What did she see?
(Eyes dart around the room, avoiding eye contact) …Chicken?
Yes! She saw a chicken! What did she think she could do with the chicken?
Money! How did she think she could get money from the chicken?
(shrugs, stares at my hands) … Eggs? I guess.
Eggs! That's right. So, she was thinking about the eggs she could sell. What was she going to do with all the money from the milk and the eggs?
Yes, buy stuff! She was getting very excited, wasn't she? What happened because she was so excited?
(frowns slightly) … Milk… spilled? (looks at teacher, then quickly looks away)
The milk spilled! Oh no! What happened to Molly's plans then?
Gone! Everything she was planning disappeared with the milk. So, did she get to buy the chicken and sell the eggs?
(shakes head slowly, staring at the floor) …No.
No. And why didn't she get to do those things?
Because she spilled the milk! She was counting on having that money, but she didn't have it yet, did she? What do you think Molly learned from this?
That's ok. Maybe it's like...don't make plans about something until you actually *have* it. Did Molly *have* the chicken and the eggs?
Right. So, her mom said something important at the end. She said, "Don't count your chickens until they...what?"
Hatch! That's right! Why do you think her mom said that? What does "Don't count your chickens until they hatch" mean?
(shrugs, stares blankly) Dunno. What does it mean? (looks at the teacher with a slightly confused expression)

It means, don't be so sure about something good happening until it *actually* happens. Like Molly, she was sure she'd have money from the chicken, but she didn't even *have* the chicken yet! Does that make a little more sense?
(nods slowly, but still looks unsure) …Uh… Maybe.
Okay, let's try another way. Can you think of another time when it might be bad to count on something before it happens? Like maybe waiting for a birthday present?

Okay, how about this? Imagine you are going to play a game and you are certain you will win. But you haven't played the game yet. Is it good to start bragging to your friends that you are going to win before you have even played the game?
No! Why not? What could happen?

You could lose! And then you'd feel silly for bragging. So, it's better to wait and see what happens *first*, right? Just like Molly should have waited to *sell* the milk before planning what to buy. Do you think you understand the story a little better now?
(nods very slightly, still avoiding eye contact) …Uh… I guess.
Okay. So, in your own words, what's the most important thing you learned from the story of the milkmaid and her pail? What's the main idea?
(long pause, looks up at the ceiling, then back down) …Uh… (mumbles) …Don’t… count… chickens… before… they… hatch?
Yes! Exactly! And what does that *mean* in the story of Molly and the milk? What should Molly have done differently?
(shrugs, looking down at hands) …Don’t… plan… 'til… milk… sold?
Perfect! Don't plan until the milk is sold. You got it! Molly learned a valuable lesson that day. Do you have any questions about the story? <finish>

dialogue:
Okay, wonderful! You've read "The Farmer and the Well." That's a fun story, isn't it?

First, can you tell me in your own words, what happened in the story? Who are the characters?
Uh... (shrugs, looks at the desk) There was a... farmer. And someone else. (Sticks tongue out slightly, thinking).
That's right! There was a farmer. And who was the "someone else"? What did the farmer want from him?
(Looks down, fidgeting with hands) ...Um... neighbor? He wanted... (long pause) ...water?
Yes! A neighbor. The farmer wanted water *from* the well. So, what did the farmer do to get water?
That's okay! Let's think. The farmer didn't have a well. What did he do about that? Did he build one? Or did he do something else? Look back at the story if you like.
(Grumbling) ...Bought it. (Looks at the story for a brief second, then back down)
He bought it! From the neighbor. Good job remembering. So, the farmer bought the well. Then what happened? Did he get water?
...No. (Shakes head slightly, picks at a loose thread on shirt)
No, he didn't. Why couldn't he get water even though he bought the well? What did the neighbor say?
Louder, please! You're right! He said he sold the well, but not the water *inside* the well. Was that nice of the neighbor?
No, it wasn't nice. What did the farmer do then? He was probably very upset!
(Shrugs, picks at the loose thread again) ...Went... somewhere?
Yes, he went somewhere important. He went to see the emperor! Do you remember why he went to see the emperor?
He went to ask for help! Because the neighbor wasn't being fair. Who talked to the neighbor for the emperor?
It was the emperor's helper, the courtier! What did the courtier say to the neighbor about the water? This is the tricky part!
Yes! He said the neighbor had to pay rent for the water, or take it all away right now. Why did the courtier say *that*? What was he trying to make the neighbor understand?
(Confused look, scratches head) ...Uh... don't get it.
Okay, let's think about it this way. The neighbor said he sold the well, but *not* the water. But where was the water *inside*? Where was he keeping it?
(Eyes widen slightly, a flicker of understanding) ...In the well?

Yes! So, if the neighbor didn't let the farmer use the water, the courtier asked who will use the well that the neighbour sold to the farmer.

So, the courtier was making the neighbour pay to keep his water in the well, because if he sold the well, he shouldn't be using the well anymore.

Why do you think the neighbour realised his trick didn't work?
(Looks away, thinking hard)...Uh... 'cause... (stutters) ...he had to pay?
Yes! He had to pay. And he didn't want to pay. He was trying to trick the farmer, and it didn't work. So, what did the neighbor do in the end?
He said sorry! And he went home. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? Was the neighbor being honest and fair?
No. He was trying to cheat the farmer. Did cheating work out for him?
Right! So, what do you think the story is trying to tell us about cheating? What lesson does the story teach?
(Long pause, picks at the loose thread, avoids eye contact) ...Don't cheat?
That's it! And why shouldn't you cheat? What happens if you try to cheat someone?
You might get in trouble! And also, cheating doesn't usually work. The neighbor tried to cheat the farmer, and it didn't work. So, maybe we can say: Cheating will get you...? What?
Almost! Cheating will get you... nowhere! The neighbor ended up going home with nothing. He didn't trick the farmer. He didn't get any extra money. He got nowhere. Do you understand?
Okay! So, in your own words, what's the big lesson from "The Farmer and the Well"? What does the story teach us?
(Long pause, sighs softly, avoids eye contact) ...Don't... cheat... (mumbles) ...or you get... nowhere.
Perfect! You got it! Cheating will get you nowhere. You understood the story and the lesson it teaches. Great job!<finish>

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends."

First, can you tell me, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?

(Shrugs, looks down at desk, fidgeting with a crayon)

...Uh... sad?
Sad, that's right! Why do you think the elephant was sad?

(hesitates, picks at a loose thread on my shirt)

...Uh... no... friends?
Yes! The elephant was lonely and wanted friends. So, what did the elephant do to try and make friends?
Yes, the elephant asked the other animals! Good job! Who was the first animal the elephant asked? Do you remember?
Monkey! You got it! And what did the monkey say? Why didn't the monkey want to be friends with the elephant?

(Crosses arms, frowns)

...Couldn't... swing. (Looks at the teacher with a blank stare)
That's right! The monkey said the elephant couldn't swing. Then who did the elephant ask next?
Rabbit! And why didn't the rabbit want to be friends with the elephant? What was the problem?

(Glares at the teacher, folds arms tighter)

...Too big. (Stares stubbornly at the floor)
Too big for the burrow! That's right! Then who else said no to being friends?
Yes! The frog said no. Why did the frog say no?
Exactly! The elephant couldn't jump. So, all the animals said no because the elephant couldn't do what *they* could do. How do you think that made the elephant feel?
Bad, yeah. Probably even more sad, right? Now, what happened the next day in the forest? Why were all the animals running?
The tiger! Yes! The tiger was scaring everyone. What did the elephant do about the tiger?
Kicked it! That's right! The elephant kicked the tiger away! What happened *after* the elephant kicked the tiger away? What did the other animals think then?
Think about it. The tiger was gone. The elephant saved them. What did the animals realize about the elephant then?

(Hesitates, picks at a scab on knee)

...Good... friend? ...Uh... (looks up briefly, then back down)
A good friend! Yes! Why did they think the elephant would be a good friend *then*, but not before? What changed?

(Frowns, pushes the crayon box away)

...Big... strong?
Big and strong! The elephant was big and strong, and that helped them scare away the tiger. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us about friends? Can friends only be a certain way?

It's okay! Let's think about it. The monkey wanted someone who could swing. The rabbit wanted someone small. But the elephant helped them in a way that *only* an elephant could. So, can friends be different sizes and shapes and still be good friends?

(Crosses arms, glares at the table)

dialogue:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was a good story about the girl, her father, and the egg, potato, and tea.

So, first question: What was the girl feeling at the beginning of the story?
Uh... (looks away, fidgeting with a pencil) Frustrated.

Yes, frustrated! Good job. Do you know what frustrated means? It means she was unhappy and maybe a little angry about things.

Now, what did her dad ask her to get? He wanted three things. Can you remember what they were?
(Stares blankly, picks at a loose thread on shirt) Egg... and... uh... (long pause) ... ...

That's okay! One was an egg. He also asked for a potato and some tea leaves.

So, egg, potato, and tea leaves. What did he do with them?

You got it! He boiled them. He put each one in a pot of hot water.

Now, this is the important part. What happened to the *egg* after it was boiled? Was it the same as before?

Yes! The egg got hard. It was soft before, but now it's hard.

What happened to the potato? Was it hard or soft after being boiled?

Yes! The potato got soft. It was hard before, but now it's soft.

And what about the tea leaves? Did they become hard or soft?

That's a tricky one! The tea leaves didn't become hard or soft. They did something different. They changed the *water*. The water was just plain water before, but now it's tea!

Okay, so the egg became hard, the potato became soft, and the tea changed the water.

Now, the big question: The dad wanted to teach his daughter something. He wanted to teach her about when "adversity knocks". Adversity is like trouble or problems.

The egg, the potato, and the tea leaves all faced the same problem: hot water. But did they all react the same way?
...No. (Looks down, drawing doodles on the desk)

No, they didn't! The egg became hard, the potato became soft, and the tea changed the water. They all reacted differently to the hot water (trouble).

So, what do you think the dad was trying to teach his daughter about dealing with problems? Can we change how we react to problems, like the egg, potato and tea?
(Shrugs, sighs) Don't know. Not listening... Bored.

It's okay to feel bored sometimes! But this is important.

Think about it like this: If something hard happens, do you *have* to get sad? Or can you choose to be brave instead? Can you choose how to react?

"Guess so" is a good start! The story is trying to teach us that we can choose how to react when things get tough. We can be like the egg and become hard. Or we can be like the potato and become soft. Or we can be like the tea and change the whole situation!

So, what do *you* think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea?

Trouble *does* change things! That's very true. But the story is more about *how* we change when trouble comes.

Think about the girl at the beginning. She was frustrated. Do you think she could have changed how she felt? Do you think she could have chosen to be... well, not frustrated?
(Sighs loudly) ...Whatever. Doesn't matter. (Starts tapping the desk impatiently)

It *does* matter! It matters because it's about how you handle things when they're hard.

Okay, let's try this one last time. The egg, the potato, and the tea all faced the same problem: hot water. But they all reacted differently.

So, is it the hot water that decided what would happen, or did the egg, potato, and tea decide for themselves?
(Glares at the teacher) They decided... Leave me alone.

You're right! They decided. The egg decided to become hard. The potato decided to become soft. And the tea decided to change the water.

And *that's* the big idea! *We* decide how to react to difficult situations. We can choose.

So, the moral of the story is: We decide how to respond to difficult situations. <finish>

dialogue:
Okay! That was a good story, right? Now, let's see if you remember what happened.

Who were the main people in the story?
Uh... (looks away, fidgets with hands) the...the two...brothers?

Yes! That's right. Two brothers.

Was one brother nicer than the other?
(Shrugs) ...uh... the older one... mean? (Sticks tongue out slightly)
You got it! The older brother was mean. What did he *do* that was mean?
He did chop wood! But was that mean to his brother? Think about how he *treated* his brother.
(Mumbles) ...dunno... (Looks away, picking at a loose thread on clothing)
Okay, let's think about it this way. Did the story say the older brother was nice to his younger brother? Or did he tease him?
Yes, the older brother teased his younger brother. Now, what happened when the older brother went to the forest?
Yes! He found a tree. And was it just any tree? What was special about it?
Almost! The tree *promised* golden apples. What did the tree want the older brother to do? Or, maybe, *not* do?
Exactly! The tree didn't want to be cut. And what did the tree offer instead?
(Looks down, drawing invisible lines on the desk with a finger) ...apples...
Golden apples! Good job remembering. Did the older brother get lots of apples?
He didn't think so, did he? What did he do then?
He tried to! What happened when he tried to cut the tree?
(Confidently) Needles! (Looks up, makes a quick, almost mean, smile)
Needles! Ouch! Who helped him after that?
Yes! The younger brother. Even though the older brother was mean, the younger brother helped him. What did the younger brother do?
He did! Carefully, he took out all the needles. What happened *after* the younger brother helped him? Did the older brother stay mean?
Yes! He apologized. He said sorry for being mean. And *then* what happened with the tree?
More golden apples! Because the older brother said he was sorry and was nice to his brother. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? Is it good to be mean, or good to be kind?
...(long pause, looks away)...dunno...(shrugs, avoids eye contact).
It's okay! Let's think about it. The older brother was mean at first and got needles. Then he was nice, and he got more apples. Does being nice seem to have a better result?
...maybe...(mumbles almost inaudibly, stares at the floor).
Think about it this way. If you are kind to someone, will they want to be kind back to you?
(Hesitates) ...uh...maybe not...(looks down, scuffing shoe on the floor).

Sometimes they might not be nice back, but does it usually make people feel better when you are kind? Think about how the younger brother felt when the older brother was mean. Then think about how the older brother felt when the younger brother helped him.

Does being kind usually make things better or worse?
...(Another long pause, avoids eye contact). ...worse...sometimes...? (Voice is very quiet and hesitant).

Okay, sometimes it might seem that way. But in the story, being kind made things better, right? The younger brother was kind, and then they got more apples. The older brother was mean, and he got needles. Which would you rather have?
Okay. Let's try another way. What if the younger brother had been mean back to the older brother? What if he had left him with the needles? Would the tree have given them more apples then?

Right. So, being kind, even when someone isn't nice to you, can lead to good things. That's what the story is trying to tell us. It's saying that kindness can be rewarded. Does that make a little more sense?
...(Barely nods head, still avoiding eye contact)...uh-huh...(very quiet).
Okay. So, in your own words, what is the story about? Try to tell me the whole story in a few sentences.

(Long pause, fidgets, avoids eye contact entirely, staring at hands) ...older...brother...mean...tree...needles...younger brother...helped...apples... (trails off, mumbles the last word almost inaudibly).
That's a great start! You remembered all the important parts. Now, can you tell me *why* they got more apples in the end? What did the older brother do that made the tree happy?
...(Shrugs, avoids eye contact, picks at a loose thread on clothing)...dunno...(mumbles).
